Serpent's Mouth, Serpent's Teeth

by natsinator

Summary

After agreeing to help Duke Braunschweig put his daughter on the Imperial throne in exchange for Mittermeyer's life, Yang must figure out how to not just survive, but win the largest civil war in human history.
-------
Part Five of A Wheel Inside a Wheel. At bare minimum, you must read Speaking In Tongues and Servants of the Pharaoh before reading this work.

Notes

If you didn't read Keep the Home Fires (Burning), you probably should do that before you read this story. It contains a major event that is relevant in this chapter.

Also, SMST covers many of the events of Lighting Out for the Territories from the other side. The two books can be read independently, or in either order, but each does contain spoilers for the other, so pick your poison when it comes to reading order :)

Auld Acquaintance

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

December 486 I.C., Odin

Hildegarde von Mariendorfâ€™s only concession to womenâ€™s fashion was a pair of tiny gold earrings. Her suit was a dark, jewel blue, with ruffled lace at her throat and wrists. She clicked her heels together and stood at attention, looking at herself in the tall mirror, then decided there was nothing else that she could do to improve her appearance. She left her childhood bedroom and went downstairs, doing a familiar half-slide down the slick bannister, landing at the bottom with a light hop.Â 

Her father, Count Franz von Mariendorf, was already in the hall, and he stifled his indulgent smile. â€œArenâ€™t you getting a little old for that, my darling?â€

â€œNo,â€ she said. â€œIs Sieg here yet?â€

â€œI am,â€ Siegfried Kircheis said, appearing from her fatherâ€™s library. He was dressed in his uniform, the formal sash doing as much as it could to hide the fact that he was merely a sub-lieutenant. His fluffy red hair, though it was ever resistant to being combed into any sort of shape, was still endearing as it curled around his ears.

â€œI hope I havenâ€™t kept you waiting,â€ she said, smiling up at him.

â€œNot long. I appreciate your invitation.â€

â€œI feel like Hank would have found some way to make you come if I hadnâ€™t invited you,â€ Hilde said confidently.

He just smiled at her, his eyes crinkling up.

â€œAre you ready to go?â€ her father asked, looking between the two of them. Although Hilde was excited to go out, her fatherâ€™s tone was much more subdued and pensive, apprehensive about the party.Â 

â€œYes, sir,â€ Kircheis said.

The three of them headed out to the car, though Hilde caught her fatherâ€™s arm and let Kircheis go ahead of them. â€œYou sound like youâ€™re not ready.â€

He smiled at her. â€œIâ€™m not going to get moreso by standing around.â€

â€œIs something wrong?â€

â€œNo,â€ he said. â€œDo you remember the parties your mother used to host for New Yearâ€™s?â€

Hilde remembered very little from the time when her mother had been alive. The shock of her death had closed that door of memory. â€œYes,â€ Hilde lied. â€œIâ€™m sure this one wonâ€™t compare at all.â€

Her father laughed. â€œPlease donâ€™t insult Princess Amarieâ€™s skills as a hostess to her face.â€

â€œI am capable of tact, you know,â€ Hilde said, and let go of his arm.

They made it to the car, where Sieg and the driver were already seated. It was about a twenty minute drive to the Braunschweig house, and during it, her father and Sieg talked.

â€œHow has it been, working under the duke?â€ her father asked.

â€œI donâ€™t see much of him,â€ Kircheis said. â€œItâ€™s more that Iâ€™m working under Captain Leigh, and I enjoy that.â€

â€œHe keeps you busy, I assume.â€

Kircheis smiled. â€œHe tries his best not to.â€

â€œI havenâ€™t had the chance to speak with him as much as Iâ€™d like recently. Is he doing well?â€

â€œI canâ€™t be the judge of that, sir.â€ After a second, he added, â€œCaptain Leigh takes his responsibility towards me seriously. Even if he wasnâ€™t doing well, he would try not to burden me with his troubles.â€

â€œDoes he get enough sleep, at least?â€ Hilde asked.

â€œProbably not,â€ Kircheis admitted.

â€œIâ€™m sure you wouldnâ€™t be able to tell me what Duke Braunschweig has him actually doing, would you?â€ the count asked.

â€œNo, sir,â€ Kircheis said.

Hildeâ€™s father just nodded and looked out the window. â€œIâ€™m sorry to keep pestering you with questions, but Rear Admiral Reuenthal isnâ€™t on Odin, is he?â€

â€œHe just left, sir,â€ Kircheis said. â€œSome time last week, I believe.â€

â€œAh. I would have hoped to see more of him, but heâ€™s always been a mysterious man. Do you know him, Sub-lieutenant?â€

â€œWeâ€™ve met,â€ Kircheis said, an uncomfortable tone in his voice. â€œBut nothing more than that.â€

Hilde looked over at him, curious about what was making Kircheis uncomfortable with Reuenthal. â€œYou donâ€™t like him?â€

â€œHe doesnâ€™t like me, Fraulein.â€ Kircheis smiled, but it was stiff, and he fiddled with his uniform sash, straightening it out underneath the seatbelt. â€œI eavesdropped on one of his conversations, by accident. I doubt heâ€™ll ever forgive me for it.â€

Hilde laughed. â€œIâ€™m sure itâ€™s not that bad.â€

â€œIt was bad enough that Captain Leigh asked for me to be placed with him when I graduated, rather than sending me to the rear admiral, as he had originally intended. He apologized for stifling my career, in that way.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure he only did it because he wanted to have you in his staff,â€ Hilde pointed out.

Kircheis shrugged and fell silent.

â€œRear Admiral Reuenthal can be a difficult man to know,â€ her father said. â€œDonâ€™t blame yourself for it.â€

Since Kircheis couldnâ€™t fill the silence of the car with anything of substance, he asked, â€œHow are things at the Colonial Affairs office?â€

Her father heaved a sigh, a rare expression of frustration. â€œWorse every year,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t think theyâ€™re going to get better any time soon.â€

â€œReally, sir?â€

â€œThings have always been tense between the outer colonies and the crown. Last yearâ€™s trouble with Rear Admiral Mittermeyer could have been a breaking point, and Iâ€™m glad that it wasnâ€™t.â€ He shook his head. â€œBut Duke Braunschweig, for all his other faults, is good at wrestling his relations into compliance.â€

â€œWell, he has to,â€ Hilde pointed out. â€œIf he wants his daughter to take the throne, then he needs his clan to fall in line behind him.â€

â€œYes,â€ her father said. â€œThough perhaps no one else would say it in as many words.â€

â€œBut people outside of Duke Braunschweigâ€™s circle?â€ Kircheis asked. â€œIs there real trouble?â€

â€œNot yet. Iâ€™m doing my best to prevent it, and so is everyone else who isnâ€™t eagerly looking forward to trouble starting.â€ His lips pinched together. â€œItâ€™s been a long time since Iâ€™ve had to travel on business, but I expect that it will soon be necessary for me to go out and speak to some of the frontier nobles in person.â€

â€œI hope not,â€ Hilde said. â€œThis seems like a bad time to travel.â€

Her father raised his eyebrows. â€œDo you have more accurate information about the Kaiserâ€™s health than I do?â€

Hilde flushed. â€œNo.â€

â€œThere is no good time to travel, my dear. And it will be better to take care of these problems sooner, rather than later. Rot has a tendency to spread.â€

â€œWho is it that you would need to pay a visit to?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œLord Maximilian von Castrop. Are you familiar with him?â€

Kircheis shook his head.

â€œHis father was treasury secretary, many years ago,â€ her father explained. â€œHe made himself very rich with that, though he wouldnâ€™t have needed it. His planet is a top agricultural exporter. Thatâ€™s a dangerous thing to be.â€

â€œWhy is that?â€

â€œIt can give a planet the illusion of self-sufficiency,â€ her father said. â€œHis father never fell for that illusion, and he also knew how to toe the line with the crown. His son, Iâ€™m afraid, thinks that his fatherâ€™s prudence was cowardice.â€ He looked out the window. â€œWell, weâ€™ll see. I perhaps shouldnâ€™t slander him. He hasnâ€™t done anything too foolish yet, just threatened it. And talk has always been a cheap thing.â€

â€œI hope it comes to nothing, sir.â€

â€œWe all can. I enjoy travelling, but Iâ€™d prefer it to be for a more pleasant business, especially these days.â€

â€œIf thereâ€™s anything I can do to helpâ€¦â€ Kircheis offered, which made her father smile.

â€œI somehow doubt it, sub-lieutenant, but I thank you for the offer.â€

The topic of conversation switched to Hildeâ€™s schoolwork (studying law at Odin National University), which she was quite happy to discuss for the remainder of the ride.

Duke Braunschweigâ€™s manor was massive, far larger than her fatherâ€™s estate. Even before marrying into the royal family, the Braunschweigs had been a storied noble line, and that was evident in the construction of their ancestral home. The whole building, all white-stone pillars and tall windows that glittered in between them, was lit to a daylight brightness, though the sun had set hours ago. The three guests hurried out of the car and up the steps to be let inside, pushed along by the chill wind. Already, they could hear music straining through the doors, and the long line of parked cars to the side of the building showed that they were far from the first visitors to arrive.Â 

Hilde, her father, and Kircheis were shown into the great hall of the house, where brilliantly decorated tables encircled a dance floor. The room was crowded and loud already, filled with what seemed like half the nobility of the capital. Perhaps it was half the nobility of the capital. There was a party being held at Neue Sanssouci, and in past years, that was the one that Duke Braunschweig and his family had graced with their presence. However, this year, that party was being hosted as a mere formality only, and attended by guests chosen by Secretary of State Lichtenlade, rather than by the Kaiser. It was one of many signs of the Kaiserâ€™s deteriorating health, and it also meant that the two camps in primary competition for the throne, Duke Braunschweig with his daughter Elizabeth, and Marquis Littenheim with his daughter Sabine, were able to hold parties for their own clans and supporters.Â 

The party was too loud and crowded for the hosts to greet everyone who walked in at the door. Hilde spotted Princess Amarie across the room, already deep in conversation with a gaggle of women, all dressed in the most elegant gowns imaginable. She didnâ€™t see Duke Braunschweig, but she did see the man she was actually scanning the room to find: Captain Hank von Leigh, who was seated by himself at one of the tables, chin resting on his hands, watching people dance with a rather doleful expression. He had a glass of wine half-drunk in front of him.

â€œThereâ€™s Hank!â€ Hilde said. That was all it took for her father and Kircheis to follow her over.

Leigh didnâ€™t notice them coming until they were on top of him, and when he did notice, he stood in a most ungainly manner, nearly tipping his chair over in his haste. Up close, Leighâ€™s most distinctive features were obvious. His dark eyes, his soft face, his messy crop of hair so black that it was almost blue: all marked him as a foreigner, strikingly different from everyone else in the room. But he smiled, tense and wan, at the three who approached him. Kircheis saluted when they got close, and Leigh saluted back.

â€œCount Mariendorf,â€ he said, â€œI didnâ€™t expect to see you here tonight.â€ Although he and Hildeâ€™s father were good friends, there was a strained note in Leighâ€™s voice.

â€œIâ€™m afraid that I couldnâ€™t turn down the invitation,â€ her father said. â€œMay we sit?â€

â€œOf course,â€ Leigh said. â€œMaggieâ€” Baroness Westpfaleâ€” is sitting there, but the rest of the seats are free.â€

â€œMaggieâ€™s here?â€ Hilde asked. â€œWhere?â€

Leigh pointed across the room, where Hilde could see that Magdalena von Westpfale was among the circle of Princess Amarieâ€™s hangers-on, now that Hilde knew she was looking for her.

â€œAnd how did she manage that?â€ her father asked.

Leigh flushed and tugged at the hair at the back of his head, a peculiar but endearing nervous gesture. â€œI told you, we look better together than we do apart, sir,â€ he said. â€œShe agreed to let me help redeem her from disgrace.â€

Her father raised his eyebrows. â€œCongratulations!â€

â€œI think Iâ€™m missing something,â€ Hilde said, and glanced at Kircheis, who shrugged.

â€œI asked Baroness Westpfale to marry me,â€ Leigh said. â€œJust last week. We werenâ€™t intending to make a big deal out of it.â€

Something in Hildeâ€™s stomach did a strange flip-flop, but she smiled. â€œCongratulations.â€

â€œAre you going to be the Baron Westpfale, sir?â€ Kircheis asked.

Leigh cringed and picked up his wine to avoid answering the question, which made some of the odd tension dissipate.

â€œI will have to find something to drink to your happiness,â€ Hildeâ€™s father said, taking his seat. Hilde, Kircheis, and Leigh followed suit.

â€œThank you, sir,â€ Leigh said. He turned to Kircheis. â€œI expected that you would want an evening off at home away from all of this.â€ He waved his hand to vaguely encircle the room.

Kircheis smiled. â€œI donâ€™t mind. Fraulein Hilde wanted an escort.â€

â€œAnd her father simply wouldnâ€™t do,â€ her father said.

â€œIf I had known Maggie was going to be here, I might not have forced you to come,â€ Hilde said.

â€œI didnâ€™t have any big plans Iâ€™m missing out on,â€ Kircheis said. â€œMartin is having some friends over, but I donâ€™t really know them, so I donâ€™t think he minds me skipping out.â€ Kircheis shared a rented apartment with his friend, Martin Bufholtz, which he claimed was far nicer than the housing that was available to most junior officers. Hilde didnâ€™t know if it really was nicer (it was a little run down, and not particularly spacious), but it was a cozy place that she visited on a fairly regular basis. She and Martin were schoolmatesâ€” they both attended Odin National University, though they studied different subjects, and Martin was several years ahead of her.

â€œI should have invited Martin, and you could have tagged along after Hank,â€ Hilde said, which made Kircheis shake his head with a fond smile.

â€œI donâ€™t think this is really his milieu, Fraulein Hilde.â€

â€œNo, probably not,â€ she agreed. â€œBut it would have been funny.â€

â€œDo you know if it was Duke Braunschweig or Princess Amarie who invited you?â€ Leigh asked.

â€œDuke Braunschweig,â€ her father said. He scanned the room. â€œI doubt it was very personal as an invitation; thereâ€™s plenty of other minor nobility here tonight.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know most of them,â€ Leigh said. â€œAnd it seems like most people in the fleet have ended up at Neue Sanssouci tonight.â€

â€œIâ€™d have to think thatâ€™s for the best.â€ But her father continued to look around. â€œThough thereâ€™s Baron Merkatz, and his brother.â€ He nodded at two grey-haired men. â€œSo, not all fleet staff are at Neue Sanssouci.â€

â€œI know. I spoke with Admiral Merkatz earlier.â€

â€œHow is he?â€

â€œFine, I believe. Iâ€™m not sure if heâ€™s happy that Iâ€™m working for Duke Braunschweig, but he was glad to see me, I think.â€

â€œIâ€™m glad everyoneâ€™s past indiscretions are being forgiven and forgotten, these days. Do you know what heâ€™s doing on Odin? Isnâ€™t he usually stationed out of Iserlohn?â€

â€œI couldnâ€™t say, sir.â€ This phrasing from Leigh set off an alarm in Hildeâ€™s head, but she just listened to the conversation without interjecting.Â 

Her father and Leigh didnâ€™t have time to say much else to each other, though, because Baroness Westpfale had noticed the new arrivals at Leighâ€™s table and disengaged herself from Princess Amarieâ€™s circle to come swooping over. She wore a beaming smile on her face, brighter by far than the white-sparkling beads of her blue gown.

â€œCount Mariendorf! I did not expect to see you here!â€ Magdalena said.

â€œNor I, you,â€ her father said. â€œI understand some congratulations are in order?â€

â€œHank, you ruined the surprise,â€ Magdalena said cheerfully, going over to lean on Leighâ€™s shoulders.

â€œCongratulations, Maggie,â€ Hilde said. â€œDo you have a date set?â€

â€œOh, no, I havenâ€™t even started thinking about planning,â€ Magdalena said. She tapped her chin with her fingers. â€œThough Iâ€™m sure we mustnâ€™t make it too long of an engagement.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure if we set a date, there will be some sort of calamity that comes up right before it and ruins every plan we have,â€ Leigh grumbled, though he was smiling.

â€œMaybe we should go to the courthouse tomorrow, then, darling,â€ Magdalena said with a wicked smile on her face.

â€œTomorrowâ€™s a public holiday,â€ Leigh countered. â€œCourthouse wonâ€™t be open.â€

â€œWhat a tragedy,â€ Magdalea laughed and flopped down into her seat. She picked someone else to antagonize, and her eyes settled on Kircheis. â€œHerr Kircheis! Howâ€™s your little republican friend doing? The one who wanted to plaster every street corner with propaganda.â€

The tips of Kircheisâ€™s ears turned red. â€œHeâ€™s fine, Baroness.â€

Magdalena laughed. â€œHilde, darling, does your father know that youâ€™re hanging around with dangerous elements of society?â€

â€œMaggieâ€”â€ Leigh said, but Magdalena just waved her hand.

â€œItâ€™s no trouble to me, of course,â€ Magdalena said.

Hildeâ€™s father looked over at Leigh, who just shrugged, looking embarrassed at Magdalenaâ€™s antics. â€œHilde has always been a good judge of character,â€ her father said.

â€œOh, I know.â€ Magdalena leaned forward, elbows on the table, looking between Hilde and Kircheis. â€œYou two ought to try harder to get away from me and my meddling.â€

â€œI like your meddling, Maggie,â€ Hilde said. â€œIâ€™m glad you were able to come.â€

â€œOh, you flatter me far too much, my darling.â€

But Kircheis smiled and tugged Hildeâ€™s sleeve. â€œCare to dance?â€ he asked. â€œI think sheâ€™s trying to get rid of us.â€

â€œI would never!â€ Magdalena said, smiling.

â€œIâ€™m not really dressed to dance,â€ Hilde said, glancing down at her suit.

â€œGo enjoy yourself,â€ her father said.

Hilde glanced at Leigh, who gave her a tiny nod, and then finally sighed and got up, heading away from the table with Kircheis. She glanced back at the table a few times as they walked to the dance floor.

â€œIâ€™m not very good at dancing,â€ she warned Kircheis as they joined the crowd, offering him her hand.

â€œThatâ€™s alright,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t mind.â€

The music, played by a band at the front of the room, was loud and lovely, some sort of sweeping string piece. â€œWhat do you think theyâ€™re talking about?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Kircheis said. â€œIâ€™m sure if you ask Captain Leigh, heâ€™d tell you.â€

â€œMy father probably would, as well.â€ She frowned, but tried to relax. Dancing with Kircheis wasnâ€™t unpleasant, at least. He was sturdy and sure-footed. Still, she felt quite out of place among all the other dancers in swirling gowns, and now that she wasnâ€™t sitting down at her table, the eyes of other people were on her, not all of them kind. She kept looking around, accidentally catching some strangerâ€™s eye, then looking away back at Kircheis, who was placid as usual.

â€œI think you look nice,â€ he said to her after some time, understanding her without her needing to say anything.

â€œThanks. Iâ€™m a sight better than when I was dressed in a cadet uniform, I guess.â€

â€œYou looked good in that, too.â€

â€œAre you flirting with me, Sieg?â€

â€œIâ€™m just telling you the truth.â€

â€œYou look nice, too,â€ she said. â€œWhich is also just the truth.â€

â€œThank you, Fraulein,â€ he said with a little laugh.

On their next turn, she glanced back at the table they had left. Magdalena was leaning on Leighâ€™s arm, saying something to her father.

â€œI canâ€™t believe Maggieâ€™s getting married,â€ Hilde said.

â€œAnd Captain Leigh.â€

â€œDid you know, I was the one who introduced them?â€

Kircheis laughed. â€œReally?â€

â€œHank escorted me to a party that Maggie was hosting,â€ Hilde said. â€œThis was years and years ago. I couldnâ€™t even tell you why I wanted to go so badly. I guess I just wanted to be grown up.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t like parties, Fraulein?â€

â€œI do,â€ she said. â€œBut I donâ€™t know what I expected to get out of going to Maggieâ€™s back then.â€ She shook her head.

â€œNot everything you do needs an explanation. Baroness Westpfale invited you to a party, so you went.â€

â€œJust like youâ€™re here because I asked you to come?â€

He smiled at her. â€œI canâ€™t blame you for wanting company.â€

She laughed a little. â€œYou should have just invited me to Martinâ€™s party.â€

â€œThe wine is probably nicer at this one.â€ He was joking, and so she laughed.

â€œWhy didnâ€™t you stay home for Martinâ€™s party, really, Sieg?â€ she asked. â€œYouâ€™d probably prefer it.â€

â€œIâ€”â€ He looked away for a second. She had hit some sort of nerve that she hadnâ€™t known she was poking at. â€œIâ€™m sure itâ€™s the same reason why he wouldnâ€™t feel right here.â€ He rubbed his head, a mannerism that he was sure to have picked up from Leigh. â€œIâ€™d rather not get too acquainted with all of his friends, in the same way that I canâ€™t talk to him about work.â€

â€œOh.â€

â€œYour father doesnâ€™t mind Martin, does he?â€

â€œOf course not,â€ Hilde said. â€œHeâ€™s glad I have friends at school.â€

â€œYour fatherâ€™s a good man.â€

â€œI know.â€ There was something in Kircheisâ€™s voice, but it was an old, familiar hesitancy from him.

â€œHe likes you, too, you know, Sieg.â€

He just smiled at her. Hilde didnâ€™t really understand the mental arithmetic that Kircheis did every time he interacted with her father, and no matter how many times she told him he was overthinking it, he wouldnâ€™t listen.

They danced for a little while longer, though Kircheis remained quiet and thoughtful.

â€œWhatâ€™s on your mind, Sieg?â€ she asked.

He shook his head. â€œNothing, really.â€ It was his turn to glance back at the table, where Magdalena was pulling Leigh to his feet, tugging him towards the dance floor with a pleading expression. It was clear that he was going to go, but they were both enjoying making her fight for it. â€œEverythingâ€™s just changing so fast,â€ he said eventually. â€œLast year was so differentâ€” it feels like I donâ€™t know where anything stands anymore.â€

â€œNot just because of that surprise, I hope,â€ she said, nodding to indicate Magdalena and Leigh, who were making their way onto the dance floor now.

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said. â€œItâ€™s everything. The fleet, the Kaiser, Martinâ€¦â€

Hilde tilted her head. â€œWhatâ€™s going on with Martin?â€

â€œNothing,â€ he said. But that was clearly a lie.

She squeezed his arm. â€œWell, if itâ€™s any comfort, Iâ€™m still the same.â€

He turned his usually calm gaze on her, and when she met his eyes, she was surprised by how wide they were and unsteady he looked. â€œFraulein Hildeâ€”â€

â€œWhat is it, Sieg?â€

He shook his head and said nothing, then turned to look back at Leigh and Magdalena, who were now dancing. Her head was resting on his shoulder, and his hands were on her waist. They werenâ€™t really dancing, more just standing there in the crowd and shuffling as much as Leigh could manage. Hilde suddenly felt like a voyeur for watching, like she was one of the unfriendly gazes who had been staring at her and Kircheis all night, and she said, â€œI think I need some air.â€

Kircheis immediately dropped his hands and let her go. â€œOf course.â€

â€œIâ€™ll be back,â€ she said, and then hurried away, feeling bad in a way that she couldnâ€™t define about whatever it was that had just happened. It seemed like nothing had happened, and yet Kircheis was right: for some reason, everything was changing, and ground that had once been solid was shifting beneath her feet.

Freeing herself from the crowd on the dance floor gave Hilde some measure of relief, but she hadnâ€™t been lying when she said that she needed air. It was hot in the room, and she was sweating under her suit. As she passed a table of refreshments, she picked up a wineglass, and then spotted a door to one of the balconies that overlooked the Braunschweigâ€™s garden. It was freezing outside, so she was sure to be able to steal just a moment for herself to come back to her senses out there.

Hilde looked around to make sure no one would scold her for going out, then pushed open the glass door quickly, stepping out into the ice-cold night air. It was an immediate relief. The air was crisp, and her breath rose around her in a cloud. The music and thrum of the crowd was now only faint behind her, and she leaned on the stone balcony railing and looked out over the bare night garden, only a few statues illuminated by spotlights. Thus distracted, it took her far too long to realize that she was not alone on the wide balcony, as she had expected that she would be. She was being silently observed by someone a little ways away, who must have come out the other door to the same balcony, and had been standing there silently before Hilde arrived.

The other person was dressed much more warmly than Hilde was: wrapped in a fur jacket so voluminous that the individual hairs moved in dappled, shifting patterns with the slight breeze that blew across the balcony. She was young, Hildeâ€™s age or a year or two younger. Her dark hair was elaborately done up, and a silver coronet with segments like twinkling stars sat atop her head. Beneath her jacket, Hilde could see the bottom third of the emerald green gown she was wearing. Golden light from indoors spilled across her face, and Hilde recognized who the woman was. This was Elizabeth von Braunschweig, one of the claimants to the throne. They had never spoken before, but they had occasionally been in the same social spaces, and she was recognizable.

Hilde turned, then bowed to her. â€œIâ€™m sorry, Lady Elizabeth,â€ she said. â€œI didnâ€™t see you there.â€

Elizabeth waved her hand. â€œItâ€™s fine,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s just too hot in there.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t mind the company?â€

â€œNo,â€ Elizabeth said. Moved by some impulse, Hilde walked towards her, wine glass in hand. Elizabeth looked her over more carefully. â€œYouâ€™ll be freezing in a minute.â€

â€œIâ€™m fine,â€ Hilde said. Her suit was warmer than it looked.

â€œI thought you were a gentleman, before you said anything.â€

This made Hilde flush, though the dim light and the fact that her cheeks were already turning red from the cold did plenty to hide it. â€œNo,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™ve just never preferred dresses.â€

â€œStrange,â€ Elizabeth said, turning back towards the garden. â€œI couldnâ€™t picture myself in trousers.â€

â€œTheyâ€™re comfortable,â€ Hilde said.

â€œWhatâ€™s your name?â€

â€œHildegarde von Mariendorf. Count Mariendorfâ€™s daughter.â€

â€œI think Iâ€™ve met your father at Neue Sanssouci before.â€

Hilde didnâ€™t know what to say to that. â€œItâ€™s a lovely party,â€ she said.

â€œItâ€™s my motherâ€™s doing. And the staff, of course.â€ She leaned forward on the railing. â€œI had nothing to do with it.â€

â€œIsnâ€™t it for your sake?â€ Hilde asked, feeling strangely bold.

Elizabeth laughed. â€œMaybe.â€ She turned around, so that she could rest her back on the railing and look at Hilde more easily. â€œI assume since youâ€™re here, your father intends to support mine when my grandfather dies?â€

â€œI donâ€™t think itâ€™s my right to give you that answer,â€ Hilde said.Â 

This made Elizabeth smile for the first time. â€œOf course.â€ She noticed the wine glass clutched in Hildeâ€™s hand. â€œAre you going to drink that?â€ she asked.

Hilde had forgotten all about it, and her fingers were now so cold that she could barely feel them. â€œOh, uh, no, I suppose not.â€

Elizabeth reached out and took it from her hand, tugging it from Hildeâ€™s frozen grip by prying her fingers off of it. Her hands, from being tucked inside the sleeves of her fur coat, were quite warm, and Hildeâ€™s eyes widened at Elizabethâ€™s boldness.

â€œTo your health, Lady Mariendorf,â€ Elizabeth said, raising the glass with a strange smirk. She winced at how cold the glass was when she put it to her lips, but drank the whole thing in one go.

â€œJust Hilde, if it pleases you,â€ Hilde managed to say, watching Elizabeth down the wine.

â€œHilde, then. But I donâ€™t expect you to call me Liz.â€ She looked at the empty glass, then held it back out for Hilde to take, which she did, confused.

â€œOf course, Lady Elizabeth.â€

â€œMy mother would hate to see me drinking,â€ she said, by way of explanation, though that only covered a fraction of Hildeâ€™s confusion. Elizabeth looked at Hilde for a moment more, then said, â€œYou really are going to freeze out here.â€

â€œIâ€™m fine,â€ Hilde said again.

Elizabeth looked at her for a moment, then shrugged off her fur coat and handed it to Hilde, who took it, too surprised to say anything. Elizabethâ€™s shoulders were bare now, and gooseflesh rose on her arms instantly. Taking off her coat revealed a brilliant necklace with a stone that sparkled at the hollow of her throat. â€œI ought to go back to this party. As you say, it is for my sake. Now that youâ€™ve fortified me, it should be a little easier,â€ she said. â€œBut if you still insist on getting some air, you might as well be warm while you do it.â€

â€œThank you, Lady Elizabeth,â€ Hilde said.

â€œIf our fathers are to be allies, Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™ll see you again,â€ Elizabeth said, and without another word, she pushed open the glass door and went back inside the party. Hilde slipped the fur coat on. It was still warm from Elizabethâ€™s body, and it smelled like her perfume, something floral and girlish. Hilde wrapped it tight around herself, not wanting to go back inside.

She stayed out there for a long while, just thinking, and she had just about worked up the strength to go back into the party when the balcony door opened behind her, and Leigh came out.

â€œSub-lieutenant Kircheis was worried that you had vanished into the ether, you know,â€ Leigh said, startling her.

â€œOh, Iâ€™m sorry,â€ Hilde said.

â€œDid he do something to upset you?â€

â€œSieg? No, I donâ€™t think so. I just needed some space.â€

â€œI understand,â€ he said. â€œThese things can be a challenge to get through in one piece.â€ He ran his hand through his hair, then tilted his head back to look up at the sky. â€œIâ€™m sorry for chasing you away from the table, earlier.â€

â€œItâ€™s alright,â€ Hilde said. â€œI understand.â€

â€œThank you for understanding.â€ Leigh seemed content to stand in silence and look up at the stars. It was a brilliantly clear night out.

â€œYou arenâ€™t having some kind of argument with my father, are you?â€ she asked after a second.

â€œWhy do you ask that?â€

â€œNeither of you seemed happy to see the other tonight.â€

â€œAny other night, any other place,â€ Leigh said with a sigh. â€œI think itâ€™s a mistake for your father to ally with Duke Braunschweig.â€

â€œOh,â€ Hilde said. â€œWhy?â€

â€œBecause heâ€™s doing it only because Iâ€™m here, and I donâ€™t deserve that kind of loyalty.â€ He shook his head. â€œThereâ€™s no way that this wonâ€™t be bloody, and I wish heâ€” and youâ€” didnâ€™t have to get caught up in it.â€

â€œIt was Duke Braunschweig who invited him, not you.â€

â€œDuke Braunschweig knows that your fatherâ€™s contacts and talents from working in the Colonial Affairs office would be useful to have. Even small, outlying colonies might have a part to play in a civil war.â€ He stuck his hands into his pockets. â€œYour father would make a fine emissary, and heâ€™s well respected among the smaller noble housesâ€” there are many reasons for Braunschweig to curry your fatherâ€™s favor. But thatâ€™s not why your father came.â€

â€œI wouldnâ€™t want us to be on different sides.â€

Leigh pulled his gaze back to the ground and smiled at her. â€œI know.â€ He turned back to look at the garden. â€œAnd I know that there isnâ€™t going to be any avoiding choosing sides, and in the end if he must choose a side Iâ€™m glad that itâ€™s mine, but all the sameâ€¦â€

â€œI understand.â€

â€œWhereâ€™d you get that coat?â€ he asked.

â€œOh,â€ Hilde said, and felt embarrassed. â€œItâ€™s Elizabeth von Braunschweigâ€™s. She let me borrow it. Iâ€™ll have to give it back to her.â€

â€œYou know her?â€

â€œNo. I think this was the first time we ever spoke.â€

â€œAnd what did you think of her?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know.â€ That was the truest thing that Hilde could say. She looked at the empty wine glass, which had been left on the balcony railing, and curled her fists in the warm pockets of the coat.

â€œCan I say something?â€ Leigh asked. â€œAn observation, I suppose?â€

â€œOf course!â€

â€œI think everyone is trying to forget that she is the one who will wear the crown, not Duke Braunschweig. Everyone should be remembering that theyâ€™ll have to swear fealty to her, not her father.â€

â€œIâ€™ll keep that in mind.â€

â€œWe should go back inside, or Kircheis will think that weâ€™ve both been abducted.â€

â€œYes, sir,â€ Hilde said.Â 

They walked back in together, and with some reluctance, Hilde found a servant to hand Elizabethâ€™s coat to, so that it could be returned to its rightful owner. The rest of the party passed much more cheerfully until near midnight.Â 

Whatever tension that had passed between her and Kircheis no longer felt material, and her father and Leigh had mended their discomfort while she had been gone. And suddenly, watching Magdalena torment Leigh and him cheerfully grimace at her antics didnâ€™t strike any strange chords in her heart. Instead, Hilde found herself scanning the crowd to catch glimpses of the dark-haired Elizabeth, who sometimes stood by her motherâ€™s side, and sometimes by her fatherâ€™s. Hilde almost wanted to go speak to her, but decided against it.

At around midnight, she stood in between her father and Kircheis to listen to Duke Braunschweigâ€™s sonorous toast to the future of the Empire, the health of Kaiser Friedrich IV, and the spirit of friendship between all the guests in the room. Leigh looked annoyed with it all, but he smiled when everyone began counting down to midnight, and he raised his glass as enthusiastically as everyone else when the clock struck and the band began to play.

Magdalena didnâ€™t let him drink his toast, and kissed him, instead, which made him blush.

â€œYou should know that thatâ€™s what youâ€™re supposed to do at New Yearâ€™s, Hank,â€ she said. â€œNow you can drink.â€ And she knocked her glass against his, laughing.

Kircheis seemed pensive, and Hilde nudged him to get his attention over the rendition of â€˜Auld Lang Syneâ€™ the band was playing. â€œHappy New Year, Sieg,â€ she said.

â€œHappy New Year, Fraulein Hilde,â€ he said, and smiled.

â€œWhat are you thinking about?â€ she asked.Â 

â€œAuld acquaintance.â€

This got Leighâ€™s attention. â€œIsnâ€™t it funny to think that everyone around the galaxy is celebrating this night just the same?â€ he asked. â€œNo matter where they are.â€ His own expression and tone were melancholy, for a moment, â€œIserlohn, Phezzan, Heinessenâ€¦ We all want the new year to treat us well.â€

â€œI hope it does,â€ Hildeâ€™s father said.

Leigh opened his mouth to say something, then closed it again. Hilde knew what he was thinking, and was glad that he hadnâ€™t said it aloud.

â€œIâ€™m sure it will,â€ Hilde said. â€œHappy New Year!â€

Chapter End Notes

I'm so glad to be back... it's been about a million years (six months? something like that). Thank you for sticking around during my hiatus from this story. If you haven't, go check out some of the stuff I've written in the interim (Last Gasp at Calama, Every Hateful Instrument, and various other short fics)

This story is titled after a couple different things. First, it's from the Mountain Goats song "Rain in Soho"

No promise sweeter than a blood pact
Nothing harder to go through with than a vanishing act
No morning colder than the first frost
No friends closer than the ones we've lost
Nothing sharper than a serpent's tooth
Nothing harder than the gospel truth
Though you repent and don sackcloth and try to make nice
You can't cross the same river twice

JD is actually misquoting King Lear here ("How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is to have a thankless child")

second, it's named after-- ok, hear me out here-- one of my fic writing inspirations is the absolutely stupidly long HP fic series The Sacrifices Arc, the second book of which is called No Mouth But Some Serpent's. the thing is 3 million words long and i've read it cover to cover twice >.>

third, of course, yang's side of the story has a running imagery about speaking/silence, while reinhard's side has light imagery (we've got a "sound and vision" theme going on lol-- in case you weren't aware, the next two books will be named "silent spiral" and "lightless labyrinth" respectively). i also thought the assonance between "servants" and "serpents" was just really good-- much like "life" and "light" gets on the other side.

anyway a lot of thought went into this title so i hope you like it ğŸ˜…

as far as content of the chapter-- this is very much a "hey remember all these people had stuff going on?" chapter lol. so it's pretty low-key, but it does introduce several of the major plot points. that we'll be starting off the section with, so i think it's fine. if you have read lighting out for the territories you know where this is going, at least in part haha

hilde gets to be POV for this chapter b/c she is probably going to have the most interesting relationship with our presumptive future kaisarin :) also she's going to have pov chapters later for [thing that was covered in LOftT]

if you haven't read the alliance side of the story, I'm actually really interested in how you feel about this one haha. this is where the timelines really start to converge, so it will be interesting to see how ppl feel about it from the other side. hopefully this story will be less horrid to write than LOftT was

speaking of timelines converging, yang's comment about everyone celebrating he same night is very prescient. we see both reinhard and fredrica attend their equivalent new year's parties on the other side of the story :)

i did mean to have this chapter for NYE but the best laid plans of mice and men etc etc etc. i intend to work on this story in alternating 3-4 chapter chunks with Every Hateful Instrument. we'll see how that goes. i have a burning desire to finish them both

thank you to em for the beta read! my socials are as usual natsinator @ twitter, javert @ tumblr, gayspaceopera.carrd.co , and join my discord server https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

Letter from Belgium (B-Side)

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

January 487 I.C., Odin

Duke Braunschweig did not keep his military staff as pets in his estate. He had a three story brownstone not far from the Ministry of War, where most of his staff officers had desks. It was a pleasant building, for all that it was filled with people Yang did not much care to associate with.Â 

Duke Braunschweig technically held the rank of admiral in the Imperial fleet, but this was more of an inherited or honorary title than a mark of experienced command. As far as Yang was aware, the duke had never engaged in active combat, nor had he been trained for it in any meaningful way. His paper rank came from the fact that he had exercised his noble right to command the troops who originated from his territories.Â 

The vast majority of nobles, especially minor nobility, pledged their soldiers directly to the crown. They lacked either the desire to command, the raw numbers of pledged troops to make itÂ  worthwhile, or the courage to flaunt the rights that they technically possessed. It also spared them a financial burden of supporting their own army. These conscripted troops from minor holdings made up the majority of the actual fighting force of the Empireâ€” all of those who served in fleets under career soldiers appointed by the Kaiser, like Fleet Admiral Muckenburger. Troops from nobles like Duke Braunschweig could technically be called into service by the crown, either commanded by their lord, or loaned to the crown to be commanded by a more experienced officer. Duke Braunschweigâ€™s troops, since they were so great in number, were occasionally used in this way, but as Kaiser Friedrichâ€™s health declined, there were fewer and fewer large military dispatches planned that required these extra forces.

It had actually been a little troublesome for Duke Braunschweig to arrange for Yang (and, with him, Kircheis) to be transferred to his staff, since both were registered citizens of Odin, and therefore the crown directly. Fleet Admiral Muckenburger had apparently protested the transfer, which had surprised Yang when he learned about it through the grapevine. But Duke Braunschweig had managed it, through sheer force of will, or through petitioning the Kaiserâ€” it was unclear to Yang. One thing was certain: Yang was worth far more than his salary, as Duke Braunschweig was paying some hefty fee to have him â€œon loanâ€ from the crown. This made any and all of his wasted time while in his office at work feel all the sweeter.

Yang had now been working for Duke Braunschweig for more than half a year, and it certainly showed in the state of his tiny office. The neatest part of it were the maps on the wall, displaying every inhabited planet of the Empire, every space fortress, every critical mining zone, vague navigable routesâ€” all the information that could be crammed onto a map at a glance. Every time he looked at the maps, Yang was tempted to cover them with pins and notes, but then sighed at what a frightful breach of security that would be, since he knew he would invariably forget to take them down, and then didnâ€™t. This left the maps as pristine as the day that they had been unrolled from their poster tubes.

Everywhere else, though, was a different story. The bookshelves behind Yangâ€™s desk were crammed with volumes, some of them turned on their sides with the page-side out, so that bookmarks with descriptions of what the relevant passages were could be read with a simple flip of fingers down the stack. The desk was covered half in scattered incomprehensible papers of supreme importance only to Yang, and half in random garbage: empty bowls from microwave meals, candy wrappers, a plate full of used teabags that had formed into a solid dry mountain.

Amidst all of this, Yang sat with his computer in front of him, a single useable spot carved in the chaos. He often pulled his feet up onto his plush chair, his knees resting against the edge of his heavy desk, and leaned forward so that he could look sideways out his office window, catching glimpses of the passers-by on the street below, or the birds that were nesting in the eaves of the roof across the way.

Yang was rarely disturbed in his office, except on occasion by Kircheis. No one else in the building seemed to know what to make of him. While most of Duke Braunschweigâ€™s staff officers were concerned with the provisioning and maintenance of his fleet and the interfacing of it with the larger Imperial military, Yang had his own special tasks, the results of which were reported directly to Duke Braunschweig.Â 

It was hilarious that Duke Braunschweig had pinned the task of planning an entire war on one man. What was even funnier was that he had managed to find one of the few people in the Imperial military remotely qualified to do it. Yang knew he had plenty of shortcomings: he lacked the years of experience that someone like Fleet Admiral Muckenburger had; he was less of a strategist than he was a tactician; he did not have access to many important resources and pieces of information; he suspected that when time came to put his plans into action, he would be unable to convince Duke Braunschweig to follow them; and, perhaps most importantly, he didnâ€™t know if he truly wanted to succeed. But even with all of that, Yangâ€™s time in the PI unit under Rear Admiral Bronner had given him a clear understanding of the talents and tactics of most relevant commanders in the Imperial fleet, and his thousands of hours playing war games had prepared him to grasp the scope of a conflict writ large.Â 

It was still a fantasy story that he was weaving, another false battle, and it made Yang nostalgic for years ago, at the IOA. He would sometimes stare into space, thinking of a particularly elegant solution to a problem, and be seized by the urge to tell Reuenthal about it. Or he would laugh to himself when he jotted down a note that he knew, if he had still been a student, would have made Staden put a gigantic red question mark on one of his strats postmortems. Sometimes, heâ€™d flip through the list of commanders that he suspected that Littenheim was going to be able to recruit to his side, and he would hear Bronnerâ€™s voice in his ear, saying something like, â€œHeâ€™s miscast for the role youâ€™re having him play.â€

If Yang hadnâ€™t had the sense that in a few short years (or even months) this would all become terrifyingly real, he might have enjoyed it. But as it was, he lost sleep over it, and that only grew worse the more pieces came into play, the more resources he encouraged Braunschweig to gather, the more allies he pointed out that he should encourage to come to his side.Â 

Yang had begun his planning with the goal of ending the civil war as quickly as possible, to prevent as much collateral damage to the citizens of the Empire as he could. If he kept that idea in mind, he could at least make himself move forward. But the more he shuffled the pieces around before him, the more complex it seemed by the moment. He was haunted by knowing that there was no perfect strategy, but he was compelled to search for one regardless. He thought if he kept at this long enough, he would go slightly insane.

It was almost a relief, then, when a new and different problem landed in his lap, (or really, his email inbox) completely out of the blue.

The message was innocuous enough on its surface.

Â 

Dear Captain von Leigh,

I doubt you remember me, but I took your class on Ancient Earth History a few years back. Itâ€™s probably very strange for me to be contacting you, but Iâ€™ve been working in the Embassy on Phezzan since I graduated, and Iâ€™ve had the pleasure of hearing your name mentioned a few times.

In particular, I met this man at a party who said that he had once been aboard Rear Admiral von Reuenthalâ€™s flagship, and knew you, or knew of you, in any event. He asked me to tell you that he sends his regards to your favorite student. Unfortunately, I didnâ€™t catch his name, but Iâ€™m hoping that you understand more of what he was talking about than I did.

I hear that youâ€™ve left the IOA. Iâ€™m surprisedâ€” I thought you were a good teacher, at least. How is working for Duke Braunschweig? If Iâ€™m honest with you, that is not a staff posting that I would have chosen for myself haha. Congratulations on your promotion, though.

I hope you are doing well.

Very respectfully,

Lt. Cmdr. Neidhart Muller

IOA Class of 482, Strategic Warfare Division

Â 

Although it had been several years, Yang did remember Muller. He had been a senior when Yang had taught him, his very first year of teaching at the IOA. Muller had been fresh faced, with sandy-light hair and an enthusiasm for everything. Yang couldnâ€™t remember where in his class he had graduatedâ€” Yang wasnâ€™t teaching the SW class at the time, so it hadnâ€™t been relevant to him. Muller must have been near the top, because being assigned the embassy on Phezzan was a coveted position, and Muller had been promoted quite quickly since he graduated. In Yangâ€™s class, he had done well, despite Yang grading his first crop of students unduly harshly. (He had tempered his expectations for student performance after his first semester of classes.)

All of that was well and good: Yang liked Muller, and Muller had respected him as a teacher, even if they had never spoken outside of class.

The problem was, Yang knew exactly what Muller was trying to communicate to him with this vague ramble about someone he met on Phezzan, and it was sure to be nothing but trouble.

Of course, what the unwitting messenger Muller couldnâ€™t have known was that all of Yangâ€™s mail was read by his insatiably nosy former superior, Rear Admiral Deitrich Bronner. He had been a commodore when Yang had worked for him, but he had recently gotten a long overdue promotion, and an accordingly larger role at the Ministry of War. That had not stopped him from spying on Yang, whom he considered his personal project. Usually, Yang didnâ€™t mind it that much; he knew better than to write most things down. Muller had definitely stumbled into a minefield with this message, though.

So, Yang held off on talking to the actual intended recipient of the message, waiting for Bronner to mosey up to Braunschweigâ€™s admiralty offices and knock primly on Yangâ€™s door, which he did.

â€œCome in,â€ Yang called, hastily flipping shut the notebook at his right hand.

Bronner strode in, looking with an owlish disdain at the mess in Yangâ€™s office. Yang stood and saluted to greet him. â€œI figured youâ€™d get around to visiting me,â€ he said.

â€œAnd what made you so sure of that?â€ Bronner asked, taking a seat in front of Yangâ€™s desk, in the chair that only Kircheis ever used.

â€œThis isnâ€™t a visit to congratulate me on my engagement to Baroness Westpfale?â€ Yang asked, smiling. â€œThe formal engagement announcement and banns were in the newspaper last week.â€

â€œIâ€™ll congratulate you when the curtain finally closes on the whole affair,â€ Bronner said. â€œI notice that you didnâ€™t put a date for the wedding in the announcement.â€

â€œIt hasnâ€™t been chosen yet.â€

â€œI suggest you choose one,â€ Bronner said, voice dry. â€œAnd make it soon.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think thereâ€™s any need to rush.â€

â€œThis isnâ€™t politics, Leigh. This is personal advice: an overly long engagement only leads to trouble.â€ Yang remembered that the reason Merkatz had sent him to work for Bronner was that Bronner had once had a two-year-long engagement to Merkatzâ€™s daughter, though the whole thing had been broken off before it could turn into a marriage.Â 

â€œThe personal is political,â€ Yang said. â€œBut Iâ€™ll stop pretending that I donâ€™t know what youâ€™re here for.â€

â€œToo bad. I was hoping to see if your acting skills had improved.â€

â€œIâ€™m still working from a second-rate script,â€ Yang said. â€œAnd you would know, since youâ€™re still reading my mail.â€

Bronnerâ€™s lips curled in a thin but amused smile. â€œItâ€™s not every day that a former â€˜Phezzaniâ€™ starts getting strangely vague mail from the embassy on Phezzan. Especially mail that talks about another person who requires a watching eye.â€

â€œYou wonâ€™t have any eyes left to do your actual job if youâ€™re using one to spy on me and the other on Sub-lieutenant Kircheis.â€

â€œSpying?â€ Bronner said. â€œHardly. Itâ€™s simply that I have orchestra seats to your performance, right near the stage.â€ He trailed his fingers through the air, like he was conducting some music. â€œWatching all the players come and go.â€

â€œOf course,â€ Yang said.

â€œSo, explain it to me, if you would, Captain.â€

â€œYouâ€™re not going to like what I have to say.â€

â€œAnd why is that?â€

â€œIâ€™m going to tell you that this is completely harmless.â€

Bronner didnâ€™t react. â€œLeigh, let me tell you something.â€

â€œWhat?â€

â€œYou are just a little too valuable to be let out of my sight at the moment. I wouldnâ€™t want to see you dragged out of your post and sent to a work camp on the frontier.â€

â€œIâ€™m flattered,â€ Yang said in as deadpan of a voice as he could muster.

â€œSo, itâ€™s probably not your skin on the line here if you donâ€™t convince me of this all being harmless. Itâ€™sâ€” what was his name again?â€ Bronner prompted. Yang was sure he knew the name, but wanted to annoy Yang, or see if Yang had any reaction to saying Mullerâ€™s name.

â€œLieutenant Commander Muller,â€ Yang said.

â€œThatâ€™s right. You seem to remember his name well enough.â€

â€œI remember him as a student,â€ Yang said. â€œBut nothing much more than that.â€ He shrugged. â€œHe wasnâ€™t a special project of mine, anyway.â€

â€œPity. Theyâ€™re always so interesting.â€

Yang just rolled his eyes. â€œMuller wasnâ€™t that interesting. If he was, you and I both know he wouldnâ€™t have gotten posted to Phezzan. Interesting is not a thing you want in people working at the embassy.â€

â€œVery true.â€ Bronner smiled again. â€œAnd I did check up on his family. His lovely parents are still comfortably at home, with the same check that he sends them every month to help pay off their houseâ€” nothing more and nothing less.â€

â€œI hope you didnâ€™t bother them,â€ Yang said.

â€œOf course not.â€ Yang couldnâ€™t tell if Bronner was lying.

â€œI suspect that if there had been any other recent IOA graduate there in Mullerâ€™s place who had me as a teacher, they would have gotten the same request to pass along the message. Mullerâ€™s just the pigeon carrying it home.â€

â€œAbout as intelligent as one, too,â€ Bronner intoned. â€œHe should know better than to put any of this on paper.â€

â€œThis is only suspicious because youâ€™re already suspicious of me.â€

â€œSuspicious? I wouldnâ€™t describe it that way. Merely curious.â€

â€œThatâ€™s much better.â€

Bronner just smiled thinly. â€œSo, convince me that this is harmless, Leigh. Whatâ€™s this all about?â€

â€œDo you know who the person Muller is talking about is, or do I have to explain it to you?â€ Yang asked.

As Muller had said in his letter, the person who had once been aboard Reuenthalâ€™s ship was sure to be Reinhard von MÃ¼sel, formerly a cadet at the Allianceâ€™s equivalent of the IOA. While Reinhard had been working in a summer posting at a starship facility called Condor Base, he and one of his coworkers, another cadet named Fredrica Greenhill (notably, the daughter of one of the Allianceâ€™s most respected admirals) had survived an attack by Reuenthal on the base. Somehow, they then proceeded to sneak aboard Reuenthalâ€™s flagship, free a swathe of prisoners of war, commandeer one of the other ships in the fleet, and escape. It had been a major personal embarrassment for Reuenthal, since Reinhard even had the gall to impersonate an Imperial lieutenant, and went into Reuenthalâ€™s office to speak to him personally.Â 

Although he would have never admitted it to Reuenthal, who was like a ruffled cat whenever the subject was brought up, Yang found the whole thing very funny.Â 

What Reinhard was doing on Phezzan, or why he had occasion to talk to Muller, Yang didnâ€™t know.Â  He also had no idea if Bronner had been following the news on Phezzan closely enough to put all these pieces together.

â€œYou take all the fun out of things.â€ Bronner reached into his pocket and pulled out a piece of folded paper. He looked like he was about to slide it across the desk to Yang, but the clutter on Yangâ€™s desk made that impossible, so he just held it out with a look of disdain. Yang took it and unfolded it, revealing a photocopy of an intelligence report from the Phezzani embassy: a rote description of one of the Allianceâ€™s staff at their own High Commissionerâ€™s office on Phezzan. It was accompanied, of course, by a picture of Reinhard von MÃ¼sel. His long golden hair was done in twin french braids, and he was wearing a lieutenant commanderâ€™s pin on his collar and a frown on his face. The photograph had been taken with a long zoom lens: he appeared to be walking down the street, lost in thought.Â 

â€œIs this your man?â€ Bronner asked

â€œHe is. I didnâ€™t know that was where he was working, or that he had gotten promoted so quickly. He just graduated from their school last year, as far as Iâ€™m aware,â€ Yang said, putting down the paper, though he didnâ€™t give it back to Bronner. â€œI suppose the rebel fleet doesn't subscribe to the idea of not letting interesting people work at their embassy.â€

That actually made Bronner chuckle. â€œI get the impression that they enjoy having interesting people work there. Itâ€™s some sort of public relations scheme.â€

â€œShame that we gave up on public relations sometime under Rudolph the Great.â€ He was tempted to add a more scathing criticism of the Empireâ€™s handling of the public, but decided against it, considering who he was talking to.

Bronner was too used to Yang to react to what he had said, at least. â€œWhat I would like to know, Leigh, is what this interesting man wants with your little protÃ©gÃ©.â€

â€œThey used to be friends,â€ Yang said. â€œMÃ¼sel there is an expat; he and Kircheis were next door neighbors, years ago.â€

Yang couldnâ€™t help but feel distantly fond of Reinhard, despite the fact that they were on opposite sides of a war and had never met. Anyone that Kircheis liked, Yang was sure he would like also. And did feel a solidarity with refugees, even though Reinhard had fled in the opposite direction.

It was funny, the strings of fate that connected them across the universe. It was only by staggering coincidence that Reinhard knew who Yang was, or how to contact him. Reinhard happened to eavesdrop on an ansible conversation that Yang had with Reuenthal, where they discussed sending Kircheis to join Reuenthalâ€™s fleet upon his graduation.

For a coded message passed hand to hand across the galaxy, it really was simple and sincere. At heart, it was, â€œHello, old friend, Iâ€™ve missed you.â€ All Yang had to do was convince Bronner of that.

â€œThat strains the limits of my imagination,â€ Bronner said.

Yang shrugged. â€œItâ€™s true enough. I can prove it to you, if youâ€™d like.â€

â€œI would very much like,â€ Bronner said. â€œBut before you prove it, tell me why this neighbor went to all this trouble to contact Sub-lieutenant Kircheis.â€

â€œIâ€™m fairly sure that MÃ¼sel really was just saying hello. Thereâ€™s not much information in that letter, is there?â€

â€œThere could be some sort of code.â€

â€œThe day you break it, let me know. I think that the only reason that this greeting has gone through such a winding route is because MÃ¼sel genuinely had no other way to contact Kircheis, after having lost touch with him years ago.â€ Yang said. He tilted his head and looked at Bronner. â€œI recall during that incident with Rear Admiral Mittermeyer, you seemed very sure that Kircheis would be able to speak to anyone, on any planet he liked.â€

â€œDid I?â€ Bronner asked, voice dry. â€œI donâ€™t recall.â€

Yang just stared him down, but Bronner refused to admit anything.

â€œIn any event,â€ Yang said, â€œThis is harmless. And, even if it wasnâ€™t, youâ€™re keeping so close of an eye on Kircheis that Iâ€™m sure he couldnâ€™t even sneeze in Phezzanâ€™s direction without you making note of it somewhere.â€

Bronner smiled. â€œThe question remains, Leigh: what are you going to do about this?â€

â€œDo?â€ Yang asked, then sighed. Bronner wasnâ€™t stupid. He leaned his chin on his hands, elbows on his desk. â€œIâ€™ve been told that MÃ¼sel has a particular desire to destroy the Goldenbaum dynasty. I suppose I should keep an eye on him.â€

â€œAnd are you going to pass along this message to your favorite student?â€

â€œI havenâ€™t yet.â€

â€œAnswer my question.â€

â€œYes,â€ Yang said. He might have elaborated, but he had no desire to give Bronner much more than was necessary.

Bronner looked at him for a long second. Yang wanted to squirm, but he didnâ€™t. â€œYou keep an eye, then, Leigh.â€

â€œWhat do you mean by that?â€

â€œA more sensible person would ignore this message, and not respond.â€

â€œYou think Iâ€™m going to write Muller back?â€

â€œOf course you will.â€

â€œAnd why do you say that?â€

â€œBecause neither one of us can resist peeking behind the curtain whenever we get the chance,â€ Bronner said finally. It sounded like an admission, and it made Yang smile.

â€œYou know, sir, there could be worse things for us to have in common.â€

Bronner shook his head. â€œNot for all the money on Phezzan would I want to have more in common with you, Leigh.â€ He leaned forward. â€œBut before I let this drop for nowâ€” you mentioned you had proof?

â€œI do.â€ He checked the timeâ€” it was just after noon, and Kircheis was almost certainly at lunch right now. Yang stood, and stretched, though the motion caused a few papers to fall to the floor. He looked at them with an annoyed frown, then left them where they lay. He went to the door. â€œCome on,â€ he said.

â€œWhere are we going?â€ Bronner asked, suspicions.

â€œKircheisâ€™s desk.â€

â€œIs he here?â€

â€œIâ€™m sure heâ€™s gone off to lunch,â€ Yang said, leading Bronner through the hallway and then down the back stairs. The second floor was different in layout than the third. The rooms off the hallway were larger, and were filled with cubicles for the more junior staff. Yang was glad he had an office. Most of the junior officers were off at lunch, though there were a few still at their desks, and they stood, alarmed, when they saw the rear admiral stripes on Bronnerâ€™s shoulders. Bronner waved them back down and then ignored them, as Yang led him to the back of the room to Kircheisâ€™s desk, tucked up against one frosty window. Kircheis, as Yang had anticipated, was not there.

â€œThereâ€™s your man,â€ Yang said, pointing at the single framed photograph on Kircheisâ€™s desk. It showed a fifteen year old girl and two ten year old boys. The striking red hair of one of the boys marked him as Kircheis, while the girl and the boy were both blonde and angelic. There was a lock of that hair tucked in between the photograph and the frame.

Bronner reached to pick it up, but Yang said, â€œLeave it alone,â€ and Bronner complied.

â€œThey were close, it seems,â€ he said, looking at the hair.

Across the room, the heavy door swung open. Yang and Bronnerâ€™s heads both snapped up, and Yang was quite embarrassed to see that it was Kircheis walking in.Â 

He was good at keeping his face placid. â€œWere you looking for me, Rear Admiral, Captain?â€

â€œItâ€™s good that youâ€™re here, actually, Sub-lieutenantâ€”â€ Bronner began, but Yang cut him off.

â€œ I was looking for you. Rear Admiral Bronner was just leaving,â€ Yang said.

Bronner took Yangâ€™s interruption in stride. â€œOf course. Iâ€™ll see myself out. Have an excellent day, Sub-lieutenant.â€ He nodded to Yang, then pushed past him and Kircheis to head to the door. Yang was grateful that this was all it took to get Bronner to leave. If he had chosen to cause a scene about Kircheisâ€™s relationshipâ€” current or formerâ€” with Reinhard there in the office, it would have been deeply unpleasant. As it was, Yang was sure that Bronner would be writing everything he knew or suspected down in his endless notes, but there was nothing Yang could do to stop him from doing that.

After Bronner left, Kircheis asked, with a more honest note of concern in his voice, â€œWhat can I do for you, Captain Leigh?â€

â€œCome up to my office, for one thing,â€ Yang said. â€œI have something to give to you.â€ He scratched the back of his head, then said, â€œItâ€™s funnyâ€” Iâ€™m not sure if youâ€™ll appreciate having it or not.â€

â€œYouâ€™re making me nervous, sir,â€ Kircheis said. They walked out of the junior officersâ€™ cubicle room and back upstairs.

â€œWhat are you doing back early from lunch?â€ Yang asked.

â€œMartinâ€™s exam ran late, so he couldnâ€™t meet me,â€ he said. â€œSo I came back early.â€

â€œI see.â€Â 

They climbed the creaking back stairs, and Yang unlocked his office door and let Kircheis in. When the door closed behind them, Kircheis relaxed, just a little. He always held his hands so stiffly when he was nervous, like he was resisting with all his strength the temptation to curl them into fists. When he sat down in the chair in front of Yangâ€™s desk, his hands now draped loosely over the armrests, though one finger picked at some of the chipped varnish on the wood.

â€œWhat is it that you wanted to talk to me about?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œI was going to wait until later this afternoon, but it might as well be now,â€ Yang said. He sat down in his own chair, pulling his legs up to sit as cross legged as possible, though his knees were bent upwards by the armrests. â€œI received a letter the other day,â€ Yang said.

â€œAbout what, sir?â€

â€œAbout nothing, really.â€ He pulled at his hair again. There was no easy way to deliver this information. â€œYour childhood friend, Reinhard von MÃ¼selâ€”â€

Kircheis immediately stiffened in his seat.

â€œâ€”says hello,â€ Yang finished.

â€œHow?â€ Kircheis asked.

The paper that Bronner had handed Yang was still on his desk, and he handed it to Kircheis, who read it over, his eyes wide. The edge of the paper shook; he wasnâ€™t holding it steady.

As Kircheis read, Yang said, â€œHe met a former student of mine, Lieutenant Commander Muller, whoâ€™s stationed at the embassy on Phezzan, and convinced him to pass along a message. Heâ€™s lucky I knew how to interpret it.â€ Yang opened his computer and pulled up the message, then spun it around so that Kircheis could read it. â€œIt really is just â€˜hello.â€™â€

â€œThis is what Rear Admiral Bronner was here for?â€ Kircheis asked. He was trying very hard to be professional. His mask was firmly in place, but Yang knew he was wearing a mask.

â€œYes.â€

â€œWhat are you going to do, sir?â€

â€œThe question is, Kircheis, what would you like me to do?â€

â€œIâ€”â€ There was so much strange emotion wrapped up in that single syllable. Kircheis stifled it and tried again. â€œI donâ€™t know, sir.â€

â€œBronner expects me to send a reply to Muller.â€

â€œWhy would he let you do that?â€

â€œDo you want the truth, Kircheis?â€

Kircheis thought about this for a second too long for comfort. â€œYes.â€

â€œBronner would let me do it because, as a soldier in His Majestyâ€™s fleet, I should try to use this opening to see if there is a weakness that can be exploited. To see if Reinhard von MÃ¼selâ€™s desire to speak with you might lead to him giving something valuable away.â€

â€œHe wonâ€™t, sir,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œMaybe not. Bronner, Iâ€™m sure, also thinks that thereâ€™s a possibility that MÃ¼sel is fishing for weaknesses in our fleet, trying to find someone he could turn to his side.â€

Kircheis looked down at the paper in his hands. â€œI donâ€™t think Reinhard would do that to me.â€

â€œYou trust him very much, for a man you havenâ€™t seen in a decade.â€

â€œI know him,â€ Kircheis said. â€œAndâ€¦â€

â€œAnd what?â€

â€œHe made me a promise, a long time ago. I think heâ€™s still keeping it.â€

â€œI wonâ€™t ask what it was.â€

â€œThank you.â€

â€œWell,â€ Yang said, â€œthink on this. I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s any hurry to respond, if you want me to respond.â€

â€œThank you, sir.â€

Yang let his feet fall back down to the floor with a final thump. â€œThatâ€™s all I really have for you,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™ve just been a messenger for a messenger.â€

â€œThank you for telling me, sir,â€ Kircheis said. â€œYou didnâ€™t have to.â€

â€œI did,â€ Yang said. â€œI would like to think that you and I can be honest with each other, at least.â€ Even as he said that, he offered Kircheis a somewhat apologetic smile, because even that wasnâ€™t true. â€œI trust you, even if Rear Admiral Bronner doesnâ€™t.â€

Kircheis met his eyes. Yang wasnâ€™t sure what he saw in them, but it was earnest, whatever it was. â€œThank you, sir.â€

â€œJust be careful,â€ Yang said. â€œBronner is keeping tabs on you.â€

â€œI will.â€ And then Kircheis stood, and with a nodded goodbye, headed out of Yangâ€™s office. Yang noticed belatedly that he had taken the intelligence report on Reinhard with him.

Chapter End Notes

i know that some of you have been waiting for this particular event for a while

this is simultaneously the perfect job for yang and also yang's literal nightmare hell job. sorry yang. we'll get to see more about yang's civil war planning as things progress, but for now we've got kircheis drama lol. i hope this plot point does not feel /too/ abrupt for people who have only been reading the empire side of the story! this was a whole thing on reinhard's side. for those of you who haven't read that half yet, i don't want to spoil what happens in it, but there's /significant/ crossover plot points between the two story halves. i want to talk about it but I'll restrain myself :p

it's the return of bronner! love him or hate him, he's bringing something to the table. might not be good. might be bad. but it's certainly on the table. i think his theater metaphors might be pushing the bounds of silliness but look. i am allowed to have a silly man whose speech patterns amount to "hi there's Theme happening in this book. did you know?" lmao. he should go hang out with ms kino "cinema" mejia over in ItSoH (they would hate each other and drive each other insane).

the letter from belgium b-side is "attention all pickpockets"

In comes you, not the same person I knew
Looking roughly the same but something hungry getting restless in your brain
[...]
So there I go, not the same person that you used to know
Peeking through the fish-eye lens at you

but i reserve the right to title a different chapter after this song at some point in the future

it's a bit of a nasty web that is being woven here i am not going to lie lol

kircheis keeps that photo of reinhard at his desk at work b/c martin would be annoyed if he kept it in their shared bedroom lmao

i feel like there was something else I was going to say? i've forgotten it completely.

thank you very much to em for the beta read! my social medias are as follows: javert @ tumblr , natsinator @ twitter, gayspaceopera.carrd.co , https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

Sending It Along!

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

January 487 I.C., Odin

Captain Leigh should have waited until Kircheis was about to leave for the day to tell him about the letter. Since it was right after lunch, the rest of his work day was sure to be ruined. Kircheis was a good worker, and usually could focus on his tasks despite distractions, but there were very few things that could have knocked him as off-balance as this news. His daily tasks, a list of subjects to research for Leigh and some scheduling of fleet resupply that had been pushed onto his plate by the more senior staff in Braunschweigâ€™s office, fell by the wayside. All Kircheis could do was look back and forth between the framed photograph on his desk and the wrinkled paper in his hand, comparing the Reinhard he had known in childhood to the one he saw in the new image.

It wasnâ€™t as though he hadnâ€™t seen recent photographs of Reinhard before. There had been the grainy security footage in the Phezzani newspapers along with his school yearbook photo. But this was somehow different. It wasnâ€™t just that the image was clearer, and that the expression on his faceâ€” a tight lipped half-scowlâ€” was familiar. Although Kircheis knew it was unlikely, he couldnâ€™t help but imagine that in this picture, he was what Reinhard was thinking about.

He got himself a cup of coffee, then let it go cold at his elbow as he stared at the pictures some more. Lieutenant commander! Reinhard outranked him by a mile. The thought made Kircheis smile. It seemed like the natural order of things, in a way. It must have been his actions at Condor Base that had earned him such a promotion, even though they had happened when he was a student. Unless he had been allowed to leave school early, and had been promoted several times within the year? Kircheis wished he knew. What he wanted, more than anything in the universe, was to sit down across a table from Reinhard and listen to him tell every story he had from the past ten years. He could just imagine his voice, deeper with age but still with the authoritative tone that he assumed Reinhard would never drop.

That was impossible, of course. There was no way that Kircheis could go to Phezzan, even if it would have technically been legal. It was frustrating, to be so close and so far away. He would have to make do with this, a flash of communication.

Had Reinhard reached out just because of the connection that they shared? Or did he want to ask Kircheis for something? The idea was heavy in his stomach. He had, with Reinhard, sworn to destroy the Goldenbaum dynasty, a decade ago. Reinhard had told him to gain power by joining the fleet, and although Kircheis had not been planning to, he had done exactly that. With Captain Leigh, he had nestled himself up to the presumptive heir of the Goldenbaum throne.

What, exactly, did that mean for the promise that Kircheis had made to Reinhard, all those years ago? He didnâ€™t know. And asking that question of himself only brought up more complicated and pressing ones.

What was Kircheis doing here under Braunschweig? He was going to have to answer that question eventually. When he lifted his head to look above the edge of his cubicle, he could just see the Braunschweig family crest, carved and painted wood, hanging on the wall across the room. He knew he was here because he had wanted to follow Captain Leigh. Leigh had offered to find him a place elsewhereâ€” there were many places that he could have goneâ€” but Kircheis had wanted to stay with him, even if Leigh did feel like it was stifling his career.

But what was Leigh doing under Braunschweig? Of course, Kircheis knew about the trade that Leigh had made: his services in exchange for Rear Admiral Mittermeyerâ€™s life. But that didnâ€™t explain Leighâ€™s ultimate goal. And Leigh must have had some kind of goal. Kircheis thought back to one of the first conversations that he had with Leigh, sitting across from him at Josefâ€™s bar, Leighâ€™s legs all twisted up in the booth seat as they talked about ambition. He had said that he wanted to do more good than harm in the universe, and so he must have thought that he could accomplish that somehow under Braunschweig.

Kircheis could never ask Leigh directly if he was planning to overthrow Braunschweig when he was weak, after the civil war that was sure to be coming. It didnâ€™t seem like that was the case from the work that Leigh was having him do, but Leigh wouldnâ€™t be careless enough to let anyone else figure that out, even if it had been his intention.Â 

Did Kircheis want to overthrow Duke Braunschweig, and the Goldenbaum throne with him? When he thought about what he wanted, his ambitions for the wider world, he wasnâ€™t able to form a coherent picture. The Goldenbaum dynasty was wrong, certainly. He could see that clearly enough. But even if he and Captain Leigh were in a position to replace it with something else, what was that other thing? Did Leigh want the same things that Reinhard did? Or even the same things that Martin did?

It was funny. All his life, Kircheis found himself following behind people who saw their goals very clearly, while he stayed as their helpful shadow, tagging along. First Reinhard, and then Martin, and now Captain Leigh. He could admit that part of the reason that he had fallen in love with Martin was because his passion reminded him of Reinhardâ€™s, if in a different way. The thought made him smile, though another glance at the photo of Reinhard made the smile feel uncomfortable on his face.

At the end of the day, he hurried out of the office and began the long trek back home. The apartment he shared with Martin was far closer to Odin National University than it was to the Ministry of War, though Kircheis didnâ€™t mind. The subway trip and the brisk walk in the cold air was usually a good time to push all of his workday thoughts out of his mind before he saw Martin. He needed the separation between those two worlds.

Of course, today, even the light snowfall couldnâ€™t distract Kircheis enough, and when he arrived back at home he was actually startled to walk in the door and find Martin sitting at the kitchen table, a pen between his teeth as he furrowed his brow at his computer. Kircheis didnâ€™t know what he had been expecting to find at home. His mind had just been elsewhere. He shrugged off his jacket and went to change out of his uniform before saying anything to Martin, who looked up at him with a smile when he came in.

When Kircheis was in his underwear in the bedroom, fishing new clothes out of the closet, Martin wandered in, trailed his friendly hand across Kircheisâ€™s back, then sat down on the bed. â€œRough day at work?â€ he asked.

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said. â€œJust strange.â€ He pulled a new shirt on over his head so that he wouldnâ€™t have to look at Martin for a moment, then turned to face him.

â€œStrange in a way you can talk about?â€

â€œNot really,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI got some unexpected news from Phezzan.â€

Martin raised an eyebrow, and Kircheis shook his head.Â 

â€œItâ€™s complicated. Iâ€™m just not sure what to do about it.â€

â€œI understand.â€

â€œHow was your exam?â€

â€œFine,â€ Martin said. â€œIâ€™m sorry I couldnâ€™t meet you for lunch.â€

â€œItâ€™s alright.â€ He found pants and sat down next to Martin on the bed to pull them on.

â€œYou seem very out of it.â€

â€œPerceptive.â€

â€œI try.â€

â€œDo you have any plans for dinner?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œI think thereâ€™s some leftover meatloafâ€¦â€ Martin said, then trailed off, catching Kircheisâ€™s expression. â€œYou want to go out, since we missed lunch?â€

â€œYeah,â€ Kircheis said. â€œThat sounds good.â€

â€œSure. Give me twenty minutes.â€ He leaned over to press a kiss to Kircheisâ€™s cheek, then stood. Kircheis smiled up at him, a real smile this time, and Martin nodded and headed out.

Twenty minutes later, they were bundled up in their coats and walking to a nearby pub that Martin liked, about a kilometer away. It was dark and cold, with snowflakes drifting down to land softly on Martinâ€™s black toque, glistening like little stars each time they passed beneath a streetlight. The sidewalks were mostly empty, though cars rushed by, so they could speak freely without being overheard. Martin nudged Kircheisâ€™s arm as they went.

â€œYouâ€™re paranoid, you know that?â€ Martin said.

â€œI know,â€ Kircheis said. â€œBut thatâ€™s better than being careless.â€

â€œThatâ€™s true.â€ He scuffed at some of the snow on the ground with his toe. â€œWhat was it that you wanted to talk about?â€

â€œNothing too specific,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI still think itâ€™s better if I donâ€™t talk about details.â€

Martin nodded, silent.Â 

â€œI just have been thinking a lot, recently.â€

â€œYouâ€™re making me nervous.â€

â€œNo, thereâ€™s nothing to be nervous about.â€

â€œGood.â€

Kircheis glanced around the street again, just confirming that they were alone. â€œYou know I love youâ€”â€

â€œAw,â€ Martin said, interrupting him with a smile. Kircheis didnâ€™t mind, but he continued.

â€œI do. I think it started because you always knew exactly what you wanted the world to look like. You know whatâ€™s right, and you donâ€™t let anything stand in your way of chasing it.â€

â€œYouâ€™re flattering me, Sieg.â€

â€œNo, really,â€ Kircheis said. â€œIâ€™ve never had that kind of drive. And I really admire that about you.â€ He stuck his hands in his pockets.

â€œYou do have it,â€ Martin said. He frowned. â€œItâ€™s not everybody who would rush in to get arrested forâ€”â€

â€œI did that for you,â€ Kircheis said. â€œNot for any other reason, like ideology or convictions.â€ He looked away down the street. â€œJust for you.â€

Martin was silent for a long second. â€œI know,â€ he finally said. â€œBut even so. You know whatâ€™s right and whatâ€™s wrong. You could do anything you needed to.â€
