â€œCould I?â€ Kircheis asked. He looked up at the sky. Some snowflakes landed, fluttering, in his eyelashes, and he blinked them away. â€œWill I?â€

â€œWhatâ€™s this about, Sieg?â€ Martin asked.

Kircheis didnâ€™t say anything for a second, but in the darkness as they passed beneath a burnt out streetlamp, he reached for Martinâ€™s gloved hand. Martin squeezed his fingers.

â€œCaptain Leigh is in a position to make sure Duke Braunschweigâ€™s daughter becomes Kaiserin,â€ Kircheis finally said. To forestall Martinâ€™s objections, he added, â€œI know you donâ€™t think thatâ€™s a guarantee, and I know you donâ€™t think as highly of Captain Leigh as I do, but he really is a genius. If nothing happens to him, he will figure out a way for his side to win.â€

â€œOkay,â€ Martin said slowly, trying to figure out Kircheisâ€™s angle.

â€œAnd Iâ€™ll be right there with him.â€

â€œMaybe.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know what Captain Leigh wants the world to look like, but Iâ€™m pretty sure itâ€™s not what Duke Braunschweig wants the world to look like.â€ He realized he was crushing Martinâ€™s hand in his, so he relaxed his fingers. â€œAnd I know what youâ€™d want the world to look like.â€

â€œAnd you?â€ Martin asked, nudging him with his shoulder.

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œWhat are you getting at, Sieg?â€

â€œIf everything goes well, I might be in a position toâ€”â€

â€œKill Duke Braunschweig?â€ Martin asked. â€œStart a coup?â€

Although Martinâ€™s voice was light, giving voice to Kircheisâ€™s anxieties made his stomach drop. â€œOr something,â€ he finally said.

â€œArenâ€™t you lucky,â€ Martin said.

They were just a little ways away from the pub now. Kircheis stopped and turned to face Martin. â€œWould you ask me to do that for you? Or something like it?â€

He wasnâ€™t just asking Martin, Kircheis realized. He was also asking Reinhard. But Reinhard wasnâ€™t there to answer, and Martin was.

Martin looked up at him. â€œAnd if I did?â€

Kircheis opened his mouth, then closed it again, looking away. â€œPlease donâ€™t,â€ he said.

â€œAre we on the same side, Sieg?â€ Martin asked. His voice was quiet, but there was an iron edge in his tone, the same conviction that Kircheis had fallen in love with coming back to cut as deeply the other way.

â€œI hope so,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI want to think so.â€

â€œThen why would it matter if I asked youâ€”â€

â€œI just canâ€™t make promises, Martin. And I am worried that youâ€™ll ask me to make one, and I wonâ€™t be able to.â€

Martin frowned, his face half in shadow, turned away from the flashing neon lights advertising the pub just down the street. â€œYou could, if you wanted to.â€

â€œI have to be able to make my own choices,â€ he said after a moment. â€œCaptain Leigh told me once that if I didnâ€™t, Iâ€™d end up places that I donâ€™t want to be. Iâ€”â€ He shook his head.

â€œAnd would you do what your commanding officer tells you?â€ Martin asked.

There was an uncomfortable stretch of silence. â€œI donâ€™t know.â€

â€œWhy did you bring any of this up?â€ Martin snapped. â€œDid you want to have an argument about it?â€

â€œNo, of course not,â€ Kircheis said. He was tempted to explain the letter from Reinhard, but that would only make Martin feel worse, he knew. â€œThings are just changing.â€

â€œIn what way?â€

â€œI canâ€™t explain it,â€ Kircheis said. Martin turned away and began walking towards the pub. Kircheis took a few hurried steps after him. â€œMartin!â€

â€œI understand, Sieg,â€ he said, but the edge remained in his voice. â€œLetâ€™s get dinner.â€

He managed to get back into Martinâ€™s graces, at least a little bit, while they ate, talking about his schoolwork and other mundane things. The argumentâ€” or whatever it had beenâ€” didnâ€™t go far from either of their minds, but they recognized it wasnâ€™t anything that could be resolved. From the way that Martin kept sneaking glances at Kircheisâ€™s face while they ate, it seemed clear that Martin did expect Kircheis to change his mind, when the time came for it.

That night, they lay in bed, tucked under a mound of blankets as the snow spattered the window. Martinâ€™s arm was cold as it draped across Kircheisâ€™s side, and his forehead was pressed against Kircheisâ€™s shoulder, his feathery hair tickling Kircheisâ€™s back. Kircheis wound his fingers in Martinâ€™s, making him shift sleepily against him.

Kircheis wanted to say something to him, to find a way of closing the wound there in the quiet and peaceful bedroom, when it was just the two of them without the rest of the world reaching its hard hand in, but there was nothing he could say that would make it better. He couldnâ€™t explain himself, and he couldnâ€™t say the one thing that Martin would want to hear: a promise. All he could do was pull Martinâ€™s arm tighter around his chest and press a warming kiss to his cold hand.

When he eventually fell asleep, he felt a mix of guilt and elation to dream of Reinhard.Â 

â€œAnd me?â€ the dream Reinhard asked, standing out in the snow. â€œWill you make promises for me?â€

Again, Kircheis had no answer that he could give.

Â 

Â 

That weekend, Kircheis visited Hilde at her house. This was not unusual for him; she invited him over for lunch or dinner at least twice a month, and she stopped by his and Martinâ€™s apartment after her schoolday ended more often than that. It was a sunny Saturday, and the snow had frozen into a hard shell over the ground. The light reflecting off of it made strange patterns on the ceiling of Hildeâ€™s parlor.Â 

She and Kircheis sat across from each other on the couches, mugs of coffee in hand and a plate of cookies on the table between them. Her father had been home, but had needed to leave immediately following lunch to deal with some sort of urgent matter at Neue Sanssouci, so it was just the two of them. Over lunch, they had spoken about little of substance, but now that they were alone, Hilde was looking at him expectantly, knowing that he had something on his mind.

â€œCan I ask your opinion on something?â€ Kircheis asked her as she nibbled on a cookie.

â€œOf course.â€

â€œHas Captain Leigh ever told you what his plans are, for after the civil war?â€

That was apparently not the question that Hilde had been expecting. She straightened in her seat, and put down her coffee.

â€œNo,â€ she said. There was obvious conflict on her face; she opened her mouth to ask him a question, then stopped. â€œBut if he hasnâ€™t told me, Iâ€™m sure itâ€™s not my business to knowâ€” donâ€™t tell me.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know what his plans are,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI was wondering if you did.â€

â€œOh.â€ She shook her head. â€œNo, I donâ€™t even know if heâ€™d tell me if I asked. Some of the things heâ€™s said do make me wonder, butâ€¦â€

â€œWhat did he say?â€

â€œHe only told me that everyone should remember that Lady Elizabeth is going to be the one wearing the crown, not Duke Braunschweig. Itâ€™s true, but I donâ€™t know if he meant more than that.â€ She pursed her lips. â€œDoes he not like the duke?â€

â€œI donâ€™t think liking him has very much to do with the way Captain Leigh sees things. Why?â€

â€œIt only seems likeâ€” even Duke Braunschweig sees Lady Elizabeth as a toolâ€” if he thinks that she will have all the power, where does that leave the duke?â€

Kircheis took a sip of his coffee to try to cure the suddenly dry feeling in his mouth. â€œI donâ€™t know.â€

â€œI suppose he wouldnâ€™t say anything like that to you. You work for Duke Braunschweig, too.â€

â€œHe wouldnâ€™t want to put me in danger by knowing what his plans are,â€ Kircheis said. It was a startling mirror to the way he felt about Martin. Knowing anything that Martin was thinking would put them both at risk. Kircheis had the sensation that he was in a dark room, reaching blindly for someone to follow, but they were all walking away from him as quickly as they could.

â€œHeâ€™s nervous,â€ Hilde said. â€œAre you?â€

â€œAbout when the Kaiser dies? Of course. How could I not be?â€

â€œI donâ€™t like to see him be nervous,â€ Hilde admitted. She smoothed her hands over her pants. â€œI wish he didnâ€™t feel like he has to keep everything so close to his chest.â€ She looked at him. â€œHas he told you any of his plans for Braunschweigâ€™s fleet?â€

â€œSome,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI do research for him, and he trusts me with that.â€

â€œI donâ€™t want to askâ€”â€

â€œTheyâ€™re sound plans,â€ Kircheis said. â€œIf Duke Braunschweig follows them. I think heâ€™ll win.â€

Hilde relaxed a little. â€œGood. I trust your judgement on that.â€

â€œI wishâ€”â€

â€œWhat, Sieg?â€

He looked at her, and then he just smiled. â€œI wish I could show them to you, Fraulein Hilde.â€

â€œI appreciate that,â€ she said with an answering smile.Â 

But he couldnâ€™t keep things lighthearted for long. â€œIf you had your way, what would you want things to look like, when all of this is over?â€

Hilde frowned in concentration. â€œI want everyone I know safe,â€ she said.

â€œAside from that.â€

â€œWith Lady Elizabeth on the throne?â€

â€œIf thatâ€™s what you want to see.â€

â€œI thinkâ€¦â€ She picked up her coffee and took a sip. â€œWe should sue for peace with the Alliance,â€ she said finally. â€œI think everything else can follow after that.â€

Kircheis nodded. It was a practical suggestion, given that even the shortest civil war would leave the country vulnerable if they didnâ€™t sign a peace treaty, but it was an almost apolitical one. Hilde had her own reservations about politics, or at least about voicing them.

â€œI hope we can,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œWhat do you want things to look like?â€ Hilde asked.

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Kircheis admitted. He frowned and looked out the window. â€œI like to think that I want the same things that Captain Leigh wants, or that Martin wants.â€

â€œMartin is an idealist,â€ Hilde said shrewdly. â€œI love him, but he is.â€Â 

â€œThatâ€™s not a bad thing to be.â€

â€œA better thing to be is a person who can make plans and follow them.â€

Kircheis took a sip of his coffee. â€œThereâ€™s good reason that Martin doesnâ€™t talk to me about anything other than ideals.â€

â€œAre you worried about him?â€ Her voice was softer now.

â€œHow can I not be?â€ Kircheis asked. He rubbed the back of his neck. â€œIf he puts the wrong foot out of line, and he might be planning to, everything is going to come down on him. I try to be careful but thereâ€™s only so much I can do for him.â€

â€œWhatâ€™s this all about, Sieg?â€ she asked. â€œIs he in trouble?â€

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said. â€œNot that I know of, anyway.â€

â€œThatâ€™s good.â€

He sighed, then looked at her, really looked. She sat still under his scrutiny, except for the coffee dregs that she was tipping back and forth in her cup. â€œI can trust you, Hilde,â€ he said finally. It wasnâ€™t a question.

Her eyes widened, but she nodded. â€œIf you want to.â€

He couldnâ€™t quite look at her. â€œI donâ€™t think I have anyone else I can talk to like this.â€ He picked up a cookie and thought about eating it, but ended up just squishing it between his fingers. â€œI got a message from an old friend of mine, the other day,â€ he said.

â€œWho?â€

â€œHe was my next door neighbor, but his family fled the Empire when he was ten.â€

â€œHow did you get a letter from him?â€ She was leaning forward, curiosity always one of her strongest drivers.

â€œItâ€™s a long story. It came through the embassy on Phezzan.â€ He shook his head. â€œIt doesnâ€™t really matter.â€

â€œAnd what did he have to say?â€

â€œNothing,â€ Kircheis said. â€œJust hello.â€

She raised her eyebrows and said nothing.

â€œI know,â€ Kircheis said. The cookie crumbled to dust in his hand, and he ruefully tried to get the crumbs onto his little plate instead of all over Hildeâ€™s couch and floor. â€œWhen we were little, I promised to help him. I thinkâ€” well, Rear Admiral Bronner thinks that because heâ€™s reaching out to me now, he wants to try to use me as a spy, or a tool.â€

â€œIt must have been some promise that you made.â€ Hildeâ€™s voice was carefully neutral.

â€œWe were kids,â€ Kircheis said. â€œBut he was always so sure of himself, and that made me sure of him.â€ He smiled, a little wry. â€œI think he still is sure of himself.â€

â€œYou wouldnâ€™t be telling me this if you were planning to spy for him.â€

â€œNo,â€ he said. â€œI wouldnâ€™t be.â€ He looked out the window at the sparkling snow on the ground. â€œRear Admiral Bronner wants me to spy on himâ€” to be a double agent.â€

â€œAnd you wonâ€™t do that, either?â€

Kircheis was quiet for a long moment. â€œItâ€™s not really about that.â€ He shook his head. â€œItâ€™s Martin, too, and Captain Leigh. Hilde looked at him silently, waiting for him to continue.

â€œItâ€™s less about what I want and more that if he tries to do that, it wonâ€™t end well for him,â€ Kircheis finally said. â€œI worry about him.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t trust him.â€

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said. He closed his eyes. It was easy to admit things to Hilde, easy to say them aloud. â€œI canâ€™t trust him.â€

â€œOr your friend on Phezzan.â€

He nodded.

â€œAnd Hank?â€ Hilde asked.

â€œI do trust Captain Leigh,â€ Kircheis said. When Hilde didnâ€™t say anything, he opened his eyes to look at her.

â€œGood,â€ she said.

It was funny. Leigh would probably go out of his way to make sure Kircheis didnâ€™t feel like he was bound to obey him, and yet Leigh was the one Kircheis would have followed with the least hesitation. He didnâ€™t say that to Hilde; she understood.

â€œAnd you,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI trust you.â€

â€œWere you trying to ask my advice?â€ she asked, looking away and sounding uncomfortable.

â€œIf youâ€™re willing to give it.â€

â€œOf course, Sieg.â€

â€œWhat should I say back to my friend?â€

â€œWhat do you want to say to him?â€

â€œNothing that I could ever put in a letter.â€

â€œDo you feel like you understood what he was trying to say to you?â€ she asked.

â€œYes,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI think so.â€

â€œThen say something that he would understand. It doesnâ€™t have to be long, and itâ€™s probably better if it isnâ€™t.â€

He nodded. â€œYouâ€™re right.â€

Â 

Â 

Kircheis found Leigh in his office on Monday morning. Leigh was half asleep still, his thermos of tea tilting dangerously in his hand as he looked at something on his computer with bleary eyes. He didnâ€™t greet Kircheis with any formality when he came in, just waved at him to sit, and Kircheis did, silently, until Leigh seemed to come to his senses enough to recognize that it was Kircheis sitting there in front of him, and that he ought to do something about that.

â€œDid you need something, Kircheis?â€ he yawned.

â€œIf youâ€™re going to send a reply to Muller, I figured out what I want to say to Reinhard, sir.â€

This woke Leigh up, and he leaned forward, putting his thermos down with a clank amidst the mess on his desk. â€œIâ€™m glad you thought about it. Do you have a letter?â€

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI think itâ€™s better if we donâ€™t have too much contact.â€ It was a difficult admission, a painful one, but Leigh nodded and just reached for a pen and paper.

â€œWhat is it that you want to tell him?â€

â€œJust say, â€˜Iâ€™m doing what you said to.â€™â€

Leigh wrote it down. â€œRear Admiral Bronner will ask you what you said that you were going to do,â€ he cautioned.

â€œI know.â€

â€œIf he asks me, what should I tell him?â€

â€œReinhard told me to join the fleet,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œHe already knows youâ€™re in the fleet, so there wouldnâ€™t be any need for you to tell him that,â€ Leigh pointed out. â€œBronner wonâ€™t like that answer.â€

Kircheis was silent.

â€œOkay. Iâ€™ll include this when I write back to Muller,â€ Leigh finally said. He studied Kircheis. â€œAre you alright?â€

â€œI feel like I should ask you that, sir.â€ The dark circles under Leighâ€™s eyes were only growing deeper by the day.

â€œIâ€™m fine, Kircheis,â€ Leigh said. It felt unusually sharp, an end to any further questioning from Kircheis. Kircheis nodded.

â€œAlright, sir.â€

â€œIf that was all?â€

â€œIt was.â€

Leigh smiled at him, an expression that made it all the way to his eyes. â€œIâ€™ll get that letter written and passed along.â€

â€œThank you, sir.â€ Kircheis stood to leave, and Leigh turned back to his computer and thermos of tea. When Kircheis was at the door, he hesitated and turned back. â€œCaptain Leigh,â€ he said.

â€œWhat is it, Kircheis?â€

â€œDo you remember that time we went to Josefâ€™s, and talked about ambition?â€

â€œOf course.â€ Leighâ€™s voice was soft and hesitant. â€œWhy?â€

â€œIâ€™m not here because Iâ€™ve been pushed into things,â€ Kircheis said. â€œAnd Iâ€™m not going to be.â€ He met Leighâ€™s eyes, though for some reason it seemed like a struggle for Leigh to hold the eye contact; his face twitched and his gaze flicked away and back again. â€œWe have the same ambitions, so whatever it is you need from me, I am your loyalâ€”â€

â€œFriend,â€ Leigh finished, cutting him off.

Kircheis wasnâ€™t sure how to respond to that. â€œYes, sir.â€ He wished he hadnâ€™t said anything.

Chapter End Notes

happy birthday kircheis? lol

martin's found an old trunk of stage makeup in the basement and he's sending it along! we could always use more makeup

this chapter was weirdly difficult to write and i also feel like the conversations are an awkward length. hm. well it is what it is. i think most of the actual parts of this chapter speak for themselves though. soon we'll get some actual action ğŸ¤

and now it's time for this story to go on a mini-hiatus so i can write three chapters of Every Hateful Instrument which i am kinda in a hurry to finish. I think that alternating decent chunks of chapters will be good for me. if you haven't read EHI and you like this series... you will like EHI. I can pretty much promise that you will enjoy it. it's got a) gay people who make extremely questionable life choices b) galactic politics c) fraught family relationships d) thinking about what it means to be a tool for someone else e) misusing your magic powers for horny reasons

anyway please read EHI and tell me what you think about it anyway. I'll probably be back to this story in ~2 weeks but why not entertain yourself with that in the mean time :p

thank you very much to em for the beta read!

you can find me on tumblr @ javert , on twitter @ natsinator , at gayspaceopera.carrd.co , and on discord https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

Our Side of the Galaxy (Neidhart Muller and Hank von Leigh: Selected Correspondence)

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

January 22, 487 I.C.

Muller!

Of course I remember you. If Iâ€™m not mistaken, you wrote your final paper on the Spanish Civil War, which I quite enjoyed. Interesting choice of topic, though I believe I said that you could have used a narrower focus. I was too harsh in grading back then. Well, all water under the bridge.

I canâ€™t believe people are talking about me on Phezzan. I would honestly prefer that to not be the case. Working in the Embassy must be an interesting position. Iâ€™m slightly jealous, though perhaps not if youâ€™re busy around there, which I suspect you must be.

As far as the man you encountered at a party, yes, I do believe I know who youâ€™re referring to. Iâ€¦ hope... that you do not have too many reasons to come into contact with him, but if you should see him again, you may let him know that his message was received very happily, and that, quote, â€œIâ€™m doing what you said to.â€

Speaking as your former teacher, Muller, I would advise you to stay out of it. For your own sake. Iâ€™m sure you understand very well the reasons why. I appreciate whatever instinct moved you to be a messenger, butâ€” you know what? I have no room to talk.

I wish I had had you in my strats course, but you had already graduated by the time I started teaching it. I would have referred you to one of my core principles, which is to carefully choose what engagements you fight. The same principle can be broadly applied.

Iâ€™m still talking about it, arenâ€™t I?

As for my promotion, some would say itâ€™s undeserved, and some would say itâ€™s long overdue. Youâ€™re right that I miss teaching at the IOA. I liked it. Braunschweig isnâ€™t so bad, if you know how to deal with him, and I think his daughter is delightful. Takes after her mother rather than her father, which I think is something of a blessing.

I hope you are also doing well. Another piece of teacherly advice: Phezzan is a unique place; Iâ€™m sure you donâ€™t need to be told to learn as much as you can while youâ€™re there.

V/r,

Captain Hank von Leigh

February 12, 487 I.C.

Dear Captain von Leigh,

I must admit that Iâ€™m a little surprised to hear back from you, especially so quickly. Iâ€™m very glad itâ€™s not too much of an inconvenience for you to speak with a former student.Â 

I did have a minute to chat with my fellow studentâ€™s friend in a park the other day. He seemed well, but I doubt weâ€™ll have much opportunity to talk again. Phezzanâ€™s a big place, and if you run into the same person over and over, you begin to get the feeling that theyâ€™re chasing after you, which can get uncomfortable.

I appreciate all your advice, honestly. I feel like I am learning so much here. Itâ€™s unavoidable on this planet to pick up a bit of interest in business. At least in the capital, that seems to be all Phezzanis want to talk about. Iâ€™ve been reading this blog on the subject [attachment] â€” you may find it of interest. Iâ€™ve actually met the authorâ€” Marian Evansâ€” but thatâ€™s just a pen name, of course. I suppose I must respect their anonymity!Â 

Maybe itâ€™s ironic, I feel like Iâ€™m learning less about the Alliance and Phezzan than I am about my own country, despite being so far from home. You would think that Phezzanis wouldnâ€™t care so much about all the gossip about the royal family, but they do. Perhaps since they donâ€™t have the fear of being charged with lese majeste, theyâ€™re more willing to say salacious things. Iâ€™m never sure how much of the rumors I should take as true or not, especially when theyâ€™re so far removed from the source.

In any event, I am keeping myself very busy. Youâ€™re right that the Embassy is never a quiet position.Â 

Though I hear heâ€™s been sent to the front, if you should happen to see him amongst the cohort of former IOA professors, please give Commodore Staden my regards.Â 

Respectfully,

Lt. Cmdr. Neidhart Muller

February 22, 487 I.C.

Dear Muller,

I hope this letter makes it into your hands without too much difficulty, and that Iâ€™m not overstepping too many boundaries by opening up a second line of communication. From your last letter, you seemed to have an interest in speaking more, and more directly. I hope Iâ€™m not wrong about that. Although I would prefer it be face to face, weâ€™ll have to make do.Â 

I decided that it was worth the effort and expense to be able to speak with you freely. If youâ€™re wondering how I was able to arrange for a courier serviceâ€” your address is a matter of record, and as you know, I used to live on Phezzan and am familiar with the way things operate. I still have a small and untraceable amount of money that I have access to there, and this is as good of a time as any to spend it.

Since this is a rare opportunity for the two of us to be direct, I will be direct. Iâ€™m sure that by sending you this message through unofficial channels, you have lost whatever trust in me you had that I am operating above-board. And Iâ€™m sure you believe that I cannot trust you, either.Â 

Iâ€™m not sure what impulse it was that compelled you to pass along a message from an Alliance soldier. You were never one of my worst students, so you must know what doing something like that looks like!

But, if we cannot trust each other, what can we do?

I will be as honest as I can, and you can choose to believe me or disbelieve me. This correspondence, on my end, is sanctioned by Duke Braunschweig. He believes that the opportunity to learn the Alliance and Phezzanâ€™s plans is too valuable to waste. He wants me to make Reinhard von Musel a(n unwitting) spy, or, failing that, make you a source of information.

Itâ€™s obvious why he would want this done secretly: itâ€™s an avenue to gain an advantage over Marquis Littenheim when the time comes for them to fight things out. If this were all carried out through official channels, there would be no advantage for him. And, even if he wanted to, Duke Braunschweig would not be able to order you to carry out investigations officially. He has no authority over the embassy on Phezzan. So, all he can do is ask me, and all I can do is trust you.

Of course, I wouldnâ€™t be surprised if you said to yourself, â€œI always knew that Leigh was the craziest teacher at the IOA, and I want nothing to do with him.â€ (Or, even, â€œI donâ€™t want to pick a side in the fight over the throne; itâ€™s not my place as an official of the crown.â€) I couldnâ€™t blame you! Butâ€” and forgive me if I am wrongâ€” you did always seem to me to be the type of person who has an interest in, as a friend of mine once put it, peeking behind the curtain. Perhaps thatâ€™s why you were willing to reach out to me in the first place, un-sanctioned by your own superiors as it is, Iâ€™m sure.

By the wayâ€” I assume that Ms. Marian Evans is none other than Reinhard von Musel? You wouldnâ€™t be sending me that blog otherwise. It was a fascinating read, either way.

I wonâ€™t demand that you work for me, but I would like you to write me back anyway. If you have your own questions, itâ€™s only fair for me to try to answer them. Thereâ€™s instructions on how to contact the courier in the other file.

-Hank

March 5, 487 I.C.

Captain Leigh,

I appreciate your candor, or what feels like candor, anyway. Itâ€™s difficult to tell these things over text.

Respectfully,

Neidhart Muller

March 10, 487 I.C.

Muller,

I would like to ask why you think I know the answer to that question. If you were here in person, asking me to my face, I would run around in circles talking about how we construct knowledge, and walk through all the knowledge that I might have been able to construct.Â 

But you want a simple and straightforward answer, because for some reason you think that you will learn if I am trustworthy. The only reason you would think that would prove my truthfulness is if you already know what you believe to be the truth.

I keep walking myself into a conclusion and then walking out of it. Why are you asking me ? Is it my engagement to Baroness Westpfale, and Baroness Westpfaleâ€™s associations?Â 

You are asking me to make quite a leap of faith, Muller. But I will make it.

I hope that when your embassy caught and tortured Ingrid von Roscher at the border, and got whatever confession she gave, it did not take too long.Â 

That should answer the question to your satisfaction.

-Hank von Leigh

P.S. Ignore the letter that you will receive tomorrow, and if youâ€™re going to respond, donâ€™t mention this one. I have gone to a great deal of effort to ensure that my letters to you are only being read by the people who are intended to see them, but the same cannot always be said for your letters to me.

March 11, 487 I.C.

Muller,

If youâ€™re asking who killed Prince Ludwig in order to determine who to support for the throne, I donâ€™t think I have a satisfying answer for you. Some people would want to support a man who would kill the prince so that their daughter might take the throne. There is a type of person who might feel like it shows initiative.

I donâ€™t know who killed Prince Ludwig. Who benefits most from him being dead? The two other claimants to the throne? It would be reasonable. A third party who would like to see the Empire weakened by the greatest civil war ever to befall humanity? Gods know there are plenty of those around.

Let the dead bury the dead, Muller.

-Hank von Leigh

March 15, 487 I.C.

Captain Leigh,

I ask because RvM told me that the Earth Church had organized his killing. This information was somewhat in exchange for allowing his (Prince Ludwigâ€™s) wife to flee to the rebel territories unharmed. Not that I would have been able to do much to stop her, going short of causing a disaster: the rebel fleetâ€™s Rosenritter regiment in plainclothes snatched her away just a little while ago. It was quite annoying.

(Whatâ€™s funny is that RvMâ€™s sister is in the Rosenritterâ€” they look identical. I bet he had some hand in getting her unit such an interesting assignment. I certainly wouldnâ€™t have picked to send a bunch of dubiously loyal expats on a field trip to Phezzan if I were in the rebel fleet command. But maybe thereâ€™s some propaganda value in it.)

Speaking of propaganda. Weâ€™re going to have to do some real work in the Embassy to keep that from becoming a full blown rumor back at home. Iâ€™ve lined up some stories to be published about her dying on Earth and this being a fake woman trying to claim the throneâ€” I hope I donâ€™t have to use them. By the way, if you hear anyone talking about it, let me know. Honestly, I had thought she was already dead, based on what I had heard or assumed. I was very shocked when she turned up on Phezzan. People who get exiled to wasteland planets donâ€™t usually ever tend to see the light again.

If Duke Braunschweig had killed Prince Ludwig, it felt reasonable to assume that you would know. He seems to trust you, after all. Or, at least, youâ€™re close enough to his inner circle that I feel like you would be able to tell. Because of that, I think that RvM is indeed telling the truth.

I donâ€™t know much about Duke Braunschweig, but from watching how the Earth Church operates on Phezzan, the idea of them having a planâ€¦ I donâ€™t like it.

Respectfully,

Neidhart Muller

March 17, 487 I.C.

Muller,

Hah, Iâ€™d like to think that I have that much of Duke Braunschweigâ€™s confidences, but I doubt thatâ€™s the case. If I was Duke Braunschweig, I think I would be doing my best to take any knowledge of what happened to the prince to my grave.Â 

Everything you just told me sounds extremely strange. Iâ€™m putting together a picture of our friend RvM, but itâ€™s the most contradictory picture Iâ€™ve ever drawn. Heâ€™s helping the Earth Church take IvR to safety but telling you to sabotage their ultimate plan at the same time? I donâ€™t understand what reasons he could have for doing that.Â 

Iâ€™d love to figure out what the invisible unifying element is. There must be somethingâ€” the synthesis between the thesis and antithesis. I suppose I could ask my favorite student, but they havenâ€™t seen each other since they were children, so I doubt heâ€™d know anything about it. You probably know much more about our enigmatic acquaintance than he does at this point.

So, Iâ€™ll ask you. How much contact do you have with him, anyway? And whatâ€™s his ultimate goal?

And, to gather information with a different tack, I assume you are watching the Earth Church? Just to confirm or deny the things heâ€™s saying, at least?

-Hank

March 22, 487 I.C.

Leigh,

I have no idea what his problem is. I donâ€™t see him very often, for obvious reasons. Weâ€™re not exactly friends! I mean, aside from watching the comings and goings from the rebel fleetâ€™s offices on Phezzan. I see plenty of him then. And I read his blog. But thatâ€™s not much of a relationship.

I think his genuine goal is to destroy the Goldenbaum dynastyâ€” heâ€™s said as much to me. But he said that the reason he was working with the Earth Church to help Ludwigâ€™s wife cross the border was because he felt sympathetic towards her, though he wouldnâ€™t tell me why.

I was surveilling the Earth Church, but my informant vanished. I still am watching them, as closely as I can, but Iâ€™m not able to learn as much as I would like.Â 

Theyâ€™re a big organization, bigger than you might think. Their membership numbers arenâ€™t huge as a percentage of the population of Phezzan, but I think theyâ€™re surprisingly large in the rebel territories. Outside of the Empire, theyâ€™re essentially the only religious organization in town, and thereâ€™s a certain kind of person whoâ€™s drawn to that.

They have more of a compelling sales pitch than the great gods, at least. It makes sense in a twisted kind of way, to want to go back to the place you came from. I mean, it still is junk, just junk that is good at getting into peopleâ€™s heads.

I have to say, I donâ€™t really like being a messenger who feels more like a pawn. I donâ€™t know how much I can really help you.

Respectfully,

Neidhart Muller

April 1, 487 I.C.

Muller,

Of course, I completely understand. I donâ€™t want to put you in a bad position, especially with your superiors over at the Embassy. I still do feel responsible for everyone who was my student, and I would hate to be the cause of trouble for you.

And, as for religion, I can hardly blame people for wanting one. We all have stories that we cling to, to make sense of the world. Itâ€™s never really mattered if theyâ€™re true in an objective senseâ€” what matters is how we use what we believe to influence our actions.Â 

Iâ€™ve never been a believer in religion, but I do believe in many things that are almost as abstract, and almost as likely to be proven wrong. Somewhere in me, I do find I have hope for humanity to discover its own better nature, despite the historical record being one of us scrabbling bloody in the mud over and over again, always falling to our worst impulses.

But thatâ€™s the thing about belief and hope: they persist regardless of the evidence. I suppose if they didnâ€™t, none of us would be able to get a single thing done.

-Hank

April 10, 487 I.C.

Leigh,

I need to ask: who the hell is Siegfried Kircheis?

Respectfully,

Neidhart Muller

April 15, 487 I.C.

Muller,

Sub-lieutenant Kircheis is my favorite student. He works in my office. I would appreciate knowing why youâ€™re asking, after all this time.

-Hank

April 19, 487 I.C.

Leigh,

Sorry for being abrupt. I think that RvM is trying to send some kind of message, maybe to you? Iâ€™m not sure. We havenâ€™t spoken, but I watch where he goes, and heâ€™s been visiting half of the major resource extraction conglomerates here on Phezzan. Iâ€™ve done a little bit of digging (having someone follow him in and look at the sign-in sheets in the reception areasâ€” not very high tech but it works most of the time) and heâ€™s been using that false nameâ€” Siegfried Kircheisâ€” to speak with them. Itâ€™s very strange, and I canâ€™t figure out what the hell heâ€™s doing or why.

Itâ€™s pretty unusual for one of the rebel fleetâ€™s staff to go out and do something like this. I know they have a stack of Phezzani IDs that they can shuffle through, but they usually have a bunch of other stock documentation attachedâ€” we're pretty familiar with the way these look, and this does not look anything like the usual pattern. Heâ€™s being weird.

See attached for the list of companies heâ€™s visited. He hasnâ€™t posted anything about it on his stupid little blog, so it has to be something heâ€™s doing for other reasons than personal edification. Heâ€™s working overtime to do it, also, by the way. He goes to these things after he leaves the office.

Â Is this something I should be concerned about?

Respectfully,

Neidhart Muller

April 28, 487 I.C.

Muller,

You certainly already seem concerned, so I canâ€™t tell you how to feel!Â 

Iâ€™ve done some research of my own. You probably already noticed that all the places heâ€™s been visiting are Alliance-Phezzani businesses only. Thereâ€™s not a single solely Phezzani venture (or Imperial-Phezzani) business in sight. Also, the connecting link between all of these is, as you mentioned, resource extractionâ€” but it looks like there are a few types of minerals that are common across all the groups. Gold and precious metals, of course, but tungsten, too.

Thereâ€™s a limit to how much investigation I can do from here, but it seems like our friend is doing some off the clock digging into his own countryâ€™s resources.Â 

My first, off-hand speculation is that heâ€™s seeing if the Earth Church has a chokehold on the production of various critical resources. Tungsten is used in ship-building, and of course gold is important across electronics. If the Earth Church controlled these companies, and began squeezing, they might be able to subtly weaken the Alliance fleet. If the Earth Church were to do that, it might allow the power struggle in the Empire to play out for much longer than it would otherwiseâ€” if the Empire does not need to unite to fight an outside threat, our fleet could spend years eating itself alive, leaving the country in a much more favorable position for an Earth Church takeover. If the Earth Church does not believe that they can count on material support from the Alliance, that might be a strategy theyâ€™re looking into.

But, again, thatâ€™s just pure speculation on my part. And perhaps if the Earth Church does control those resources, they might already be doing the same to us.

As for why heâ€™s sending a message, that may be the reason: heâ€™s already warned you about the Earth Churchâ€™s designs on the throne once, so he may be doing so again.

Youâ€™re in a much better position to research this than I am. Let me know what you find.

-Hank

May 7, 486 I.C.

Leigh,

Iâ€™m not entirely sure itâ€™s the Earth Church. Some of these companies do have ties to it, but not all of them. Granted, I could be missing something, but unless theyâ€™ve gotten much more savvy about disguising their membership recently, I donâ€™t think so?Â 

All of these companies are hiring, though, and their employment listings are only asking for Alliance citizens, not Phezzanis. It seems like heâ€™s investigating their rapid growth. It could be that heâ€™s concerned about the stranglehold that Phezzani capital has over the Alliance economy in general, so maybe this is a mission from someone back on Heinessen?Â 

Heâ€™s stopped doing this now, so either heâ€™s figured out what he was searching for, or somebody told him to stop being weird. Or both. Or he caught on that I was watching him.

This is going to haunt me until I figure it out.

Respectfully,

Neidhart Muller

May 15, 487 I.C.

Muller,

Why would it be that all of these companies are suddenly hiring Alliance citizens only? I donâ€™t see any evidence of rapid expansion of tungsten mining on their side of the galaxy. That is the kind of thing that ends up in papers on Phezzan, and I do pay attention to those.

The industry is preparing for rapid growth of some kind, but not saying a word about it. I think I have a better idea. Thereâ€™s some mine opening that they absolutely do not want us to know about. No clue why RvM is drawing our attention to it, but I think itâ€™s clear that the Alliance wants this to be a secret.

Since Phezzani money is involved, Iâ€™d bet that this new mine isnâ€™t somewhere in the Phezzan corridor: Phezzan wouldnâ€™t stand for that. So thereâ€™s only one other place that it would matter for it to be. Iâ€™m going to see if Duke Braunschweig is amenable to spending some resources on what could end up being a wild goose chase.

This is the first time Iâ€™ve asked him to commit money to something that doesnâ€™t directly benefit his daughterâ€™s claim to the throne, so I might end up shot down. Iâ€™ll let you know how it goes.

If anything else pops up, do let me know. I could still be wildly off-base.

-Hank

Chapter End Notes

reinhard and annerose got an epistolary chapter in Life Out of Balance, so Yang and Muller can have one here lol

for anyone who didn't read Lighting Out for the Territories (ie the reinhard story that covers these events) i hope all of this is comprehensible and doesn't feel like it's coming out of absolutely nowhere lol. all of this takes way way way more time on that side of the story, since reinhard (and annerose) are the ones actually doing things

the mental image of yang reading reinhard's stupid little economics blog and being like "aw i have a weird fondness for this deeply strange guy" and later reinhard reading yang's history book and going ???? at the whole thing is such a fun thing for me to think about. yang has a much more positive image of reinhard than reinhard has of yang lol

what's also funny is thinking about yang and muller's little correspondence in the context of the singular conversation they have in the OVA where they lament that they weren't on the same side. yang is going to be so deeply annoyed at muller when [redacted for spoilers on the other side of the story. if you know you know.]

anyway glad to be back writing this! i'm going to do 2 more chapters before going back to my original fiction, Every Hateful Instrument, which you should absolutely definitely read (it's posted on ao3/rr). it's very good if i do say so myself!

thank you very much to em for the beta read!

socials: javert @ tumblr, natsinator @ twitter, gayspaceopera.carrd.co , https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

The Duel

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

May 487 I.C., Odin

Yang had lied to Muller, though it was a white lie. If, as he suspected, the Alliance did have plans to build some kind of outpost inside the Iserlohn corridor, it had suddenly become absolutely vital to his civil war planning to have control of that base instead. He didnâ€™t care about its possible tungsten output; its position on the other side of Iserlohn fortress was more valuable by far.

He had originally become Duke Braunschweigâ€™s subordinate with the promise of being able to orchestrate the capture of Iserlohn fortress. Whoever controlled the fortress would be in a position to strike a bargain with the Alliance, if it became necessary: allow the Alliance fleet through the corridor, and with their massive and fresh forces, install a regent on the throne that suited them. This wouldnâ€™t be the worst outcome, Yang supposed, but he didnâ€™t trust that anyone trying this would have the best interests of the Empireâ€™s common people at heart. In order to stop things from going badly, Yang wanted to have that option in his own back pocket.

Although he had once predicted a way that Iserlohn fortress could be defeated, and with that prediction had narrowly saved the Iserlohn fleet from total annihilation, Yang did not really like the idea of attempting to capture Iserlohn himself. Although he had plenty of ideas, some of them even good ideas, most of them relied on subterfuge, and careful planning, and a delicate touch. All of these were qualities that he had noticed that his superior, Duke Braunschweig, was noticeably lacking in.

Iserlohn fortress had many weaknesses, Yang decided. Most of them were internal, or even psychological. But it did have one physical weakness that he might be able to exploit. The fortress was meant to only prevent attacks from one direction, and the Thor Hammer, the fortressâ€™s fleet-obliterating beam weapon, could only fire in one direction at once. A pincer attack, coming from both sides, would be the surest way of brute-force defeating the fortress. The problem with that strategy, of course, was that he would need to start off with his own forces on either side of the corridor.Â 

If the Alliance was setting up some forward base within the corridor, and he could get it under Duke Braunschweigâ€™s control, that would serve as his second pincer point to allow an assault on the fortress. And, even if he couldnâ€™t capture Iserlohn directly, having a further outpost than the fortress itself would allow him to put up resistance to any ships that passed through in either direction, halting or delaying anyone elseâ€™s attempts to ally with the Alliance forces.

The problem was that Yang had to hand only extremely tenuous information from Muller about this possible base. In order to capture it, he would need to first find out where it was. It was possible that the Alliance had mapped some kind of branch within the Iserlohn corridor, one that the Empire didnâ€™t know about, that contained this base. That was likely why there was such intense secrecy around it, to allow the Alliance to truly entrench themselves on this new planet without interference.

The first step would be convincing Duke Braunschweig of the potential value of this place, and getting him to send out scouts to find itâ€” monitoring ships stationed through the corridor to detect any Alliance ships headed through bearing supplies. This would probably be the most difficult part: Braunschweig was not a man who enjoyed chasing ghosts.

Even after that, in order to get permission to bring his own ships out past Iserlohn and seize the base, Duke Braunschweig would need to petition the Kaiser for a charter. Even the highest nobles couldnâ€™t simply take whatever planets they wished and declare them their own territory. This would probably alert Littenheim to the plan, and cause a political fightâ€¦

Yang, sitting at his desk, leaned his head in his hands.Â 

And, assuming Duke Braunschweig even won that fight, there would still be the actual matter of capturing the base and holding it. Forward of Iserlohn fortress, the Alliance might be willing to make it quite a spectacular battleground, like Kapche-Lanka was.

But he needed to tackle one problem at a time. That was the worst thing about this job, he thoughtâ€” he was being asked to solve ten thousand problems that didnâ€™t exist yet.

Yang sighed and stood, resolving to go speak to one of his least favorite people, Captain Ansbach. Ansbach was Duke Braunschweigâ€™s aide-de-camp, or something close enough to it. Inside Braunschweigâ€™s organization, which was crammed top to bottom with family members in nebulous roles of authority outside of their military rank, actual duties and chains of command sometimes grew hazy, and no request for resources could land on Braunschweigâ€™s desk without it going through Ansbach first.Â 

Ansbach and Braunschweig werenâ€™t relatedâ€” Ansbach wasnâ€™t anything approaching nobilityâ€” but he had originated from Duke Braunschweigâ€™s estates before he had joined the Imperial fleet, and there must have been some reason why Braunschweig trusted him, or at least gave him responsibility. Yang didnâ€™t know by what mechanism they had originally become acquaintedâ€” he had never asked, and he doubted that either of them would ever say. It was likely that Duke Braunschweig had sponsored Ansbachâ€™s attendance at the Imperial Officersâ€™ Academy, from which he and Yang had graduated in the same year, both among the top ten students in the class.

Although he had his own office in the official building where Yang also worked, Ansbach spent most of his time in Duke Braunschweigâ€™s estate, at his beck and call. So, it was there that Yang headed, a portfolio with all of his gathered speculation under his arm. From his office, it was a twenty minute train ride, and then a short walk away.

Yang didnâ€™t think he would ever get used to the size or splendor of the Braunschweig manor, no matter how many times he visited it. Its white steps and columns dwarfed him as he shook off a misty spring rain from his umbrella and headed inside, greeted at the door by one of the many servants. They were used to him by now, but that didnâ€™t stop them from still looking on him with vague suspicion. He wasnâ€™t sure if that was due to his foreign appearance, or due to them knowing the way he had come to be working for Braunschweig in the first place. Either way, he was always uncomfortable in the dark, opulent hallways of the family home. Even if the overall aesthetic tastes were little different than the Mariendorf house, there was no familiarity or warmth to be found here.

Ansbach had a tiny desk in a corner of the servantâ€™s wing of his own in the house, but that wasnâ€™t where Yang was instructed to meet him. He was instead shown into the library, and he ran his fingers over the spines of a few dusty tomes while he waited for Ansbach to appear. The rain pitter-pattered the windows.Â 

When the heavy door opened after a few minutes of Yang standing alone, he expected that it would be Ansbach coming in, but it wasnâ€™t. It was Duke Braunschweigâ€™s daughter, Lady Elizabeth, the woman upon whose head Yang was theoretically trying to place the crown. She was as surprised to see Yang as he was to see her. He was never sure if he needed to bow to her, and he didnâ€™t particularly want to, so he just nodded and stood with his hand twisting the hair on the back of his head.

â€œCaptain Leigh,â€ she said, â€œare you here to see my father?â€ She walked across the long room with a purposeful stride, and dropped the book she was carrying onto the writing desk by the window with a heavy thump. She looked out the window at the drizzling rain for a second, the shadows made by the droplets on the glass streaming down her face.

â€œIn a roundabout way,â€ he said. â€œI usually have to go through Captain Ansbach first when I need something.â€

â€œAnd what do you need?â€

â€œScout ships in the Iserlohn corridor,â€ Yang said. â€œOut past the fortress.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t actually expect you to tell me anything.â€

â€œAre you going to go repeating it to other people?â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œThen I donâ€™t see any reason why I shouldnâ€™t tell you, at least in the generalities,â€ Yang said, studying her. She was black haired and handsome like her mother, but young, a little younger than Hildegarde von Mariendorf. Her shoulders were always thrown back, her head always held high. Whatever finishing school she had been sent to had drilled that much into her, though Yang suspected that she had been an unholy terror to the other pupils: there was something in the cold way she looked at people, eyebrows furrowing in a scowl that didnâ€™t reach her lips, that conveyed a capabilityâ€” or desireâ€” for violence, at least of a social sort. That ability, too, had come from her mother, though the desire must have come from her father.

â€œMy father wouldnâ€™t.â€ Her tone was light, and she leaned back on the edge of the desk to watch him.

â€œYour father and I are different people,â€ Yang said. â€œBut if everything goes as he hopes, you will be the Kaiserin one day. And even if there is the chance for peace in the galaxy within my lifetime, I donâ€™t think anyone in the Empire is well served by having a leader who is wholly ignorant of military affairs.â€

â€œIâ€™m told that will be my husbandâ€™s concern,â€ she said, and she drummed her fingers against the edge of the desk, her thin engagement ring making a soft but intentional click.

â€œAnd how is Lieutenant Commander von Vering?â€ Yang asked.

â€œHans is fine,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™ve been meaning to ask: did you have him as a student, when you were teaching?â€

â€œNo, I didnâ€™t have the pleasure,â€ Yang said. He said nothing more than that. The reason he had not had Hans von Vering, the scion of one of the wealthiest families in the nation, as a student was that he had graduated from the IOA quite in the middle of the pack; Yang only taught the top ranked sections. Yang suspected that Vering had been allowed into the IOA on family name, and had attended for its prestige only. His posting in the fleet was some sort of desk job in the capital.Â 

Similarly, his engagement to Elizabeth was of a wholly political nature, securing his family fortune for Duke Braunschweigâ€™s use, while promising his family power in the coming regime.

â€œToo bad.â€

Yang smiled. â€œThere were plenty of students at the IOA who were glad not to have me as their teacher.â€

Elizabeth was about to say something to that when the door opened again, and this time, it was Ansbach who came in. He took in the scene, then bowed to Elizabeth, not glancing at Yang.

â€œGood afternoon, Captain Ansbach,â€ she said as he straightened. His sallow face looked even sallower in the dim light filtering in through the rainy windows, but perhaps Yang was being ungenerous to him.Â 

â€œGood afternoon, Lady Elizabeth.â€

â€œI should get out of your hair, so that Captain Leigh can ask you for his scout ships in the corridor.â€ She straightened.

â€œYouâ€™re welcome to stay, Lady Elizabeth,â€ Yang said, before she could start heading to the exit.

â€œAm I?â€ It wasnâ€™t quite a question, and when she looked at Ansbach, it wasnâ€™t for approval, it was gauging his reaction. Ansbach always had the same tight lipped expression as he did now. â€œI donâ€™t think I am.â€ She nodded to Ansbach as she passed him en route to the door, and then left without a backwards glance at Yang, the door closing behind her with a heavy thump.

â€œA teenage girl, out-maneuvering the untouchable Hank von Leigh,â€ Ansbach said.

â€œWhat?â€ Yang asked. He sat down on one of the couches, but Ansbach didnâ€™t take a seat, instead wandering across the carpeted floor, not quite pacing. Yang followed him with his eyes.

â€œDuke Braunschweig would not appreciate you using her approval or disapproval to sway me.â€

â€œI wasnâ€™t trying to get her on my side. Itâ€™s not like Iâ€™m here to argue with you.â€ He ran his hand through his hair.

â€œThen what was the point of that?â€

â€œIf sheâ€™s going to run the country, she should know something about how,â€ Yang said.

Ansbach scoffed. There was very little they could say on the subject without wandering into dangerous territory, so he said, â€œWhat did you really come here for?â€

â€œExactly what she said. Scout ships in the Iserlohn corridor, past the fortress.â€ Yang held out his portfolio full of evidence, and Ansbach made him wait with his arm outstretched for a long second before he walked over and snatched it out of Yangâ€™s hand. As he flipped it open, Yang explained, â€œMy informant on Phezzan has told me that the rebel fleet is building some kind of tungsten mine somewhere in the corridor. The mine isnâ€™t important, but to take Iserlohn, we need our own outpost on that side of the corridor. Seizing the mine under the pretext of wanting the tungsten profits will give us a foothold. We just have to find it, first.â€

Ansbach was silent for a long time as he shuffled through the papers, combing them over. Kircheis had been the one to prepare this report, and Yang had appreciated his thoroughness. He didnâ€™t have much doubt that Ansbach would understand the value in the propositionâ€” for all that Yang had defeated him in war games as a student, Ansbach was talentedâ€” but Yang was sure that Ansbach would like nothing more than to sabotage Yangâ€™s plans and position.

â€œHow lucky for you that this critical piece of your Iserlohn strategy has fallen right into your lap,â€ Ansbach said, dropping the portfolio down on the coffee table in front of Yang. â€œYou donâ€™t have an alternate plan, do you?â€

Yang looked up at him. â€œI do.â€

â€œWhat is it?â€

â€œIf you needed to know it, I would tell you.â€ He kept his voice even. â€œI have plenty of ideas for other eventualities. But this is a simple solution, and if we can make it work, itâ€™s one that Duke Braunschweig will like.â€

â€œCommitting ships to something your spy on Phezzan thinks is happening? I donâ€™t think so.â€

â€œNo, I agree he wonâ€™t like that,â€ Yang said. â€œBut if there is something there, something he can put his hands onâ€” he likes physical resources. And a well positioned planet that can be dug for profit even after the warâ€¦â€ Yang trailed off and shrugged, then looked away. â€œYou know it would be easy to convince him, if you donâ€™t try to stab me in the back here.â€

â€œYou think I would?â€

Yang shrugged. â€œWeâ€™re not schoolboys anymore.â€

Ansbach let out something that might have been a laugh. â€œYouâ€™re usually blunt enough to ask if I have more loyalty to the duke or hatred of you.â€

â€œWhen you ask a question where there can only be one answer, be it true or a lie, you donâ€™t learn much from it.â€ Yang stood, pushing up from the couch with his hands on his knees. â€œAre you going to pass along my request?â€

â€œIf I didnâ€™t, Iâ€™m sure youâ€™d find a way to ask him yourself.â€ His lip curled. â€œI appreciate you going through the middleman, rather than having Lady Elizabeth petition on your behalf.â€

â€œIf I didnâ€™t have to go through you, I wouldnâ€™t.â€ He looked at Ansbach steadily. â€œIf we were friends, Iâ€™d give you advice about that.â€ He would have never wanted to be in Ansbachâ€™s position. It seemed more than a little dangerous to be too indispensable to Braunschweig.

â€œGood thing weâ€™re not,â€ Ansbach said. He edged away from Yangâ€™s gaze and picked up the portfolio again. â€œYou donâ€™t have to argue your case with me, but youâ€™ll have to be prepared to fight it with him.â€

â€œEven you can see that this is a good strategy.â€

â€œNo,â€ Ansbach said. â€œBut I want to see you fail on your own merits.â€ It seemed more likely that Ansbach understood that he would lose his favored position with Braunschweig if Braunschweig caught him deliberately sabotaging any part of the war effort, including Yangâ€™s plans, and so could do nothing against him at the moment.

â€œIâ€™m glad to hear we have that in common, at least,â€ Yang said.

Ansbach scoffed, but returned to a businesslike tone as he gestured with the portfolio. â€œIâ€™ll pass this along. If he needs to speak with you about it, it will be on Friday.â€

Â 

Â 

July 487 I.C., Odin

Yang got his scout ships in the corridor, traveling out with one of Braunschweigâ€™s fleets to perform a fake training exercise, then peeling off to perform their secret duties. This paid dividends far faster than anyone expected, including Yang. It was a scant month and a half later, on a sweltering early July day, that the news reached him that an Alliance supply ship had been followed through a meandering offshoot branch of the corridor, towards an inhospitable little ball of dirt: the third planet orbiting a nondescript star.Â 

The planet was in a system that Imperial starmaps had no name for, just a string of numbers. Alliance starmaps had named all the stars in that region of space, despite them being previously inaccessible. They called the star the planet orbited â€˜Cahokiaâ€™. The Alliance was much more generous with designating places with names than the Empire wasâ€” so many planets on this side of the galaxy were only named after the local noble family.

Cahokia would serve as a name just fine, Yang decided. There was no need to go complicating things by trying to name the star after some ancient German earthworkâ€” after all, those names were probably already taken by some other planet in the Empire. There were a finite number of places in ancient Germany, and all the best ones had already been used up as namesakes.

Although he had not even been sure that the scout ships would turn up anything useful, Yang had nevertheless been sitting on a complete plan for Braunschweig to put into action. Now that he had the information brought back by the scout ships, he was quite confident in it. His plan was made easier by the report that the installation on Cahokia was tiny, probably in an attempt to keep the place undetected. If Yang hadnâ€™t been specifically looking, that might even have worked. But as it was, its small profile was now a weakness: it would be easier to take. There were no ships in orbit, and probably only a very minimal ground force to protect the mine operation.Â 

Yang reported all of this to Braunschweig, standing stiff backed and sweating under his collar in front of Braunschweigâ€™s heavy wooden desk in his estate office. Standing behind Braunschweigâ€™s shoulder, Ansbach glared at him.

â€œSo, sir, the mine looks easy to take now , but we shouldnâ€™t wait on petitioning the Kaiser for authority to start building on the planet,â€ Yang said. â€œEvery day we wait is another day that the rebel fleet could decide to increase their presence in the starzone. Iâ€™m sure there are some people looking at their unprotected investment and wondering just how long it can stay secret. If I were them, I wouldnâ€™tâ€¦â€ He trailed off under Ansbachâ€™s glower, though Braunschweig seemed in good spirits.

â€œAnd youâ€™re sure that thereâ€™s no way that we could take it before petitioning the Kaiser?â€ Braunschweig asked.

Yang grimaced and rubbed the back of his head. â€œThis isnâ€™t really one of those â€˜better to ask forgivenessâ€™ situations, sir. Whatever we do will have the rebel fleet retaliating, and if that draws a big force into the corridorâ€¦â€ He shrugged. â€œYouâ€™d lose your claim on the planet after that, regardless of if itâ€™s the rebel fleet taking it back, or the crown taking it from you. Nobody in Neue Sanssouci wants to amp up the pressure the rebels are putting on us right now. â€

Braunschweig drummed his heavy fingers on the desk. â€œAnd so Iâ€™m going to describe that weâ€™re going to do exactly that: antagonize them, so that we can steal their base in the corridor.â€

â€œNo, sir,â€ Yang said. â€œIf Muckenburger hears the words â€˜rebel baseâ€™, it will become a matter for the fleet proper. Youâ€™re going to have to lie to the Kaiser and say that this is a totally unoccupied planet.â€

â€œYouâ€™re quite blase about that, arenâ€™t you?â€ Braunschweig said. â€œI was under the impression that he trusted you.â€

â€œSir, the Kaiser himself was only too happy to remind me, the last time we spoke, that I no longer work for him: I work for you.â€

Braunschweig actually laughed at that, which made Ansbachâ€™s scowl deepen behind him. â€œIâ€™m glad youâ€™re keeping that in mind, Leigh.â€ He steepled his fingers and leaned forward, elbows on his ornate desk. â€œNow, what lie specifically is it that Iâ€™m going to tell my esteemed father-in-law?â€

â€œThat youâ€™ve been performing geographic surveys in less-used areas of the Iserlohn corridor, on the adviceâ€” which everyone should take to mean behalfâ€” of Count von Vering, since he thinks that you should be equal partners in some new mining venture.â€

Braunschweig was silent for a second. â€œMost people looking to open a mine would survey elsewhere.â€

â€œExactly,â€ Yang said. â€œIf there are questions about why you chose the corridor, explain that the other frontier is overdeveloped already, and to find a new planet to mine that far away would mean having an untenably long supply chain. Things in the corridor, out past Iserlohn especially, are ripe for picking, because no one dares build where the rebels could come knocking on their door. But youâ€™re convinced that you have the military strength and expertise to keep the mine profitable. Itâ€™s worth stationing ships in order to have such a fast access route to the center of the Empire.â€

â€œI donâ€™t like bringing up Count Veringâ€™s name.â€ Braunschweigâ€™s face twisted in monetary distaste. Although he had agreed to allow his daughter to marry the son of the Vering family once Elizabeth had taken the throne, he had no love in his heart for them.Â 

â€œI think you have to, sir. Your estates are primarily agricultural, and you havenâ€™t shown interest in expanding into uninhabitable planets before now. But everyone knows Count Vering has allied himself with you, and is planning to tie his industrial fortune to your lands and the crown. Having a legitimate business interest will make this more believable.â€

Braunschweig thought for a second, then stood, nearly knocking Ansbach with his chair as he pushed it back from his desk. â€œLetâ€™s go immediately, then, if there is as little time to waste as you say.â€

â€œNow? To see the Kaiser?â€

â€œHe has lunch with Marquise Benemunde every day at twelve exactly, and then he strolls the garden when heâ€™s feeling well. Heâ€™s usually even in a generous mood, since he has a fondness for the flowers.â€ Braunschweigâ€™s smile was grim. â€œBothering him then is not something I like to do often, but is occasionally justified. It would be difficult for him to refuse to see me without very good reason.â€

â€œUrgency might show your handâ€”â€

â€œMaking a formal petition would give things away even more, wouldnâ€™t it?â€

Grudgingly, Yang had to admit that Braunschweig might be right. â€œYes, sir.â€

â€œYou can come. The Kaiser likes you.â€

â€œButâ€”â€

But Braunschweig was already heading out of the room.

â€œHeh,â€ Ansbach said once he had gone. â€œI look forward to him realizing that the Kaiser has no desire to save you any longer.â€

Yang frowned and followed after Braunschweigâ€™s retreating footsteps.

One very uncomfortable carâ€” and then horse and carriageâ€” ride later, during which Yang mentally rehearsed a thousand different questions he could be called on to answer by the Kaiser or by Duke Braunschweig, they arrived at the wide and imposing entrance to Neue Sanssouci. Although Yang had been here many times, having Ansbach at his side brought back his most unpleasant memories of the place. He kept wiping his sweaty palms on his pant legs, but this didnâ€™t help him any.

Braunschweig strode in like he owned the palace, and the way he looked around made Yang suspect he was dreaming of a future when he did. The staff were all very deferential towards him, but despite their bowing and murmurs of assent, they seemed to be giving Braunschweig the runaround when he asked where the Kaiser was and if he might be able to speak with him. Yang watched one of them run off down the hallway after this first request, and he saw Ansbach notice it too, though Braunschweig was oblivious. He and Ansbach made eye contact, each of them realizing that something was afoot (and realizing that the other realized) then looked away, neither saying a word to Braunschweig. They were led deeper into the palace, and not towards the gardens where the Kaiser was supposed to be having his daily constitutional.

At length, they were let into a small audience room. Servants waited at the door. Yang and Ansbach eyed them, but again said nothing. Braunschweig, who had been given a cup of tea and a plate of cookies to pacify him while he waited, sat on one of the plush velvet couches and tapped his foot.Â 

When the door opened, he stood to bow, thinking it was Kaiser Friedrich, but instead it was the wrinkled visage of Minister of State Lichtenlade. Braunschweig aborted his bow immediately, straightening and frowning. Lichtenlade bowed instead.

â€œGood afternoon, Duke Braunschweig,â€ Lichtenlade said.

â€œI was told that I was going to speak with the Kaiser,â€ Braunschweig replied, wrinkling his lip. Lichtenlade was unperturbed by his tone.

â€œHis Majesty is indisposed,â€ Lichtenlade said. â€œHe was feeling quite ill after his lunch.â€

Braunschweigâ€™s frown deepened, but he sat back down on the couch. Lichtenlade took the seat across from him. Yang and Ansbach did their best to blend into the scenery, like the servants in the back of the room, though Lichtenladeâ€™s nose twitched in displeasure when he looked at Yang.

â€œIâ€™m very sorry to hear that His Majesty is ill. Nothing serious, I hope?â€

â€œNothing that a rest will not cure,â€ Lichtenlade said. â€œIf there was something that you needed, Iâ€™m sure that either I can assist you, or I can pass your request to His Majesty, as appropriate.â€

â€œAnd am I not allowed to see my father-in-law as simply a friendly visit?â€

â€œIf this were a social visit, Princess Amarie would be accompanying you,â€ Lichtenlade said. â€œBut what is it that I can help you with?â€

Braunschweig stared at Lichtenlade for a moment, who kept his obsequious expression on his face. â€œA charter for an inhospitable little piece of land that nobody else would ever be willing to pay good money to the crown for,â€ Braunschweig finally said. â€œCount Vering is breathing down my neck about a joint business venture, now that he thinks he has my fleet at his disposal.â€Â Â 

Braunschweig may not have been a good actor, but he was already annoyed at being faced with Lichtenlade rather than the Kaiser, so that covered up most of the falseness in his tone, though it did nothing to hide the fact that he was talking in a completely abnormal casual register.

â€œThis is a matter for the colonial affairs office, then,â€ Lichtenlade said, not seeming to notice. â€œIf you have a petition to make, make it through the proper channels.â€

â€œInhospitable, I said. It wouldnâ€™t be a colony.â€

â€œAll land grants are handled through that office, as Iâ€™m sure Count Vering has told you, since he is quite familiar with the land grant process. You would have been wise to listen to him.â€

Braunschweig seethed. â€œI would like to speak with His Majesty.â€

â€œHis Majesty is not available, and furthermore, would not wish to grant special privileges to one citizen above another.â€

â€œSpecial privileges?â€ Braunschweig asked.

â€œIf I can assist you in any way within my legal power, please allow me to do so,â€ Lichtenlade said, inclining his head. â€œI would be happy to pass along your request to the Colonial Affairs office if you provide me the details, and this all can be worked through the proper channels.â€

â€œLeigh,â€ Braunschweig said, and waved his hand. â€œWhatâ€™s the name of the place again?â€

â€œSir. Duke Braunschweig wishes to form a mining partnership with Count Vering on planet 25571-3, just outside the Iserlohn corridor. Recent surveys of the space in that area have confirmed a navigable route, and a planet rich in tungsten, though ill suited for permanent habitation.â€

â€œOutside the corridor? Past Iserlohn, you mean?â€

â€œAs I said, no one else would pay for this patch of dirt,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œIâ€™m the only one who could station a force there to protect it, if the rebels came knocking.â€ He paused, then added, â€œAnd I wanted to start this venture quietly , keep it away from the papers that report on colonial affairs, so that the rebels donâ€™t appear as soon as Count Veringâ€™s earthmoving machines broke ground.â€

â€œYouâ€™re not the only one who could station a force there,â€ Lichtenlade said. â€œI see there are several reasons why you would be hesitant to take things through the proper channels.â€

Braunschweigâ€™s scowl deepened. â€œHe wonâ€™t want it.â€ He , in this case, was Marquis Littenheim, the father of the other primary contender for the throne.

â€œThat remains to be seen.â€ Lichtenlade tilted his head. â€œI hope, for the sake of your business partnership with Count Vering, that he does not, because should there be a competition between you and Marquis Littenheim over the patch of dirt, as you say, His Majesty will not favor one of you over the other.â€

Braunschweig stood, which made Lichtenlade rise as well. â€œIf Littenheim wishes to compete with me, there are plenty of other planets in the corridor. He is welcome to make his own surveys and choose one that suits him. Or, if he has a problem with my business, he may address it with me.â€

â€œI see,â€ Lichtenlade said. â€œAnd shall I forward this request to the Colonial Affairs office on your behalf?â€

Braunschweigâ€™s lips pinched. â€œTry to exercise discretion when you do. I donâ€™t want it all over the papers.â€

â€œOf course.â€ Lichtenlade gave a half bow. â€œAnd I will give your regards to His Majesty. Iâ€™m sure he regrets missing the opportunity to speak with you.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure.â€

â€œUntil some more amenable time,â€ Lichtenlade said, then bowed again and headed out. As soon as he left, one of the servants standing by the door also swiftly departed, though the other remained, to watch Braunschweig huff and scowl, until they were shown out.

Their way out of Neue Sanssouci was delayed by Duke Bruanschweig meeting one of his extended relations in the hallway, and they stood in a dappled pool of sunlight coming in through the window to chat. Yang wandered a little way down the hall, not caring about Braunschweigâ€™s family matters in the least, though Ansbach stayed at Bruanschweigâ€™s shoulder, ready to take notes on any tasks that this meeting might cause Ansbach to be required to perform. Yang leaned on the windowsill, looking out over the great front courtyard of the palace.

A horse and carriage was approaching at top speed, and it stopped in front of the main steps with a clatter of hooves and wheels on the stones. Yang watched as Marquis Littenheim emerged from the carriage, straightened his vest, and then began walking up the stairs.

â€œAnsbach,â€ Yang said.

Deeply annoyed, Ansbach came over to see what Yang was looking at. Braunschweig gave him a weird look as he came over, but swiftly returned to talking to his relative. Yang gave a nod out the window, and Ansbach registered how quickly Littenheim was jogging up the steps, flanked by his own assistant.

â€œI think weâ€™ve been caught,â€ Yang murmured. â€œCan you go intercept that before he reaches anyone importantâ€” Colonial Affairs, Lichtenlade, the Kaiser?â€

â€œYouâ€™re not in any position to give me orders,â€ Ansbach hissed.

Yang just rolled his eyes. â€œOr I will.â€ He made to start walking down the hallway, but Ansbach thought the better of it and grabbed his arm to stop him.

â€œGet the duke to the main entrance. Iâ€™ll hold him there.â€

â€œRight.â€

Ansbach took off down the hall at an unseemly sprint, though when he reached the intersection he skidded to a halt and looked down the next hall to make sure no one important was in his way before he started running again.

Yang wandered back over to Braunschweig and stood at his elbow, which he ignored. The conversation with the grey-haired relative had turned into a screed about how annoyed Braunshweig was at one of the managers of his planetary estates, and the relative was nodding along sympathetically.

His phone buzzed in his pocket, and Yang pulled it out to look.

Â 

Ansbach: hurry

Â 

â€œSir,â€ Yang said, finally trying to get a word in edgewise, â€œCaptain Ansbach says youâ€™re needed in the main entrance right away.â€

â€œAnsbach?â€ Braunschweig asked, and then seemed to process that Ansbach had indeed disappeared. He frowned. â€œWhat does he need me for?â€

â€œAbout our visit hereâ€”â€

Braunschweig finally caught on to the urgency. He clapped his relative on the shoulder. â€œIâ€™m sorry, Pieter, I must run. If your son wants the position, tell him to call me. Weâ€™ll see what we can arrange.â€

â€œThank you,â€ the man said. â€œI appreciate itâ€”â€

But Braunschweig was already taking long legged strides down the hallway, with Yang jogging at his heels.

They didnâ€™t make it to the entrance, because Littenheim had escaped Ansbachâ€™s delay tactic, whatever it had been. They met him as he was walking purposefully and alone down the hall. Littenheim, who was slick where Braunschweig was stocky, gave a menacing smile as he saw them.

â€œYou may have sent your dog to yap at my heels,â€ he called, â€œbut you canâ€™t stop me from speaking with my father-in-law.â€

â€œWhat do you want, Littenheim?â€ Braunschweig asked, stepping in front of him to block his passage. Yang, already nervous that this would come to blows, crept towards the edge of the hallway. Both nobles ignored him completely. He could see Ansbach in the distance, approaching at a more sedate pace.

â€œIâ€™m afraid I want the same thing you do, Otho,â€ Littenheim said. He fished around in his pocket and pulled out a folded piece of paper. â€œA charter to build a mine and small colony on planetâ€¦ 25571-3, in the Iserlohn corridor.â€

â€œYou bastardâ€”â€ Braunschweig said, and took a menacing half step forward. Littenheim dipped away.

â€œThe walls have ears, Otho! If you had gone directly to Colonial Affairs with business as usual instead of running so urgently to His Majesty, we could have avoided all of this trouble.â€ His smile stayed plastered on his face, and this only made Braunschweig step even further towards Littenheim, reaching out for his cravat, snagging his fingers on the silk, though again Littenheim stepped back. He smoothed his necktie back down from Braunschweig ruffling it out of place.

â€œWhat do you want it for?â€ Braunschweig asked.

â€œI have my own business interests,â€ Littenheim said, rushing the words breathlessly. â€œI need to protect my investments. This sometimes requires me dealing with the competition.â€

â€œLike you dealt with the Schaffhausen family.â€

Littenheim smiled, predatory. â€œWould you like to resolve our dispute that way?â€

â€œThe Kaiser isnâ€™t going to give you that charter,â€ Braunschweig said.

â€œOh, you say that. You donâ€™t know. He may favor me.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t have any idea what youâ€™re doing here. Youâ€™re in over your head.â€

â€œIs that a threat, Otho?â€

â€œIf you try to go to the Kaiser with this request, yes.â€

Littenheim laughed. â€œIâ€™m sure youâ€™re rightâ€” His Majesty wonâ€™t favor me over you. Heâ€™s been very careful not to. But that just means I have to put in my claim as well so that there isnâ€™t an appearance of favoritism. So, I will. And weâ€™ll settle this between ourselves like gentlemen.â€

â€œYouâ€™re eager to start a fight with me. Youâ€™ll lose.â€

This time, it was Littenheim who stepped forward and clapped Braunschweig on the shoulder, brushing past him. â€œI wouldnâ€™t be so sure of that, if I were you. When you and I duel, and I win, I think that will make everyone reconsider just how much the odds really favor you.â€

Braunschweig tried to grab him again, but Littenheim was swiftly walking down the corridor, and Braunschweig didnâ€™t chase him as he left armâ€™s reach. â€œYou issued the challenge, so I get to choose the time and place.â€

â€œOf course,â€ Littenheim called over his shoulder. â€œMake it sometime convenient, will you? And a big arena. Iâ€™m sure the attendance will be excellent.â€ And then he was gone, chuckling to himself as he went.

Braunschweig scowled, and Ansbach finally made it the rest of the way down the hallway. â€œI will write a formal challenge, sir,â€ Ansbach said. â€œAnd contact your hired duelist.â€Â 

Â 

Â 

The duel, though it was not announced in any of the papers what it was about, was the talk of the capital for the week or so leading up to it. The sums being bet were astronomical, according to Magdalena, who was listening in to all the gossip.

â€œYouâ€™re going to it, right?â€ she asked on Thursday night, voice crackling over the phone. She was drivingâ€” he could tell because the wind blasting through her open-top convertible made her hard to hear, despite her practically yelling into the phone. It was quite late, so he wondered where she was going to or from. Probably some party. It didnâ€™t matterâ€” he was happy to talk to her on her drive. He was in bed, his phone on the pillow beside him, staring up into the dark ceiling of his bedroom.

â€œI have to go,â€ he said. â€œAnsbach said that all of Braunschweigâ€™s officers in the capital are required to attend. Itâ€™s supposed to be a show of strength, but Iâ€™d think he wouldnâ€™t want meâ€¦â€ He trailed off.

â€œGreat,â€ Maggie said. â€œIâ€™ll see you there, then.â€

â€œYouâ€™re coming?â€ Yang asked. â€œWhy would you want to?â€

â€œAm I not allowed to love bloodsport as much as the next man?â€

â€œNobodyâ€™s going to get really hurt. These are professional duelists,â€ Yang said.

â€œItâ€™s the social event of the summer. The year, even. Everyone really is looking at it as a forecast of who will claim the throne.â€

â€œDonâ€™t be superstitious.â€

â€œI canâ€™t help it, darling.â€ She laughed. â€œMen are coming to revel in superstition and gossip, and women are coming to gape at bloodshed. The fainting in the stands will be spectacular.â€

â€œYou canâ€™t see it, but Iâ€™m rolling my eyes right now.â€

â€œBesides,â€ Maggie said, â€œitâ€™s an excuse to see you.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t need an excuse for that.â€

She just laughed at him. â€œI should have said, â€˜an excuse to drag you out to dinner after.â€™â€
