â€œYes,â€ Yang said. â€œIt would be easier from the inside, but I thinkâ€” thereâ€™s no such thing as an unsinkable ship.â€

â€œIt would be easier from the inside,â€ Reuenthal intoned. â€œHow fortunate that I am posted here.â€

Yang shook his head. â€œNo guarantees youâ€™ll stay here by the time the Kaiser dies. Better to plan ahead.â€Â 

He finished his drink and looked sadly down into the empty cup. Reuenthal reached for the bottle and leaned heavily across the coffee table to pour him some more without even asking. Reuenthal steadied Yangâ€™s hand with his own when Yang held out the glass, which made Yangâ€™s stomach flip with something other than alcohol.

Yang was going to have a terrible headache in the morning, but for now he felt pretty good. He probably wasnâ€™t doing the best job at explaining the finer points of his strategy, but the relief of simply talking about it with them was enough that it didnâ€™t matter. Plans were sure to change between then and now, anyway.

â€œAnyway, thatâ€™s why I was on Cahokiaâ€¦ Learned about that place from my spy on Phezzan.â€ He yawned.

â€œYou have a spy on Phezzan?â€ Mittermeyer asked. â€œYou have been busy.â€ He laughed. â€œI guess I shouldnâ€™t have thought that you needed my help for anything.â€

â€œI do,â€ Yang said, drunk and very earnest.

Mittermeyer smiled, pleased. During Yangâ€™s explanations, he had scooted even closer to Reuenthal on the couch. Their sides were pressed together, and his hand had moved from Reuenthalâ€™s back to his side, drifting in lazy arcs up and down between his ribs and his hips.Â 

â€œWhoâ€™s your spy?â€ Reuenthal asked. â€œHowâ€™d you find him? What makes you trust him?â€

â€œHeâ€™s a former student of mineâ€¦â€ By the time that Yang had finished his, admittedly rather garbled, explanation of his correspondence with Muller, he had finished his drink. â€œYou havenâ€™t told us what you want to happen at all,â€ Reuenthal pointed out. â€œThis has been a lecture from Braunschweigâ€™s most loyal supporter, completely dedicated to helping him put his daughter on the throne.â€ He tossed his head. â€œI could have gotten as much from Ansbach.â€

Yang frowned. â€œNo, Iâ€”â€

Reuenthal smiled. It was a predatory smile, like he had cornered Yang. â€œThen tell me, Wen-li. Who do you want to put on the throne?â€ His voice was low and rich. He, too, had finished his last drink, and was still fiddling with the palm fronds. He had ripped off so many of them that the nearest branch of the palm was nearly stripped bare. When one of his leaves brushed Mittermeyerâ€™s fingers crawling across his side, Mittermeyer would strain his fingertips towards it, but Reuenthal would pull it out of the way a moment later. â€œElizabeth can have the throne,â€ Yang said. He couldnâ€™t look away from Reuenthalâ€™s hands, fixated on the motion of him weaving the strands into and out of each other. â€œOh? Is that a good thing?â€

â€œBraunschweig has fought so hard for power, heâ€™d never willingly give any of it up.â€ Yang closed his eyes. â€œI thinkâ€” Elizabeth could open a parliament. Especially if the nobles who backed her father during the war demand it of the crown. A house of lords could lead somewhere elseâ€¦â€ He trailed off into mumbles, and cracked his eyes back open when he was met with only silence.

â€œItâ€™s a funny dream,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œBut it wonâ€™t come true.â€

â€œIt wonâ€™t?â€ Yang asked. â€œI think thereâ€™s a chanceâ€”â€

â€œYou say Braunschweig would never give up his power. I agree. She would have everything to lose and nothing to gain.â€Â 

â€œThere would be something to gain,â€ Yang said.

â€œOh?â€

â€œIt would beâ€”â€ He got the sensation that no argument about ethics would satisfy Reuenthal, and Yang couldnâ€™t blame him. The Goldenbaum dynasty had never once cared about morality in its rule, and the only standard Reuenthal had to judge Elizabeth by was the precedent her forefathers had set. â€œIt would be the only way for her to save the dynasty,â€ Yang said. â€œIt canâ€™t continue on as it has. Someone will decide the throne canâ€™t remain as it is. If sheâ€™s assassinated before she has an heirâ€¦â€

â€œAnd who will that someone be?â€ Reuenthal asked.

â€œI donâ€™t know. Someone.â€

â€œAnd if she refuses to listen to your humble words of advice?â€ Reuenthal asked.

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Yang said again.

Reuenthal was cruel, picking at him when he was this drunk. But perhaps that was the point: sober, Yang might have been able to steer the conversation away from this dangerous ground.Â 

â€œIt seems to me,â€ Reuenthal said, â€œthat there will come a point when you cannot stand idly by and allow the Goldenbaum dynasty to run its course.â€

â€œEl Facil,â€ Mittermeyer said. He had been quiet, leaning on Reuenthalâ€™s side, but he had been listening. He looked at Yang and sighed. â€œYouâ€™d throw all your influence away the first time she did something you couldnâ€™t watch happen. Throw yourself on the sacrificial altar.â€

â€œNo,â€ Reuenthal and Yang said at the same time, though with very different tones. Yang was protesting something that he knew was true. Reuenthal was almost cajoling, playing off Mittermeyerâ€™s words.

â€œIâ€”â€ Yang said, then looked at Reuenthal, to let him finish his thought.

â€œNo,â€ Reuenthal said again. He looked down at his hands, at the palm fronds he had been weaving. He had fastened the ends together, making a circle. He pulled himself out of Mittermeyerâ€™s arm and stood, bearing his circle of palm. He walked behind Yang on the armchair and put his hands on Yangâ€™s shoulders, keeping him still. â€œYouâ€™re a man with the wrong kind of ambition for that, Wen-li.â€

Yang was frozen, like a deer in the lights of an oncoming train. Reuenthalâ€™s hands brushed his hair back from his face and put the crown of leaves on his head.

â€œWhat do you think, Wolf?â€ Reuenthal asked.

Mittermeyerâ€™s expression was impossibly strange. Looking at him alone on the couch, Yang wondered if this was what he had looked like, watching him and Reuenthal close together during the evening. Reuenthalâ€™s hands were still in Yangâ€™s hair. Mittermeyer opened his mouth to say something, but no sound came out except for a strangled, â€œIâ€”â€

This broke the spell that Reuenthalâ€™s touch had on Yang, and he took pity on Mittermeyer. He shook his head, dislodging Reuenthalâ€™s hands.Â 

â€œI have to pee,â€ he said, and stood. As he turned towards the bathroom, he very pointedly put his hand on Reuenthalâ€™s back and pushed him gently back to the couch and Mittermeyer. â€œSit."

Reuenthal chuckled. â€œAs you wish,â€ he said.

That didnâ€™t make Yang feel any less confused, but he stumbled off toward the head, which happened to be through Reuenthalâ€™s bedroom. His eyes fell again on the sword above the bed as he passed it, and he flinched away and hurried, shutting the door behind him too hard.

He stared at himself in the mirror, gripping the sides of the porcelain sink to keep himself from falling over. The crown of palm fronds was still on his head, his cheeks were flushed, and his forehead was shiny with sweat. Yang touched the crown with his fingertips, accidentally setting it askew; he was always clumsy where Reuenthal was graceful.Â 

Yang couldnâ€™t keep a single thought moving coherently through his head. It was only partly the alcohol. Everything elseâ€” everything Reuenthal did and saidâ€” was more overwhelming. The only conclusion that he could come to was that it was probably time for him to leave for the night, before someone did something that they would regret, which seemed more and more likely to happen, if Yang let Reuenthal keep talking about ambition, or anything else. That subject was dangerous, but this drunk and with the mood in the room this strange, there were no safe subjects left whatsoever.

He splashed cold water on his face and tried to breathe deeply, steeling himself to leave. He felt melancholy about it, but that was a familiar feeling, one that he could understand. And that was better than whatever the crown on his head made him feel, or Mittermeyerâ€™s flushed face, or Reuenthalâ€™s hands on his temples.

It took him a long minute to stabilize himself physically before he left the bathroom. In the bedroom, he took the circlet of leaves off and dropped it on the bed beneath the sword, looking at it in the dim light for a moment.Â 

When Yang left the bedroom, he saw immediately that his assessment that it was time for him to leave was correct: while he had been in the bathroom, Mittermeyer had divested Reuenthal of his shirt completely, and they were engaged in a passionate kiss on the couch, limbs tangled together such that it was hard to tell where one of them began and the other ended.

Yang watched them for a second, standing in the doorway, feeling warm and bittersweet in the particular way that drunkenness facilitated. After a moment in which neither seemed to notice his presence, he shuffled back towards the door of Reuenthalâ€™s suites to go.

â€œWhere are you going?â€™ Reuenthal asked before Yang had even made it ten steps to the door.

Yang turned back towards him. He had hoisted himself up on his elbows, and Mittermeyer was sitting back, looking at Yang as well.

â€œI should goâ€”â€

â€œNo,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œStay.â€

Yang was frozen. There was a bubbling elation in his chest, one that clarified what he had been feeling all evening. The strangeness of the talk had only been a distraction, a cover. But that was how it had always been, hadnâ€™t it? And now, something he hadnâ€™t even dared to hope for, that he had forbidden himself from thinking about, was being handed to him, without any effort whatsoever. Reuenthal had torn back the veil.Â 

It didnâ€™t feel real. He looked at Mittermeyer, trying to make sure he wasnâ€™t mistaken, or dreaming, or misinterpreting because he was too drunk.

Mittermeyer had never been good at keeping his feelings from his face. His mouth was open in surprise, and his cheeks were already flushed, eyes wide. There was just a moment of the old hesitation, but when Mittermeyerâ€™s eyes met Yangâ€™s, it was like a switch flipped, and the crease in his brow melted awayâ€” the same thing clarifying for him, maybe. Wordlessly, he smiled and held out his hand towards Yang.

Chapter End Notes

fyi, there's an extra scene that takes place at the end of this chapter... lol

This Action Will Have Consequences

well, some of you have been waiting for this for um. 700k words. so here it is lol. treason threesome treason threesome treason threesome

mea culpa on the fade to black. i'm working so hard to keep this series rating low so that as many people can read it as possible lol. anyway the threesome is an exercise for the reader's imagination lol. you're welcome to write it yourself. maybe someday after i finish this series i'll go back and just write all of the sex scenes that i have omitted ğŸ˜…

anyway this is essentially the pivot point upon which the second half of the story rests. so yay for making it to the halfway point? this feels ridiculous to say lol.

please let me know what you think :3c i love to hear from you all

thank you very very very much to em for the beta read. telling me to fix this half of the chapter was a good decision haha.

Respect for the Sklavenmoral

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

August 487 I.C., Iserlohn Fortress

All of Duke Braunschweigâ€™s staff on Iserlohn had a few days of waiting before they were to be picked up and shipped back to Odin. Without any assigned duties, this left Kircheis with a lot of time on his hands. Since he had never been on Iserlohn before, he decided to make the most of his time there and do some sightseeing in the fortress. Of course, not being part of the fortressâ€™s staff meant that most of the operational areas were firmly off limits, but he could still visit the main concourse, and the gardens. He went to the gardens first, thinking that a pleasant stroll through them would do him good, but despite the medical attention he had received aboard Rear Admiral Mittermeyerâ€™s flagship, his ribs were still tender in a way that made breathing difficult. He made one long circuit of the space, though, considering how winding the paths were, this barely encompassed seeing any of it, and was too fatigued for it to be pleasurable to continue.Â 

Iserlohn had a library, and this was where Kircheis went in search of a quiet place to spend his time. He wondered if Captain Leigh would show up there, since it seemed like his type of milieu, but there was no sign of him whatsoever. Not like Kircheis needed him for anything, but wandering through the bustling fortress without knowing anyone there was a particularly lonely feeling, and Kircheis wouldnâ€™t have minded Captain Leighâ€™s quiet company in the least, even if they were just sitting across from each other and reading.

The library conformed to the most austere of the Imperial design philosophies: a cavernously high ceiling, wide tables of dark wood with individual reading lamps placed down their length, ornate molding of the walls, and columns that disguised the utilitarian metal structure of Iserlohn beneath. Although it seemed that in such a space that sounds would travel, especially given how oppressively quiet the place felt, the designers had included some trick in the ventilation to suppress noise. The library itself seemed to breathe, and this constant low rush of air swallowed the sound of Kircheisâ€™s footsteps and any hushed voices.

He didnâ€™t sit down at the long reading tables, but instead found a corner in the back with smaller seating areas, well out of the way of most of the foot traffic. It would have been a perfect little spot if there had been a window to look out of, but instead it was simply dark and quiet. The library had a huge section of books on strategy, and Kircheis pulled one from the shelf that Captain Leigh had offhandedly mentioned once. He intended to read it, and he had the book open on his table in front of him, but his eyes kept glazing over and circling the same lines in the introductory chapter over and over. His thoughts were troubled but indistinct, flitting between subjects too quickly for him to focus in on one thing and come to any resolution about it.

After a half hour, during which he had made it about ten pages into his book, a shadow fell between him and the nearest light source. Kircheis looked up, and saw an unfamiliar man standing in front of him. He was wearing a captainâ€™s uniform, and he had a dour face, hair streaked prematurely grey.

â€œSub-lieutenant Kircheis?â€ the captain asked.

Kircheis stood and saluted. â€œYes, sir,â€ Kircheis said. â€œDo you need me for something, sir?â€

â€œAt ease. May I sit?â€

â€œOf course, sir,â€ Kircheis said. He was already confused and on guard, but couldnâ€™t say no.

The captain took the seat across from Kircheis, and waited for Kircheis to sit down before he said anything else.Â 

â€œYou have an excellent commander, Sub-lieutenant,â€ the captain said. His voice was flat and nasally, and despite the fact that he had his back to the light, his eyes glittered in an unnatural way.

If this compliment to Captain Leigh was intended to put Kircheis at ease, it did not work. â€œYes, sir,â€ Kircheis said, and nothing more than that.

â€œIt seems that he did not mention me to you. I am Captain Paul von Oberstein. Captain Leigh isâ€¦ a friend of mine.â€

The name was familiar. â€œYouâ€™re the one who saved the Iserlohn fleet,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œCaptain Leigh is the one who saved the Iserlohn fleet,â€ Oberstein said. â€œI was only the one who put his advice into action.â€

â€œHe wouldnâ€™t describe it like that,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œNo,â€ Oberstein agreed. â€œBut that does not stop it from being true.â€

â€œDid Captain Leigh send you here to talk to me?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œNo. He speaks highly of you, so it seemed prudent for me to make your acquaintance while I had the opportunity.â€

Kircheis was grateful for the dim light in the library for hiding any flush that rose to his ears. Still, he kept his voice even. â€œIâ€™m pleased to meet anyone Captain Leigh considers a friend.â€

â€œIndeed, Sub-lieutenant.â€ Oberstein studied him for an uncomfortable second. â€œAs am I.â€

There was an awkward moment of silence as Kircheis struggled to find something to say. â€œAre you permanently stationed on Iserlohn, sir?â€

â€œFor now, yes. I imagine that might change in the future.â€

â€œWhy is that, sir?â€

Oberstein gave him a look. â€œFleet Admiral Muckenburger has been known to have a personal hand in some staff assignments, when it suits him. It may be that an officer with volatility on his record will not be well suited to a post on Iserlohn in the coming years.â€

Kircheis could read between the lines of that statement well enough: Oberstein knew about Leighâ€™s plans for Iserlohn. It at least proved that Leigh did trust Oberstein, but Kircheis wasnâ€™t sure that made him any more comfortable with the man. It would have been different if Captain Leigh was here, but he wasnâ€™t.

â€œI see.â€ He opened his mouth, then decided not to ask the question on the tip of his tongue.

â€œNo one can hear us here, Sub-lieutenant,â€ Oberstein said. â€œSay what you like.â€

This reassurance was not reassuring in the least, but their conversation probably would be nearly incomprehensible to anyone who didnâ€™t already know what they were talking about, so Kircheis acquiesced. â€œWould the fleet admiral be right to reassign you?â€

â€œYes,â€ Oberstein said. In a peculiar movement, Oberstein reached up to his face, then dug his fingers into his right eye. Kircheis flinched, then watched in fascinated horror as Obersteinâ€™s eyeball came out into his pinched fingers. It was clear now that it was mechanical, and Oberstein was not in any distress, but that didnâ€™t make the empty, dark hole in his face any less disturbing to look at. Oberstein pulled a handkerchief from his pocket and wiped the mechanical eyeball dispassionately.

â€œDid that happen when youâ€”â€ Kircheis asked, unable to stifle his curiosity. He was sure that Oberstein was doing this to invite a question, but it still felt uncomfortable to comment on.

â€œNo,â€ Oberstein said. â€œI was born blind.â€ He examined the eye in his hand, and the iris flashed momentarily red. â€œI apologize. This unit is beginning to fail.â€

â€œItâ€™s fine,â€ Kircheis said. â€œDo you need help?â€

â€œNo.â€ Obersteinâ€™s fingers were unusually narrow and delicate, and they deftly moved around the eyeball, surely touching and checking things that were too small for Kircheis to see in the muted library light. After a moment, he replaced the eyeball in his face. Kircheis relaxed some of the tension that he had been holding in his back, though now when Oberstein looked at him, he had the sense that the captain could see directly through him. This feeling was not reduced any by what Oberstein said next. â€œUnlike Captain Leigh, I am fortunate to be able to hide the qualities that many in the Empire would despise me for, most of the time.â€

There was no way that Oberstein knew about Martin. Captain Leigh didnâ€™t even know about Martin, not really, and he certainly wouldnâ€™t have said anything even if he did. Yet Kircheis somehow felt that Oberstein had seen directly to his center, coldly. Kircheis kept that thrum of fear out of his voice. â€œYes, sir,â€ he said.

â€œBut it can be to Captain Leighâ€™s benefit as a leader. It encouragesâ€¦ a kind of loyalty.â€ Oberstein broke his piercing gaze. â€œAnd he is a man who can put that loyalty to good use, if he is given the opportunity.â€

Kircheis remained silent. He didnâ€™t think there was anything to say to Oberstein that wasnâ€™t incriminating, on some level. And the frankness with which he spoke, although Kircheis understood it, alarmed him.Â 

â€œYou understand, Sub-lieutenant,â€ Oberstein said. â€œCaptain Leigh considers you a friend, and not simply someone who works under him by obligation. I am sure that this means you have no small measure of personal loyalty towards him.â€

Oberstein was waiting for him to respond. Slowly, Kircheis nodded. â€œAs you said, he is an excellent commander.â€

Oberstein didnâ€™t smile, and there was no change in the flat stare of his eyes, but the slight motion of his head indicated that Kircheis had said something that he wanted to hear. â€œHe is an excellent commander, if he is in a position to command. He has far more enemies than he has friends.â€

â€œWhat are you saying, sir?â€

â€œI think you understand well, Sub-lieutenant.â€ Oberstein steepled his thin fingers on the table before him. â€œIf you are loyal to him, you have a responsibility that goes beyond the chain of command.â€

â€œLike you and the Iserlohn fleet, sir?â€ Kircheis asked. He knew he was on dangerous ground.

â€œMoreso,â€ Oberstein said. â€œIf Captain Leigh dies, there will not be another man this generation who is capable of accomplishing what needs to be done. He is the only one with the talent, in the right position, who understands the true nature of the Empire.â€

â€œYouâ€™re asking me to protect him with my life, sir?â€ Did Oberstein think he wasnâ€™t already doing that? Captain Leigh must have given him the wrong impression.

Oberstein stared at Kircheis in silence for a long moment. â€œWith more than that, should it become necessary.â€

â€œMore than my life?â€

â€œThere are things greater than that,â€ Oberstein said. â€œHe would not ask them of you, so I must. Anything that it takes for him to succeed, you must do.â€

Kircheis tried to keep his face expressionless. â€œIt seems like youâ€™re asking me to disobey his orders, if I think itâ€™s for the greater good.â€

â€œYes,â€ Oberstein said.

â€œAnd obey yours, sir?â€

Oberstein stared at him. â€œNo,â€ Oberstein said. â€œI am not the type of man who would inspire that loyalty in anyone, and I do not expect it of you.â€

â€œThen what are you asking of me?â€

â€œI understand that you value Captain Leighâ€™s friendship highly. If there should be a time when you need to disobey his orders, to sacrifice your friendship, to save his life, I expect that you will.â€

â€œAnd what kind of time would require that?â€

Obersteinâ€™s gaze was piercing. â€œYou know about El Facil.â€

Kircheis tried to keep his expression neutral. â€œYes.â€

â€œHe must not be allowed to sacrifice himself, no matter what the cost isâ€” to you, or to anyone else. His value is far too great.â€

â€œI see,â€ Kircheis said. â€œHe wouldnâ€™t see it that way.â€

â€œI know. But you must, for his sake.â€ He paused. â€œIf you would take a bullet for him, or swallow poison meant for him, taking other burdens up for him is also your duty.â€

â€œWhat would you have done, if you were at El Facil?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œAt the time, I did not realize his value,â€ Oberstein said.

â€œIf something like El Facil were to happen again tomorrow.â€

â€œIf I must, I would do the same thing I did at Iserlohn,â€ Oberstein said. â€œIn some ways, the greatest danger to Leigh is himself.â€

â€œCaptain Leigh would not stand down from a gun pointed at his head, if there were people at stake like there were at El Facil.â€

â€œThen I would find some other way, Sub-lieutenant.â€

â€œDoes Captain Leigh understand this about you?â€

â€œYes. And he understands that I can be of use to him.â€

â€œDoes he understand that you are going to tell his friends to make him abandon his morals?â€

â€œIâ€™m not asking him to abandon anything,â€ Oberstein said. â€œIf the time comes, I do not know if he has the strength to do so. I hope that he understands what will be required of him, but I am not a man to put my trust in hope, and so I am preparing for other eventualities.â€

â€œDo you expect me to tell you Iâ€™ll do something one way or the other, sir?â€

Oberstein stood. â€œNo, Sub-lieutenant. But you will think about it, which is all I need from you today.â€ He nodded at Kircheis. â€œGoodday.â€

Kircheis watched him go, without saying another word.

Kircheis didnâ€™t see much of Captain Leigh during their short stay on Iserlohn. He caught one or two glimpses of him in bars or strolling the main concourse, often walking next to Rear Admirals Reuenthal or Mittermeyer, or Captain Oberstein, who stood out now that Kircheis knew who he was. It didnâ€™t seem like Leigh was avoiding him, and if Kircheis had sent him a message asking to meet, he certainly would haveâ€” when they passed each other on the concourse, Leigh gave a funny smile and waveâ€” but Kircheis decided not to disturb him.

They ended up on a transport ship provided by Braunschweig to return them to Odin a few days later, and on that long journey he did see plenty of Leigh. He seemed to be filled with a strange new emotion, and he would alternate between smiling off into space and scowling at whatever plan he was trying to concoct in front of him. The two expressions lived on his face without much in between, aside from his usual good-natured smile when he saw Kircheis.

â€œIs everything alright, Captain Leigh?â€ Kircheis asked as he sat across from Leigh in the officersâ€™ mess, watching him type something on his computer, with two fingers dancing over the keyboard, while his other hand waved a bagel distractedly through the air. His eyebrows were furrowed, and it looked like he had forgotten that he had a bite of the bagel in his mouth.

â€œMmph?â€ Leigh asked, and then came to his senses more fully. â€œOh, yes, Kircheis, everything is fine. For now, I suppose.â€

â€œIs this thinking about what youâ€™re going to do with Captain Ansbach on Cahokia?â€

â€œOh, er, no,â€ Leigh said. â€œI just have to get Braunschweig to fortify that position. Heâ€™ll probably have Ansbach come home, honestly. Itâ€™s a waste to keep him out there.â€

â€œYou think so?â€

â€œAnsbach is a valuable member of the dukeâ€™s staff,â€ Leigh said. â€œWe might have our differences, but Iâ€™d prefer to have him on Odinâ€” or wherever the duke is. Heâ€™s a tempering influence, in a way that I am not capable of being.â€

â€œI see.â€ Kircheis was tempted to glance at Leighâ€™s computer screen, but resisted the impulse. â€œWhat are you working on, then?â€

â€œCaptain Oberstein had some suggestions for me about some of our future strategies.â€ Leigh glanced around pointedly at the other soldiers in the mess, most of whom were involved in their own meals and discussions and ignoring Leigh and Kircheis, but Kircheis got the message.

â€œI see.â€

â€œHe told me he spoke to you, by the way.â€

â€œHe did. In the library.â€

â€œWhat did you think of him? Heâ€™s a good friend of mine, but I thinkâ€” through no fault of his ownâ€” he sometimes comes off badly.â€

â€œYou trust him?â€

Leigh stared off into space, a melancholy expression on his face. â€œYes, I do. I donâ€™t think that I will always agree with him, but we have the same goals, and heâ€™s an honest and good manâ€” and my friend.â€

â€œIâ€™m glad to have spoken with him, then,â€ Kircheis said. It was a diplomatic answer, delivered in a diplomatic tone, but it made Leigh smile.

â€œGood.â€

September 487 I.C., Odin

Kircheis was very glad to return to Odin. He arrived in the middle of the day, and so when he arrived at his apartment that he shared with Martin, it was dark and empty, Martin being at school still. It was good to have a period by himself, to acclimate to the atmosphere of his home, before Martin filled the space and all of Kircheis's thoughts.Â 

The late of the Odin summer was still hanging on, and the warm sun was coming in through the open windows. There was the chittering of birds in the eaves of the roof, and the hustle of traffic on the street below. Water dripped from the kitchen sink faucet, and the refrigerator hummed tunelessly. Kircheisâ€™s chair at the kitchen table creaked as he leaned back in it, and the glass of ice water he poured for himself tasted just as mineral as ever. It all grounded him, reminded him of where he wasâ€” safe at home, shedding the skin he wore when he was out for his job.

It was difficult to let go of the tension that he carried, the outer shell, but he tried to relax before Martin returned. It didnâ€™t take long at all for Martin to get back. He had known Kircheis was coming, so he probably had left school as soon as he could, and ran back home. It warmed Kircheisâ€™s heart to hear the door banging open, and Martin seeing his shoes lined up in the entrance and yelling out, â€œSieg! Youâ€™re back?â€

â€œI am,â€ Kircheis responded, standing to hover in the kitchen doorway to watch Martin pull off his own shoes.

There was a moment when they just looked at each other, both remembering the argument that they had parted on, and then Martin smiled, and all must have been forgiven, because he took the few steps forward and fell into Kircheisâ€™s arms to kiss him.

Kircheisâ€™s bruises were all healed now, of course, but the tenderness of the touch still shocked him, and he wasnâ€™t sure what to do with his limbs. He had to let Martin guide him through it: letting Martin run his hands through his hair, letting Martin cup his cheeks with his delicate hands, letting Martin tug him through the apartment until they fell onto the couch, which creaked beneath their sudden, falling weight. If Martin noticed that Kircheis was making him take the lead, he didnâ€™t care. His enthusiasm floated Kircheis along, and was enough for both of them.

Only when Martin stilled enough to rest against Kircheisâ€™s chest was he able to move of his own volition, brushing his hand down Martinâ€™s back and very gently tucking his hair behind his ear. Martin was smiling, the unrushed, languid, familiar expression. Kircheisâ€™s face was much more serious, looking into Martinâ€™s eyes.

â€œHow have you been?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œFine,â€ Martin said. â€œIâ€™ve missed you.â€

â€œI missed you, too. Iâ€™m glad to be back early.â€

â€œI wish you wouldnâ€™t have had to leave at all.â€

Kircheis was silent for a moment, fingertips brushing Martinâ€™s hair. â€œYeah,â€ he said. â€œI wish I didnâ€™t either.â€

Martin smiled, like he had won a victory, and he rolled over so that he could wedge himself in between Kircheis and the back of the couch, half reclining on Kircheisâ€™s chest. Despite the heat in the room, the sweat making both their clothes cling to them oppressively, Martinâ€™s bodyweight was comforting against him.

â€œWhat makes you change your mind on that?â€ Martin asked.

â€œI never really wanted to go.â€

â€œYou volunteered.â€

â€œFor Captain Leighâ€™s sake,â€ Kircheis said. â€œIâ€™m glad I was there for him, butâ€¦â€

â€œHm.â€

Kircheis was silent, letting Martin nestle into his shoulder.

â€œBut it wasnâ€™t what you expected?â€ Martin asked.

It certainly hadnâ€™t been, but not for any reasons that he was willing to express to Martin. There was no need to bring up Annerose. â€œIt went pretty badly,â€ Kircheis said. â€œIâ€™m lucky to be alive.â€

â€œOh. So much for Captain Leighâ€™s plans.â€

â€œNo, it wasnâ€™t really his fault,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œIf you say so.â€

â€œHe did his best to make sure as many people made it out safely as he could. Thatâ€™s the kind of man he is.â€

â€œHeâ€™s the kind of man who works for Duke Braunschweig,â€ Martin pointed out.

â€œSo am I.â€

This brought Martin up short, but he came up with a response quickly enough. â€œI think youâ€™re different. And you were forced into it.â€

â€œSo was Leigh.â€

Martin shrugged. Although the conversation was already treading in dangerous waters, Martin was still relaxed, which made Kircheis feel like he had room to clear the air.

â€œI killed people out there,â€ Kircheis said after a minute. His voice was low, barely even audible. Martin stiffened against him, but didnâ€™t immediately leap up. Kircheis didnâ€™t know what he would have done if Martin had. Maybe the reason Martin didnâ€™t react was because he didnâ€™t know what either of them would do either. â€œI did it because I was protecting Captain Leigh, and because I might have died if I didnâ€™t. But I still made the choice. Thereâ€™s only so much you can say I was forced into.â€

â€œMost people who make excuses donâ€™t understand that,â€ Martin said. â€œWhy are you telling me this, Sieg?â€

â€œBecause if I didnâ€™t, you would wonder, wouldnâ€™t you?â€

â€œAnd thatâ€™s worse?â€

â€œI donâ€™t want to lie to you.â€

â€œIt would be easier for you if you did,â€ Martin said.

â€œI donâ€™t know why you think so.â€

Martin let out a heavy breath, and, after a second, said, â€œWas it difficultâ€” to kill, I mean?â€

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said. He closed his eyes. â€œIt wasnâ€™t.â€

â€œOh.â€

â€œWhy do you ask?â€

â€œIâ€™m in my last year of school,â€ Martin said. â€œNo more deferment after that.â€

â€œYeah.â€

â€œHow do you justify all this to yourself?â€ Martin asked. â€œI know you. You couldnâ€™t possibly enjoy it. But you do it anyway. I know I wonâ€™t. No matter what anyone tries to make me doâ€” I wonâ€™t go out there and kill for the Empire.â€

â€œYouâ€™re a better man than I am.â€

â€œNobody else would say that.â€ The flatteryâ€” though it hadnâ€™t been intended as suchâ€” soothed Martin, made his tone warm. â€œWe donâ€™t live in a time or place where people valorize anything other than death.â€

â€œI wish we did live in a different time,â€ Kircheis said. â€œMaybe someday.â€

Martinâ€™s voice took on the tone it always did when he was quoting something, though Kircheis didnâ€™t recognize it. â€œSomeone, I tell you, will remember us. Even in another time.â€

The silence filled the room as Kircheis waited for Martin to finish the poem, or whatever it was he had been quoting, but Martin didnâ€™t say anything else.

â€œCan I ask what youâ€™re planning to do, when you are called up?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œItâ€™s dangerous to ask.â€

Kircheis fell silent.

â€œI wonâ€™t go to the killing fields. Iâ€™d rather do anything else.â€

â€œAnything?â€

Martin shrugged. â€œI canâ€™t stand by and watch it happen. To me, or anybody else.â€

â€œWill you run away?â€

Martin shrugged again, but this time he looked up to the ceiling, and there was a contemplative tone in his voice. â€œI donâ€™t know. Maybe.â€

â€œWhatâ€™s the alternative?â€

â€œThere are plenty of alternatives.â€ The weird, thoughtful tone in Martinâ€™s voice put Kircheis on edge.

â€œYou wonâ€™t do anything dangerous, will you?â€

â€œIâ€™m not afraid of dying,â€ Martin said. â€œI just donâ€™t want to be made to kill.â€

â€œMartinâ€”â€

â€œMaybe we shouldnâ€™t talk about it.â€ He paused. â€œI wonâ€™t ask you for anything, Sieg.â€

That was painful, and Kircheis couldnâ€™t even tell if it was designed to cut, or if it was meant to be an olive branch.

â€œI would help you run,â€ Kircheis said. â€œOr hide. Whatever you needed.â€

â€œMaybe,â€ Martin said. â€œItâ€™s still a year away. Donâ€™t worry about it, Sieg. Iâ€™ll figure something out. And I donâ€™t want you to get in trouble.â€

Kircheis tried to push the fear away. â€œI feel like youâ€™ve changed the way youâ€™re thinking about this since I left.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think so,â€ Martin said. â€œMy morals have always been the same.â€

â€œBut you donâ€™t want to ask me for anything, now.â€

â€œI believed you, when you said you didnâ€™t want to give it.â€

Kircheis wanted to protest, to say that he had been referring to something completely different, but to Martin, they must have been one and the same. Martin was good at making him feel ashamed, even if it wasnâ€™t his explicit intention. It was the guilt of knowing that Martin was right, and that Kircheis was going to continue down his own path, far away from the clear and cold light that Martin saw so clearly.

Â 

Returning to work in Duke Braunschweigâ€™s staff offices felt odd. Although Kircheis had been through the most harrowing ordeal of his life thus far, the world of Odin and Braunscwheigâ€™s normal fleet routines had continued on without him. His desk and cubicle was just as he had left it, and his fellow junior officers and the rest of the staff of the building greeted him warmly upon his return, asking jovially how it had been on Cahokia. Kircheis responded to this with as much friendly candor as he could, but the mask was firmly back on, and he couldnâ€™t say much to any of his coworkers, aside from Leigh, who was not around. Since Ansbach had remained on Cahokia, this meant that Leigh had the unenviable responsibility of going over the current status and future plans with Duke Braunschweig himself, in his manor.

Kircheis wasnâ€™t sure when Leigh would be back, and, although Leigh had left him with a handful of clear tasks to accomplish, Kircheis kept leaning backwards in his seat and glancing out the window, hoping to see Leigh return, walking up the street with his hands in his pockets and his face up towards the sky, as was his usual way.

There was no sign of Leigh, but on one of the times that Kircheis glanced backwards out the window, he saw a familiar car pulled up outsideâ€” it was Count Mariendorfâ€™s personal vehicle, recognizable by its slightly antique make and its unusual forest green color. Kircheis had no idea why Count Mariendorf would be stopping by Duke Braunschweigâ€™s admiralty except to speak to Leigh, but Leigh wasnâ€™t around. He slipped out of his cubicle and jogged through the building to find the count, checking upstairs at Leighâ€™s office first, where Count Mariendorf was just beginning to knock on the door.

â€œCount Mariendorf!â€ Kircheis said. â€œIâ€™m sorryâ€” Captain Leigh isnâ€™t here right now.â€

The count turned and smiled at Kircheis. â€œOh, Sub-lieutenant Kircheis. Itâ€™s good to see you again. Leigh told me in a letter that you had an unpleasant time on your trip. Iâ€™m happy youâ€™re back safely.â€

â€œThank you, sir,â€ Kircheis said. â€œWas there something you needed from Captain Leigh?â€

â€œI was hoping to ask his advice, but if heâ€™s not here I might have to do without it.â€

â€œIâ€™m happy to pass along a message for you, if you like.â€

â€œIâ€™m afraid that will be a little too late. Iâ€™m leaving tonight.â€

â€œWhere are you going, sir? If I may ask?â€

â€œIs there somewhere private we can speak?â€

â€œOf course, sir.â€ Kircheis pulled out his ring of keys and unlocked Leighâ€™s office, which made the count raise a silent eyebrow. â€œI sometimes come in here to drop things off while the captain is out,â€ Kircheis said. â€œHe wonâ€™t mind if we talk in here.â€

â€œCaptain Leigh trusts you quite a lot.â€

â€œYes, sir. I try to live up to his expectations.â€

Leighâ€™s office was just as messy as ever, though he had made some effort to tidy it before they went to Cahokia. Kircheis pulled out the two chairs in front of Leighâ€™s desk so that they could sit facing each other, neither wanting to offer the count the messy spot that Leigh usually occupied, nor take it himself. â€œDid you see Rear Admiral Reuenthal while you were on Iserlohn, by the way?â€

â€œI saw him, but didnâ€™t speak to him. Captain Leigh did, though. He seemed to be doing well.â€

â€œThatâ€™s good, thatâ€™s good.â€ The count settled himself into his seat, rubbing his hands across his knees. â€œIâ€™m going to pay a visit to Lord Maximilian von Castrop,â€ he said finally. â€œThe situation has become so untenable that the crown has asked me to make a personal intervention before the fleet is sent in to resolve the issue.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t realize it was so bad, sir.â€

â€œVery few people do, Sub-lieuenant. And thatâ€™s by design. Itâ€™s not good to let the rest of the court know just how far Lord Castrop has been able to push things while we continue handling him with the kid gloves.â€

â€œYes, sir. I can see that. What was it that you wanted to ask Captain Leigh?â€

â€œI have a distinct feeling that Lord Castrop is going to force the crown to take off its gloves sooner or later. I doubt that I will be of any effect going there.â€ He sighed. â€œI wanted to ask Leighâ€™s opinion, about how much I should warn Lord Castrop about whatâ€™s coming. If the situation is not going to be resolved with words, then the Fleet will need to enforce order.â€

â€œDo you know which fleet is going to be sent, if the worst happens?â€

â€œThatâ€™s part of what I was hoping to ask Captain Leigh. He has a very good sense of where everyone is and who goes where. But I know it wouldnâ€™t be one of the ones stationed at Iserlohn,â€ the count said. â€œCastropâ€™s lands are in the other direction. I assume that the first forces sent will be some small peacekeeping fleet. Nothing huge. Fleet Admiral Muckenburger wouldnâ€™t want to be seen to overreact of his own volitionâ€” he will send the smallest force he can until the crown orders him otherwise. After all, he doesnâ€™t want to look like someone eager to step on the toes of all the other noble families.â€

â€œYes, that sounds reasonable, sir.â€

â€œThe other thing I want to know isâ€” Lord Castrop has a set of satellites protecting his planet. Itâ€™s called the Artemis Necklace. He believes that it makes his planet safe from invasion, even if he doesnâ€™t have a fleet of his own.â€

â€œWhere did he get that?â€

â€œHe used part of his fatherâ€™s fortune to buy it from Phezzan, as well as a cut of his profits on some of his business.â€

â€œPhezzan doesnâ€™t have one, does it?â€

â€œNo, but the rebel territoryâ€™s capital planet, Heinessen, does.â€

â€œInteresting,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œIn what way?â€

â€œI can probably tell you what Captain Leigh would say.â€

â€œHeâ€™s that predictable, is he?â€

â€œYes, sir.â€

â€œWell, in lieu of Captain Leighâ€™s advice, Iâ€™ll be happy to take yours.â€

â€œHeâ€™d say that there isnâ€™t a technological solution thatâ€™s infallible, no matter what the person who built it thinks.â€

â€œHe would say that.â€

â€œAnd Iâ€™m sure that he would also say that Phezzan has some reason for selling this technology to Lord Castrop and the rebel territories, while not using it themselves.â€

Count Mariendorf laughed. â€œYes, that is the kind of thing that Leigh would say. Phezzan must not have been kind to him, to make him question their motives so often. â€œI wouldnâ€™t know, sir.â€

â€œYes, of course. Thatâ€™s just speculation on my part, anyway. So, Leigh would tell me to warn Castrop that the Imperial Fleet is more than a match for his Phezzani technology.â€

â€œYou would have to say that anyway, wouldnâ€™t you, sir?â€Â 

â€œWell, I would at least like to lend some honesty to my words.â€

â€œDo you think heâ€™ll believe you?â€

Count Mariendorf sighed. â€œNo, I doubt it. If he felt that the Fleet posed a real threat, he wouldnâ€™t have gotten to this point.â€

â€œSo youâ€™re being sent on a foolâ€™s errand?â€

â€œSomeone has to,â€ the count said. â€œMuch like Leigh, I would prefer to have a peaceful solution before sending the Fleet in. Especially if any of Lord Castropâ€™s confidence is well founded. I donâ€™t want to see our soldiers die, but especially not in a petty internal squabble about taxes and inheritances.â€ Even as he said it, the count made a chagrined expression: there would undoubtedly be a great loss of life in the forthcoming civil war, which everyone could see on the horizon and no one could do anything to stop.

â€œI hope not, sir. How long do you expect to spend with Lord Castrop?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know. I doubt that Iâ€™ll be on his planet more than a week. If he isnâ€™t interested in me speaking to him, then thereâ€™s no reason for me to stay for any longer. I certainly donâ€™t want to be anywhere in the area when the Fleet comes through.â€

Kircheis hesitated. â€œWill you be safe there?â€

â€œIâ€™m an emissary of the crown,â€ Mariendorf said. â€œAnd I myself am not a threat to Lord Castrop in any way. I donâ€™t foresee there being any personal trouble. Did Hilde speak with you?â€

â€œNo, I sent her a letter while on the way back, but we havenâ€™t spoken yet. Why?â€

â€œOh, sheâ€™s concerned about me traveling. I had wondered if those fears had rubbed off on you.â€

â€œI thought she was concerned about the Kaiserâ€™s health.â€

â€œI think His Majesty will hold out for the few weeks Iâ€™m dealing with Lord Castrop,â€ the count said. â€œIt certainly would be inconvenient if he died now. But then, of course, Lord Castrop would suddenly become the least of everyoneâ€™s problems.â€ He laughed, but it was resigned.

â€œI hope so, sir.â€ He hesitated, then asked, â€œIs the reason youâ€™re asking Captain Leigh for advice because Duke Braunschweig would like Lord Castropâ€™s favor?â€

Chapter End Notes

sorry for my absence. i finished the itsoh act 1 rewrite and a bunch of other stuff which you should go read. i'm planning to write the rest of this story straight through now though so i shouldn't vanish again

title is about nietzche, who disagrees with me and martin certainly.

the opener asked the crowd how to tune his guitar lol

anyway a few points of order: there are TWO chinese translations of WIAW available! if you prefer to read in chinese, both translations are linked in the series notes. i should be back with another chapter sooner rather than later. anyway u know where to find me

In the Heat of the Moment, Alliances Are Formed,

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Although her father had traveled for work many times in the past, either on the business of the crown or to visit the Mariendorf family holdings, Hilde found the silence of her house different this time. Perhaps it was just because she was older, and so all the time spent outside of her manor at school or visiting friends made the emptiness of home feel more real. She didnâ€™t know what the precise cause was, but, in the first week of her fatherâ€™s trip, she spent as much time away from home as she could, only really coming back to eat dinner and sleep. It wasnâ€™t even like something had gone wrongâ€” her father was still en route, and he sent her a mundane letter daily. But Hilde couldnâ€™t shake the feeling that something was going to go terribly wrong.Â 

She couldnâ€™t explain why she had such a foreboding about her father going to visit Lord Castrop. When she tried to rationalize the feeling, she decided that it was probably just projection. There was some part of her mind that was latching onto this small matter as a portent to divine the future of the Empire as a whole.Â 

It made no sense to do that, of course. Whatever happened, the civil war that was looming on the horizon, which everyone could see and no one could stop, would look a lot different than the squabble of one tiny planet and one tiny family with the crown. But it was the first major internal strife within the Empire in her lifetime. At least, it was the first that had escalated into the threat of the Imperial Fleet being sent out against a noble family, rather than a small peopleâ€™s rebellion put down on a border planet.

This felt different. It felt like there was something in the air. The flexing of the power of the nobility was a sign that things were changing, faster and faster.

After all, the elder Lord Castrop, in his time, had been a loyal servant of the crownâ€” holding the post of Minister of the Treasury, even. If he had used that post to enrich himself, that was no different than any other man who had held the post before or after. That wasnâ€™t close to treason. The fact that his son was willing to rebel so openly felt representative of the shifting sands of the era.

She spoke with Martin about this one day, after her classes at ONU let out. They were sitting outside on a low wall by the main gate. Hilde was waiting for her driver to pick her up, and Martin waited with her, as was his habit on days when they got out of class at the same time. It was a warm afternoon, the summer not having completely retreated, though the first few crisp red leaves were beginning to tumble from the trees and crunch along the pathways underfoot. Martin was twirling one of these leaves in between two fingers.

â€œLord Castrop is right that the times are changing,â€ Martin said. â€œBut heâ€™s too early. If he had tried this after the Kaiser dies, he might have actually succeeded in â€˜liberatingâ€™ his little fiefdom.â€ The leaf spun back and forth between his thumb and index finger. â€œAt least for a while.â€

â€œWhile everyone else is busy fighting for the crown, you mean,â€ Hilde said.

â€œOf course. Itâ€™s a time that everybody who wants things to change should take advantage of.â€

Hilde glanced around, making sure there was no one in earshot. â€œI hope youâ€™re not thinking about anything dangerous.â€

Martin just smiled. â€œI feel like your friend Captain Leigh might try to take advantage.â€

â€œWhat do you mean?â€ Hilde asked, her voice suddenly sharp. â€œDid Sieg tell you something?â€

â€œNo,â€ Martin said. â€œBut he has no reason to like the status quo, and heâ€™s put himself in a position to change things. Thatâ€™s all Iâ€™m saying.â€

â€œYou scare me sometimes, Martin,â€ Hilde said.

â€œSorry.â€ But he didnâ€™t sound sorry at all. Worrying about Martin brought her back around to worrying about her father, and she let out a sigh.

â€œWhatâ€™s the matter?â€ Martin asked. He twiddled his leaf under her chin, which tickled. It was silly, but it did cheer her up at least enough to answer.

â€œOutside of all your thoughts about things Lord Castrop should have done better if he wanted to make a stand, do you think my father is in danger?â€ She leaned back with her hands splayed for support on the low brick wall, looking up at the puffy clouds darting across the blue sky above.

â€œDoes he think heâ€™s in danger?â€

â€œIf he did, he wouldnâ€™t tell me. He wouldnâ€™t want me to worry.â€

Martin hummed under his breath. â€œIs Lord Castrop prone to anger?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Hilde said. â€œIâ€™ve never met him. I donâ€™t have a good impression of him, from all of this, obviously, but at least a long rebellion from the crown isnâ€™t something thatâ€™s done on a whim. It seems unlikely that my father coming to speak with him will make him angry enough toâ€” I donâ€™t know.â€

â€œWell, thatâ€™s something, at least.â€ Martin didnâ€™t sound confident.

â€œBut the other thing?â€

â€œIf you were Lord Castrop, do you think you could get anything out of holding a count hostage?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know. He seems very confident in his planetâ€™s protective systemâ€” the Artemis Necklaceâ€” so it doesnâ€™t seem like it would even be necessary for him to ward off any attacks by threatening my father or keeping him prisoner.â€

â€œDoes Lord Castrop own a ship?â€ Martin asked after a second.

â€œA ship?â€

â€œA ship.â€

â€œWhy do you ask?â€

â€œIf he has a way to get off the planet, it might be a backup plan.â€ He looked off into the distance. Down the road, Hildeâ€™s ride was waiting in traffic at the closest stoplight, and would be pulling up to the curb in a moment or so.Â 

â€œI donâ€™t know if heâ€™s thought any of this through,â€ Martin said. â€œBut this is probably his only chance to ensure his own safety if he does have to flee his planet. If the Artemis Necklace doesnâ€™t work. Or maybe he hasnâ€™t thought of using your father as a human shield, and he just, I donâ€™t knowâ€” a stupid man would want to make sure that he had someone from the Empire to show his military dominance to, when the Fleet inevitably comes through. If heâ€™s confident enough that he will wipe them out, he probably wants a pet witness. To see his face.â€

â€œAnd you think this is likely?â€

The car was pulling up in front of them. â€œI have a bit of a low opinion of the noble class, Iâ€™m afraid,â€ Martin said. â€œI think itâ€™s more likely than your father being able to accomplish anything he was sent for.â€

â€œI hope youâ€™re wrong,â€ Hilde said. She stood, and picked up her bag from the ground. Martin stood as well, and tossed away his leaf. It fluttered away on the breeze, and landed in the road, where a car promptly ran it over.

â€œFor the record,â€ Martin said. â€œI hope so, too. Of all the nobles in this world, I do like your father.â€

Hilde gave him a thin smile. â€œThanks.â€

â€œIâ€™ll ask Sieg to keep an ear out for you,â€ Martin said. â€œSee if thereâ€™s any chatter coming through Duke Braunschweigâ€™s office, or anything like that. He should be allowed to talk about that kind of thing with me, Iâ€™d assume.â€

Hilde nodded. Kircheis would have told her anything he heard, of course, but she did appreciate Martinâ€™s attempt at being helpful. â€œThanks,â€ she said, with as much of a smile as she could muster.

Â 

Â 

It didnâ€™t take long for Hildeâ€™s premonitions about things going wrong to bear fruit. After her father arrived on Lord Castropâ€™s planet, and after the departure of the merchant vessel he had flown in on, all communication from her father suddenly ceased. Since her father was in the habit of writing her daily, this struck an immediate alarm in Hildeâ€™s head, and she called up the colonial affairs office several times, trying to get an update about her fatherâ€™s status. The staff working in the office had the same line: there had been no news from Count Mariendorf, but this didnâ€™t mean that anything was awry. It could just mean that he was busy.

Hilde suspected that they were lying, and she wondered how long they would keep up the pretense for. She could understand wanting to keep it under wraps, whatever had happened to her father, because it would cause a stir among the nobles. She was sure that the whole thing was going to be kept quiet until the Fleet could deal with it.

But that almost made it worse. She wondered if there had been a message from Lord Castropâ€” was her father alive and being held hostage, or was he dead? She didnâ€™t want to assume the worst, but she couldnâ€™t help but feel a sucking dread. The balance of terrorâ€” the idea that he was already deadâ€” the hope that there was still something that someone could doâ€” this made her barely able to eat, hardly able to sleep, for several days. Each day that passed without a word from her father sent her deeper.

She had called Kircheis as soon as she felt the first inkling that something had really, truly gone wrong, and he had promised that he would look into it, and had said that Captain Leigh would, as well. Although Kircheis probably didnâ€™t have very many useful contacts, she was sure that Leigh did, and thinking of his friendship with her father settled her nerves, at least a little. If there was anything that Leigh could do for her father, he certainly would do it.

So, when Kircheis arrived at her house unexpectedly during dinner, when Hilde had been poking her salmon and asparagus around on her plate, alone in the dining room, she felt sure that the news must be terrible, though perhaps not the worst. If the news had been her fatherâ€™s death, she was certain that Captain Leigh would have come himself. Of all the things that Hilde remembered from the summer that her mother had died, it was Leighâ€™s steady presence that remained in her mind most clearly.

Her butler let Kircheis into the dining room immediately, though he politely declined the offer of dinner, and sat down across from her. Hilde pushed her plate away.

â€œYour father is still alive,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œI know,â€ Hilde replied.

â€œHow did you know?â€ he asked. â€œCaptain Leigh just told me, and I came straight here.â€

Hilde just shook her head. â€œHow did Hank find this out?â€

Kircheis shifted uncomfortably in his seat. â€œHis former CO, Rear Admiral Bronner, knows more than he should about everything,â€ Kircheis said. â€œThough in this case, I think he came by the information legitimately. His department was ordered to give Fleet Admiral Muckenburger a dossier on the best fleet to send to deal with Lord Castropâ€” delicately. The Kaiser would like the fleet to make sure your father stays alive.â€

â€œDo you know why he told Hank?â€

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said. â€œIt might just be because theyâ€™re friends, or maybe Captain Leigh traded him the informationâ€” I donâ€™t know. But this is otherwise being kept very tightly under wraps, until Muckenburger sends out the fleet. He wants this to be over before anyone knows that itâ€™s started.â€

Hilde was silent for a moment. â€œIf he sends a fleet against Lord Castropâ€¦â€

â€œI donâ€™t think thereâ€™s any way to know what Castrop will do,â€ Kircheis said. â€œHeâ€™s already so far outside of everyoneâ€™s expectations.â€

â€œSo Iâ€™m just supposed to hope that Lord Castrop is kinder and saner than all of his behavior would lead me to think, and that the fleet manages to broach the Artemis Necklace? I donâ€™t want to say that Castrop is right that his planet can withstand the whole strength of the Imperial Fleet, but the rebel territories use the same technology to protect their capital. They wouldnâ€™t do that if they also didnâ€™t think that it was a powerful tool.â€

â€œCaptain Leigh pointed out to me that the rebel fleet also keeps thousands of ships within that starzone,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI agree with him that no technology is invincible. And Lord Castrop doesnâ€™t have a fleet to speak of.â€

â€œThat doesnâ€™t really make the situation any better. If the Artemis Necklace is destroyedâ€” Martin thinks that Lord Castrop would keep my father as a hostage to run away, but what if he doesnâ€™t do that?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Kircheis said. He sounded strained. â€œI wish there was something I could do.â€

â€œThere has to be something I can do,â€ Hilde said. â€œI canâ€™t just sit here. I feel so useless.â€

â€œIt might be a while before the fleet admiral sends anyone out,â€ Kircheis said. â€œYou have some timeâ€” I donâ€™t know, maybe you could write a letter to Lord Castrop andâ€”â€

â€œThat wouldnâ€™t do anything,â€ Hilde said.

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis agreed. He looked down at his hands. â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

â€œNo, itâ€™s not your fault,â€ Hilde said. â€œIâ€™m sorry for snapping at you.â€ She bit her lip. Suddenly, an idea came to her. â€œMy father is Duke Braunschweigâ€™s ally,â€ she pointed out.

â€œYes?â€ Kircheis said, unclear as to where Hilde was going with this.

â€œDo you think that he has an obligation to help my father, in this circumstance?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Kircheis said. â€œPolitics arenâ€™t really my strongest suit.â€

She wasnâ€™t sure if he did, especially since the whole matter was supposed to be kept under wraps. If Duke Braunschweig refused to help her fatherâ€” and she didnâ€™t even know how he would be able to helpâ€” no one would ever find out. It wouldnâ€™t cost him anything aside from the Mariendorf familyâ€™s loyalty, and maybe a few other people that Hilde would warn against going to Braunschweigâ€™s side. But, if nothing else, Braunschweig was a man who lived in the court, and always had. He probably had some sense of honor about alliances. Andâ€” Hilde thoughtâ€” even if she couldnâ€™t speak to the duke directly, she might be able to convince his daughter.

â€œSiegâ€”â€ she began.

â€œWhat?â€ Kircheis asked, echoing the anxiety in her tone.

â€œCould you ask Hankâ€” does he think that thereâ€™s anything that he could do, if I asked Duke Braunschweig to help my father, if I go to Lord Castrop to negotiate for his release, even if that doesnâ€™t workâ€” do you think that Hank could help rescue him?â€

Kircheis was silent for a long time, seriously considering her words. She was so grateful to him, for not just dismissing her with a platitude, or telling her that it was too dangerous. â€œI will ask him,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI donâ€™t know what he would be able to do, but I will ask.â€

She nodded. â€œIâ€™ll ask for Duke Braunschweigâ€™s help, then.â€

Â 

Â 

Hilde didnâ€™t have a good strategy for meeting with Duke Braunschweig. She knew that the duke would have no desire to speak with her directly. Even being her fatherâ€™s heir didnâ€™t mean enough to counter the fact that she was a woman without her own proper title, and as young as his daughter. If she had asked him to meet, she suspected that she would be given a run-around.Â 

She could ask to meet with Princess Amarie, and she would likely be given an audience, at least, but from everything that Hilde had learned about the princess, it seemed that she would be harder to convince to take up her fatherâ€™s cause than the duke. Amarie was a calculating woman, and might decide the Mariendorf family alliance was not worth encouraging her husband to involve himself in yet another scheme that went contrary to the crownâ€™s official stanceâ€” which was to keep the entire Castrop affair as a matter between the crown and one rebellious noble, not to involve one of the largest political alliances in the Empire. Duke Braunschweig getting involved would escalate the matter into something that could have real portents for the civil war.Â 

Duke Braunschweig was more hot headed than his wife, and so he would not look that far out when considering if he should give his aid. He would likely only look at the immediate expenses and rewards. He might even, if he were feeling bold, try to demand some sort of reward from the crown for any helpful efforts that he chose to provide in rescuing Count Mariendorf, and putting down Castropâ€™s rebellion.

But Hilde couldnâ€™t get an audience with the duke herself, so she would have to take a different track.

That left his daughter, who might be able to convince the duke. Hilde didnâ€™t know if the young Elizabeth had that kind of advisory relationship with her father, but it didnâ€™t hurt to try. Especially since she was social with Lady Elizabeth, which meant that it was not too unusual when she followed Captain Leigh to the Braunschweig manor, and asked to see her.

It was an unexpected visit, to be sure, but not one that would cause anyone alarm. Captain Leigh had other business with the duke, so he left to go speak with him, which left Hilde waiting in the large, dim library for Lady Elizabeth to find a second to see her. It was a rainy September day, and the wind lashed the drops of rain down against the windows in thick sheets, blurring out the view of the outside world. It was warm in the library, but the drumming of the rain was loud. It was a fitting accompaniment to Hildeâ€™s mood.

Lady Elizabeth made her appearance quite quickly, striding into the library with a precision that Hilde admired. If she had been wearing a dress as complex as the auburn and gold outfit that Elizabeth was wearing, Hilde would have tripped over her own legs. Or that was the sensation that looking at Elizabeth gave her, anyway. She was so perfectly poisedâ€” even though it seemed unlikely that she was planning to leave the house today, her hair was done in an elaborate coiffe, and her face was delicately pale with makeup, her lips a dark and crisp red.

â€œLady Hildegardâ€” to see you standing there in silhouette against the window,â€ Elizabeth called as she came in, â€œI almost thought that you were Hans. He has a jacket just like yours.â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry to disappoint, Lady Elizabeth.â€

â€œHardly,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s a pleasant surprise to have company, especially yours.â€

â€œI hope I didnâ€™t pull you away from anything important.â€

â€œNo, I was painting. But thatâ€™s nothing that canâ€™t be picked up and put down again. And I tire of solitary activities.â€ She draped herself across one of the couches, and gestured for Hilde to sit across from her, which she did. â€œYou came in with Captain Leigh, I assume? â€œYes,â€ Hilde said. â€œI apologize for using him as an excuse to invade your home.â€

â€œThatâ€™s what we pay Captain Leigh for, isnâ€™t it? Planning invasions?â€ Elizabeth laughed, but it wasnâ€™t clear if she actually found her own joke funny. â€œAre you and he here on the same business?â€

â€œYou see right through me, Lady Elizabeth. I am here for business, but my own, rather than Captain Leighâ€™s.â€

â€œHilde, if this were a social call, you would have asked ahead of time. But you wanted to corner me unexpectedly. I knew you must be after something. And Iâ€™m sure a woman like you is not after my social graces.â€ Hilde felt disarmed by this comment, and had no idea what Elizabeth meant by it.

â€œNo, itâ€™s unfortunately nothing as simple as that.â€

â€œWell, you have my attention.â€

â€œDo you remember when we met?â€

â€œWasnâ€™t it this past January?â€

â€œAt your New Yearâ€™s party, yes.â€

â€œAnd what about that occasion are you asking me to recall?â€ She smiled, as if they hadnâ€™t had almost the same conversation about Hilde dressing like a man then, too. Elizabeth had a sharp memory, and clearly did remember.

â€œI told you that it wasnâ€™t my right to give my fatherâ€™s answer about being Duke Braunschweigâ€™s ally, at the time.â€

â€œAh, yes, I do remember that. A true enough thing to say.â€

â€œI was hoping that something like that would be less true for you than it is for me.â€

â€œYou want me to speak for my father?â€ Elizabeth raised her eyebrows. â€œOr play some kind of trick on him? You are as bold as I imagined you to be.â€

â€œNot a trick, Lady Elizabeth,â€ Hilde said. â€œYouâ€™re just the only one I can ask for help.â€Â 

â€œYou always do intrigue me, Hilde. What is it that you want? Ask.â€

â€œMy father has been taken hostage by Lord Castrop, on his planet. If I donâ€™t do something to free him, I think that he will die. Either when Lord Castrop decides that he is no longer entertaining, or when the Imperial Fleet arrives to put a stop to his rebellion.â€

This statement, delivered in Hildeâ€™s most earnest tone, made Elizabeth briefly speechless. â€œThings have gone that far?â€ she asked. â€œI read about his contentions with the crown in the papers a while ago, but I assumed nothing had come of it, since this is the first Iâ€™m hearing of it since.â€

â€œYes, my lady,â€ Hilde said. â€œIn order to not worry everyone, this has all been kept very quiet. The colonial affairs office wonâ€™t even acknowledge that my father is a prisoner.â€

â€œIf they wonâ€™t acknowledge that, then how did you come to learn this?â€

â€œMy father would send me a letter every day,â€ Hilde said. â€œThey stopped when he arrived at Castropâ€™s estate. And Captain Leigh was able to gather information about a possible fleet dispatch against Lord Castrop.â€

Elizabeth squinted at Hilde for a second, looking for something in her expression. â€œHe learned this from his Phezzani spy?â€ she asked.

Hilde tried not to react too openly to this question. Elizabeth had assumed that Leigh gave her more information than she really hadâ€” no one had mentioned any more to her about the matter of Kircheisâ€™s friend on Phezzan since the issue had first come up. She had assumed that it had gone away. The idea that there continued to be someone feeding Leigh information from Phezzan was interesting, and she wished she could pry through what Elizabeth knew.Â 

â€œIâ€™m not sure where the information comes from,â€ Hilde lied. â€œIt probably did come from there, if the fleet office on Phezzan has been instructed to keep an eye out for Castrop running.â€

â€œI see.â€ Elizabeth brushed some of her hair off her shoulder. â€œIâ€™m deeply saddened to hear that your father is in trouble, but Iâ€™m not sure what I can do about it.â€

â€œMy family is allied to yours,â€ Hilde said. â€œI would like to formally request your assistance.â€

â€œYou know you should be asking my father. You said so yourself.â€

â€œNo,â€ Hilde said. â€œMy father should be asking your father. But because my father is gone, and your father would likely pay me no mind, I must ask you.â€

â€œMy father would not ignore you.â€

â€œWill you ignore me, Lady Eizabeth?â€ Hilde had a sudden flash of imaginationâ€” picturing herself kneeling to ask Elizabethâ€™s aid. She brushed the thought out of her mind before it could show on her face.

â€œItâ€™s too late for that. You make yourself very hard to ignore.â€

â€œI have cornered you in your home.â€

â€œWhat is it that you actually want me to ask my father for? There arenâ€™t that many resources that he could feasibly spend.â€

â€œI would like to go to Lord Castropâ€™s estate and try to negotiate for my fatherâ€™s release.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t need my fatherâ€™s help for that, surely. You are capable of chartering passage on a ship yourself.â€

â€œYes, of course,â€ Hilde said. â€œBut I do not expect that any pleading I do with Lord Castrop will be successful at all.â€

â€œThen why try?â€

â€œBecause I would like to remove my father from Lord Castropâ€™s prison by force, if necessary.â€

â€œLady Mariendorf, I can tell you with absolute certainty that my father would not dispatch his fleet against Lord Castrop. Not unless the Kaiser himself asked for it.â€ The cold and firm tone in her voice, and the switch to a much more formal address made Hilde feel despair for the first time in this conversation. Perhaps she should have relied on Captain Leigh to present her case to Duke Braunschweig, rather than asking herself.

â€œIâ€™m not asking for a fleet, Lady Elizabeth,â€ Hilde said. â€œI know that isnâ€™t on the table.â€

â€œThen what is it that I can help you with?â€

â€œOne ship,â€ Hilde said. â€œOne ship to take me to Lord Castropâ€™s planet, and Captain Leigh and Sub-Lieutenant Kircheis to help me rescue my father. I donâ€™t need a fleet.â€

â€œCaptain Leigh is a personal friend of your fatherâ€™s, isnâ€™t he?â€

â€œYes, he is.â€

Elizabeth stared Hilde down, and Hilde straightened her back. â€œI like Captain Leigh very much,â€ Elizabeth said, finally. â€œBut if you do not believe you will be successful in convincing Lord Castrop to release your father, what makes you think that Captain Leighâ€” without a fleet behind himâ€” would be able to rescue him?â€

â€œCaptain Leigh is a very talented man,â€ Hilde said. â€œHe told me that he would do everything in his power to rescue my father, and I believe that is quite a lot.â€

â€œOne man cannot do everything.â€

â€œLady Elizabethâ€” even if he fails, I would rather try than not try. If I do nothing, and my father dies, I wonâ€™t be able to live with myself. And neither will Captain Leigh. I know you canâ€™t give me many resources, but with the ones that I can haveâ€” please. Let me try.â€

Elizabeth continued to stare her down. â€œYou make such a convincing case,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™m moved by pity for you.â€ Her voice was still very cold, though. â€œBut at the end of the day, I am not the one in charge of my fatherâ€™s fleet and staff. And he relies on Captain Leigh being here with him. Especially since Captain Ansbach is still out in the corridor. I canâ€™t decree that we will help you.â€

â€œBut you could convince your father.â€

Elizabeth stood from her languid sprawl on the couch, and walked over to the window. She looked much more imposing against the dim light. â€œHeâ€™ll ask what it will gain. And donâ€™t tell me the Mariendorf family's loyalty, because if you fail, which is likely, the Mariendorf family will no longer have anything to offer me.â€

Elizabeth was asking about what could be offered to her father, but she referred only to herself. Hilde remembered Leighâ€™s comment about who would actually be sitting on the throne, and she felt a sudden thrill of fear, though it was accompanied by a firm feeling that she had made the right choice in asking Elizabeth for help.

â€œCaptain Leigh believes that he can destroy the Artemis Necklace,â€ Hilde said. â€œIf he does so, it will prove your familyâ€™s strength, and will certainly attract more people to your side.â€

â€œSo much depends on Captain Leighâ€™s plans,â€ Elizabeth said. â€œWe are putting so much faith in one strange man.â€

Hilde hesitated. â€œAnd, if he canâ€™t do as he believes, it will prove that heâ€™s not a reliable advisor,â€ she said. â€œYouâ€™ll have a better idea of what will be possible when you try to take the throne.â€

Elizabeth considered this. â€œYou make it sound like thereâ€™s nothing for me to lose by helping you. If that were really the case, you would have asked my mother.â€

â€œIt will displease the crown,â€ Hilde said. â€œThe Kaiser doesn't want this to become part of the squabble between you and the Littenheim family. But if you help my father, it will be seen as part of that conflict. Your mother would probably not enjoy adding fuel to that fire.â€

â€œAnd you think I would?â€

â€œYou stand to gain much more than your mother does.â€

Elizabeth tilted her head to look up at the stormy sky out the window. â€œYou see things so clearly.â€

â€œSo do you, my lady.â€ Hilde said nothing else, giving time for Elizabeth to think.

â€œIf I do nothing, I will lose your friendship,â€ she said. â€œAnd that would be a pity.â€

â€œYes.â€

â€œThough I would lose it equally as much if you failed in your quest. Only the living are helpful to me, Iâ€™m afraid.â€

â€œI would like to promise not to fail.â€

This made Elizabeth laugh. â€œYou phrased that exactly like Captain Leigh would.â€

â€œHe has been an excellent teacher to me for many years.â€

â€œIâ€™m aware. He serves my father well.â€ Her tone was neutral. â€œWhy didnâ€™t you ask him to plead on your behalf?â€

â€œI like to handle my affairs myself.â€

â€œYou inherit, donâ€™t you?â€

â€œI hope not for a long time, Lady Elizabeth.â€

â€œWhen you do, you donâ€™t seem the type to have your husband manage your affairs for you.â€

â€œNo,â€ Hilde said firmly. â€œThe Mariendorf estates will be mine.â€

â€œI admire that about you, you know.â€

â€œYou will be Kaiserine.â€

This made Elizabeth smile, but it was a grim expression. â€œI will ask my father to loan you Captain Leigh, and a ship. On one condition.â€

â€œWhat is that?â€

â€œCaptain Leigh advises my father. I want you to advise me .â€

Hilde stood. â€œLady Elizabethâ€” we hardly even know each other.â€

â€œIs that a refusal?â€

â€œNoâ€” Iâ€”â€

Elizabeth came towards her, her skirt rustling. They were the same height, or Elizabeth was a little shorter. â€œI need someone who sees things clearly,â€ Elizabeth said, looking into Hildeâ€™s eyes. â€œSomeone who understands my world, and the rest.â€

â€œIâ€™m honored that you think Iâ€”â€

â€œDo you know why my father trusts Captain Leigh?â€ Elizabeth asked suddenly.

â€œBecause of his skill and his work with Iserlohnâ€”â€

â€œNo,â€ Elizabeth said. â€œThatâ€™s not it.â€

â€œThen what is it?â€

â€œItâ€™s something that Captain Ansbach told him. Leigh is an outsider.
