The Washing of the Hands

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

October 487 I.C., Planet Castrop

It took two days to hike from their landing spot back to the city. The journey was exhausting and stressful. They tried to mainly walk at night, to avoid seeing people, and to avoid the heat of the day, since it was quite warm on Castropâ€™s planet. They hid during the day, sleeping in shifts in the forests away from the road. They stole food from fields as they walked byâ€” it was mainly fruit that they could get their hands on, not quite ripe, or too-ripe and fallen from trees in the orchards they passed. It sufficed, at least, but it gave Hilde terrible indigestion, which didnâ€™t help the walk go faster.

As they came closer to the city, kicking up dust along the path (at least it hadnâ€™t rained at all during their long march), they had to be much more careful of being observed. Hilde wondered if they should try to steal outfits like the ones everyone on this planet wore, but they hadnâ€™t passed any farmhouses at night with laundry hung out that they could steal, so the opportunity to change clothes had not presented itself. At least the airfield was on the far outskirts of the city, and, as they approached it at the end of the second night, they were able to hide and crouch in the scraggly bushes that lined the far edge beyond the wire fence. Security was, as it was in most places on Castropâ€™s planet, minimal.

Castropâ€™s ship still remained exactly where it had been. And, indeed, the whole scene was empty, except for a few bored looking guards at the front of the airfield. Hilde and Kircheis watched their patterns through their tiny pair of binoculars. The guards mainly stood in the single cone of light provided by the lights from the guardhouse, and smoked cigarette after cigarette. Occasionally, one or two of them would make a halfhearted circle of Castropâ€™s ship, but rarely did they do anything else.

Even if Hilde and Kircheis could have snuck up to Castropâ€™s ship easily, there was no way that they could get on board. There was a chance that within the little guard hut, there was a mechanism to remotely open the shipâ€™s doors, but there was no way to be sure. Even if they did manage to open the ship that way, it would immediately lead to their detection.

She and Kircheis discussed this as they sat in their little hideout, a ditch hidden by brambles on the edge of the airfield. Kircheis propped himself up on his elbows and watched the guards through the binoculars.

â€œThe only thing that we can do,â€ Hilde said, â€œis wait for them to open the ship themselves, and then I can sneak on.â€

â€œ You can sneak on?â€ Kircheis asked.

Hilde frowned. â€œThink about it logically, Sieg. If theyâ€™re opening the ship, theyâ€™re going to be hanging out right next to it. Youâ€™ll need to cause a distraction that will let me on.â€

â€œBut why shouldnâ€™t I go, and you cause the distraction?â€

â€œBecause if you got caught on the ship, theyâ€™d kill you.â€

â€œAnd not you?â€

â€œIâ€™m valuable to Castrop,â€ she said, trying to keep fear out of her voice as she did. â€œHe wouldnâ€™t kill me.â€

Kircheis clearly understood the logic, but that didnâ€™t make it any more pleasant. â€œIâ€™d still rather go myself. Captain Leigh and your father would ratherâ€”â€

â€œI donâ€™t care,â€ she said. â€œI appreciate that you want to protect me, but if thereâ€™s a greater chance of you dying by doing it, then Iâ€™m not going to let you. Itâ€™s as simple as that. And I still have Captain Leighâ€™s program.â€ She pulled out her data stick and held it up. It glinted dimly in the starlight. Kircheis looked at it, holding himself so tense and still that she was sure he was debating snatching it out of her hands, but he didnâ€™t.

â€œI donâ€™t like it,â€ he said. â€œHow could I live with myself if I let anything happen to you?â€

â€œNothing will happen,â€ she said. â€œYouâ€™ll cause a distraction, Iâ€™ll run in, install the program, and run out.â€

â€œAnd if you canâ€™t get out?â€

â€œThen Iâ€™ll just have to hide on the ship,â€ she said. â€œI can do that. I memorized all the layouts.â€

Kircheis nodded. â€œWhat kind of distraction would you want?â€

Hilde gestured for him to hand her the binoculars. With them, she peered out towards the guardhouse. Inside, it had electric lights, and the distant glow of a couple computer screens, visible through the windows. But outside, the light was provided by torches in brackets, which flickered and danced in the wind.

â€œEasy enough to burn something down,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s hot and dry. A fire would probably spread pretty quickly, and it would be something that they needed to respond to.â€

Kircheis took the binoculars back. â€œBut we just have to wait until they decide to open the ship.â€

â€œWhen Castrop decides to leaveâ€¦â€

And that was the main issue: there had been no sign of Castrop looking to vacate the planet. So the Artemis Necklace must not have been destroyed yet. Hilde had no idea what it would look like from the ground, but Castrop certainly would know as soon as his defenses fell.

They waited and hid for another tense, hot day. They were sweltering without the protection of a truly leafy forest around them, and without the ability to leave to drink from springs and streams that they passed on the walk. Hilde hadnâ€™t believed that it would somehow be preferable to be hiking than sitting still, but it was.Â 

As she was trying to sleep, her head resting on one of the lumpy canvas bags, Kircheis was sitting watch, keeping an eye on the activities of the guards. Suddenly, he shook her awake, and she bolted upright.Â 

â€œWhat?â€ she hissed, not wanting to be too loud in case the reason he had woken her was because they had to move.

â€œLook at that!â€ Kircheis said, also in a low voice, and he pointed directly up. The sky was a brilliant crimson, the sun on its way down and the heat of the day finally breaking, but what was truly spectacular was the light show that danced from zenith to horizon in blinding streaks.

The display was like fireworks, but silent and far too distant. It was like the dim stars themselves were bursting open. Hilde and Kircheis craned their necks to see it, staring wide eyed at first the beams that shot out across the expanse of space, and then the fiery explosions that followed.

â€œCaptain Leigh must have figured out the Artemis Necklace,â€ Kircheis said.

Hilde hastily started gathering up all of their equipment. â€œCastrop will be running as soon as he knows itâ€™s over. You go get ready to make a distraction, and Iâ€™llâ€”â€

â€œGood luck,â€ Kircheis said.Â 

â€œYou too.â€ She looked him in the eye. â€œDonâ€™t stick around and watch for me to come out, if thereâ€™s people around. You keep yourself safe. Weâ€™ll meet back up by the farm down the road, the one with the pear tree out front. If we get separated.â€

â€œRight,â€ Kircheis said.

There wasnâ€™t much time for other discussion. Already the guards, who had been watching the display in the sky, were beginning to move in a chaotic way, clearly untrained for the situation at hand, having never expected it.

Hilde gave Kircheis one final grim smile, clasped his hand for just a moment, and then ducked down into their ditch that they had been hiding in, and began her trek around the perimeter of the airfield. She had with her just the few things that might be useful to her: the binoculars, a small pair of wire clippers to let her through the fence, her gun, and the data stick that would destroy Castropâ€™s ship.

After some time, Hilde became aware that she was hearing distant sounds of shouting, not coming from the guards but from the city farther away. Hilde couldnâ€™t make out who or why or what the shouting voices were saying. They only seemed to be carried on the wind.

In the darkness at the edge of the field, she watched the guards perform various duties, but none of them had yet involved opening the great door that would allow entrance to the shipâ€™s loading bay. Some of them were checking the exterior of the ship, while others were swarming around the guardhouse, or opening the gates at the entrance to the airfield.

The source of the shouting became obvious soon enough. From the city, there came a crowd of people, all heading towards the airfield. Most were on foot, but a few were riding horses. Hilde even heard the revving of the motorcycle that she had spotted when she and Kircheis had first been escorted through the city. She understood what was happening: all those who felt that they were in some kind of danger from an Imperial fleet were eager to board the only ship heading off the planet. These must have been mostly lower officials, people who worked directly for Castrop, or perhaps even regular peasants of the planet who feared the unknown more than they feared their lord.

Hilde had a sudden, vivid memory from her childhoodâ€” sitting down with Hank, while he described the chaotic evacuation of the planet El Facil, with all the civilians trying their hardest to escape in the face of an oncoming Imperial fleet. At the time, Hilde had been young enough that she hadnâ€™t really understood what that would have looked like on the ground, and she had only been thinking of the cold movements of ships through space. Now she was old enough to recognize this terror and desperation for what it was. She wished that she could tell these people that there was no reason to be afraid: Captain Leigh in the sky above them bore them no ill will whatsoever. But of course, they had no way of knowing that.

Visible above the top of the crowd, there came Castropâ€™s entourage, or the first part of it. There were small trucks, military surplus from the looks of it, that pushed through the crowd, attempting to scatter the crowd as the trucks rolled up to the airfield gates, trying to get through. These must have been some of Castropâ€™s supplies, or select group of people who were chosen to accompany him. Hilde couldnâ€™t tell if Castrop himself was among their numberâ€” maybe, maybe not.

As they came through the gates, all of the guards who had been assigned to the airfield were occupied in keeping the general population out. The trucks pulled up to the ship, and the ramp began to slowly descend.Â 

Hilde watched this with increasing fear, waiting for Kircheis to make his move, whatever that move would be. Although the ramp was coming down, the guards and whoever else were in the trucks were still right there, and would prevent Hilde from being able to enter the ship.

â€œCome on, Sieg,â€ she whispered under her breath, every muscle in her body taught as she prepared to leap from her hiding place.

Cutting through the sounds of the crowd and the roar of the truck engines, Hilde heard the clear and unmistakable whine of a shot being fired. Things seemed to move in slow motion: down at the entrance to the airfield, one of the guards who had been holding back the tide collapsed. Then there was another shot, impossible to determine the direction from which it had come, and another guard collapsed, and another. This gave the crowd enough room and courage to burst through in one wave. The guards that remained opened fire on the crowd, but they were quickly overwhelmed by sheer numbers, and vanished under the wave of the stampede.

This had the intended effect: the guards who had begun unloading the trucks immediately had to abandon this task. If Hilde had been one of them, she would have run up into the ship and tried to close the door to stop people from getting in, but these guards were not well trained, and instead they also tried to take up defensive positions at the trucks. They shot randomly into the crowd with their sidearms, but they, too, were immediately overwhelmed.

Some of the crowd started tearing open the boxes of supplies on the trucks, while others began to swarm up into the ship. Hilde knew that this would be her only chance.

From down the airstrip, she heard the sound of more engines coming, this time not stopping at the gates. This was probably a better trained contingent of the guard, possibly Castropâ€™s personal vehicles. There was the sound of machine gun fire.

Hilde abandoned her hiding place and made the mad dash across the airfield, covering the short distance to Castropâ€™s ship faster than she would have thought possible. She was barely even cognizant of her own body; the distance melted away before her.The crowd ignored her, even though she was dressed oddly. Her feet pounded up the metal ramp, and her body was shoved side to side, surrounded by the crush of others attempting to enter the ship.

Hilde pushed through the screaming, urgent crowd. They had broken into the main section of the ship from the loading bay, and she found herself in strange hallways, a ship so different from the normal Imperial designs. Here, even the sounds of the crowd behind her as she ran were muffled. The floor was tiled with mosaics, and the walls were covered in drapes that ate the sound from the air.Â 

Having memorized the layout of the generic type of ship she was on, she had at least an idea of where she needed to go, towards any place that would have computer terminals that controlled the ship. She felt the engine room was likely to be emptier than the bridge, so she tried to make her way in that direction. But as she ran, she realized that extensive modifications had been made to the ship in its layout, and hallways ended randomly, or twisted unexpectedly. She wasted precious minutes trying to get her bearings.Â 

By the time she had made it to the engine room, she could no longer hear the crowd in the ship. She felt completely alone.

The engine room was locked, as she had expected that it would be, but Leigh had told her the generic passcode that was installed on ships of this class, and she tried it. It did not surprise her that Castrop, for all his aesthetic work on the ship, had never bothered to update the passcodes for the doors.Â 

The engine room was dark, and cavernous, and for the moment, silent: the engine was turned off while the ship was still sitting quiescent on the airfield. Her footsteps clanged over the diamond pattern metal floor panels, and she located one of the first maintenance computers.

She hit a few keys to wake it up, and before it even presented the login screen, she jammed the data stick into its port. The program that Leigh had given her was one that needed nothing other than bare access to the computer, and she could see it begin to work, the screen flashing black and a single loading bar crawling across it.

She alternated her attention between the computer and the door of the engine room, listening for any sounds of footsteps. The yelling of the crowd was coming closer again, she caught distant strains of it as it echoed through the ventilation shafts and corridors.Â 

It took three minutes for the program to install itself, and when the loading bar flashed green and the screen cleared to show the harmless login, Hilde ripped out the data stick and turned back the way she had come. She needed to get out.

This, however, proved to be impossible.

As she moved back towards the front of the ship, she tried to avoid being seen. Now, mixed amid the chaotic yells of the crowd rejoicing in getting aboard, there were the sounds of gunshots, and terrified screams. The passage back seemed blocked, and she might just have to find a place to hide on board the ship.

As carefully as she could, she crept through the hallways, turning whenever she heard voices or footsteps or any other sound. As she went, she felt herself losing track of her position in the ship relative to the drawings she had memorized earlier. Her anxiety mounted and she moved faster, not even sure if she was looking for the way out or a place to hide. She should have stayed in the engine room, which would not have much traffic passing through it, but it was too late now.

As she went, she felt a sensation that made her blood run cold: the strange twist in her gut that was the gravity engine at the center of the ship waking up, and beginning to lift them off the planet. At this point, she knew, there would be no escaping the ship.

The best place to be was the emergency shuttles, she realized. Ideally, Lord Castrop would not know that she was on board his ship, and when time came to evacuate onto the shuttles, she would still be safe. She turned in the direction she thought they were, but then realized that there were footsteps behind her. She hastened her pace, and ended up in another narrow corridor where she could hear voices in front of her, as well.

Hilde looked back and forth, frozen, pulling back the drapes from the walls to see if there was somewhere she could slip into, but there wasnâ€™t.

The footsteps and the voices came closer and closer, and the footsteps turned towards her. Hilde whirled on her heel and found herself face to face with guards with raised guns. They pointed their weapons at her. An involuntary yelp of terror left her mouth. â€œPleaseâ€”â€

The guards, although it didnâ€™t stop them from aiming their guns, seemed momentarily surprised by her appearance. She didnâ€™t look like the rest of the crowd who had broken into the ship: she was something completely different. It made them hesitate before shooting, and this was what saved her from becoming a victim of the guards, who had all been ordered to hunt down intruders.

From the other end of the corridor, the voices she had been hearing turned into running feet, and two women, dressed in Castropâ€™s preferred fashion, appeared. Hilde recognized them as some of the dancers that Castrop had made perform at dinner. They recognized her as well, blanching like they had seen a ghost.

â€œWhatâ€”â€ one of the dancers said.

â€œRudy! Put that gun down!â€ the other commanded.

One of the two guards, Rudy, did lower his weapon. The dancers glanced up and down the hallway, checking to see if anyone else was around.

â€œYou too, David,â€ the first dancer said. She had red hair, and long, dangling earrings. David, the second guard, was more wary, but also lowered his gun.Â 

The situation had immediately deflated into something still dangerous, but less outright fatal to Hilde, and she recognized that the dancers were her allies here, or at least people she could get some sympathy from.Â 

â€œWhat the hell are you doing here?â€ the black haired dancer asked. â€œWe had all assumed you were dead.â€

â€œIâ€”â€ Hilde began, and she realized that she was going to have to change her posture. If she wanted sympathy, she couldnâ€™t be someone who had broken onto the ship to destroy itâ€” she had to be more pathetic than that. â€œI wanted to find my father,â€ she said, and the choked sound in her voice, even if she had let it come out on purpose, was all too real.

â€œYou know this person?â€ Rudy asked.

â€œItâ€™s that countâ€™s daughter,â€ the black haired dancer said. â€œDid you not see her the other day?â€ It galled to feel like it was only her noble status and usefulness to Castrop that was about to keep her alive, as opposed to the hapless peasants who were being gunned down in the corridors, but that was the reason she had gone on the ship in the first place.

â€œI donâ€™t recognize people,â€ Rudy muttered, but he looked at Hilde with fresh eyes. â€œI did hear that you were dead.â€

Hilde just shook her head, not going to explain anything, pretending to be too choked up and overwhelmed. The dancers and guards looked at each other.

â€œHow old are you, girl?â€ the redhead asked.

â€œSixteen,â€ Hilde lied. That was probably the youngest she could get away with.

The redheaded dancer looked up and down the hallway again. â€œWhat the fuck are we going to do with you?â€ she muttered.Â 

The guard David, said, â€œGive her to the lord, obviously.â€

â€œAbsolutely not,â€ the black haired dancer said. â€œHeâ€” I canâ€™t have that on my head.â€

â€œThen what?â€ Rudy asked. â€œYou gonna put her in your room?â€

This proposition made both dancers wince. â€œNo,â€ the black haired one said. â€œLookâ€” Davidâ€”â€

â€œIs thisâ€ â€”he gestured at Hildeâ€” â€œreally what you want to fight with the lord over?â€

â€œNo,â€ she hissed. â€œI donâ€™t want anything to do with this.â€

The redhead spoke up. â€œGive her what she wants,â€ she said. â€œPut her in the cell with that count. Lord Castrop doesnâ€™t need to know the details right now. And if he finds outâ€” maybe heâ€™ll think someone told him she was there while he was drunk.â€

â€œThatâ€™s the stupidest fucking thing Iâ€™ve ever heard,â€ Rudy said.

Hilde stood there and listened to this argument, wide-eyed.

â€œLook, if we do that, none of us can get in trouble for itâ€” itâ€™s what Lord Castrop wanted in the first place,â€ the redhead hissed. â€œAnd it wonâ€™t be my problem anymore. At least there will be time to think about what to actually do with her. Unless you have a better idea.â€

â€œIt doesnâ€™t have to be anyoneâ€™s problem,â€ David said, and waved his gun. The black haired dancer shoved past Hilde and whacked his arm.

Hilde decided the situation was getting out of hand. She didnâ€™t love the idea of being imprisoned with her father, but she couldnâ€™t very well tell the four to hide her somewhere else and let her wanderâ€” she wasnâ€™t in any position to be making demands. â€œPlease can I see my father?â€ she said, letting her voice stay pathetic.

â€œSee,â€ the redhead said. â€œItâ€™s better for everyone. As long as one of you brings the food there and whatever elseâ€”â€

â€œYou really want to put this on us, hunh?â€ Rudy said. â€œYouâ€™re asking for a lot. Youâ€™ll owe me.â€

â€œWhatever,â€ the redhead said. â€œYouâ€™re going to have to deal with this one way or another. Itâ€™s your problem. You figure something out.â€

â€œFine, fine,â€ Rudy said. He glanced up and down the hallway now, and grabbed Hildeâ€™s arm. She stayed loose and floppy as he tugged her along, heading somewhere into the ship.

The dancers walked ahead, and the other guard, David, took a lookout behind, making sure that no one was coming up behind them as they walked. If someone had come, Hilde didnâ€™t know what they would do.

As they went, Hilde flinched as she saw a few bodies of other people who had broken onto the ship, lying shot dead on the floor, blood seeping through the grout cracks in the tiles. She knew it wouldnâ€™t help her to feel guilty for surviving this where these people hadnâ€™t, but she couldnâ€™t help it. The faces of the dead were agonized, or terrified, or surprised, and their open eyes followed her in her imagination as she walked.

Guilt could become resolve. That was what she needed right now. If what she was doing right now could play a part in never again letting Castrop have power over people like this, then she would do it. It wouldnâ€™t make a difference to the dead, but it would make a difference to someone.Â 

The sight of these bodies hastened the guards and dancers along, none of them wanting to look at them too closely. This distraction let Hilde quickly divest herself of the various incriminating objects she was carrying while no one was looking, dropping her gun and data stick into the spread arms of a few corpses they passed. She wished that she could have kept the gun, but she figured if she was going to be searched at any point, it would be better for her not to have it on her person.

The room where her father was being kept was in an innocuous hallway, hidden behind a curtain. David pulled it open, unlocked the door, and shoved Hilde inside. Realizing that they werenâ€™t going to bother to search her, she wished she had kept the gun. This was the stupid thought her brain fixated on as she fell to the floor, and the door shut behind her, leaving her in total darkness.Â 

Her father had not said anything, and probably hadnâ€™t had a chance to even see her face in the light. She glimpsed him sitting on the floor in the corner before they shut the door, looking haggard but not visibly wounded. She crawled over towards him.

â€œItâ€™s me,â€ Hilde said.

â€œHilde?â€ His voice broke.

â€œYeah.â€Â  His hand fumbled for her, and found her arm. She leaned on him. â€œWeâ€™ll be out of here soon,â€ she said. â€œHankâ€™s plan is going alright.â€

Her father was silent, except for his choked breathing. He could tell that the confidence in her voice was false. She was so grateful to him for not deciding to yell at her for being here. It was too late for telling her to stay safe to make any difference, and so chastizing her about it only would have served to make both of them feel worse.Â 

But she could feel his arm trembling against her; he was shaking with the kind of misery that couldnâ€™t be put into words. Again, the growing combination of guilt and resolve that this made her feel churned her stomach. Maybe it wasnâ€™t that he chose not to yell at herâ€” maybe he couldnâ€™t form the words, being overwhelmed by the idea of her as Castropâ€™s captive.

â€œReally, Dad,â€ she said, and she sounded more reassuring now, knowing that she had to be stronger. â€œEverythingâ€™s in place. As long as we can hold out for a few daysâ€¦â€

Â 

Â 

After they both slept, it was much easier to talk to her father about the plan, and convince him that it really was going to be alright, that Hilde had not doomed herself by coming to rescue him. As her father grew more confident in Leighâ€™s plan (though never fully), Hilde grew less, but she didnâ€™t let that into her voice. As long as she and her father were both able to act rationally, they would be fine.

It was miserable, being trapped in the dark there with him, but it was better than being alone. The passage of time was difficult to discern, only knowable through the intermittent delivery of meals and the changing of the chemical toilet. The guards who delivered their meals were always Rudy and David.Â 

For their efforts in keeping her safe, she wanted to warn them about the shipâ€™s impending doom, to make sure that they and the dancers got a spot on the shuttle when the ship was to be evacuated, but if she had done that, the whole plan might have been revealed.Â 

Since no one other than Rudy and David knew that there were two prisoners, only one meal was ever brought for both of them to eat. She and her father split it as evenly as they could, but she was sure that each of them were subtly trying to give the other the better half of their bread and cheese and water. The food and water were meager for even one, and her father had been subsisting on this diet since he had arrived on Castropâ€™s planet, so he was suffering more.

It must have been days that they were trapped in their little cell. As time passed, Hilde wondered when Leighâ€™s program would activate, and what would happen when it did. The stress mounted, but with no signal from the outside world, it was hard to feel like she could do anything about it.

â€œI wish there was a way for me to tell Hank that I was able to activate his program,â€ Hilde said. â€œMaybe he thinks that I didnâ€™t get the chance. Or maybe he hasnâ€™t told Castrop yet because he thinks he wouldnâ€™t be believedâ€” that itâ€™s a bluff.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know. I trust Leigh.â€ This was a sentiment that her father repeated, clinging to it. She clung to it, as well. It was about the only thing that they had.

Without an easy way to track time, Hilde had no idea of how long it was taking them to get to the other side of the galaxy, or what would happen to them if they arrived there before Leighâ€™s plan went into action. Possibly, Leigh had changed his mind about the plan, and would try to get his spy on Phezzan to save them. That was a long shotâ€” they probably wouldnâ€™t even land on the planet, just pass through that corridor. Leighâ€™s battleship wouldnâ€™t be able to follow them. Without pursuers, her father would lose value as a hostage.Â 

Some time into their captivity, there were loud voices outside the door of their cell. Hilde recognized them, muffled though they were: it was Rudy, the guard, and Lord Castrop. Hilde shook her father awake and whispered to him. â€œWhatâ€™s Lord Castrop doing here?â€

Rudyâ€™s voice grew louder, and he was taking a long time to unlock the door. He must intentionally be giving her time to compose herself, or trying to find a way to get Castrop to leave.

â€œHeâ€™s probably asleep, my lord. Itâ€™s not usually the time I feed him.â€

â€œWell, wake him up,â€ Castrop said. â€œWeâ€™re getting close to Phezzan. I think itâ€™s right for me to say my goodbyes.â€

â€œHeâ€™s going to killâ€”â€ Hilde whispered.

â€œYou need to get out of here,â€ her father whispered back, and he stood. Hilde stood as well. â€œWhen that door opens, you run. Find some place to hide or get in the shuttle, whatever you need to do, Hilde.â€

â€œButâ€”â€

The door swung open, blinding light spilling in on both of them. As it did, her father leaped at Lord Castrop, swinging his fist. Castrop reeled backwards, stunned, and it gave Hilde the tiniest window to slip out between them, run past the startled Rudy, and scramble down the hallway.

Her eyes were watering with pain in the bright hallway lights, and her legs were unused to so much movement after having sat on a floor for days, but she ran, stumbling over her own dress. She wasnâ€™t sure where she was in the ship, but she knew that the shuttle was in the lower area, and so every time she had an opportunity to descend a set of stairs, she took it.

As she ran through the hallways, she flew past startled men and women, no one expecting her to run by them. This gave her some time, the element of surprise working in her favor.

She even made it to the shuttle, in the unlocked bay where it sat. It was shiny and clean, alone on an empty floor, one of the few areas of the ship untouched by Castropâ€™s decorations. But the shuttle itself was locked, and none of the combinations she tried punching into the number pad could open the door. She stood there, pulling at it uselessly, and she could hear footsteps pounding down the halls now, coming after her. She wanted to barricade the door of the shuttle bay, but there was no way for her to lock it from where she was, and even if she had locked it, that would have just enabled someone to open the other, rear doors, and pull all the air out of the room to kill her.

So, as the footsteps came closer, she straightened, and although she was filthy and unkempt, tried to appear as imposing as she could. Or at least as uncowed.

The guards were the first to enter the bay, and they aimed their guns at her, but didnâ€™t shoot. Among them was David, and Hilde didnâ€™t meet his eyes. He had a blank expression on his face, and there was no point in her getting him in trouble, or in more trouble than he was going to be in already.

Lord Castrop took a minute longer to appear. His normally so smooth hair was ruffled, and his bare arm had a long, clawed scratch down it, visibly bloody.Â 

â€œYou and your father never cease to amuse me, Lady Mariendorf,â€ he said, his voice cold.

Hilde stayed silent. There was absolutely nothing she could say that would help her, so it was safer to say nothing at all.

â€œMy guards did say they found you breaking into my ship and took care of you. I suppose I made a wrong assumption about what that had entailed. I should have asked to see the body. Thatâ€™s twice now Iâ€™ve assumed you were dead. If there comes to be a third time, I suppose I will have learned my lesson.â€

Castrop waited for her to say something, but she simply stood there and stared at him.

â€œWhat are you doing here, trying to get into a shuttle?â€ he asked. â€œYou came all this way for your father, and youâ€™d just leave him behind?â€

â€œHe told me to go,â€ Hilde said.

â€œAnd youâ€™re such an obedient daughter of his. What a wonderful quality.â€

â€œIs he alive?â€

â€œHeâ€™s useful until we get past Phezzan, which shouldnâ€™t be long. After that, of course, he wonâ€™t be useful anymore.â€ Castrop looked at her. â€œBut you might be.â€

She didnâ€™t speak.

â€œDonâ€™t you want to know what Iâ€™ll use you for?â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œHow was my Artemis Necklace destroyed?â€ Castrop asked.

â€œI donâ€™t know.â€

â€œDo you think you still wonâ€™t know if youâ€™re asked very nicely?â€ Castrop asked. â€œThe rebel territoriesâ€” you know, they have their own Necklace around their capital planet. I think they will very much want to know what its weaknesses are. Youâ€™ll be valuable to me, in telling them. I donâ€™t know what methods theyâ€™ll use to get it out of you, but Iâ€™m happy to let them try.â€

â€œI donâ€™t have anything to say.â€

â€œWeâ€™ll see about that,â€ Castrop said, with a very smug expression. He turned away. â€œTake her away. Make sure she canâ€™t escape this time. I donâ€™t need any more fuss.â€

â€œThis ship is rigged to explode,â€ Hilde said as the guards came towards her. â€œYou need to evacuate.â€

Castrop smiled thinly. â€œI doubt it.â€

The guards stepped up and surrounded her, dragging her away. This time, she struggled against them, but this didnâ€™t earn her anything other than bruises where their hands crushed her arms to keep her still. They went all the way to the top of the ship, to a place that Hilde had not been before, and where the decor was much richer, even for the standards of this already gaudy vessel. When the guards opened the last door, leading into some sort of living suite, she realized that she had been brought to Castropâ€™s private quarters. She struggled against her captors, but no matter how she kicked, she couldnâ€™t get free.

The suite was comprised of a bedroom and a living room. The living room had a water fixture on the wall, a fountain that rushed down in a small, tame waterfall, and one of the guards plunged his hand through the water and pressed a secret button, so that the whole wall opened like a door, revealing another small room. They tied Hildeâ€™s arms behind her back, attached the tie to a clasp on the wall, stuffed a gag of fabric in her mouth, and slammed the door shut. Her ties were far too tight, and they bruised her arms.

Laying there in the dark, she couldnâ€™t get her heartrate down or her breathing under control. She couldnâ€™t decide if it was herself or her father she was afraid for. How far away were they from Phezzan? She wondered if there would be any chance for her to escape this. If they did make it past Phezzan, she would try to kill Castrop herself. Even if the ship was going to explode, sheâ€™d do it with her own hands if he came in here. She ran through whatever scenarios her mind could come up withâ€” none of them were pleasant, but it was the only thing she could think about. That, and her father, but it was betterâ€” easierâ€” less painfulâ€” to think about herself. She struggled to undo the ties binding her hands, but this only seemed to make them tighter, and they bit into her skin.

Time passed strangely, made worse by constantly expecting Castrop to reappear. Perhaps he was busy enough that he couldnâ€™t spare time for her.

It was so much worse to be a prisoner alone.

After what felt like, or maybe was, hours, Hilde heard noises outside. These noises didnâ€™t sound like Castrop at all. In fact, the voices she heard, past the burbling of the water fixture, didnâ€™t even sound like they were speaking the Imperial language. Had they bypassed Phezzan and made it into the rebel territories directly? This thought elated her and terrified herâ€” if they were in the rebel territories, her father was probably dead. But whoever these rebels were might be more sympathetic to her than Castrop. She would rather be a prisoner of war than a prisoner of Castrop.

Hilde tried to yell, but the gag muffled any sound she made. She yanked even harder at her restraints, trying to inch her way forward so that she could kick the door to signal her presence. The wall was just out of reach of her foot, no matter how she twisted her arms behind her back to give herself the maximum distance.

The voices faded away, and she almost cried. But she kept her wits about her, and she listened very closely, hoping that they would come back. Time passed, and still she strained against her bonds.Â 

Hilde almost gave up hope that someone else friendly, or at least not Lord Castrop, would come and find her. But then, very faint, she heard her fatherâ€™s voice, calling her name. If she had been a less realistic person, she might have thought it was the voice of a ghost. But she had never been prone to that kind of flight of fancy.

â€œHilde!â€ her father cried. â€œHilde!â€

Desperate, Hilde tried to make any noise, but it was muffled by the gag. She did the only thing that she could think of, which was to slip her feet out of her shoes, and blindly fumble for the edge of her shoe with her toe. She almost lost it, letting it slip away out of her reach, but she found it again. She was able to pick up her shoe with her feet, and whack it against the doorâ€” it gave her just a few extra inches of reach, which was all that she needed.

â€œDo you hear that?â€ her father asked. He was speaking in the language of the rebel territoriesâ€” which he wasnâ€™t very good at.

â€œNo,â€ said someone else in that same language.

â€œHilde!â€

â€œFraulein Mariendorf! Where are you?â€ yelled the other voice, switching to the Imperial language.

She renewed her whacking on the door with her shoe.

â€œThe door opener! Give it to me!â€ the other voice said, now back in the rebel language.

There was a fumbling, knocking sound at the door, and then the seal broke open, and water splashed into the room, along with a blinding light. Hilde dropped her shoe and squinted at her rescuer.

There was a young man in the doorway, wearing a rebel fleet uniform. He was, quite possibly, the most beautiful man Hilde had ever seen, but that might have just been the impression she got from the way the light haloed his braided blond hair, and the fact that he was saving her. Her father shoved past him and crouched down on the floor, untying her gag. He didnâ€™t say anything, just looked at her with an almost unbearable love and concern.

â€œAre we in the Alliance?â€ Hilde asked, speaking in the rebel language. The relief she felt made it so easy to ask practical questions, and she hoped that her father would understand that this meant she was fine.

â€œPhezzan,â€ her father and the rebel fleet soldier said simultaneously.

The soldier came over to her and inspected the ties binding her hands. They were thick wire ropes, so, rather than trying to cut through them, the soldier pulled out a pocket knife and pried the crimps apart to let her free. She sat up and rubbed some circulation back into her handsâ€” of all the parts of her, they had fared the worst. The skin on her wrists was ripped open from her trying to escape, and her hands were swollen.

â€œThank you, Mrâ€¦?â€

â€œLieutenant Commander Reinhard von MÃ¼sel,â€ the soldier said. â€œCan you stand up?â€ he switched into the Imperial languageâ€” from his name and how fluent he sounded, she was sure he must have been an Imperial expat of some sort.

She struggled to her feet, supporting herself on her father. â€œOh, Iâ€™m dizzy,â€ she said, but then she realized, in the light, that her father looked quite haggard. â€œAre you alright?â€ she asked.

â€œYes, Iâ€™m fine now. Are you?â€

â€œBeen better.â€ But it was delivered cheerfully, as much as the situation would allow, and she smiled at him.Â 

MÃ¼sel, who had been listening to this exchange, said, â€œIâ€™m sorry to rush you, but we really do need to get off this ship as soon as possible. Can you walk?â€

â€œLet me put my shoes back on,â€ she said, and did her best to slip them back onto her feet, struggling with her dress as she did. â€œGods, I hate this stupid dress.â€

As soon as she had her shoes on, MÃ¼sel hustled them out of Castropâ€™s suite, and down the hallways of the ship. There was evidence that the ship had been searched: many of the drapes that lined the walls were pulled back, revealing hidden closets, and probably the place where her father had been held.

As they walked out towards the entrance of the ship, they passed various members of Castropâ€™s entourage, all filing back in. They must have emptied out for the rebel fleet soldiers to search it. They watched MÃ¼sel leave with her and her father with strange expressions. Hilde stared straight ahead, keeping her mouth firmly shut. Perhaps she should have tried harder to warn them all about the damage that she had done to the ship, but she didnâ€™t. It seemed like her last chance to take revenge on Castop, for both her own sake, and for the sake of all the people he had ordered killed. If she had uttered this train of thought aloud to anyone, especially Leigh, she knew she would feel guilty. But she wasnâ€™t going to say a word.

When they finally reached the exit of the ship, and stumbled out into the overwhelm of the busy Phezzani spaceport, MÃ¼sel waved over a few other rebel fleet soldiers. To them, he said, â€œTake the Mariendofs down to the High Commissionerâ€™s Office. Get them any medical treatment that they need, and clean clothes, and lodgings for at least the night. I need to stay here in case I need to deal with Castrop himself, but Iâ€™ll want to talk to them later.â€

Her father, who knew enough of the rebel language to understand the conversation, said, â€œAm I your prisoner now, Lieutenant Commander?â€

â€œNo, sir. This is Phezzan. I have no authority to take prisoners.â€

â€œIâ€™ve been finding that authority to take prisoners is not something that is really necessary. Force will suffice.â€

â€œDad, we can cooperate.â€ At the very least, staying on the good side of these soldiers was the safe thing to do for the moment. On Phezzan, if they were treated badly, the Imperial embassy would certainly find out and have some way of dealing with it.

â€œYes, alright,â€ her father said.

â€œThank you,â€ MÃ¼sel replied. The soldiers escorted Hilde and her father away, and her father kept her close, pulling her to his side and putting his arm around her shoulder. She didnâ€™t mind that at all.

They were brought down the long space elevator to the surface of Phezzan, and, as MÃ¼sel had said, were taken care of. Hilde was able to shower, for the first time in many days. A doctor looked at her wrists and wrapped them in bandages with ointment. Someone asked what size clothes she wore, and she told them to get her a pair of pants, please. She felt like a human again, when she finally got to sit down and eat something, some takeout food that a soldier procured.Â 

They were stuck in the Allianceâ€™s offices, sat in a conference room with huge plate glass windows. Occasionally, soldiers walked by and looked at them curiously, but no one was hostile to them, and hardly anybody bothered them. The man in charge of the whole operation, a commodore by the name of Blackwell, stopped in briefly and asked them about what they had been doing on Castropâ€™s ship. Her father answered in generalities, describing his trip to the planet, to negotiate with Castrop, and how that had gone wrong. The commodore didnâ€™t seem enthused about this answer, but didnâ€™t press further, and instead left after a few minutes.

He reappeared later, outside the door, with MÃ¼sel. Hilde couldnâ€™t hear the conversation he had with the lieutenant commander, but both parties could see each other. A mutual observation.

MÃ¼sel came in, which made both Hilde and her father stand. He waved at the table and took a seat across from them. They both sat back down, wary but not too afraid.

â€œCastrop left for Heinessen,â€ he said. â€œHowâ€™s your dinner?â€

â€œGood, thank you,â€ Hilde said.

â€œI appreciate the Allianceâ€™s hospitality very much,â€ her father said. He spoke in Imperial, but he dipped into the rebel language to name their country, which made Hilde smile, though she hid it behind her cup of water. MÃ¼sel smiled, too. Her father was diplomatic as always.

â€œWell, youâ€™re on Phezzan,â€ MÃ¼sel said. â€œItâ€™s in everyoneâ€™s best interest to be hospitable around here.â€

â€œWill we be allowed to leave?â€ her father asked.

â€œI assume you have no desire to immigrate to the Alliance. Youâ€™re welcome to, of course, or you can stay on Phezzan and do as you please.â€

â€œNo, I donâ€™t believe that would be in anyoneâ€™s best interest. Iâ€™m very grateful that I will have the opportunity to return to my own life, with my daughter.â€

MÃ¼sel pulled a pad of paper from the center of the table, and wrote something down on it, before passing it to her father. â€œWhen you walk out of here, go see Lieutenant Commander Neidhart Muller, over in the Imperial Embassy. Heâ€™ll make sure you get where you need to go.â€

â€œYou know him?â€ she asked. It seemed very odd that a man whose nation was at war with hers would be friendly enough with the enemy to have a personal recommendation of who to speak to.

â€œPhezzan is a very small planet. Itâ€™s inevitable that you cross paths with your counterpart on the other side, on occasion. He has a reputation for being dependable, anyway.â€

â€œThank you,â€ her father said. â€œMay I ask a question?â€

â€œOf course.â€

â€œYou said that you knew Captain Leigh. Could you explain how?â€

â€œYou know Hank?â€ Hilde asked. Was this Leighâ€™s spy on Phezzan? Her heart leapedâ€” Leigh must have sent him personally to rescue her and her father.

â€œThatâ€™s a strong word for it,â€ MÃ¼sel said. â€œI fled the Empire when I was ten, with my mother and sister. My next door neighbor, when I was a child, was one of Captain Leighâ€™s students.â€

â€œHow do you know that? Which student?â€ Hilde was leaning forward over the table.

MÃ¼sel raised an eyebrow, so her father explained, â€œMy daughter weasled her way into attending some of Captain Leighâ€™s classes when he taught at the Imperial Officers Academy. She might have been his classmate.â€

MÃ¼sel smiled. â€œWere you following the news ofâ€” not this most recent February, but the one before thatâ€” when Rear Admiral Reuenthal attacked Condor Base?â€

â€œYes, I know about that,â€ Hilde said.

â€œI donâ€™t believe Imperial papers carried the full story. Rear Admiral Reuenthal took the base staff prisoner. I was stationed there at the time, and, with a friend of mine, Lieutenant Commander Greenhill, we were able to commandeer a ship and rescue the prisoners. During that process, I overheard a conversation between Rear Admiral Reuenthal and Captain Leigh, talking about his students. Thatâ€™s how I knew of Captain Leigh.â€

â€œOskar never told me about that,â€ Hilde said, glancing at her father and leaning back in her chair. â€œIâ€™ll have to beg him for details, next time I see him.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure the rear admiral does not want to regale you with that story,â€ her father said.

â€œHe won the engagement,â€ MÃ¼sel pointed out.

â€œWait, but who is the student of Hankâ€™s that you know?â€

MÃ¼sel put his hand on his chest. â€œSiegfried Kircheis. Do you know him?â€

Hilde laughed aloud. â€œOh, gods, yes, I know him. Heâ€™s my closest friend. He was justâ€”â€ Her happiness was cut off when she realized that she had no idea what had happened to Kircheis after she left Castropâ€™s planet. She had been assuming that he was fine, but she had no way of knowing.

â€œSmall universe,â€ her father said. â€œSub-Lieutenant Kircheis is a good man.â€

â€œPlease give him my fondest regards.â€

â€œI will, I promise,â€ Hilde said.

â€œWhat were you doing on Castropâ€™s planet, if I may ask?â€ He looked at her, specifically.

â€œThere was the idea that I might be able to negotiate for my fatherâ€™s release. Obviously, it failed.â€

â€œAnd how did you end up being taken prisoner?â€

â€œI knew Castrop was going to use my father as a bargaining chip for as long as he could. So, I was attempting to free him, and I ended up trapped as well.â€

â€œI see. And what caused Castrop to leave his planet?â€ This was a very pointed question, and her father deliberately stepped in.

â€œI donâ€™t know. Neither of us were in much of a position to observe what was going on, when we finally ended up on his ship.â€

MÃ¼selâ€™s eyes narrowed, but he nodded. â€œCastrop said that the Artemis Necklace that was protecting his planetâ€” the same one that protects Heinessenâ€” was destroyed, and that caused him to flee. Do you know anything about that?â€

â€œIf anyone could do something like that, it would be Hank,â€ Hilde said.

â€œBut you donâ€™t know how he did it.â€

â€œNo,â€ her father said confidently.

â€œI lost contact with him before everything happened. I donâ€™t know what he did.â€

â€œAlright,â€ MÃ¼sel said. â€œI appreciate your honesty.â€ He stood, and Hilde and her father did as well. MÃ¼sel offered his hand to her father, and then her, shaking their hands. â€œIf you need anything else while on Phezzan, donâ€™t hesitate to contact me, or anyone else at the High Commissionerâ€™s Office.â€

â€œThank you,â€ her father said. â€œI owe you a great debt, for myself, and for my daughter.â€

â€œDonâ€™t worry about it,â€ MÃ¼sel said with a smile. â€œI have developed something of a reputation for freeing captives, it seems.â€

Hilde laughed. â€œIt was a pleasure to meet you, Lieutenant Commander. I wish I could get to know you better.â€

â€œThis war wonâ€™t last forever, Fraulein Mariendorf. When it ends, perhaps we can be friends.â€

â€œI would like that very much.â€

She and her father were let out of the Allianceâ€™s offices, and onto the bustling streets of Phezzan. It was so different from Castropâ€™s planet and Odin that Hilde had difficulty taking it in for a minute, just standing on the street corner and listening to all the noise. People rushed by hither and thither, and neon lights buzzed from every window, and cars had to fight with pedestrians for passage on the streets. The buildings rose up so high at points that the thick evening clouds surrounded them.

â€œShould we go directly to the embassy?â€ Hilde asked her father after she had taken stock of her senses.

Her father nodded silently, and pointed down the street, beginning to walk. He had been to Phezzan before, for business and pleasure, and so was familiar with it where Hilde was not. He seemed morose, or at least lost in thought, despite the fact that they were free.

â€œIs something the matter?â€ she said after a few minutes of walking, dodging in between other pedestrians. â€œAre you okay?â€

It took a moment for her father to answer. â€œI wonâ€™t question your decision,â€ he said, â€œbut you didnâ€™t tell the rebels that you sabotaged Lord Castropâ€™s ship.â€

She lifted her chin, looking up in the black sky above. â€œNo, I didnâ€™t.â€

Her father nodded.Â 

â€œIâ€™ll tell Lieutenant Commander Muller, in the Imperial Embassy,â€ she said.

â€œYou know that he wonâ€™t do anything with that information.â€

â€œProbably not.â€

He looked over at her. â€œDid Castrop hurt you?â€

â€œNo,â€ she said. She wasnâ€™t sure if her father believed her, but she was telling the truth. â€œI was very lucky, or there just wasnâ€™t time.â€

After a moment, her father said, â€œCaptain Leigh would not want those people to die for no reason.â€

â€œIâ€™ll tell Lieutenant Commander Muller,â€ she said again. â€œIf he doesnâ€™t do anything with it, then itâ€™s the crownâ€™s decision.â€

â€œOne that youâ€™ll have to live with.â€

â€œHe was going to kill you!â€

â€œHe didnâ€™t.â€

â€œDo you want me to turn around and go tell the rebel fleet to pull Castrop off his ship?â€

â€œNo,â€ he said. â€œIf I really wanted that, I would also do it myself.â€

She nodded. There was a part of her that had been convinced to change her mind, but she stopped herself. The guilt was heavy in her stomach, but she tried to twist that feeling into resolve.Â 

Chapter End Notes

not sure if i love this chapter lol but i'm glad to be free of it. finally we can move on to the actually interesting parts of this book ğŸ˜… not that it hasn't had its moments so far, but a lot has been rehashing LOFTT and now we finally get to original material :3c hold onto your hats etc

i feel like the thing about hilde is that in the OVA she takes on these roles that aren't always natural to her, because she's trying to be what reinhard needs from her-- she's a replacement annerose and a replacement kircheis at times. and she's pretty good at that. but i think it is not... if she didn't feel like it was something that she was "required" to do, that it was a hole that she needed to fill, i'm not sure that she would behave like that naturally. she's a tempering influence in the OVA, but in a situation where she doesn't need to temper anyone-- her closest relationships in WIAW are the chillest characters around, Yang and Kircheis-- what is her natural state? we know in the OVA she is political and shrewd, and she's not afraid to take risks. nor is she exactly afraid of violence-- at the end of S1 when reinhard's fleets are invading the capital, she's thrilled rather than terrified, even though this is a military attack on her home that will lead to bloodshed. anyway all that is to say that i don't think hilde is cruel or wants violence for its own sake, but i also am not sure she would always take the high road when it's offered. idk. you can disagree with me if you want lol

thank you very very much to em for the beta read as always

social medias: javert @ tumblr, natsinator @ twitter , gayspaceopera.carrd.co , discord https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

Lord of Lies

October 487 I.C., Odin

Yangâ€™s journey back to Odin would have been a lot worse if he hadnâ€™t gotten the chance to speak with Hilde and Count Mariendorf on the ansible, once they were safe on Phezzan. He and Kircheis breathed a mutual sigh of relief to see them both safe and as well as could be expected. Yang apologized deeply for not freeing Hilde and the count from Lord Castropâ€™s ship earlier. Although Yang had chased his ship as far as he could, right until the entrance to the Phezzan corridor, and had tried to tell Castrop about the sabotage on his vessel to get him to abandon it, Castrop had paid no attention to his bluffâ€” though it was in no way a bluff.

So, although the prevailing feeling was reliefâ€” everyone he cared about had gotten out safelyâ€” a cloud of worry and guilt hung over Yang on his way back home. It wasnâ€™t just the fact that he worried his relationship with Count Mariendorf might be permanently strained. He felt bad for the news he had received from Muller on Phezzan, that Castrop was dead. This seemed like Yangâ€™s fault, and a pointless loss of life. He had warned Muller about the sabotage, but, of course, Muller had his own duties, which involved stopping Castrop, now a traitor, from fleeing to the Alliance.

Yang also wasnâ€™t sure what to expect upon his arrival back homeâ€” his letter to the Kaiser had surely been received, but Yang had heard nothing in response, which seemed like a worrying sign. At the very least, if he was going to be arrested for going against the Kaiserâ€™s will, it seemed like it would happen on the ground. No warship had been dispatched to shoot him down, though he made his route quite public, following all the usual rules about the movements of military ships within the Empire, which would have made him very easy to hunt down en route.

But when he arrived back at Odin, he settled his ship back into Braunschweigâ€™s fleet hangars without incident. And when Yang stepped out of the spaceport and into the chill October air, there were no police waiting for him, or any other kind of trouble. No trouble, except for Magdalena, who met him at the doors, sitting alone in her convertible right outside. Although it was well into autumn, she had the roof downâ€” she liked the feeling of wind in her hair more than she hated the cold, and she was dressed in a sleek fur coat to compensate.

â€œIf it isnâ€™t the talk of the town!â€ she called, to get his attention, not like she needed to do anything to capture his attention.

Kircheis, who had followed Yang out, beat a swift retreat back into the spaceport, and Yang watched him go dolefully, then climbed into Magdalenaâ€™s car.

â€œI could have given a ride to your little lackey,â€ she said, looking affronted. â€œDoes Herr Kircheis not trust my driving skills?â€

â€œI think he just wanted to give us space,â€ Yang said.

â€œAww.â€ Magdalena revved her car and pulled out into the street. â€œHeâ€™s such a considerate young man.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t realize you were going to meet me here.â€

â€œAnd what kind of a fiancee would I be if I didnâ€™t?â€ she asked. â€œItâ€™s not like I have much else going on.â€

â€œIs that so?â€ Yang asked, and Magdalena just laughed.

â€œUsually, Iâ€™d say itâ€™s boring around here without you, but you have this unique talent of making things interesting even when youâ€™re half the galaxy away.â€

â€œTo be honest, I expected to be met at the spaceport by MPs coming to arrest me,â€ Yang said. â€œIf thatâ€™s the kind of â€˜interestingâ€™ that youâ€™re talking about.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure itâ€™s one and the same.â€ Even though she was driving, whipping around corners a little too quickly, Magdalena reached across the car to fish in her purse for something. It was heavy envelope, which she handed to Yang.

â€œWhatâ€™s this?â€ he asked, though he could tell from the seal exactly who the letter was from.

â€œThe Kaiser wants an audience with you,â€ she said. â€œThatâ€™s your invite.â€

â€œDo you know what for?â€ The letter in his hands felt like a live bomb, and he pried it open but didnâ€™t look at it.

â€œNot a clue,â€ Magdalena said. â€œBut since I thought you were out of His Majestyâ€™s good graces, Iâ€™m pleased that youâ€™ve somehow found your way back into them.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know how I could have. Did Princess Amarie say something to him?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know. Itâ€™s possible. I like the princess, but Iâ€™m not exactly her bosom friend, however much Iâ€™d like to be. So Iâ€™m not aware of all her activities.â€

â€œShe probably would have told you if she was intervening on my behalf.â€ Yang sighed and looked out at the road. â€œI just want things to be simple, you know.â€

â€œThey never will be. What does the letter say?â€

Yang finally looked at it, reading it slowly. â€œItâ€™s a formal audience, in front of the whole court. Next week.â€ He laughed bitterly. â€œI could really do without that. Before, when the Kaiser wanted to speak to me, it was always private. Nobody in the court likes me, so thereâ€™s no reason for him to show me off in front of them if heâ€™s happy with me. He probably wants to make a point about Braunschweig stepping out of lineâ€¦â€Â 

The possibilities tumbled around in his head, and most of them were pretty unpleasant. The fact that it was an invitation made him think he wasnâ€™t in any personal danger, but he was sure it was about to be a political mess. He flipped the thick card over in his handsâ€” this probably hadnâ€™t actually come from the Kaiser, but from Marquis Lichetenlade, the prime minister. Yang could practically feel the political chastizing that he and Duke Braunschweig were about to be subjected to.

â€œDress nicely,â€ Magdalena said. â€œThatâ€™s my advice.â€

â€œIâ€™ll wear my dress uniform.â€

She shook her head.

â€œHas anything else been happening while Iâ€™ve been gone?â€ Yang asked, struggling to change the subject. Magdalena was only too happy to comply.

â€œIâ€™ve been working very hard on planning our wedding,â€ she said. â€œI made some selections for the menu and the decorations. Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ll love them.â€

â€œYou have excellent taste, Maggieâ€” I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll have any criticisms.â€

She laughed at him for that. â€œYou wouldnâ€™t know good taste if it bit you. But Iâ€™ll be grateful that youâ€™re correctly choosing not to question my choices.â€

â€œAm I in any danger of getting bitten by good taste?â€

Luckily, they were at a stop light, so when Magdalena leaned over to nip at Yangâ€™s earlobe, she didnâ€™t send the car swerving off the road.

November 487 I.C., Odin

Yang had been to Neue Sanssouci many times, so many that he had lost count, so it wasnâ€™t unfamiliarity that was making him nervous as he waited in the formal hall for the audience with the Kaiser. He had even been to these audiences before, tagging along after Duke Braunschweig a couple times, so he was familiar with the procedure. Every party who had some stake in the business of the day was gathered in the great hall, waiting for the Kaiser to come in and give his judgements or favors or, more rarely, punishments to those he needed to speak to. Lately, because of the Kaiserâ€™s declining health, this duty had often been performed by the prime minister, instead. As Yang stood in the hall, shuffling nervously on his toes, he expected that it would be Lictenladeâ€™s dour figure who emerged from the heavy doors at the end of the room.

There were a great number of other people in attendance, though Yang doubted that most of them had anything to do with his summons. The Kaiser had many diverse pieces of business to attend to in these forums. But it made the room crowded, and the looks that Yang received from many of the nobles standing across from him were unpleasant in the extreme. Yang wondered if this was just the normal looks, or if these ones were now tinged with something elseâ€” fear, maybe. Having gone to single handedly attack Lord Castropâ€™s planet, what was stopping Yang from going after any other noble?

Duke Braunschweig had received an invitation to this audience, as had Count Mariendorf, and, strangely, Magdalena. Yang imagined that, since they were all associated with him, they had been invited to witness whatever Lichtenlade had to say. Count Mariendorf brought Hilde with him, but Hilde had been very disappointed to find that Duke Braunschweig had not brought his own daughter to tag along. So, she was standing with Magdalena, waiting for the whole show to start.Â 

Yang had only gotten to say a few words in greeting to the count, and he wasnâ€™t sure if he had been forgiven yet. He didnâ€™t deserve to be forgiven, of course, but he had to think that getting yelled at by the crown might earn him some sympathy on that front.

Braunschweig was not in a pleasant mood. Yang could tell from the way that Braunschweig coldly looked around, but he kept a smile on his face for the rest of the court. At least there werenâ€™t any members of the Littenheim clan in attendance, which prevented Braunschweigâ€™s mood from getting out of hand.

Yang steered clear of the duke, which was easy enough, because Braunschweig usually wanted nothing to do with him at public social events. This suited them both well. But all of this meant that Yang was standing by himself, just watching as everyone who needed to speak to the Kaiser filed in. If Magdalena hadnâ€™t been so absorbed in chatting with Hilde, she would have come over and smacked Yangâ€™s hands away from his hair. He kept running his fingers through it, his usual nervous habit, and while it had been combed smooth to match the neat appearance of his dress uniform when he arrived, it was now quite floppy and out of sorts.

As the appointed time approached, the room ceased to be a casual social gathering, and everyone took up their final positions in the room, lined up along the carpet, looking expectantly towards the front. A minute or so before the clock struck, one last guest walked in: Fleet Admiral Muckenburger. He ended up in a position directly across from Yang, people shuffling positions to give him room.

The great doors swung open. Unsurprisingly, it was Lichtenlade who walked in, accompanied by secretaries and guards. Yang felt the kind of relief that came with a bad premonition finally coming true, and his shoulders slumped. Fleet Admiral Muckenburgerâ€™s eyes followed Yangâ€™s changed posture, and his lips twitched in an almost invisible frown. Yang averted his eyes, and tried to stand up straighter.

The business of the day, which Lichtenlade began to address without any fanfare whatsoever, was extensive, and in the long first section, none of it had anything to do with Yang. He almost completely tuned it out, but anxiety made him listen for his own name. He idly wondered what Muckenburger was here for, because so far none of the petitions that Lichtenlade heard and addressed had anything to do with the military. Muckenburger, too, seemed to be in his own thoughts, not reacting to any of the business passing before him as he stood perfectly at attention and looked straight ahead.Â 

The minutes dragged on. After some time, Lichtenlade fell silent, having perhaps addressed everyone in the room, aside from Yang. He made a signal to some of the guards, and they turned and opened the heavy doors at the end of the room once again. Lichtenlade stepped back, and Kaiser Friedrich walked out. The whole roomâ€™s tenor changed completely, everyone shifted (aside from Muckenburger), even if they had the good grace not to gasp.

It had only been about a year since Yang had last seen the Kaiser in person, but he looked much worse than he had at Count Marbachâ€™s funeral. He had lost a significant amount of weight, and his face seemed like his skin revealed every contour of his skull. The Kaiser wasnâ€™t even that old, so it seemed clear to Yang that he was suffering from some sort of illness, and possibly had been for quite some time. Either his decline was progressing more rapidly than it had been, or he had given up efforts to disguise it, or a combination.

The sight of him in this state made Yang feel very strange. He was the Kaiser of the Galactic Empire, an institution that Yang despised on principle. He was a lecherous old man, one who wielded too much power that he had no right to. But his ill health meant that billions of people were about to be plunged into a civil war, which was a tragedy that Yang wished he could prevent, even by keeping the Kaiser alive. And, beyond all that, beyond every political consideration: Friedrich had always been unduly kind to Hank von Leigh. The sadness that Yang felt, gazing at the Kaiser, was, at least in part, a personal one.

He wondered, sparing a glance around the rest of the room, if there was a single other person who felt the same. Not Lichtenlade, not Muckenburger, not Count Mariendorf or Magdalena, and certainly not Duke Braunschweig. Perhaps Yang was the only one who bothered to see Friedrich as he wasâ€” a sad and lonely old man. It was Friedrichâ€™s fault, Yang supposed, for clinging so completely to the power that kept him from being cared for as a person, but it still was a lonely existence, to be nothing more than a vessel for power, empty of all human spirit, in everyoneâ€™s eyes.

Yang shook himself out of his contemplation as the Kaiser sat down on his chair at the head of the room, and everyone held their breath, waiting for him to speak.

â€œCount Mariendorf,â€ he said, stretching out his hand.

Everyone, including Yang, was surprised by this summons, but the count stepped out before the Kaiser and knelt. â€œYour Majesty.â€

â€œCount Mariendorf, I sent you as an agent of the crown to bring Maximillian von Castrop before me. I am told that you were taken hostage, and you have suffered as the crownâ€™s agent.â€

â€œYes, Your Majesty. I apologize for failing to bring him before you.â€

The Kaiser waved his hand. â€œHe is dead, it makes little difference now.â€

â€œYes, Your Majesty.â€

â€œYou were freed from your captivity by an agent of Duke Braunschweig, is that correct?â€

â€œYes, Your Majesty. Captain von Leigh was responsible for it.â€

â€œSo Iâ€™ve heard.â€

â€œYour Majesty, it was at my daughterâ€™s request that Duke Braunschweig lent his strength to free me,â€ he said. â€œIt was not meant as an insult to the crown.â€

â€œCount Mariendorf, if I had sent my fleets to Planet Castrop, do you believe that they would have succeeded in freeing you?â€

This put the count in a very awkward position, and from his place on the floor, his eyes flicked around the room. â€œIâ€™m not a military man, Your Majesty. And Lord Castrop was a fickle and vindictive personâ€” I donâ€™t know what he would have done if a whole fleet had arrived at his doorstep. I couldnâ€™t speak of hypotheticals like that.â€

â€œVery well.â€ The Kaiser looked at him for a long second. â€œThis duty was performed for the crown, but it was your loyalty to Duke Braunschweig which saved you, was it not?â€

â€œYour Majesty, if I may speak plainlyâ€”â€

â€œYou may.â€

â€œI am very grateful to Duke Braunschweig for loaning me his aid. I will owe him a debt for my entire life. But I do not doubt that, had Duke Braunschweig refused to loan my daughter a ship and crew, my daughter would have found some other way to try to free me.â€

â€œAnd Captain von Leigh?â€

The count hestated. He was clearly trying to protect Yangâ€” Hilde was relatively untouchable as a political figure, since she had very little power and there would be no point in punishing her, so it was easy to say that she would have done something, true as it was. Yang was a different storyâ€” for him to be Duke Braunschweigâ€™s agent was one thing, for him to act independently was another. Yang wasnâ€™t sure which was preferable, in the eyes of the crown. But Count Mariendorf was an honest man. â€œYes, Your Majesty. Captain von Leigh would have, as well.â€

â€œHe must value your friendship very highly.â€

â€œYes, Your Majesty.â€

â€œI understand that this has been a difficult ordeal for you, on the crownâ€™s business,â€ the Kaiser said. â€œIf you wish to be released from your duties to the crown, I release you.â€

â€œNo, Your Majesty,â€ the count said. â€œI prefer to put this incident behind me. So long as Your Majesty has use of my services, I am happy to provide them.â€

â€œSo long as I have use of them,â€ the Kaiser said, with a dark half-laugh. â€œVery well. That is all,Â  Count Mariendorf.â€

â€œCaptain von Leigh,â€ the Kaiser said.

â€œI read your letter, Captain von Leigh,â€ the Kaiser said.

â€œIâ€™m glad that it made it to you, Your Majesty.â€

â€œCount Mariendorf believes that you would go to great lengths for your friends. Is this true?â€

â€œWho would say that?â€

â€œI see.â€ The Kaiser stared at Yang for a second. â€œIn your letter, you wondered if there had ever been any friendship between us. If there had been, what would you expect me to do for you, Captain Leigh?â€

â€œAnd you asked for the crown to give special care to Lord Castropâ€™s people.â€

â€œYes, Your Majesty.â€ Yang lifted his head to look at the Kaiser. â€œNot for my own sakeâ€” but those people deserve more than Lord Castrop was allowing them. I hope that you will consider it.â€

â€œI have considered it, Captain.â€

â€œAnd?â€ He regretted the question as soon as he asked it, but, even kneeling, Yang couldnâ€™t help but speak his mind when it came to things like that.

â€œEvery question Iâ€™ve ever asked you, youâ€™ve answered honestly. I would hope that you would answer this one in the same way.â€

â€œYour Majesty, itâ€™s not for me to decide. The gap between usâ€” in station, in life, in everythingâ€” is too large. The Kaiserâ€™s silence stretched on, making Yang deeply uncomfortable. Everyone in the room seemed to be holding their breath.

â€œYouâ€™re marrying Baroness Westpfale?â€

â€œCaptain Hank von Leigh, over the years I have known you, you have rendered service to the crown many times. The honest and true answer was that no matter how high Yang was raised, the gap could not be closed. As soon as the door shut behind him, the room, which had been dead silent, erupted into chaos. Every noble in the room seemed to have something to say, either to Yang or at him, or about him. Magdalena, who had been grinning widely, realized that the sentiment in the room was approaching dangerous, and tried to step towards Yang, along with the Mariendorfs. â€œCaptain Leigh, if I may speak with you for a moment?â€ Muckenburger asked.Â

â€œI wonâ€™t take up too much of your time, Captain Leigh,â€ Muckenburger said.

â€œI donâ€™t need anything, at the moment, Leigh, but I wanted to make something very clear to you.â€

â€œIs this aboutâ€” I swear Iâ€”â€

â€œNo,â€ Muckenburger said. â€œI donâ€™t care one bit about court politics.â€ Yang remembered that Muckenburger was actually a count, but he had never once heard anyone refer to him that way. â€œThat makes two of us, sir.â€

Luckily, Yangâ€™s disappearance from the crowd had allowed the crowd to disperse, and so Yang was able to peek back around a corner and find Magdalena waiting for him, leaning against the wall, the picture of relaxation, even if he knew her well enough by now to guess that this was probably as much of a carefully controlled persona as anything else.

â€œAnd you thought this would go badly!â€ Magdalena said.

Yang shoved the silver scroll into her hands. â€œLetâ€™s get out of here,â€ he said.

Â 

Â 

Although Magdalena acted nothing but thrilled about Yangâ€™s change in fortunes, Yang couldnâ€™t bring himself to share her enthusiasm. When she sent him back to his apartment, leaving him alone with his thoughts for the first time that day, Yang could do nothing but pace back and forth in front of the fireplace, occasionally interrupting his tracks around the room to go run over to his desk and scribble a passing thought down on a scrap of paper.

He had no desire to rule, or inherit, or participate in the structure of Imperial society. It was a cruel joke that the Kaiser was playing on him, and the Kaiser had to know that. Friedrich had always appreciated Yang for his complete lack of enthusiasm in the palaceâ€™s power games: he wasnâ€™t a crawling status seeker; he was nobody, and wanted to stay nobody. Friedrich probably was amused at Yangâ€™s expense, even if the gift, and talk of friendship, had been genuine. He probably thought that giving Yang status of his own would be a way to protect him after his death, moreso than just being married to Magdalena.Â 

The fact that the Kaiserâ€™s generosity probably was real only made it feel worse. He seemed to genuinely believe that Yang was capable of running a planet. To hear Magdalena say it, Yang was barely capable of dressing himself in the morning. Why should he have power over a million other people?Â 

He knew that these whining thoughts were born out of a helpless bitterness, and completely unproductive for it, but that didnâ€™t stop him from having them. Heâ€™d reach the end of his room in his pacing, have some other aspect of the situation occur to him (â€œAnd another thing!â€) and turn angrily on his heel to complain to an imaginary audience on his way across the floor in the other direction.Â 

Yang exhausted himself with this, but it was at least better that he got it out of his system by the time he reported for work the next day, trying to slink back into his office like nothing had changed. Even Kircheis said nothing, until he came up to Yangâ€™s office to ask about a delivery of supplies intended for Cahokia. He got through his business quickly, but Yangâ€™s constant distracted glances out the window made him finally ask, â€œAre you alright, sir?â€Â 

â€œAre you, Kircheis?â€ Yang asked. He smiled at Kircheis, who, in his endless patience, did not seem to mind Yangâ€™s latest attempt to slip back into his teacher persona to free himself from thinking about his own troubles.Â

â€œDid that have anything to do with you, sir?â€Â

â€œNo, sir, of course not.â€ He looked away.Â 

â€œI told Muller to do whatever he could to help,â€ Yang said. â€œI knew that would probably involve your friend, as they have some sort of working relationship, there on Phezzan.â€ He tilted his head to study Kircheis. â€œYour friend seems like a good man.â€Â

It took a second for Franz to compose his answer. â€œItâ€™s because you are a good man, that it is your responsibility. You are intelligent, and capable, and fair.
