â€œItâ€™s not really about capability, sir,â€ Yang said.

â€œItâ€™s not?â€

â€œIâ€™m a soldier, sir. I know I couldnâ€™t go into a battle and ask the soldiers to vote on what we should do.â€

â€œThis is no different, then.â€

â€œNo, it is.â€ Yang tugged at the hair on the back of his head. â€œPeople should have the ability to decide how to live their lives.â€

â€œItâ€™s not like youâ€™re decreeing what everyone should eat for breakfast,â€ the count said.

â€œNo, but I would decide the law, and how the law is enforced, and if I were a petty tyrant I could kill people for petty offenses. Castrop certainly did. He shouldnâ€™t have had that powerâ€” and not just because he was a bad ruler, but because no one should have that power.â€

â€œI see,â€ the count said, though he sounded like he didnâ€™t agree whatsoever. â€œBut that doesnâ€™t change the facts. You still are the lord, and you are responsible.â€

â€œI know,â€ Yang said. â€œI actually also came here to ask Hilde something.â€

â€œOh?â€

â€œIâ€™m sure as your heir, sheâ€™s had more of an education on running an estate than Iâ€™ve had.â€

â€œWhat did you want to ask her?â€

â€œIf she wants the position of administering it for me,â€ Yang said. â€œI figured she would enjoy the work, and it would give her some experienceâ€” sheâ€™ll want that for when sheâ€™s in charge of the Mariendorf lands.â€

The count considered it. â€œYou can ask her. I have no real objections, but I suspect that sheâ€™ll say no.â€

â€œWhy?â€

â€œSheâ€™s busier than you think she is.â€

â€œWith school?â€

â€œNo. It seems like she failed to mention something to you.â€

â€œWhat?â€

â€œIn exchange for Duke Braunschweigâ€™s help, sheâ€™s agreed to become Lady Elizabethâ€™s personal advisor. I expect that is going to take up quite a lot of her attention.â€

This thought ticked around in Yangâ€™s brain. â€œAnd you approve of that?â€

â€œYou donâ€™t?â€

â€œItâ€™s not my place to approve or disapprove.â€

â€œWhat do you think of it, then?â€

â€œI think Lady Elizabeth is a complicated young woman, and being that close to power will be dangerous for Hilde. But if she wants that, then itâ€™s her choice.â€

â€œYes, it is.â€

â€œAnd what do you think of it?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Franz said. â€œI understand Duke Braunschweig, but I keep feeling like Iâ€™m completely out of touch with the younger generation. Maybe the world is changing, or maybe Iâ€™m just getting old.â€

â€œYouâ€™re not that old, sir.â€

Franz laughed. â€œWhat will you do, if Hilde says no?â€

Yang sighed. â€œI will write up as comprehensive a directive as I can, and have the man Maggie recommends administer it for me,â€ he said. â€œSheâ€™s offered to take care of everything.â€

â€œUsually itâ€™s the other way around, when a couple gets married,â€ Franz said. â€œBut Iâ€™m glad that you have been blessed with a competent future wife.â€

â€œShe covers up my glaring weaknesses pretty well,â€ Yang said. He thought about their argument of the night before, the image of Maggie twisting the ruby engagement ring around her finger. He reached to refill his glass of whiskey, and the count didnâ€™t object. â€œSheâ€™s too good for me.â€

Â 

Â 

On Monday, Yang made his way to the Braunschweig manor. It was ostensibly a trip to discuss with Duke Braunschweig what supplies they needed to put on Cahokia, as well as various bases around the Empire, but Yang also wanted to see Elizabeth. He had a strange feeling about Hildeâ€™s new position, and so he wanted to see what Elizabeth had to say.

Unfortunately, when he arrived at the Braunschweig house, she was nowhere to be seen. The butler said that she was out with her mother, and he led Yang to Braunschweigâ€™s office, where another, even less pleasant, surprise was waiting for him.

Ansbach had returned from Cahokia, and he was standing behind Braunschweig, in his old spot at his shoulder.

The look that Braunschweig gave Yang as he came into the office was a mixed oneâ€” distaste and calculation all at once. He waved at Yang to sit down in the chair before his desk, which Yang did. Ansbach looked straight ahead, not looking at Yang. This already made Yang deeply uncomfortableâ€” the feeling of the room had changed, and it probably wasnâ€™t just the fact that Ansbach had been away from Odin for so long.

Yang tried to ignore the discomfort that crawled along his back, and he put a smile on his face. â€œGood morning, Duke Braunschweig. And I didnâ€™t expect to see you back here so soon, Captain Ansbach,â€ Yang said.

â€œI asked him to return when you left for your little errand on planet Castrop,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œIt took some time for him to wrap up his business there and come back.â€

â€œWell, Iâ€™m glad to see you again,â€ Yang said, at least trying to come off genuine. They had parted on better terms than they had ever been on, so he hoped that would continue.

â€œIâ€™m honored, Lord Leigh,â€ Ansbach said. He stared straight ahead, and his voice didnâ€™t have even the slightest quiver of sarcasm in it. This, perhaps more than anything else, made Yang feel sick.

Braunschweig laughed. â€œIâ€™m certain this was something you never expected, Ansbach.â€

â€œNo, my lord.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t either,â€ Yang said, rubbing the back of his head.Â 

â€œI think youâ€™re lucky, Leigh,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œIâ€™m very happy for you, of course, but there are many people in the court who donâ€™t feel half as pleased as I do. If you didnâ€™t have my protection, the Kaiserâ€™s generosity might have been deadly.â€ The threat could barely even be considered veiled.

â€œI think the Kaiser was trying to protect me, sir,â€ Yang said. â€œHe has a different view of things, looking down on the rest of us, than we do looking up at him, though.â€

â€œHow astute.â€

â€œIâ€™m glad that you arenâ€™t upset by it.â€

â€œWhy would I possibly be upset?â€ Braunschweig asked. He wasnâ€™t a very good liar. â€œYouâ€™ve been telling me for months that I should court more rich and powerful allies into my court, and here youâ€™ve just landed in my lap.â€ He smiled. â€œAnd, of course, Iâ€™m pleased that the Kaiser didnâ€™t see fit to punish you. I would have hated to lose a talented officer on a jaunt like that.â€

â€œYes, sir.â€

â€œSpeaking of that,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œIâ€™m promoting you.â€ He opened one of his desk drawers and handed Yang an envelope. â€œCongratulations, Commodore.â€

â€œReally?â€ Yang asked, alarmed. â€œWhat for?â€

â€œServices to the crown,â€ Braunschweig said in a flat voice. â€œAfter the Kaiser was so pleased with your performance with the Artemis Necklace, how could I not reward it?â€Â 

No, Yang decided, he was just still afraid of his father-in-law, worried that if the Kaiserâ€™s favorite wasnâ€™t treated well under Braunschweigâ€™s care, the Kaiser still had power to do something about it. Yang idly wondered what that might beâ€” would the Kaiser raise him still higher? The idea made Yangâ€™s head spin. And he didnâ€™t want to be a flag officer, either. Especially not for no reason.Â 

Yangâ€™s panicked, roving gaze landed on Ansbach, who was very deliberately not looking at Yang. The sudden injustice of it all struck him, and he was compelled to open his mouth.

â€œWill Captain Ansbach be promoted as well?â€ Yang asked.

The silence that descended on Braunschweigâ€™s office was even worse than the silence of the tomb.

â€œI just thinkâ€” I meanâ€” heâ€™s been a captain for longer than I have been, and he just spent so long on the front, and getting Cahokia set up wasâ€¦ important.â€ He trailed off and rubbed his head. â€œIt just seems fair, sir.â€

â€œIâ€™ll consider it.â€ Braunschweig said, in the flattest, dullest voice imaginable. â€œWhat was it that you wanted to discuss about Cahokia?â€

Relieved to change the subject, Yang pulled out the papers he had prepared for requisitions.Â 

The meeting proceeded as normally as it could, though Yang never approached feeling comfortable. It ended unexpectedly, when Braunschweig got a phone call from one of his relatives, and dismissed both Yang and Asbach from his office.Â 

Anbach immediately strode off down the hallway, without saying a single word to Yang. He was certainly aware that Yang followed him, down the steps into the servantsâ€™ hall in the basement of the building, but he said nothing. The only time he stopped was to open a rickety set of drawers in the hallway, from which he pulled out a couple things that Yang couldnâ€™t see. He stuck them in his pockets, and then marched out of the house. The door to the outside nearly slammed shut in Yangâ€™s face when Ansbach went out, letting it shut behind him. Yang caught it just before it could hit his nose.

Outside, Ansbach was standing in the light dusting of snow on the ground, a cigarette pinched between his lips as he tried to shield it from the wind and light it.

â€œI didnâ€™t know you smoked,â€ Yang said. He sat down on the stone step, looking up at Ansbach as he curled his arms around his knees.

â€œThe servants hall isnâ€™t a place for someone of your station, Lord.â€

â€œPlease, donâ€™t,â€ Yang said.

â€œDonâ€™t smoke, Lord?â€ he asked. â€œIâ€™ll put it out for you.â€ He pulled the cigarette out of his mouth and looked at it. He hadnâ€™t actually lit it yetâ€” Yang had interrupted him before he could win his battle with the winter wind.Â 

â€œAnsbachâ€”â€

â€œWhat?â€

â€œI didnâ€™t want this,â€ Yang said. â€œI didnâ€™t ask for it.â€

Ansbach was silent.

â€œI was really hoping you, at least, wouldnâ€™t treat me any differently.â€

â€œI will treat you as is befitting to your station and rank, Lord.â€ Yang was sure that Ansbach was aware of just how miserable this was making Yang, and was doing it on purpose, but that couldnâ€™t be the whole story. But it was effective as a tactic, and if Yang had been a more aggressive person, he would have yelled. But instead, his shoulders just slumped further and further, and he leaned his chin on his arms.

â€œI never wanted to be above anyone,â€ Yang said. â€œNot even when we were back in school. Those fucking class ranksâ€” it was all so stupid. They had to make a game out of putting students at each otherâ€™s throats. Iâ€™m honestly surprised that I was the only one who ever almost got killed over it.â€

Ansbach lit his cigarette.

â€œI guess I was an easy target. Weak, or foreign, or both.â€Â 

There was silence.

â€œI forgive you for that, by the way,â€ Yang said. â€œYou probably already knew that. But I guess I should say it.â€

Ansbachâ€™s cigarette was half gone before he said anything. â€œWhy did you tell the duke to promote me?â€

Yang tugged at his hair. â€œItâ€™s not fair to you if he doesnâ€™t.â€

â€œLifeâ€™s not fair.â€

â€œAnd you need to be the voice of reason around here.â€ He sighed. â€œWeâ€™re in the same boatâ€”â€

â€œWe are not, Lord.â€

â€œYou know we are,â€ Yang said. He scuffed at the snowy ground with his toe. â€œForget the title. You know it doesnâ€™t actually mean anything to Braunschweig except as some sort of threat from the Kaiser. If he thinks Iâ€™m not useful to him anymore, or if he decides he canâ€™t stand me, the title wonâ€™t mean anything. Weâ€™re not his family. We donâ€™t haveâ€”â€ He waved his hand, broadly encompassing everything he knew Ansbach already understood. â€œWeâ€™re always going to be on the outside.â€

â€œAnd what do you want me to do about it?â€

â€œDo about it? Thereâ€™s nothing that anybody can do about it.â€ Not while the Empire remained as it was, anyway. But that wasnâ€™t a conversation he could have with Ansbach.

â€œThen whyâ€”â€

â€œWe donâ€™t have to be friends,â€ Yang said. â€œI know you hate me. But we can work together as equals. And thatâ€™s easier if youâ€™re a commodore.â€

â€œFine. Weâ€™ll see if he listens to you.â€

â€œHe trusts you. There isnâ€™t any reason for him not to promote you. He just probably hadnâ€™t thought about it yet.â€

â€œIf you say so.â€

â€œWhy does he trust you so much, by the way?â€

â€œHe doesnâ€™t trust me. He just doesnâ€™t think about not trusting me.â€

â€œHe doesâ€” he thought you were the right person to watch over me.â€

Ansbach rolled his eyes, and dropped the stub of his cigarette. He ground the glowing ember into the snow with his heel.

â€œAnd whatâ€™s the difference between those two things, anyway?â€ Yang asked.

â€œA world of difference.â€

â€œExplain it to me?â€

â€œI was a hall boy, in his country estate on Westerland,â€ Ansbach said. â€œMy mother begged him to sponsor me to go to school. But the boy who blacks your boots never stops being just another part of the scenery.â€

â€œOh,â€ Yang said.

â€œI suppose you wonâ€™t tell me where you come from, Lord.â€ Ansbach had lost his flat tone, and was openly mocking on the title. It was a significant improvement.

â€œPhezzan,â€ Yang lied. But he smiled at Ansbach, who shook his head and stepped past him to go back inside.

Chapter End Notes

lol there's a bunch to say about this chapter i suppose.

poor yang is truly learning the meaning of "suffering from success" lol.

hilde #gender or something

magdalena doesn't exactly have cold feet, but for all her quasi-cheerful "well, you've just gotta do it"-ness of previous chapters, she's remembered that the entire reason she started hanging out with yang in the first place was so that she could avoid getting married. obviously the circumstances are very very different than they were back in the beginning of 'servants of the pharaoh' but maggie is still herself. it's not that she doesn't love yang-- it's that Living In A Society is really just getting to her haha. hopefully i have gotten this across semi-clearly, even though no one in any conversation should ever be allowed to speak their minds

Mind The Gap, as usual. ([lenny TheYoungPope voice] My Mind Is A Gap)

ansbach backstory reveal! i love my horrible boy

per the chapter title, the yang - odysseus parallels are in full force. constant descriptions of himself as 'nobody', and we're reminded of his leg scar lol. along with the large numbers of lies he tells in this chapter haha. "why does yang get to be odysseus?" you may ask. well because reinhard has always been achilles (through the transitive property with alexander the great, anyway). it's foils.

it's very fun to read the chinese translation of talking without speaking by ChiefAccelerator, because it is reminding me of just how far back some of the themes and imagery that i've been building up stretches. when i was first writing the beginning of this story, i wasn't super consciously building a narrative about lies, specifically. just about the way stories are told. but it's been there from the very beginning in how many times yang lies about things. lies, performances, games, histories, truths... lot going on with this axis of concepts ğŸ˜‚ but that's what i love about writing, especially things that are wicked long and grow in complexity and depth over time-- the way i get to reinterpret and make deeper ideas that have been there from the beginning... ough. anyway i hope you are enjoying being on this ride with me haha

oh also in this chapter i am really being blunt about the relationships of power destroying people concept haha. but that's a fun one.

i'd love to hear what you all think <3 we're moving swiftly towards the second half of this book. i also really have no idea who is actively reading this story anymore, so pls do say hi. and any of my readers from lofter-- i would love to chat over here ğŸ’™ğŸ’™

thank you so much as always to em for the beta read!

you can find me on tumblr @ javert , twitter @ natsinator , gayspaceopera.carrd.co , and on discord https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

Friends Like These

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

December 487 I.C., Iserlohn Fortress

Reuenthal had not kept much with him in the way of personal property on his flagship, which made packing it all up easier. He had never thought of himself as a sentimental man, but, as he walked the halls of the Ostberlin for the last time, he found himself standing in doorways, peering into empty rooms, feeling a tug in his chest. The ship, which was at the end of its service life, was set to be used as a training vessel for a few years, and then scrapped. It and the Westberlin had been some of the last ships in their class to be in service, and it had only been a matter of time before the two ships would be retired. Now that Reuenthal and Mittermeyer were being transferred back to Odin, that time had come.

He walked off the ship one last time, carefully not giving it a single backwards glance until he was far enough from it that no one was paying attention to his moment of weakness. He looked at it through the long windows that overlooked Iserlohnâ€™s drydock, felt strange, and hurried away to the bar where Mittermeyer was waiting for him. They would both be on a passenger transport back to the capital in a few hours, but there was time before then to drink and talk in the semi-privacy afforded by a corner booth at a bar. He wasnâ€™t sure how much time they would be able to spend together while en routeâ€” and, besides, Mittermeyer always got antsy in the few days before he was to leave Iserlohn; Reuenthal found it hard to believe that this trip would be any different.

The bar was crowded and dark. Although it was one meant only for officers, this didnâ€™t make it any less busy. It was the time of the month when personnel reassignments were going out, and so there were a higher number of people than usual inside, doing exactly as Reuenthal and Mittermeyer were: celebrating or mourning transfers. Paradoxically, the more crowded the bar was, the easier it was for their conversations to remain private.

Mittermeyer was already sitting in the back of the bar, and had already gotten drinks for himself and Reuenthal. There were two untouched beers in front of him, and shoved one over to Reuenthal as he sat down without saying a word.

Reuenthal raised his glass silently, and they had an unspoken toast.

The beer took his mind off the desolate Ostberlin , as did seeing Mittermeyer, his flaxen hair reflecting the dim yellow lights of the bar.

Reuenthal finally said,â€œI wonâ€™t ask you if youâ€™re pleased to be leaving.â€

â€œAt least our punishment is over.â€

â€œIs it?â€

â€œWell, I wonâ€™t have to do any more patrols, at least,â€ Mittermeyer said. â€œAnd Iâ€™ve never heard anyone else say that a do-nothing job in the capital is a punishment. Most people think itâ€™s a vacation.â€

â€œHaving my flagship scrapped seems like a punishment to me.â€

Mittermeyer frowned into his beer. â€œDonâ€™t remind me.â€

â€œYours isnâ€™t even being used for training is it?â€

â€œNo,â€ Mittermeyer said. â€œSheâ€™s headed for the scrapyard immediately. Unless they use her as target practice first. She got too beat up when I had to go pull Leigh out of the corridor.â€

Reuenthal gave a dark chuckle. â€œAnd I crashed your carâ€” you seem to have some bad luck concerning vehicles.â€

â€œIâ€™ll make a note to never buy a yacht when I retire, in case you or Leigh need me to scuttle it for some reason.â€

â€œSound choice.â€

Mittermeyer sighed. He fished around in his pocket for something, and pulled out a little metal emblem: the Westberlin â€™s symbol, wrought in bronze, which he had clearly pried out of the door to his office on the ship. He tossed it to Reuenthal. â€œThereâ€™s your memento.â€

Reuenthal reached into his own pocket and pulled out the matching one. They were sister ships, and the two emblems mated perfectly, forming an old city map of a place on Ancient Earth that had once been split in two. He laid them together on the table for a moment, just looking at it, then flicked the Ostberlin â€™s emblem towards Mittermeyer, who picked it up and turned it over in his hands.

â€œItâ€™s not a punishment,â€ Mittermeyer said. â€œYou know itâ€™s political.â€

â€œOf course.â€

â€œAfter what Leigh did with the Artemis Necklace, Muckenburgerâ€™s got his eyes firmly fixed on Iserlohn. He couldnâ€™t just let us stay here.â€

â€œLeigh wouldnâ€™t need us to sabotage it from the inside,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œMuckenburger should know that.â€

â€œHe probably does, but itâ€™s still smart for him to reassign us. And Leighâ€™s friend Obersteinâ€” youâ€™ve met him, right?â€

â€œYes.â€ Reuenthal couldnâ€™t quite hide his distaste.

â€œHeâ€™s out, too. Iâ€™m honestly surprised we werenâ€™t all kicked out to the frontier.â€

â€œTaking away our fleets makes us powerless. Having a fleet but being far away would still mean that we posed threats. I donâ€™t think Muckenburger has a choice, except to give us a â€˜vacationâ€™.â€

â€œDo you know if any of these other shufflings are for the same reason?â€ Mittermeyer glanced around at the busy room. â€œYou know the people here better than I do, since Iâ€™m out on patrol all the time.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know. Thereâ€™s not anybody that Leigh mentioned, but I donâ€™t keep an exhaustive list of Braunschweigâ€™s allies. And it might only be fair to kick out anyone from Littenheimâ€™s camp, too. I donâ€™t know if Muckenburger wants to look like heâ€™s favoring them.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure he doesnâ€™t.â€ Mittermeyer finished his beer, and flagged down the waitress to get a new one. â€œWell, weâ€™ll just have to make the best of our time on Odin. Iâ€™m sure if Leigh needs us, heâ€™ll find us something to do.â€

â€œDo you really want to work for Braunschweig?â€

â€œI could ask you the same question.â€

â€œYou already know what the answer is.â€ Under the table, Reuenthal slid his foot up Mittermeyerâ€™s leg, which elicited no reaction other than Mittermeyer shifting subtly in his seat, allowing Reuenthal to press the heel of his black leather boot into the softest part of his thigh. It was dangerous, but no one could see them, and they were about to leave Iserlohn anyway, so he didnâ€™t care. Through his heel, he couldnâ€™t feel anything of Mittermeyer except the resistance of flesh, but it was enough to ground him in the moment. He drank his beer, too frothy and sour for his taste.

â€œItâ€™s been a long time since I had a post on Odin,â€ Mittermeyer said, changing the subject. â€œIt will be nice to be in the same place as Leigh.â€

Failing to mention his wife didnâ€™t do Mittermeyer any favors. It was almost worse when she hovered unmentioned in the edges of the conversation. It made it so there was almost nothing that could be discussed: the illicit was forbidden here in the bar, and the licit was avoided to spare Reuenthalâ€™s feelings.

â€œBefore he gets married, you mean,â€ Reuenthal said, picking a knife to twist.

â€œAnd after, Iâ€™m sure.â€

Reuenthal let out a dark laugh. â€œIâ€™m sure.â€

â€œAre you planning to go to the wedding?â€

â€œIâ€™m planning on it.â€

â€œBut plans might change.â€

Reuenthal looked at him cooly, perfectly cognizant of the position of his heel, and the warmth of Mittermeyerâ€™s legs against his own. â€œIâ€™ll go,â€ Reuenthal said.Â 

â€œThatâ€™s good.â€ He looked away. â€œI suppose itâ€™s not for a few months, anyway.â€

â€œLeigh can enjoy a little more time as a free man.â€

â€œLike I said, I donâ€™t think marrying will make him any less free.â€ But he smiled. â€œThe funny thing isâ€” he wrote to me and told me all about how much he was trying to avoid all the trappings of being a count, but as soon as he goes through with all of this, heâ€™ll be living in her mansion anyway.â€ Not saying Magdalenaâ€™s name was probably another accession to Reuenthalâ€™s feelings.

â€œLeigh considers being rich the cruelest turn of fortuneâ€™s wheel,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œIâ€™m certain his fiancee is happy about it.â€

â€œWhy do you say so? Itâ€™s not like she was after his money,â€ Mittermeyer said with a laugh. â€œIf itâ€™s â€˜for richer or for poorerâ€™, she agreed to marry him when he was definitely â€˜poorerâ€™.â€

â€œShe told me once that thereâ€™s always a use for money. I doubt sheâ€™s the type to turn up her nose at it.â€

â€œTo be fair, I donâ€™t think I would turn up my nose if the Kaiser decided to make me a count,â€ Mittermeyer said. â€œLeigh has a stronger backbone than I do, to hate it.â€

â€œIs that so?â€

â€œYou sound like youâ€™re surprised. I thought youâ€™d say something like â€˜the most middle-class of dreams is the dream of being rich.â€™â€ Mittermeyer laughed. â€œI suppose it is pretty middle class of me. Besides, itâ€™s never going to happen, so itâ€™s a funny thing to imagine.â€

â€œMaybe,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œAre you saying that youâ€™d turn down the money and title?â€

â€œI have no real desire for a heritable title. Even if I wanted to be lavishly rewarded by the Kaiser and join the ranks of the nobles, which I have no desire to do, Iâ€™m not going to have a child to pass the title down to. So it would be pointless. Passing titles down only ensures that someone incompetent will hold them, anyway.â€

The mention of children, or lack thereof, was a sore spot for Mittermeyer, as Reuenthal was well aware. But Mittermeyer could give as well as he got. â€œAnd you think that Leigh is going to have a child?â€

Reuenthalâ€™s mouth twitched in displeasure. â€œI doubt it. Westpfale doesnâ€™t seem like the type.â€

â€œThe type?â€ Mittermeyer asked. â€œItâ€™s not like it takes a certain kind of personality. And sheâ€™s probably been told since birth that sheâ€™ll have to pass down her title.â€

â€œSo, you think they will?â€

â€œUp to them. I donâ€™t know.â€

Reuenthal had succeeded in making them both miserable, it seemed. This was what always happened when leaving Iserlohn. The fortress, with its artificial and regimented way of life, kept its occupants safe from the encroaching troubles of the natural world and polite society. For someone who fit into the natural order of the world, who fit into politie society, leaving Iserlohn for a safe desk job on Odin was a vacation. For Reuenthal, it was a kind of punishment.Â 

â€œI suppose it doesnâ€™t matter,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œI donâ€™t think Leigh would want to even think about it until after everything is resolved.â€ As part of his concession, he shifted his foot to relieve some of the pressure on Mittermeyerâ€™s leg, but Mittermeyer, below the table, rested his free hand on his ankle, continuing to welcome it.

â€œYouâ€™re right.â€ Mittermeyer said. â€œThis would be a bad time to have a child.â€

â€œNot that much worse than any time in the past hundred years.â€

â€œTrue.â€ Mittermeyer shook his head. â€œLife keeps going on for everybody, even soldiers, I guess.â€

â€œUntil it doesnâ€™t.â€

â€œDonâ€™t be morbid.â€

â€œIâ€™m notâ€” Iâ€™m just being realistic.â€

Â 

Â 

December 487 I.C., Odin

Reuenthal settled himself back in his home on Odin without the least bit of fanfare. He wanted to see Yang, but this seemed to involve passing through a gauntlet by the name of Magdalena, who, having learned through Mittermeyerâ€™s wife that Reuenthal was back on the planet, invited Reuenthal to dinner with herself and Yang before Reuenthal could get a chance to speak to Yang on his own. On some level, it was his fault for having the bad habit of always trying to sneak back onto the planetâ€” but he blamed Magdalena for the annoyance nonetheless.

They met at a restaurant, a place that was very upscale but was pretending that it belonged on Phezzan rather than Odin. It had neon lights of flickering blue and green, and the music was by a live band, something jaunty with a wailing singer whose lyrics Reuenthal attempted to tune out. They sat at a small, round table right near the stage, Magdalena having picked the spot. She kept smiling up at the singer, who was distractingly moving in and out of Reuenthalâ€™s peripheral vision. The whole atmosphere set his teeth on edge.

â€œIsnâ€™t the music good?â€ Magdalena asked, after they had gotten their drinks.

â€œI donâ€™t know anything about music,â€ Yang said.

â€œThatâ€™s another thing that I suspect Iâ€™ll have to fix about you pretty quickly,â€ Magdalena said. â€œYou could use a broader education in the arts. Itâ€™s vital.â€

â€œYou sound like my father,â€ Yang grumbled. â€œHe would always tell me that art and business are the only things worth studying. So, as an ungrateful son, I took the greatest pleasure in not studying either of them.â€

â€œHmph,â€ Magdalena said. â€œWell, weâ€™ll have to make up for his failures in imparting good taste.â€

â€œItâ€™s a pity that your life has followed the wrong trajectory,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œWhat is it people say? â€˜I study war so that my son may study business and diplomacy, and my son studies business so that his son may study art.â€™â€

â€œMen have been studying war since the dawn of time,â€ Magdalena said dismissively. â€œIf a generational progression like that was even possible, it would have happened long before now. I simply suspect that there are too many men who prefer to study war rather than art.â€ She curled her lip at Reuenthal. â€œOr am I wrong about that, Oskar?â€

â€œI can hope for peace in this generation,â€ Yang said. â€œEven if itâ€™s a short lived one, Iâ€™d like it. Some children should get to grow up without war.â€

â€œA pleasant fantasy,â€ Reuenthal said. He picked up his menu and studied it, rather than looking at Yang or Magdalena, or the wailing singer. â€œThatâ€™s true!â€ Magdalena said. â€œStudying business and diplomacy seems to have done well for them, in that respect. Too bad thatâ€™s all their sons want to study, too.â€ She laughed.Â 

â€œI donâ€™t think itâ€™s true that people on Phezzan grow up without war,â€ Yang said. â€œTheir whole way of life is shaped by it, if indirectly.â€ He frowned down at his own menu. â€œWorking hard to pretend something doesnâ€™t exist is also a kind of acknowledgement that it does.â€

This cast a pall over the conversation.

â€œIs becoming acquainted with art something that all the nobility has to do?â€ Reuenthal asked Magdalena. â€œOr is Leighâ€™s art education a personal vendetta of yours?â€

â€œOh, there are plenty who donâ€™t,â€ Magdalena said. â€œIâ€™m sure youâ€™re aware of them all. But theyâ€™re all such boors, and hard to make conversation with. Yang continued to scowl down at his menu.

â€œSo, no love for art for artâ€™s sake. Itâ€™s all a social game?â€ Reuenthal asked.

â€œEverything is a social game, darling. Youâ€™re lucky to know me, since Iâ€™m honest about that fact.â€

â€œI have to wonder what other indignities youâ€™re going to force him through. It surprises me that you havenâ€™t completely thrown out his wardrobe.â€

â€œWe can take things one step at a time. Everyone in the capital, at least who I care about associating with, understands that these things will take some getting used to. â€œYou donâ€™t have to make me into a project, Maggie,â€ Yang said, but he sounded resigned.

â€œItâ€™s for your own health and safety,â€ Magdalena said bluntly. â€œIâ€™m sure even Oskar understands that.â€

â€œâ€˜Even Oskarâ€™?â€ Reuenthal asked. Magdalena just laughed. â€œAnd who are these supposed members of the nobility that you actively want to associate with?â€

â€œOh, thereâ€™s plenty. I couldnâ€™t possibly name them all right now.â€ She tilted her head in a very predatory way. â€œBut Oskar, Iâ€™m glad you brought up the subject, and Iâ€™m glad youâ€™re back on Odin.â€

â€œWhy is that?â€

â€œThereâ€™s someone I want you to meet.â€

â€œOh?â€

â€œSheâ€™s been off Odin for several years, but sheâ€™s finally made it back home. I think youâ€™d get along with her.â€

â€œI have no interest in meeting your friends.â€

â€œOh, sheâ€™s not a friend.â€

â€œThen why would I care?â€

â€œBecause I want you to,â€ Magdalena said. â€œAre you going to the solstice party at the capitol?â€

â€œIf Iâ€™m invited, itâ€™s mandatory.â€

â€œSheâ€™ll be there. Iâ€™ll tell her to be on the lookout for you.â€

â€œI donâ€™t like this asymmetry of information,â€ Reuenthal said, which made Magdalena laugh again.

â€œUnfortunately, I do.â€

â€œAnd what are you hoping to get out of this?â€

â€œNothing,â€ Magdalena said. â€œThis is out of the kindness of my heart. For you and for her. Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ll understand when you meet her.â€

â€œThe fact that you believe that introducing me to a woman is a kindness makes me thinkâ€”â€

â€œOh donâ€™t bother finishing that sentence, Oskar. I know what you think of me already.â€

â€œAnd what is that?â€

Magdalena just smiled. And then she turned to Yang. â€œWhat are you having for dinner, darling?â€

Reuenthal ground his teeth. Yang looked uncomfortable. He had been sinking down into his chair during the whole exchange between Reuenthal and Magdalena, and now he seemed reluctant to say a single word. It was unfortunate that Magdalena had chosen a restaurant for them to meet in, Reuenthal thought. They hadnâ€™t exactly gotten along at dinners at their private residences, but in private, they could at least speak openly. And Magdalena would have felt less ownership over Yangâ€” she might have him in public, but in private it was a different story. As if she could read his mind, she reached over to Yang and tucked some of his hair behind his ear, and then raised her glass at Reuenthal in a cheeky little toast.

The whole meal was deeply frustrating, and it was made worse by Yang becoming quieter and quieter as the night wore on. As Yang paid the bill, Reuenthal asked, â€œDo you want me to give you a ride home?â€

â€œPlease,â€ Yang said, with some relief in his voice.

When they went out into the parking lot, Magdalena gave Yang a kiss goodnight, and she thankfully stopped short of trying to kiss Reuenthalâ€™s cheeks as they stood out in the snow. She left for her own car in a swirl of petticoats and furs, leaving Yang and Reuenthal standing next to his car, the old one that had used to belong to his father. Without speaking, Reuenthal and Yang got in, and Reuenthal turned them towards Yangâ€™s apartment. The snow was falling gently, but the roads were still clear. Reuenthal drove in silence for a while.

â€œYouâ€™re not taking me back to your place?â€ Yang asked, when he finally caught sight of a landmark that let him know which way he was heading.

â€œI said I would drive you home.â€

â€œAlright,â€ Yang said. â€œAs long as you donâ€™t mind my landladies. Your house does avoid that, at least.â€ He laughed, but it was just to break up the strange atmosphere, and it sounded anechoic and muffled in Reuenthalâ€™s ears.

â€œIt surprises me that you havenâ€™t moved into a larger house yet, now that youâ€™re a count. You inherited some property in the capital, didnâ€™t you?â€

â€œI guess,â€ Yang said. He rubbed the back of his head. â€œIâ€™m going to be moving in with Maggie in a couple months, so there isnâ€™t really a point in me uprooting my whole life before then. I like my apartment, anyway.â€

â€œI see.â€

Reuenthal turned towards the highway, and they sat at a red light, just watching the snow swirl in the empty intersection, counting the seconds until the light changed.

â€œIs something the matter?â€ Yang finally asked.

â€œOf course not.â€

â€œYouâ€™re not good at pretending that something isnâ€™t wrong.â€

â€œNothingâ€™s wrong,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œAlright.â€ Yang wasnâ€™t going to press, and he just leaned his head on the passenger window, watching the snow land in wet flakes on the glass as Reuenthal drove.

â€œCan I ask you a question?â€ Reuenthal asked, breaking the silence once again.

â€œOf course.â€

â€œYouâ€™ve been given a lot of money.â€

â€œThatâ€™s not a question.â€

â€œYou could use it to pay off your debt, go back to Phezzan, get away from all of this. Free yourself. Live under your own name again.â€

Yang was silent.

â€œAre you going to?â€

â€œNo,â€ Yang said. It took a long time for him to continue, and when he did, his voice was rough and strained. â€œI feel responsible for things here. I keep telling people that Iâ€™m a servant of the whole Empireâ€” the ordinary people, not just the Kaiser. If I donâ€™t do something to take their lives into account, nobody else will. â€œI see.â€ Dutyâ€” that was all.

Yang was silent again for a long time. â€œAnd Iâ€™m a very selfish person,â€ he said. His head was pressed against the glass of the window, and his eyes were closed.

Â 

The solstice party in Neue Sanssouci was one that Reuenthal thought that he shouldnâ€™t have had an invitation to, but on paper, there was no reason for him not to get one. Every flag officer in the capital who was part of the Reichsflotte â€” not belonging to a private nobleâ€™s fleetâ€” had been invited, along with sundry nobility and other court functionaries who Prime Minister Lichtenlade considered to be harmless enough. It seemed ridiculous that he and Mittermeyer had been invited, since they had just been kicked out of Iserlohn for their associations with Duke Braunschweig, via Yang, and Reuenthal wished that someone had realized this and scrubbed his name from the invite list. He had no desire to be here, but it was mandatory.

When he complained to Yang about it, Yang just gave him a sympathetic smile and said, â€œWell, try to think of it as part of your paycheck. Besides, Mittermeyer will be there.â€

Of course, Mittermeyer being there meant that Mittermeyerâ€™s cheerful wife was hanging onto his arm as they stood together in the dance hall. She and Reuenthal were doing their best not to acknowledge each other too much, but it was difficult. They stood near some pillars at the edge of the room, watching dancers narrowly avoid collision in their swirling dresses and crisp uniforms. Due to the more military nature of the party, the gender ratio was imbalanced, and there were plenty of single officers like Reuenthal who stood around the edges and simply watched the dancers. Not everyone had a wife to bring like Mittermeyer did.Â 

The party was sumptuously decorated and packed with people, though the mood remained strangely somber despite the cheerful music and energetic dancing. Perhaps it was due to the conspicuous lack of the Kaiserâ€™s presence. The party was in the capitol, and at the front of the ballroom an elaborate seat was set up for the Kaiser, but there was no way he would make a showing. This was Lichtenladeâ€™s party, and everyone knew it.

â€œLeighâ€™s lucky to be in Braunschweigâ€™s camp,â€ Mittermeyer said. â€œHeâ€™s missing out.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure he avoided becoming a flag officer for so long just so that he would have the ability to avoid these kinds of things,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œHe hates parties.â€

â€œThis one could be worse,â€ Mittermeyer said, looking around. â€œI donâ€™t see anyone I particularly hate.â€

â€œThereâ€™s always time to make new enemies,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œAre you planning on making enemies tonight?â€ Evangeline asked, looking around.

â€œI hope not,â€ Mittermeyer said.

â€œI wonâ€™t try to,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œBut itâ€™s a good opportunity to learn whatâ€™s been going on in the Lichtenlade camp these days.â€Â 

Mittemeyer nodded. â€œListening to who is speaking to whom is always valuable, I suppose, even if no one could possibly be stupid enough to talk about their plans at a public party.â€

Across the room, Reuenthal could see Fleet Admiral Muckenburger, speaking with High Admiral Ovelesser. Neither of them looked particularly happy with the other, but those were two men who wouldnâ€™t cowedâ€” either by oneâ€™s rank or oneâ€™s physical stature. â€œI wouldnâ€™t be so sure about that,â€ Reuenthal said, and he nodded over at them. â€œI wonder what theyâ€™re discussing.â€

Mittermeyer raised his eyebrows. â€œDissention in the ranks?â€

â€œMaybe. Do you know if Braunschweig is particularly friendly with the high admiral?â€

â€œNo idea. Do you want him to be?â€

Reuenthal scoffed. â€œYou forgot what happened at Kapche-Lanka so quickly.â€

â€œNo, I didnâ€™t. Iâ€™m just more willing to forgive.â€

â€œWhat happened at Kapche-Lanka?â€ Evangeline asked. â€œDid High Admiral Ovelesser do something to annoy you?â€

â€œOh, er, it wasnâ€™t much,â€ Mittemeyer said. â€œJust some tactical decisions that Reuenthal disagreed with.â€

There was a moment of awkward silence between the three of them. Evangeline opened and closed her mouth, clearly aware that Mittermeyer was hiding something.

â€œIt was a long time ago, Frau Mittermeyer,â€ Reuenthal said.

Mittermeyer coughed. â€œRight, it was. Can I get you both a drink?â€

Of course, if Mittermeyer escaped the tense moment, that would leave Reuenthal and Evangeline standing there next to each other. This was something that neither of them wanted, but neither could refuse.Â 

â€œYes, thank you,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œWine, or something.â€

â€œOne of thoseâ€”â€ Eva pointed at someone who walked by carrying a thick looking mixed drink. â€œWhatever it is.â€

â€œSure,â€ Mittermeyer said, and vanished into the crowd.

Evangeline looked around for a second, clearly searching for a conversation topic and not finding one until the silence between them had already become unbearable. â€œAre you doing anything for the New Year, Herr Reuenthal?â€ she asked.

â€œNo,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œIâ€™m not planning on anything.â€

â€œYouâ€™re welcome to join Wolf and I. Weâ€™re not doing anything special, but Iâ€™m sure he would like your company.â€

It would have been hard to name anything less pleasant sounding than a night spent with Evangeline Mittermeyerâ€™s pity. â€œIâ€™ll think about it,â€ he said. â€œI appreciate the invitation.â€Â 

She looked across the room, trying to find Mittermeyer in the line at the bar, but he didnâ€™t stand out in the crowd, and so was invisible.

â€œMay I ask what did happen on Kapche-Lanka?â€ Evangeline asked. â€œI know Wolf doesnâ€™t want me to worry about things, but it was so long ago, I canâ€™t really worry about it retroactively.â€

Her words brought him back to three years ago, tumbling around with Mittermeyer in the snow that was so cold that it squeaked underfoot, with air that froze the tears at the corners of the eyes and the moisture in the breath.Â 

â€œWhat did he tell you about it?â€

She shook her head. â€œNot much. He just said that his base came under attack, and that he was very lucky you were close enough to come reinforce him before the main forces on the planet arrived.â€

â€œI wasnâ€™t close,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œI was a dayâ€™s drive away.â€

â€œOh.â€

â€œBut I had to go, because Ovelesser wasnâ€™t going to send any reinforcements. He was going to leave him to die. I disobeyed the overall strategic plan to do it, and got a black mark on my record for it.â€

â€œWhy?â€ Her voice was high and thin.

â€œBecause he wasnâ€™t worth the resources to the Imperial Fleet.â€ But he had been worth it to Reuenthal. â€œA half constructed mine, and a nobody commander with a single battalion of workers. Not worth committing anything to, until I forced their hand.â€

â€œHe should have told me so that I could thank you myself,â€ Evangeline said. â€œIâ€™m very grateful that you are Wolfâ€™s friend.â€

Reuenthal didnâ€™t say anything for a second. He could see Mittermeyer coming back through the crowd, drinks in hand. â€œYou should tell your husband to stop keeping secrets from you,â€ he said.

As Evangelineâ€™s face twisted like she had been hit, Mittermeyer made it back over. Reuenthal took the offered wine from his hand. â€œThanks,â€ he said. â€œI think Iâ€™ll take a walk.â€

â€œOh, Iâ€”â€ Mittermeyer began, but Reuenthal was already gone.

He left the two of them with some relief, and headed through the crowded sides of the party, listening to chatter and pushing his way through the crowd. He had a vague intention of trying to get closer to Ovelesser and Muckenburger, just to give him something to do at this party other than stand next to Mittermeyer. Unfortunately, by the time that he made it up to the front of the room, Ovelesser and Muckenburger had gone their separate ways. Ovelesser was standing by one of the refreshment tables and filling a glass with ice cubes, which he then proceeded to eat one by one. Muckenburger had vanished. But it wouldnâ€™t have been useful following him anywayâ€” Reuenthal knew he was smart enough to keep his mouth shut. It was only Ovelesser who might have been tempted to say something in anger.

But now Reuenthal was standing at the front of the room, looking around like a hawk at everyone for no reason. His eyes settled on the table where Prime Minister Lichtenlade was sitting, along with a bunch of other nobles. They clearly werenâ€™t military, and more than half of them were women, most of them with the same shade of blonde hairâ€” it must be a group of his extended relatives. Most of them were talking and eating quite pleasantly, but there was one young womanâ€” probably in her mid twentiesâ€” who was staring out at the party with a glare that could have frozen water into ice. As Reuenthalâ€™s gaze roved across the table, he couldnâ€™t help but smirk at her miserable expression. But, as he did so, her eyes landed on him, and he was caught in her death glare.

She had nothing to do with him, so it wasnâ€™t losing face to turn away and leave that area of the party to go look at other guests.

Reuenthal wandered around alone for a little while. There were some people he knew, or at least recognized, aside from Mittermeyer, but he wasnâ€™t in the mood for socializing, and kept checking the time to see when he would be allowed to leave the event. He caught the occasional glimpse of Mittermeyer across the room, who was introducing his wife to various people he happened to know. Evangeline was smiling and laughing, and this made Reuenthal lose interest in going back over to rejoin him. He ended up standing near one of the tall glass windows, looking out over a snowy garden, and drinking another glass of wine.

He had lost his supposed interest in eavesdropping on the other guests at the party, and he had also lost some of his situational awareness. So, when he heard someoneâ€™s voice directly behind him, he didnâ€™t register that he was being addressed until she spoke his name.

â€œYou must be the one I was told to find, Rear Admiral Reuenthal.â€

Reuenthal turned on his heel. There was the woman who had been sitting at the Lichtenlade table, standing a few feet from him, tilting her head to the side. She had long, blonde hair and was shorter than he was by a fair amount. Although she was slim and didnâ€™t look like she would present much of a danger to anyone, her eyes were cold and hard, ice blue. It was this open meanness that gave him pause. She was wearing an emerald green dress that contrasted with her blood red lipstick, and her tongue flicked out to lick her lips as she waited for Reuenthal to answer her.

â€œI assume the Baroness Westpfale told you to hunt me down,â€ he said.

â€œDid she tell you to find me? I saw you were staring, earlier.â€

â€œNo,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œShe told me someone would be looking for me, but she refused to say who. I suppose because you are a member of the Lichtenlade clan, she thought I would be prejudiced against you.â€

â€œHah.â€ The woman laughed, but it was a cold sound. â€œAnd why would that be, Herr Reuenthal?â€

â€œUnless something changes over the next few months, it seems like Iâ€™m destined to be your enemy, or at least your familyâ€™s.â€

â€œThen letâ€™s be enemies.â€

â€œI was told not to make any new ones at this party.â€

â€œThatâ€™s a pity.â€ She glanced behind herself at the table where her family sat. One of the older women was watching her every move.

â€œWhy do you say that?â€

â€œBaroness Westpfale saidâ€” and if Iâ€™m wrong, please do not take this the wrong wayâ€” that you and I are very similar people. She has told me in the past that I am not capable of holding any warm feeling in my heart other than the heat of anger.â€ She smiled. â€œIf Iâ€™m incapable of a warm love, a burning hatred will have to satisfy me. And Iâ€™ve been very bored, recently. If you want to be my enemy, it might make things more exciting.â€

He stared at her, and she met his eyes without flinching. â€œLet me get you a drink.â€

â€œPoison, if you want to prove your best intentions,â€ she said.

His lips curled, and he headed off to the bar to go get her something. He glanced behind himself as he went, and saw her lean against the windowsill, watching him watch her. At the bar, he procured drinks for both of themâ€” there was a nasty cinnamon flavored bottle of spirits that the bartender was putting into eggnog as a holiday drink, but Reuenthal asked for it straight. Drink acquired, he went back to her at the window and held out one of the glasses.

â€œTo warm your heart,â€ he said.

â€œIâ€™ll take the other, thank you,â€ she said, and reached for the glass in his right hand instead of the one he was offering.

â€œI thought you wanted poison,â€ he said, but let her have it.

â€œWhat kind of enemy of yours would I be if I didnâ€™t also try to make you drink poison?â€

â€œIâ€™ve poisoned both glasses.â€

She lifted hers to her lips, smiled, and knocked it back at once, not flinching even a little. Reuenthal drank his just as fast. It burned on the way down, cinnamon and high proof alcohol. It tasted disgusting.

â€œDelicious,â€ she said. â€œInvigorating. Letâ€™s dance.â€

â€œYou like dancing?â€

â€œVery much so,â€ she said. She grabbed his arm, and pulled him towards the dance floor. He went willingly, but she seemed nervous about something, her fingers digging into his arm. He saw what it was immediately: one of the women who had been sitting next to her at the Lichtenlade table had gotten up and was walking purposefully towards them. To avoid this encroaching presence, she flung herself into Reuenthalâ€™s arms, and they hid themselves among the swirling, seething mass of dancers, becoming one with the motion of the crowd. The first song they danced to was bright and fastâ€” heavy on the horns from the band at the frontâ€” and there was a prescribed dance that went along with it, one that Reuenthal had to search the depths of his memory to find the steps to.

She was a very good dancer, but the nervousness didnâ€™t leave her, even as they moved body to body. When they turned, she would whip her neck around like a ballerina, but she was scanning the crowd, and at times would try to take the leading step in the dance to move them both further into the room. This annoyed Reuenthal, and instead of letting her, he gripped her more tightly, feeling the thin strings of muscle move beneath her skin. She stopped trying to move after that.

â€œHow do you know the baroness?â€ he asked as the song changed to something that would allow for conversation, a slower dance that pushed them more tightly together.

â€œWe went to school together,â€ she said. â€œAnd you, how do you know her?â€

â€œI donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll tell you.â€

â€œIâ€™ll have to assume that youâ€™re a jilted lover, then. Now that sheâ€™s marrying someone else.â€

â€œAnd sheâ€™s trying to set me up with a replacement? Does that seem like something she would do?â€

â€œOf course. She loves to play that kind of game with people. The only problem comes when she learns that sheâ€™s not the only one capable of playing it. And that the rules arenâ€™t ones that she gets to write herself.â€ Even as she spoke, she kept her eyes on the side of the crowd. When she flinched, Reuenthal too glanced at the woman who was trying to push through the crowd towards them, and spun them through into the deepest mass of swirling dresses.

â€œFor a friend of hers, you have a low opinion of her.â€

â€œThatâ€™s because sheâ€™s not my friend,â€ the woman said, rather viciously.

â€œWhat is she to you, then?â€

â€œI donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll tell you.â€Â 

â€œTell me, or Iâ€™ll stop dancing with you. Your family can have you back.â€

â€œWhy do you want to know?â€ she asked.

â€œBecause I want to know why the baroness was so insistent that we meet each other. What could we possibly have to gainâ€” or what could she have to gain?â€

â€œShe owes me,â€ the woman said. â€œThis is for my sake. Though Iâ€™m sure she has her reasons for choosing you, rather than some other man she knows. Gods know sheâ€™s familiar with plenty of men.â€

â€œAnd I have to be a man, for whatever scheme is going on?â€

â€œObviously.â€

â€œAnd what is it that you want, here? Whatâ€™s your goal?â€

â€œI want to win.â€ She stared into his eyes as she said this, and he didnâ€™t doubt that she was telling the truth. But they turned, and he could see the older woman on the edge of the crowd, her expression cold.

â€œAnd what will happen to you if you lose?â€ he asked.

â€œIâ€™m not going to answer that question,â€ she said.

It was unfortunate that this was her answer, because the song ended at that moment, and Reuenthal dropped his hands and released her. She tried to grab him again, to keep dancing, but he said, â€œYou should have answered my questions. Too bad.â€

He started to walk off the dance floor, and she followed him. â€œWaitâ€”â€

But it was too late. The woman who had been watching from the sidelines came up to the both of them, as soon as they left the crowd.

â€œEfriede,â€ the older woman said, â€œwhat are you doing?â€ Her glare had fallen away, replaced with a concerned, motherly impression. It was vaguely sickening, to contrast with the former expression. She stepped towards Elfriede controllingly, but the hand she laid on her arm was feather light.

Elfriedeâ€™s whole manner changed. She made her tone light, and her smile sickly. â€œIâ€™m dancing, mama.â€Â 

â€œWith what gentleman?â€ the older woman asked, turning to Reuenthal.

â€œOne whoâ€™s leaving,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œGoodnight, Fraulein.â€

He left, but as soon as he was far enough away that he didnâ€™t think anyone was watching him, he turned back to look at Elfriede and her older relative. Elfriedeâ€™s face had twisted into something bitter, and her motherâ€” Reuenthal had to assume it was her motherâ€” was digging her nails into her arm and pulling her away, back towards their family table. As she was dragged along, she turned her head like an owl, scanning the crowd, and she looked directly at Reuenthal, bitter anger in her gaze. Reuenthal cocked his head to the side. What was she going to do to him? He deliberately turned away.

Reuenthal got himself another drink. He was tempted to go find Mittermeyer again, but then he spotted him, dancing with his wife. He leaned against the window and watched them, drinking his wine and speaking to no one. They wove into and out of sight, just like every other pair of dancers, and Reuenthal stared, and stared. He doubted that Mittermeyer saw himâ€” he wasnâ€™t as observant of these things as Reuenthal tended to be.

He spared an occasional glance at the Lichtenlade table. Just as he was watching the Mittermeyers, Elfriede was watching him, with just as cold an expression on her face. On his fifth drink, not sure what he was motivated by other than drunkenness, he raised his glass to her across the room. She had no response. He downed his drink, and then decided that he couldnâ€™t bear to be at this party any longer, even if the alcohol was free.

He left, but he stopped in one of the bathrooms first.Â 

Beyond the noise and heat of the party, he was suddenly cognizant of the ringing in his ears from the sudden cessation of noiseâ€” the faint strains of music and sounds of voices still carrying through the dark and empty hallway of Neue Sanssouci, but they were difficult to hear over the buzzing in his headâ€” and the sweat that suddenly cooled on his forehead from leaving the sweltering crowd. He was drunker than he thought, too, and he swayed on his feet as he shoved open the bathroom door.

It was blessedly empty, and he was washing his hands and staring into his reflection when he heard the door open behind him. He caught a glimpse of emerald green in the glass, and he turned to find Elfriede right behind him, her disdainful gaze roaming over the urinals.

â€œWhat are you doing here?â€ Reuenthal asked.

â€œI donâ€™t give up that easily.â€

â€œSo you followed me into the bathroom? You must be particularly stupid, or trusting, or lack some aspect of self-preservation.â€

â€œThatâ€™s what my mother says.â€

â€œMaybe you should listen to her and develop one,â€ he replied. â€œGet out of here.â€

â€œNo, I wonâ€™t.â€

Reuenthal took a step towards her. â€œYouâ€™ve made a fundamental error: you donâ€™t want me anywhere near you.â€

She didnâ€™t flinch at all, and she stared directly into his eyes. â€œYou arenâ€™t going to hurt me,â€ she said.

â€œSaying something like that would make a lesser man want to try.â€

â€œThatâ€™s the goal,â€ she said. â€œThe only way you could hurt me is by ignoring me. And I wonâ€™t let you do that.â€

â€œWhy do you think that youâ€™re going to get whatever it is that you want out of me?â€

â€œMaggie told me that you have a house,â€ she said, changing the subject completely.Â 

â€œAnd what else did she tell you about me?â€

â€œThat you were my ticket, that I could get you to do whatever I needed.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know what gave her that impression. Itâ€™s a wrong one.â€

Elfriede reached out towards him. He wasnâ€™t sure what she was trying to do, but he grabbed her wrist, yanking it upwards so that she was forced to step towards him, close enough that he could feel the heat of her body and smell her perfumeâ€” something musky and vaguely masculine. He had pinned himself against the sink onthe other side,and she bore down on him, leaning forward.

â€œYou want something from me, too,â€ she said.

â€œI donâ€™t want anything from you.â€

But his body betrayed him as her other hand crept between his legs, tracing its way up towards his belt. He was too drunk to think properly. He should have pushed her away, but instead he grabbed her chin, his grip far too strong, maybe even enough to bruise. He tilted her head up to face him, and pressed his thumb against her lips, smearing her lipstick. Her breath came out through her teeth.

â€œShe said that you wanted someone to hate.â€ Now she was breathing rapidly. â€œYou can hate me. But I need to get out of here.â€

â€œYou want to be hated?â€

She opened her mouth enough to bare her teeth, and Reuenthal let go of her chin to slip two fingers inside her mouth. She tried to bite him, but he hooked them into the soft flesh of her cheek and pulled, making her beautiful face twist into something ugly by his hand.

â€œItâ€™s better to be hated than ignored,â€ she said, garbled past his fingers. Her roving hand had made it past his belt.

â€œNot here,â€ he said, and pulled his fingers out of her mouth with a wet pop. â€œYour mother knows we were talking. Sheâ€™ll know where you went.â€

â€œBut she wonâ€™t be able to hold me.â€

And she smiled, knowing that she had won.

Chapter End Notes

"With friends like these, who needs enemies?"

Sorry for the slight delay in getting this chapter moving lol. I had covid haha. Can't believe after like 2.5 yrs I finally got the plague. I suppose it was only a matter of time u.u

Also idk this chapter was just weirdly difficult to write for some reason. usually "reuenthal behaves really badly at someone's dinner party" is my favorite type of scene to write,but I struggled with this one. i think it would have been easier to write from Elfriede POV, b/c then we would have gotten a lot of information that I can only sorta say indirectly here. but my plans for an elfriede chapter were deemed TOO out there so they were scrapped lol. I'll keep her POV in my back pocket in case I need it later. anyway she's gonna be weird and horny and terrible along with reuenthal for the foreseeable future lol. i know a lot of people have been waiting for her to show up. considering that she's hands down one of my fave chars in LOGH, it's incredible that it's taken me um. almost a million words of fic for me to get around to writing her at all

anyway considering that the civil war is coming soon, probably everyone in the empire is going to stop having stupid little parties, at least for a while. so i'll have to find a different backdrop for my nonsenses :p

i'd love to hear what you all think :]

thank you so much to em for the beta read!

you can find me in the usual places javert @ tumblr, natsinator @ twitter, gayspaceopera.carrd.co , discord https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

Scenes on the Occasion of a Wedding

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Mittermeyer

April 488 I.C., Odin

It never ceased to be strange to invite a baroness, and now a count, over for dinner at his flat, but Mittermeyer found that Yang and Magdalena were quite natural in the small and cozy space. Magdalena was relentlessly charming, even if she was overdressed for the casual gathering, and Yang was all gentle smiles; he had a way of looking at Mittermeyer, catching his eye, and putting him instantly at ease. That was just the way that Yang had always been.

The dinner conversation was lively, with Magdalena tugging everyone else along with her in her boundless enthusiasm for discussing plans: what the weather forecast was for the day of the wedding, the bachelorette party that Eva was throwing for her at the end of the week, and her plans for her honeymoon with Yang. Mittermeyer, even if he had wanted to contribute, couldnâ€™t have gotten a word in edgewise. But this, he had come to understand, was still Magdalena on her best behavior. She kept on her best behavior because she was enamored with his wife, and so she designed the conversation around engaging and amusing her, rather than the men at the table. Yang didnâ€™t seem to mindâ€” when he finished eating, he propped his hands on his chin and just smiled and let Magdalenaâ€™s talk wash over him.

â€œNow, you have to tell me, Eva, and be honest,â€ Magdalena said, â€œdo you think Iâ€™m going to enjoy married life?â€ Yangâ€™s eyebrows twitched in concern, but there was no edge in the question that Mittermeyer could detect, and Magdalenaâ€™s cheeky smile stayed plastered to her face. Yang was probably better at reading Magdalenaâ€™s capricious moods than anyone else, thoughâ€” there must have been some invisible signal she was giving off.

Eva giggled, helped by her second glass of wine. â€œYou wouldnâ€™t have agreed to get married if you didnâ€™t think you would,â€ she pointed out.

â€œWell, one often finds that thereâ€™s a mismatch between expectations and reality! Come on, tell me, do you think Iâ€™ll enjoy it?â€

â€œYes, of course I do,â€ Eva said. â€œI think youâ€™ll be very happy. And Hank, too.â€

â€œWhy do you think that?â€ Magdalena asked. â€œReallyâ€” I want to know.â€ She, too, was a little drunk, and while her tone remained light, her sincerity made her lean forward on the table and look Eva intently in the eyes.

â€œWell, I donâ€™t know,â€ she began. Eva was clearly flustered. â€œBut Hank is, you know, very kind, and honest, and he is handsome.â€ She glanced at Mittermeyer, with her sweet smile. â€œYou donâ€™t mind me saying so, I hope, darling?â€

Mittermeyer laughed. â€œNo, of course not. Youâ€™d be doing Leigh a disservice by saying heâ€™s not handsome.â€Â 

This caused Yang to redden, carefully not looking at Mittermeyer. â€œYou donâ€™t need to tease me,â€ he said. â€œAnd none of those things means anythingâ€¦â€ He trailed off into mumbles, and rubbed at the back of his head.

â€œI think they mean quite a lot,â€ Mittermeyer said quietly. Yang did look up at him then, and his awkwardness fell away as he met Mittermeyerâ€™s eyes.

â€œYes,â€ Eva said, â€œthey really do. You and Wolf are very similar, in that way.â€ She tilted her head with a smile. â€œIâ€™m very happy to be married to Wolf, and Iâ€™d never want a different husband, but if things had somehow turned out differently, Iâ€™m sure I would have been very happy to marry Hank instead.â€

â€œAnd I would get to marry Wolf?â€ Magdalena asked with a silly, gleeful trill. She turned to him. â€œOh, darling !â€ And she comically leaned towards him and clutched at his arm, making everyone laugh. â€œToo bad youâ€™re already taken, when youâ€™re the only man I know who isnâ€™t a scoundrel, Iâ€™m told.â€

â€œYouâ€™ll have your own husband, so youâ€™ll have to keep your hands off mine,â€ Eva said with a giggle.

â€œHmm, well, I would be happy to share Hank with you, if you like him so much,â€ Magdalena said with a wicked grin. â€œItâ€™s only fair.â€

Yang buried his face in his hands. â€œMaggieâ€¦â€

â€œWhat?â€ she asked, a cheeky smile plastered to her face.

â€œI believe at one point you said that he could only handle one woman,â€ Mittermeyer teased. â€œOr have you changed your mind about that, recently?â€

â€œHmâ€¦â€ Magdalena said. â€œYouâ€™re right. I suppose I should be lucky to marry a one-woman man.â€

Eva shook her head indulgently and got up to start clearing the dishes away. Mittermeyer hastened to help her. Magdalena wandered into the living room and began fiddling with the sound system, causing the strain of some unfamiliar orchestra to fill the air.

â€œThis is the band I hired for the wedding,â€ she called. â€œNice, isnâ€™t it?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know the first thing about music, Iâ€™m afraid,â€ Mittermeyer replied.

â€œAll you soldiers are so uncultured!â€

â€œI think itâ€™s very nice,â€ Eva said. They finished gathering all the dishes from the table, and went out to the living room, where they found that Magdalena was forcing Yang to dance with her, though there was very little room for them to do so, between the coffee table and the TV stand. Yang kept glancing behind himself nervously, afraid that Magdalena was going to make him trip over some furniture if he didnâ€™t keep track of it all. He gave Mittermeyer a relieved smile when he appeared in the doorway, because this caused Magdalena to spin around one last time, then let go with a laugh.

â€œEva, darling, letâ€™s go to the boudoir â€” I want to show you how to do your hair with the little circlet I got you.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t mind us abandoning you?â€ Eva asked Mittermeyer.

â€œOf course he doesnâ€™t mind,â€ Magdalena said dismissively. â€œHeâ€™s happy to spend time talking with Hank about whatever it is husbands talk about when their wives arenâ€™t in the room.â€

â€œYouâ€™re not his wife yet!â€ Eva pointed out

â€œClose enough. Come on, darling.â€

Eva flashed Mittermeyer an apologetic smile, and he gave her a genuine one back, letting her leave. This left Yang and Mittermeyer alone, with the music still playing loudly enough to cover up any conversation that could otherwise travel between closed doors. Mittermeyer couldnâ€™t quite make up his mind on if Magdalena was a cruel genius or a kind one.

â€œYou still donâ€™t like dancing, I see,â€ Mittermeyer said. There was a small bar cart tucked into the corner of the room, half hidden behind some potted ferns, and Mittermeyer fixed drinks for both of them.

â€œNo matter how much I practice, I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll ever get good at it. I just let Maggie push me around.â€ But he was smiling as he said it, and he accepted his drink from Mittermeyer with thanks.Â 

They sat down on the couch together, very companionable, shoulder to shoulder. Yang was different than Reuenthal in that respectâ€” had Reuenthal been here, he would have been unable to resist taking advantage of the moment, even with Eva just in the next room. But Yang was peaceful and content, and Mittermeyer knew he wouldnâ€™t disturb the sanctity of Mittermeyerâ€™s house unless he invited him to.

â€œHow long do you think theyâ€™ll be in there?â€ Mittermeyer asked.

â€œIâ€™m sure it wonâ€™t take less than an hour,â€ Yang replied. â€œI know as soon as theyâ€™re finished with hair, Maggie will make her show off her dressâ€¦ You know how it is.â€ Magdalena was a kind genius, was what Yang was attempting to say.

Mittermeyer nodded and sipped at his drink, just listening to the music. Yang did the same.

â€œYouâ€™re very quiet tonight,â€ Mittermeyer pointed out after a while. â€œSomething on your mind?â€

â€œThe things that arenâ€™t on my mind would be a shorter list.â€

â€œIs there something specific?â€

Yang looked down into his glass. â€œNot really. I was just thinking about your wedding, I guess.â€

â€œWhat about it?â€ He couldnâ€™t help but be wary, though Yang would never be malicious in bringing it upâ€” he clearly only was mentioning it because he was pressed, and he was an honest man.

â€œItâ€™s nothing important,â€ he said hastily. â€œYou just reminded me, when you asked about if I liked dancingâ€” at your wedding I said that you would never have to dance with me.â€ There was an audible melancholy in his voice, one that belied that he had been thinking about this topic more than his casual phrasing would suggest. He shook his head. â€œThatâ€™s all Iâ€™m thinking aboutâ€” Iâ€™m being silly.â€

Mittermeyer looked at him for a moment, Yangâ€™s eyes skating away from his, a flush on his cheeks that couldnâ€™t quite be attributed to alcohol. Mittermeyer looked behind himself at the closed bedroom door into which Magdalena and Eva had disappeared, then put his drink down on the coffee table and stood, offering his hand to Yang. He looked up at him with wide eyes before taking it, and Mittermeyer gently tugged him to his feet and into the small center of the room, on the worn braided rug.

Yang was a nervous person in some ways, so Mittermeyer moved slowly as he put his hand on Yangâ€™s waist, stepping very close to him. Yang didnâ€™t say anything, but over the gentle music, Mittermeyer could hear the hitch-change in his breathing, shallow and fluttering. He pulled Yang against him, and Yang leaned his head on Mittermeyerâ€™s shoulder, his soft hair tickling his neck.

He had expected that dancing with Yang would be pleasant, but it was so much nicer than he had expected, to have Yangâ€™s warm body against his, pliant as Mittermeyer shuffled him around in a simple four step square. It could hardly even be considered dancing, but that didnâ€™t matter. It was perfect for what it was. With Yang, Mittermeyer didnâ€™t find himself missing the urgency that so much else in his life demanded from him.

But the song eventually ended. Yang lifted his head off of Mittermeyerâ€™s shoulder to look at him. Yangâ€™s eyes glitteredâ€” the darkness of space, with stars in itâ€” maybe it was the light, and maybe it was something else.Â 

â€œThank you,â€ Yang said. He touched Mittermeyerâ€™s cheek, so lightly that his fingertips barely grazed Mittermeyerâ€™s skin, and tickled the dayâ€™s worth of growth of his beard. He wasnâ€™t asking for anything, but Mittermeyer kissed him anyway, and pulled him back down to the couch. Yangâ€™s body melted against him, not at all urgent, but welcoming Mittermeyerâ€™s touch.

It was dangerous to kiss on the couch, and Mittermeyer positioned himself so that he could see the door of the bedroom. He had never had any self control when it came to this, which made him feel guilty, even as Yang seemed to be doing his best to push every thought out of Mittermeyerâ€™s headâ€” stroking his hair, leaning heavily against him, kissing him with a mouth that still tasted like alcohol.

They continued like this for a while, until Yang pulled away. Mittermeyer wondered why, and then he realized that while he had been paying attention to how Yangâ€™s body felt soft under his hands, Yangâ€™s hand traveling down his arm and side must have felt how he was tensing every muscle in his body at onceâ€” the strain of holding the guilt and pleasure of the moment in balance. Yang smiled at him, and Mittermeyer tried to relax.

â€œI should ask whatâ€™s on your mind,â€ Yang said.

â€œYou already know the answer.â€ He missed Yangâ€™s touch as soon as he no longer had it, but he couldnâ€™t quite bring himself to ask for it back. Yang saw the still-wanting look in Mittermeyerâ€™s eyes, and while he didnâ€™t kiss him again, he curled up on the couch, and let his head rest in Mittermeyerâ€™s lap. Mittermeyer ran his fingers through Yangâ€™s hair.

â€œIâ€™m jealous of you, you know,â€ Mittermeyer said after some time.

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ Yang murmured.

â€œNo, donâ€™t apologize.â€ He kept playing with Yangâ€™s hair. â€œYou just have a very good way of making me aware of how life could be. You always have.â€

Yang was silent.

â€œShould I tell Eva?â€

â€œShe would forgive you, if you did.â€

Mittermeyer knew that this was trueâ€” Yang wouldnâ€™t lie to him, and he knew Eva very well. She was a forgiving person, and better than he was. But he didnâ€™t want to be the kind of person who needed to be forgiven. It was worse to keep her in the dark, but her knowing would change the way she saw him, make him into something difficult and complicated. It would hurt her, to know that her husband was not an honest man.

He had spent years thinking about this, and had never come to a conclusion, and he doubted that he was going to now. But he let his fingers drift through Yangâ€™s hair, and this eased some of his tension, even as the thoughts continued to pass on their circular journey through his mind. He realized, after some time, that Yang had fallen asleep.

Although he really should get Yangâ€™s head off his lap, he didnâ€™t want to move. Perhaps he was testing himself. So, when Magdalena and Eva emerged from the bedroom, with Evaâ€™s hair coiled up delicately around a flowery circlet, Yang was still curled up and snoring and using him as a pillow. â€œYou must not be letting your fiance get enough sleep,â€ Mittermeyer said to Magdalena. â€œHe passed out on top of me.â€

â€œNo, I think it must be that you bored him to sleep,â€ Magdalena retorted.Â 

The noise woke Yang up, and he jolted upright, his face beet red, and he looked at Mittermeyer in a momentary panic. â€œIâ€™m so sorry, I must have fallen asleepâ€” I didnâ€™t mean toâ€” on you.â€ He was still half incoherent in his return to consciousness.

â€œItâ€™s fine, Leigh,â€ Mittermeyer said. â€œIf it bothered me, I would have woken you up.â€

Reuenthal

Why he had been convinced to come here tonight, Reuenthal couldnâ€™t explain. The bar that Yangâ€™s bachelor party was being held at was upscale, and a far cry from most of the bars that Yang had preferred to frequent back in the days when he was teaching at the IOA. He was sure that Yang hadnâ€™t picked it, even though it was his event. It must have been suggested to him by his fiancee, or even by someone like Duke Braunschweig. At least everyone else at the gathering seemed to appreciate the venue, probably due to the tab Yang had opened at the bar, on which everyone was putting their drinks.

Yang had not so much announced that he would pay for everyone as simply, in his usual unassuming way, let the information percolate, quietly enough that no one could protest or thank him. It had been over half a year since he had been made a count, and this was the first outlay of his money that Reuenthal had even seen. Yangâ€™s lifestyle, such as it was, hardly seemed to have changed in the interim. This was the subject of no small amount of derision from Elfriede, when Reuenthal happened to mention it. But he had fallen out of the habit of mentioning Yang to her, for that reason, and others.

Elfriede wasnâ€™t in the bar tonight, of course, since it was Yangâ€™s bachelor party. There was Mittermeyer, who seemed completely unencumbered by the world, laughing and joking with Bittenfeld and Wahlen. Bittenfeld had arranged his leave specifically to see Yang married, and had come back to Odin from some distant frontier resupply duty. He was a captain these days, and therefore in charge of a whole squad of ships, but he complained endlessly about how dull supply runs were. Wahlen, on the other hand, had made it to commodore, and was on an extended personal leave already due to the birth of his son. He showed everyone who would give him the opportunity pictures of the extremely rotund, bald baby and the tiny wife he had apparently emerged from.Â 

Eisenach, who also remained a captain (and probably would for the rest of all time, unless someone decided that a flag officer who refused to give verbal orders was a thing that the Imperial Fleet could suffer to have), was playing darts with Yangâ€™s red-headed eavesdropping protege, Lieutenant Kircheis. It seemed that the lowest-ranked person at the party had decided that the silent captain was the safest avenue for socialization.

After a little while spent speaking with people in obligatory greeting, Reuenthal was sitting at the bar, drinking a whiskey. He wasnâ€™t quite alone: Yangâ€™s friend Oberstein, the dour looking captain with prematurely gray hair, sat a seat away from him with a flagon of beer in front of him that never seemed to get any emptier. It seemed they had both received pity invitations to the party.

When Bittenfeld roared out, â€œYou invited WHO?â€ Reuenthal looked over at Yang, over at the pool table, who waved his hands in a conciliatory manner.

â€œWell he said he didnâ€™t want to come, so itâ€™s a moot point anyway!â€

â€œLeigh, you have a saintly ability to forgive, I think,â€ Wahlen said. â€œIâ€™m willing to take your lead, but I remember when we graduatedâ€” Iâ€™m glad Ansbach had the sense to stay away, so he doesnâ€™t accidentally repeat that infamous fight at Josefâ€™s.â€

â€œWeâ€™re not at Josefâ€™s,â€ Yang pointed out.

â€œYeah, this place is much classier. It would make a much funnier image for me to toss him over a table,â€ Bittenfeld said.

â€œAnsbach is fine,â€ Yang stressed. â€œIsnâ€™t he, Kircheis?â€

Kircheis, startled at being summoned, missed his dart in the game, and it thunked into the wall outside the board, causing Eisenach to shake his head and go retrieve it. â€œEr, yes, sir,â€ Kircheis said, though he sounded more like he was trying to preserve some kind of peace than he had any real convictions.

â€œIâ€™ll believe that when I see it,â€ Mittermeyer said.

â€œWell, heâ€™s coming to the wedding,â€ Yang said. â€œSo I guess Iâ€™m glad I warned you all. He really is fine, though.â€

â€œIf you say so,â€ Wahlen said.

â€œLookâ€” if you made me choose between Ansbach and Baron Flegelâ€”â€ Yang said.

â€œWell if THATâ€™S the kind of choice that you have, no wonder,â€ Bittenfeld said. â€œLike a drink of piss in the desert.â€ Presumably, Yang had complained about Duke Braunschweigâ€™s extended family in his letters to Bittenfeld as much as he had to Reuenthal.

â€œYour talent for metaphor has greatly improved since I last saw you,â€ Yang said dryly.

â€œThank you,â€ Bittenfeld said with a comical bow.

Reuenthal shook his head and turned back to his drink. He drank in silence for a while. It was easy enough to listen to the chatter of his old friends, the ambiance of the bar outside their small circle. It neither soothed nor discomforted him. He could feel Yangâ€™s occasional glances in his direction, but he seemed to have decided that truly disturbing Reuenthal would be unwise. Was he right? Reuenthal didnâ€™t know.
