He remained at the bar, and was unfortunately joined by Lieutenant Kircheis, who sat down near him and got a beer.

â€œNo interest in poker, Lieutenant?â€ Reuenthal asked.

Kircheis seemed surprised to be addressed. â€œCommodore Leigh would feel very bad if he won money from me, and heâ€™d spend the next week trying to pay me back,â€ Kircheis said. â€œItâ€™s better if I bow out before the game begins.â€

â€œSo, just convinced youâ€™d lose.â€

â€œItâ€™s a game of chance, sir. Thereâ€™s a chance Iâ€™d lose, no matter how well I played my hand.â€

â€œThe lieutenant is right,â€ Oberstein said. He had been listening to their brief conversation, and paying attention to the goings-on at the party just as much as Reuenthal had. â€œStrategy is about playing hands you know you can win.â€

â€œYou count cards, Oberstein?â€ Reuenthal asked. Thinking about it, it wouldnâ€™t surprise him if Oberstein could see through the cards, with his mechanical eyes.

â€œIâ€™m not a gambler.â€

â€œYou and Lieutenant Kircheis have met before, I assume?â€

â€œYes. On Iserlohn,â€ Oberstein said. â€œItâ€™s rare that all of Commodore Leighâ€™s close friends are together on Odin.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure he apologized profusely to you for costing you your Iserlohn post.â€

â€œItâ€™s no matter,â€ Oberstein said. â€œI knew that it was a matter of time. There are other posts.â€

â€œWhat are you doing on Odin, sir?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œActuarial duty,â€ Oberstein replied dryly.

â€œAnd Iâ€™ve been moved to the budget office,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œItâ€™s interesting that Fleet Admiral Muckenburger considers hands on the purse strings to have no power.â€

â€œWhen the Kaiser dies, Braunschweigâ€™s fleet will continue to fund itself on his planetsâ€™ revenues, and what heâ€™s managed to stash away for this occasion. There isnâ€™t time for meaningful change in the movement of money to make a difference, at this point. If you had been assigned there five years ago, there would have been time, and reason.â€

â€œYou speak so openly of defrauding His Majestyâ€™s fleet, Captain Oberstein.â€

â€œDefrauding? No. There would have been ways to move money that no one could have called improper. Funding one fleet while disbanding others for budgetary reasons. Unless you would have thought to directly enrich yourself?â€

Reuenthal laughed darkly. â€œThere are plenty of men who would.â€

â€œAn innovation that was promptly conveyed to the rebel fleet, before anyone even had a chance to get a tactical advantage out of it,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œTrue,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œItâ€™s an interim position, anyway. He wonâ€™t be in it for long. And the same for myself in the budget office, and Oberstein, fixing the fleetâ€™s accounts. You and Leigh are very lucky that you have a permanent place.â€

â€œYes, sir,â€ Kircheis said, though he didnâ€™t sound so sure.

â€œYou donâ€™t like working for Duke Braunschweig?â€

Kircheis hesitated, then said, â€œItâ€™s not Duke Braunschweig Iâ€™m working for.â€

â€œYou should be careful, Lieutenant,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œDangerous talk.â€

â€œYes, sir,â€ Kircheis said.

Reuenthal wasnâ€™t sure if he should pity Kircheis or not. Yang clearly trusted him and liked him, enough to invite him to this party, anyway. â€œCommodore Leigh has a unique talent for gathering loyal friends,â€ he said.

â€œAnd in such great numbers,â€ Reuenthal said, sarcasm in his voice, though it wasnâ€™t exactly fair. Yang had plenty of contacts who werenâ€™t invited to the small partyâ€” Count Mariendorf, his spy on Phezzan, surely more who Reuenthal didnâ€™t know about.

â€œPerhaps not,â€ Oberstein said. â€œBut he is well positioned, and a small group is easier to coordinate, when the time comes.â€

â€œAre you trying to ask who here is loyal enough to Leigh?â€ Reuenthal asked. â€œIâ€™m the wrong person to get that information out of.â€

â€œItâ€™s for the best that Commodore Ansbach declined his invitation tonight. It would be unwise to talk about all of this with him in the room,â€ Reuenthal said.

Reuenthal could remember. He was sure that Mittermeyer had the same sensation concerning his own wedding, years ago. That was the reason he had gotten married in the first place.

Mittermeyer continued. â€œBut everything just keeps happening, and afterwards it doesnâ€™t feel like anythingâ€™s fixed or normal, and as soon as I get used to the status quo, thereâ€™s something else just looming out there.â€ He tilted his beer towards the darkness of the horizon, against which the city lights stood out, until they vanished under an oncoming curtain of rain. It was still far off in the distance, but it had begun to obscure the furthest lights.

â€œAnyway,â€ Mittermeyer said, â€œthe thing about the war isâ€” I canâ€™t even imagine whatâ€™s on the other side of it. So I canâ€™t build it up as this perfect place in the future where everything will be somehow, magicallyâ€¦â€ He trailed off and shook his head.

â€œYou canâ€™t? Iâ€™m surprised.â€

â€œI mean, I can say â€˜once itâ€™s over, Iâ€™ll be happyâ€™ but thatâ€™s not anything,â€ Mittermeyer said.

Perhaps Mittermeyer had cut to the difference between the two of them, though he didnâ€™t realize it. He wouldnâ€™t have been saying so much if he had seen it, cold and clear as dayâ€” though he was drunk, which made him talkative.Â

â€œI thought you were happy now,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œThatâ€™s the impression you give.â€

â€œIs it?â€ He laughed. â€œI guess Iâ€™m glad I do.â€ He finished his beer, and looked forlornly into his glass, trying to summon more from the air. â€œI am happy, when Iâ€™m not thinking about it. That, Reuenthal could understand. And Mittermeyer was telling the truthâ€” he always was happy in their snatched moments on Iserlohn, but when he started anticipating going on leave, it fell apart. He nodded silently.

â€œWhat about you, Oskar?â€ Mittemeyer asked.

â€œWhat about me?â€

â€œAre you happy, these days?â€

â€œDoes it matter?â€

â€œIt matters to me.â€

â€œIâ€™m looking forward to the war, too,â€ Reuenthal said shortly. This satisfied Mittermeyer, who nodded. He could imagine a future with everything he wanted to see, the kinds of futures that swirled through his dreamsâ€” visions of Yang and Mittermeyer, and fire, and bloodâ€” but that wasnâ€™t the anticipation that he felt in his waking moments.Â 

It wasnâ€™t dread. The feeling that was closest to his heart was one that he couldnâ€™t express to anyone elseâ€” not even Yang or Mittermeyer. It was a feeling of wanting. Craving. Waiting to be tested, waiting for the blow to come, and wondering if he had prepared himself enough to endure it.

And yet, he didnâ€™t want to get it over with. What if the moment before the blow landed could stretch on forever? What if the moment of being hit could last forever, too? Perhaps, unlike Mittermeyer, he was waiting for the storm to begin, but hoped that it would never end. Whatever Mittermeyer saw as beautiful on the other side disgusted him.

Reuenthal turned around, leaning against the railing with his elbows behind him. He was looking out the large, sliding glass doors onto the balcony, either looking at Reuenthal and Mittermeyer, or past them, at the clouds that were swiftly scuttling towards them on the horizon. He was startled when Reuenthal turned around, and their eyes met across the distance.

â€œI should go home,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œIâ€™ll see you tomorrow, Mittermeyer.â€

Â 

It was pouring rain when Reuenthal arrived home. His car headlights slashed through the haze and illuminated the walls of his house. Even though it was well past midnight, approaching two in the morning, there were lights on in the windows, and he could see Elfriedeâ€™s shadow cross the kitchen.

He sat in the car with his lights off and watched her silhouette move across the room. He pretended like she was someone else, but he didnâ€™t know who. When she stopped her pacing around the kitchen and stood in front of the window watching him, Reuenthal finally turned off the car and walked up to the house, splashing through the invisible puddles in the driveway and slamming open the side door.

When he made it into the kitchen, she was no longer there. This was a familiar game, at this point. If he stopped in the kitchen, or went into the living room to get himself a drink, she would wander through the building like a ghost, creaking on the stairs and on the floor overhead, letting Reuenthal only catch glimpses of her in windows or doorways until he hunted her down.

It was hot inside, almost unbearably so. Elfriede wanted things to be so warm. She once said that it was the only thing she had liked about being trapped in her familyâ€™s frontier homeâ€” it was tropical. Reuenthal could hardly imagine it, except that his house had become like a sauna. He wondered if she would do this all through the summer, raising the temperature degree by degree, until they both boiled to death in it.

The kitchen smelled like spoiled milk. He discovered the culprit immediately, a half-gallon that had been left out on the countertop, open. He was unsure when it had gone bad, or why it had been left there, but he poured it down the sinkâ€” thick, white slime coating the stainless steel.

He could still feel the alcohol in his system, distantly, and the throbbing of his head, more distantly still. The hot air of the house pressed down upon him and made him feel dizzy as he swam through it, up the stairs and down the hall. He still was in the habit of moving silently, no matter how disoriented he was, and so Elfriede didnâ€™t hear him coming until he stood in the doorway of the master bedroom, or she would have turned around to face the door before he arrived.

She was standing at the window, naked, curtains pulled all the way open. The window faced the back of the house, and there were no neighbors for a quarter mile anyway, so no one but Reuenthal could see her.

â€œWere you waiting for me?â€ Reuenthal asked.

Elfriede spun around, startled. He didnâ€™t know why she was so surprised. She had known he was coming, even if she hadnâ€™t heard his footsteps in the hallway.

â€œNo,â€ she said. When he studied her more closely, he saw that she was wet with rainwaterâ€” the window behind her was open, and drops were tracing their way down her skin. She had goosebumps on her arms, and her hair hadnâ€™t been washed in several daysâ€” it fell limply around her shoulders.

â€œThen why are you still up?â€

â€œYou think Iâ€™m going to go to bed just because youâ€™re here?â€ This was the opening salvo of an old argument. He would tell her that she obviously would be.Â  They would go through a few lines of back and forth exchange to escalate, and she would call him a splenetic egoist, or something like it, and he would call her a cunt.

Thinking of going through with this, Reuenthalâ€™s head throbbed like an open wound. He stepped through the doorway without saying anything else and began mechanically removing his constricting jacket. Elfriede watched him.

â€œDid you have a bad time with your friends?â€ she asked mockingly.

Reuenthal continued to say nothing. She was like the buzzing of an insect in his ears.

â€œI donâ€™t know why you bothered to go.â€

He struggled with the crimson fabric of his cravat. Before he could get it off, Elfriede came up behind him and slipped her fingers beneath the band, taking up all the slack and making the silk cut into his throat, making the knot impossible to undo. He could still breathe, for now. Her hands were hot on his skin, sliding across his neck, to press on the soft flesh just below his jaw.

â€œWhat do you want?â€ Reuenthal asked. It wasnâ€™t a necessary questionâ€” he knew exactly what she wanted from him. She wanted him to get angry enough to turn around, to lay hands on her, to give her an excuse to hit and claw with impunity. To make it so that if he wanted something from her, he would have to take it by force. He sometimes tried to see if he could make her strike first, but she had a way of provoking him, and he had never yet succeeded in remaining entirely unflinching under her insults and touches that didnâ€™t quite make it to pain. He wondered what it would take to make her break, to make her anger come uncorked completely.

It was easy to understand why she had more restraint, why she didnâ€™t crack into immediate violence no matter how much he tried to twist verbal knivesâ€” they were very similar people, in their way. She was scared of him. If she was on the defensive, if she made him strike first, she could unleash her whole strength at him, struggling and writhing. She enjoyed that liberation. But if she struck firstâ€” what would he do? How far would he allow his strength to take him? This was a question that Reuenthal wasnâ€™t even sure he knew the answer to. At his core, he knew that even in his darkest moments, he always had an iron shell of self restraint that he had not managed to crack. How many times had he stood on a precipice and not thrown himself off? A number too high to remember or count.Â 

It was interesting to wonder how far he would go, if that shell ever broke. They danced on the edge of that question, afraid of falling off the cliff, and on better days it was easy to eroticise the fear. Today was not one of those better days.

Elfriede hadnâ€™t answered his question, and instead just tightened the pressure on his throat. It made it hard to swallow, pressing against his Adamâ€™s apple. He wondered what she would do if he just stood there and took it. He closed his eyes. The world, having narrowed to the sensation of her hands on his neck, crashed around him like waves. He couldnâ€™t hear her breathing anymore, though it had been harsh and loud a moment ago. His ears rang.

He had some time in the space between taking his last breath and losing consciousnessâ€” he had the luxury of deciding if he wanted to allow it or not. The image of himself falling to the floor, his body completely vulnerable without his mind to inhabit it, flashed across his vision. In his imagination, he controlled Elfriede, inhabited her skin, let her loom over him with deadly intent, watched his empty shell from above, struck it. In his mind, he could be the knife and the wound at the same time.Â 

But that was a fantasy, and he couldnâ€™t allow it to become real. He toppled forward, pretending to lose consciousness. Elfriedeâ€™s hands were stuck in the fabric of his cravat, and she came down with him, hard, her body heavy on his back. She yanked her hands free, and Reuenthal flipped them both over and grabbed her wrists, pinning her to the wooden floor. He loomed over her now, trapping her body completely beneath his, their faces together, breathing heavily. The oxygen rushed back into his blood, fizzing and electric.

â€œWhat do you want?â€ she asked him in a snarl. She tried to squirm out of his hold, but they both knew that she wouldnâ€™t be able to get up until he let her go. Abstractly, he thought it was a pity that she hadnâ€™t let him undress first. He would have to let go of her hands to take off his pants, and this would lose the moment.

She clearly knew this, too. Although she kept trying to free her hands from where he had them pinned above her head, at the same time, she was rubbing herself against him.

â€œYouâ€™re disgusting,â€ Reuenthal said, but he forced his leg in between hers, bearing down, giving her the pressure from his thigh that she was looking for.

â€œSo are you,â€ she said through gritted teeth.

She was right. He matched her movement for movement, her leg between his. A push and pull, if not a give and take. It was unpleasant to the point of pain, but there was still enough there that he wanted it desperately, couldnâ€™t stop himself from seeking it out. His nails dug into her wrists; she bit at his collarbone hard enough to bruise.

It wasnâ€™t that he didnâ€™t understand Mittermeyer. He understood perfectly well how in the moment he could be happy, because the moment pushed out every other thought. This was true for Reuenthal now, though it wasnâ€™t happiness. It wasnâ€™t anything. There was a kind of emptiness that came from overwhelming every receptive channel in his bodyâ€” the signals became a violent white noise: a static, electric. There were other ways to get to this place, but this was the way he got there now.

This emptiness carried him through the act to the end. It carried him past the disgust that drifted across the surface of his thoughts when they were both done, when he looked at her body beneath him, beautiful and slick with sweat. It carried him through his cold shower, and lasted until he returned to the bedroom and found her still awake and waiting, though she had turned off the lights. The window was still open, and all the heat that she loved so much was slipping out into the rain, which was coming in to puddle on the floor. Reuenthal shut the window and tossed his towel onto the water before it could ruin the hardwood.

â€œYouâ€™re coming with me, tomorrow,â€ he said as he mopped up the water. He didnâ€™t look at her.

â€œI didnâ€™t think you wanted to show me to your friends.â€

â€œDonâ€™t embarrass me.â€ He tossed the towel into the laundry basket and got into bed. As he put his head down on the pillow, she leaned over him and ran her hand through his wet hair. The touch was gentle, but she twisted the short strands around, letting him know that she could pull it if she wanted to.

â€œWhat changed your mind?â€ she asked. And she tugged on his hair enough to make him know she wanted an answer to the question.

â€œThey wonâ€™t stop asking about you,â€ he said. â€œIt will shut them up.â€ This wasnâ€™t the real reason, but he couldnâ€™t find the words for what the reason was, and even if he had them, he certainly wouldnâ€™t tell her.

â€œI doubt it,â€ she said. â€œPeople love to talk about a scandal.â€

â€œYour family must be grateful that you provide them with so many interesting conversation topics.â€

She twisted his hair again. â€œDonâ€™t talk about my family.â€

â€œNo? I did at the bar.â€

â€œAnd what did you say to your friends?â€

â€œWe were discussing how to destroy them,â€ he said. â€œBuilding our own castles in the sky above the ruins of Neue Sanssouci and your grand uncleâ€™s control of the Kaiser.â€

Her fingernails traced lines of ice across his scalp. â€œDuke Braunschweig hardly wants you to build him a new palace. He would be happy enough with the old one. Why would you need to tear it down?â€

He could hear Yang in his voice when he spoke. â€œWhy does it deserve to exist?â€

â€œAnd your new castle in the sky would be different, somehow?â€

â€œIf the person on the throne is the one who built it, then theyâ€™re worthy of it. A living thing, not some relic handed down from useless son to useless son.â€

â€œHah,â€ she said. â€œI doubt it.â€

â€œWhy?â€

â€œEven if Duke Braunschweig wins the throne through burning down his enemyâ€™s house, heâ€™s not any different. If you hate the Kaiser now, youâ€™ll hate him, too.â€

â€œI know.â€

â€œOh? Then why do you want to help him?â€

He was silent, which made her tug on his hair again, until he slapped her hand away. She let go, and settled down into the bed to face him.

â€œSo,â€ she said. â€œWho do you want to see on the throne?â€

â€œAfter he wins, Duke Braunschweig will be weak, and heâ€™ll think heâ€™s consolidated his camp,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œThatâ€™s room for opportunity.â€

â€œYouâ€™re a rebel to the bone,â€ Elfriede said. â€œBut I donâ€™t think you have the strength.â€

Yang didâ€” he knew this, as surely as he knew his own nameâ€” but Reuenthal would never say that to Elfriede. â€œIf I didnâ€™t, you wouldnâ€™t be here,â€ he said.

That was enough to shut her up.

Â 

Yang

The wedding was being held in the garden outside Magdalenaâ€™s mansion, with dinner and dancing inside afterwards. It was well into spring, and though the weather had been predicted to be fine, there was a light drizzle of rain falling by the afternoon. The plans remained the same, though, rain or shine, as the wedding had always been expected to take place under tents. The largest was nestled in among the just-greening bushes, with a covered corridor that led from the back of the house to the seats.

Even though Yang felt like she had invited the entire population of Odin, Magdalena kept saying that this was a small wedding. For nobility, it probably was. Aside from Yangâ€™s handful of friends, here was Magdalenaâ€™s huge number of extended relatives and acquaintances; the Braunschweigs, who needed to be invited to prevent offense; and many of Yangâ€™s former coworkers. Yang was very grateful to Magdalenaâ€™s family servants for taking care of so much of the greeting and seating of the guests, because even the minimal amount of socializing that he did before the ceremony began left him exhausted. Even Magdalena, with her desire to control the show, had bowed to the necessity of hiring an event organizer, who kept the whole show moving forward. It took all the work off Yangâ€™s plate, which meant he just had to show up and smile. That was about all he felt capable of doing, so that was for the best.

While he felt comfortable enough in his dress uniform, which he had worn so many times, it was his own skin that felt tight and itchy, and he was using all his self-restraint not to destroy the slick way his hair had been done by the stylist Maggie had hired. He wished that she was by his side as he walked around saying hello to people he knew, or barely knew. Without her to guide him through it all, he felt completely lost. She was hiding somewhere in the house, getting the last touches put on her outfit, which he had not been allowed to seeâ€” it was bad luck, or so she said.Â 

But at least this feeling of missing her by his side did more than anything else to calm his nerves about being married. They needed each other, or at least he needed her.Â 

As the appointed time drew closer, and the tent filled up with more and more people, Yang nervously walked around, and made his last few bits of small talk. Kircheis, who continued to take his duties as Yangâ€™s aide seriously, followed him around as a buffer, even though he wasnâ€™t part of the wedding ceremony in the least. Yang truly appreciated his help nonetheless.

It seemed a little too fraught to spend too much time speaking to his friends, especially Reuenthal and Mittermeyer, so Yang brought Kircheis over to introduce him to Admiral Merkatz and his daughter, Cora Feldmann. She was sitting in between Merkatz and Rear Admiral Bronner, which was an arrangement that Yang thought was an odd choice, but he wasnâ€™t going to question it. There was a seat reserved for Commodore Staden on the other side of Merkatz, but he had gotten up to find some water in the house to take some stomach medication with, and so wasnâ€™t here to say hello.

â€œIâ€™m so glad your schedule permitted you to come, sir,â€ Yang said to Merkatz.

â€œOf course. Iâ€™m glad I happened to be on Odin. I really must congratulate you, Leigh. Youâ€™ve come a long way.â€

Yang reached towards the back of his head to rub his hair, then remembered that his hair was supposed to stay neat, and dropped it awkwardly back down to his side. â€œYes, sir.â€ His smile was uncomfortable, but Merkatz didnâ€™t push the issue.

â€œAnd all of this because you didnâ€™t pay attention to my warning about Baroness Westpfale,â€ his daughter Cora said with a laugh. â€œMaybe thatâ€™s for the best.â€

â€œWell, sheâ€™s succeeded in putting a leash on me,â€ Yang said. â€œI think thatâ€™s what the intent was, wasnâ€™t it?â€

â€œI donâ€™t think Baroness Westpfale, of all people, can be thanked for your good standing in society,â€ Bronner said, wrinkling his nose. â€œI think you should be thanking someone else.â€

â€œYou know, Rear Admiral, I did thank you in the acknowledgement section of my book,â€ Yang said. â€œIâ€™ll get you a copy.â€

â€œIâ€™ve already read it, Leigh,â€ Bronner said, but he smiled, which made his owlish face look almost uncanny. Yang laughed.

â€œAdmiral Merkatz, have you met my, er, aide, Lieutenant Kircheis?â€

Kircheis had not expected to be dragged into this conversation, and he was startledâ€” he had been looking across the tent to where the Braunschweigs were sitting. Hilde was over there, talking to Lady Elizabeth, sitting in the seat that had been reserved for Elizabethâ€™s fiancee, Hans von Vering.Â 

â€œNo, I havenâ€™t had the pleasure,â€ Merkatz said. He offered his hand to Kircheis, who shook it.

â€œThe pleasure is mine, sir,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œI figured I should introduce you, since it seems like we may be working together more closely again in the future.â€

â€œYes,â€ Merkatz said, though this was with a pinch of his lips. â€œThat may be so.â€ He switched the topic. â€œI notice you didnâ€™t introduce him to Rear Admiral Bronnerâ€” have the two of you already met?â€

â€œOh, yes, Iâ€™m very well acquainted with Lieutenant Kircheis. Itâ€™s no surprise to me that he was Commodore Leighâ€™s favorite studentâ€” theyâ€™re both humanitarians.â€

â€œIs that so?â€ Merkatz asked.

â€œIâ€™m sure Rear Admiral Bronnerâ€™s next remark will be to say how terrible of actors we are, as well,â€ Yang said dryly.Â 

â€œWell, you wouldnâ€™t want me to accuse you of anything else on your wedding day!â€

Yang laughed. â€œWell, Iâ€™d say that there are far worse things in the world than being a humanitarian, or a bad actor.â€

â€œNot many,â€ Bronner said. â€œBut youâ€™re lucky that there are some.â€

â€œI think Iâ€™ve come around on humanitarianism,â€ Merkatz said.

â€œReally?â€ Yang looked up at him, startled.

â€œTo a degree.â€

â€œWell, everything to a degree,â€ Yang said wryly.

Merkatzâ€™s tone became serious. â€œIâ€™m afraid that without humanitarians close to the duke, weâ€™ll see far more bloodshed than this nation can really withstand. I hope that youâ€™re in a position to advise him well.â€

This ruined the cheerful mood, but Yang nodded. And he was glad to have Merkatz on his side, at least. â€œIâ€™ll do my best, sir,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™m sure you donâ€™t have any reason to doubt that.â€

â€œIâ€™m glad that I donâ€™t have to doubt that weâ€™ll be playing the same game, on the same team.â€

â€œYes, sir,â€ Yang said.Â 

It looked like Bronner was about to make another comment, but Kircheis pointed out to Yang that the event organizer was coming over to shoo everyone back to their seats, including Kircheis, and to get Yang into position. He bid his leave of his former superiors and made his way up to the front of the room, waiting near the small band for the signal for the event to begin. His heart had begun to beat strangely, and he tried to calm it by looking out past the edge of the tent into the dripping rain. The noise behind him turned from social chatter to everyone trying to find their seats, and faded out in Yangâ€™s ears, leaving only the soft dripping of the rain and the strings of the band. As the noise dimmed, Yang turned back to look at the assembled crowd.

Everyone was settled in the nice white event chairs on the green fake-grass carpet. There was Mittermeyer and Evangeline, smiling and turned backwards in their seats to speak a few remaining words to the rest of Yangâ€™s friends, all with their assortment of wives and girlfriends who had come. Reuenthal sat next to Mittermeyer, but was quieter, and at his side was a beautiful blonde woman, wearing a dress that, even in Yangâ€™s eyes, was about thirty years out of date. She must have been Elfriede von Kohlsrauch, though Reuenthal hadnâ€™t yet introduced her to Yang. But still, Yangâ€™s heart was warmed to see him there, and he smiled, even though Reuenthal wasnâ€™t looking at him. Reuenthal was doing exactly what he had done just a moment beforeâ€” his head was turned to look at the rain.

There was such a feeling of love and gratefulness in Yangâ€™s heart as he looked over the gathering. During the rush to say hello to people, he hadnâ€™t stopped to process how it felt to see all of his friends here at onceâ€” it overwhelmed him, and made him misty eyed. He wasnâ€™t usually a tearful person, but he could have cried about that. He couldnâ€™t quite comprehend that all of these people were here for him, and yet the evidence that they were was incontrovertible. It felt, for a moment, like he was where he belongedâ€” even if that feeling came with twists of guilt. Most of these people were here for Hank von Leigh.

But his eyes settled on Reuenthal and Mittermeyer again. Reuenthal, as if feeling his gaze, turned to look at him. Yang tried to smile, but he wasnâ€™t sure what came across on his face. Reuenthal looked away after a moment, but it was enough to shake Yang free of his winding thoughts.

The event organizer gave Yang the signal to move to the front of the room, on the small raised platform. He steeled himself, taking a breath, and nervously smoothed down the red sash of his dress uniform before he got into position.

Up front, Yang stood at attention and looked down the strip of red carpet towards the covered entryway of the tent, where he was waiting for Magdalena to emerge. Everyoneâ€™s eyes were on him, and the chatter under the tent faded to nothing. On some unspoken signal, the bandâ€™s music changed, and they struck up the wedding march.

Magdalena walked out of the open doors of the house, under the flower-bedecked archway, down the aisle. She was radiant in all whiteâ€” perhaps the most beautiful woman Yang had ever seen. Her black hair fell in waves around her shoulders, and was topped with a silver and diamond tiara made to look like a dewy crown of roses. Her gown was voluminous, but she somehow made it look natural, moving with a grace that even at a distance made Yang feel clumsy and unprepared. Sheer lace wrapped around her arms and neck, and a veil fluttered over her face, doing little to obscure her ruby lips and her glittering eyes. Her cheeks were flushed, and her expression was so strangeâ€” he had never seen her look at him in quite that way before. But his expression must have matched hersâ€” if anyone had asked him what he was feeling in that moment, he would have had to lie, because he had no idea how to name the strange and familiar feelings that were tumbling around in his heart.

It seemed to take forever for her to walk up the aisle towards him, but she eventually arrived and smiled at him. All of his nervousness fell away at that expression on her face. If she was there, as ready to go through with it as he was, then it would all be alright.Â 

Before the wedding march had finished, before the celebrantâ€” some Imperial priest that Madalenaâ€™s mother had chosenâ€” stepped forward, Magdalena said, quietly enough that only he could hear, â€œI guess we really are getting our revenge on them all, arenâ€™t we, Hank?â€

She wasnâ€™t serious, not really. â€œYouâ€™re right,â€ he said, smiling at her. â€œWe are living well.â€

She shook her head, but he could see that he had said the right thingâ€” her face was twitching as she fought to stifle the smile that rose to her lips.

Later, Yang could hardly recall anything else that happened at the ceremony. All of the actionsâ€” the standing, the kneeling, the binding of the hands, the exchanging of ringsâ€” seemed to pass in a blur. He would have liked to have committed them to memory, to savor them later, but the only thing that stuck in his mind was the feeling of it. The world dimmed at the edges to only encompass Magdalenaâ€™s laughing eyes. It felt like they were, for a minute, the only two people in the world who really knew what was going onâ€” like they were playing some kind of game, or joke, on the rest of the world, and they were on the winning team.

When it came to the profession of vows, it was very easy to swear to love one another in sickness and in health, for richer or for poorer, til death do us part. It was only when the officiant asked Magdalena if she took Hank von Leigh to be her husband that he felt anything other than like laughing. He looked deeply into her eyes, resisting the temptation to look anywhere else, and she cocked her head with a knowing smile.Â 

â€œOf course I do, Hank,â€ she said.

â€œAnd you, Hank von Leigh, do you take Magdalena von Westpfale to be your wedded wife?â€

â€œI do,â€ Yang said. And that was that.

And when he lifted up her veil to kiss her, she couldnâ€™t stop herself from smiling so broadly that her lips no longer covered her teeth, and her lipstick ended up above his upper lip.

There was a loud wolf-whistle from the audience, which Yang, in a distant corner of his mind, suspected came from Bittenfeld.

At the end, the band struck up again, some rousing song, and Yang was swept along on a tide of well wishes, back into the house, clinging to Magdalenaâ€™s arm all the while.Â 

After dinner and speeches, which Yang sat through with a flush of embarrassment permanently affixed to his face, there was dancing, and Magdalena and Yang had the first dance together. They had practiced, and while this couldnâ€™t make Yang good at dancing by any stretch of the imagination, he was very happy that he didnâ€™t step on Magdalenaâ€™s feet as her gown swirled around them both. As they spun across the center of the room, where they had first danced together years ago, Yangâ€™s gaze crossed the room, watching everyone who watched them. Most people were simply eager for their own turn to dance, but he caught Mittermeyerâ€™s eye, and then Reuenthalâ€™s. The expressions on their faces couldnâ€™t have been more different, but it seemed to Yang that they came from the same place. Mittermeyerâ€™s broad smile wished Yang well, and while Reuenthalâ€™s gaze was hard and cold, Yang knew that it was because it cost Reuenthal greatly to stand there and watchâ€” and he was paying that price out of love. Yang wanted to go talk to him, but there hadnâ€™t been a good moment to speak with him alone.

He kept dancing with Magdalena for a few more songs, until his limbs did finally stop cooperating with him, and he began to step on her toes. She let him go with a laugh, and went to find Evangeline to dance with. Yang sat back down at his table, and this gave the opportunity for everyone who wanted to say something to him to come over and do so. He wasnâ€™t used to being the center of attention in any time other than being a teacher, so to adapt, he found himself slipping back into that casual teacher role, even when it was very funny to answer Magdalenaâ€™s motherâ€™s questions about their honeymoon plans with his broadly gesticulating hand and lecture tone. He could feel Count Mariendorfâ€™s indulgent smile at thisâ€” he had been on the receiving end of Yangâ€™s talks in the past. Eventually, the dowager Westpfale and Count Mariendorf went off to dance to some of the slower songs, and new sets of people sat down to visit at Yangâ€™s table like he was holding court.

Yang kept an eye on all the guests, watching the little cliques of nobles and friends form and move between each other. In one corner, the Braunschweig clan sat and didnâ€™t dance, except for Flegel with a few of Magdalenaâ€™s cousins. Duke Braunschwieg helped himself to the wine, while Princess Amaraie watched the party like a hawk. â€œItâ€™s a pity my father was unable to attend, Count von Leigh,â€ she had said when Yang went over to say hello to her.

â€œHe sent me a card with his best wishes,â€ Yang said. â€œI hope that His Majesty is in good health.â€

â€œAs good as can be expected.â€

But she didnâ€™t want to put a pall on the party. And she kept an eye on her daughter, who did dance with her fiancee. Yang only spoke to Hans von Vering briefly, when Lady Elizabeth dragged him over. He was a healthy looking, stout young man a few years older than Elizabeth. There was nothing remarkable about him, but even as he spoke to Yang, he looked around the party with a judgemental stare. He followed Elizabeth around and often leaned over her to say something in her ear and visibly point at one of the other guests. His constant attachment to Elizabeth made Hilde, who had gone over to join the Braunschweig party, look bored and distracted. Yang eventually ordered Kircheis to stop running interference for him, and go cheer Hilde up. This seemed to work, because the two of them ended up laughing about something over by the windows.

The party was a cheerful one, despite the rain outside. It dripped down the tall windows of the ballroom and made grey shadows on the colorful array of dancers on the floor. Yang, though he hadnâ€™t really expected to enjoy the party, found that he was.Â 

Of course, the general peace of the wedding was not to last. It couldnâ€™t, not with so many people who were tangled up in the politics of the court in attendance.

It was Bittenfeld who came over to give Yang a very drunk toast, who prevented Yang from understanding the beginning of the trouble until it was already far too late. Bittenfeld was telling Yang all about the drink that the bartender had invented (apparently) and how great it was that Yang was finally married and how Bittenfeld wished he had taken up Yangâ€™s offer to steal his date to Mittermeyerâ€™s wedding, years ago, and then it could have him as a count or whatever. Bittenfeldâ€™s congratulations were completely sincere and harmless, and they made Magdalena laugh as he whacked Yang on the shoulder. But there was another voice, snide and loud, sitting at the table behind Yang, making sure that Yang could hear.

â€œSo, Fraulein Kohlraush,â€ Baron Flegel said, â€œhow is it that you, of all people, have found yourself at this particular wedding? I was under the impression that you were still on your familyâ€™s country lands.â€

â€œI somehow doubt you thought that, Thomas,â€ she said. â€œYouâ€™ve always made yourself quite good at paying attention to gossip.â€

â€œI saw you come in with that Rear Admiral Reuenthal. Isnâ€™t he a little beneath you?â€

â€œAnd if he is? What are you going to do about it?â€

â€œYou donâ€™t see them here, do you?â€

â€œNo, I donâ€™t. Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m surprised that this is the circle youâ€™ve chosen to run in. How far the mighty have fallen.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think you have room to talk. Youâ€™re here, too.â€

â€œIt was bad enough when he was only going to be marrying a baroness. After the minor incident with Flegel, things calmed down, especially as people began to trickle out of the party, leaving only the guests who actually cared about the bride and groom, and who liked staying out late and getting very drunk.Â 

Magdalena eventually demanded that Yang dance with her again, which did for a while. Yang saw Reuenthal head out of the glass doors that lead to the back of the house, where the empty tents sat silent in the drizzling rain. Yang disentangled himself from Magdalenaâ€™s arms, offering a mumbled excuse. She sighed, but gave him a little shove and let him go.

Â Yang slipped out of the party.

Reuenthal hadnâ€™t gone far. He was walking underneath the tents outside, sticking his hand out into the water and collecting drops in his palm, but not getting fully wet. He didnâ€™t seem to notice Yang following him. Though the tents were lit against the night with fairy lights, the rain made everything outside of them appear as through a fog, and Yang could no longer distinguish the figures in the windows of the house, no matter how brightly they were lit. He doubted that anyone could see him and Reuenthal out here, so it was the private moment that he had been looking for for days. â€œOskar,â€ Yang said, getting his attention when he was still about five meters away.

â€œIâ€™ll go back in. I justâ€¦ If you were leaving, I wanted to say goodbye.â€

â€œOh, okay.â€

â€œSo, you can go back inside.â€

â€œThank you for coming,â€ Yang said. â€œIt means a lot to me.â€

â€œI feel like Iâ€™ve hardly seen you since you came back to Odin. I hopeâ€”â€

â€œWhat?â€

Yangâ€™s grimace was still a little cheerful. â€œYou wouldnâ€™t want me to say that I hope youâ€™re doing okay.â€

â€œYouâ€™re allowed to say it,â€ Reuenthal said. It was funny, the way that conversations they had years ago stuck in their minds, formed a basis of shared understanding. There was tenderness in thatâ€” their way of silently confirming that they still had each other. A call and response.

â€œThen I do hope so,â€ Yang said.Â 

â€œIâ€™m fine, Wen-li.â€

â€œWeâ€™re just looking for excuses to see you more often. He knew it was a bit of a facile thing to say when they were standing out in the rain, outside his own wedding. They could spend individual moments pretending like the outside world didnâ€™t existâ€” that whatever space they carved, it was for them aloneâ€” but that didnâ€™t make it true.Â 

â€œWhenâ€”â€ Reuenthal began.

â€œWhat?â€

â€œI never doubted that for a moment,â€ Yang said. â€œNot ever.â€

Yang wished that there was something he could give to Reuenthal in returnâ€” Reuenthal was asking for something by professing his loyalty. It was the closest promise he was allowed to give. In his pocket, Yang twisted the gold band on his finger. He would have to get used to that.

â€œWill you use it, though?â€

â€œYes,â€ Yang said. â€œIf you want me to.â€

Reuenthal nodded. There was tension in his back, even as Yang ran his hand up and down it.

â€œI donâ€™t think I can do this without you,â€ Yang said, hitting upon something he felt like he could give Reuenthal, that might accept. â€œI need you. And Mittermeyer.â€

â€œYou could,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œYou always beat me in our games.â€

â€œNo, I didnâ€™t,â€ Yang said. â€œAnd weâ€™re not in a game anymore.â€

â€œIt wouldnâ€™t matter if we were. You always played the game on a different level than the rest of us.â€

â€œI wish it all wasnâ€™t. I wishâ€”â€

â€œWhat, Wen-li?â€Â 

â€œIf it was a game, I wouldnâ€™t have to worry about it.â€ He shook his head. â€œBut I keep having nightmares.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know why,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œYouâ€™re going to win.â€

The confidence that Reuenthal had in him was undeserved, but Reuenthal probably wouldnâ€™t hear otherwise, so Yang accepted the premise.Â 

â€œItâ€™s not about winning,â€ Yang said. â€œEven if the gameâ€™s rigged for me to win, and the endingâ€™s a foregone conclusionâ€” what is it going to take to get there? Thatâ€™sâ€” thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m worried about.â€

â€œMay I say something?â€

â€œYou donâ€™t have to ask.â€

Reuenthal was still staring out into the rain. â€œDonâ€™t hold yourself back because of that,â€ he said. â€œSpend the loyalty you have to spend. Whatever it takes.â€

Yang understood what Reuenthal was asking for. If he couldnâ€™t live for Yangâ€” he at least wanted Yang to promise to let him die for him. Why was that the one thing that Yang would never in a thousand lifetimes want to give him? Why was that the only thing that Reuenthal felt he had left to ask for?

He didnâ€™t know what to sayâ€” refusing would hurt Reuenthal, and he couldnâ€™t bring himself to acceptâ€” so instead he rested his head on Reuenthalâ€™s shoulder. â€œIt wonâ€™t come down to that,â€ he said.

Chapter End Notes

it's literally so late and i have to be up so early doing complicated things tomorrow ğŸ˜­

ok fun times over. kaiser's dying next chapter and shit is about to fully hit the fan. um. yang gets all of 3 seconds to enjoy married life sorry yang.

everybody's got so many fucking problems. reuenthal and elfriede... they made me break my fade to black streak b/c they literally cannot have a conversation without being insane and horny about it. he has filled his house with the remnants of his abusive childhood. to keep him insane i fuck him on the floor.

speaking of-- yang making a note that elfriede is wearing a dress that is 30 yrs out of date-- that's reuenthal's mom's dress. b/c elfriede knows exactly what buttons to push.

still not sure if i'm satisfied with that last scene but it is what it is. maybe i'll come back to it later.

anyway everyone is thinking about the moment vs the future and this is causing them all to be sad in 5000 different directions.

you may say "man yang sure did get married to magdalena in this chapter and she got like 0 speaking lines" i'm probably going to write a bonus chapter about her in a hot sec so hopefully this lack is not too egregious. sorry maggy ilu. but she is not having overt problems at this wedding lol. unlike everybody else.

idk. sorry this chapter took so long it was a struggle and a half. hopefully things will get back on a normal schedule? but i make no real promises lol

What Will You Say of the Bond We Had, Tender Comrade?

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

May 488 I.C., Odin

Kircheis let himself be lulled into a false sense of security by the beauty of spring on Odin. It was like everything in the world was softer for a few months. The weather was bright, and warmer than he remembered it being at this time of year. Every scrap of ground was lush with greenery. The wind was playful in his hair. The rain was soft.

And Martin had taken it into his mind to be strangely gentle and unargumentative to Kircheis.Â 

This should have alerted him to something being wrong, the way Martin would ask him to go with him on the weekends someplace nice. He didnâ€™t vanish in the evenings to spend time with his group of republican friends, and instead stuck close to Kircheis. When they had time, and the weather was good, they would go rent little boats to paddle around the lake in the grand nature reserve not far from the capital, and kiss among the weeping willows where no one could see them. Martin would stay up late and read him poetry, which Kircheis had always liked. He often tossed aside his schoolwork on the weekday evenings, and would do anything else just to spend time with Kircheis. Even when he was clearly busy with something that occupied his mindâ€” the things that he did not allow Kircheis to know aboutâ€” if Kircheis came into the room and found him frowning at a message on his phone, he would immediately put it away and deliberately smile, letting his outside concerns fall to the wayside.

Kircheis recognized all this as unusual, but he wanted to to assign the credit to the weather, to Martin feeling done with school, to anything other than what he should have recognized it as: a sign of dangerous things to come, and Martin wanting to savor the moment while he had it.Â 

It all made Kircheis so happy that he didnâ€™t want to think about the spring ending and what that would portend. Martinâ€™s graduation from ONU was on Saturday, May 20th. On the night of Thursday the 18th, he lay beside Kircheis in bed. The windows were open, and the warm air was coming in. Even in the city, there was the sound of crickets and cicadas in the air.

Kircheis was spent and exhausted, the usual sluggish but pleasant sensation in all his limbs after sex. Still, he had enough energy to stroke Martinâ€™s feathery hair as he lay against his chest. Martin had been so deliberate with everything he had done all eveningâ€” he had made a point of kissing Kircheis before he even was able to take off his uniform after work, and Kircheis had found him watching him as they ate dinner, a strange expression on his face. There was a calmness about him, when usually he was excitable. Their conversations hadnâ€™t been laden with Martinâ€™s tangents or diatribes, and so there had been long lapses of comfortable silence between them. The same was true now.

â€œIs there something on your mind?â€ Kircheis asked. â€œYouâ€™re quiet today.â€

â€œYes,â€ Martin said.

Kircheis remained silent, inviting Martin to elaborate, but he didnâ€™t. He carded his fingers through Martinâ€™s hair.

â€œDid you want to go out to dinner tomorrow?â€ Kircheis asked. â€œI can try to get home from work early, so that we can beat the crowds.â€

â€œI promised my advisor Iâ€™d go talk with him about my future plans,â€ Martin said. â€œI probably wonâ€™t be back until late.â€

â€œAlright. Iâ€™ll save you some leftovers.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t have toâ€” he said to meet him at a bar. Iâ€™ll probably eat there.â€

â€œIâ€™m jealous,â€ Kircheis said, his tone light. â€œGoing out without me.â€

â€œI love you.â€

â€œI was teasing,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI didnâ€™t mean to imply anything.â€

â€œI know. I just wanted to tell you.â€

â€œAh.â€ He pressed a kiss to the crown of Martinâ€™s head. â€œWell, I love you.â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry I wonâ€™t be home tomorrow.â€

â€œItâ€™s alright,â€ Kircheis said. â€œMaybe Sunday.â€

â€œMaybe.â€ But there was something in Martinâ€™s voiceâ€” hesitation.

Kircheis had to ask again. â€œWhat is on your mind?â€

â€œI got my service letter the other day,â€ Martin said.

â€œAlready? I thoughtâ€”â€

â€œThey know when the university graduation is, and thatâ€™s when the standard deferment ends. Iâ€™m supposed to report by the end of the month.â€

â€œOh.â€ Kircheis wanted to offer Martin assistance, of whatever kind he could, but he doubted that Martin would accept any of it. â€œWhy didnâ€™t you tell me?â€

â€œI didnâ€™t want you to worry. I wantedâ€”â€

The spring to stay as it had been.Â 

Kircheis wanted that, too, and he knew by asking his next question, he was making that impossible, but he had to ask it anyway. â€œWhat are you going to do?â€

Martin shook his head, and Kircheis squeezed his eyes shut, and pulled Martin closer to his chest, clinging to his breathing, his heartbeat, the feeling of his stringy frame, warm and alive.

â€œDonâ€™t do anything youâ€™ll regret,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œI wonâ€™t.â€

Â 

Â 

When Kircheis returned home to his and Martinâ€™s shared apartment after work on Friday, he found the place cold and empty. Although he had expected that Martin would not be there, he could tell something was different immediately. From the instant he stepped into the door, he had the sensation that something vital that had once lived in the house had vanished. He would later realize that the instant sense of foreboding was from his subconscious processing of the scene; both Martinâ€™s hiking boots and daily shoes were missing from their usual place near the door.

Kircheis took off his uniform jacket and hung it up on the hook near the entrance, taking just a minute to forestall any discovery that might lay further in. Nothing was awry in the kitchen, save for the dripping sink that their landlord had yet to fix, but when Kircheis walked into the bedroom, he found that the closet door was open, and all of Martinâ€™s clothes were missing. The dresser, too, had been emptied. All that remained were Martinâ€™s various trinkets on top of the bureauâ€” his collection of miniature ancient statues, which he had made a habit of purchasing whenever he went to Odinâ€™s national art museum. On the wall, there had once hung a picture of both of them and Hilde, taken at the Mariendorf house, but that photo had been removed, and only the frame was still there, sitting propped against the wall on the floor. In the living room, most of his books remained, but there were a few exceptionsâ€” the slender books of ancient poetry had vanished from their usual place of honor stacked on the top shelf. His toiletries were missing from the bathroom, and Kircheisâ€™s toothbrush looked pathetic alone in its cup by the side of the sink.

Kircheis sat down on the neatly made bedâ€” the fact that Martin had bothered to make the bed as he walked out of Kircheisâ€™s life without a trace struck him somewhere low in his chestâ€” and picked up Martinâ€™s pillow. It still smelled faintly of his shampoo, and Kircheis held it and stared at the empty picture frame on the floor until the ache in his heart turned into a numbness that allowed him to take out his phone and dial Hildeâ€™s number. He didnâ€™t know what he was going to say to her, but she was the only person he could imagine talking to in this moment.

It wasnâ€™t particularly unusual for him to call her, and she picked up after a few rings.

â€œHi, Sieg,â€ she said, sounding slightly out of breath. â€œWhatâ€™s up?â€

Her cheerful tone made Kircheis momentarily lose control of whatever he had been about to say, and his mouth opened silently. The silence over the line caused Hildeâ€™s tone to change.

â€œSieg?â€ she asked.

â€œHildeâ€”â€ The tightness in his throat made it hard for him to get the word out. â€œDid you see Martin today?â€

She was wary when she answered. â€œWe had lunch together. He asked to meet me and we ate on campus.â€

â€œDid he seemâ€”â€

â€œIs he alright?â€ There was a warble in her voice, and she clearly feared the worst.

â€œHeâ€™s gone. He left.â€

â€œAre you at home?â€

â€œIâ€™ll be there in twenty minutes.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t have toâ€”â€

â€œDonâ€™t go anywhere.â€

He didnâ€™t think he could, even if he wanted to. His legs felt like they werenâ€™t going to obey him any longer. He just kept sitting on the bed, thinking. The only thing he could register was fear for Martinâ€™s safety, and an overwhelming grief. He knew why Martin had goneâ€” it was for his sakeâ€” but that didnâ€™t make it any easier to bear. Martin intended to do something stupid, but the hope that he could stay safe, that he could still find some way to protect him, somehow made it all worse.

He heard pounding footsteps on the stairs outside the apartment, and then Hilde ringing their doorbell. Had he already been sitting there for that long? Mechanically, he rose to his feet and went to unlock the door and let her in.

Hilde had been in his apartment many times. She would often stop by after her classes let out for the day to say hello, since Kircheis and Martin didnâ€™t live far from the ONU campus. She looked around with an investigative eye the moment she stepped in the door.

â€œHe took both his pairs of shoes,â€ she said immediately. â€œHe usually leaves his boots with yours, doesnâ€™t he?â€

â€œHe took most of his clothes,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œDid he leave a note?â€

â€œI didnâ€™t see one.â€

She looked around briefly, and her eyes settled on the closed door to the second bedroom, the one he never slept in, the one with the brass SIEGFRIED KIRCHEIS nameplate he had taken from his dorm room at the IOA. â€œDid you check your room?â€ she asked.

â€œEr, no,â€ he said. But he didnâ€™t have a good reason not to look in there, so he did. Hilde followed behind him.

There was the neatly made spare twin bed, and the desk that he occasionally used when he needed to be completely undistracted to work, and a beat up old dresser that held their out of season clothes. This room was so small that it didnâ€™t even have a closetâ€” which was his excuse for hanging up his uniforms in Martinâ€™s closet, if anyone had ever noticed.

Hilde scanned the room, though there wasnâ€™t much to see. But when she walked around the other side of the bed to look at the nightstand, she said, â€œWhat do you usually keep in this safe? It looks like he wanted you to be aware he took something out of itâ€” he left it open.â€

Kircheisâ€™s blood ran cold. â€œItâ€™s open?â€

Hilde bent down and pulled out various documents and tossed them onto the bed. He felt ill watching her do this, primarily because the largest object that should have been first to be pulled out of the safe was not among the things she extracted, and, second, because among the innocuous paperworkâ€” the copy of his birth certificate and some government bondsâ€” there was his court orders detailing the conditions of his service in the fleet. She didnâ€™t look too closely at the sheaf of papers, and Kircheis probably wouldnâ€™t have minded her knowing, but, much like her presence in his false bedroom, it was something he would have liked to do on his own terms. Though considering all he had shared with Hilde over the years, and the fact that it had never managed to come up, maybe that time was never going to be any time but now.

â€œAll yours,â€ Hilde said, glancing over the stack. â€œDid he keep all his papers in here, too? I assume you donâ€™t have more than one safe.â€

â€œMy gun isnâ€™t in there?â€ Kircheis asked.

Even in the dim light that came in through the window to the alley, he could see Hilde pale. â€œYou kept a gun in there?â€

â€œMy fleet sidearm,â€ Kircheis said. â€œItâ€™s issued to me permanently as an officer, but I donâ€™t need to take it to work. I keep it locked up.â€ And the safe stayed in this room, far out of thought and sight, since Martin didnâ€™t like the idea of it in their bedroom.

â€œNo,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s not there.â€

â€œOh,â€ Hilde said. â€œAnd heâ€¦â€Â 

â€œYes.â€

June 488 I.C., Odin

Kircheis waited until the beginning of the next month to ask Leigh for help. He did some poking on his own, and he might have continued to do so, except for the fact that on June 5th, military police showed up at his apartment door, looking for Martin.

Kircheis was at home when they came, eating a very sad meal of microwaved canned pasta. He hadnâ€™t yet taken off his uniform after dinner, since Martin was no longer around to be discomforted by him wearing it. When the doorbell rang, he initially ignored it, thinking it was probably just the mail, or someone wanting to prosthelytize for the Earth Church, but then the doorbell rang again, and he was forced to get up and answer it.

At the door were two MPs. Although it was clear from their uniforms that they were only enlisted men, even as an officer the sight of them was enough to put a chill down Kircheisâ€™s spine.

One of them leaned back and looked at the number outside Kircheisâ€™s apartment door. They clearly hadnâ€™t been expecting to meet someone in uniform, and they quickly moved to salute, and Kircheis saluted back.

â€œHello,â€ Kircheis said. â€œWhat can I do for you, gentlemen?â€

â€œWhatâ€™s your name, sir?â€

â€œLieutenant Siegfried Kircheis,â€ he said.

One of them wrote that information down in a little memo pad.

â€œMay we come in, Lieutenant?â€

This was the last thing Kircheis wanted, but he didnâ€™t have any way to refuse, so he smiled and said, â€œOf course, gentlemen.â€ He held the door open, and both of them stomped their muddy boots into his kitchen, and neither of them took off their caps as they came inside.

â€œMay I ask you a few questions?â€ one said, while the other began walking through the apartment. Kircheis had, luckily, taken his name off the false bedroom and had stripped the bed, leaving the room open and empty looking. â€œOf course. I can give you his familyâ€™s phone number, if you like. He might just be there,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œNot since he left, no.â€ Kircheis pulled out a pad of paper and pen from one of the kitchen drawers, and consulted his phone to write down Martinâ€™s uncleâ€™s phone number, which was Kircheisâ€™s landlordâ€™s business partner. â€œThatâ€™s fine, thank you, sir. I appreciate your helpfulness.â€

â€œOh, well, if he cooperates, and itâ€™s just some kind of honest mistake that he didnâ€™t report, probably nothing but a reprimand,â€ the MPs said. â€œItâ€™s if we donâ€™t find him that it becomes an issue.â€ He laughed, but not in an amused way. Kircheisâ€™s smile was thin.

â€œYou put out a notice for his arrest, I assume?â€

â€œYes, sir. Thatâ€™s what weâ€™d do.â€Â

â€œOf course,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œAnd if he doesnâ€™t report, I do hope you call our number.â€ He reached into his pocket and pulled out a card with the tips hotline number printed on it. â€œOf course.â€

They saluted Kircheis again, who saluted back, and he showed them out of his apartment. When they had gone, he slumped against the door. His heart rate, which had been calm and under control when they were talking to him, spiked, all of the panic he had been suppressing coming up at once.

Â 

Commodore Leighâ€™s office was in the same state of disarray that it always was when Kircheis came to see him the next day. Leigh was looking out the window, chair tilted all the way back with his legs on his desk, so his view was up to the sky, where puffy white clouds were scuttling along, chased by the wind that whistled down the street. When Kircheis knocked and announced himself, Leigh rolled his head to look at him.

â€œDonâ€™t you usually go home around now?â€ Leigh asked. It was past the end of their assigned workday, but that didnâ€™t mean much for either of them.

â€œI figured I could catch you before I left,â€ he said. â€œYou were at the Braunschweig house for most of the day.â€

â€œYes,â€ Leigh said with a frown. He straightened himself up and put his elbows on his desk, replacing his feet that had been up there a moment before. â€œWhat can I do for you, Kircheis?â€

Kircheis shut the door of the office behind himself, and took the seat in front of Leighâ€™s desk. Leigh waited patiently for him to state his businessâ€” there was that kind and concerned look on his face: the intensity of his gaze and the slight furrow of his brow.

â€œIâ€™m afraid Iâ€™ve come to ask you about a personal problem, sir,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œIâ€™m happy to help,â€ Leigh said. â€œPlease.â€

â€œItâ€™s about my friend Martin.â€

Leigh sighed. â€œI had wondered about him. Is he alright?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know. Heâ€™sâ€”â€

â€œMissing?â€ The knowing tone of Leighâ€™s voice made Kircheis feel worse.

â€œYes, sir.â€

â€œIâ€™m afraid to admit that Iâ€™ve been keeping a little secret from you, Kircheis,â€ Leigh said.

â€œWhy didnâ€™t you tell me that the rear admiral had asked you?â€ With anyone else, the direct question would have been cause for a reprimand, but Leigh just answered him honestly.

â€œI didnâ€™t want to interfere in your business,â€ Leigh said. â€œAnd as far as Bronner is concerned, I was telling him the truth.â€

â€œHe couldnâ€™t have gone far,â€ Leigh said, somewhat bitterly. â€œAnybody whoâ€™s a flight risk, they make sure you canâ€™t leave the planet, unless a nobleâ€™s smuggling you on their private ship. Thereâ€™s no passenger ship to Phezzan that would be allowed to let him on board.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ he said.

The next night, Kircheis dressed in dark clothing, tucked his distinctive hair beneath a cap, donned a large pair of reading glasses purchased from the drug store, and walked through the center of the city, a can of spray paint tucked into the satchel that swung at his side. He had a destination in mind, though he was open to alternate possibilities if any occurred to him on the way.Â 

He was almost waylaid by the Earth Church headquarters, the one that had burnt down several years ago, and had now been reconstructed on the same spot with a smooth concrete facade, something so unlike the usual Imperial architectural style that it was a wonder they had ever gotten a building permit. But eyeing the security cameras that dotted the corners of the building conspicuously, Kircheis moved on.

He almost turned down towards the residential part of the city, where brownstones clustered close together, and where had once been arrested on Martinâ€™s behalf. But he figured that there was no reason that Martin would ever be looking at that old house again, and so Kircheis didnâ€™t walk in that direction.

Instead, he made his way towards Triangle Street, which was dark and eerie at this time of night, even with the streetlights. There was rarely anyone in the odd, triangular plaza, even on a busy day, and this was after midnight. He looked around, just for good measure, and wished he had a spotter with him. But the only person he could have invited was Hilde, and he didnâ€™t want to involve her.

He shook his can of white spray paint, and the rattle of it echoed and bounced off the tall buildings around him, announcing his presence like an alarm. But no one came out of any of the buildings, and the cars that drove by on the main streets didnâ€™t stop, though their headlights briefly illuminated the whole square, flashing like lightning bolts as the cars rumbled by.

On the wall, in an unfamiliar script, Kircheis carefully wrote a fragment of a poem.

It was a week later that a postcard appeared in Kircheisâ€™s mailbox. The front was a picture of birds flying over the ocean, with a picturesque sailboat cresting a wave beneath themâ€” it was the kind of postcard that one could get in a tourist shop near any of the beaches about an hourâ€™s drive from the capital. This one bore the name of what Kircheis presumed was a bar in the corner: The Captainâ€™s Lounge. The back was scrawled in Martinâ€™s undisguised handwriting.

â€œIâ€™m enjoying my summer vacation. Youâ€™d like the beach too, if you ever left your office. Come by on Friday, and Iâ€™ll buy you a drink. Love, Your Anactoriaâ€

Kircheis laid the postcard on his kitchen table and stared at it for a long time. It was dangerous for both of them if he did go visit Martin. He doubted that Martin was staying anywhere near this particular beach and this particular barâ€” he was probably in the capital still, which would be how he saw Kircheisâ€™s message in the first placeâ€” but it was a good idea to meet further away. Especially if Martin didnâ€™t trust him. Although he had been the one to request the meeting, the fear of what he would say to Martin when he saw him made Kircheis want to skip it.

He had asked to meet under the pretense that he wanted to join Martinâ€” he knew that was how Martin would interpret his message. He didnâ€™t want to join him. He wanted something impossible, and what was there to say to Martin about that impossibility?

But he asked for the day off of work, which Leigh granted him without any comment, and Kircheis took an early morning train out to the beach.

The sun was just coming up when he arrived, and it hadnâ€™t yet cut through the fog that crept over the salt marshes that turned into beachhead further down. Herons stood with their tall legs among the reeds, and gulls wheeled and cawed overhead. Kircheis walked the kilometer or so from the train station over the paved bridge road through the marsh, towards the beach, which was empty except for a few people hunting for shellfish and a few others running their dogs through the packed sand where the tide had just gone out.

Kircheis took off his shoes and rolled up the legs of his pants to walk along the beach. He let the cold ocean water wash over his feet, and he trekked towards the boardwalk a ways away where there were a few restaurants and closed carnival games. It was too early for any tourists to be on the boardwalkâ€” there were only a few local fishermen dangling their long poles out over the deeper water. But this was where Martin had asked to meetâ€” there was the bar at the beachside end of the structureâ€” so Kircheis climbed the wooden steps and walked along until he reached the far end, and he leaned against the railing, looking out over the ocean.

The sun was burning off the fog now, and the morning light glittered on the waves beneath their foamy crests. It was going to be a hot day, but the air was still cool for now. Kircheis had brought a book to read, in case he had to wait for Martin to appear, but watching the low tide begin to roll back in was enough to occupy him for a long while.Â 

He was so engrossed that he didnâ€™t notice someone coming up behind him until he felt a hand on his shoulder. He whirled, and for a moment didnâ€™t recognize the person before him.

Martin had bleached his hair to a straw blond and cut it short. He was dressed in an outfit that seemed wholly unsuited to himâ€” a pair of workmanâ€™s jeans and a loose and stained shirt, tied with a messy kerchief at his throat. They were so unlike his usual neat clothing that they changed his whole silhouette. But all the rough fabrics in the world couldnâ€™t disguise the way his hands were uncalloused, and his limbs were willowy. He had a canvas bag slung across his back, though it looked mostly empty, probably just holding a bagged lunch.

â€œI didnâ€™t expect you to be here so early,â€ Martin said.

â€œYou didnâ€™t give me a time.â€

How strange, that these were the first words they said to each other. Had Kircheis been expecting Martin to fall into his arms, right there on the beach? No. But there had been a part of him that had hoped for it, nonetheless.

â€œYou didnâ€™t bring much,â€ Martin said, pointing at the satchel that swung by Kircheisâ€™s side.

â€œShould we really talk here?â€

â€œNo, youâ€™re right.â€ Martin looked around warily. Though there had been only fishermen out when Kircheis arrived, there were now more people trickling onto the boardwalk, the early summer crowd, and some of the vendors were rattling open their metal stall doors and beginning to play music that wavered through the salty air, breaking the morning stillness. â€œYou werenâ€™t followed, were you?â€

â€œNo, I donâ€™t think so.â€

They walked together back down the boardwalk and away from the beach, back towards the salt marsh. There was an area of rolling sandy dunes before they sank down into the still water of the swamp on one side, and the packed sand of the beach on the other. This was where they headed, finding a place like a basket of scrubby grass woven into the crumbling, sandy earth. It was cool and shady in their hollow between the dunes, and the sand walls were tall enough to hide them completely from sight when they sat. They took up positions across from each other, their knees close enough to touch.

â€œIâ€™m so glad you came,â€ Martin said, as soon as they were hidden. â€œI had hoped you would. But I didnâ€™t want to presume anythingâ€”â€

â€œYou left without saying goodbye.â€

â€œI know,â€ Martin said. â€œIâ€™m sorry. I didnâ€™t have a choice.â€

â€œYou did. You could have told me what you were going to do. I wouldnâ€™t have stopped you. I donâ€™t think I could have.â€

â€œYou would have tried, and then you wouldnâ€™t have come to find me here.â€

â€œDo you really think that I would just never want to see you again?â€ Kircheis asked. Although he was trying to stay calm, and he was usually good at it, the pain crept into his voice. â€œDo you really think that about me?â€

â€œNo,â€ Marin said. â€œBut if you had tried to stop me then, I probably wouldnâ€™t have let you find me.â€

Kircheis ripped at the grass that grew from the dunes. Its roots went deep, and it was wiry and scratched his hands as he tried to pull it out. â€œI would have tried anyway.â€

â€œI know.â€ There was a moment of silence. â€œIâ€™m so glad you came. I didnâ€™t really know what I was going to do without you. Youâ€™ll make things so much better whenâ€”â€

â€œMartinâ€”â€ It was Martinâ€™s fantasies that brought Kircheis down to reality.

â€œSieg?â€

â€œIâ€™m not here to join you,â€ Kircheis said. â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

Martinâ€™s whole demeanor changed. He tensed, and his face lost its pleased smile.Â 

â€œThen why are you here?â€ Despite the warmth of the sun cresting over the dunes, with Martinâ€™s icy voice, it was suddenly cold.

Truthfully, Kircheis didnâ€™t know the answer to that question. â€œBecause I love you.â€

â€œBut not enough.â€

â€œMartinâ€” donâ€™tâ€”â€

â€œWhat power?â€ Kircheis asked. â€œI donâ€™t have any power over you.â€

â€œItâ€™s funny that you can think that. You could have me arrested right now. You could kill meâ€” youâ€™re stronger than I am.â€

â€œYou stole my gun.â€

â€œDid you bring it with you today? Just in case?â€

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI didnâ€™t ever think you would hold me at gunpoint. If Iâ€™m wrong, then Iâ€™m sorry for having misjudged you. And Iâ€™m sorry that you thought that I would be the kind of person youâ€™d need to point a gun at.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t bring it,â€ Martin said, but he was lying. Kircheis could always tell when he was lying. His gaze twitched towards his canvas bag, sitting in the sand next to him.

It had happened so long ago that it almost felt more like a dream than a memory, but Kircheis remembered the day he had spent in the forest with Reinhard, when he had been terrified of Reinhardâ€™s potential for violence, and Reinhard had soothed him by pressing the gun into Kircheisâ€™s hands, entrusting him with everything.Â 

Martin didnâ€™t trust him at all.

â€œI wanted to see you,â€ Kircheis said. â€œAnd I want to protect youâ€” to make sure youâ€™re safe.â€

â€œI do want to help you,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI just canâ€™t blindly leap into whatever youâ€™re planning. I donâ€™t want to watch you throw your life away. I could help you get to Phezzan, orâ€”â€

â€œNo,â€ Martin said.

â€œWhy wonâ€™t you come with me?â€

â€œIf things were different, I would,â€ he said.

â€œDifferent how?â€

If he had never met Commodore Leighâ€” that was the way it would have to be different. If he hadnâ€™t met Leigh, he might have been content to try and fail at Martinâ€™s side. â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Kircheis said.Â 

â€œI wish youâ€™d figure out what youâ€™re doing,â€ Martin said, and his voice was purposefully cruel. â€œItâ€™s all very easy to see, if you open your eyes.â€

â€œI wish it was easy for me.â€ He paused. â€œI have always loved that about you.â€

â€œStop it.â€

â€œWhat do you want me to be to you, Martin?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œWhat I want you to be and what you are are two totally different things.â€

â€œI donâ€™t want to stop loving youâ€” donâ€™t make me.â€

â€œYou wonâ€™t join me.â€

â€œYou wouldnâ€™t have?â€ Martin asked. His voice was still cold. â€œYouâ€™ve run away on some errand that would have killed you, if you hadnâ€™t been lucky. If you had died on Cahokia, or planet Castrop, or wherever youâ€™re sent next, how is that any different?â€

â€œIâ€™m not intending to get killed.â€

â€œAnd neither am I.â€

There were several things that Kircheis could have said. He wanted to point out that Martin had never been good at protecting himself without Kircheis there to save him. â€œItâ€™s not futile.â€

â€œYou think that you can stand up against the whole of the Empire? You alone?â€

â€œI canâ€™t watch you throw your life away on something pointless!â€

â€œItâ€™s not pointless. Thatâ€™s you problem, Sieg. It matters to me, even if it doesnâ€™t to you. At least if I die, Iâ€™ll be doing it for something right, something that means something, not just because your superior ordered you to.â€

â€œIâ€™m trying to fix it, too,â€ Kircheis said. â€œThereâ€™s an actual plan to make this place better.â€

â€œAnd thatâ€™s what youâ€™ll tell yourself when Duke Braunschweig orders you to kill for his right to the throne. I think you can justify a lot by telling yourself that itâ€™s all for the best.â€

â€œSo can you!â€ Kircheis said. â€œYou can be as cruel as you want me, if you tell yourself that youâ€™re right.â€

â€œYes,â€ he said. â€œBecause I am right, and Iâ€™m going to do the right thing, no matter what it takes. I couldnâ€™t live with myself if I didnâ€™t, and I donâ€™t know how you can.â€

â€œBecause I donâ€™t just care about myself,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI canâ€™t throw away a decade of my life with youâ€” or anyone else I know. I canâ€™t be that selfish.â€

â€œBut it hasnâ€™t occurred to you that there are people in the world outside of you and me, billions of them. I think their lives matter a little bit more than whatever you feel.â€ Martin was breathing heavily, and a flush had risen to his cheeks.

Kircheis wanted to shake him. None of those billions of strangers would know or care that Martin was going to kill himself for them, but Kircheis would be the one who would have to bear it. But telling Martin that wouldnâ€™t have made any difference, so he didnâ€™t say it. Instead, he looked at Martin in silence, and wondered if there was anything he could say. â€œI hope itâ€™s worth it,â€ Kircheis finally said. â€œI hope it makes you happy.â€

â€œIt doesnâ€™t matter if it makes me happy. Itâ€™s something I have to do. Maybe youâ€™ll get that, someday.â€

Martin stood. As he did, he knocked over his bag, which had been sitting next to him. It flopped down the side of the dune. When Martin grabbed for it in a panic, sending rivulets of sand cascading down around his sliding feet, the gun fell out onto the sand and came to a stop in the lowest part of the hollow between the dunes. They both looked at it, and neither of them moved.

â€œKeep it,â€ Kircheis said. â€œIf itâ€™ll help you stay safe.â€

Martin picked up the gun and shoved it back into his bag, which he slung over his shoulder. He didnâ€™t look at Kircheis.

â€œCan I see you again sometime?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œWhat good would it do either of us?â€

â€œMaybe none. But I donâ€™t want to leave you like this, and never see you again.â€

Martin scuffed the ground with his toe. â€œI donâ€™t want to listen to you begging me to give up everything I stand for,â€ he said. â€œIt makes me think less of you.â€

â€œI wonâ€™t try to stop you.â€

â€œIâ€™ll think about it,â€ he said.

That was the best Kircheis was going to get, so he nodded. Martin looked at him for a second longer, then scrambled up the side of the dune and slid down the other side, headed back to the beach. Kircheis leaned back into the stiff grass and looked up at the sky, watching the birds wheel overhead.
