October 488 I.C., Odin

Kircheis was asleep in his empty apartment when his phone rang. After months, he had gotten used to sleeping by himself in the queen bed, but he still sometimes woke up disoriented when he got tangled in the sheets, reaching for a body that wasnâ€™t there. There was that moment of disorientation now, as the phone buzzed and jangled on his nightstand, and Kircheis sat up in a thrashing panic.

There was only one type of phone call that Kircheis could get at three in the morningâ€” a bad one.Â 

It took a moment for Kircheis to gather his wits about him in the dark, trying to think past the loud ringing. He centered himself by looking around in the dimness and reminding himself of the familiar furniture, only the outlines visible. It was pouring rain outside, and the window of his bedroom was smeared with the water dripping down, rendering the streetlights an indistinguishable orange haze in the darkness, casting strange glows onto the ceiling.

He answered the phone before its fourth ring.

â€œHello?â€

â€œKircheisâ€”â€ It was Commodore Leigh.

â€œYes, sir,â€ Kircheis said. â€œWhatâ€™s happening.â€

â€œThe Kaiser died about an hour ago,â€ Leigh said. â€œDuke Braunschweig is going to evacuate his family.â€

Kircheis had been prepared for this happening. Something clicked in his mind, and he put away everything other than the task Leigh had for him.

â€œWhat do you need me to do, sir?â€ Kircheis asked.

There was a moment of silence from the other end of the line. â€œLichenlade controls part of the military police,â€ he said, though Kircheis already knew that. â€œAll of Duke Braunschweigâ€™s allies are in danger.â€

â€œYes, sir.â€

â€œGo to the Mariendorf house. Do whatever the count tells you.â€

â€œSirâ€” what about you?â€

â€œI think weâ€™ll meet upâ€” Count Mariendorf will probably need to join the duke, but everyone knows heâ€™s an ally that the duke considers valuable, and I donâ€™t have anyone else I can sendâ€”â€ Of course, all of the dukeâ€™s small staff on the planet would be helping evacuate his household.

â€œYes, sir,â€ Kircheis said. â€œIâ€™ll go.â€

â€œDo what the count tells you,â€ Leigh said again. â€œWhatever he says.â€

â€œI will, sir.â€

â€œAnd Kircheisâ€”â€

â€œYes, sir?â€

â€œStay safe.â€

â€œYou too, sir.â€

Leigh hung up the phone. It took less than two minutes for Kircheis to get his clothes on, get his boots on his feet, and take his gun from the safe. As he tucked it into its holster on his belt, he realized that Commodore Leigh probably hadnâ€™t gotten himself a new sidearm, and a shiver of fear went through him. But that didnâ€™t stop him moving, and he was already out his door, dialing his phone to get a taxi, and then calling Hilde to tell her the news.

He was standing under the awning in front of his apartment and waiting for his taxi, barely shielded from the rain that cascaded down when Hilde picked up the phone. She was groggy, but she too knew that there was no good reason for a phone call in the middle of the night.

â€œSieg,â€ she said. â€œWhatâ€™s happening? Are you alright?â€

â€œThe Kaiser died,â€ he said. â€œWake up your father, and anybody else. Commodore Leigh told me to go to you, to make sure you and your father are safe. Itâ€™s going to be dangerous for Braunschweigâ€™s allies if they donâ€™t get off Odin right away.â€

There was a moment of silence from the other end of the line as Hilde processed the information. â€œI should get to the Braunschweig house,â€ she said. â€œThatâ€™s where we should go. Weâ€™ll leave the planet with them.â€

â€œDonâ€™t go anywhere,â€ Kircheis said. â€œNot until I get to you.â€

â€œBut if we need to hurry we should hurry. We can meet you there.â€

Kircheis knew that the reason Leigh had told him to go to the Mariendorf house was so that Count Mariendorf could order Kircheis to protect Hilde. That was one of the things Leigh had taken away from Hildeâ€™s time in Castropâ€™s captivity. But Hilde wouldnâ€™t accept that as an excuse, so Kircheis said, â€œI donâ€™t want to get separated. The Braunschweigs have already probably left their house and are headed somewhere safe temporarily. When I get to you, Leigh can tell us what we need to do. The situation is probably changing by the minute.â€

â€œHow long will it take for you to get here?â€

â€œI donâ€™t think many people know whatâ€™s happening yet,â€ Kircheis said as he looked down the street. He could see the lights of the taxi coming towards him. â€œThe roads are still clear. Give me twenty minutes.â€

â€œDo you know what Hank is doing? And Maggie?â€

â€œHe didnâ€™t say. But Leigh will take care of her.â€

â€œIâ€™ll wake up my father,â€ she said.

â€œIâ€™ll be there soon.â€

â€œSiegâ€”â€

â€œYeah?â€

â€œStay safe.â€

â€œI will.â€ He hung up as the taxi pulled up to the curb in front of him.

Chapter End Notes

hope you enjoyed yang getting married. the fun times are over.

martin my little combeferre kinnie... oh no...

much of this story is concerned with secret language and the ways that people who know each other well communicate. kircheis writes a poem in a language he doesn't know. the poem is the last stanza of sappho 16, which is the same poem that martin quoted in chapter 14 of servants of the pharaoh. martin, in his reply, signs his name as the subject of the poem, anactoria. [it's i guess a motif that martin and reinhard both at points use women's pen names haha. but that's neither here nor there.]

interestingly, the anactoria poem was written about in a different poem by swinburne, from which part of the title of this book is drawn (through a long chain ğŸ˜‚)

I would my love could kill thee; I am satiated
With seeing thee live, and fain would have thee dead.
I would earth had thy body as fruit to eat,
And no mouth but some serpentâ€™s found thee sweet.

i feel like i had more to say but i've lost it.

title is from lingua ignota

many thanks to em for the beta read!

you can find me on tumblr @ javert, twitter @ natsinator , gayspaceopera.carrd.co , and discord https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

The Opera Begins

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

October 488 I.C., Odin

Even though it was the middle of the night, the Braunschweig house was in total chaos when Yang arrived. He wasnâ€™t surprised by that, but it was one thing to expect it, and another thing to see it in the flesh. It was pouring rain outside, though that didnâ€™t stop Braunschweigâ€™s small personal contingent of soldiers and large staff of servants from running back and forth on the lawn. They were removing all the most essential items from the house and putting them out front in rows. Everything needed to be loaded onto Duke Braunschweigâ€™s personal ship, the Berlin , which should soon be en route from the airfield at which it was moored. All the houseâ€™s lights were on, and they illuminated the normally perfect lawn as the running of people back and forth tore the grass into muddy pits.

Ansbach stood in the rain, half yelling to direct the movement, and half speaking urgently into the phone that he kept squeezed between his ear and his shoulder so that he could have both his hands free to point and carry things. As Yang walked up the driveway, Ansbach stomped over to one soldier emerging from the house. The soldier had stacked two heavy boxes on top of each other, and Ansbach took the top one before it toppled over and fell. Lopsidedly, he carried it over to its correct spot on the lawn. When he put the box down, he looked up and saw Yang. He hung up his phone call.

â€œYouâ€™re here,â€ he said.

â€œDid you think I wouldnâ€™t be?â€ Yang asked.

Ansbach looked behind Yang at the car that was swiftly departing the Braunschweig house. â€œJust you?â€

â€œMy wife is going to stay with her mother for now, and I sent Lieutenant Kircheis to go find Count Mariendorf. Itâ€™s just me.â€

â€œFine,â€ Ansbach said. â€œAre you prepared to go?â€

Yang shrugged. Every plan he written had been either already put into action, or was too late to enact now. He didnâ€™t have much in the way of possessions that he needed to take with him. It was strangeâ€” he had arrived on Odin with nothing but the clothes on his back once, and it seemed like he was about to leave it in almost the same fashion.Â 

â€œYouâ€™re wanted inside,â€ Ansbach said.

â€œAbout what?â€

â€œHer Majesty is apparently wondering where you are.â€

Yang resisted the urge to roll his eyes at the title for Elizabeth. â€œShe hasnâ€™t been crowned yet.â€

â€œYouâ€™d better watch your mouth,â€ Ansbach said, but there wasnâ€™t enough venom in itâ€” he was too distracted, and the idea of Elizabeth as the nationâ€™s first kaiserin probably felt just as alien and funny to him as it did to Yang, albeit for different reasons.Â 

Yang hurried inside, though it was far too late to stop himself from being soaked, and he dripped his way through the house. For all the chaos outside, the interior, with all its dark wood, was still trapped in the quiet stillness of the night, once Yang left the front hall and headed towards the dukeâ€™s office. He passed the library, and saw that the door had been propped open, so he glanced inside as he walked byâ€” and then stopped in his tracks when he saw Elizabeth standing alone by the window, watching the chaos outside through the curtains of rain. He knocked on the door to get her attention, and then came in.

â€œI was told you were looking for me,â€ he said.

She didnâ€™t turn around immediately, but she could easily gauge his relative lack of formality by his tone. â€œYouâ€™d better bow,â€ she said. â€œMy father will make sure of it.â€

â€œBut will you make sure, Your Majesty?â€

She did turn around, then. He still didnâ€™t bow.Â 

â€œWhere is Fraulein Mariendorf?â€ she asked.

â€œWhy do you want to know?â€

She narrowed her eyes at him for a moment. â€œBring her here.â€

â€œNo,â€ Yang said.

â€œNo? Iâ€™m not sure youâ€™re in the position to refuse orders, Commodore Leigh.â€

Perhaps it was for the best that they were having a confrontation immediately. If Elizabeth wanted to flex her authority, Yang was a safe person for her to test it on. Ordering her father around would not get her far, and they both knew it.

â€œWhy do you want her here?â€ Yang asked. â€œIâ€™m certain that her father believes she will be safer remaining on Odin, rather than traveling with either him or yourself.â€

â€œAm I not allowed to have my advisors?â€ she asked.

â€œIf Fraulein Mariendorf arrives under her own power, I doubt anyone would have an objection to her staying,â€ Yang said. â€œBut your father would not jeopardize his alliance with Count Mariendorf by dragging his daughter onto the front lines for your sake. Nor would I.â€

She wrinkled her nose in childish, obvious displeasure, but she didnâ€™t argue. She was probably tired and still in mild shock, since it was the middle of the night and it would take some time for her to really grasp her new station. This was what prevented an argument, Yang was sure. But he wouldnâ€™t push it too far.

Just a little further.

â€œMay I ask a question, Your Majesty?â€

â€œFine.â€

â€œWhat matters would you expect her to advise you on while we head out into space?â€

Her gaze became a glare. â€œWhat does it matter to you?â€

â€œI hope that I might be able to serve as a poor substitute for Fraulein Mariendorf, since Iâ€™ve been her teacher for many years.â€

She curled her lip. â€œYouâ€™re my fatherâ€™s advisor, not mine.â€

â€œMay I say one more thing, Your Majesty?â€Â 

She was silent, which Yang took as permission.Â 

â€œIâ€™ll say to you the same thing I said to your grandfather more than once. I am a servant of all the people of the Empireâ€” and by the transitive property, that makes me your servant too, even if only a humble one.â€

Elizabeth rolled her eyes. â€œIf that line worked on my grandfather, it wonâ€™t work on me.â€

â€œWell, if there is any opportunity for me to be useful to you, I hope that you do not hesitate to tell me. There are some benefits of being your fatherâ€™s advisor.â€

â€œSuch as?â€

â€œSince he controls my paycheck, he at least knows the value of taking me seriously.â€

This unexpected joke made Elizabeth laugh. â€œYou hardly need a paycheck. My grandfather took care of that for you.â€

â€œI donâ€™t work for free,â€ Yang said, and his affrontedness was only half-feigned. â€œI said Iâ€™m a servant, not a slave. Thereâ€™s dignity in getting a paycheckâ€” my father impressed that on me at a very young age.â€

She shook her head and turned back to the window. â€œIâ€™m afraid I will simply lack for pleasant company,â€ she said.

â€œHerr Vering is not enough company for you?â€

â€œHe lacks the feminine grace to make good conversation. At least least enough to entertain me until itâ€™s safe to return home.â€

â€œWhen I next see Fraulein Mariendorf, Iâ€™ll be sure to pass along that you think sheâ€™s a good conversationalist.â€

â€œYou do that,â€ Elizabeth said. â€œIâ€™m sure sheâ€™d appreciate the compliment.â€

There was something in her voice that made Yang change his mind immediately, but he still gave her his placid smile. â€œAre you ready to leave?â€ he asked

â€œIt hardly makes a difference if Iâ€™m ready,â€ she said. â€œWeâ€™re leaving regardless.â€

â€œThatâ€™s true,â€ Yang said.

â€œAre you ready, Commodore Leigh?â€ There was more in her voice than simple concern for himâ€” in fact, there was none of that at all.Â 

â€œYes, Your Majesty,â€ Yang said. He tried to put as much calm honesty into his voice as he could, even if calm and honest were not things he had felt for a long time. Even if her tone was one of demanding answers about strategy, and about victoryâ€” Yang could see how small she was, standing at the window. She was half his age, and she would come out of this with either half the galaxy on her shoulders, or dead. She could keep her voice cool, but he suspected that she wanted reassurance, of the kind she might have wanted from Hilde. He could give her that. â€œWeâ€™re ready.â€

She nodded, and that was a dismissal. He slipped out of the library.

Â 

Â 

Yang ended up caught in the flurry of activity around the Braunschweig manor for quite some time. He had texted his various allies who remained on Odin during his car ride to the Braunschweig house, but since he was sending warning messages to so many people, he hadnâ€™t had a chance to call anyone other than Kircheis. Yang slipped away from where Duke Braunschweig was surveying the scene from the front hall, sneaking down the back of the house and out towards the yard where he had once spoken with Ansbach, down near the servantsâ€™ hall. There was no one there, since all of the servants were hurriedly engaged in getting the house ready to leave, and so Yang had some privacy there in the very early hours of the October morning. He stood beneath the lip of the roof, and the bulk of the house made sure the wind didnâ€™t toss the drops at him.

He shivered in the cold, and rubbed his hands together before he pulled his phone from his pocket and dialed Reuenthalâ€™s number with shaky hands. The adrenaline from having woken up in the middle of the night had long since worn off, and it was tiredness that quavered Yangâ€™s limbs now. Reuenthal picked up on the second ring.

â€œWhere are you?â€ Reuenthal asked, before Yang could even say a word.

â€œThe Braunschweig house,â€ Yang said. â€œWeâ€™ll be leaving the planet as soon as the dukeâ€™s ship arrives.â€

There was a moment of silence from Reuenthal. In that empty space, Yang had to wonder what he was thinking. Well, he didnâ€™t have to wonder. He knew Reuenthal well enough. Reuenthal didnâ€™t want to stay on Odin, but there was no way he could come with the Braunschweig family.

â€œCan you tell me where youâ€™re going?â€ Reuenthal asked.

â€œGeiersburg,â€ Yang said. â€œMost of the dukeâ€™s pledged-troopsâ€ â€”those that could be called upon by the crownâ€” â€œare stationed there. Weâ€™ll meet up with his forces heâ€™s calling up from his own lands, and then weâ€™ll take the fortress as a base.â€

â€œAnd then youâ€™ll return to Odin with a fleet?â€

â€œI hope so,â€ Yang said. â€œI donâ€™t want to do anything else if we can help it. But it depends on how it all goes. Iâ€™m sure that this will be our first stop.â€

â€œWill I be able to join you then?â€

It was a simple question, but it didnâ€™t have a simple answer. â€œIf we can get to the ground, then it will all be over. If we canâ€™tâ€”â€ There wouldnâ€™t be any way for Reuenthal to get off the planet, nor any reason for him to do so. They both knew that.

â€œWhat do you want me to do?â€ Reuenthal asked. There wasnâ€™t any rancor in his words at being refused, but the calmness of Reuenthalâ€™s voice was often deceptive.

â€œLieutenant Kircheis has a lot of information, and heâ€™s staying on Odin, I think. Unless he gets here in the next five minutes,â€ Yang said, trailing off into mumbles.

Â In the sky, visible now through the rainclouds, Yang could see a distant light growing larger and closerâ€” Duke Braunschweigâ€™s personal ship, breaking through the fog. He shook himself out of his reverie watching it.Â 

Yang continued. â€œMeet up with him and Oberstein. I donâ€™t know whatâ€™s going to happen on Odin enough to plan for it entirely, butâ€¦ he has what Iâ€™ve given him, at least.â€

â€œFine,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œReuenthalâ€”â€

â€œLeigh.â€

â€œPlease stay safe,â€ Yang said. â€œBefore anything else. Please.â€

There was silence again from the other end of the line. This time, Yang had no idea what Reuenthal was thinking. Or if he did, he didnâ€™t want to put words to it.

â€œShould I get in contact with Mittermeyer?â€ Reuenthal finally asked. â€œTell him to meet you?â€

â€œNo,â€ Yang said. â€œAt least not yet.â€

â€œWhy not? He has ships, unlike me.â€

â€œHalf-built ones,â€ Yang pointed out. Mittermeyer had been shuffled off Odin early in the summer, his duties changed to include overseeing the building of the first few ships in a new class, at a shipbuilding station far from Odin. This posting had annoyed Muckenburger, since it was a real thing for Mittermeyer to be working on, but Admiral Schaft, Mittermeyerâ€™s direct superior, had assigned him there when the previous holder of the position had retired. Mittermeyer hated it, predictably. But even if Muckenburger was annoyed, it wasnâ€™t like Mittermeyerâ€™s micro-fleet of under-construction ships could do much.

â€œHe would want to be useful to you.â€

Yang closed his eyes. The ship in the sky was coming closer and closer. He could hear the drone of its engines now. If Mittermeyer stayed out of things, no matter what the eventual outcome of the civil war was, he would live through it. But Reuenthal wouldnâ€™t like that answer, and neither would Mittermeyer if he heard it.Â 

â€œI donâ€™t want him to come to Odin,â€ Yang said. â€œThere wouldnâ€™t be any benefit in itâ€” if anything, it would be a waste of a surprise element we might need later.â€

â€œFine,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œThis shouldnâ€™t take too long.â€

â€œOh? You expect to win quickly?â€

â€œIâ€™d like to,â€ Yang said. â€œBut even if I donâ€™tâ€” thereâ€™s only so long either side can sustain a full force, especially if everything has fallen apart around the Empire. It canâ€™t go on more than a year. If it does, even if weâ€™re still fighting it out, weâ€™ll be too weak to fend off the rebels. And theyâ€™re going to be waiting for that.â€

Reuenthal made a non-commital noise.

â€œIf it gets that bad,â€ Yang said, â€œhopefully I will have Iserlohn, and can make a deal.â€

â€œYou probably shouldnâ€™t be talking so loudly.â€

Yang glanced aroundâ€” he was still totally alone in the yard, but now the ship was right overhead, slowly descending down to the front of the Braunschweig mansion.

â€œI should go,â€ Yang said.

â€œI wonâ€™t keep you.â€

â€œIf I can, Iâ€™ll contact you when weâ€™re back at Odin,â€ Yang said. â€œIâ€™ll do my best.â€

â€œDid I say that you wouldnâ€™t?â€

â€œOskarâ€”â€

Silence from Reuenthalâ€™s side.

Yang looked around again. The shipâ€™s lights on the other side of the house were catching on the falling raindrops and illuminating the sky to an eerie, almost daylight brightness. â€œI love you,â€ Yang said.

He could hear Reuenthal breathing. â€œIsnâ€™t your phone still tapped, Hank?â€

Yang smiled, despite everything. â€œI donâ€™t think I care anymore.â€

â€œThen goodbye, Wen-li,â€ Reuenthal said, almost quietly enough that Yang couldnâ€™t make out the name. He felt an overwhelming warmth in his heart, enough to make it hard to speak through the choke of emotion rising up through his throat. By the time he had figured out what he wanted to say to Reuenthal, he had hung up.

Â 

Â 

The journey to Geiersburg Fortress was not particularly long. The fortress was about halfway between Duke Braunschweigâ€™s owned territory and the capital, further back into the heartland of the Empire, away from the Iserlohn and Phezzan corridors. Throughout the journey, Duke Braunschweig was in very high spirits, and this was a contagious feeling for some of his family members. Baron Flegel seemed cheerful, anyway. Of the two women on board, Princess Amarie and Kaserin Elizabeth, it was impossible to tell if their smiles and laughter in the presence of the duke were sincere. Both of them were very good actors.

For his own part, Yang ended up in a little informal cadre made of three people: himself, Admiral Merkatz, and Count Mariendorf. Both the count and the admiral had joined Braunschweig at his house before his ship departed, having made arrangements to do so beforehand.

Count Mariendorf and Admiral Merkatz knew each other from simply being in the same general social sphere, but they both knew Yang better, so he found himself in the odd position of being looked to by two people he respected. Yang would have invited Ansbach into this little circle, but Ansbach was glued to the dukeâ€™s side, a position that Yang did not envy in the least. It wasnâ€™t clear that Ansbach would have accepted such an invitation, anyway.

In any event, the dukeâ€™s cheer didnâ€™t quite make it as far as Count Mariendorf and Admiral Merkatz. Both of them were serious men, and found it difficult to laugh at a future that they couldnâ€™t see. Yang couldnâ€™t help but agree with them. The civil war, even if they won easily, would have a human cost that weighed on him heavily.

Both men were concerned about their families back on Odin, though they didnâ€™t speak of it much. Hilde had remained behind, as Yang had known she would, even if she had wanted to come. Merkatzâ€™s wife had gone to stay with his daughter and son-in-lawâ€™s family, who had a country home. Yang said that so far away from the city, there probably wouldnâ€™t be too much chaos, which seemed somewhat reassuring to Merkatz, though this was hard to tellâ€” he always had such an unflappable facade.

Although Merkatz still outranked Yang significantly, now that he was a flag officer, it was easier for them to speak as relative equals. Merkatz had always respected Yangâ€™s tactical abilities, but now they spent long hours poring over Yangâ€™s plans, both for Geiersburg and for the larger civil war. The only thing that Yang held back from Merkatz was the plan for Iserlohn. He suspected that Merkatz would have ideological trouble going through with it, if it wasnâ€™t of dire need. There was no point in bringing up something that looked like a defeatist plan early.

Braunschweigâ€™s ship Berlin met up with his small contingent of vessels that had come from his home territories. Yang considered it very lucky that the Berlin had been able to make it away from Odin without being chased or hunted down by any of Littenheimâ€™s allied ships. Even if the fleet that Braunschweig had managed to gather was only some thousand ships strong, it was still so much more secure than traveling alone.Â 

Braunschweig had many soldiers under his command, but the majority were those in his personal territories, including most of his ground troops, which were required to remain where they were to prevent Littenheim from launching an attack on the Braunschweig homelands that could halt a forward advance to Odin. The remainder of his soldiers were those pledged for the crownâ€™s use, and they were stationed primarily at Geiersburg. This would be Braunschweigâ€™s main fighting force for the rest of the civil war, if they could join up with it.

Braunschweig appointed Merkatz to be the commander of his fleet, which reassured Yang more than anything else. Flegel had been jockeying for the position, in his needling way, but there was nothing anyone could say to deny that Merkatz had more experience as an actual commander. Flegel was promised his own section of the eventual full fleet, which appeased him a little, especially since neither Yang nor Ansbach were given ships of their own. This suited Yang fine; he had no desire to command directly.

On the last day before they made it to Geiersburg, Yang needed to speak with Braunschweig, to confirm the timeline of their planned attack. Merkatz had gone off onto a different ship which would serve as his temporary flag. The Berlin , since it was still carrying the precious cargo of Elizabeth, would need to hang back in the battleâ€” and so Yang was serving as an unofficial go-between to coordinate everything. He got the sense that Merkatz and Braunschweig barely tolerated each other, and their working relationship would be better the less they saw of each other.

He found Braunschweig in his richly appointed lounge, sitting on one of the couches, with Baron Flegel next to him, and Ansbach sitting across from him. Ansbach looked cool and collected, but Braunschweig was leaning forward over the coffee table where there was an ornate chessboard set up. Ansbach was playing white, and it seemed that Flegel and Braunschweig were playing together as black, though Yang had to wonder how much Flegel was helping rather than hindering. The game was already well underway.

As Yang walked in, Flegel looked up and said, â€œOh, good, you can help Ansbach lose.â€ His uncle simultaneously picked up a pawn and moved it forward two spaces.

â€œIâ€™m afraid Iâ€™m terrible at chess,â€ Yang said. But he came to sit down anyway, perching on the arm of the couch where Ansbach sat.

Ansbach barely looked up at Yang, but a slight twitch of a frown crossed his face. For once, Yang couldnâ€™t tell if it was because of him, or because of the move Braunschweig had just made. His hand hovered over his bishop, considering moving it back from where it was now being threatened by the black pawn, but instead he moved his knight to capture.

Flegel pointed at the board, where one of Braunschweigâ€™s remaining pawns could take the knight. â€œSee?â€ he crowed, as his uncle followed his instructions and captured.

Silently, Ansbach struck back with his bishop and took this pawn.

â€œWhat was it you wanted?â€ Braunschweig finally asked, not taking his eyes off the board to look at Yang.

â€œI wanted to talk over our plans for tomorrow, sir.â€

â€œMm.â€ The move Braunschweig made on the board, shifting one of his knights around, was inscrutable to Yang. Similarly, the move that Ansbach followed up withâ€” castlingâ€” meant little to him. â€œTalk, then.â€

â€œSir, are you completely certain that your men in the fortress will have the ability to disable Geiersburgâ€™s main gun?â€

Flegel whispered something in his uncleâ€™s ear, but Braunschweig had no outward change in facial expression.

â€œIâ€™m certain. Does Merkatz doubt it?â€

â€œNo, sir. I just would like to be careful, before we put our entire force within range of the gun.â€

â€œWe only have a thousand ships, Leigh. Iâ€™m surprised you want to split them.â€ He was focused on the board, so his tone was one of distraction.

â€œI donâ€™t want to split them, sir. I just want to send in radar decoys first, to see if Geiersburg takes the bait.â€

â€œNo,â€ Braunschweig said, without looking up from the board. â€œWeâ€™re moving in as quickly as possible. Weâ€™re sitting targets for Littenheimâ€™s fleet if we donâ€™t get into that fortress. And donâ€™t bother telling me that this ship should remain behind by itself. We were lucky to even survive getting off Odin.â€

â€œIt shouldnâ€™t take long to test if they will fire, sir,â€ Yang tried.

â€œAnd if they donâ€™t take the bait? I said no, Commodore.â€

The game was continuing, but Yang wasnâ€™t following the moves until Flegel pointed out that Braunschweig should try to take Ansbachâ€™s queenâ€” though Braunschweig had just moved, and so Ansbach was presumably about to move his queen to safety. Ansbach had no reaction to this happening, and leaned back in his seat to listen to Yang. Braunschweig did the same, and so the game was paused for a moment. Now that Braunschweig was looking up at Yang rather than down at the board, he could see some of the tension held in the crease of his forehead, not quite a scowl, but almost.

â€œI donâ€™t think we need any of your tricks,â€ Flegel said dismissively.Â 

â€œIf you have some other suggestion, tell me quickly,â€ Braunschweig said. His eyes kept flicking to the chessboard.

Yang ran his hand through his hair. â€œFine, sir. If we have to go in quicklyâ€” Iâ€™m not suggesting that we stay split up, but I do suggest that as we initially enter the gunâ€™s range, we should spread thinly, and deploy radar decoys in between our ships. When weâ€™re still that far out, the gun can only target a tiny angle, and if it fires on us, weâ€™llâ€¦ lose a minimum of men.â€

â€œAnd if it doesnâ€™t?â€

â€œThen weâ€™ll proceed towards the fortress and group back up as we come closer,â€ Yang said. He was much more worried about if the gun did fire on them, but Braunschweig seemed to consider that a non-issue. Yang wasnâ€™t sure he was so trusting.

He was sure that the fleet would not deploy. Of the sixteen thousand ships or so in the bays of Geiersburg, twelve thousand belonged to Duke Braunschweig outright. If the fortress command ordered the fleet out, then most of those ships would likely immediately join the duke. So, the fortressâ€™s only defense was its main gun, its liquid metal armor, and its floating gun turrets.

â€œAnd weâ€™ll take out the floating turrets as we planned,â€ Flegel said. â€œIâ€™m sure they wonâ€™t be an issue for our Valkyries.â€

â€œYes, if we can get close enough to deploy them,â€ Yang said.

â€œIâ€™m certain that we can,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œWas that all, Leigh?â€

â€œIf you donâ€™t want to discuss alternatives, in case we are fired upon, yes.â€

â€œWe can discuss alternatives if we need to. If weâ€™re fired on, weâ€™ll retreat out of range and regroupâ€

â€œFine,â€ Yang said. He started to get up to leave as Braunschweig turned back to the chessboard, but Ansbach stopped him.

â€œGive me a moment to finish this game, Count von Leigh. Iâ€™d like to talk to you about the plan to breach the fortress, once the gun turrets have been taken care of,â€ Ansbach said. Yang could tell this was not what Ansbach wanted to talk aboutâ€” their plan for physically entering the fortress had been hashed out long in advance, and it was one of the things Yang felt most confident about.

â€œOf course,â€ Yang said, and he sat back down on the arm of the couch.

Ansbach pushed his bishop across the board, took Braunschweigâ€™s rook. Braunschweig was forced to follow that up by using his knight to capture the bishop, since his king was in danger. Ansbach moved his queen.

â€œCheck,â€ he said.

â€œMove your knight,â€ Flegel said.

Braunschweig did, without comment, and took the queen.

â€œYouâ€™re up in material now,â€ Flegel said.

But Ansbach moved his rook all the way across the board. â€œMate,â€ he said.

â€œOh, come on,â€ Flegel whined. It was true. Ansbachâ€™s bishop was simultaneously pinning down the king in concert with the rook.Â 

â€œGood game, my lord,â€ Ansbach said. Braunschweig leaned back in his seat, though still studying the board.

â€œYes, good game.â€ Braunschweig waved Ansbach off, and together he and Yang made their way into the hallway.

â€œDid you want to go to your office?â€ Yang asked.

â€œNo,â€ Ansbach said. â€œHere is fine. This wonâ€™t take long.â€ Although they got along better, these days, the scowl in Ansbachâ€™s voice when he addressed Yang was habitual. Yang didnâ€™t mind it.

They spoke quietly, not loud enough to be heard by anyone who might happen to pass by the corner and see them.

â€œThis isnâ€™t about the boarding party, is it?â€

â€œYou think weâ€™re going to get hit,â€ Ansbach said flatly.

â€œI think itâ€™s worth considering. I donâ€™t personally care if we lose this war before we even fire a single shot, but Iâ€™d prefer not to be blasted out of the sky tomorrow.â€

Ansbach made a derisive noise. â€œYou need to keep your mouth shut.â€

â€œIâ€™d just like to be prepared for the idea that his agents havenâ€™t managed to disable the gun.â€

â€œIf we get shot at, what next?â€

â€œTheyâ€™ll aim for our midsection,â€ Yang said. â€œJust to maximize their chance of hitting us at all, from this big of a firing distance. We should put most of our decoys in the center of our formation.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t think theyâ€™ll bait us in closer by not firing?â€

â€œNo, I donâ€™t think itâ€™s likely. Thatâ€™s why I figured we might be able to bait them out with decoys. Anyone in that fortress command wants to defeat us before the rank and file figure out that weâ€™re even there. If thereâ€™s some kind of rebellion within the fortress for our side, they wonâ€™t be able to contain it for very long. They need to shoot us down fast if they want to stop that from happening. Well, if it happens anyway. I know Braunschweig sent agents there to organize something like that, but I donâ€™t know if theyâ€™ll even be successful.â€

Ansbach nodded.

â€œBut even if nothing happens inside the fortress, Iâ€™m sure that the fortress command are aware of the possibility of sabotage. I certainly would be. Theyâ€™re going to want to test their gun on us as soon as possible, so that if itâ€™s not working, they can come up with some kind of plan. Ideally theyâ€™ll surrender, butâ€¦â€ Yang rubbed at the back of his head.

â€œYouâ€™re deluding yourself if you think they will.â€

â€œYeah. I know,â€ Yang said.

â€œYou keep dodging the question. If we do get fired onâ€¦â€

â€œWe either wait until the fortress collapses from the inside, orâ€¦â€

â€œOr what? Braunschweig doesnâ€™t like waiting.â€

â€œI donâ€™t want to render the fortress unusable,â€ Yang said. â€œThat would defeat the purpose of capturing it.â€

â€œYou are full of yourself. Tell me your idea.â€

Yang looked over Ansbachâ€™s left shoulder, down the empty hallway. In a rather dead voice, he said, â€œThe gun can melt ships into slag, even vaporize them at close range, but the light-pressure of it isnâ€™t enough to halt their momentum, even if theyâ€™re husks.â€

â€œGo on.â€

â€œWe can capture a large asteroid. Sacrifice a few ships to push it. Unmanned. If they accelerate from outside the range of the gun, stay behind the rock, they can move it up to speed, maybe even keep accelerating within the gunâ€™s range, for a while. And if itâ€™s pointed directly at the fortress, that kind of mass moving at speed canâ€™t be budged by the beam gun. It will hit, and will take out whateverâ€™s behind it. To move it, theyâ€™d have to slam their own ships into it, even to just divert it. And if they open those doorsâ€”â€

Ansbach was silent for a moment. â€œAnd you think this will work?â€

â€œYes,â€ Yang said.

â€œAlright. Iâ€™ll make sure this ship is far back, and in one of the flanks.â€

â€œThank you,â€ Yang said. Ansbach turned to go. â€œOne questionâ€”â€

â€œWhat?â€

â€œWhen did you know you were going to beat him? In the chess game, I mean.â€

â€œI decided to win as soon as Baron Flegel walked in the door.â€

Yang let out a huff of a laugh. â€œWhen should he have resigned, then?â€

â€œProbably when I refused his queen trade,â€ Ansbach said. â€œBut he never resigns. Itâ€™s not like him.â€

Â 

Â 

Yang explained his alternate plans to Merkatz, who quickly dispatched a few ships to find and gather a suitable asteroid for their purposes. Although on a map, it appeared that Geiersburg was in the middle of empty space, it was situated along one of the major routes that ships could use to travel faster-than-light through the Empire, where the strings of gravity formed channels for shipsâ€™ engines to cut their ways through. Long agoâ€” many billions of years, Yang supposedâ€” this part of the galaxy had held a star system, or something that might have tried to form a star system. Now there was only cold rubble, sparse through space, but it was massive enough to draw those invisible lines of force closer together. And it was plentiful enough that it was easy to find a suitable chunk of rock, one that even two strikes from Geiersburgâ€™s main gun wouldnâ€™t be able to vaporize entirely.

Merkatz understood why Yang had wanted to have Braunschweig put this plan into place early. Geiersburgâ€™s main gun had a range of six hundred thousand kilometers. Light could travel that distance in about two seconds, but there was no way they could use their shipsâ€™ sub-light engines to accelerate a rock anywhere close to that speed, and there was no way to use their superluminal gravity engines to push a rock in concert like that. They wouldnâ€™t be able to drop it back down to sub-light speeds.Â 

But the rock didnâ€™t need to be moving faster than light. They didnâ€™t even have to get it up to one percent of the speed of light. Yang could make do with something around 1/500th of lightspeedâ€” six hundred kilometers per second. It was still a speed that was unfathomably fast, but it was well within the limits of the engines of their ships. If the rock was approaching Geiersburg at that speed, it would arrive in about sixteen minutes. Geiersburgâ€™s main gun could only fully charge and fire once every ten minutes. Yangâ€™s rock, if it was big enough, wouldnâ€™t be vaporized in two hits. Even he could do that math. And a rock that size, solid, moving at that speed, would cripple the fortress, even if Yang aimed it to only do the most glancing blow.

He really did not want to put this plan in action, but if the fortress was firing on them with its main gun, he didnâ€™t see much of another way to disable it, not with their tiny fleet. He couldnâ€™t count on there being any breaking ranks within the fortress itself. Yang lacked Braunschweigâ€™s confidence.

Even Merkatz was skeptical of their chances of not being fired on, and he made his own preparations to get out of Geiersburgâ€™s range quickly, should they come under attack.

As the time came for their advance, Merkatz arranged the fleet. As Yang had suggested, he bulked out their visible numbers by preparing to deploy radar decoys in between their ranks.

Even though this made their fleet look twice as large, spread out in a wide band across the stars, it could still only look like a paltry two-thousand-strong fleet.

Merkatzâ€™s contribution to the fleet arrangement, his own paranoia about being able to escape Geiersburgâ€™s gun, was visible on the screen now. Since there was no chance that they were about to meet another fleet in battle, Merkatz could perform a rather esoteric fleet maneuverâ€” the kind of thing that was run as a drill more than it would ever see battle.

This whole exercise was turning out to be one of playing with Newtonâ€™s laws. Before the fleet entered Geiersburgâ€™s attack radius, they accelerated, then stopped accelerating, cruising under their momentum. Without changing their paths or their speed, Merkatz ordered all the ships to turn around. They were flying, unpowered and backwards, into Geiersburgâ€™s territory. If they were fired upon, this would give them the maximum ability to retreat quickly, to get out of range before a second shot could go off and critically disable the fleet. They wouldnâ€™t have to waste precious time turning around.

â€œSomeone in Geiersburg is laughing at us right now,â€ Yang muttered to himself as he leaned against the wall on the bridge of the Berlin , watching the big screen at the front of the room, standing well back from Braunschweig in the main chair. Ansbach, who happened to be walking past Yang at that moment, gave him a glare. Yang returned a sheepish smile, though he didnâ€™t really feel like smiling.

â€œWhy donâ€™t you go make yourself useful?â€ Ansbach said under his breath, pretending to look at a nearby console.

â€œI am useful,â€ Yang said.

â€œYouâ€™re about as useful as him.â€ Ansbach gave a slight nod over to Lieutenant Commander Hans von Vering, who was also standing around the bridge of the Berlin . He seemed to have little understanding of what was going on, and was anxiously moving back and forth between several operator stations on the bridge, bothering the men manning them. Braunschweig and Flegel were both watching this movement with annoyance.

â€œIs this your way of telling me to get rid of him?â€ Yang asked.

â€œBe delicate about it. If youâ€™re capable of that.â€ And Ansbach headed back over the center of the room to report to Braunschweig.

Yang sighed and stuck his hands in his pockets, then wandered over to where Vering was haunting the poor radar operator, leaning over his shoulder and breathing down his neck to look at the dots of ships on the screen, as though they meant anything to him.

â€œLieutenant Commander Vering,â€ Yang said.

Vering jerked up, not having realized that Yang was there. When he realized who was addressing him, he scowled a little. â€œWhat do you need, sir?â€ he said, with some reluctance.

â€œI was wondering if you might walk with me,â€ Yang said. â€œI need to speak with you.â€

â€œAbout?â€

â€œThis is not a matter for the bridge,â€ Yang said.

Vering looked around, hoping that Duke Braunschweig or Flegel would step in to save him from needing to leave with Yang, but the duke and baron were engaged in a discussion behind the audio privacy screen, and they were paying no attention to Yang. Even if they had been, Yang suspected that they were as eager to get Vering off the bridge as Ansbach had been. Neither of them particularly liked Elizabethâ€™s future husband.

Even though the person giving the order was Yang , Vering couldnâ€™t actually refuse it, so he followed Yang out of the bridge. Yang didnâ€™t say anything as they walked through the hallways for a minute, until Vering finally spoke up, in an annoyed voice.

â€œWhat was it that you wanted to talk to me about, sir?â€

â€œOh.â€ Yang was almost startled to be addressed. He pulled his hands out of his pockets so that he could rub at the back of his head. â€œI just thought that Her Majesty might like your company. This is a very delicate time, and sheâ€™s never been on the battlefield before. It seemed to me that it would be prudent of you to provide her some reassurance.â€

â€œIs she asking for me?â€ Was his voice hopeful?

â€œWell, er, sheâ€™s not really the type to ask for something like that. But if youâ€™re going to marry her, wellâ€¦â€ He trailed off.

â€œAnd what am I supposed to say to her?â€ Vering asked. â€œItâ€™s not even like weâ€™re in the middle of the action. Itâ€™s not even like there is action. Weâ€™re on the flank, and weâ€™re not even really moving.â€

â€œWeâ€™re moving, Lieutenant Commander.â€

Vering scowled. They were coming close to the personal quarters of the Braunschweig family, and Yang had absolutely no compunctions about ringing the bell. He stood loosely, with his hands at his side, while next to him Vering was stiff, and smoothed down his light colored hair with an anxious hand. He fiddled with his uniform, and was tugging his jacket into place when the door finally opened, revealing Princess Amarie.

â€œHansâ€¦ and Count von Leigh, what a surprise to see you both,â€ Amarie said. Her tone was inscrutable. â€œI had assumed everyone in uniform would be far too busy to come pay visits.â€

â€œWell, my job is mostly done, at this point,â€ Yang said. â€œItâ€™s up to everyone else now. But itâ€™s actually Her Majesty that the lieutenant commander has come to see. Iâ€™ve just been providing him an escort.â€

Amarie clearly understood that Vering was about to become her problem. She smiled. â€œAn escort? I find it hard to believe that such a thing would be necessary. Please, come in.â€

â€œThank you, my lady.â€ Yang did incline his head politely as he stepped past her into her familyâ€™s quarters.

For the interior of a ship, their quarters were luxe. There were lush green houseplants in pots and along the walls, some in bloom, which cheered the space. The furniture was heavy wood, not like the light fiberglass and plastic that was found in the staff quarters. The lights were warm, and the air smelled fresher and cleaner than the rest of the ship. At the far end of the living room area, there was a huge plate window, one that looked out over the battlefield. Elizabeth sat sideways to this view with an embroidery hoop on her lap. Her needle moved down and out of the fabric with a machine-like force and precision, continuing its motion even as she looked up at her guests.

â€œI thought my father considered you indispensable, Hans,â€ Elizabeth said. She nodded at Yang, who gave a shallow bow, then wandered over to the window to look out. Amarie sat back down on the armchair across from the couch and watched the other three with an eagle eye.

â€œIâ€™ve been dispensed with,â€ Vering said. He sat down on the couch next to Elizabeth. â€œOr Iâ€™ve been told that I would provide greater value here, as your future husband. To reassure you about whatâ€™s happening.â€

â€œWe seem to be moving backwards,â€ Elizabeth said. â€œThis window looks out over the aft of the ship.â€

â€œAn astute observation,â€ Vering said, puffing himself up. â€œAdmiral Merkatz is doing something strange with the fleet arrangement. Iâ€™m surprised that your father allowed the Berlin to go along with it. Especially with us out in the flank.â€

Elizabeth looked up at Yang, who was scanning the black sky outside for the tiny dot that was Geiersburg. â€œIs this your plan?â€ she asked.

â€œNo,â€ Yang said. â€œAdmiral Merkatz decided the specifics of the fleet movement. I only advised.â€ He found the tiny dot among the stars, fixed it in his vision, and pointed it out. â€œThereâ€™s Geiersburg.â€

Elizabeth stood up from the couch, passing her embroidery off to her fiancee, who looked down at it. The picture was of a bouquet of roses, half done.

â€œWhy are we spread out so far? In photos of other battles, Iâ€™ve never seen gaps like that in the line,â€ Elizabeth said as she stood next to Yang at the window. â€œTo the fortress, it doesnâ€™t look like there are any holes,â€ Yang said. â€œWeâ€™ve deployed radar decoys to make our fleet look bigger than it is. Theyâ€™re too small for you to see with the naked eye from here, but they look just like ships to someone looking at radar far away.â€

â€œHow long until weâ€™re in range of the fortress?â€ Vering asked.

This caused Amarie to speak up. â€œElizabeth, why donâ€™t you sit down? Youâ€™re making me nervous.â€

â€œNervous?â€ Elizabeth asked. â€œIâ€™m just standing here.â€

â€œCommodore, may I speak with you for a second?â€ Amarie asked.

â€œOf course.â€

He followed her one room over, into a private dining room, and she she shut the door behind her.Â 

â€œWhat are you doing here, Commodore?â€ she asked. All pleasantries were gone from her voice.

She didnâ€™t need him to tell her the obvious reason for escorting Vering over. â€œDonâ€™t you think that the leader of the Empire should know something about how the business of the Empire is conducted?â€ Yang asked.

â€œShe doesnâ€™t need to worry about this. I donâ€™t need to worry about this.â€

It was unusual that Amarie was showing him this moment of weakness. It was unlike her. He wondered what the purpose of it was. Amarie always had some kind of purpose. She probably just didnâ€™t want him too close to her daughter. But he tried to keep his voice gentle. â€œFor some people, knowing whatâ€™s happening is better than being kept in the dark.â€ When Amarie pursed her lips, Yang added, â€œIâ€™m not trying to overstep my place.
