â€œMy daughter is not a soldier, and doesnâ€™t need to be taught to be one.â€

â€œThen let me provide an explanation for Herr Veringâ€™s sake, since you expect him to take on this duty for your daughter in the future.â€

Amarie shouldnâ€™t have let herself be backed into that corner. â€œI assume that she and I will never have occasion to be part of an active battle again.â€

â€œI doubt that you will be,â€ Yang said. â€œIt would be very stupid to put either of you in danger unless it is absolutely necessary.â€

â€œWhy are we here, Commodore?â€

â€œDo you think that I suggested bringing you to the front lines?â€ Yang asked, incredulous.

â€œYou could have suggested putting us on a different ship to hang back.â€

â€œAnsbach tried to say that. Did you bring it up with the duke?â€

Her lip curled. â€œYou may stay. Just this once.â€

â€œThank you,â€ Yang said.

â€œDo not overstep your place, Commodore.â€

â€œI wonâ€™t,â€ he said.

They returned to the main living area. Elizabeth was still standing by the window, but Vering had shifted to drape himself on the arm of the couch, leaning sideways to put himself as close to her as he could get without getting up. Her embroidery lay abandoned on the coffee table.Â 

â€œWeâ€™re coming close to Geiersburgâ€™s range,â€ Yang said as he stepped back up towards Elizabeth.

â€œDo they know weâ€™re here?â€

â€œUnless someone sabotaged all of their sensors, yes, Iâ€™m sure that they do. Even with a small fleet, weâ€™re presenting a large enough face for them to detect. A single ship might slip by unseen at this distance, but not what looks like two thousand.â€

â€œWill they fire at us?â€

Yang was silent for a moment. â€œI hope not.â€

â€œWill I be able to see it, if they do?â€

â€œYou wonâ€™t see it coming,â€ Yang said. â€œItâ€™s a beam cannon, and light canâ€™t travel faster than itself for us to see it before it gets here. So the first youâ€™ll see is it hitting us.â€ His voice filled the silence of the room, just over the whirr of the air filters.Â 

â€œItâ€™s not visible light,â€ he continued. â€œGeiersburgâ€™s cannon is in ultraviolet. Any light you see will be from the things it hits. The metal of the ships will glow before theyâ€™re vaporized. This window should block out the brightest parts of it. Every window on a ship has to be able to shield out a whole starâ€™s worth of radiation. So you donâ€™t have to close your eyes.â€

She nodded, and stared out into space, at the distant dot of Geiersburg. Maybe they couldnâ€™t actually see it from here. Maybe that was just a dim star that Yang had pointed out by mistake.

Yang checked his watch, and gave a muttered countdown to the time when they would cross the threshold. The time of entering Geiersburgâ€™s range came and passed. The two seconds it would have taken for the beam to arrive ticked by with nothing to mark their going. The ships continued to slide under their momentum towards Geiersburg.

â€œAre we safe?â€ Vering asked from the couch, a tense three minutes of silence later.

Yang didnâ€™t answer the question. He suddenly felt just as helpless as he was sure Elizabeth did. He wanted to be back on the bridge, where he was sure that Braunschweig, now feeling like the worst of danger had passed, would be calling up Merkatz and demanding that all the ships turn back around and accelerate towards the fortress. Just wait a few more minutes, Yang thought. Please.

He had said that the fortress wouldnâ€™t bait them in, and he still thought that. But there was a chance that it wasnâ€™t baitâ€” that it was just taking longer to aim and fire than Yang had anticipated.Â 

The gravity engines of the ship were also what made the shipâ€™s acceleration impossible to feel from the inside, so Yang only saw the field of stars start to swing as the Berlin began turning. Ships turned slowly. Painfully slowly.

They were on the left flank, and the ship swung counterclockwise, momentarily aligning the aft-facing window with the rest of the fleet. Yang could see them all beginning to turn.

It was at that moment that a blinding light filled his entire field of view. Geiersburgâ€™s gun, finding its targetâ€” the ships in the center of their formation becoming little suns under the onslaught.Â 

It was silent. Yang didnâ€™t know why he felt like it should make a noise. There was no sound except the hum of their own ship, completely untouched. Yang, despite his own advice to Elizabeth, closed his eyes.

Elizabeth stumbled forward as if struck, and steadied herself with her hands splayed on the glass of the window. Behind Yang, Vering exclaimed, â€œWhat the fuck?!â€

As glow faded behind Yangâ€™s eyelids, he still took a moment before he opened them to survey the damage.

â€œThey canâ€™t fire again for ten minutes,â€ Yang said. â€œWe should be able to retreat.â€ Even as he said this, he could feel the subtle shift of gravity beneath his feet, signaling the Berlin â€™s engines fighting to dampen the feeling of acceleration as the ship hurried to move. The stars spun dizzyingly outside, and Yang only caught a glimpse of the gaping hole that had been left in their formation.

â€œDid you tell him that we shouldnâ€™t advance, Commodore?â€ Amarie asked from somewhere behind Yang. He felt dizzy. It was hard to pinpoint where her voice was coming from. Everything seemed to spinning and swirling around him.

â€œI did,â€ Yang said.

â€œHow many ships was that?â€ Elizabeth asked.

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Yang said. â€œI need to go to the bridge.â€

He stumbled past Elizabeth and ran out of the room.

Â 

Â 

Even though it was chaotic on the bridge, Yang was relieved beyond words to find out that Merkatz was still alive and was coordinating the retreat. The fleet was in disarray, which meant that it took too long to get all the ships moving again. It almost took the full ten minutes of Geiersburgâ€™s recharge time on its beam cannon, and, as they retreated, they were fired on again, a second shot that wiped out one of the straggling sections of their fleet. At least this time they kept moving out of range without needing to turn.

They finally made it well out of Geiersburgâ€™s firing distance, and then there was time to regroup. In all, they had only lost one hundred ships â€”a tenth of their fleetâ€” to Geiersburgâ€™s attack, due to how thinly they had been spread out. It was far less of a blow than they had any right to expect, but Yang couldnâ€™t feel happy about that loss of life. He felt guiltyâ€”he should have pushed harder for some alternate plan, one that didnâ€™t involve charging headlong into Geiersburgâ€™s range.

Once all the ships had been gathered, Merkatz temporarily left his flagship and came to the Berlin , where Yang met him at the shuttle bay. They talked as they walked down towards the wardroom to discuss their next steps.

â€œYou didnâ€™t give the order to turn around, did you, sir?â€ Yang asked.

â€œNo, I did not,â€ Merkatz said shortly. â€œDuke Braunschweig gave the order. I had planned to wait at least a half hour. Time was on our side before they fired on usâ€”we should have been patient.â€

â€œDoes the duke understand that countermanding your order cost us lives?â€

â€œYou would know that better than I.â€

Yang frowned. â€œYeah.â€

â€œYour plan is already in place,â€ Merkatz said. â€œThe asteroid will enter Geiersburgâ€™s range within the next three hours.â€

â€œCan you do me a favor, sir?â€

Merkatz raised one of his bushy eyebrows. â€œIt depends on what it is.â€

â€œDonâ€™t call it my plan,â€ Yang said.

Merkatz looked at him, then nodded.

They were at the door of the wardroom. Yang steeled himself, then followed Merkatz in.

The meeting to discuss the alternate plan was unpleasant. Flegel kept getting out of his seat and stomping back and forth across the front of the room, to deliver menacing statements about what he would do to those who had dared to fire on the true kaiserin. Braunschweig, though he was more subdued, nodded along, and let Flegel take command of the party that was going to board Geiersburg once they had gotten its doors open. Yang and Ansbachâ€™s eyes met across the table when this assignment was given, though Ansbach swiftly looked away.

Merkatz talked through Yangâ€™s plan without mentioning Yang, or the fact that he had put the plan into action the day before. Braunschweig nodded along to that, too.

â€œWe should give them the opportunity to surrender, and redirect the asteroid ourselves before it arrives,â€ Yang said. â€œIt would be better to not do any damage to Geiersburg if we can help it.â€

â€œIf they fire on it, we wonâ€™t be able to change its trajectory,â€ Ansbach said. â€œEven if the beam canâ€™t vaporize the entire rock, it will likely fry the communications arrays on the ships pushing it.â€

â€œThey wonâ€™t surrender,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œNot until theyâ€™ve tried firing on it.â€

This was probably true, but Yang didnâ€™t like it. â€œWe should warn them anyway.â€

â€œNo,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œThis is war, Leigh.â€

Yang couldnâ€™t reasonably object more, so he just slid back in his seat.

Â 

Â 

This time, Yang stayed on the bridge to watch the action. It was uniquely terrible to see the huge rock on the monitors, pushed by four empty ships, their engines flaring red. With the magnification up so high, the jutting, craggy rock was visible in a horrid clarity. As their cameras tracked it, filling the whole screen at the front of the bridge, it didnâ€™t even seem like it was movingâ€”the only indication of its motion were the specks of stars that flashed past the edge of the video feed. It was traveling far too fast for the human eye to follow, even if it had been close enough to see. It was maybe only a hundredth of Geiersburgâ€™s mass, probably even less, but it was dense, and that density would protect most of its mass from the beam. It was oblong, too, and the pushing ships were at the far end. The beam would have to eat through more than two kilometers of solid rock to completely vaporize it.

The bridge was a bustle of activity, with everybody looking up from their own stations and consoles to watch the rock speed towards the fortress.

â€œThey can see it, right?â€ Flegel asked as the rock crossed the threshold. â€œThey know itâ€™s there?â€

â€œUnless their sensors arenâ€™t working right,â€ Ansbach said.

He neednâ€™t have asked: moments later, the fortress fired. They didnâ€™t see the beam, but they saw its effect on the rock in their magnified view: its front end glowed like it was falling through an atmosphere, and it warped and bubbled, some of it vaporizing, other parts of it just turning into rolling liquid, some of which was pushed back along the rock by the force of the expanding gas. The whole rock was now so hot that what was liquid took a long time to re-solidify.

â€œWeâ€™ve lost contact with the shipsâ€™ radios,â€ the man in charge of monitoring the ships pushing the rock said. The rock was no longer accelerating. Presumably, the heat had been so much that it had destroyed the ships, even if they had been shielded from the blast itself.

After watching the first shot, the whole bridge fell silent. The chatter ceased.

â€œItâ€™s at the halfway point,â€ someone announced a few minutes later.

The fortress, as soon as its main gun was charged, fired again. It had just as little impact as it had the first time, though now those waiting outside of its range didnâ€™t have eyes on the front of the rock, only the rear as it sped away from them. The rear was untouched, though lit by an unnatural glow from the other end.

â€œOh, come on,â€ Yang said under his breath. â€œPlease.â€

He clenched his fists in his pockets. Now the camera was trained on Geiersburg. Yang hoped desperately that those in the fortress would realize what they had to do in time to actually do it. The rock was on a course to only graze the fortress, so all they had to do was nudge it a tiny, tiny bit, to make it sail harmlessly by. It would only take a few ships throwing themselves at it to move the rock enough.

At three minutes before impact, on their magnified view, they saw ships emerge from Geiersburg. First a few, then a swarm, then more and more. Perhaps a general evacuation order had been given, or perhaps everyone had decided that imminent destruction was enough to make them disobey orders and leave.

In the chaos of all the ships rising at once and fleeing from the fortress, two broke off from the crowd and sped towards the rock. They were tiny in comparison to it, like minnows beside a whale, but their engines flashed white hot, and they crashed into it with as much force as they could produce. Yang hoped that there hadnâ€™t been any crew on those ships, but he doubted it.

It was enough, though barely.

The rock screamed towards Geiersburg and brushed the edge of its liquid metal shell. The force of that impact on the liquid metal vaporized some, and sent other wild spinning droplets glittering and careening off into space. The fortress itself shook, the perfect spherical bubble warping and vibrating and beginning to spin. Even just that tiny touch seemed to be structurally devastating to the fortressâ€™ outer shell, but if it had hit completely, the fortress would have ceased to exist.

Now, in the space around the fortress, a chaotic scrum was breaking out between Braunschweigâ€™s troops, many in number, and the fortressâ€™s neutral guard. It was too messy to be called a battle, since there seemed to be no commander on either side giving orders. It was ship against ship, no one in any formation, as they all tried to dodge the ship-sized globs of liquid metal that were flying off the fortress.Â 

Merkatz ordered Braunschweigâ€™s fleet to advance at top speed. Now that the space around the fortress was surrounded by this fracas, and the fortress itself was in complete disarray, there was no chance that the main gun would go off again.Â 

By the time that their fleet had made it to the space around the fortress, the liquid metal shell had stopped writing quite so much, but Braunschweigâ€™s allied forces had won the day, and they let Braunschweigâ€™s ships through. They sailed past a field of debrisâ€” wrecked ships, dead ships, globs of liquid metal like huge funhouse mirrors. They reflected the carnage and Braunschweigâ€™s ship alike, distorting the view and making it appear like there were twice as many vessels in the area, peeking out past micro black holes that bent the light.

Their ships descended into Geiersburgâ€™s bays. Even though the liquid metal appeared smoother on the surface, as they sunk down through it, their ships were pushed to and fro.

When they docked, they could see the evidence of the damage that even the glancing blow from the rock had dealt. Some of the ships that had not managed to launch in time had been knocked hard into the walls of the fortress.Â 

Yang had not been ordered to leave the ship and board the fortress, so he didnâ€™t. Braunschweig did, along with Flegel and Ansbach and Hans von Vering. Flegel charged out at the head of a pack of armored soldiers, and Braunschweig walked calmly behind, surrounded by his own guard. Yang watched them go, until they left the view from the Berlin â€™s monitors, and then he closed his eyes and leaned back in his chair on the bridge.

They had won the day, and cost had not been too steepâ€” though any cost tended to weigh heavily on Yang. Their losses had been more than recouped by winning Geiersburg, and the fortress itself wasnâ€™t too damaged by Yangâ€™s plan. Although it looked bad, it didnâ€™t seem in danger of imminent collapse, which meant that the damage could and would be repaired. He listened to the radio chatter, hearing the occasional staticky sound of Merkatzâ€™s voice as he ordered the cleanup and organization to begin.

Yangâ€™s even breathing and trying to force himself to relaxâ€” he had made it through the day whole and aliveâ€” almost put him to sleep. But then he heard an unexpected voice say his name, cutting through his mental haze.

Startled, he jerked up, and found himself face to face with Elizabeth, who had made it onto the bridge. Perhaps all the junior staff who remained onboard had not felt like contradicting her when she asked to be allowed in, even if it was completely against the usual decorum.Â 

â€œSleeping on duty, Commodoreâ€, she asked. â€œI should reconsider your paycheck.â€

â€œYou can dock my pay for sleeping if you want, Your Majesty,â€ Yang said as he hastened to stand. â€œBut I donâ€™t think it will make much difference,â€ he added with a yawn.

â€œPerhaps.â€

â€œDoes your mother know youâ€™re wandering through the ship?â€ he aksed.

â€œSheâ€™s sleeping.â€

â€œIâ€™m jealous,â€ Yang said, which made Elizabeth smile despite herself. â€œWas there something you needed, Your Majesty?â€

â€œNo,â€ she said. She wandered a few steps away from Yang, tracing her hands along the consoles. â€œI just thought Iâ€™d like to see whatâ€™s here, while no one who will say no to a woman being on the bridge is around.â€

â€œLook all you like,â€ Yang said. â€œItâ€™s not particularly exciting.â€

â€œPerhaps,â€ she said again. Whenever she wandered over to one of the operator stations, the man at it got up uncomfortably and let her sit down at the chair. She was very careful not to push any of the buttons, but she read the labels and looked at the displays with her trademark detached curiosity. For some reason, Yang got the impression that she was killing time.

â€œWhat are you doing here, Your Majesty?â€ he asked, as she circled back around the first console she had looked at and started examining it again.

â€œMy father said that he had a gift for me, and he said heâ€™d give it to me when I step into Geiersburg,â€ she said.

â€œReally?â€ Yang asked. â€œAnd what type of gift is it?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know. I would like to answer that question myself.â€

â€œAnd you think that waiting here will get you the answer sooner than being in your quarters?â€

She gave him a sidelong look. â€œCommodore, are you trying to get rid of me?â€

â€œYour mother will accuse me of overstepping my bounds by letting you stay here.â€

â€œIâ€™ll tell her I demanded it.â€

Yang laughed. â€œOf course, Your Majesty.â€

This only made Elizabeth scowl. â€œTell me to leave, then,â€ she said.

Yang said nothing, and so Elizabeth remained on the bridge, though she stopped feigning interest in the operator stations and instead sat down in the chair at the center of the command dais. Every soldier who walked into the bridge did a double take to see the small teenager sitting there as regally as anything. She didnâ€™t speak to Yang much, but she listened to the radio chatter for about forty minutes, and sipped a cup of tea that someone brought her. Yang was jealous of that, too. He wondered when she would give up on waiting for her father to call her in.

He shouldnâ€™t have doubted Elizabethâ€™s patience, however, because the call did come. Ansbachâ€™s voice came over the radio. â€œAnsbach to the Berlin ,â€ he said. â€œWho is on the bridge?â€

â€œLeigh here,â€ Yang said, answering the radio.

â€œOh,â€ Ansbach said. â€œPlease tell me that Her Majesty is asleep right now.â€ Yang could tell exactly what that tone of voice meant from Ansbach. Even if Elizabeth was not asleep, he was supposed to lie.

â€œSheâ€™sâ€”â€

â€œIâ€™m right here, Commodore,â€ Elizabeth said, coming up behind Yang and taking the radio mic from his hand. â€œIs my father asking for me?â€

There was a painful moment of hissing silence over the radio. Finally, Ansbach said, â€œYes, he is, Your Majesty. He wants you in Geiersburgâ€™s reception hall.â€

â€œOh, excellent,â€ she said, sounding almost genuinely cheerful. â€œIâ€™ll come straight away.â€ She pressed the mic back into Yangâ€™s outstretched hand.

â€œLeigh here. Is there an escort ready or do I have to find one?â€

â€œIâ€™ll have guards meet you at the bay. You go with her.â€

â€œMe? Why me?â€ The heavy silence from the other side was enough to make Yang sigh and say, â€œFine. Weâ€™ll be there in about a half an hour. Can you tell me what sheâ€™s needed for?â€

â€œNo,â€ Ansbach said. â€œI have no idea.â€

So Yang escorted Elizabeth out of the Berlin , met up with the contingent of heavily armed soldiers, and walked with her through the eerily silent corridors of Geiersburg fortress. She spent the whole walk looking around intently. Yang figured she was probably trying to assess the damage, and what fights had taken place in these halls, but he wasnâ€™t sure how much she could learn from that observation. They didnâ€™t meet a single soul on their way to the reception hall, until there were a gaggle of similarly armed soldiers outside, who let them all in.

The reception hall was empty and large, with a small throneâ€” or something that approached a throneâ€” down at the far end, past a long red carpet. It was meant to mimic the halls of Neue Sanssouci, and it seemed truly ostentatious for a military fortress, but it was presumably a feature that the Braunschweig family had added during the fortressâ€™s construction, so that when nobility came to visit, they had a suitably splendid place to hold parties. The duke was sitting on the throne, but when his daughter came in, he stood and held out his arms.

â€œElizabeth, my darling,â€ he said. Yang never heard him so warm in greeting his daughter before, but he was in a strange mood, it seemed, riding the high of conquering the fortress.Â 

Elizabeth trotted away from Yang up to her father, her yellow dress fluttering as she went.Â 

Yang got out of the way, and went to stand near the wall, waiting with the other soldiers. Curiously, there was no sign of Ansbach, Flegel, or Vering.Â 

â€œI see youâ€™ve conquered the fortress for me,â€ she said with a smile. Her attitude was totally different now, too, matching what she thought her father might want from her. â€œIs this your gift?â€ She let her father embrace her, though even with Braunschweigâ€™s cheer, it was a somewhat unnatural looking hug.

Her father laughed. â€œWell, part of it. Come here.â€ He ushered her to sit down on the throne, then gestured for one of the soldiers who was standing by the wall to bring over a wooden box that he was carrying. Braunschweig opened the box and revealed a crownâ€” not the huge ceremonial one that Kaiser Friedrich had worn in pictures, of course, but a crown nonetheless. It was gold, with sparkling red stones nestled in a floral filigree.Â  He held it up, and Elizabeth smiled at it as he placed it on her head. She touched it with two fingers.

â€œIâ€™m afraid it will be a little while yet before we can crown you in Neue Sansouci,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œBut this will do for now.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s beautiful.â€

â€œItâ€™s very fitting for you. Iâ€™ve been waiting for this moment for a long time. Are you ready for people to bow to you as kaiserin?â€

She smiled, but didnâ€™t answer the question. Yang thought Braunschweig was asking in hypotheticals, but then he gave a signal to some of the soldiers at the far end of the room. â€œBring them in,â€ he said loudly.

The doors swung open, and Ansbach stepped into the room first and gave a deep bow to Elizabeth sitting on the throne. â€œYour Majesty,â€ he said. â€œThe prisoners.â€

And in through the door, at gunpoint, came soldiers who had been captured while taking the fortress. These were the imperial troops, those who didnâ€™t belong to Braunschweig, who had resisted the invasion and lived. Some were wounded, though they all could walk. They shuffled into a few miserable looking rows, enlisted men and officers together.

â€œYou are the lucky few!â€ Braunschweig called out over the assembled as soon as the shuffling had stopped. â€œThe first to greet your new kaiserin!â€

There was dead silence from the crowd.

â€œHer Majesty is very forgiving,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œEven though you fired upon her person, and failed to welcome her with the honors that she is due, she has no desire to waste your lives. She wishes that all of you remain her loyal subjects.â€ He glanced back at Elizabeth, who was sitting stiff and silent on the throne. If he took her expression under consideration at all, it didnâ€™t seem to reflect in the contents of his speech.

â€œIf you bow today, and swear your loyalty, and join my fleet, you will live,â€ he said. â€œIf you fail to do so, you will be killed, to serve as an example for anyone else who thinks that they should refuse to bow to the rightful heir to the throne.â€

Yang couldnâ€™t help but speak up. â€œSirâ€” you canâ€™t kill prisoners of war! Thatâ€™sâ€”â€

Braunschweig turned to face him, realizing he was there for the first time. â€œIf I wanted your opinion, Leigh, I would have asked for it.â€

Yang glanced at Elizabeth, but she was staring ahead of herself at the assembled crowd with a completely inscrutable expression on her face. Her lips were slightly parted, and her breathing was heavy enough that Yang could see the rise and fall of her chest.

Ansbach pointed to the nearest man in the front row of conquered soldiers. â€œYou. Kneel and say youâ€™ll serve Her Majesty.â€

The soldier looked around nervously, first at the men next to him, then at the cold glare of Duke Braunschweig and the others.Â 

â€œNow,â€ Ansbach said.

The soldier stumbled forward out of his line, and knelt before Elizabeth. â€œI serveâ€” Kaiserin Elizabethâ€”â€ he said haltingly.

â€œGood,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œGet up.â€Â 

The man did, and was shuffled away into a different room by some of Brauschweigâ€™s guards.

This process was repeated another ten or so times, enough for the first row of captives, all enlisted men, to be cleared. Elizabeth didnâ€™t say a word during this process, and just looked on with that strange gaze. When the first officer, a captain, was pulled out of line, Yang suddenly knew that something was going to go wrong.Â 

Yang watched as the captain was pulled in front of Elizabeth. He refused to bow, so Braunschweigâ€™s soldiers tried to force him to his knees. Braunschweig held them off, raising his hand.

â€œIf he doesnâ€™t want to bow, then he can serve as an example for the rest,â€ Braunschweig said. He took out his sidearm, checked it over like it was a dueling pistol. â€œAre you sure you donâ€™t want to pledge to serve the true kaiserin?â€ he asked.

â€œYou think Iâ€™m the traitor?â€ the captain asked. â€œYou donâ€™t have any claimâ€”â€

â€œWell,â€ Braunschweig said, and raised his gun. â€œIf thatâ€™s the way you feel.â€

Although Yang fixed his eyes on Elizabeth, who watched the scene with her lips slightly parted, and her hands clutching the armrests of her small throne, he could still see as Braunschweig pulled the trigger, and the man toppled to the ground at Elizabethâ€™s feet, staining the carpet with blood, and spraying the captive soldiers behind him with flecks of hot gore.

â€œGet this out of here,â€ Braunschweig said, and two of his men hastened to comply, dragging the corpse away.

â€œYou,â€ Ansbach said, and pointed at the next soldier in line. â€œKneel.â€

The soldier did, falling quickly to knees before the throne, staining his hands and pants with blood.

Chapter End Notes

it's my birthday :3 so i will give you a chapter

it's fun to try to come up with solutions to problems that seem a) like something that would happen in logh, b) something that yang would think of, and c) don't make my engineer instincts scream in horror at how little the numbers make sense. anyway yang's patented solution to so many things is "chuck a big rock at it" so i feel justified in continuing to chuck rocks at things lol.

Elizabeth has just gotten signed up for "trauma tuesdays". sorry elizabeth!

the chess game that braunschweig/flegel and ansbach play is based on the opera game, which is very famous. included here by request ;)

it is time for everyone to start killing each other with beams. we can see some of the cracks in the braunschweig camp already. this is not going to be pretty for anyone.

thank you very very much to em for the beta read as always

hey did you read The Destruction of the Second Temple? It's my "it's time to talk about the earth church plot" fic. I personally think it's really good and you should check it out if you haven't :^) let me know what you think!

[i'd love to hear what you think of this chapter too of course lol]

you can find me in the normal places: gayspaceopera.carrd.co , javert @ tumblr , natsinator @ twitter , and join my discord https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

The Master of the House Does Not Know the Hour When the Thief Is Coming

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

October 488 I.C., Odin

If one looked at the capital from above, it wasnâ€™t immediately obvious that anything had changed over the few weeks since the Kaiser died. There had been no fighting in the street, no bombs dropped on the city, no tanks trundling down the roads to enforce a brutal new regime. Even coming closer, down at the level of the buildings, one might have been forgiven for thinking that there was nothing amiss. There had been no cancellation of the normal workings of society. People still went to school and to their jobs. The temple bells still tolled out every hour.

Everyday life went on. Almost.

The capital was emptier than normal. When Kircheis walked past the formerly lively downtown district, especially the upscale areas where people with â€˜vonsâ€™ in their names attended private clubs, he found the streets nearly deserted, and the music that had once drifted out in faint strains at night was silenced. Luxury goods stores were closed, and their windows were blocked up with plywood covered in cheerful looking posters, proclaiming that there was construction ongoing inside and that they would reopen soon. This was a lie.

The further one walked from the richer areas of the city, the livelier it became, because the average middle class citizen of the capital had no ability to pack up their entire life and head for either the countryside or another planet entirely. They were forced to remain, no matter what was coming.Â 

Store shelves were sparser than usual, though it was hard to tell if this was panic buying on the part of those who remained in the city, or the first ripples of the supply chain being shaken by civil war. Kircheis wasnâ€™t worried about food right now, but he was on an errand from Hilde, clutching a prescription in his hand, and searching four different pharmacies for anyone who could fill it. He was dressed inconspicuously in civilian clothes, and if anyone wondered why a man his age was not in the fleet, the question would have been answered well enough by the prescription for seizure medication he brought up to the pharmacy counters.

This last pharmacy he visited did seem to have the medicine in stock, and he waited by the counter, listening to the store music and counting the other customers who came in.

The pharmacist handed him the bottle of pills, and Kircheis asked, â€œDo you know if youâ€™re going to have more of these, when I need to pick them up again next month?â€

The pharmacist gave him a pitying expression. â€œNo, I do not.â€

Kircheis looked at the bottle. â€œThese arenâ€™t from Phezzan, are they?â€

â€œIf we can get the Phezzani version of them, we might have more later. These are local.â€Â 

â€œThen whatâ€™s the issue with supply?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ the pharmacist said. â€œCall when you run out. Iâ€™ll tell you if weâ€™ve been able to switch suppliers.â€

â€œThank you, sir,â€ Kircheis said.

Outside, he examined the pills further, and looked up the manufacturer. O-Line Pharmaceuticals was the name, but the subtitle only became obvious when he visited the website: a Vering Industries subsidiary, with its manufacturing center right on Odin. That explained it.

The businesses which Count Vering hadnâ€™t been able to relocate off Odin before the Kaiser died had all been shut downâ€” some of the Vering family scionâ€™s own volition, the rest shuttered byâ€¦ someone. It wasnâ€™t entirely clear to Kircheis who was giving the orders.

It seemed a little unlikely that Lichtenlade, who had pronounced the young Erwin Josef to be Kaiser and was ruling as his regent, would have any interest in closing down pharmaceutical plants, since that would only lead to more instability in the capital, which Lichtenlade was desperately trying to avoid. But the force had come from somewhere, and the only other explanation was the part of the military on Odin that was operating as a shadow force for the Littenheim clanâ€” the MPs, and their secretive, uncontrolled hierarchy.Â 

It would be simple enough to drag away all the owners and management of a factory, keep them in hidden jails or kill them outright, and lock the factory doors. The military police had plenty of experience doing so even during times when they were directly working for the Imperial government. They wouldnâ€™t need to go as far as bombing the factoriesâ€” this was just about sending a message and consolidating power.

Kircheis slipped the bottle of pills into his messenger bag, and then took the subway to the outskirts of the city, a long train ride. He watched the other passengers get on and off, and mentally compared the number to how many there used to be.

At the last stop on the line, Kircheis got off and found the car in the parking lot that had been left for his use. It belonged to the Mariendorf family, but it was a beat up old pickup truck that was used for hauling landscaping equipment, so it was quite unremarkable, and Kircheis didnâ€™t expect any trouble while driving it.

He would have been making the three hour drive south into the countryside to see Hilde anyway, but it was convenient that he could do her a favor by searching the city pharmacies.Â 

The medicine wasnâ€™t for Hilde, but for her cousin, Baron Kummel, with whom she was staying, along with the Baroness of Westpfale. (Magdalena had changed her name after getting married, but it was still easier in Kircheisâ€™s mind to think of her as the baroness, rather than Countess von Leigh.) Since Baron Kummel had a second estate far out in the countryside, he had offered to let them both stay there and away from trouble. The trouble must have included Magdalenaâ€™s mother, since she had left her own country estate to join the baron, though he probably just enjoyed the company.

As Kircheis drove, the city gave way to suburbs, then forest, then interspersed farmland. It was a bright day out. The leaves on the trees were past their peak of color, and were shaking loose to expose bare branches, coating the ground with brown mats of leaf litter. He didnâ€™t mind the long drive. Out in the country, he could almost forget how strange and tense the city felt, and he was looking forward to seeing Hilde again. He had come up to visit before, but things had been so chaotic for the remains of Braunschweigâ€™s staff on the planet in the days right after the Kaiser died that Kircheis hadnâ€™t stayed long. He hoped to get a chance to speak with Hilde seriouslyâ€” now that the first blows of the war had been exchanged.

Baron Kummelâ€™s country estate was nearer to one of the forested areas than the farmed ones, and Kircheis had to drive up a long, ill-maintained path to get to it, the pickup truck bumping along over the ruts in the road. The building itself was beautiful, but it looked like it hadnâ€™t been used in many years prior to the civil war. So, while the house wasnâ€™t in ill-repair exactly, the landscaping had gone half-wild, and the roof could use new tiles. It just wasnâ€™t at the level of polish that Kircheis had come to expect from noble houses. Still, it was pretty, nestled in among the autumn leaves, and Kircheis was grateful to the baron for allowing Hilde and Magdalena to stay there.

He parked the pickup in the wide circular turn-around in front of the house, and didnâ€™t bother ringing the doorbell, just walked inside. There were a few servants who would have answered the door, but Kircheis always felt odd about them, and he knew the door was likely unlocked.

Inside, the house was quiet. The lights werenâ€™t on, so all the light in the massive foyer was coming in through the tall windows, filtered a warm red and yellow by the leaves outside. Kircheis headed for the library, where he knew Hilde often spent her days, but she wasnâ€™t there. He happened to glance out the library window, though, and saw her outside, sitting on a lawn chair in the paved courtyard, next to the baron in his electric wheelchair.

He made his way outside, and Hilde looked over when she heard the creaking of the door opening, and her face broke into a magnificent smile when she saw Kircheis. â€œSieg,â€ she said. â€œWelcome back!â€

The baron rolled his head to look at him, too. â€œHello, Herr Kircheis.â€

Kircheis inclined his head in greeting. â€œBaron, Fraulein.â€

â€œPlease, take a seat,â€ the baron said. He lifted his arm to gesture at one of the other lawn chairs, but this revealed how frail and weak he was. Although he was not more than a few years older than Hilde, his hair was pure white, and his skin was so paper-thin that the blue of veins was visible even up into his face.

Kircheis sat, and Hilde handed him one of the blankets that she was wrapped in, since it was chilly out. Kircheis put his bag on the floor and accepted it gratefully, pulling the quilt around his shoulders. It was a nice day, but cold enough that he was surprised that someone in as ill health as the baron would want to be out in it.

â€œHow was the ride up?â€ Hilde asked.

â€œIt was fine,â€ Kircheis said. â€œLong, but there wasnâ€™t any trouble on the road.â€

â€œYouâ€™re staying the night, right?â€

â€œIf youâ€™ll have me.â€ The answer was, of course, yes, so he smiled as he said it. â€œI was able to find your medicine, by the way, Baron.â€

â€œOh, you shouldnâ€™t have gone to the trouble,â€ he said. â€œI hope it wasnâ€™t too difficult.â€

â€œNo trouble at all.â€ He pulled the bottle of pills from his messenger bag and set them on the patio table. â€œThough I think thatâ€™s the last of it, unless there are Phezzani imports on the way.â€

Hilde looked at the bottle forlornly. â€œWill you be alright if you run out, Heinrich?â€

He didnâ€™t answer the question, and just lay back on his chair to look up at the blue sky peeking through the leaves of the trees above. â€œIf it is willed that I have more, then I will have more,â€ he said. â€œIt isnâ€™t important either way.â€

Kircheis glanced at Hilde with some concern, and she gave a sad little smile back.Â 

â€œWell, if there is anything else I can get for you in the capital, Baron, please do let me know.â€

â€œThank you, Herr Kircheis.â€ There was a moment of silence. â€œHow has the city been?â€

â€œNot too bad,â€ Kircheis said. â€œIt feels like everyone is just waiting for the other shoe to drop.â€

â€œHave they evacuated the National Galleries yet?â€

â€œTheyâ€™re still open. I havenâ€™t gone in to look at whatâ€™s on display.â€

â€œI hope they put everything in vaults,â€ Kummel said. â€œI would likeâ€”â€ Whatever he was about to say was interrupted by a coughing fit that wracked his whole body. Hilde leaned towards him, but there was no comfort or help she could provide, so they all simply waited until it was over, and Kummel lay back, wheezing and catching his shallow breath. He didnâ€™t seem like he wanted to continue his previous thought.

â€œHave you heard any news?â€ Hilde asked, when there seemed to be no more immediate danger from the baron.

â€œGeiersburg fortress was captured,â€ Kircheis said. â€œThat was where Commodore Leigh said heâ€™d go first, so thatâ€™s good.â€

â€œDo you know any of the details?â€ she asked. She kept her voice steady, though Kircheis knew she was worried.

â€œNo, other than that the Imperial forces lost it, and very few of the Imperial ships there were able to escape. If anything bad had happened to Braunschweigâ€™s ship, I would have heard. So Iâ€™m sure the Braunschweig family is alrightâ€” and Commodore Leigh and your father.â€

â€œGood,â€ Hilde said.

â€œI expect that Kaiserin Elizabeth is going to stay in the fortress, since itâ€™s the most easily defensible place, but Braunschweig and his fleet will head back to Odin as soon as theyâ€™re settled and have supply lines in place. I donâ€™t know how long thatâ€™s going to take, but the faster the better.â€

â€œIs my father still going to coordinate getting supplies?â€Â 

Count Mariendorf was supposed to interface with minor nobility, and convince them to sell supplies from their home planetsâ€™ farms and factories directly to Braunschweig, to keep him supplied. Convincing people to do this would be a difficult task, as would logistically ensuring the supplies that were available actually made it to Braunschweigâ€™s forces. Braunschweig had enough supplies to last him a few months, but he couldnâ€™t count on his home territories to arm and feed his entire army in perpetuity, especially not if those lands came under attack, or if he had the routes between his homelands and his fleet blockaded.

â€œHe is, unless plans have changed,â€ Kircheis said.

She nodded. â€œHave you heard anything about Littenheim?â€

â€œNo, not yet. Itâ€™s going to take a while for him to gather his troops, and when he does, heâ€™ll come to Odin. He probably wonâ€™t have to engage with the Imperial fleet before then, and news about the Imperial fleet is all Iâ€™m able to get right now,â€ Kircheis said. â€œNo,â€ the baron said. â€œCount Landsberg said he would come for dinner if she brought him.â€

Â 

Magdalena did indeed haul Count Landsberg to the baronâ€™s residence for dinner. The count was a man who gave Kircheis an unpleasant sensation of looking at a warped version of Martin. Â 

Kircheis didnâ€™t return to the city until the afternoon of the next day, and when he got back to his apartment, he had the sense that something was off before he even opened the door. He didnâ€™t know what gave him that impressionâ€” perhaps it was just the fact that he had been on high alert ever since he had entered the city limits and dropped off his borrowed car in its designated space. After spending so much companionable time out in the countryside, and the silent and lonely drive back, the glances of the other passengers on the subway seemed suspicious and hostile, and none of Kircheisâ€™s small polite smiles assuaged the feeling. The ominous feeling mounted until Kircheis went to open his door and found it already unlocked, swinging open beneath his hand.Â 

He wished, for the first time in his life, that he was carrying the sidearm that Commodore Leigh had given to him, but that was locked away in his safe inside the apartment.

If there was an intruder still inside, they most certainly had heard the clicking of the handle as Kircheis fumbled with his keys and tried the door, so he couldnâ€™t very well try an alternate method of entryâ€” going around to the side of the building and climbing up the fire escape. So, he went in.

There, sitting at his kitchen table, was Rear Admiral Bronner. His hands were folded on a binder in front of him, and on the center of the table was the spare key to Kircheisâ€™s apartment, the one that he kept taped inside his mailbox.

â€œLieutenant,â€ Bronner said, smiling at him with his sickly smile, â€œitâ€™s such a pleasure to see you again.â€

This probably wasnâ€™t immediately dangerous, though it certainly was dangerous in a more abstract way. Without making any expression, Kirchies silently closed the door behind himself. â€œWhat are you doing in my house, Rear Admiral?â€

â€œYou should be more careful about where you leave your spare key,â€ Bronner said. â€œItâ€™s not very secure to put it in a place associated with yourself. Hardly any better than putting it under the doormat, or above the lintel.â€

â€œDid you check there, first?â€

â€œOf course.â€ Bronner kept smiling. â€œPlease, take a seat. I have something I need to speak with you about.â€

â€œThen why are you here?â€

â€œJust because Leigh doesnâ€™t trust me doesnâ€™t mean that Iâ€™m not still interested in him, and you by extension.â€ He slid the binder across the scratched kitchen table to Kircheis, who did not open it until Bronner pointedly stared at it. With some trepidation, Kircheis flipped open the cover. The first few pages of the binder were taken up by the text of the play shown on the cover, like Bronner was pretending to be a director, but as Kircheis flipped through, he found, to his horrorâ€” though not surpriseâ€” page after page of information about Martin nestled in among the innocent pages of the play There were marked locations on a map of the nearby areas, and photographs of Martin taken with a zoom lens, and bank records, and logs of people coming and going, and lists of names that Kircheis didnâ€™t recognize.

â€œYour friend Martin is extremely lucky that most people who would ordinarily care to stop little would-be revolutionaries are all occupied with factional problems,â€ Bronner said as Kircheis leafed through the binder. â€œI donâ€™t know what you want from me, if you already have all of this information,â€ Kircheis said. â€œIt seems like if you want to arrest Martin, you could just do it.â€

â€œWhat makes you think I bear your friend any ill-will whatsoever?â€

â€œIf you were a republican, Commodore Leigh probably would have told me.â€

Bronner laughedâ€” a thin, unpleasant, nasally sound. â€œOf course Iâ€™m not a republican.â€

â€œWhat do you want?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œI want this country to continue to exist,â€ Bronner said. â€œI donâ€™t particularly care how that gets accomplished, but I have no desire to see Neue Sanssouci bombed by little homegrown terrorists when no oneâ€™s paying attention to them.â€

â€œThe country is not Neue Sanssouci,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œNor is the country the Kaiser,â€ Bronner said with a thin smile. â€œBut letâ€™s not get ahead of ourselves. The symbols are important, and if everyone starts to realize that the people in charge are just people playing the roles given to them on the stages set up for them, weâ€™ll have more problems on our hands than two noble families at each othersâ€™ throats, especially if people happen to realize that right now.â€

Kircheis was silent.

â€œWhat, am I giving Herr Bufholtz and his ilk more credit than you would even give them? Thatâ€™s what they intend to do, isnâ€™t it? Make it clear that all of the people, all across the land, donâ€™t have to bow to some child whose father claims the throne is theirs?â€

â€œDo you think theyâ€™ll succeed?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œItâ€™s a good story,â€ Bronner said. â€œIt would make an excellent scene in a play, if the director was doing a good job. It might stir the audience.â€ He cocked his head. â€œSometimes, a story is what you need.â€

â€œStop telling me riddles,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œIâ€™m not.â€

â€œThen what are you saying? Are you going to arrest Martin or not?â€

â€œThatâ€™s not really in my wheelhouse,â€ Bronner said with a smile. â€œI work in the basement of the Ministry of War. Your friend isnâ€™t even remotely on my departmentâ€™s radar. I only care about members of the fleet.â€

Kircheis stared at him.

â€œWhat do you want?â€ Kircheis asked again.

â€œThen leave him alone.â€

Â â€œâ€”but I also have no desire to allow him to turn the capitol into a pillar of flame.â€ He steepled his hands over the binder. â€œThis all can be taken care of in a way that would satisfy Commodore Leigh.â€

â€œI doubt it.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t say it would satisfy you .â€

â€œWhat do you think Commodore Leigh wants?â€

â€œAs little loss of life as possible,â€ Bronner said, and this time, his tone was severe, and he had lost his thin smile. â€œThat is all he has ever cared about. He would sacrifice his own life, and he would sacrifice your life, or my life, or Herr Bufholtzâ€™s, if that was what it took to stop a real massacre, which is what your friend wants to provoke. â€œYes, sir,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œI do not always agree with the commodore, but I have always understood him very well.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think heâ€™d want you to interfere.â€

â€œIâ€™m not going to interfere,â€ Bronner said, and his voice was back to its usual slimy cadence. â€œBut you are.â€

Kircheis could hear his own heartbeat. â€œWhat are you saying?â€

â€œYou, lieutenant, are going to use all of your skills, which I know you possess, and you are going to act. You are going to play the role of Herr Bufholtzâ€™s friend. You are going to find out the day and the hour that he plans to make his move. And then you will tell me.â€

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œNo?â€ Bronner asked. â€œI donâ€™t think you have a choice, lieutenant.â€

â€œIâ€™m not going to betray him. I donâ€™t know what kind of man you think I am, but Iâ€™m not that one.â€

Bronner leaned back in his seat. â€œIâ€™m not asking you to betray him. Iâ€™m asking you to help him. I can make it so that when the day comes, he can be spared.â€

â€œYouâ€™re lying.â€

â€œIâ€™m not.â€ Perhaps Bronner really was as good of an actor as he claimed to be. There was something in his voice, serious and calm, having lost his usual brittle smile, that made Kircheis almost believe him.

But it didnâ€™t matter if Kircheis believed him or not. Even if Martin were somehow capable of being saved, that would be the last thing that Martin would want. Though that didnâ€™t stop Kircheis from wanting it.

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said again. He wondered if there was a little less conviction in his voice this time.

They stared at each other silently across the table for a moment.Â 

â€œVery well,â€ Bronner finally said. He picked up his binder and stood. â€œIâ€™m sure you will go warn your friend that heâ€™s under watch: fine. It wonâ€™t make any difference. Youâ€™ll come home, and until this is all over, youâ€™ll spend every waking moment thinking if this is the day that someone with the authority has been convinced to waste their time, and go raid the headquarters of a student group. It will be a waste of their timeâ€” and to save it, theyâ€™ll just shoot everyone there. You probably wonâ€™t even hear about it until you go back there, and you donâ€™t find the bodies, but you find the bloodstains. And youâ€™ll wonder if Herr Bufholtz survived, and youâ€™ll look for him, but in your heart, youâ€™ll know he didnâ€™t. And youâ€™ll spend the rest of your life wondering if you could have done anything to stop it. Iâ€™m telling you now: you could. But you wonâ€™t, because youâ€™re not that kind of man.â€

â€œHow long did you practice that speech, sir?â€ Kircheis asked.

Bronner snorted like a bull. â€œTen minutes, in the bathroom mirror. Pity it didnâ€™t change your mind.â€

Bronner flipped open the binder and neatly extracted one page, the one with the maps. The binderâ€™s rings clacked open and shut. He held the sheet out to Kircheis, who didnâ€™t take it. He wiggled the paper at him.

â€œIâ€™m assuming you donâ€™t already know where your friend is hiding, since I havenâ€™t seen you go there. Here. Take it. Meeting him there will prove that your warning about him being watched is sincere.â€

Kircheis took the map.

â€œAnd if you change your mind, you know how to contact me,â€ Bronner said. â€œI sincerely hope you do.â€

Bronner started to go for the door.

â€œRear Admiralâ€”â€ Kircheis said.

â€œYes?â€

â€œAre you going to make this offer to anyone else?â€

â€œTo little Lady Mariendorf, you mean?â€ Bronner asked. â€œWhy, is she more likely to agree with me?â€ He smirked, and then was gone out the door. Belatedly, Kircheis realized that he had stolen his spare key.

Â 

Â 

The day that Kircheis went to visit Martin was cold and bright. The trees had lost all of their leaves, and the branches stood out in thin, whip-like lines across the cloudless blue sky. Martinâ€™s hiding place was way off in the suburbs, in a town that was eerily like the one he and Kircheis had grown up in. The house was normal, tooâ€” a two story building with sage green siding, near the far end of a dead-end road, sitting on a well kept lawn. Kircheis wondered whose family member had died and left it vacant, since it didnâ€™t seem like the kind of place that a rebel group would choose as a base. The houseâ€™s property was woody in the back, and it edged up against a forest that belonged to the town, one with a plethora of walking trails. In the aerial view that Bronner had provided, Kircheis could see one of these slim paths branching off from the main trail and heading towards the back of the house. He suspected that many of the members of the group were instructed to approach from that direction if they were coming, since the neighbors would likely find it odd to have a rotating cast of young people coming and going at odd hours of the day.Â 

Kircheis, however, approached on the main road. He had borrowed the Mariendorf familyâ€™s pickup again, but he left it some half a mile away and walked the rest of the way on foot. He didnâ€™t want to scare Martin by leaving an unfamiliar vehicle parked on the street outside the house, though his presence would probably do enough harm on that front.

He let his hands dangle loosely at his sides as he strode up to the front door. He wanted to jam them into his coat pockets, since it was quite cold out, but he resisted the temptation. Kircheis wasnâ€™t carrying a gun, and he didnâ€™t want Martin to think that he might be.

It was the apprehension of the unknown that made his heart pound strangely as he hopped lightly up the few front steps and rang the doorbell. He craned his neck to look at the sky as he waited, and waited.

He was sure that someone was home. He was sure he was being ignored. He rang the doorbell again and got no response. Thinking of Bronner, Kircheis was tempted to kick back the mat on the step and look to see if there was a spare key, but instead he just sighed and sat down. The cold stone of the stairs leeched the heat from his body, and he shivered despite his warm jacket.

It was over half an hour before anything happened. Kircheis wasnâ€™t sure how long he would have waited, but eventually a car pulled up into the driveway, one with two people sitting inside it. Martin was driving, and he got out, leaving the second person to sit as a vague shadow behind the tinted window. Kircheis didnâ€™t stand upâ€” he thought that would appear too threateningâ€” and he put his hands on either side of his knees, gripping the cold stone of the stairs, in view so that they could see he wasnâ€™t holding a gun.

â€œWhat are you doing here?â€ Martin asked. His tone was hostile and his whole body was tense. He squinted at Kircheis, though Martinâ€™s back was to the white ball of the sun on its way down the sky.

â€œI needed to see you,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œI told you not to look for me. How did you find me?â€ Kircheis wondered how much of Martinâ€™s harshness was because he suddenly had to put on a show for the person in the car behind him, to prove his own loyaltyâ€” that he hadnâ€™t given Kircheis his location.

â€œCan we talk about this inside?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œNo,â€ Martin said. â€œYou need to leave, right now.â€

â€œI came to warn you.â€

â€œWarn me about what?â€

â€œBronner is the one who told me where you were. Thereâ€™s going to be a raid on this place someday. I donâ€™t know when, but itâ€™s going to happen. You need toâ€”â€ Kircheisâ€™s voice froze in his throat.

Martin just looked at him with a cold stare.Â 

â€œMartin, please,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œWhat do you want?â€ Martin asked.

â€œI want to help you.â€ And the words cloyed in his mouth, not quite true as they were.

But this alone was what could soften Martinâ€™s expression, if only for a second, his eyes finding Kircheisâ€™s and holding there for just a moment too long. But then his expression hardened again. â€œWhy did Bronner send you here?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Kircheis admitted. â€œIâ€™m probably playing into some trap of his, but I had to warn you.â€

Martin glanced behind himself at the figure in the car, who made no movements.

â€œYou need to leave,â€ Martin said again. â€œNow.â€

Kircheis didnâ€™t know what he had expected to get out of this conversation. Perhaps if Martin had been alone, they could have spoken more candidly. But he had set out to warn Martin, and he had. So that would have to be enough, at least for now. Kircheis nodded and stood. â€œMartinâ€”â€

â€œWhat?â€

â€œPlease let me help you.â€

Their eyes met again, and Martin opened his mouth to say something, but changed his mind. â€œDonâ€™t try to find me,â€ he said. â€œIf I need youâ€”â€

â€œYou know where I am,â€ Kircheis said. He began to walk down the driveway. He resisted the temptation to look into the tinted windows of the car, and just stared straight ahead. He could feel eyes on him. When he reached the bottom of the driveway, he turned his head and saw Martin looking at him. He stopped walking, and they looked at each other steadily. Kircheis raised his hand in a still and solemn wave.

â€œStay safe!â€ he called.

Martin nodded, and Kircheis dropped his hand and walked away.

Three days later, in his mailbox, he found an unmarked letter, one that was heavier than usual. He pulled it out with some trepidation, and discovered that it was just a single address. His heart would have soared to think that the letter had been sent by Martin, but to the back of it, he found taped the spare key to his house.

Chapter End Notes

[American Psycho voice] Very nice. Now let's see Nat Rome's takes on Art.

chapter title is from Matthew 24:36-44. figured it was appropriate since everyone in this chapter is waiting for the other apocalyptic shoe to drop, and several people get unexpected guests

welcome to the story a new group of randos haha. every time i introduce new characters it's like oh no now i've got new guys whose arcs i have to juggle...

"noodle why do you write so many characters who were sent to horrible Special Ed situations as children?" complicated question to answer. i sure do keep doing it though.

uh i thought i had more to say here but i've gone and forgotten it all lmao. you all can do the saying for me. tell me your takes

fyi that this story may go on mini-hiatus for november while i work on yuletide fic/some other micro projects that need to get done. i'm not 100% saying that will happen but if i don't post for a month, that's why lol. you'll all be the eventual beneficiaries of said work anyway so it probably doesn't matter but you know. forewarned is forearmed.

speaking of writing other things: you may want to check out "And the Big Wheel Keep On Turning"

thank you very very much to em for the beta read!

you know where to find me: javert @ tumblr, natsinator @ twitter, gayspaceopera.carrd.co , join my discord for many stimulating discussions https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

The Battle of Valhalla

October 488 I.C., Geiersburg Fortress

Admiral Merkatz and Count Mariendorf had, thankfully, not been present at Braunschweigâ€™s execution of the prisoners, but both of them had heard of it from someone other than Yang, so the mood when they met the next morning was somber.Â 

Yang didnâ€™t want to talk about it.

They met over breakfast, on Merkatzâ€™s temporary flagship docked in Geiersburg, in his personal dining room. There wasnâ€™t much personal about the place. The dining table and chairs they sat at were expensive real wood, but there was no other decor, just bare walls. The three silently ate for some time, the clinking of dishware the substitute for conversation.

â€œHave you spoken to the duke?â€ Merkatz finally asked. It wasnâ€™t clear which of them, Count Mariendorf or Yang, he was addressing.

â€œNot today,â€ Yang said.Â 

â€œIâ€™m meeting with him at ten,â€ the count said. â€œAfter that, I expect Iâ€™ll be leaving.â€

â€œAlready?â€ Merkatz asked.

â€œThereâ€™s no reason for me to stay,â€ Franz replied. â€œI have a job to do, and travel isnâ€™t fast.â€

â€œIâ€™m not a military man,â€ Franz said. â€œI wouldnâ€™t be useful to you, even if I was here.â€

â€œNo,â€ Merkatz said, â€œyou might be. The duke is far more likely to take the advice of a peer than he is to take anyone elseâ€™s.â€

â€œIâ€™m hardly his peer. My estate is small, compared to his. Leigh is equivalent to me, in that respect,â€ Franz said. It was intended as a joke to lighten the mood, but neither Yang nor Merkatz laughed. â€œAre you certain he wonâ€™t listen to you?â€ he asked Merkatz.

â€œOn military matters, he will defer in part. The duke is aware of his own shortcomings when he wants to beâ€” he wouldnâ€™t have recruited capable advisors if he wasnâ€™t. But this is not going to remain a military matter for long, if everything goes well.â€

â€œAre you headed directly for the capital?â€

â€œAndâ€”â€

â€œItâ€™s not one my daughter would ask,â€ Franz said with a bit of a chuckle.

â€œShe should,â€ Yang said. â€œIâ€™d always give her an honest answer.â€

â€œAnd do you think youâ€™ll win?â€

â€œLittenheim has far more ground troops than we haveâ€” Braunschweigâ€™s ground forces are committed to his estatesâ€ â€”and Cahokia, but Yang didnâ€™t mention thatâ€” â€œso weâ€™ll be at a disadvantage if it becomes a land battle. In space, I think weâ€™re better off.â€

â€œWill it become a land battle?â€

Yang shrugged. â€œLittenheim knows his weaknesses and strengths better than I do, so if he decides he canâ€™t win in space, heâ€™ll force it to become one. But thereâ€™s plenty of good reasons to stay off of Odin.â€

â€œI almost feel like I should wait to leave, to see the outcome,â€ Franz said. â€œIf it is decisive, there wonâ€™t be a point in making the rounds for supplies.â€ The silence from Yang and Merkatz told him enough. He wiped his hands on his napkin. â€œThat would be too easy, of course.â€

â€œDecisive will need to mean complete annihilation,â€ Merkatz said. â€œThis is a battle for his own futureâ€” and he either wins or dies.â€

â€œI donâ€™t want to be,â€ Franz said. â€œBut be careful. Donâ€™tâ€”â€ And he cut himself off.

Â 

Â 

Although there was a great rush of activity on Geiersburg before the fleet headed out, the living area where the Braunschweig family was staying was quiet. Yang, though he had no right or official reason, headed there, on an errand of saying one last goodbye.Â 

When he rang the bell on the Braunschweig family quarters, he was surprised to see Princess Amarie open the door. Perhaps he shouldnâ€™t have been.

â€œCommodore Leigh,â€ she said, â€œwhat brings you here?â€ For once, her hair was down around her shoulders, and she was wrapped in a delicate shawl. It made her look more fragile than usual.

â€œCome in, Commodore. You donâ€™t need to stand in the hallway.â€ She held the door open, and Yang stepped inside the lavish quarters, his footsteps suddenly quieted by an elaborate rug. â€œCan I offer you a drink?â€

â€œNo, thank you,â€ Yang said. â€œI should be getting back soon. Weâ€™re not that long from heading out.â€

Amarie nodded, but poured herself a drink from the decanter sitting on the coffee table. She sat down on the green velvet couch, and gestured for Yang to take a seat across from her, with his back to the huge, glass-fronted bookshelves and cabinets.

â€œAnd why was it that you wanted to say goodbye? It is overstepping your bounds, as you said.â€

â€œPrincess, against my better judgment, I care about your daughter as a person, rather than just as a head to wear a crown,â€ Yang said. â€œI was hoping to make sure sheâ€™s doing well.â€

She was silent for a second, then she said, â€œMy husband told me about the last meeting you had with my father.â€

â€œWhat about it?â€ He watched her tip her glass back and forth.

â€œWere you really my fatherâ€™s friend, in the end, Commodore?â€

â€œNo,â€ Yang said. â€œAnd Iâ€™m sure itâ€™s just as impossible to be your daughterâ€™s friend. But I did care about your father, in the way that I could, and I care about her.â€

â€œI see. And you hoped to reassure Elizabeth, and tell her that her father will return victorious?â€

â€œNo,â€ Yang said. â€œI donâ€™t like making overconfident predictions.â€

â€œThen what would you say to her?â€

â€œIâ€™d tell her the plan, if she wanted to know it. I know you donâ€™t approve, Princess.â€

Amarie tapped her fingers on her glass. â€œItâ€™s not that I donâ€™t approve. This isnâ€™t my world, Commodore, and itâ€™s not hers. I wouldnâ€™t be assured by you telling me about how you plan to conquer Iserlohn Fortress, and I doubt she would be, either.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t know you knew about that.â€

â€œIt may not be my world, but Iâ€™m not stupid, or blind. From the day my husband tried to petition my father for an outpost in the corridorâ€” thereâ€™s only one thing that could possibly be for.â€

â€œAh.â€

â€œI know you have some sympathy for us,â€ Amarie said, â€œthough Iâ€™m not sure I appreciate the sense of pity.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know if anyone could pity you.â€ It was funnyâ€” she reminded Yang very strongly of Reuenthal in that moment, though the two of them were as different as people could possibly be. They had some of the same cold grace, though, and the same hatred of being seen as weak.

â€œOh, they could.â€ Although she hadnâ€™t actually drank anything from her cup, she put it down on the table before her. â€œYou donâ€™t like giving overconfident predictions, but you understand what will happen if my husband loses this war.â€

â€œMay I give you some advice, Princess?â€

â€œHow could I stop you?â€

â€œIf things look like theyâ€™re going badly, get to Phezzan.â€

She laughed. â€œOh, the worst thing anyone could do is prolong the inevitable. I despise false hope.â€ She looked in his eyes, and Yang wanted to squirm away. â€œIf Littenheim has any sense, heâ€™ll send a few ships to wait just out of range of this fortressâ€” if any little convoy starts fleeing to Phezzan, it will be hunted down. As soon as my husbandâ€™s fleet leaves, weâ€™ll be trapped here, with whatever few ships he sees fit to give us. And donâ€™t tell me that this fortress is defensibleâ€” weâ€™re sitting in it right now.â€

â€œIn a situation where there is a fleet that can launch from Geiersburg, it is much easier to defend,â€ Yang said. â€œWe were able to capture it by preying on the weaknesses of the situation, not the fortress itself.â€

â€œWe?â€ she asked, very pointedly.

â€œThen let me put it bluntly: I donâ€™t know if a different commander would be able to take this place.â€

â€œAnd when Littenheim has won, and he brings the whole brunt of his forces against me here? Even if I could be a prisoner forever, I have no doubt that everyone else here would rather surrender than be entombed with me.â€ She pointed behind Yang, to the bookshelves and drawers that he was sitting in front of. â€œThird drawer, if you please, Commodore.â€

Yang twisted on the couch and leaned far over the back to pull open the heavy wooden drawer of the cabinet. Inside was a small jewelry box, which he pulled out to sit on his lap. When Amarie said nothing, he lifted the lid, finding small, unmarked bottles of pills.

â€œYouâ€™re welcome to take some with you, if you like. I have more than enough,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™m told the pinks are only a sedative, but you take it at the same time as the blues so that youâ€™re peacefully asleep when the poison takes effect.â€

â€œAnd did you offer these to anyone else?â€

â€œWho else would I offer them to?â€

â€œHerr Vering, maybe. Or your husband. Or Ansbach, since youâ€™re offering them to me.â€

â€œAnsbach was the one who got them for me,â€ she said.

â€œYou trust him quite a bit.â€

â€œHeâ€™s been a loyal man for many years. I notice these thingsâ€” thatâ€™s a skill of my world.â€

â€œIs that why weâ€™re talking now?â€ Yang closed the jewelry box and put it back in the drawer.

â€œYou prefer your sidearm?â€ she asked, watching him.

Yang splayed his hands. â€œI donâ€™t carry a sidearm. I gave mine to my lieutenant, and heâ€™s back on Odin. I prefer not to die.â€

She shook her head. â€œYou are a strange man, Commodore. I should have given you the same gift for your loyalty that I gave Ansbach a few years ago. Pity I only had one.â€

â€œI donâ€™t need any gifts,â€ Yang said. â€œIâ€™m a very simple man.â€

â€œYou didnâ€™t like my fatherâ€™s gift to you, either.â€

â€œHe was too generous.â€

â€œNo, I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s it,â€ she said. â€œYou donâ€™t like gifts, because they might mean something.â€

â€œAnd what would it mean?â€

â€œThat you might actually be the loyal man you pretend to be, Commodore.â€

Yang frowned.Â  â€œI should go.â€

â€œGood luck to you,â€ she said. â€œI hope we see each other again.â€

November 488 I.C., En route to Valhalla Starzone

There were a few routes to Odin from Geiersburg Fortress, all of which were about equal length, but they narrowed down to one trunk as they came towards Valhalla starzone. Odinâ€™s location as the capital planet had been chosen for this reason: this singular entry point made it very defensible, even from enemies within the Empire itself.Â 

Braunschweigâ€™s fleetâ€™s journey to Odin was safe until they reached this last branching point. Until that point, there was no one chasing them or blocking their path, simply because it would have been too difficult to predict which of the many routes Braunschweig would take. But when they reached the main line on the map, although they kept plowing ahead, their navigators kept their eyes fixed to their instruments, eyes peeled for any kind of deviation in the track that they were following.

The tension rose higher and higher as they approached Odin. Even Braunschweig, a man known for his confidence, took to pacing back and forth on his command dais. Travel was always long and difficult to bear, and things had been tense on their way to Geiersburg, but not knowing where the enemy was going to approach from made it worse by a thousandfold.

Yang was lucky to be awake and on the bridge when the first signs of trouble appeared. In a normal battle, this might have been a communications blackout, but here, the alarm was raised by the chief navigator.

â€œSirs, Iâ€™m getting a signal of obstructions along the path,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t know what it isâ€” could be asteroids, or a gas cloudâ€”â€

But everyoneâ€™s mind immediately went to the only place it could: Littenheim had arrived at Odin first, and had blocked the path. It was either ships or mines, but as they approached closer, they could see that the mass wasnâ€™t quite enough for ships. Littenheim had been here, and had filled the path behind him with mines. If their ships tried to fly through them faster than light, they would be torn to shreds, as they would be if they tried to pass their ships through the solid bulk of a planet. But even if they slowed to sublight speeds, they would be vulnerable to the mines, and would have to clear the field before they could head towards the planet.

Braunschweig convened his advisors to discuss what they were going to do about it, though it was clear that he had already made up his mind from the moment they all sat down in his wardroom. Braunschweig sat imposingly at the head of the table with his nephew, Baron Flegel, on one side, and Ansbach at the other. Also in attendance were Yang, Merkatz, and the unfortunate Hans von Vering, who sat next to Flegel uncomfortably.

â€œWe donâ€™t have much of a choice,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œWe need to clear the mines to get to Odin. And as quickly as possible. The question is only of how. Can we get away with a long narrow passage, or do we have to clear the majority? Gentlemen?â€

â€œMay I say something, sir?â€ Yang asked.

Braunschweigâ€™s nose wrinkled. â€œYes.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think we should spend our time clearing the mines,â€ Yang said.

At first, the room was quiet, and then Flegel laughed. â€œAnd how do you think we get to Odin, then?â€

â€œWell, sir, look at it this wayâ€” do we know where Littenheim is?â€

â€œOn the other side of those mines, Leigh,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œHe wants to wear us down, and have time to entrench himself. That is generally what mines are used for.â€

â€œBut what would he get out of that?â€ Yang asked. â€œSirâ€” right now, this is the only path to Odin, right? Heâ€™s essentially cut off his own supply linesâ€” and the entire population of Odin with himâ€” if heâ€™s hiding behind there. Itâ€™s like heâ€™s invited us to starve him out. It doesnâ€™t make sense as a strategic choice.â€

Merkatz spoke up. â€œDo you think that Littenheim believes we will starve him out? I believe heâ€™s expecting us to clear the mines, and this is just buying him time. He couldnâ€™t have arrived here too long before us. An extra few days would be to his advantage.â€

â€œHe does expect us to clear them, sir,â€ Yang said. â€œBut I donâ€™t think heâ€™s waiting for us on the other side.â€

â€œAnd why not?â€ Merkatz asked.

â€œThis seems designed to waste our time.â€

â€œI think weâ€™re all in agreement there,â€ Ansbach said.

Yang pulled a pad of paper from the center of the wardroom table towards himself and started drawing a diagram on it. â€œLook,â€ he said, â€œthe most important thing to understand is that Littenheimâ€™s goal right now is not Odin itself. He doesnâ€™t care about defending the capital from usâ€” he wants to crush us. If weâ€™re too fixated on getting to Odin, we lose sight of the bigger picture.â€

Yang sketched a line on the paper: their forces, the mines, Odin. Then he continued. â€œLook at this: weâ€™re trapped in a narrow little corridorâ€” just like Iserlohnâ€” with, right now, a wall on one side of us. If we start wasting our time clearing the mines, and Littenheim comes up behind us, we will be completely encircled, and wonâ€™t be able to retreat either out into space or down towards Odin.â€ He shook his head. â€œLittenheim doesnâ€™t need to care about his position in space around Odinâ€” he already has us walking into the perfect trap.â€

â€œThatâ€™s a very interesting story, Commodore,â€ Flegel said, in his most dismissive tone. â€œBut thereâ€™s no evidence for it to be true.â€

â€œBaron Flegel is correct,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œAnd, contrary to Commodore Leighâ€™s assertion, Odin is valuable. If Littenheim controls the capital, he controls the perception of this war.â€

Yang glanced over at Merkatz, hoping for support, but Merkatz said nothing.

â€œYouâ€™re friends with Count Mariendorf, arenâ€™t you, Commodore?â€ Vering asked.

â€œYes,â€ Yang said.

â€œThen you should know how important it is to have something to use to gather support among the lesser nobles, the industrialists like my fatherâ€” theyâ€™re the people who will keep us able to fight.â€

Yang was losing this argument. â€œMines and ships arenâ€™t symbolic,â€ Yang said. â€œLittenheim needs to defeat us if he wants control. If heâ€™s smartâ€”â€

Braunschweig laughed. â€œHeâ€™s not. Thatâ€™s your problem, Leigh. Youâ€™re a little too clever.â€

Yang frowned and slumped back in his seat. He lifted his eyes just once. Ansbach didnâ€™t look back at him, but was studying Yangâ€™s scribbled diagram.

Â 

Â 

After the meeting, which devolved into a long discussion about the best way to clear up the mines, Yang caught Merkatz on his way back to his shuttle.

â€œSir!â€ Yang called. Merkatz stopped and waited for him in the hallway, though he waved for his own aideâ€” some young man named Schneiderâ€” to go ahead to the shuttle.

Yang was out of breath when he caught up to Merkatz.

â€œAre you going to try to ask me to change my mind about where Littenheimâ€™s fleet is, Commodore?â€ Merkatz asked.

â€œNo,â€ Yang said when he had caught his breath. â€œButâ€” why?â€

Merkatz looked at him sidelong. â€œFor once, I find myself in agreement with the dukeâ€™s strategic thinking.â€

â€œYes, sir,â€ Yang said, though he couldnâ€™t keep the disappointment out of his voice.

Merkatz never showed much emotion, but he took pity on Yang. â€œCommodore, if it was you and me in the corridor, and we encountered the rebels doing this, I would believe that there is some kind of trick involved. But the duke knows his opponent far better than I doâ€” and I have to agree that he has never shown much creativity, in the years Iâ€™ve heard his name.â€

Yang frowned. â€œEven if Littenheim isnâ€™t creativeâ€” heâ€™s been recruiting talent.â€

Merkatz raised an eyebrow. â€œAnd is he any more likely to listen to that talent than the duke is?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know, sir.â€

â€œI know Admiral Ovlesser,â€ Merkatz said. â€œHeâ€™s a very direct man. If heâ€™s coordinating, there wonâ€™t be any tricks.â€

â€œYes, sir.â€

â€œAnd Lieutenant Commander Vering is right, as well. We need a victory at Odinâ€” in Valhalla.â€

Yang nodded.

â€œYouâ€™ll be with the duke, at least, and in the rear, since he has no interest in clearing mines himself. Does that ease your mind any?â€

â€œSome,â€ Yang said. â€œJust as long as we can react quickly.â€

â€œIâ€™ll admit it eases my mind,â€ Merkatz said. â€œBut I hope nothing comes of it.â€

â€œEnjoy your cleanup duty.â€

â€œI will, thank you, Commodore,â€ Merkatz said with his wry voice.

Â 

Â 

The procedure to clear out a minefield, especially one as widely spread as the one blocking their path, was a slow one. It involved ships proceeding as carefully as they could through the dangerous area, sending out jets of directional zephyr particles, which they would then ignite with the shipâ€™s guns once the gas was far enough in front of them, creating a ball of flame that would swallow up the nearby mines. Before the invention of directional zephyr particles, the process had been much slower: bomb attracting decoys had needed to be sent to clear a path through. That was costly in terms of resources as well as time, and a fleet the size of Braunschweigâ€™s might not have even carried enough decoys to clear a path. At least zephyr particles could be manufactured on the engineering ships, even if the process was time consuming.

Yang didnâ€™t want to leave the bridge, feeling tied to it by the impossible-to-dismiss fear of an ambush, but even he had to sleep sometimes. And Braunschweig, who also spent much of his time in his position of authority, could only tolerate so much of Yang (and Hans von Vering, for that matter), so Yang couldnâ€™t lurk there as much as he might have preferred.

He and Vering ended up in the same place quite often for this reason. Yang got the sense that Ansbach thought that Yang should babysit him (or should be tortured by having to deal with him), so when Yang wandered off the bridge to go take his dinner, or sit in the officersâ€™ lounge, Ansbach would quickly dismiss Vering to go do the same. And when Vering left, Ansbach would give Yang a signal to go follow him and make sure he was not in trouble.Â 

Vering wasnâ€™t even a troublemaker, so it all seemed quite pointless. In the times Yang watched him, he mainly sat around and drank, and would try to get the other officers to gamble with him. They rarely took him up on the offer, but he never seemed to grow tired of asking. He was a sore winner and a grumbling loser, though he had so much money to throw around that he should hardly have missed it when he did lose. Yang supposed it must be the principle of the thing for him, but it made him quickly run out of willing opponents on board the ship, even when he offered to bet over things other than cards: the outcome of a chess match, or darts. It was almost painful to watch him continue to try to recruit friends in this way, since it never worked.

It was strangeâ€” Yang had always liked people that he felt he could give a helping hand to, and Vering certainly was in this category, but Yang struggled to find much affection or even sympathy for him. It was unfair to the young man, of course.
