There was plenty about his situation that was deserving of sympathy: he was out of his depth, and, like Elizabeth, was being used as a tool of the older generation. And Yang often found himself friends with people whom nobody likedâ€” he could see immediately through Obersteinâ€™s cold and awkward demeanor to a person whom Yang could respect and enjoy the company ofâ€” but there seemed to be very little to Vering to like. And he made no effort to like Yang, either. For this reason, Yang, and Yang alone, was spared being asked to play cards. He might even have taken Vering up on the offer out of pity, if he had asked. But he never did, no matter how much time they spent in the same place.

This was why, when the alarm finally came, as Yang had known it would, he and Vering were alone in the officersâ€™ lounge, sitting as far away from each other as they could get. Yang had arrived first, and had positioned himself near the faux fireplace to read a book in the plush armchair there, which meant that Vering was at the other side of the room, drinking a beer and playing a game of solitaire on one of the tables, pointedly not looking at Yang. When the wail of the alarm pierced the air, he jumped, knocking his beer with his elbow, and it fell to the floor and shattered, foam and glass going everywhere.

He stood in a hurry, then clearly didnâ€™t know what to do with himself once he had stood, looking back and forth between the mess on the floor and the door, where the visible alarm flashed red.Â 

â€œWhatâ€™s going on?â€ Vering asked. He might not have been asking Yang specifically, but since Yang was the only person in the room, it was up to him to answer.

â€œI assume weâ€™re getting ambushed,â€ Yang said. He tucked his bookmark into his book, then tossed it on the side table. â€œCome on. Are you coming to the bridge?â€

â€œIâ€”â€

Outside the lounge, they could hear pounding feet in the corridor as soldiers ran past, all headed for their duty stations. Yangâ€™s nonchalance was unfeigned when he walked to the door and held it open for Vering. There was something about the breaking of tension that made him slip into a cool decision-making mode. He would feel the horror of it all later, but for now, he could keep his wits about him. It all broke down into simple, clear steps that he could take: get to the bridge, assess the situation, come up with a plan. Walking through a sequence of events, one following another, no matter where they led, gave Yang a strange clarity and calmness that other people seemed to lack.

Yang escorted Vering to the bridge. Ansbach was already there, as was Braunschweig, of course. Yang was relieved that Baron Flegel had, with his section of the fleet, been assigned mine-sweeping duty, and was not on the flagship. The bridge was frantically busy, and Yang pulled Vering over to Ansbach to get an update on the situation.

â€œHow much time do we have before they get here?â€ was Yangâ€™s first question.

â€œThey didnâ€™t drop sublight until they were on top of us,â€ Ansbach said. â€œThirty minutes to contact, I think.â€

â€œIs that good?â€ Vering asked, naked fear in his voice.

â€œItâ€™s better than if we were already being shot at,â€ Yang said. â€œHas Merkatz started moving the fleet?â€

Ansbach pointed towards the front of the bridge, where the display showed the positions of each individual section of Merkatzâ€™s fleet buried among the mines. They had scooped out a cavity in the center of the minefield, but this had been done by spreading the fleet, and now that cleared area looked less like a victory, and more like a death trap. If the fleet did not carefully maneuver back into position, they would obliterate their own flanks by running them into the mines, without Littenheimâ€™s fleet firing a shot.

What they needed was time, time to get Merkatzâ€™s fleet out of the minefield, time to organize into a defensive lineâ€” but that was what they did not have. They had a small section of the fleet outside the minefield, Braunschweigâ€™s â€œrear guardâ€, and with it, they would need to fend off Littenheim for as long as they could. With them were about half of the engineering ships, the ones generating zephyr particles, which rotated in and out of the minefield in shifts as their tanks refilled. It was this little detail that Yangâ€™s mind seized on.

â€œDoes the duke already have a plan he wants to enact?â€ Yang asked. There was no point in bringing up his idea if the duke was already settled on something.

â€œNo,â€ Ansbach said. â€œWhat are you thinking?â€

â€œCan we retreat right to the mouth of the minefield, and use our FTL, just for a moment, so we move faster than theyâ€™re coming at us?â€ Yang asked. â€œIt buys us a little more time, and gets us closer to our allies.â€

Ansbach looked skeptical. â€œItâ€™s dangerous to do that so close to the mines.â€

â€œOur formation out here is small enough that Iâ€™m not worried about overshooting the mark, and weâ€™re in one of the transit lanesâ€” not in the gravity well of a star. That makes it a lot easier.â€ Yang said.Â 

Ansbach nodded slowly.

â€œAnd, while we do that, send all of the zephyr gas we have out in front. It wonâ€™t go too far, but if weâ€™re backing up, Littenheim will end up closer to it than we will. It might break up their front line, or at least give us a little more time.â€

Ansbach thought about it for half a second, then nodded sharply and turned away to go relay the plan to Braunschweig. Yang was fine with thisâ€” it was easier if he did it.Â 

â€œThis is crazy,â€ Vering muttered under his breath. â€œThis isâ€”â€

â€œPlease get a hold of yourself,â€ Yang said. â€œHere. Come talk to Merkatz with me. Iâ€™m sure he already knows what needs to happen, but letâ€™s make sure weâ€™re on the same page.â€ He pulled on Vering, who had gone all pale and sweaty already, though a single shot hadnâ€™t even been fired. Yang led him like a puppy over to the communications console, where he asked the radioman to get in contact with Merkatz.

Yang saluted as Merkatzâ€™s fuzzy image appeared on screen. â€œSir,â€ Yang said.

Merkatz squinted into the camera, and saw Vering looming behind Yang. â€œI assume you have a contingency plan, Commodore?â€ Merkatz asked.Â 

Now wasnâ€™t the time for apologiesâ€” and Yang just nodded, getting to the point. He briefly explained what the rear guard was going to do.

â€œYouâ€™ll need to arrange the fleet behind us while we hold the line,â€ Yang said. â€œWill you have enough space to move?â€

â€œWeâ€™ll make it work,â€ Merkatz said. â€œAnd when they arrive?â€

â€œIt will be up to you and your fleet, sir,â€ Yang said. â€œAll you can do is try to break through. When youâ€™ve formed up, take a spindle formation. Weâ€™ll hold them off until then, and when youâ€™re ready, weâ€™ll get out of the way so you can punch through. You might even be able to herd them back into the minefieldâ€” or if you canâ€™t, just retreat in the other direction.â€ He didnâ€™t really need to explain this to Merkatz, but he said it for the sake of the listening Vering, and Merkatzâ€™s aide, standing at his shoulder.

â€œYou donâ€™t have any tricks? No secret plan to lead the mines like a pied piper into the enemy fleet?â€ Merkatzâ€™s voice was tonelessly gruff as always, but he smiled, maybe an attempt to put Yangâ€™s mind at ease.

â€œIâ€™m not a magician,â€ Yang said. â€œJust a tactician. And if I had anything like that up my sleeve, we wouldnâ€™t have been wasting all our time with zephyr particles.â€

â€œVery true. Do you expect Littenheim has aâ€¦â€

Yang felt the telltale twitch of gravity as the shipâ€™s engine worked to compensate for movement. As the ship engaged its faster than light engines, the picture of Merkatz warped and shifted and broke apart, leaving nothing but a smear of static and a tuneless buzz, which Yang stared at for a moment before looking up at Vering, who was clutching the back of a chair with white knuckles.

â€œHow can he joke at a time like this?â€ Vering asked.

â€œSit down, Lieutenant Commander,â€ Yang said. â€œCalm down.â€

Although Yangâ€™s words had the effect of making Vering angry, a red face was an improvement from a pale one, so Yang considered it a success. He stalked away from Yang, and went to go haunt the other side of the bridge, though Yang realized that Ansbach was right, and that he did need an eye kept on him. Yang watched him out of the corner of his eye, even when he went to talk to Braunschweig directly about the specifics of their fleet movement.

They dropped back to sublight speeds almost immediately, then began the complicated process of turning their ships around. Luckily, there was still a few minutes before Littenheimâ€™s fleet came within firing distance, and in that time, Yang received reports about how Merkatzâ€™s fleet reorganization was going. It was slow, because any too-quick movements within the minefield could set off a chain reaction of destruction, but the fleet was coming together. If Braunschweigâ€™s â€œrear guardâ€ could hold the line for even forty minutesâ€” thirty minutesâ€” then Merkatzâ€™s fleet could form a spindle, and break through Littenheimâ€™s line. All they had to do was keep the fleet from forming up to pin Merkatz within the minefield.

The enemy ships were visible now, or at least they were on the peak magnification on the screen at the front of the bridge. Tiny swarms of light, almost like stars, but coming closer, faster and faster. The analysis of the data pouring in confirmed what Yang had already guessed about Littenheimâ€™s fleet: it was slightly smaller than Braunschweigâ€™s in number, by a few thousand ships. Surprisingly, there werenâ€™t many bulky transport ships among their number, but perhaps that shouldnâ€™t have been a surprise: Littenheim had arrived here first in time to put up the minefield, so all his many thousands of ground troops might already be on the other side, headed to Odin. If their ships were useless in a fight, there was no reason to keep them involved. He wondered where they would wait to meet up with Littenheimâ€™s main fleet, if they were hiding, how many of them there were, and what kind of defenses they would encounter if they did try to land on Odin.

For Yang, it was this logic puzzle which kept him in the ideal state of distraction and focus. If he didnâ€™t have something to think through, his eyes would settle vacantly on the ships ahead, and it would begin to weigh on his heart. Some other people on the bridge were not lucky enough to have this train of thought to chase. Vering stood, staring at the screen, slack jawed.

It didnâ€™t surprise Yang that he was having this reaction. After all, Geiersburg, for all it had been a victory, had taken the fearless wind out of many peopleâ€™s sails. And in that battle, they hadnâ€™t fired shots of their own, for the most part. It hadnâ€™t been fleet on fleet like this, and it was completely different to watch the enemy approach than it was to do the approaching.

Looking at Vering, Yang asked himself if he was afraid. He couldnâ€™t find an answer, or he didnâ€™t want to.

The ships came closer.

â€œHow long until they enter our zephyr cloud?â€ Braunschweig asked.

â€œForty seconds,â€ the radar operator said.

â€œAre we in firing range of that?â€

â€œYes, sir.â€

â€œAre we out of range of the gas?â€

â€œAffirmative, sir.â€

Although it felt to the onlookers that Littenheimâ€™s fleet should slow as they approached the invisible danger, they plowed directly into the cloud, unaware of its presence.

â€œFire!â€ Braunschweig ordered.

The bright beams that lanced out into space felt like the first real shots of the civil war. This was against their true opponent, meeting him in battle for the first time.Â 

Since the zephyr particles were so dispersed in space, it took an unusually long moment for the chain reaction to ignite the cloud, but then it did, blooming like a rose, consuming the first few rows of Littenheimâ€™s fleet.

The chaos, too, took a moment to unfold. Ships still accelerating behind the explosion began to change course as quickly as their hukling masses would allow, pitching and rolling to avoid the debris of the disabled ships that had been caught in the blast. This spoke to poor management of a hodgepodge fleet more than anythingâ€” clearly Littenheimâ€™s fleet was not disciplined enough to maintain formation at all cost. The effects of the front lines breaking ranks traveled backwards, until the cameras on the Berlin could no longer pick out the movements of individual ships in the crowd. The movement of the fleet slowed: a commander must be yelling at them to get back in line.

Yangâ€™s trick had done its work at least, bought them a little more time. Every second that they could gather would mean more of a chance for Merkatz to form his own lines.

But the disorder among Littenheimâ€™s fleet hadnâ€™t lasted long, and though they had momentarily slowed, they did not stop their advance, even as Braunschweigâ€™s ships fired again and again.

The wall of ships moving towards them soon overwhelmed the zoom of the cameras. Though the camera backed out further and further, the ships still somehow managed to fill the entire screen, no matter how many times the magnification was reduced.

They couldnâ€™t retreat, but if they didnâ€™t move, they were sitting targets for the enemyâ€™s guns, so it was no surprise that Braunschweig ordered their paltry rear guard forward, focusing their fire and trying to open a weak spot in Littenheimâ€™s line for Merkatz. Yang glanced behind himself at the display that showed Merkatzâ€™s positionâ€” painfully slowly, the ships were gathering together.

As the actual battle began, Yang stopped paying attention to Merkatzâ€™s progress. All he could do was watch what was happening in front of them. The outside world, though seen through cameras, became a confusing jumble, ships coming close to each other, swerving away, fire streaking out, bright flares when ships were hit. The soundscape was disjointed from the imageâ€” like watching a silent movie in a theaterâ€” the only sounds to accompany the death-scenes of ships in front of them were the inrushed breaths and choked exhales of the onlookers on the bridge of the Berlin .

The flagship was under fire, but the navigator kept them safe from the worst of it, and their shields deflected some, though the power draw of doing so made the whole shipâ€™s gravity shudder underfoot.Â 

Even though he wasnâ€™t in command, and there wasnâ€™t much more he could do in his advisory position, Yang didnâ€™t lose track of the battle situation. Braunschweig, to his credit, wasnâ€™t making mistakes when he directed the focus of fire of his ships, and tried his best to keep them in a position where they wouldnâ€™t be picked down. But even if he didnâ€™t make mistakes, there were no good choices he could make, no orders that would win the day. Their rear guard was two thousand ships against Littenheimâ€™s force five or six times greater than that.

When the ship directly to the right of the Berlin exploded under concentrated fire, the blinding light of its engines giving way briefly blacked out the flagshipâ€™s cameras, leaving the bridge blind to the carnage outside. Most people tensed, waiting for a blow that they wouldnâ€™t be able to see coming.

Yang, able to tear himself away from watching for the first time, scanned the bridge and realized that Hans von Vering was missing.

This was a problem. There were only so many places it would make sense for a panicked Vering to go, and at least one of them would be a certain death sentence. Though Braunschweig probably wouldnâ€™t mind if Vering did something to get himself killed, it would be a major problem for Count Mariendorfâ€™s efforts to recruit allies. The elder Vering would not take kindly to his sonâ€™s death, and would have the power to tear the Braunschweig alliance apart financially.

Yang left the bridge just as the cameras regained power and a flickering image of the outside world reappeared overhead. The chaos of the fight would continue, regardless of Yangâ€™s presence. He couldnâ€™t affect the battle one way or another at this point, but he could make himself care about Hans von Vering.

The hallways of the ship were strangely quiet, now that everyone was at their battle stations. The only evidence that the ship was even under attack was the occasional shudder of the gravity engine, either from moving the ship or deflecting a blow. It was a disconcerting sensation, but it made it very easy for Yang to cross the entire length of the ship.

There in the rear were the shuttles, including the one reserved for Braunschweigâ€™s personal use. They all sat nestled in their launchpads in the small bay, unattended at the moment. Surprisingly, Vering had already managed to break into Braunschweigâ€™s shuttle: Yang could see him through the front window, sitting at the helm and looking completely overwhelmed. His movements were erratic as he poked at the buttons in front of him, presumably trying to get the ship to launch.

He didnâ€™t notice Yang until he climbed the steps up to the shuttle door, leaned over the handrail sideways, and rapped on the front window. Vering didnâ€™t stop what he was doing, and maybe even redoubled his efforts.

It should have been Ansbach here instead, Yang thought. Ansbach almost certainly knew the code that would open the shuttle door. Yang had to resort to yelling, hoping to be heard through the thick glass.

â€œLet me in!â€ he said.

Vering could hear him. He shook his head wildly.

â€œI know the launch code!â€ Yang yelled. â€œI can help you!â€

Vering hesitated for a moment, then yelled back, â€œWhy?â€ His voice was so muffled, Yang only barely understood him, half through the movements of his lips.

â€œI want to get out of here!â€

Vering ignored him again and went back to pushing buttons on the console for a minute, or at least hovering his hand over them. Yang couldnâ€™t see if he was making any progress with launching the shuttle. Yang banged on the window again. â€œI can help you launch it!â€

At this moment, the shipâ€™s gravity fluctuated again, and Yang lurched, almost falling over the railing. He clutched it until the ship stabilized, and when he looked back up, Vering had gone even paler.Â 

â€œCome on,â€ Yang pleaded. â€œOpen the door.â€

And, miraculously, Vering did. The door of the shuttle slid open, and Yang stumbled inside and closed it behind himself. He took a seat in the copilotâ€™s chair at the front of the shuttle, then leaned back and sighed, draping his arm over his face.

â€œThe launch code!â€ Vering demanded, then hissed in a breath as the ship was rocked again. â€œThe launch code!â€ he said again a second later, and Yang lifted his arm off his face to realize that Vering was pointing his sidearm at him.

â€œPut that away,â€ Yang said. Vering didnâ€™t lower the gun at all, and his finger itched towards the trigger.

â€œTell me what the code is!â€

Yang dropped his arm back over his face. â€œI donâ€™t know it. Donâ€™t you think that if I knew it, Iâ€™d also know how to open the door myself?â€

Vering made a sound that was halfway between a whine and a snarl. Yang was probably closer to death in that moment than he had been in many yearsâ€” Vering was perfectly capable of shooting him, and possibly willing, too. But Yang didnâ€™t move, didnâ€™t lift his arm to look, and just waited.

â€œPut the gun down,â€ he said after a moment.

â€œNo.â€

â€œYouâ€™re not going to shoot me, so I donâ€™t know why you need to keep pointing it at me.â€

â€œWhat are you doing here?â€

â€œStopping you from killing yourself, or getting yourself killed,â€ Yang said. He held out his other hand blindly. â€œThe gun, please. Well, actually, the energy pack. You can keep the gun.â€

Nothing was placed into Yangâ€™s hand, but he heard Vering slump down into the seat next to him.

â€œWeâ€™re going to die,â€ Vering said.

â€œMaybe,â€ Yang replied.

The ship rocked again.

â€œI canâ€™t get out of here.â€ Veringâ€™s voice was almost completely overtaken by panic.

â€œNo. And if you did, this is interstellar space. This shuttle canâ€™t get you back to Odin, even if you didnâ€™t get shot down.â€

â€œShut up.â€

â€œAlright.â€

â€œI donâ€™t want to die,â€ he said, choking on the words.

â€œThatâ€™s good,â€ Yang said. â€œYeah. Thatâ€™s good. I donâ€™t want to die, either.â€

When Yang lifted his arm to look at the boy, he found Vering sobbing with his face in his hands, his shoulders shaking as he tried and failed to get enough air with each breath.Â 

They sat together in Braunschweigâ€™s shuttle, feeling the ship sway and rock, otherwise oblivious to the world outside. They sat there until Merkatzâ€™s fleet broke through Littenheimâ€™s line, and pushed them back into the minefield, where they used a failsafe to disable their mines, and retreated to Odin. But Yang wouldnâ€™t learn of this until many hours later.

Chapter End Notes

the title is a bit of a misnomer lol since this chapter's action hinges on the fact that they are in interstellar space, but i really wanted to have a "the battle of xyz" chapter title for the first real shots of the civil war haha

i find spacebattles so hard to write you guys you don't even know... this was struggle city. but i hope it feels both true to the way logh does spacebattles and also interesting/fun to read/true to the way i like to write :p

do i know how the ships are supposed to work in logh? no lol. so i feel free to make up my own worldbuilding there.

oh no you know what i've done in this chapter? gotten attached to my sad little failson OC lmao. here's the thing about logh: all the people who are sympathetic are also supposed to be extremely brave and stoic all the time. but i like to sympathize with people who are not that sometimes lol

anyway... new year new chapter haha. sorry for disappearing for like two months! i have been writing some stuff in the meantime, which i highly encourage you go check out. it's good! those things are
- Pictures of Decency, a 45k word canon-compliant novella about Yang, Jessica Edwards, and Jean Robert Lapp, set between the Spiral Labyrinth gaiden and Overture
- "A War From Which There Is No Discharge", a canon-compliant short fic about how Schenkopp ends up tutoring Julian to be a soldier. Set between e16/17.
- "That Which Remains In the Absence of a Confession", an experimental fic about the question "did Reuenthal's dad kill his mom?" and the fallibility of memory

Would love if you checked those out ğŸ’™ğŸ’™

in terms of the schedule for this story-- i have one other short fic commitment that i have to write before i can write the next chapter, but after that i don't foresee any major breaks for the remainder of this story. so sorry for my sporadic upload schedule ğŸ˜… life is. you know. lmao.

i hope everyone had a wonderful new year, and i'd just like to thank you all for coming with me on this journey for another trip around the sun ğŸ’™ i hope you're all enjoying it still haha.

thank you so much as always to em for the beta read!

socials: javert @ tumblr, natsinator @ twitter, gayspaceopera.carrd.co , https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

Matthew 5:29-30

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

November 488 I.C., Odin

Even though Reuenthal was sure that his name was on a secret list somewhere of men who should be given no information, news reached him quickly. His desk job in the Ministry of War still provided him with a host of underlings, all of whom ate in the basement cafeteria and wandered the building on their business, and some of whom could even be trusted to deliver news to Reuenthal when they heard it.

One of Reuenthalâ€™s closest subordinates was a stocky man with reddish-brown hair named Bergengrun, who had been given to Reuenthal as a way of getting rid of a problem. He was younger than Reuenthal by a few years, and was a captain. One might say he was a captain â€œalreadyâ€, because he was young, but that seemed as far as he would get. He had risen to the rank through the usual skill and luck, but it was the combination of a common name and a too-quick temper when drunk that had halted his forward career progress in its tracks. It hadnâ€™t been enough to have him removed from the fleet, but it had been enough to make him enemies, including among his former superiors. Very few nobles in the Imperial fleet appreciated subordinates who spoke whatever disagreements were on their minds. Reuenthal found it useful, for the most part.

Bergengrun was friends with another captain in the building. That captain was among the first to receive the report that a fleet was limping into the space around Odin, and that Odinâ€™s own, relatively paltry, defense fleet would be sortieing to meet it. When Bergengrun got his hands on a copy of this information, it ended up on Reuenthalâ€™s desk.

Several things became immediately clear.

Firstâ€” it was Littenheimâ€™s fleet that was en route to Odin. Their satellites throughout the system picked up the image of his flagship on their cameras. His fleet looked battered, and was missing a significant part of its number.

Secondâ€” Littenheimâ€™s fleet was coming to Odin in a flight of desperation. If it had not been a harried rush to escape a larger threat, if Littenheim had won whatever engagement had scarred his fleet so badly, he would have stopped before approaching the planet and made an announcement that he had defeated Braunschweig and demand that Lichtenlade turn over the Imperial government to him. There was no announcement, so it seemed that Littenheim was planning to use the only remaining resource he hadâ€” ground troops, and the foothold he had in the Military Policeâ€” to entrench himself on Odin.

Thirdâ€” Littenheim would be successful in getting to Odin. The defense fleet that had been left on the planet was paltry, hardly more than a token fleet of three thousand ships. Because of Odinâ€™s protected nature within the Empire, it had never been a high priority to keep a large standing military force on the planet. In fact, it had been considered dangerous to do soâ€” having a full stationed fleet on Odin, a planet where people could get ideas, increased the danger of a military coup by an order of magnitude. Muckenburger had raised the fleet presence in the system marginally before the civil war, but he had hoped to avoid a major conflict between the remains of the Imperial government and either of the dueling families, so had not done as much as he could have. Even though Littenheimâ€™s fleet was battered, it was still more than a match for Odinâ€™s ships and the relatively junior commander in charge of them, a vice admiral whose name Reuenthal had only ever heard in passing.

Fourthâ€” once Littenheim arrived on Odin, the planet would be under his control, at least physically. The Military Police had, even before the civil war, functioned as a combination of secret police and the most significant military presence on the planet. Outside of Neue Sanssouci, they were the Kaiserâ€™s personal force on Odin. Since Kaiser Friedrich, to whom they had nominally reported, was dead, Littenheim controlled the military police, and this left Lichtenlade with little military strengthâ€”Â  he only controlled the few small ground units of the Fleet on Odin, the Neue Sanssouci guards, and whatever city police units would obey him when they came under fire. It wasnâ€™t much, and it certainly wasnâ€™t enough to stop Littenheimâ€™s army from occupying the capital.

Of course, that didnâ€™t mean that Lichtenlade was going to surrender. Lichtenladeâ€™s plan was to turn things over to the victor, and even an occupation of Neue Sanssouci was not a sign of victory. Littenheim retreating to Odin gave Braunschweig as much time and space as he needed to gather resources, and a large enough army, to eventually crush his rival.Â 

By the end of the day, it seemed like the whole building had heard the news. Every man in the building was either rushing around like he was being drawn forward by invisible high-tension stringsâ€” twanging around corners and vibrating with the energy held in the cordsâ€” or had withdrawn into himself. When Reuenthal walked out, he passed men huddled in corners speaking in hushed voices, and a man leaning against walls with one arm thrown over his head while their other pressed his phone to his ear and whispered something to his wife. Everyone talking about secrets that everyone knew.

Reuenthal walked out in the strangely peaceful late November evening, pulling his coat tight around his shoulders to stave off the chill. Looking behind himself as he left the building, he wondered how many times he would return there. Not many, he was sure. Already, there were people packing up every sensitive document in the building, moving them into secure storage far outside the capital city, deep underground, in places Littenheim wouldnâ€™t be able to access even if he took control of the whole planet. Those wouldnâ€™t be unsealed until Muckenburger, or whoever succeeded Muckenburger, gave his blessing to the new order.Â 

Rather than going home, Reuenthal drove the opposite direction, through the city. Even now, things seemed normalâ€” a few pedestrians running their errands through the grim and snowy air, at shops that remained resolutely open. For Reuenthal, the last edges of normalcy had fallen away, and everyone now was walking around clinging to an illusion. It couldnâ€™t last much longer, and knowing that was almost a relief. It made things clearer.

He drove towards the part of the city where expensive townhouses lined tree-shaded streets. Some of these were the city homes of the nobility who kept country mansions elsewhere, and some were the only homes of the lesser nobility, or the wealthiest echelons of commoners, or Phezzani merchants who had a presence on Odin. The exteriors were, unlike the countryside manor houses, not ostentatious. The location announced the wealth of the owner far better than any facade could.

Reuenthal parked on the street outside one of these houses, braced himself for an unpleasant task, and walked up the tall set of steps to ring the bell. If Elfriede had not been living in his house, he would have insisted that they meet there instead, but she left him with little choice.

An old butler answered the door, inclined his head to Reuenthal, and let him in.

â€œHe is expecting you, sir,â€ the butler said. â€œIf youâ€™ll come this way?â€

Reuenthal followed him through the house. It was dark insideâ€” the overhead lights were dim, and the wooden paneling on the walls swallowed what little light there was. What of the house Reuenthal could see was old, tasteful, and well kept. A few paintings and photographs lined the walls, but none of them were people whom Reuenthal recognized.

The butler knocked on, then opened, the door to the office, deep into the house. Reuenthal stepped inside, and the butler swiftly left.

â€œCome here, Dog,â€ Oberstein said from his seat at the desk.

The command was not for Reuenthalâ€” it was for the wobbling old Dalmatian that was standing in front of him, blocking his path forward. Reuenthal wasnâ€™t sure if the dogâ€™s stance was out of curiosity or threat, but it didnâ€™t matter to Reuenthal either way. He didnâ€™t like dogs much, and he waited until the animal registered Obersteinâ€™s command and walked with arthritic legs over to lay its head in his lap.

It was only then that Reuenthal had a chance to look around the office, and realized that the lights were even dimmer here than they were in the hallway. Only a single floor lamp was on, near the door, and probably for the sake of the dog. Oberstein had his eyes closedâ€” or he closed his eyelids over the sunken holes that usually held his eyes. The mechanical replacements were soaking in a cup of water at his elbow. Oberstein had a tablet in front of him, although the screen was completely black. He tapped on it twice, apparently issuing some kind of invisible command, then moved it aside.

â€œYou were expecting me?â€ Reuenthal asked.

â€œI knew you would come. Please, take a seat, Rear Admiral.â€ He made no motion to stand or salute, despite their difference in ranks. â€œIâ€™m sure that the lieutenant will be here presently.â€

â€œDid you invite him?â€ Reuenthal asked, taking a seat in the chair in front of Obersteinâ€™s desk.

â€œHeâ€™ll come. He has his own ways of hearing the news. He may still be delivering it to everyone who needs to know.â€

â€œOh?â€

â€œI believe the commodore left him with explicit instructions to watch over a certain list of people. Since time is not of the essence right now, I canâ€™t fault him for obeying. But you and I can talk before he arrives.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t want to wait for him?â€

â€œNo,â€ Oberstein said.

â€œVery well.â€ Reuenthal leaned back in his seat and looked around the room some more. There was a large family photograph hanging behind Obersteinâ€™s deskâ€” an older man in uniform (a vice admiral), a slender woman next to him, and a young boy standing in front, the womanâ€™s hands grasping his shoulders. A dog, a black lab, leaned its head against the childâ€™s hips. The child was clearly Oberstein as a youth, though the boy had wide-open brown eyes, not the blue ones in the jar that Reuenthal couldnâ€™t help but glance at with revulsion. The family photograph was easier to look at than Oberstein or anything else, so it was to that which he addressed his comments. â€œLittenheim will be here in a few days.â€

â€œThere wonâ€™t be much resistance. Lichtenlade will find somewhere to hide.â€

â€œBut will he be able to? If he or his child-kaiser dies, the rest of the government will surrender to Littenheim, which will make the whole fleet go after Braunschweig. Thatâ€™s the only way that he can win, with his fleet in the condition it is.â€

â€œLichtenlade will be well hidden,â€ Oberstein said.Â 

â€œYouâ€™re very confident. The MPs know where all of the government safehouses are.â€

â€œBut not the Lichtenlade familyâ€™s personal secrets,â€ Oberstein said. â€œI expect that he has been careful for many years preparing for this.â€

â€œSecrets are a hard thing to keep around here.â€

â€œAre you asking if we should throw our support behind Lichtenlade?â€

â€œNo,â€ Reuenthal said, though he had been wondering if Oberstein would suggest it. â€œI just wonder how long he can hold out, and how long Leighâ€™s plan is going to take.â€

â€œI believe he would have left for Iserlohn immediately after his battle with Littenheim,â€ Oberstein said. â€œIt wonâ€™t take more than a few weeks for him to arrive.â€

â€œDid he tell you thatâ€™s where heâ€™s going?â€

â€œItâ€™s the only place for him to go. Even attacking Littenheimâ€™s lands or allies wouldnâ€™t draw him off of Odin, so thereâ€™s nothing he can do without ground troops to fight in the capital. The ones that arenâ€™t keeping Braunschweigâ€™s own lands in order are trapped in the corridor. Attacking Iserlohn is a threefold solutionâ€” reuniting with his forces, perhaps convincing Lichtenlade to back Braunschweig after that demonstration of power, and being able to make the threat of an alliance with the rebels to claim the throne.â€

Reuenthal was about to respond when the doorbell rang. The Dalmatian immediately lifted its hoary head from Obersteinâ€™s lap and limped over to the door of the office, waiting to investigate the visitor.Â 

â€œThe lieutenant,â€ Oberstein said, though that was obvious. It would take a long minute for the butler to retrieve the intruder and escort him to the office.Â 

â€œOf course,â€ Reuenthal said, then waited in silence, staring up at the picture of Obersteinâ€™s family. The silence pressed on him far too much, and so he asked, â€œIs that a photo of your family behind you?â€

â€œYes. Myself, my father Alfred, and my mother Emmeline.â€

Out of a morbid curiosity, he commented, â€œYou changed the color of your prosthetic.â€

â€œNo,â€ Oberstein said. â€œI still had my eyes then.â€

â€œLeigh told me you were born blind.â€

â€œI was, but not without eyes. Since the risk of complications was great for the brain implant, my mother insisted that the procedure not be performed until I was older.â€

â€œHow thoughtful of her.â€

â€œA clever blind child was easier to tolerate than a sighted idiot,â€ Oberstein said.

â€œBut you chose blue eyes.â€

â€œShe chose them. There was no reason to pick a less desirable color, and there has been no reason for me to change since.â€

Reuenthal was grateful for the sound of footsteps in the hallway, the butler and Lieutenant Kircheis. The dog let out a soft woof as the door swung open. Kircheis saluted at the entrance, though he held out his other hand for the dog to sniff, not bothered by it at all.

â€œRear Admiral Reuenthalâ€” I didnâ€™t know you were going to be here,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œWe have things to talk about, donâ€™t we?â€ Reuenthal asked.

â€œTake a seat, Lieutenant,â€ Oberstein said. Kircheis did, taking the seat next to Reuenthal. His eyes, too, lingered on the eyeballs in a cup at Obersteinâ€™s elbow, though the dog followed him to his seat, and Kircheis scratched its head absently.

â€œYouâ€™ve heard the news, I assume,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œYes, sir.â€

â€œFrom whom? You donâ€™t work in the Ministry of War, and Leigh canâ€™t contact the planet.â€

â€œRear Admiral Bronner told me.â€

â€œItâ€™s unclear who heâ€™s working for,â€ Reuenthal commented.

â€œI donâ€™t think heâ€™s working for anyone. But he tells me whatâ€™s going on, and he doesnâ€™t have any reason to lie about things I can confirm myself.â€

â€œBe careful that when you confirm things you arenâ€™t also giving him information about what you know,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œYes, sir.â€

â€œDid Leigh leave you with any instructions for this eventuality?â€ Oberstein asked.

â€œSome,â€ Kircheis said. â€œHe wrote a lot about what he thought would happen to the civilian government, but he understood that there isnâ€™t much that he can do on Odin without agents on the ground. Even the resources he hasâ€” I donâ€™t think anybody on the planet can access money from the Braunschweigs or Count Vering.â€

â€œEven if we could access money, it isnâ€™t worth much, or it wonâ€™t be.â€

â€œYes, Commodore Leigh knows that. But he couldnâ€™t keep a standing force on the planet.â€

â€œSo he wrote that we should sit on our hands,â€ Reuenthal said.Â 

â€œNo, sir,â€ Kircheis said, but didnâ€™t elaborate on what Yang had written.Â 

â€œThere are very few things that we can do,â€ Oberstein said. â€œAt best, with our limited number of allies, if it came to be that we needed to join forces with Lichtenlade, we might be able to shelter him. Or perform small guerrilla actions against Littenheimâ€™s forces.â€

â€œNone of that is necessary now,â€ Reuenthal pointed out. â€œThough we should prepare for it.â€

â€œI agree,â€ Oberstein said. He tipped his blind face towards Kircheis. â€œI understand that the commodore has already had some resources laid away?â€

Kircheis nodded, then said, â€œYes, sir,â€ for Obersteinâ€™s sake. â€œThereâ€™s caches in some of the Braunschweig familyâ€™s safehouses. I know where they are.â€

â€œLetâ€™s hope we donâ€™t need to use them,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œI agree.â€ Oberstein turned his face back towards Reuenthal. â€œThe only other thing we can do for the commodore now is coordinate. We on Odin can still speak with most other places in the galaxy, at least for now. Is there anything that Leigh needs to capture Iserlohn that we could send him?â€

There was a moment of silence. Reuenthal turned to Kircheis. â€œHis plan is a pincer attack on Iserlohn? Bait out the fleet on one side, and rush the fortress from the other?â€

â€œYes, sir.â€

â€œAnd he has enough ships in the corridor already?â€

â€œYes, sir. He believes itâ€™s enough.â€

â€œAnd who is the commander of the forces on that side of the corridor?â€

There was a moment of silence, and Kircheis said, â€œUhâ€” itâ€™s one of Duke Braunschweigâ€™sâ€” I can find his nameâ€”â€

â€œA nobody,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œIs this someone that Leigh trusts for a reason?â€

Again, for a moment, Kircheis was silent. â€œI donâ€™t believe so, sir.â€

â€œBut Leigh is confident in this plan?â€

â€œHe wanted a different commander there, sir,â€ Kircheis admitted. â€œBut Duke Braunschweig wouldnâ€™t send one before the Kaiser died.â€

â€œSo Leigh is going to try a two pronged assault without the second prong assisting. Is that what he intends?â€

â€œHeâ€” well. I think he intended to bait the rebel forces in the corridor into providing a distractionâ€” he had some system of feigned distress calls left on Cahokia for thatâ€”â€

â€œHe needs a commander there who can execute this,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œThe rebels canâ€™t be relied on.â€ Already, a plan was ticking forward in his mind, though it began with a slight sting of jealousy.

â€œAnd who do you suggest?â€ Oberstein asked.

â€œRear Admiral Mittermeyer,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œHe has ships under his command, and Leigh would vouch for his skill. We could send him a message, and he could provide the other half of Leighâ€™s pincer.â€

â€œHow would he get there?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œThere are two corridors through space, arenâ€™t there?â€

â€œThat is a difficult and long journey,â€ Oberstein said.Â 

â€œMittermeyer is capable.â€

â€œBut waiting for him to arrive will cause Littenheim to fully entrench himself on Odin.â€

â€œLet him,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œItâ€™s Muckenburger in Iserlohn who really wields the power to surrender the Imperial forces to Braunschweig, no matter what ruling power Lichtenlade claims to hold. Once heâ€™s hidden away in whatever hole he has prepared, he wonâ€™t be able to issue commands any longer, or wonâ€™t be able to enforce them, anyway.â€

â€œAnd how will we communicate to the commodore that weâ€™re putting this idea in motion for him?â€ Oberstein asked.

â€œCount Mariendorf has ways of contacting Duke Braunschweig,â€ Kircheis said. â€œHeâ€™s trying to gather support for Braunschweig with the frontier nobles. We can send a message through him.â€

â€œAnd the rear admiral himself?â€ Oberstein asked. â€œHow will he be told?â€

Reuenthalâ€™s lip curled in distaste. â€œHis wife,â€ he said. â€œShe can send him a letter any time she chooses. Thatâ€™s not out of the ordinary.â€

â€œIâ€™ll give her a message to send,â€ Kircheis volunteered. â€œCommodore Leigh told me to make sure sheâ€™s out of the city, so Iâ€™ll be seeing her anyway.â€

Reuenthal made no comment on that.

Â 

Â 

It was pitch dark outside when Reuenthal left Obersteinâ€™s house, and snowing, though the flakes that hit the windshield of his car melted and disappeared immediately. When he arrived at his house, he was unpleasantly surprised to find another car parked in the driveway: a nondescript black vehicle which bore an official fleet plate. Reuenthal drove past his house, hoping he was unnoticed, parked his car on the street some distance away, then crept up around the back.Â 

The light was on in the kitchen, but Reuenthal entered through the basement staircase, lifting the metal bunker-like door from the ground as quietly as he could, then leaving it open on the snow. He descended the steps quickly, then entered the wine cellar. He didnâ€™t bother turning on the lightâ€” he knew the place by instinct. Before he reached the front stairs up to the kitchen, he took off his shoes and pulled his sidearm from its holster, flicking off the safety.

Silently, he crept up the stairs and listened at the top.

A manâ€™s voice, someone he didnâ€™t recognize. â€œFraulein Kohlrausch, I can assure you that your grand-uncle and the rest of your family are only concerned for your safety.â€

Elfriede. â€œAnd thatâ€™s why they sent an armed man here to drag me back. To keep me in whatever prison theyâ€™ve devised.â€

â€œIt seems as though youâ€™re the one threatening me with a weapon, Fraulein.â€

â€œAnd you donâ€™t have a gun under your coat?â€ A moment of silence. â€œDonâ€™t move! Donâ€™t move at all!â€

â€œHere,â€ the man said,.Â  A thump of something heavy hitting the table, and then Elfriedeâ€™s light footsteps as she walked forward. â€œI hope youâ€™ll give that back to me when I leave.â€

â€œI thought you had been ordered to drag me out of here. Youâ€™d get it back then.â€

â€œI wouldnâ€™t do that to a friend of a friend,â€ the man said. â€œThat is why I volunteered to come, rather than someone else.â€

â€œAnd whose friend are you?â€

â€œCountess von Leighâ€™s.â€

Elfriede made a dismissive sound. â€œSheâ€™s not my friend. And she didnâ€™t tell me you were coming. I donâ€™t really believe you.â€

â€œIf you wonâ€™t come back with me, Iâ€™ll tell your grand-uncle that I couldnâ€™t find you. But Iâ€™m afraid that Iâ€™ll be signing your death sentence by doing so. You are aware that Rear Admiral Reuenthal is known to be an agent of Duke Braunschweigâ€™s? This place wonâ€™t be safe, when his enemies arrive.â€

Elfriedeâ€™s voice rose in pitch. â€œYouâ€™re very stupid if you think that my grand-uncle has a better chance of surviving than I do.â€

â€œHeâ€™s going to be well protected.â€

â€œI know where heâ€™s going,â€ Elfriede said. â€œIâ€™m not as confident as he is. And Iâ€™m not the kind of animal to walk into a cage.â€

â€œAnd what is this house?â€ the man asked. â€œIâ€™m told you donâ€™t ever go out.â€

Reuenthal was tempted to emerge from the staircase into the kitchen, but he waited. He wanted to hear what she would say.

â€œIâ€™m the kind of animal that will chew her leg off to get out of a trap,â€ she said.

â€œSo you think you could leave here, if you needed to, or wanted to?â€

She laughed. â€œYou misunderstand me.â€

â€œI apologize.â€

â€œThis is me using my teeth,â€ she said.

The man seemed at a loss for words for a moment. â€œYou could be a poet, Fraulein.â€

There was the sound of something hitting the table again, though thrown from a few feet away this time. â€œYou should leave now. Heâ€™ll be home soon, and you donâ€™t want to be here when he is.â€

â€œI would like to meet the Rear Admiral. I have a message for him.â€

â€œNo, you donâ€™t.â€

â€œMay I have the energy pack?â€

â€œNo.â€

Footsteps. â€œYour grand-uncle does care about you, and so does the rest of your family,â€ the man said. â€œIf you change your mind, you know where you can go.â€

â€œI wonâ€™t,â€ she said. â€œAnd donâ€™t come looking for me again.â€

â€œOther people wonâ€™t be quite so willing to let you slip out of their hands,â€ he said.

â€œI donâ€™t like threats, Captain. You should leave.â€

â€œGoodnight, Fraulein.â€ He walked to the front door. Reuenthal heard it creak open. â€œI hope youâ€™re correct.â€

â€œAbout what?â€

â€œThe cages,â€ he said. The front door shut, and Elfriedeâ€™s footsteps crossed the kitchen floor once again. A chair creaked as she sat down at the table, and then there was silence.Â 

Reuenthal waited for some time before creeping back down the stairs, climbing out of the basement, and retrieving his car. He parked it in the driveway and entered the house through the kitchen door, as was his usual route. He found Elfriede sitting at the table in her diaphanous white nightgown, the one that had once belonged to his mother, which she had found somewhere in the house. One of the large kitchen knives was on the table in front of her, and she seemed to be staring down at her reflection in the blade.

â€œPlanning to stab me?â€ Reuenthal asked. The words snapped her out of whatever trance she was in, and she grabbed the knife.Â 

â€œCastrate you,â€ she said. There wasnâ€™t enough venom in it, so he answered in kind as he took off his coat.

â€œYouâ€™re about twenty years too late to make me sing like a castrati, and I have no interest in children anyway.â€

She laughed, but there was a wild edge to the sound.

Reuenthal went to stand over by the sink, looking out the window at the darkness. â€œLeigh beat Littenheim in space.â€

â€œReally?â€ She knew this already. She was planning to lie to him. He wondered what the best time to reveal that he knew about her visitor would be.

â€œLittenheimâ€™s retreating to Odin. Heâ€™ll be here in a few days.â€

â€œAre you afraid?â€ she taunted. This, too, came out wrong.

He walked up behind her, and slid his hands down her arms until he reached her hands, still holding the knife upright in front of herself, the butt of the handle resting on the table. His chest pressed against her back, and he could feel her breathing.

â€œLittenheim is walking himself into a trap. Heâ€™s not going to get out alive,â€ Reuenthal said.

She tensed beneath him. â€œHe doesnâ€™t think that way.â€

â€œNobody ever does.â€

â€œThatâ€™s not true.â€

â€œOh?â€ His hands tightened on her wrists. â€œAre you a counterexample?â€

â€œNo. But you are.â€

â€œIn what way?â€

â€œWhat are you doing here?â€ she asked. â€œIn this house?â€

â€œWith you?â€

â€œYes.â€

â€œTell me what Iâ€™m doing, if you have something to say about it.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t think thereâ€™s a world outside the trap, so you pretend youâ€™re strong to stay alive inside it.â€ She laughed again. â€œIâ€™m not as stupid as you are, Oskar.â€

â€œAnd are you going to say youâ€™re stronger than me, too?â€ He crushed her wrists with his hands, but she didnâ€™t loosen her grip on the knife. He wasnâ€™t sure that he wanted her to.

â€œItâ€™s a weakness that runs in your family,â€ she said. â€œYour motherâ€”â€

â€œWhat about her?â€

â€œNevermind.â€

â€œNo, tell me.â€

With surprising strength, Elfriede lifted her arms off the table, swinging the tip of the knife abruptly towards Reuenthalâ€™s face. The sight of the blade coming towards his eye horrified him, and he let go of her and stumbled back. She let her hands fall back down to the table, and dropped the knife with a clatter.

â€œYou said she almost killed you,â€ Elfriede said.

Reuenthal tried to compose himself, walked around in front of Elfriede, and picked up the knife. She didnâ€™t try to stop him, though she watched him. Testing himself, Reuenthal brought the blade to the corner of his brown eye. â€œShe almost cut it out,â€ he said. â€œShe wasnâ€™t trying to kill me.â€

â€œShe would have been free if she had.â€

Reuenthal pressed the knife to the skin at the corner of his eye, still over the bone. The blade was dullâ€” it would take real effort to cut, unless his hand slipped, but his hand was very steady. â€œGetting rid of the evidence wouldnâ€™t free her from her sin.â€

Elfriedeâ€™s face twisted in disgust, and she stood. â€œThatâ€™s not what Iâ€™m talking about.â€

As she started to walk away, Reuenthal grabbed her. She didnâ€™t struggle, but she did tense, genuinely afraid this time. Reuenthal held the knife to her chin, the point pressing into her skin.Â 

â€œWere you not going to tell me about your visitor?â€ Reuenthal asked.

She breathed heavily in his arms for a moment before she said anything. â€œDid he wait on the street for you?â€Â 

Although Reuenthal held the knife steady, talking made it prick her skin. A drop of blood slipped down the edge of the blade.

â€œNo,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œI saw there was someone in the house, so I came in through the basement.â€

â€œYou wanted to catch me in the act.â€

The idea that Elfriede might be cheating on him hadnâ€™t crossed his mind, and was almost laughable. â€œYes,â€ he said.Â 

With his other hand, he pulled up her nightgown, slipped his hand underneath it, and trailed his hand across the smooth expanse of her stomach until he reached her breast, which he squeezed roughly.

â€œHow much of the conversation did you hear?â€ she asked.

â€œEnough.â€

â€œThen you know I wasnâ€™t planning to leave you.â€ She struggled against him, but it wasnâ€™t with real force, and Reuenthal kept the knife to her chin until she pushed his arm down.

He dropped the knife back to the kitchen table. â€œWhatever captain that was is right.â€

She made a noise of disagreement and pushed against him, trying again to get out of his arms. â€œI donâ€™t care,â€ she said. â€œYouâ€™re not going to send me back to my family.â€

â€œNo,â€ he said. â€œBut you shouldnâ€™t stay in the city. Weâ€™re both enemies of Littenheim.â€

She snarled. â€œIâ€™m not going to be locked up in some hole.â€

â€œFine,â€ he said, and he let her go. She stumbled forward a few steps, and turned back towards him, but he was already walking away. She didnâ€™t follow him all the way to his office, where he spent the remainder of the evening, poring over the information that Kircheis and Bergengrun had provided. Although he looked at it carefully, he couldnâ€™t keep other thoughts from drifting through his head.

When he got ready for bed, he leaned on the counter in the bathroom, nude, staring into his own reflection. He pulled down the lower lid of his eye with one finger, looking at the veiny underside of his eyeball, the red flesh, imagining it replaced with an empty hollowâ€” or a blue replacement. The thought sickened him.

The door to the bathroom was ajar, and Elfriede walked past, then stopped as she saw him performing this strange little ritual. She entered the bathroom and sat on the counter next to where he leaned. Delicately, she replaced her finger with his on his face. He kept looking straight ahead, into his reflection. She kept the lid of his eye pulled down.

â€œYou told that captain that youâ€™d bite off your leg to get out of a trap,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œYes.â€

â€œYour station for your freedom?â€

â€œOr something like it,â€ she said.

â€œAnd you say Iâ€™m keeping myself in a trap.â€

â€œYes.â€

â€œWhat would I have to give up to get out of it?â€

â€œNothing as easy as cutting out your eye,â€ she said. She shifted her hand so that she was covering his eye with her palm. He closed his eyes.

â€œWhat, then?â€

She didnâ€™t answer the question. Her other hand found his hair and stroked it, oddly tender. â€œWhere would you say that I should hide, when Littenheim arrives?â€

â€œThe country house where Leighâ€™s wife is,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œLeigh thinks itâ€™s safe enough there.â€

â€œAnd will you come?â€

â€œNo,â€ he said.

Chapter End Notes

i reserve the right to title a different chapter after this bible verse, and also to write a different chapter about how reuenthal feels about oberstein's eyes lol. sometimes i need more room to work over an idea but it also fits here so i'll put it in here

this chapter's pretty short b/c it's really the first half of events on odin during littenheim's invasion. next chapter will belong to somebody else. but we haven't had a reuenthal chapter in aaaages so.

one guess as to who the captain was who visited elfriede lol

elfriede thinks that she is out of the labyrinth. she is wrong. reuenthal thinks that there's no way out of the labyrinth. he might be right but he has probably arrived at this conclusion for the wrong reasons.

thank you so much to em for the beta read as always

you can find me on tumblr @ javert , on twitter @ natsinator, gayspaceopera.carrd.co , and on discord https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

Leaving the City

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

December 488 I.C., Odin

The apartment Evangeline Mittermeyer shared with her husband was not large or ostentatiousâ€” in fact, it was smaller and cheaper than the lodgings of probably any other rear admiral in the Imperial fleetâ€” but it was home. The walls held photographs of friends and family, interspersed with paintings that Eva herself had made, or that she found particularly pleasing. The wooden floors were warmed by colorful woven rugs, and every afternoon she would make her rounds watering the flowering plants that hung in macrame bowls near the windows. Even though her husband was often away, she tried to make the place a haven, one where she never felt lonely . Her home was cheerful and warm, and if she ever needed, she could call on any number of friends to visit.Â 

Most of the time, this worked. Or she pretended it worked, which would have to be enough.

But now, as December closed in on Odin, that last comfort seemed to have fallen away. It had been ebbing ever since her husband had been sent off on his most recent dutyâ€” out to an experimental starship construction facility. It was somewhere that she couldnâ€™t locate on a map no matter how many times Wolf pointed out to her the star in the night sky that it orbited. Her sense of peace had throbbed keenly when the Kaiser died, and Hank had left the planet with only a text message of warning. Maggie departed the capital city not long after, headed for a countryside retreat.Â 

But now none of that sense of calm remained. Eva had clung to normalcy as much as she could, but it had slipped out of her grip at last.

She stood at the window and anxiously pulled back the curtains with one hand, looking up into the night. Flakes of snow were drifting down, but even through the thin cloud cover, bright flashes of light illuminated the horizon and sky aboveâ€” a battle that was raging right up to the edge of the planetâ€™s atmosphere. Odinâ€™s surface defensive guns were shooting at Marquis Littenheimâ€™s ships as they descended towards the city. Even at this great distance, even through the thick glass of her window, Eva could smell the harsh ozone created by the guns blasting through the air.Â 

Her other hand clutched at her tablet, and she kept waking up the screen with her thumb every time it went dim. It was open to her messages, and one long message from her husband in particular.

The beginning half of the letter was a response to Lieutenant Kircheis, telling Eva to reassure him that the coded message she had helped pass was understood, and that he was going to act on it. The second half of the letter was personal. Although Eva tended to read his letters many times in general, this one had not left her hand since she received it, and she kept looking at it over and over, trying to divine its meaning.

Â 

Eva, I know Iâ€™ve said it a hundred million times before, but I canâ€™t tell you how much you mean to me. If I had a way with words like Leigh does, Iâ€™d figure some way out to write it down. Maybe youâ€™re like the stars in the sky, or I need you like I need to breathe, or something like that. Iâ€™m not a poet, and maybe thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m a soldier. Even when Iâ€™m trapped out here tinkering with machines, pretending not to be a soldier for a while, I donâ€™t have to think too much about the heart and the things it does. Thatâ€™s good, because if I think about it too much, I start missing you more than I can bear.

I know I can bear it, but I donâ€™t want to have to. Itâ€™s hard not to know when Iâ€™ll get to see you again. I hope this little war is over quickly, and Leigh does too, but thereâ€™s no way for me to say for sure if it will be. Thatâ€™s what makes it difficultâ€” not knowing when weâ€™ll get out the other side.

I keep thinking about this conversation I had with Reuenthal before Leighâ€™s wedding. We were talking about what things would be like after all of this. Back then, I told him that I didnâ€™t know what life would look like. I couldnâ€™t picture it, and I just wanted to be happy. But I think Iâ€™ve figured it out, what I want. Itâ€™s the kind of thing I always dream of when Iâ€™m out in space, but I think itâ€™s worse this time because Iâ€™m by myselfâ€” it makes me see things differently.

I know if Leigh was reading this letter heâ€™d be sighing and giving me that funny little smile he hasâ€” Iâ€™ve had this conversation with him more times than I can really count, and I donâ€™t know how he stays patient with me. Itâ€™s what I talked about with him when I ran away to stay at his house after proposing to youâ€” do you remember that? It felt like the right thing to do at the time, but in hindsight I know it must have made me look stupid. Mom later said it must have just been that I stomped all my nerves down so that I could go through with asking, and then as soon as the pressure stopped holding them in, they exploded, regardless of you saying yes. That wasnâ€™t it, but it makes more sense than what it was that made me run away.

I think I need to stop doing this. Iâ€™ve triedâ€” gods know Iâ€™ve triedâ€” before, but Iâ€™ve never managed to do it. Maybe thatâ€™s because Iâ€™m always having this conversation with Leigh instead of with you. When I get home, when all this is over, I should talk about it with you.Â 

I donâ€™t think it will be too long until then. This war canâ€™t last very long, and Leigh is going to win, and thenâ€” it can be a different world we live in. Leighâ€™s dreaming of something tooâ€” he wants to sue for peace with the rebels. Maybe then us soldiers will be out of a job. That might be a good thing.

Please stay safe on Odin. If Leighâ€™s little lieutenant tells you to do somethingâ€” do it. Or Reuenthal. I know he can be difficult, but he would help you if you needed help.Â 

I love you so much, forever and always,

Your Wolf

Â 

The letter felt like the direst possible portent. It had always seemed like bad luck, as a soldierâ€™s wife, to ever discuss anything but the most mundane things that would happen â€œafterâ€ a deployment. She never wanted to make a promise that could be broken by fate, and it seemed unbelievably cruel to make her wait for whatever he wanted to talk about, to bring up the subject and leave her with the responsibility of holding its weight.

It wasnâ€™t that she didnâ€™t know. She knew.

At least, she knew the shape of it, off in the distance, like a shadow on the wall. She couldnâ€™t see what was casting it, but she knew it was there. When she had become aware of it, she couldnâ€™t quite say. Had it been since before she had been married? Yes, probably.

She had read it in his eyes the day he proposed to her. That warm, bright May day, five years ago, standing in the garden behind the house. He had been so afraidâ€” not afraid of her, but afraid of himself. His hands shook when he held out the flowers to her, and he asked to marry her like he was asking for forgiveness.Â 

On the night of Maggie and Hankâ€™s wedding, having been reminded of the subject by the events of the day, she had felt bold enough to ask him about that. They had come home exhausted and a little drunk, falling onto the couch in a tangle of limbs, still in their party clothes. The rain had been beating down at the window that night.

â€œDid you enjoy the wedding?â€ Wolf asked her as she lay on his lap, looking up into his eyes. He should have tried to get her dress off, but both of them were too tired to move, yet too awake to make their way to bed. It was a strange mood that gripped her.

â€œI did,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™m so happy for them.â€

Wolf smiledâ€” funnyâ€” the melancholy coming out when tiredness allowed it. â€œTheyâ€™re a good match. It took them long enough.â€

â€œMaybe they were right to wait until now, and you were in a rush,â€ she said with an answering smile. She reached up one lazy hand and brushed her fingers through his hair.

â€œMaybe.â€

â€œI would have waited for you, you know,â€ she said. â€œYou were so nervous that day you asked me. You didnâ€™t have to be.â€

â€œIf I hadnâ€™t gotten my courage up then, Iâ€™m not sure I ever would have.â€

â€œMmm.â€ She let her arm fall back down, and picked up his hand, heavy and warm. She kissed his knuckles, then held it to her chest. â€œI donâ€™t understand why you were so afraid. Didnâ€™t you know I would say yes?â€

He was quiet for a long time, which was unusual for him. Only the movement of his thumb on her hand made it clear that he hadnâ€™t fallen asleep right where he sat. â€œI was afraid because I knew that,â€ he said.

â€œThatâ€™s very silly, Wolf.â€ She kissed his hand again.

â€œNoâ€” Iâ€”â€

She waited, squeezing his fingers gently.

â€œIt seemed like I wasnâ€™t giving you a real choice,â€ he said. â€œI knew you would say yesâ€” that made me feel bad for asking.â€

She splayed out his fingers and pressed his hand to her cheek. â€œI said yes because I love you, and wanted to marry you,â€ she said. â€œI had already made my choice, and I was glad to do it.â€

That had been the end of the conversation, but it had stuck with her since, and came back to her now as she stared out at Littenheimâ€™s ships descending through the sky.

Wolfâ€™s secretsâ€” she loved him enough that she was willing to ignore that lurking it in the corner of her life. It sometimes seemed like he was taking refuge in her arms from it , and there was a part of her that was pleased to feel like she could provide that, some shelter from whatever storm was chasing him.

She tried not to think about what it was, though she had her suspicions. Hank clearly knew, and so did Wolfâ€™s friend Reuenthal. She couldnâ€™t blame them for keeping his confidenceâ€” though Hank, especially, was apologetic whenever the subject slid sideways into their conversations. Even Reuenthal was frustrated with whatever Wolfâ€™s secret shame was. She recalled his annoyance when they had spoken at the Solstice party the previous December: â€œYou should tell your husband to stop keeping secrets.â€

Eva had this fantasy, or nightmare, about what the secret wasâ€” trying to fit all the clues together in her mind, or perhaps just dreaming of the thing that lived exactly on the edge of desire and misery. Maybe, she thought, he didnâ€™t tell her the secret because it would make her too sadâ€” the one thing she desperately wanted but could not give. Perhaps Wolf, as a boy in school, had fathered a child with some other woman, one that his friends knew about.

She sometimes pictured this child in her mindâ€” always imagining a little girl. She might be ten now, looking just like her fatherâ€” blonde hair pulled by the windâ€™s fingers when she ran, laughing, into some womanâ€™s arms. The image made her weep, when it came to her strongly. Not so much out of jealousy, for this piece of her husband that some other woman had, but for the ten years she, too, might have known that child and loved her. She would have loved her as her own, Eva thought. She could have. There was no vindictive bone in her body; she felt entirely suffused with love, so much so that it wounded her, having nowhere to put it and no one to give it to.

Eva was not a very religious woman, but on holidays when she might go to the temple, sheâ€™d sometimes look up at the statue of the goddess Freyja and think a silent prayer for the health of the child. That was all she didâ€” she never mentioned it to Wolf.

She said one of those prayers now, watching the ships come down. They were through the clouds nowâ€” the first dark underbellies sinking through the sky, looking for any patch of open ground to land on. They werenâ€™t headed towards the airfieldâ€” she could see them descending over the great park in the center of the capital city, and anywhere else that one of their bulks could fit. In hours, if not minutes, there would be soldiers in the streets.Â 

Hours before, she had seen tanks trundle down the road, setting up blockades to protect important buildings, traps on the bridges, and barriers on the streets. Watching all this happen, Eva knew that she should have taken Lieutenant Kircheisâ€™s advice and left the city days ago, but something had stopped her. She had told him that she would wait. She was hoping that Wolf would send her another message, but he didnâ€™t, and now it was too late. There would likely be no more communication with anyone for a while, and Wolf was probably already on his way to Iserlohn.

She had, at least, packed her bag, so she was ready when she heard the quiet knock on her door, though it still made her jump. She reluctantly dropped the curtain back down and went to open the door. There was Lieutenant Kircheis, smiling wanly down at herâ€” he really was so tall.

â€œGood evening, Frau Mittermeyer,â€ he said. â€œMay I come in?â€

â€œIf youâ€™re here to tell me itâ€™s time to leave, I packed my bag,â€ she said, but she held out the door so that he could step inside her apartment. Although he had been here before, checking up on her for Hank and her husband, he still moved himself very delicately, as if aware of his size and not wanting to break anything in her space. Eva wished she could see the apartment with his eyes instead of her ownâ€” a strangerâ€™s place, rather than a home that she did not want to leave.

â€œIâ€™m afraid that we canâ€™t leave the capital today,â€ Kircheis said. â€œThe roads are all blocked.â€

She half pretended not to hear him. â€œCan I offer you some tea?â€ she asked.

â€œNo, thank you, Frau Mittermeyer. We should get moving. This wonâ€™t be easier if we wait.â€

â€œWhere are you taking me, if we canâ€™t leave the city?â€

â€œWe canâ€™t leave by road, but we should be able to get out on foot in a few days. I arranged for Fraulein Mariendorf to meet us with a car outside the city,â€ Kircheis said. â€œUntil then, weâ€™ll wait in one of the safehouses that the Braunschweig family had preparedâ€” it has a basement, in case there are bombings.â€

â€œWe can drive there?â€

â€œPartway,â€ Kircheis said. â€œWeâ€™ll probably have to leave the car somewhere when we get close to the city limitsâ€” I saw that the traffic from people trying to leave on the highways has blocked up into the main streets. Nobody can get out, but nobody can turn around either.â€

â€œAlright.â€ She said that as if it was somehow alright. It wasnâ€™t at all. Kircheis seemed calm, and she tried to be calm as well, but she wasnâ€™t used to this. She wanted Wolf with her, not this boy, even if the boy was someone that Hank trusted.

She disappeared into her bedroom for a minute, leaving Kircheis standing in the middle of her living room with his hands behind his back. Distantly, from far off in the city, there was a bone-groaning deep boom, one that made the windows rattle in their frames. When she came back into the living room, bag in hand, she found Kircheis looking out the window, in the same posture that she had been in earlier.Â 

â€œWhat was that?â€ she asked.

â€œA ship went down,â€ Kirchesis said. He pointed to the horizon, where there was the glow of a fire burning in unnatural greens and purples, and the beginnings of a pillar of black smoke beginning to form. She looked at it, and Kircheis must have seen her tremble, or give some other sign of fear, because he said, â€œItâ€™s alright, Frau Mittermeyer. Iâ€™ve got you. But we should go.â€

â€œYes, right.â€ She pulled on her coat. â€œIs there anythingâ€”â€ She looked around the apartment in despair, turning in a circle and looking at it all like she would never see it again. Her hands twitched out towards things, as if to grab them, but there was nothing else she could bring. The plants in their macrame bowls would wilt and die when she left.

â€œIf you need something later, I can get it for you,â€ Kircheis said.Â 

â€œAlright,â€ she said. â€œAlright.â€

She took her keys from the side of the fridge, and shut off all the lights and locked the doors. When they were in the hallway, there was another boom, louder, closer, but they couldnâ€™t see it. Kircheis took her elbow and steered her out of the apartment, down towards the parking garage.

They took her car, but Kircheis drove. He seemed to have knowledge of what streets were blocked and which were passable, because he took a circuitous route, weaving down side streets and moving in a great circle around the edge of the city. As they passed beneath the highway overpass which headed towards the river bridge, Eva could see above them the stalled line of car headlights, tracing the line of the bridge even though the decorative lights it usually bore were off. Some dark shadows walked along the edge of the bridge, both directions, fleeing for safety or changing their minds. In the center of the city, the roads had been almost deserted, and no lights were on in the windows, but as they got further towards the edge, Kircheis was right that the roads filled more and more, people disobeying any traffic laws and going wherever their cars would take them.

Kircheis was headed in a northerly direction. Northâ€” there were smaller bridge crossings many kilometers away, ones that might not be blocked with cars. But the highway there was inaccessible, and eventually Kircheis gave up on driving. He pulled her car to a parkâ€” a little place Eva had never been before, with the childrenâ€™s swingset off in the distance, and the bare trees huddled against the snow. He hopped the curb, which made her yelp, and parked her car in a drift of snow beneath an old barren oak.Â 

â€œMaybe no one will hit it, if itâ€™s not on the street,â€ he said, and then handed her the keys.

â€œAlright.â€ It seemed like the only thing that she could say.Â 

â€œItâ€™s about four kilometers from here. Can you make it that far?â€

â€œYes.â€ She had put on boots, at least, and that made the going on the slick road easier. She walked pressed to the buildings, and Kircheis stood between her and the road, where the barely illuminated forms of car drivers menaced the few pedestrians who hurried through the line of barely moving cars.Â 

Behind them, the sounds of the fighting had grown fiercer, and now a fine ash was mingling in with the snow that fell. Kircheis gave her his scarf, to pull over her nose when he noticed it accumulating as a crust on the freshly fallen snow on railings and the tops of garbage cans. She thought of protesting, and saying that he should have it, but she knew he wouldnâ€™t allow her to do so.

â€œYou arenâ€™t afraid,â€ she said as they walked. Maybe conversation would keep her mind off the terror at the back of her head.

â€œIâ€™ve done this before, Frau Mittermeyer,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œWhen?â€

â€œWhen Commodore Leigh rescued Count Mariendorf from Lord Castrop. When the Imperial fleet landed on Castropâ€™s planet, it wasâ€”â€ He cut himself off and said nothing more.

Above them, a ship that had been hit by planetary fire and was half destroyed but still somehow fighting for a place in the air, came close enough to them that if the buildings around them had been any taller, it would have knocked their tips off. Its engines lit the scene with a devilâ€™s furnace glow, casting wild shadows in its bright orange light for the moment that it was overhead, before it disappeared over the buildings. They could still hear it after it was out of sight, a creaking and keening sound of its structure fighting the wind and gravity.

â€œDoes your family live in the capital?â€ Eva asked.

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said. â€œA couple districts away.Theyâ€™ll be safe. Littenheim doesnâ€™t have enough of an army to occupy much other than this city.â€

â€œThatâ€™s good.â€

They kept walking. The ship that had flown above them crashed in the distance, though the tearing of metal as it hit the ground was audible from kilometers away. Any screaming that might have accompanied it was swallowed by the distance. Cars around them tried to turn and head the other direction, but none could go anywhere, and one by one they began to open their doors, disgorging panicked pedestrians onto the streets. Kircheis grabbed Evaâ€™s arm, and they picked up the pace, moving quickly enough that Eva didnâ€™t have breath for conversation, or focus for anything other than keeping her feet in front of herself. She had no idea where she was.

Kircheis held her arm gently with his right hand, but produced a gun and held it with his left. Eva almost didnâ€™t noticeâ€” he kept his arm at his sideâ€” but when they turned a corner she saw him move his arm just enough for it to catch the light, and recognized the gleam of the metal. Was he left handed?

They came to a nondescript looking warehouse in between two different car repair places. It could have belonged to either business, but it seemed to belong to neither. Kircheis looked all around, pulled her through an alley, then opened the back door with a combination on a pad. The door buzzed open, and they entered. It smelled industrial, like old greasy metal, and all the lights were offâ€” only what light came in through the skylights illuminated the scene. There were crates and boxes, all closed, and some vehiclesâ€” cars, though some motorbikes, too, and a truck without a trailer.

Kircheis didnâ€™t relax, even though they had made it to their destination. He led her down a set of stairs into a basement area, which was well lit, and had people in it. There were a few that Evangeline didnâ€™t recognize, all men with the look of soldiers, though none were in uniform. They stood around or sat on the couch against the wall. Only one face was familiar to her.

Evangeline never thought she would be happy to see Rear Admiral Reuenthal, but she couldnâ€™t deny that the relief she felt was real. He was sitting at a table in the corner, a military radio at his elbow spitting out garbled and incomprehensible updates, while he looked at a paper map of the city. A sheet of plastic was laid on top of it, and he drew lines on that with a marker. He didnâ€™t acknowledge her and Kircheis at all, except to look up at them briefly and then back down at the map.

â€œMake yourself at home,â€ Kircheis said. â€œThereâ€™s food over there, and the bathrooms, andâ€”â€ He pointed over to the back corner of the basement, where there were some cots set up. Flimsy privacy curtains stood against the walls, and would need to be moved into place. â€œThese are some of the rest of Duke Braunschweigâ€™s staff who stayed on the planet, and some of Rear Admiral Reuenthalâ€™s men. Iâ€™ll introduce you.â€

Eva nodded mutely and let Kircheis show her around so that she could say hello. Most of the men didnâ€™t care about her one way or the other, and they went back to their own business as soon as she took a seat on one of the cots in the back of the room. She clutched her single bag of possessions to her chest and watched the men as they talked in quiet voices and listened to the radio. Occasionally the ground rumbled as something happened outside, making her flinch each time. Kircheis occasionally glanced over at her with some concern, but she busied herself with looking at her tablet, reading the letter from Wolf over again.

Over the course of the evening, the men who had been in the place trickled out, either sent out by Reuenthal or going on their own errands and business. She didnâ€™t know if theyâ€™d be backâ€” none of them announced their departure. A silence interrupted only by the radio fell over their little hideout. Kircheis kept trying to make a phone call, but either the reception was too bad in the basement, or the lines were dead. He gave a short explanation that he was going out to see if he could get through, and then left.Â 

It was then just Eva and Reuenthal. The space suddenly felt like a set on a stageâ€” it was the lighting that did it, she thought.

â€œIs Fraulein Kohlraush with her family?â€ Eva asked, breaking the silence. Reuenthalâ€™s marker squeaked across the map in front of him.

â€œNo,â€ he said. â€œSheâ€™s in the same safe house youâ€™re going to, with Countess Leigh.â€

â€œOh. I didnâ€™t know that.â€

Reuenthal said nothing else, but after a minute got up and poured some coffee from the pot on the counter. He poured two mugs and brought one to her. She had to put down her tablet to take it, and he saw what she was looking atâ€” the long message from Wolf. He couldnâ€™t possibly have read any of the words, standing above her as he was, but he could guess at the sender.

â€œLieutenant Kircheis told me that Mittermeyer is on his way to Iserlohn,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œYou understood that from whatever letter he sent?â€

â€œI did,â€ she said. â€œIt was your plan for him to go?â€

Reuenthal gave a half nodâ€” confirmation, but not asking for too much credit.

â€œWhy didnâ€™t you write to him?â€
