Interlude: The People Next Door Will Close In Like a Wolf Pack

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

February 489 I.C., Phezzan

Years ago, if anyone had asked Commander Neidhardt Muller if he would miss any of the cast of characters who rotated in and out of the Alliance embassy on Phezzan, he would have laughed and said that his posting on Phezzan was interesting for the weather, and the entertainment, and the liberated Phezzani womenâ€” not for whatever the Alliance was doing. Even now, he still would have said that line, and did: it was a useful reply to have on hand when someone at a party asked him what he enjoyed about his posting on Phezzan, and if he ever intended to go back home, and what he thought about his counterparts from the other side of the galaxy. His time on Phezzan had taught him a lot of things, and telling charming lies at a party was one of the first lessons he learned.

The trouble was that he did miss Reinhard von MÃ¼sel, who had left his post at the Alliance embassy well over a year beforehand. Not that they had been particular friendsâ€” their relationship, such as it was, was contentious even at the best of timesâ€” but MÃ¼sel had been a source of information, and entertaining besides that. There was a part of Muller that wondered if MÃ¼sel missed him just as much, doing whatever it was he was doing over in the Alliance. He doubted it, but it was fun to wonder.

Muller had tried his best to keep track of what had become of MÃ¼sel. He had been dismissed from Phezzan to attend some kind of inquiry on Heinessen, which had to do with the Castrop affair, and, Muller suspected, MÃ¼selâ€™s willingness to allow Imperial prisoners to walk free on his request. That was all Muller had learned about itâ€” the actual proceedings were the kind of secrets that didnâ€™t make their way to Phezzanâ€™s Imperial embassy, and it wasnâ€™t like MÃ¼sel was going to write him to say how it all turned out. After that, from going over crew posting lists with a fine tooth comb, Muller determined that he had been sent to the front. From there, MÃ¼sel vanished from his radar almost completely. This wasnâ€™t unusual, but it did make him a little wistful, not knowing what the man was up to. At least he knew that he was still alive out thereâ€” his pseudonymous blog still updated about once every month and a half. This was far less frequently than it had in the past, and it contained even less personal information than it used to, but the posts still read like MÃ¼sel was trying out concepts for a doctoral thesis, and Muller still read them all, cheap Phezzani beer in hand.

Like so many other things in Mullerâ€™s life, the blog posts from â€œMarian Evansâ€ seemed to exist in a bubble where nothing had yet gone wrong, and Muller was standing inside that bubble, watching everything tumble down around him. Somehow, ever since the Kaiserâ€™s death, MÃ¼sel had managed to avoid talking about the complete economic chaos that was sweeping the galaxy, despite half the comments on his posts asking for his (or her, since his writer persona was a woman) thoughts on the matter. (Muller doubted that MÃ¼sel looked at his Phezzani comment section at all, which was one of the only things that stopped him from leaving his own remarks.) It was deeply strange that MÃ¼sel refused to talk about it, since even among the economically disinterestedâ€” which comprised most of the Imperial Embassy staff on Phezzanâ€” it was a topic of conversation.

When Kaiser Friedrich died without a clear successor, things in the Empire had ground to an almost complete standstill. At first, it hadnâ€™t been too badâ€” there was an influx of immigration to Phezzan, most of it â€œtemporaryâ€, as many members of the upper class who didnâ€™t want to be around for civil war found a place to escape to. They brought their assets with them, and froze what they couldnâ€™t carry. Nobles who remained began to take on a personally isolationist policyâ€” keeping whatever their lands produced, rather than trying to sell. That was one thing, Muller thought, that was positive about the feudal systemâ€” each planet could be self sustaining for quite some time, and the lives of the peasants wouldnâ€™t change much. The Empireâ€™s steady flow of trade began to fall apart, with the remaining Imperial government unable to control its movement (and certainly unable to tax it). What remained was essentially a black market between individual planets and families, those allied to each other sharing resources. But these tenuous supply lines were vulnerable, and also inaccessible to Phezzan.

Phezzan had a great deal of its own economy tied up in the Empireâ€” a lot in trade, but a not-insignificant amount of it in the form of loans, which abruptly stopped returning interest as no one in the Empire could pay them. In normal years, Phezzan also functioned as a kind of clearing house for Imperial goodsâ€” importing from noble families, either raw materials or finished products, and then re-selling them within the Empire.Â 

The merchant class of the Empire had almost completely been absorbed into Phezzanâ€™s economy. This was something that MÃ¼sel had written about extensively on his blog, many years before, and Muller called the memory of it to mind when thinking about the current situation. With such a sharp divide between nobility and peasantry, the middle class of the Empire was small, and social mobility was limited. The educated middle class tended to be concentrated in urban areas, primarily on Odin, and almost exclusively functioned as a quasi-artisan class, with work often tied to specific noble families. The only form of class mobility was through the Fleet, and even that was highly restrictive. Those who managed to gather the wealth to form part of a mercantile class were welcomed with open arms by Phezzan, while they had no way to move forward into the upper echelons of Imperial society. Over time, it had become somewhat self defeatingâ€” with no existing social structure to support a merchant fleet, all business went through Phezzan, which further reduced the space available for tradesmen to become merchants. This system had calcified within two generations of the settlement of Phezzan, and no one in the Empire had cared enough to put policies in place to change it. That, too, was a combination of factors: the nobility had reason to protect their class position within the Empire, and Phezzan had reason to discourage the Empire from working to loosen their near-stranglehold on Imperial goods.

Although MÃ¼sel, in his writing, had described the system with nothing but contempt, Muller thought that it seemed to work well, at least up until this point. After all, even if it gave Phezzan power over the Empire, the reason they had that power was the same reason that they were compelled not to exercise it: their economic fortunes were completely tied together. And Muller could certainly understand what the appeal was for every individual involved, beyond the rational calculations of money moving through the galaxyâ€” there was a reason he enjoyed his post on Phezzan so much. Not having a â€˜vonâ€™ in his name meant less on Phezzan than it did in almost any other officerâ€™s posting.Â 

Mullerâ€™s father was a member of the tiny educated middle classâ€” a doctor. He had encouraged him as a child to find some livelihood that would keep him equally well fed, and Muller had been talented enough to earn a seat at the IOA. He sometimes wondered what he would have done if he hadnâ€™t scored well on the entrance examâ€” would he have ended up on Phezzan after all, only as someone working in the offices of one of their conglomerates? He didnâ€™t know. It was very funny to picture himself as a salarymanâ€” like he had been amused several years ago watching MÃ¼sel put on a suit and fake glasses to attend all his interviews with Phezzani mining companies.

As far as the Allianceâ€™s economy went, they were just as invested in Phezzan as the Empire was, if in a different way. It was funny how closely the two sides of the galaxy was tied together, considering the Empire and the Alliance were permanent enemies, and had been at war for well over a hundred years.Â 

The Phezzani currency, called charges, was a smoke and mirrors way for Phezzan to use the real value that they siphoned off of the Empireâ€™s trade as a lever in the Alliance economy. When Imperial goods were passed through Phezzan, though the business between parties was usually conducted in Reichsmarks, Phezzan extracted a sales tax. Phezzan used this extracted value from the Empireâ€™s economy as a backing for issuing its own currency. In the early days of Phezzanâ€™s trade with the Alliance, they had used their currency to offer loans to the Alliance. They fully expected the loans to never be repaid, but gave compelling interest rates for interest paid in the Alliance dinar. Slowly, this allowed them to stockpile Alliance currency as well, and made the planet a way to exchange currencies between the two nations. And Phezzan never hesitated to profit off of that, either.

The Allianceâ€™s internal economy was significantly more robust and complex than that of the Empire, but much less stable. Unlike the Empire, which by its feudal nature was slow growing at best, the Alliance prized growth in everythingâ€” physical expansion, population, standards of living, any metric they could think of to measure. But any gains they could eke out were in direct competition with the fact that their economy was shackled to the endless needs of war production. The governmentâ€™s search for revenue to fund the army squeezed every other sector, and left private businesses reliant on regular injections of Phezzani cash, which floated around the Alliance as a ghostly alternative currency. Phezzan was also quite happy to provide things of real value: Imperial goods that churned through Phezzanâ€™s system, all their serial numbers filed off. Much like anyone who set foot on Phezzan could become an anonymous â€œPhezzani citizenâ€ if they wished, so too could wheat and cloth and circuit boards.

As Phezzan grew richer, they had not shied away from running real businesses, ones that produced something, within the Alliance or Empire. These were the giant conglomerates that did so much business on the planet. But the more complicated and â€œrealâ€ Phezzanâ€™s economy grew, the more the Phezzani government had license to perform economic manipulations that no one outside their government could keep track of. Phezzan could issue as much currency as it wanted, and so long as the galaxyâ€™s economy continued to chug along, no one would mind if what backed Phezzanâ€™s currency was mostly faith.

In any event, the disaster of the civil war had knocked life out of balance. With the sudden cessation of most Imperial trade, the faith that underpinned Phezzanâ€™s ability to function was shaken. Phezzani businesses were now desperate to sell all their physical goods, and could no longer do so in the Empire, so a huge number of additional goods were being flushed into the Allianceâ€™s markets. Although this only represented a fairly small real percentage increase, it caused a shockwave in the prices of domestic goods, outcompeted by suddenly-cheap Phezzani products. Simultaneously, Phezzan hiked interest rates on their loans to try to cushion the loss of revenue from the Empire. With the sudden deflation in prices, Alliance businesses found their profits falling short, and they were unable to service their existing loans. Those that were critical to the economy leaned on the Alliance government for support, while those that were non-essential began to go under one at a time. The situation would have to level out eventually, but to Muller it looked like it was going to keep getting worse for a while.

On Phezzan, life went on, but what he read in the Alliance papers about the situation made Muller wince. He could understand why Phezzan was acting in such a self-interested way, but it seemed shortsighted at best. If the Alliance grew wary of Phezzanâ€™s power over their economyâ€” and from the howling of the pundits in the papers, it seemed like more and more were coming to that conclusionâ€” Phezzan could find itself cut off from that side. If the Alliance recovered from this stumble, they wouldnâ€™t immediately reinvest in Phezzan, and if the Imperial civil war dragged onâ€”

Well, Muller didnâ€™t want to think about that.

News that reached Phezzan about what was going on in the Empire was all shoddy. They had contact with â€œa governmentâ€ on Odinâ€” Littenheim had taken over the capitalâ€” but everyone could see that its position was tenuous at best. Lichtenlade, whom everyone at the embassy considered to still be the actual head of government, was in hiding. Most of their real instructions, such as they were, came from Fleet Admiral Muckenburger on Iserlohn, functioning as a kind of government-in-exile. But all Muckenburger cared about was their ongoing information gathering on the Alliance, to see if there was any preparation for an invasion through Iserlohn while the Empire was weak. Muller and his coworkers dutifully reported what they could.Â 

Aside from that, they were helpless to do anything, even if they had wanted to. They couldnâ€™t halt the trickle of refugees through the corridor, even those that were bringing along military secrets or other things of value in hope of securing a favorable spot within the Alliance. As a tiny diplomatic outpost that served a country that had functionally ceased to exist, they had little power. But Muller still showed up to work each day, gritting his teeth and smiling.

Phezzanis wanted everyone in the Embassy to pretend that life was going on as usual. Everyone on the planet was blissfully fiddling while the galaxy burned, it seemed like to Muller. Perhaps that was an illusion, and within the corporate boardrooms and bedrooms of CEOs there was just as much anxiety as he felt, but if there was, it was all taking place far from his line of sight. Instead, invitations were still regularly extended to the members of the Embassy, and it was Mullerâ€™s duty to attend. He sometimes wanted to shriek, thinking about what was going on at home, while sipping martinis at some party.

He should have been glad to not be in the thick of itâ€” after all, if he had been assigned to some other section of the fleet, he would have been obliged to fight against his own countrymen, but instead he just felt a gnawing uselessness. That was one other thing he missed Reinhard von MÃ¼sel forâ€” if MÃ¼sel had been around, surely he would have told Muller to stop being ridiculous, even if doing so would have caused Muller to amp up his efforts to spy on him, in particular. Somehow, that man had a way of injecting other people with a kind of purpose.Â 

Muller was at one of these miserable parties now, on a yacht in the river. The boat was moving so slowly that other ship traffic had to swerve around it to pass, but as the sun set the other traffic mostly disappeared, leaving the only sounds the music of the band further up the deck, and the lapping of the water on the side of the boat, and the distant hum of city noise. Muller wasnâ€™t in uniformâ€” this wasnâ€™t that kind of partyâ€” and he was the only member of the Embassy who had come. Muller had, unfortunately or fortunately, become the designated invitee to all of these events. He was young and handsome and an interesting conversationalist, and not quite as cold-bloodedly Imperial as his superiors. Muller could never really decide if that was a good thing about himself or not.

He didnâ€™t know what this party was ostensibly celebrating, and the only people here were Phezzanis, aside from himself. The Alliance embassy, caving to the popular sentiment in their homeland, had begun to boycott all the usual Imperial events. Muller didnâ€™t mind not seeing them aroundâ€” none of their current crop of staff was particularly interesting, and none of them were stupid enough to say anything at a party that Muller could use.Â 

He had spent the dinner before boarding the yacht socializing with the other guests, but now Muller found he had no one he wanted to talk to, and was leaning over the rail on the aft of the yacht, watching the churn of the water from the slow-moving propeller. He had a whiskey in his hand, and while the sun had just gone down, the sky was still a dusty red on the horizon. The yachtâ€™s fairy lights twinkled above his head, and he stared into space, thinking idly, once again, of how his parents were doing on Odin.

He should be more dutiful, he chided himself, but he didnâ€™t want to go up towards the main deck of the boat, where the dancing was. The back of the ship was secluded, and looking out at the city lights was peaceful, in its own way. Phezzan wanted to pretend like life was still going on; well, the lights there were proof that somewhere, at least, it did. A self-fulfilling prophecy, maybe, but then again, what else was Phezzan?

â€œNot enjoying yourself at my party, Commander Muller?â€

He was so startled to hear the sonorous voice behind him that he almost dropped his drink over the railing. He straightened up and turned around. Landressher Rubinsky, whom Muller had only ever spoken to once before, had come down the stairs to the empty bottom section of the deck.

â€œYou have an excellent memory, sir,â€ Muller said. Although Rubinsky had spoken in the Imperial language, Muller responded in the Phezzani patoisâ€” not for any real reason, other than that it had become second nature to him after so long at his post. â€œIâ€™m not even in uniformâ€” Iâ€™m not sure how you know me from any man on the street.â€

â€œHavenâ€™t you attended almost every one of my little events for years?â€ Rubinsky asked, remaining resolutely in the Imperial language. â€œIâ€™m nothing if not good with faces. It comes with the territory.â€

â€œItâ€™s true that Iâ€™m the embassyâ€™s designated guest, unless my superiors are specifically summoned,â€ Muller said. â€œI assume itâ€™s because whichever secretary of yours sends invites thinks Iâ€™m handsome.â€

Rubinsky laughed. Muller looked behind him inconspicuously, trying to see where his usual cadre of security had gone. They were nowhere in sight, but that didnâ€™t mean much.Â 

â€œWe would be a poor Imperial territory if we didnâ€™t extend invitations to someone from your party,â€ Rubinsky said.

â€œAnd thatâ€™s why you invite the Alliance, as well?â€ He smiled, making it clear that the remark was meant only as a joke.

â€œYou donâ€™t see the rebels here today,â€ Rubinsky said, gesturing broadly at the fore of the boat behind them.

â€œI know. It makes me feel a little unbalanced, to not have something to counteract. Iâ€™m useless without an enemy.â€

â€œYouâ€™re not enemies while youâ€™re both my guests.â€

â€œI always did like that line,â€ Muller said. â€œThe way everyone here pretends to live in a better world.â€

â€œAre you drunk, Commander?â€ Rubinsky didnâ€™t sound accusatory, merely curious.

Muller looked down at the glass in his handâ€” still mostly full. â€œNo. Youâ€™ll have to pardon me for speaking out of turn.â€

â€œNo pardon required at all,â€ Rubinsky said. â€œIâ€™m just surprised you have an opinion like that.â€

â€œI like Phezzan,â€ Muller said. He could have elaborated, but didnâ€™t. Rubinsky was, after all, not a trustworthy person. One didnâ€™t become the leader of Phezzan through honesty and fair play.

â€œYouâ€™re one of very few who hold that opinion,â€ Rubinsky said.

â€œMoreâ€™s the pity.â€ Muller leaned on the railing, looking out over the darkening water. The yacht had turned a bend in the river, and now directly behind the boat, the spire of the elevator rose up into the sky, still lit by traces of the sun, like a signal flare that kept burning. â€œIâ€™ll miss it here when Iâ€™m reassigned.â€

â€œAnd are you expecting that to happen anytime soon?â€

â€œHerr Rubinsky, if youâ€™re asking for information, Iâ€™m afraid I know as little about how things are gong on my side of the galaxy as you do.â€

â€œOf course. I was merely curious about staff changes at the Embassy.â€

Muller smiled, but this time it was uncomfortably tight. â€œPhezzan is a country of the status quo,â€ he said. â€œUnfortunately, the rest of the universe is not. Thatâ€™s the only thing I know about the future.â€

â€œIâ€™m not sure thatâ€™s true,â€ Rubinsky said.

â€œIn what way?â€

â€œThere isnâ€™t a single creature in the universe who can survive without being able to adapt. Those are the laws of natureâ€” and governments, and businesses. They hold for Phezzan, just as much as they hold for the Empire, or for the rebels.â€

Muller was silent for a moment. â€œPhezzanâ€™s certainly been forcing the Alliance to adapt.â€

â€œItâ€™s not my doing, I assure you.â€

â€œNo?â€

â€œAll this government does is issue currency,â€ Rubinsky said, which was such a vast and laughable oversimplification that Muller had to make an effort to control his facial expressions.

â€œAnd couldnâ€™t you, as a currency-issuing body, have offered to prop up Phezzani firms that were hurting from the loss of Imperial business, rather than letting them hunt down their debtors and crash the Alliance economy?â€

Rubinsky smiled, but didnâ€™t answer the question. â€œItâ€™s interesting that a representative of the Imperial government is so concerned with that.â€

â€œItâ€™s my job to care about the Alliance. Besides, if the Alliance learns to live without you, Phezzan will be in a worse position,â€ Muller said. â€œAnd as I said, I happen to like Phezzan.â€ He looked down into his drink. â€œMaybe for my own reasons, but neverthelessâ€¦â€

â€œThe rebels will find it very difficult to live without us,â€ Rubinsky said, dismissing the comment. â€œA wholly insular economy is one that will tear itself apart sooner, rather than later. Like you said, Commanderâ€” one needs someone to compete against. A matching pair.â€

â€œThat might be true,â€ Muller said. â€œBut I donâ€™t know if Phezzan will survive long enough to benefitâ€”â€ He realized that he was saying far too much. â€œForgive me, sir. I donâ€™t mean to overstep.â€

â€œWords are words,â€ Rubinsky said. â€œIâ€™ve never really found much need to take them to heartâ€” Iâ€™d rather have money than promises of love.â€ He paused. â€œAnd maybe youâ€™re right. I have no idea what the rebels are planning to do, if it doesnâ€™t involve us. Maybe weâ€™ve made them accidentally unpredictable.â€

â€œMaybe, sir,â€ Muller said. He couldnâ€™t interpret Rubinskyâ€™s commentâ€” was it meant to be a warning. â€œYou think theyâ€™re a poked tiger?â€

Rubinsky smiled. â€œWhat do you think, Commander?â€

â€œItâ€™s not like the Alliance has exactly been a tame housecat before now. But other than that, I couldnâ€™t say, sir.â€

Rubinsky stared at him for a moment, then said, â€œThey send you here because youâ€™re the least cowed of all the people in that embassyâ€” you should use that to your advantage.â€

â€œIâ€™m not sure what advantage you expect me to gain, sir,â€ Muller said. â€œNor which ones you think I should want.â€

Rubinsky cocked an eyebrow. â€œEvery man has something he wants.â€

â€œAnd are you here to offer me something?â€ Muller asked. He sipped his drink, then laughed a little. â€œSir, Iâ€™m eating better at this party than I have in weeksâ€” the Embassy ran out of money for payroll, and Iâ€™ve been eating nothing but canned beans to stretch my last paycheck. Thereâ€™s not much I can trade you, even if I wanted to. The Embassy is functionally the last outpost of a ruined country, until someone manages to pick up the pieces.â€

â€œYouâ€™re too honest. And I wasnâ€™t looking for anything.â€

â€œJust in caseâ€” itâ€™s better to head you off at the pass,â€ Muller said. â€œYou sounded like you forgot that the reason I have this post in the first place, and why Iâ€™ve been here so long, is that Iâ€™m a loyal servant of the Imperial government. Whoeverâ€™s government it ends up being.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t have a stake in the civil war?â€

Muller smiled. â€œI donâ€™t have a noble name. Even if I had an opinion, it wouldnâ€™t matter much.â€ He was a good liar, when he needed to be.

â€œI see.â€

â€œAnd besidesâ€” thereâ€™s no war here on Phezzan.â€

Rubinsky smiled too, though his smile was tight.Â 

â€œWas there something you wanted, sir?â€ Muller asked.

â€œNo, noâ€” I just wanted to get the thoughts of someone closer to the situation in the Empire than I am.â€

â€œWeâ€™re the same distance away,â€ Muller said. â€œHere in the center of the galaxy.â€

â€œYouâ€™re a flatterer to my country.â€

â€œThatâ€™s my job.â€

â€œSheâ€™s a fickle mistress to flatter, so Iâ€™m told,â€ Rubinsky said. â€œOf all the people who come here looking for her favor, she gives it to very few.â€

â€œWell, for those who have it, that makes her the best kind of mistress, doesnâ€™t it?â€

â€œIndeed.â€

A womanâ€™s voice sounded from atop the deck behind them. â€œAdrian?â€ she called. â€œAre you busy?â€

Rubinsky glanced up behind himself, looking over at the red-haired womanâ€” Dominique Saint-Pierreâ€” and waved his hand at her.

â€œI didnâ€™t mean to distract you from your much more important guests,â€ Muller said.

â€œHardly. Perhaps Iâ€™ll see you again, Herr Muller,â€ Rubinsky said. â€œEnjoy the party.â€

â€œI will, thank you, sir.â€

Rubinsky walked away. Muller realized, playing the conversation over in his head, that he had stayed in the Phezzani patois, and Rubinsky had stayed in Imperial the entire time. It felt strange to him, though he couldnâ€™t explain whyâ€” didnâ€™t understand the point Rubinsky had been trying to make. Muller wasnâ€™t intending to be deferent to Phezzan, and he doubted Rubinsky had any reason to flatter him, a relatively lowly soldier. It buzzed around his head.

He hadnâ€™t gotten much information about the Alliance, either. It all seemed very ominousâ€” that was the only thing he knew for sure. He dumped the rest of his whiskey over the side of the boat, watched it disappear into the churning water, and went to go mingle with the guests some more. He wouldnâ€™t learn anything from them, either, but he wanted to try.

When the boat finally docked, around three in the morning, and all the other guests stumbled drunkenly off into their limousines, Muller took a bus back to the embassy building. Aside from the guards, he was the only one in the offices. It was creaky and quiet in the old marble building, with just the humming of computers and the whirr of the HVACs kicking on and off. The lights were off in the main office floor, and Muller went directly to his own tiny office, and woke up his computer.

Although he addressed the message he was sending to Fleet Admiral Muckenburger in Iserlohn, he knew well enough that Commodore Hank von Leigh would read the message eventually, when he gained access to Iserlohnâ€™s computer systems. Leighâ€™s plans were obvious to anyone who had been paying attention, and Muller had been sufficiently convinced by the Castrop affair that Leigh couldâ€” and wouldâ€” take Iserlohn. And Leigh was someone Muller knew how to write to.

Muller finished writing his letterâ€” a long one, detailing the current state of the Alliance and Phezzan, the disrupted status quo, the way the Alliance was being pushed to the breaking point, and Rubinskyâ€™s strange curiosityâ€” by six-thirty in the morning, finished reading it over and pressed send by six-forty-five. He was in the process of writing a note for his superior, describing the communique with Iserlohn (and telling him that he would be taking the morning off to have a nap) at seven. At three minutes after seven, an urgent message from the Iserlohn fleet arrived in the Embassyâ€™s secure ansible system. It was marked with so many bright red urgent flags that Muller stopped everything that he was doing to read it, and he was therefore the first to know what had happened on the other side of the galaxy.

Iserlohn fortress had been captured, and the Embassyâ€™s new orders were, regardless of cost, to kill any member of Duke Braunschweigâ€™s family if they attempted to enter Phezzan.

Chapter End Notes

boy i wonder what phezzan's up to :p

i hope my "muller regurgitates a half remembered rein blog post to infodump phezzan's economics" is a) not boring and b) at least makes a /little/ sense lol. i try. i'm not an economics expert unfortunately ğŸ˜… why i have written a series that foregrounds it, i couldn't really tell you lol. b/c i have terminal "i need to explain how things work" hard sf writer brain ig. the unholy lovechild of victor hugo and kim stanley robinson that lives in my brain and rattles the bars of its cage occasionally

shorter chapter but that's why it's an interlude. just have to remind everyone (esp my imperial-side-only readers) that yang's civil war problems are, uh, only some of his problems lol

it would be fun for me to have made this series a 3 way split, and given the rubinsky-dominique-kesserlink-earth church leadership squad their own section, but also, no it wouldn't have lmao. you should thank me for not doing that.

as with most of the chapters involving muller in this section, the title is from 'letter from belgium'

as usual, you can find me at tumblr @ javert, twitter @ natsinator, gayspaceopera.carrd.co, and you can join my discord https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

Mene, Mene, Tekel Upharsin

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

February 489 I.C., Iserlohn Fortress

Mittermeyer had never been more struck by the difference between himself and Yang Wen-li than he was while watching the fall of Iserlohn Fortress. Mittermeyerâ€™s ships were responsible for keeping the pace of the battle, but Yang was charged with winning â€” which seemed like something only he was capable of doing.

Mittermeyerâ€™s scout ships, at the outside edge of his fleet, could see around the side of Iserlohn. Despite the communications blockage, they could report what Yangâ€™s fleet was doing, and they sent Mittermeyer a video feed, which he watched with one eye as he directed the movements of his ships with the other. When he saw the missiles rushing towards the Thor Hammer, he almost didnâ€™t pay attention until the first few hit, and then he lost focus on what he was saying to his aide as the rest impacted the fortressâ€™s shell.

He was well aware of the Thor Hammerâ€™s destructive power: his own fleet had been baiting out its blows and staying just outside its effective range. Even at a distance, it was terrifying. It had felt like an insurmountable obstacle, a force of nature. And yet, there it was, being hit with one bright flash of missile-fire at a time, until the whole thing collapsed in on itself. It had the death-throes of an animal, a giant taken down by a pebble in its eye.

It took Mittermeyer a moment to remember that Yang was his friend, to try to connect this vision of Yang, with the power of life and death wholly in his hands, to the gentle and quiet man he knew. He struggled to resolve the image in his mind, and the resolution came only when he realized why he felt such horror at the gaping hole in Iserlohnâ€™s side.Â 

Mittermeyer, now fighting the fortress fleet, recognized the ships that flew by: he could name many of their captains and crews, all the men he had worked with for months. He knew the staff inside Iserlohn, as comrades, if not friends. The fear he felt watching Iserlohnâ€™s walls tumble down was not just awe at Yangâ€™s skill. He wondered if, even if he had been as brilliant as Yang, if he would have been able to strike that final blow.

Yang felt the same amount of pity for Alliance soldiers as he did for any member of the Imperial forces in Iserlohnâ€” perhaps because he had been born on Heinessen, but Mittermeyer suspected that if they ventured out of this galaxy and found a race of aliens to war with, Yang would open his heart to the inhuman, too. It was a positive quality of his, and on some level Mittermeyer felt ashamed for lacking his indiscriminate compassion, but it also meant that Yang had as little hesitation attacking Iserlohn as he would attacking anywhere elseâ€” his universal tenderness paradoxically making him feel more brutal here.

Even after the Thor Hammer had been destroyed and the fortress rendered impotent, the fortress fleet fought with all its strength to keep Mittermeyerâ€™s slow crew transports from making their way in. This was fine. He corralled the Iserlohn fleet to stop them from attacking Braunschweigâ€™s landing party. Whatever contingent of landing forces Braunschweig had on his side, he would be able to use them to force a surrender, so Mittermeyer didnâ€™t press as hard as he could to get his landing forces down. The battle was wonâ€” it was just a matter of not wasting lives until Iserlohn acknowledged it.

Many hours passed, and Mittermeyer only got occasional updates on the number of ships that had landed inside the fortress. It was hard to tell how things were going inside, but there were no obvious signs that things were going badly.Â 

The situation only changed when finally, finally, the communications blockage that Iserlohn had been imposing dropped, and their radios picked up a message from the fortress itself. It was Yangâ€™s voice. Although he sounded miserable even over the radio, Mittermeyer couldnâ€™t help but feel elated.

â€œIserlohn Fortress Fleet,â€ Yang said, â€œFleet Admiral Muckenburger is dead, and Iserlohn has been captured. Surrender now and you will be treatedâ€”â€ Yangâ€™s voice was strained, and he audibly stumbled. â€œYou will be treated with mercy.â€

â€œAnd if they donâ€™t surrender?â€Â 

Mittermeyer hadnâ€™t realized that the leader of Cahokiaâ€™s ground forces had come up behind him on the bridge to listen to the announcement, and he was startled to hear his voice. When he had arrived at Cahokia, he had been surprised to find that he actually knew the man from years ago. They had been former schoolmates, though they had fallen out of contact after they left the IOA. That time was so long ago that it felt like a dream, but they had played their student wargames together. This was undoubtedly why Captain Ferner had been given the position as leader of Cahokiaâ€™s ground forces, and why he now had a perhaps unwarranted sense of familiarity towards Mittermeyerâ€” he spoke his mind without considering if he wanted to hear it or not.

â€œTheyâ€™ll surrender,â€ Mittermeyer said.

â€œI donâ€™t know why youâ€™re sure of that.â€

â€œTheyâ€™re defeatedâ€” thereâ€™s not much else they could do.â€

â€œAnd why hasnâ€™t Commodore von Leigh radioed us with instructions?â€ Ferner asked. â€œHeâ€™s perfectly capable of doing so, since weâ€™re receiving what heâ€™s broadcasting to the Iserlohn fleet.â€

He understood what Ferner was implyingâ€” Yang wanted him to do something that he could not order, and simply trusted him to do. The only thing that was in that category was allowing the Iserlohn fleet to escape. If Braunschweig was giving orders, he would order their destruction if no surrender was forthcoming. Ferner, who had played on Yangâ€™s team for the war games many years ago, was well aware of his merciful tendencies.

Mittermeyer pressed his lips into a thin, annoyed line, then said, â€œHe doesnâ€™t have the authority to issue orders. Iâ€™m sure heâ€™s waiting on Duke Braunschweig, or Admiral Merkatz.â€

â€œOf course.â€

â€œPrepare our forces to land inside,â€ Mittermeyer said. â€œIt sounds like thereâ€™s still resistance that weâ€™ll have to deal with.â€

â€œYes, sir.â€

Mittermeyer turned back towards his console, and Ferner walked away, though he could feel his occasional glances back at him. For the fleet, there was only one thing left to do, which was to enter Iserlohn. It would serve the dual purpose of getting their ground troops inside, and giving Yang what he wanted.Â 

He ordered his fleet to take up a spear formation and break through the fortress fleetâ€™s remaining defenses. After such a prolonged back and forth and the confusion that Yangâ€™s message had caused, the fleet was already in disarray, so this was the perfect moment to strike.Â 

He baited them forwards and then back, just like they had been doing for hours, then ordered his fleet to break through as the fortress fleet pulled back from their false retreat. The new rush, much more powerful and deliberate than any of Mittermeyerâ€™s previous attacks, caught the fortress fleet off guard, and they broke through easily. His heavily armored battleships then broke off on either side and circled back around the bulk of the fleet to protect the weaker crew transports.

The Iserlohn fleet attempted to attack Mittermeyer now that his battleships were bunched up near the outside of Iserlohn; they were sitting targets until all of them had gotten inside the liquid metal walls. As the fleet charged, the remaining bulk of Braunschweigâ€™s forces came around the side of the fortress to provide support, and it became clear that the battle was lost for the Iserlohn fleet. When Braunschweigâ€™s fleet charged, they had no choice but to flee. Braunschweigâ€™s fleet chased them, but Mittermeyer suspected that they wouldnâ€™t pursue very far. There was nothing to be gained from killing the fortress fleet.

The battle moving away from the fortress meant that there was an eerie kind of peace as his forces descended. It was punctuated by radio contact with the command center of Iserlohn, finally getting a report on what the status of the fortress itself was. Although the command center was fully under the dukeâ€™s control, there was heavy resistance in almost every other area, especially near the engines. There were fires in the greenhouses, along with other acts of sabotage.

The ground troops that had been on Cahokia were greater in number than the Iserlohn garrison, and although the garrison had the advantage of familiarity, Mittermeyer still felt confident in sending Ferner and his men to deal with the issues. Over the radio, Braunschweig ordered them to kill anyone who resisted. He seemed irate at the fact that the fortress garrison still refused to surrender, and his voice was too loud for the microphone he was yelling intoâ€” the overwhelmed digital whine on the receiving end caused the radio tech to crank the volume down hastily when his voice picked up.Â 

Ferner, now suited in armor, though with his helmet under one arm, raised an eyebrow at Mittermeyer at this command. â€œI see that Commodore Leigh is no longer the one giving orders.â€

â€œSome will surrender,â€ was all he could say, ignoring Fernerâ€™s comment. â€œTake them prisoner if you can. Theyâ€™ll be happy to swear loyalty later.â€

â€œYes, sir,â€ Ferner said.

Mittermeyerâ€™s stolen white ship descended into Iserlohn, her shields protecting them from the worst of the movement of the liquid metal shell. Other ships in his fleet were already docking, taking positions indiscriminately in the empty bays. There was an odd sense of familiarity in this, despite the situation. How many times had he anticipated the feeling of coming home to Iserlohn? It was no different now, even if it was Yang he was waiting to meet, rather than Reuenthal.

The Alliance-facing side of Iserlohn had been spared the worst of the damage. Mittermeyerâ€™s potshots at it with missiles, and their battle with the fleet, had glanced off the liquid metal shell.Â 

The doors could be easily opened, since the computers were under the dukeâ€™s control, so they didnâ€™t have to waste time cutting open paths through the fortress. Mittermeyer let Ferner handle the whole boarding operationâ€” it was what he had been stationed on Cahokia specifically to do, and he knew Yangâ€™s detailed plan for taking Iserlohn well. Their forces would need to meet up with Braunschweigâ€™s soldiers on the other side, and since the fortress was some sixty kilometers across, they would have to take control of all the various elevator shafts and train tunnels, while simultaneously putting a stop to any intentional destruction of vital equipment from the fortress garrison.

Mittermeyer watched the progress of their boarding from his position on the white ship. He wanted to get to the Iserlohn control center and find Yang, but he couldnâ€™t yet abandon his duties as fleet commander. He had various video feeds of his troops as they stormed Iserlohn, and when he wasnâ€™t looking at a map of how people were progressing through the fortress, he watched those. A contingent of his soldiers forced their way through the smoke-filled greenhouses, a line of white armor pushing through rows of corn and soy. They found and deployed the irrigation systems, since the automatic fire-suppression had been disabled by the garrison as they burned Iserlohnâ€™s supplies to nothing. Without gravity, the fire moved strangely, crawling along surfaces in unintuitive directions, and the smoke didnâ€™t roil in clouds near the ceiling, but instead choked the air in a wide river between the fire and the air vents.

Other teams stormed down the elevator shafts towards the central engines, and a real battle raged there for control of the fortressâ€™s heart. Mittermeyer was hopeful that when that fell, and they were able to staunch some of the worst damage, the fortressâ€™s remaining defenders would begin to surrender. Already, there had been some pockets where that was happening. Though they were few in number, it did give Mittermeyer hope that things would calm down.

Mittermeyer listened to the radio. They had open communications now as they solidified control. What he wanted was to get on a private radio channel and speak to Yang, but that was impossible. He occasionally heard Yangâ€™s voice answering questions or giving direction, though it was impossible to divine anything from it other than his exhaustion. Other voices mingled in the airwaves: Ferner, Braunschweig, Admiral Merkatz (apparently coming into Iserlohn in an escape podâ€” he seemed lucky to have survived), Flegel, and Ansbach.Â 

Although the chaos inside Iserlohn continuedâ€” a tempest in a teacupâ€” a call came for Mittermeyer specifically. The voice delivering it, unpleasantly, was Ansbachâ€™s.Â 

â€œRear Admiral Mittermeyer,â€ he said, â€œDuke Braunschweig requests that you join him on the Berlin for a celebratory dinner.â€

It wasnâ€™t exactly an offer that he could refuse, even though the last thing he wanted to see was most of the members of Braunschweigâ€™s closest circle, including the one who was speaking. â€œOf course.â€

â€œIt will be easier to move your ship into closer docks than trying to take yourself through Iserlohn,â€ Ansbach said. â€œIâ€™ll provide you with landing instructions.â€

â€œIâ€™m well aware of that. It seems a little early for a celebration dinner, if the fortress hasnâ€™t been brought under control.â€

There was a pause from Ansbach, an empty silence like he had taken his finger off the transmit button on his mic. â€œNevertheless,â€ he finally said, â€œyour presence is requested.â€

Now that he had been ordered to take his mind off of the battle situation, Mittermeyer suddenly didnâ€™t want to. But Ferner had it well under control, so there was no choice but for him to order his white ship to lift off, circle around Iserlohn, and land in the docking bays next to the Berlin . In this area of Iserlohn, the damage was very apparent, and he saw it up close when he left the white ship on foot (as much as one could be on foot without gravity), flanked by a squad of soldiers, just in case of trouble. He lingered outside Braunschweigâ€™s flagship for a moment to survey the damage.Â 

Here, where the initial push into Iserlohn had been made, the walls were scorched with signs of both exploded zephyr gas and the pockmarks of laser shots. The doors had all been pulled open, and there were dead bodies that had drifted through the air to collect at the intake vents for the air filtration system, which had been turned back on. Their limbs tangled together and wavered in the slow moving air. It was grotesque, but horror wasnâ€™t exactly what Mittermeyer felt to look at it. He turned away and pushed off the floor to head to the Berlin , where the doors were open and waiting for him.

Even after just a short jaunt outside, he was grateful for the feeling of gravity catching him as he entered the Berlin , and landed on his feet with a thump. The ship was a hive of activity, soldiers heading in and out on errands, but there was still someone waiting to escort him up to dinner in Braunschweigâ€™s personal section of the ship.

Outside the dining room was a lounge area, which only had one other person in it when he arrived. He should have been less punctual, he realized, because the person waiting in the lounge, a glass of wine already in hand, was Baron Flegel. He was looking out the huge window at the docking areas of Iserlohn, and at Mittermeyerâ€™s stolen ship in particular. He turned around when he came in, and his smile curled unpleasantly. As Mittermeyer stepped closer, he discovered that although Flegel was clean and washed, one side of his face was bruised in a way that even a dusting of white makeup couldnâ€™t disguise, and though he held himself with his usual proud swagger, he also winced when he lifted his arm to take a sip from his wine.Â 

â€œRear Admiral,â€ Flegel said, â€œhow wonderful it is that you could join us.â€

â€œFor dinner, or in Iserlohn?â€Â 

â€œFor dinner, certainly.â€ Flegel turned back to the window and pointed at his ship. â€œI wasnâ€™t aware that the high command gave out such pretty flagships to rear admirals who have been in recent disgrace.â€

â€œThey donâ€™t,â€ Mittermeyer said. â€œI stole her.â€

The bluntness with which he delivered the line made Flegel laugh. â€œYou never fail to surprise.â€

Mittermeyer didnâ€™t have anything to say to that.

â€œWhatâ€™s her name?â€ Flegel asked.

â€œShe doesnâ€™t have one, aside from Test Ship 744.â€

â€œDoesnâ€™t roll off the tongue. No nicknames?â€

â€œNot in particular.â€

â€œWhy not?â€

Because he had been planning to offer the ship to Yang, who would want to name it himself. Of course, he couldnâ€™t say that.

â€œIâ€™m not a creative man,â€ he said. â€œAnd I assume Her Majesty will want to give the ship to someone as a reward, since I stole it for her sake.â€

â€œYou arenâ€™t planning to fight for your right to it? As the spoils of war?â€

â€œYou think youâ€”â€

Mittermeyer cut himself off as the door opened and Duke Braunschweig came in, followed by Admiral Merkatz, Yang, Ansbach, and some young lieutenant commander that he didnâ€™t recognize. Mittermeyer couldnâ€™t help but study Ansbach as they sat down, and he didnâ€™t seem to be the only one to do so. It was very strange for Mittermeyer to see Yang in this environment. Perhaps Mittermeyer was the least acclimated to the room. He was an outsider to Braunschweigâ€™s camp, and furthermore not a noble. When soldier-servants came around bearing wine and covered dishes, there was an unwritten protocol that everyone else in the room knew how to follow. He watched Yang and Ansbach across the table from himself, and just copied what they were doing.

Ansbach didnâ€™t even look at Yang, but it was clear that neither minded sitting next to each other. When Ansbach, left-handed, reached for his wine glass, his arm bumped Yangâ€™s, and Yang glanced at him with a small smile.

â€œSir,â€ Yang said. His voice had a strange effect on the roomâ€” everyone stopped what they were doing to listen to him, except for Braunschweig, who speared a piece of potato and put it in his mouth before looking at Yang.

â€œYes, sir,â€ Merkatz said. Yang looked across at Merkatz, rather searchingly, and Merkatz added. â€œI would appreciate Rear Admiral Mittermeyer joining me, if possible.â€

The conversation turned towards Braunschweig family matters, which didnâ€™t interest Mittermeyer at all. He studied Yang, who had returned to looking down at his plate, and Ansbach, who now took the role of echoing Braunschweigâ€™s thoughts back to him. When their eyes happened to meet across the table, Ansbach looked back at Mittermeyer unwaveringly.

Which of the three of them had changed since their school days? Mittermeyer wondered. He didnâ€™t feel the difference in himself, nor in Yangâ€” at least, not anything that he could put a finger on. When the dinner was finished, Braunschweig and Flegel left to attend to something on the bridge of the Berlin , and Vering, Ansbach, and Yang followed them out. Merkatz and Mittermeyer stayed behind in the dining area for a moment.

â€œI assume weâ€™ll have plenty of time en route to discuss our plan for Odin,â€ Mittermeyer said.

â€œWe certainly will, and Leighâ€™s plan is quite comprehensive,â€ Merkatz agreed. â€œI appreciate you coming all this way. Iâ€™m not sure we would have won the day without your help.â€

â€œLeigh would have found some way to win.â€

â€œYouâ€™re very confident in him.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t think so?â€

Merkatz made a noncommittal noise. â€œLeigh is brilliant,â€ he said. â€œThat canâ€™t be denied. And he has loyal friends.â€ There was almost a warning in Merkatzâ€™s tone.

Mittermeyer paused. â€œAnd is that why you asked me to go with you to Odin?â€

â€œI think we will have to trust each other, Rear Admiral,â€ Merkatz said. â€œNo, I didnâ€™t do it to separate you from himâ€” he asked me to do so. I think he planned to remain on Iserlohn even if Duke Braunschweig went to Odin, and he trusts you to take care of things elsewhere.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know why heâ€™d prefer to stay at Iserlohn by himself.â€

â€œYouâ€™ll have to ask him.â€ He looked at Mittermeyer squarely. â€œBut it doesnâ€™t escape me that you are personally loyal to him, rather than the dukeâ€” and I wonâ€™t ask about your loyalty to his daughter. Iâ€™d prefer not to know.â€

â€œI wasnâ€™t crossing my fingers behind my back when I took my oath to serve in the fleet,â€ Mittermeyer said. â€œSometimes I feel like I might be the only one.â€

Merkatz was not a laughing man, but he did have some approximation of a smile. â€œThere are plenty of loyal men in this world,â€ Merkatz said. â€œBut Iâ€™m glad we can work together.â€

â€œWeâ€™ll need to.â€

â€œYes,â€ Merkatz said. His thoughts about Baron Flegel came through quite clearly in that one word, and Mittermeyer couldnâ€™t help but smile. Merkatz stood. â€œThis is a strange world we find ourselves in, Rear Admiral.â€

His words reminded him of something he had said to Reuenthal, months ago, when they were out celebrating Yangâ€™s wedding. â€œIt is,â€ he said. â€œI never could have predicted all of this. But I hopeâ€” when itâ€™s all overâ€” whateverâ€™s on the other side will be better.â€

â€œThat, I believe, is a quality that most of Leighâ€™s friends share.â€

â€œMaybe.â€ They headed out into the lounge area. Merkatz glanced at his stolen white ship out the window.

â€œThat is a beautiful ship.â€

â€œIâ€™m trying not to get attachedâ€” I doubt Iâ€™ll be able to keep her.â€

â€œOh? Who will have her instead?â€

â€œLeigh, I hope. He deserves it. Weâ€™ll see if it happens.â€

â€œLeighâ€™s friends outnumber his detractors. Iâ€™m sure that between all of us and the facts at hand, we can make a compelling case to the Kaiserin. Leigh would never ask for himself.â€

â€œI wasnâ€™t aware that Leigh had many personal friends around hereâ€” aside from yourself.â€

â€œAllies, at the very least,â€ Merkatz said. â€œIâ€™ll see you tomorrow, Rear Admiral. We should prepare ourselves.â€

â€œYes, sir.â€

They came to the door to the hallway, and he and Mittermeyer turned in opposite directions, Mittermeyer intending to head to the bridge to find Yang, Merkatz turning towards the exit of the ship.

He didnâ€™t have to go farâ€” he heard Yangâ€™s voice around a corner. It seemed like he had decided to wait for him so that they could spend the evening together, which made him smile, but the warmth was tempered by what he heard Yang saying.

â€œâ€”it would be worth it. A full scale invasion by the Alliance would be one of the worst things that could happen right now.â€

â€œThen let me suggest it. You need to learn to keep your mouth shut, My Lord.â€

â€œYou wonâ€™t, though.â€

Mittermeyer didnâ€™t get a chance to hear Ansbachâ€™s responseâ€” a moment of silence fell between them, and he decided that was his time to interrupt. He turned the corner to see Yang leaning against the wall, his head pressed against it, with his hair tousled and falling around his face. The wall seemed to be the only thing holding him up. Ansbach stood before him, arms crossed and a scowl on his face.

â€œCommodores,â€ Mittermeyer said, announcing himself. Ansbach glanced over at him, smoothed out his facial expression, and then nodded.

â€œIâ€™ll be going,â€ he said. â€œGoodnight, gentlemen.â€

â€œAnsbachâ€”â€ Yang said.

But Ansbach just held up a hand in a half-wave and walked away. Yang didnâ€™t straighten up from his lean against the wall until he was well and truly gone and Mittermeyer walked over. He smiledâ€” a real smile this time.

â€œDonâ€™t lecture me,â€ Yang said. â€œIâ€™ve already heard it from him.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know what Iâ€™d lecture you about. I seem to be missing much of the context.â€

â€œDonâ€™t worry about it, then. Just assume youâ€™d agree with himâ€” I know you would.â€

â€œI find that hard to believe.â€

Yang put his hand on his arm. It was shocking, after so long in space by himself, and very welcome, though he couldnâ€™t help but turn his head to make sure there was no one else coming down the corridor. â€œHeâ€™sâ€”â€Â 

Yang didnâ€™t seem to know how to complete his thought, but he looked at Mittermeyer, clearly hoping he would nevertheless understand him. He resigned himself to it. â€œDoes he call you â€˜My Lordâ€™ to make up for trying to kill you?â€

Yang visibly reddened and looked away. â€œHe just does that because it annoys me. You notice it doesnâ€™t stop him from telling me to shut up.â€

Mittermeyer laughed. â€œCome on. Let me show you my stolen beauty.â€

Yang dropped his hand from Mittermeyerâ€™s arm, though with a lingering brush of their hands together, and let him lead him towards the white ship.

Even Yang, who was usually loathe to express admiration for weapons of war, couldnâ€™t help but admire the ship. When they made their way into the open bay doors, he caught himself on the side for a moment and touched the gleaming white shell with his palm flat to the coated metal. Mittermeyer, from previous experience, knew how strange it feltâ€” even when in their inactive state, the shields, with their machinery just below the skin of the ship, had such a strong effect that the delicate nerves in the hand could feel it. Tingling, like gooseflesh on a part of the body that couldnâ€™t get gooseflesh.

They didnâ€™t talk about anything important on the way to Mittermeyerâ€™s quartersâ€” Yang was too tired, or too sad, to even ask about how his half of the battle had gone, aside from confirming that Captain Ferner was alright. Mittermeyer filled the silence by telling him about how he had acquired the ship, and what had happened to its red companion. The story made Yang smile.Â 

â€œI canâ€™t help but feel sympathy for expats,â€ Yang said. â€œKircheis would like the story, I think. One going, one staying behind.â€

â€œWell, I hope they donâ€™t just take her apart. Sheâ€™s too nice of a ship for that.â€ He decided not to tell Yang that he hoped to give this ship to himâ€” he would protest. So instead he just held open the door to his personal quarters and let him step inside.

The furnishings left something to be desired. Usually, whoever was given a flagship of this stature would have their own furniture at hand to decorate with. But since he had stolen the ship on very short notice, the rooms were mostly bare, and only contained a few pieces that had been moved from the enlisted mensâ€™ lounges and quarters. Since the shipâ€™s crew was so minimal, the furnitureâ€™s absence hadnâ€™t been noticed. But it gave his quarters an impersonal feeling. Yang didnâ€™t notice, or at least didnâ€™t care, and sat down on the creaking sofa, draping himself across it in his usual haphazard way.

â€œDo you want something to drink?â€ Mittermeyer asked. Yang just yawned and held his hand out, inviting him to the couch with him.

â€œIâ€™m going to fall asleep before I could even finish drinking it,â€ he said. â€œI havenâ€™t slept in about thirty hours.â€

â€œNot even the tank bed?â€ Mittermeyer asked, taking Yangâ€™s hand. It was his left handâ€” with his wedding ring on it.

â€œToo busy,â€ Yang murmured. â€œItâ€™s been a hard day, Wolf.â€

â€œI know.â€ He should have sat on the couch, but instead he sat on the floor in front of it, leaning back against it, still holding Yangâ€™s hand in his. Yang shifted, rolling onto his side so he could look at him. â€œWe donâ€™t have much time right now, do we?â€

â€œIserlohnâ€™s always just a place people pass through,â€ Yang said, sounding very melancholy. It was a funny thing to say about a place that had been intended to be a wall, rather than a door, but Yang had his own way of seeing things. â€œIâ€™ll see you again on Odinâ€” soon.â€ It sounded like he was promising it to himself, more than to Mittermeyer.Â 

â€œI donâ€™t really understand why youâ€™re having me go to Odin. I feel like I just got to you.â€

â€œI feel responsible for all of this. But you can take care of things on Odin. I trust you.â€ His voice was low and quiet, half asleep already, maybe. â€œIt wonâ€™t be long,â€ he said again. â€œAnd Oskarâ€™s thereâ€¦â€

â€œAnd youâ€™ll be by yourself.â€

â€œI wonâ€™t be by myself.â€ With his other hand, Yang combed his fingers through Mittermeyerâ€™s hair.Â 

â€œYes, youâ€™ll have Ansbach.â€ Despite Yangâ€™s sleepiness, Mittermeyerâ€™s tone remained a little scathing.

â€œI do trust him,â€ Yang said. He seemed to have figured out what he had wanted to say earlier. â€œHeâ€™s a good man.â€

â€œItâ€™s hard for me to believe you.â€

â€œNo, he is,â€ Yang murmured. â€œThings would have been different if we had met somewhere elseâ€” if we all lived in the Allianceâ€¦ or even Phezzanâ€¦ somewhere else. Not that schoolâ€¦â€ He was trailing off in tiredness.

â€œWhat does that have to do with it?â€

â€œHe was trappedâ€” just like the rest of us,â€ Yang said. â€œThatâ€™s all.â€

There were plenty of things he should have asked Yang about while he was still awakeâ€” what Ansbach had stopped him from saying to Braunschweig, what they should do about the possible Alliance invasion, what Yang wanted him to do when he got to Odin, what the rest of the civil war would look likeâ€” but all of that fell out of Mittermeyerâ€™s mind as he sat there with Yang and held his hand, touching his gold wedding band, twisting it around his finger.Â 

Mittermeyer pressed Yangâ€™s hand to his faceâ€” his lips, not quite a kiss, then his cheek, then his forehead. He held it there, closing his eyes.

â€œWen-li, when I get back to Odinâ€”â€ Mittermeyer said.

Yang waited.

â€œIâ€™m going to tell Evangeline.â€ It felt somehow more real to say it aloud.

Yangâ€™s breath was a little unsteady, but his fingers continued their inexorable journey through his hair, across the crown of his head, towards his ears, the nape of his neck, then back up.Â 

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ Yang said.

â€œFor what?â€

â€œI love you.â€

Mittermeyer did kiss Yangâ€™s hand, then.

Chapter End Notes

we are about to enter the most exciting string of chapters in this story yet lol. i don't think i've been this excited to write something since the end of itsoh act 2 lol. i love it when all the dominoes i've spent so long setting up finally get to start falling-- it makes the writing way easier b/c all the tools i need are at hand and it's payoff all the way down haha. anyway no one has yet guessed what is going to happen next chapter even though i've set it up in a /very/ obvious in hindsight way so i have to imagine you all are going to be very surprised lol. we're headed back to the horrible girl house next chapter :3

anyway... um well the title of this chapter is from the book of david and belshazzar's feast. it's maybe a /little/ on the nose but i've wanted to name a chapter this for aaages so here it is haha

thank you very much as always to em for the beta read ğŸ’™

you can find me in all the usual places: javert @ tumblr, natsinator @ twitter, gayspaceopera.carrd.co , and on discord https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu

Blessed Are You Among Women

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

January 489 I.C., Odin

It was a lean winter in the old Von Kummel country home in the woods, far from the capital city. The group staying thereâ€” Baron Heinrich von Kummel, Evangeline, Magdalena, Hilde, and Elfriede, and a rotating cast of Mariendorf family servants (the rest gone home to their families)â€” had enough to eat, and the house was easily heated with wood fires and solar panels, but the leanness was present nevertheless.Â 

For Evangeline, it was less of a physical lack than it was a spiritual one. Despite the abundance of people in the house, she found herself quite lonely. It would have been easier to explain her loneliness if it had originated from some definable source, perhaps the way she was the only woman in the house of common lineage. But that wasnâ€™t it. In the woods, so isolated from the rest of the universe, there was no real status left to hold on to. There was simply an aura of misery that pervaded the air, clinging to each woman in her own way, and Evangeline found herself helpless to change it, or to shake off her own troubles. It was the lack of anything to doâ€” any sense of purposeâ€” that led to rumination. Before, when Wolf had been deployed, Eva had plenty to occupy herself with, and that had kept her able to maintain a cheerful rigor in her life. There was nothing like that now.

The four women drifted through the house like little ghosts. Hilde was the easiest one of them for Evangeline to talk to, but perhaps that was only because they had so little in common. With Magdalena, every conversation seemed to risk opening wounds. Eva didnâ€™t know why that was suddenly the case, but it clearly was now. Magdalenaâ€™s smile always seemed false and brittle, even when there were guests to entertain. Certain topics of conversation made her flinch and stare off into space. Maybe Eva was the only one who noticed.

But with Hilde, there was nothing they could talk to each other about , so the conversation rarely risked falling into dangerous territory, or if it did, it was only in one direction, and Hilde was good at hiding it.Â 

Hilde, Evangeline found, was a master of pragmatism. She spent most of her days in the library. She said she was studying, since she was missing her semester at Odin National University, but perhaps both of them knew that it was unlikely that she would simply rejoin her university course after the end of the war.Â 

The books that Hilde stacked up around herself were not just the textbooks from her law course. When Magdalena went out on social visits or invited other guests to the house, Hilde always begged them for any books they might have in their country libraries. By doing this, she managed to accumulate quite a few on history and military strategy, which seemed to be her favorite topics. She said that reading kept her occupied, but when Evangeline walked by the library, sheâ€™d often find her standing by the window, looking out over the cold pines and the dim sun in the grey sky, hands clutched behind her back.

Eva, half out of genuine kind-heartedness, and half out of a desire to relieve any part of the houseâ€™s oppressive atmosphere, baked cookies one day and brought a plate of them to Hilde. She knocked on the frame of the library door, and Hilde, staring out the window once more, jumped in surprise.

â€œHave you eaten?â€ Eva asked. She held out the cookies, still warm.

â€œLunchâ€” ah, no.â€ It was almost five in the evening. â€œBut Iâ€™ll take advantage of your generosity, if youâ€™re offering.â€

â€œOf course. What else would I be doing?â€

â€œI feel like you should be telling me Iâ€™ll spoil my dinner if I eat right now,â€ Hilde said, checking her watch.

â€œDo you really think Iâ€™m that much of a nag?â€ Evangeline sat down on the couch, balancing the plate of treats on her knees, and Hilde took a seat next to her. There was a thick book open on the coffee table, lines of text so small that Eva couldnâ€™t read it from where she sat.Â 

â€œNo! Of course not!â€ She took a cookie just so that she could stop herself from saying anything else that might accidentally offend, but then she mumbled around it, holding her hand over her mouth in a facsimile of politeness. â€œYou just are always asking how Iâ€™m doingâ€” seems like the kind of thing someone who cares says.â€

It was an odd way of phrasing thingsâ€” but then again, Hildeâ€™s mother had died when she was young, Eva remembered. She had probably come to that conclusion in a roundabout way.

â€œI do care,â€ Eva said. â€œBut do tell me if Iâ€™m being a pestâ€” I donâ€™t want to bother you.â€

â€œOf course not. I appreciate the company.â€

There was a moment of silence between them. Already, Eva had run out of things to say. â€œHave you heard anything from Herr Kircheis? I know heâ€™s much better company than I am.â€

â€œNo,â€ Hilde said. â€œNot since last week.â€

â€œAh.â€

â€œI wish I could tell you more,â€ Hilde said, sounding genuinely distraught. â€œI just donâ€™t have any newsâ€¦â€

â€œItâ€™s alright.â€ She leaned her shoulder on Hildeâ€™s comfortingly, and Hilde didnâ€™t seem to know what to do with the gesture. She stiffened, but smiled.Â 

She was, every inch of her, Eva decided, a girl raised without any female companionship whatsoever. Without a mother and without any female friends, as far as Eva could tell. It seemed to her that Hilde lived a very lonely kind of existence, and was possibly even more out of place in the house than she was, even though they were all here on her cousinâ€™s goodwill.Â 

â€œI think all of the military details would go completely over my head, even if you gave them to me,â€ Eva said.

â€œIâ€™m sure thatâ€™s not true. I could tell you what Hankâ€™s plan isâ€”â€ She reached for an open notebook and pen that were on the lower shelf of the coffee table before them, but then stopped herself. â€œBut Iâ€™ll take your word for it if you donâ€™t want to hear it.â€ She smiled, somewhat ruefully.

â€œI donâ€™t think it would do me any good. And youâ€™d get frustrated when I didnâ€™t understand.â€

â€œI promise I wouldnâ€™t,â€ Hilde said.

Eva reached over and flipped a couple pages of the heavy book on the table, turning to a map with a dizzying array of colorful lines drawn across it. â€œI think if I understood what Wolf did out there, Iâ€™d be more worried than not.â€

â€œReally? Not knowing drives me crazy.â€ She laughed. â€œProbably why Iâ€™m such bad company around here.â€

â€œWellâ€”â€ Eva put the cookies down on the table so she could explain, gesturing though there was nothing much to gesture to. â€œItâ€™s thatâ€” you seeâ€” I trust Wolf to know what to do, and to come back to me.â€

â€œOf course!â€

â€œBut if I had all of the information, Iâ€™d just start picking at it, thinking about all the ways it could go wrongâ€” not that I wouldnâ€™t expect Wolf to overcome them, butâ€” Iâ€™d be afraid for him, thinking about it all, and there would be nothing I could do to fix it. And heâ€™s never wanted me to worry like thatâ€” heâ€™s told me not to, since it upsets him to think that Iâ€™m making myself unhappy, worrying for him. So I shouldnâ€™t take it upon myselfâ€” it wouldnâ€™t do either of us any good.â€

Hilde was silent for a moment. â€œYeah,â€ she said. â€œI understand.â€

â€œItâ€™s strange that you donâ€™t feel the same way. I guess weâ€™re very different people.â€

â€œI donâ€™t knowâ€¦â€ Hilde said. â€œMaybe because thereâ€™s a part of me that thinks if I know enough, I can fix something. Maybe thatâ€™s silly.â€ She looked out the window. â€œSieg offered to let me go back to the city to live with him,â€ she said. â€œEven though my father wouldnâ€™t want me to.â€

â€œIt is much safer out here.â€Â 

â€œYeah.â€

â€œDo you want to go back?â€

â€œI donâ€™t really want to leave Heinrich,â€ Hilde saidâ€” but that was clearly a non-answer.

â€œWell, I think he has plenty of company. Do you want to be with Herr Kircheis?â€

â€œI meanâ€”â€ Hilde suddenly seemed very flustered. She picked up another cookie, but didnâ€™t eat it. â€œThereâ€™s nothing to do in the city either.â€

â€œMaybe thatâ€™s for the best,â€ Eva said. â€œI wouldnâ€™t want Herr Kircheis to be in danger.â€

â€œYeah.â€Â 

Again there was a moment of silence. â€œWell,â€ Eva said, â€œwhatever you decide to doâ€” Iâ€™ll support you.â€

â€œThanks. I suppose you donâ€™t know my father very well, so you wouldnâ€™t have to worry about upsetting him by letting me do something dangerous.â€

â€œIâ€™m not letting you,â€ Eva said. â€œYouâ€™re your own woman, and I wasnâ€™t put in charge of you.â€Â 

Hilde laughed. â€œVery true. But thank you, really.â€

â€œOf course.â€ Eva stood. â€œI should go see if thereâ€™s anything I can do to help move dinner along.â€

Â 

Â 

Perhaps surprisingly, it was Heinrich that Eva spent the most time with. It might have first been out of pity, although she wouldnâ€™t have admitted that. The man was suffering the winterâ€™s leanness in the most physical way: his seizure medication had run out, and no matter how far and wide anyone looked, there wasnâ€™t any more of it to be found. When one of the resulting seizures caused him to fall out of his wheelchair and fracture his collarbone, his doctor prescribed him an alternative, but it didnâ€™t stop seizures at their source, and instead simply made him so weak that he could barely move. When one of them came over him now, instead of the violent clenching of muscles that had terrified Eva when she had first witnessed it, they were now a kind of vacant shudder that passed over him. His eyes rolled back in his head and his mouth twitched uncontrollably.Â 

Eva had never before thought much about the way that the brain was an object, and a delicate one. Before coming to Heinrichâ€™s house, she had maintained the vague belief in a soul that came from not thinking much about the idea. For some reason, learning from Reuenthal that Wolfâ€™s secret was not what she had imagined had severely shaken her abstract faith. Watching the way Heinrich ceased to be himself during his seizures impressed on her how fragile and physical the spirit was, to the point where she found she had no faith left at all. She spent quite a lot of time thinking about it now, sitting at Heinrichâ€™s bedside.

He enjoyed her company, and she his. It didnâ€™t seem at all improper to spend so much time with him, which in itself Eva felt sorry for: even that part of being a man was denied to him. She knew Wolf would never resent her time with him, anyway.

When he was awake and alert enough to focus, she would read to him: books of poetry and short stories, mostly, provided by Maggieâ€™s friend Count Landsberg. Sometimes Hilde would bring in one of the books of history that she had finished, and Eva would patiently go through that one as well, but it wasnâ€™t her preference, and Heinrich told her to pick what she liked, since he didnâ€™t want to do anything that would risk straining her patience.Â 

When Heinrich was too tired to focus, Eva would paint or knit. She set up her watercolor paper on an easel, tilted so that he could see it, and she painted picture after picture. She wasnâ€™t anything more than a hobbyist painter, but she enjoyed it, and the paintings had a charm of their own. They were mostly imagined landscapes: mountains, summer skies, birds wheeling above the ocean. Heinrich liked watching them take shape, seeing some glimpse of a world beyond his bedside.

Sometimes, she painted portraits, working from old photographs. She drew a picture of Hilde and Heinrich as children, and that one ended up pinned to the wall where Heinrich could look at it at any time. She painted Wolf and herself from a photo taken at Hankâ€™s wedding, and that one, too, was given a place of honor in Heinrichâ€™s bedroom. She gave pictures of Hank and Kircheis to Maggie and Hilde, respectively, and even worked up the nerve to paint Reuenthal for Elfriedeâ€” though she didnâ€™t quite work up the nerve to give her the picture. It was one of the best of the lot, painted more from memory than from the photograph. His expression was the one she had remembered from years ago: her wedding day, when he had kissed her hand. There was something so cold and miserable in his eyes that day, and that same look stared out from the otherwise unassuming portrait of Reuenthal, sitting in front of a dark window. She ended up tucking that painting in among the discarded stack of less-than-perfect landscapes, which were tossed into a desk drawer.Â 

When Heinrich slept, she occasionally turned her easel around so that she could paint him. They were just simple little sketches, trying to capture the gentle way sleep smoothed out the pain in his eyes. These paintings, she kept tucked away. She supposed she would probably give them to Hilde and Count Mariendorf eventually, when the inevitable happened, but they were hers for now.

She didnâ€™t always stay around when he was sleepingâ€” he was only awake for a few hours a dayâ€” but she did spend most of his waking time with him. He was quite deliberate in telling her how much he appreciated her company, though it always made her flush.Â 

â€œI enjoy your company, too,â€ sheâ€™d say. â€œYou make it sound like Iâ€™m obliging you. Iâ€™m not.â€

â€œYou say so. But donâ€™t feel like you need to stay for my sake, Eva.â€

â€œDo you know, Heinrichâ€” Iâ€™m quite lonely when youâ€™re asleep.â€ She didnâ€™t know if he believed her, but it was true.

The only time that she didnâ€™t stay with him was when his priest came by. She didnâ€™t know his name, since Heinrich only ever called him Father. He was as nondescript as men come, with brown hair and Imperial blue eyes. The only thing unusual about him was the white Earth Church stole that he draped over the shoulders of his black suit. The priest slipped in and out of the house without speaking to anyone, except the servant who let him in and Heinrich up in his bedroom. The door to Heinrichâ€™s room was left open during his visits, in case he had an emergency, but it meant that Eva could hear the manâ€™s sonorous voice as he read scriptures and gave Heinrich some blessed water to drink. During these visits, Heinrich rarely said anything aside from the words of the prayers, and Eva always gave him space afterwards. When the priest left, he usually stared out the window quietly for some time, watching the snow swirl across the glass.

Hilde didnâ€™t mind her cousinâ€™s religious beliefs, and Magdalena avoided the subject, but Elfriede was dismissive. On one of the rare occasions that the four women all ate dinner together, she told Hilde, â€œYou ought to put a stop to that priest coming here.â€

â€œWhy would I do that?â€ Hilde asked. â€œIt makes Heinrich happy.â€

â€œYesâ€” exactly,â€ Elfriede said.

â€œAnd you want to take away a dying manâ€™s happiness?â€ Maggie asked. â€œCome on, El. Even youâ€™re not that sick.â€

â€œThey flatter him,â€ Elfriede said, ignoring Magdalena entirely. â€œThey just want his money, when he dies. He hasnâ€™t got an heirâ€” heâ€™ll leave everything he can to them. Itâ€™s twisted, isnâ€™t it?â€ She delivered this in a very flat tone, though still somehow mocking. â€œI expect youâ€™d inherit, if he doesnâ€™t bequeath it all to them, in exchange for them feeding him a fantasy. I suppose every sick man wants to believe their soul will fly away somewhere.â€

Hildeâ€™s face turned various colors in the dim light, pale and then red. â€œI donâ€™t care about the money,â€ she said. â€œAnd Iâ€™ll thank you to never mention this to Heinrichâ€” and donâ€™t bother his priest, either.â€

â€œWeâ€™re all here because Heinrich is kind enough to let us stay here,â€ Eva said. â€œIf he wants to be a charitable man, then Iâ€™m thankful to be a recipient of his charity.â€

Elfriede laughed. â€œOf course.â€

â€œAnd where would you be if you werenâ€™t here with us?â€ Magdalena asked. â€œIf itâ€™s so disagreeable, youâ€™re free to leave.â€

Elfriede tipped her glass at Magdalena in a mock toast. â€œOf course not, darling . Iâ€™m so very happy to be here with you.â€

Hilde stood up without another word, then picked up her plate to bring it to the kitchen with such jerky movements that she dropped her fork on the floor. Eva retrieved it, gave an apologetic glance to the other two women, then followed Hilde out into the kitchen with her own dishes in hand. She dropped them into the sink while Hilde stared out the dark kitchen window.

â€œAre you alright, Hilde?â€ Eva asked.

â€œYes, Iâ€™m fine.â€ But her voice came out choked, and she didnâ€™t turn away from the window to look at Eva. â€œThank youâ€”â€ she said.

â€œFor what?â€

â€œFor being kind to Heinrich.â€

â€œHeâ€™s my friend,â€ Eva said. â€œYou donâ€™t have to thank me for that.â€

Hilde nodded and didnâ€™t say anything else.

Evangeline brought up the subject the next day, when she was sitting with Heinrich.Â 

â€œHeinrich,â€ she said. â€œCan I ask you a personal question?â€

He rolled his head towards her; he had been staring out the window again. The sun was just going down, and his bedroom was lit by the light, incongruously golden for how cold it was. It made his white hair and pale face seem less deathly, at least for a moment. â€œOf course.â€

â€œHow did you start believing in Terraism?â€

â€œOhâ€”â€ He laughed, which turned into a wheeze. â€œYouâ€™ll think Iâ€™m very stupid if I tell you.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure I wonâ€™t.â€

â€œYears agoâ€” back when I was a little better, and could still go out sometimesâ€” the church put on an exhibition in the capital. â€œNo, of course not, Heinrich.â€

â€œI cried like a baby,â€ he said.

â€œDo you have a picture of it?â€ she asked.

â€œI wouldnâ€™t say that,â€ she said. â€œI think itâ€™s a beautiful story.â€

â€œI donâ€™t see how.â€

â€œYes. I would want to blameâ€” you worship Mother Earth, donâ€™t you?â€

He nodded.

â€œOf courseâ€” of course, Heinrich.â€

Â 

Â 

There wasnâ€™t anything to do in the von Kummel house except wait for time to pass. It would soon be March, but she didnâ€™t let herself look forward to spring: that seemed too far away to be real. Eva thought that perhaps she could pass an indefinite amount of time this way, in a spiritual hibernation, except that one day, quite abruptly and without any warning whatsoever, it ended.

Oskar von Reuenthal and Siegfried Kircheis appeared at their door one evening, long after the four women had already eaten their dinner. Kircheis slipped out to find Hilde immediately. Eva encountered him in the hallway, but there was something very unhappy in his usually-placid eyes, so she let him brush past without saying more than hello, and telling him that Hilde was in the library.

Reuenthal was in the dining room, but he hadnâ€™t sat down. He was looking at the painting of Hank, which Maggie had hung on the wall. â€œYes.â€

â€œOhâ€” I wasnâ€™t sure if I had gotten his expression right.â€ In the painting, Hank lounged on a couch, his arm beneath his head, smiling wistfully out at the viewer. â€œYou did.â€ Reuenthal kept looking at it.
