Evaâ€™s heart twisted in her chest and she felt faint. Blindly, she reached for one of the dining room chairs and sat down in it. Reuenthal didnâ€™t turn to look at her at all. When she had collected herself enough to speak, she asked, â€œIs that why youâ€™re here? To warn us?â€

â€œNo. I need to speak to Elfriede. I told one of the servants to get her.â€

â€œThis has given Littenheim a way to win the civil war. â€œOh.â€ She didnâ€™t quite understand the ramifications of everything Reuenthal was saying, but she didnâ€™t have any reason to doubt that it was true. â€œWhy do you need Elfriede?â€

The Idyll of the Rue Plumet and the Epic of the Rue Saint-Denis

See the end of the chapter for notes

February 489 I.C., Odin

Hilde didnâ€™t sleep for more than forty minutes that night. She knew that was foolish of her, since there might not be time for sleeping later and she should take what she could get now, but it was exactly that knowledge that made her unwilling to lie down. She instead spent the night packing her few things that she would want to bring to Kircheisâ€™s apartment and transcribing the plan they had worked out into her computer. She didnâ€™t realize that it was morning until the cold winter sun began to stream through her window and she heard a knock on her door. She opened it.

It was Eva (wonderful, kind-hearted Eva) standing there in her bathrobe and proffering a steaming mug of coffee and a plate of toast and eggs.

â€œI would have come down to breakfast,â€ Hilde said. â€œBut thank you.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think thereâ€™s going to be much of a breakfast,â€ Eva said. â€œI donâ€™t know how you missed Maggie and Elfriedeâ€™s screaming match last night.â€

â€œIâ€”â€ Hilde flushed. â€œI didnâ€™t want to get involved. I figured it was personal.â€

â€œYeah. Maggie told me what it was about. Maybe for the best that you resisted any temptation to walk in on it.â€ She smiled. â€œCan I come in?â€

â€œOh, yes, of course.â€ She took the offered breakfast out of Evaâ€™s hands and held the door open with her foot. Hildeâ€™s room, usually quite neat, was currently in a state of complete disarray: papers everywhere so that she could see all her notes at once, and a jumble of clothes that she had picked through to find what she wanted to bring back to the city. Her small bag was neatly packed in the cornerâ€” she wouldnâ€™t need much, and anything she was missing, she figured she could borrow from Sieg. She was even still dressed in her clothes from the night before.

Eva shuffled some of the papers around on the bed and then sat down on it, while Hilde took her seat at her desk.Â 

â€œYouâ€™ve made this place look like Hankâ€™s office,â€ Eva said.

â€œI wish I could be flattered by the comparison.â€Â

â€œI know. Iâ€™m sorry.â€

â€œIâ€™ll try,â€ Eva said. â€œWhat else am I good for?â€

â€œDonâ€™t say that!â€ Hilde wiped off her hands and shoved her plate to the side. She moved to the narrow bed where Eva was sitting, and gathered up all the papers. As she shuffled them into a neater stack, she said, â€œIâ€™ve always really admired that about you, honestly.â€

â€œThank you,â€ Eva said. There was something very strained in her voice, and Hilde looked away, down at the sheaf of messy, handwritten notes. She cleared her throat and pulled one to the top of the stack, and tried to think about how Hank would explain things.

â€œSo, uh, you know why we need to go to get Lichtenlade, right?â€

She explained the plan to Eva for about an hour, going over their goals and how confident they were in each step of the multi-faceted plan. In order to capture Lichtenlade and Erwin Josef, they would need to get to the mountain home where Lichtenladeâ€™s family was hiding, break past the security without the family noticing, and get into the house to catch the important people before they had a chance to flee into hidden passages dug into the mountains. The house Elfriede described was a stately manor, but one built over old mines, which the Lichtenlade family had kept as a refuge and escape hastch of last resort. They were so deep, she said, that they could survive a nuclear blast down there. So long as Reuenthal and his men could capture the family before they fled, after that, it was a matter of getting out alive, and bringing the captives back to a Braunschweig safehouse without Littenheimâ€™s men discovering where they were.

Eva, despite saying that she wouldnâ€™t understand any of it, was an intelligent woman, and when she asked questions, they were astute ones: often things that she or Kircheis had wondered about during their initial planning. â€œWe need a distraction,â€ she said. â€œIdeally in the capital, ideally at Neue Sanssouci itself, but anything that keeps Littenheimâ€™s secret police occupied. Â

â€œSo, youâ€™re leaving,â€ Heinrich said. His voice was weak, and she wanted to beg him to drink some water, but that wouldnâ€™t have done any good in this conversation.

â€œDid Eva tell you?â€

â€œYouâ€™re dressed to say goodbye,â€ he said. This was true. She was already wearing her coat and boots.

â€œIf itâ€™s any consolation, I didnâ€™t plan it and keep it a secret. It was decided after you went to sleep last night.â€

â€œHave I really?â€

â€œI should be saying that to you,â€ she replied.

â€œIâ€™m a lost cause. Youâ€™re not.â€

â€œDonâ€™t say things like thatâ€” you make me feel bad for leaving.â€

â€œIâ€™ll look forward to it,â€ he said. â€œDonâ€™t worry about me. Iâ€™ll be alright. Evaâ€™s been good company. As long as youâ€™re not stealing her away with you, I really have no right to complain.â€

â€œHank would say itâ€™s a human right to complain, and youâ€™ve got as much of it as anybody else.â€

â€œThatâ€™s a good maxim. Iâ€™ll have to say some prayers for him, too, as thanks for it.â€

â€œThank you.â€ She put his hand down on the blanket, patted it once in a meekly reassuring gesture, then headed for the door, rubbing her eyes though she wasnâ€™t crying.

When she stepped out of the house into the driveway, she just stopped and looked around herself for a moment before she got into the car. She would be back, but she tried to fix in her mind the peaceful glistening snow on the pines, the dripping sound of it melting in the pale morning sun, and the clear blue sky overhead. She knew she was stupid to be leaving this placeâ€” even if nothing was wrong in the city, it was as idyllic as it could get, at least in its surroundingsâ€” but she saw Elfriedeâ€™s shadow pass across one of the windows on the lower floor, and an involuntary shudder crossed her. She passed it off as a shiver, but hastened to open the door of the car and drive away.

Â 

Â 

Hilde drove back to the city by herself, and she spent the entire journey ruminating. The further she drove from her cousinâ€™s house, the stronger her relief grew to be away from it. Even aside from all the misery the house contained that she was escaping, she wanted to see Kircheis again. After everything they had done together, it felt almost unbearable to let him be alone in the city.

Her thoughts turned around and around, trying to attack the problem that she and Kircheis had been assigned to think over. What distraction would keep Littenheimâ€™s military police occupied enough that they wouldnâ€™t notice an attack on Lichtenladeâ€™s safehouse? Although Reuenthal had said that he was near certain that he had evaded detection by the MPs so far, Kircheis himself was under some kind of surveillance. This was why the distraction had been handed to him, since whatever he didâ€” if he didnâ€™t go to extreme efforts to hide his tracksâ€” would draw the MPs like flies.

The problem was manpower, of course. Braunschweigâ€™s forces remaining on Odin amounted to fewer than a hundred men, all currently dispersed and in hiding. It would be enough to take the Lichtenlade safehouse, since Elfriede had provided them with plenty of information about its security, but there wouldnâ€™t be enough for anything else.

The simplest thing would be some kind of act of terrorism. Between the two of them, Hilde was sure that they could rig bridges to explode, or find one of Littenheimâ€™s storerooms and burn it to the ground. The trouble was that neither she nor Kircheis wanted to suggest anything that would be extreme enough to actually draw the MPs out in force. They were both somewhat wary of hurting the civilians in the capital city, who were already suffering a great deal of deprivation. The other problem with terrorismâ€” and Kircheis could deny it, but it was trueâ€” was that it would almost certainly be fatal for the perpetrator, especially if it was being done specifically to draw the ire of the MPs.

More than anything, this was the reason that Hilde had asked Kircheis to let her come back to the city. She didnâ€™t think that Kircheis wanted to put himself in danger, but if he was under pressure, and saw no other way, he might talk himself into it. There were things in this world worth dying for, Hilde thought, but a distraction was not likely to be one of them.

Hilde left the car on a street in the suburbs, a ways away from the city itself, near to where one of her familyâ€™s servantsâ€™ families lived. She pulled her jacket tightly around herself, then began her long walk. There was a guarded border around the city, one that she didnâ€™t want to try bringing a vehicle through, and she would have to meet Kircheis on the other side of it. The easiest crossing would be through a frosty little patch of greenbelt between two stretches of highway.Â 

The roads were completely empty, so she didnâ€™t feel any hesitation in hopping over the barrier, jogging across the road, and ducking into the barren brambles in the center of the split highway. From there, she made her way through the trees, watching carefully to make sure no one spotted her as she crept past the small guard encampments on the road. She was well hidden by wood, and no one was paying attention to the greenbelt, so she made it past easily. When the two sides of the highway lifted up off the ground to join a bridge a little way down, Hilde slid down the snow covered slope of the greenway and ended up on familiar city streets. A little ways away was the park where she was supposed to meet Kircheis.

This was still the very outskirts of the city, and the park was completely empty. She passed the time sitting on some childrenâ€™s swings with her bag in the snow near her feet. Even with just the watery noonday sun, the snow was beginning to melt, and for the first time in months, Hilde felt a stirring of hopefulness that this was almost over. She ran the math in her headâ€” how long would it take for Hankâ€™s ships to get from Iserlohn to Odin? A month or so. They might arrive before spring did, but spring was coming nevertheless.

She wondered how Elizabeth was doing. The plan had always been to leave her in fortified Geiersburg, so that was likely where she was, with her mother. She was sure that Hank would have left them with enough ships and supplies to defend themselves, so she wasnâ€™t exactly afraid of the idea of the Imperial fleets attacking, despite the order from the defeated Iserlohn forces. Although she wouldnâ€™t want to be Elizabeth, trapped in a lonely fortress, Hilde still felt a pang of regret at not being allowed to accompany her. It was better that she was on Odin with Kircheisâ€” but she couldnâ€™t help but wonder about the alternative.

She was shivering from how long she had been out in the snow, and her pants were all wet from tromping through the brush, but Kircheis finally pulled up. He was driving an unmarked pickup truck and had a woolen hat pulled down tightly over his ears. Before he could even get out of the car to help her with her meager luggage, she was already halfway inside, dragging her bag in after her and tossing it at her feet.

â€œI cannot wait for spring,â€ she said by way of greeting, flopping back in her seat and luxuriating in the carâ€™s warmth. She turned her head towards him and grinnedâ€” something about the situation and what she was doing suddenly striking her as funny. Kircheisâ€™s face crinkled up in his usual beatific smile.

â€œItâ€™ll come,â€ Kircheis said. â€œHow was your driveâ€” and getting into the city?â€

â€œOh, it was fine,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™ve just been thinking a lot.â€

â€œItâ€™s hard not to do that.â€

â€œYouâ€™d be surprised,â€ Hilde said. â€œIf you told me I couldnâ€™t come here, Iâ€™d have to try to turn my brain off for the next month.â€

â€œYou wouldnâ€™t have listened to me if I said that,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI donâ€™t think youâ€™re capable of it.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know if thatâ€™s a compliment, Sieg.â€

â€œIt is.â€

â€œHave you been alright? I feel like we havenâ€™t gotten a chance to really talk in ages.â€

â€œWeâ€™ll have plenty of time now,â€ he said.

â€œWellâ€” tell me.â€

â€œWhat do you want to know?â€

He was being evasive on purpose. â€œHave you seen Martin?â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œSpoken to him?â€

â€œNo.â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry, Sieg.â€

â€œItâ€™s alright,â€ he said. â€œHe made his choices.â€

â€œI donâ€™t believe you,â€ Hilde said. â€œYou havenâ€™t really given up on him, have you?â€

Kircheis was silent for a long time. In fact, Hilde wasnâ€™t sure if he was going to answer at all, but she waited. â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI suppose I wonâ€™t, until Iâ€™m not given a choice about it.â€ He stared straight ahead of them down the roadâ€” empty of all cars, except for a few abandoned ones on the side of the street. â€œHe just thinks I donâ€™t have that choice anymore. I canâ€™t change his mind about that. I canâ€™t make him.â€

â€œI am sorry.â€

â€œI know.â€

They drove some more in silence. Hilde kept glancing over at Kircheis, wondering what he was thinking, but his face was quite impassive. Before they left the cityâ€™s outskirts, Kircheis glanced over at her.

â€œAre you sure you want to come with me?â€ he asked. â€œI could tell you where the safehouses are instead, and how to get there without being noticed. You wouldnâ€™t be under surveillance there.â€

â€œI want to stay with you,â€ Hilde said. â€œThatâ€™s why I came.â€Â 

He nodded, and they entered the city proper, moving from the vaguely industrial area into the region where shops and apartment buildings commingled.

It looked very different than Hilde remembered, though the snow did a lot to disguise the worst of the damage. Some buildings had burned down, storefront windows had been shattered, but the biggest change was how empty everything felt. Much like Hilde, everyone who could leave the city had done so. Some people couldnâ€™t pick up their entire lives, but enough could that it was very obvious how far the population of the city had shrunk. There were no stores open either, and so little reason for people to be out on the streets. The few people they saw, shoulders hunched and walking with a protective, scurrying gait, all stopped to watch their car go byâ€” one of the few vehicles moving anywhere. They stared at the car with hostile gazes, and some put their hands inside their jackets, reaching for hidden weapons. The first time she saw someone do this, Hilde looked over at Kircheis, looking down his side, and she saw the noticeable bump at his hip beneath his jacket where he carried his own sidearmâ€” the one he had been given by Hank.

â€œHas it been bad in the city?â€ she asked. For some reason, she lowered her voice, though of course no one could hear them inside the car.

â€œPretty bad,â€ Kircheis said. â€œThereâ€™sâ€¦ not much food coming in.â€

â€œIs there any?â€ Hilde asked.

â€œSome.â€ They came to an intersection, and he slowed the car to a crawl so that he could look around and decide which route to take. They were winding a very circuitous path through the city, following some intuition that only Kircheis had about where there was likely to be trouble. â€œThereâ€™s nothing coming in from space,â€ he said as he picked a direction and went off in it. â€œBut there are still farms down south producing foodâ€” itâ€™s just a matter of distribution. Minor nobility who own land on Odinâ€” if they swear fealty to Littenheim heâ€™s happy enough to use them and take their goods, if not, heâ€™s happy to try to steal from them, if he can. But itâ€™s easier to bomb a farm or a factory into nothing than it is to get it to produce for you.â€ He shook his head. â€œAnd what does make inâ€” Littenheim doles it out as favors, or itâ€™s smuggled in through the black market.â€

â€œHave you had enough to eat?â€ Hilde asked.

â€œYes, of course,â€ Kircheis said. â€œBraunschweig put plenty of supplies away, at least plenty for his agents on Odin. I wouldnâ€™t have told you to come out here if you were going to starve with me.â€

Hilde furrowed her brow. â€œItâ€™s not like we havenâ€™t done that together before,â€ she said, thinking about their several day trek across Castropâ€™s planet.

Kircheis gave her a little smile, but didnâ€™t say anything.

They parked a ways away from Kircheisâ€™s apartment, leaving the car in the lowest level of a parking garage. Vandals had already come through here, and the security gate was smashed apart. Kircheis covered the car with a dirty tarp that had been stashed inside the dumpster Kircheis parked them next to. â€œIs that really going to deter anyone?â€ Hilde asked.

â€œIâ€™ve been lucky so far. But itâ€™s alright. I just need a place to bring it that isnâ€™t the safehouse. This is fine.â€

They walked together to Kircheisâ€™s apartment. Now that they were outside in the streets, Hilde couldnâ€™t help but assume the same wary posture as the other pedestrians they had seen. She looked around nervously, feeling like every upper story dark window might have someone unfriendly behind it. She didnâ€™t really enjoy the feelingâ€” she had always considered herself quite brave, and familiar with the city. She stuck close to Kircheis, and was relieved when they finally arrived at his house.

The stairwell up to Kircheisâ€™s apartment was dark, except for the light that filtered in through the windows. There was no power in the building, and Hilde could see her breath rise in clouds.Â 

â€œI have a solar panel on the roof,â€ Kircheis said, preempting any question, though she would have accepted any living condition. â€œItâ€™s enough to live on.â€

His apartment, despite how cold it was and the lack of lights on, was just like she remembered it, and she couldnâ€™t help but smile.Â 

â€œHome, sweet home,â€ Hilde said.

â€œI suppose I donâ€™t need to give you the tour,â€ Kircheis said, but then he did anywayâ€” giving her explanations of how he lived his life without running water (water to the building had been shut off to keep the pipes from freezing, and after that the cityâ€™s water supply had faltered in general), and where he kept all his food, and how to power the small hotplate from the battery connected to his rooftop solar panel, and how to stay warm in the cold house.Â 

Kircheis had erected a makeshift tent-like canopy over the top of his bed, to keep the warmth in, by pulling the tall bookshelves to either side of the bed, and draping layers of linens over the topâ€” a plastic tarp and then bedsheets scavenged from who-knows-where, all safety pinned together to hold their shape.Â 

â€œI usually stay in here when Iâ€™m not busy with other things,â€ Kircheis said. â€œThe ventilationâ€™s not great, but itâ€™s warm.â€ He held open the curtain of blankets so that she could get into the spacious bed, but she realized her pants were still soaking wet from crawling around in the snow. She pulled open her bag and discovered that her clothes, which had been wrapped around her computer to protect it, were not in much better shape.Â 

â€œI hate to impose,â€ Hilde said, â€œbut do you have anything dry I can wear?â€

â€œYouâ€™re never an imposition,â€ he said. He smiled, but it didnâ€™t reach his eyes like it usually did. â€œYouâ€™re about Martinâ€™s size. He left most of his winter things when he left in the spring.â€

â€œLast springâ€¦ Has it really been that long already?â€

Kircheis didnâ€™t answerâ€” she hadnâ€™t expected him toâ€” but led her to the empty other bedroom. There were boxes of canned goods on the floor, and the bed had been stripped of linens so that Kircheis could use them for his tent. Kircheis bent down to look under the bed and pulled out a box of folded winter clothes: sweaters and heavy corduroy pants. Hilde picked up one off the top of the pile and hugged it to her chest. â€œThanks,â€ she said.

Â It hardly needed discussion, but Kircheis asked it anyway. â€œDo you want me to set up this room for you?â€

â€œAnd make us both freeze? I donâ€™t think so.â€ She gently tugged on Kircheisâ€™s sleeve, and they left the empty bedroom.

When she had changed into clothes that were at least dry, if not warm, she joined Kircheis on his bed, and although it was cozy and made her start yawning, they immediately got to work. She set her computer up in front of them, and he spread out a paper map across the bed, and they started to pick apart their options for a distraction in the capital in detail. Kircheis was more familiar with the state of the city than she was, since she had been away for so long, and he pointed out on the map all the major buildings that had already been destroyed, the bridges that had been toppled, and the infrastructure that had ceased to function.

Hilde poked at the map where it indicated a block of power transformers. â€œToo bad powerâ€™s already down,â€ she said. â€œThat would be my choice, if we had it.â€

â€œIâ€™ve been thinking about that,â€ Kircheis said. â€œThe cityâ€™s been cut off from power, but itâ€™s all nuclearâ€” the plant itself is still technically operational, as far as I know. Itâ€™s the transmission stations that have all been interrupted.â€

Hilde shivered, only half from residual chill. â€œAnd would there be a way to attack it without risking it getting out of hand? I donâ€™t personally want to irradiate the entire city.â€

Kircheis looked off above her head. â€œThe MPs have as much reasonâ€” or moreâ€” to stop that from happening,â€ he said. â€œWe donâ€™t actually need to cause damageâ€” we just have to get them to come out to stop us.â€

â€œThatâ€™s suicide,â€ Hilde said pointedly. â€œThe ideal distraction would be one where we create a problem that has to be dealt with after itâ€™s happened, because that means whoever causes it can get out of the way, while still keeping the MPs occupied.â€

â€œI know.â€ He looked back down at the map and pointed at the airport on the edge of the city. â€œLittenheimâ€™s parked all his remaining ships there, except for a few in the country. What about that?â€

â€œProbably the most heavily guarded place,â€ she said.

They discussed the merits of different targets for an hour or so, without coming any closer to a conclusion. When Hildeâ€™s yawns grew too potent for even Kircheis to ignore, he stretched and said, â€œI should go run and get some water, and do my daily message exchange with Rear Admiral Reuenthal. Do you want to stay here?â€

â€œDo you want me to come?â€

â€œYou can come tomorrow. Itâ€™s not that interesting.â€

â€œIf you see the rear admiral, please tell him I said hello.â€

â€œI wonâ€™t,â€ Kircheis said. â€œIâ€™m just going to a message cache.â€

â€œWhere are you getting water from?â€

â€œLittenheimâ€™s soldiers bring it in trucks to a couple places around the city,â€ he said. â€œOtherwise, weâ€™d be boiling river water, and thereâ€™d be riots.â€

â€œEugh,â€ Hilde said. She almost asked where Littenheim was getting the water from, and if that would be a viable target, but then decided that attacking it would cause more problems for the city than it would solve. â€œStay safe.â€

â€œI will,â€ Kircheis said. â€œWe can have dinner when I get back.â€

â€œSounds good.â€ Hilde rolled up the map, shut her computer, and then laid back on the bed, pulling the blankets up around herself.Â 

She listened as Kircheis collected the huge empty water jugs, shuffling all around the apartment. He yelled a goodbye to her when he left, and then an eerie silence descended. The whole building creaked and moaned in the wind. Perhaps all old buildings did, but Hilde had never been in Kircheisâ€™s house alone before. The coziness of the canopy bed nevertheless was soothing, and so the unfamiliar sounds washed over her without stirring up any anxiety about being here, in the city.

She drifted in and out of consciousness for some time, not aware of how long it was. She never had been good at napping, and so she didnâ€™t fall into a truly restful sleep. And whatever sleep she had managed to fall into was interrupted by the click of the lock on the front door, and the sound of heavy footsteps that most certainly did not belong to Kircheis. Kircheis moved quite delicatelyâ€” these steps were thumping, with short strides. The intruder paced around the kitchen, as if intending to wake Hilde up.

She cursed herself for not asking Kircheis if there was any other weapon in the house beside his sidearm. She thought that there must be, though peeking out through the curtains of the bed, she didnâ€™t see anything. The door between the bedroom and the living room was also closed, another heat saving measure, so she couldnâ€™t get a glimpse of the intruder. She crept out of the bed and gave as silent of a search of the room for a weapon as she could. She came up empty handed, not even finding anything suitable as a bludgeon. The only thing she had to hand was the long cable that emerged from the battery pack wired to the solar panel on the roof. She took it, holding it in both hands, hoping it might be useful as a garotte.

She turned the handle of the bedroom door silently, and looked out through the crack. The intruder was sitting at the kitchen table. He had helped himself to one of Kircheisâ€™s cans of tuna, and was eating it with a fork directly from the can. Although he was facing away from Hilde, she could smell it. The man was in uniformâ€” the uniform of the Military Police. He had taken off his hat and laid it on the table near his elbow, the eagle emblem glinting in the watery sunset light that was peeking its way through the kitchen window. At his side on the floor was a plain black messenger bag.

Hilde took a few steps forward, sliding her socked feet across the floor, trying not to breathe. She came within a meter of the man, and he made no indication that he had heard her coming until she raised her garrotte up, intending to lunge and strike, when he said, â€œFraulein Mariendorf, are you aware that Lieutenant Kircheis leaves his spare key in his mailbox?â€

Rear Admiral Bronner, though he also now only had a lieutenantâ€™s stripes on his shoulders, turned around to face Hilde, who lowered, but didnâ€™t unclench her hands from, her makeshift weapon. She had met Bronner at Leighâ€™s wedding, and had heard plenty about him from Kircheis besides that, but she didnâ€™t exactly trust him.

â€œDid he tell you to come here?â€ she asked.

â€œOf course not. Heâ€™ll be very annoyed that I waited until he was gone to come and pay you a visit.â€

â€œThen what are you doing here?â€

â€œLetâ€™s have a little chat, Fraulein,â€ Bronner said. He gestured magnanimously at one of the other chairs at the table.

â€œAre you an MP now?â€ she asked. She circled to the other side of the table, but she didnâ€™t sit down.

â€œIâ€™m exactly the same as I ever was,â€ Bronner said. â€œA person who likes information.â€

â€œThat doesnâ€™t answer the question,â€ she said.

Bronnerâ€™s face was expressive like a mask was expressive, the expression it carried perfectly selected for maximum effect. He smiled. â€œThe basement I usually work out of has found itself occupied, and I found myself temporarily out of a job, along with all of my subordinates,â€ he said. â€œI decided that if I wanted to remain on stage, and keep getting fed, I should pick up an understudy role.â€ His whole countenance changed, and he adopted a countryside accent, of the kind that Hilde recognized from visiting her familyâ€™s estates. â€œAnd, of course, my lady, when the esteemed Marquis Littenheim came to Odin, he needed someone from his estates to settle in to the Military Police and make sure there werenâ€™t some lingering troubles in that department, didnâ€™t he?â€

â€œYou made up a job for yourself?â€ Hilde asked, somewhat incredulous. â€œAnd nobodyâ€™s caught you?â€

Bronner dropped the accent. â€œOf course they havenâ€™t caught me. The MPs and Littenheimâ€™s inner circle are all in complete chaos.â€ He laughed. â€œEven if they knew I was a fraud, Iâ€™m still more efficient than half the idiots over there.â€

â€œHow nice to hear,â€ Hilde said. She stared him down.

â€œYouâ€™re not as easy to bother as Leigh, are you?â€ Bronner asked. â€œPity.â€

â€œIâ€™d like for you to tell me what youâ€™re doing here in Siegâ€™s apartmentâ€” especially if youâ€™re working for Littenheimâ€” or Lichtenlade, if thatâ€™s who youâ€™re spying on the MPs for.â€

â€œIâ€™m not working for anyone,â€ Bronner said. â€œOr, what was Leighâ€™s lineâ€” heâ€™s working for the Empireâ€™s people? So am I.â€

â€œI find that very hard to believe.â€

â€œWhy?â€ Bronner asked. â€œIf you can believe it from Leigh, arenâ€™t I a far better actor?â€

â€œCommodore Leigh isnâ€™t a liar.â€

Bronner let out a laughâ€” possibly the first genuine emotion he had ever expressed in his life. â€œThatâ€™s very funny.â€ But he looked at her straight on. â€œIâ€™m offended that you donâ€™t believe me. Didnâ€™t I?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know why you did,â€ Hilde said.

Bronner briefly narrowed his eyes, then shook his head. â€œIt doesnâ€™t matter.â€

â€œI came to give you some information, since your friend Lieutenant Kircheis seems reluctant to do anything with the information I have given him.â€

â€œWhat is it?â€ Hilde asked.

From his messenger bag, Bronner drew a sheaf of papers. On the top was a photographâ€” in color, but the scene was so bleak that it almost appeared black and white. Behind them, blocking the road, were the shattered remnants of a road barricade, along with the burnt out husks of several vehicles. Darker smudges of burned rubber remained on the road, showing where someone had whipped their cars into motion. Hilde looked at the photo, trying to recognize any of the dead men.

â€œIâ€™m not the only one whoâ€™s stealing uniforms,â€ Bronner said, after she had looked at the photo for a moment. â€œAnd weapons, and trucks full of Littenheimâ€™s food supply, of course.â€

â€œMartin did that?â€

â€œAt least some of Herr Bufholtzâ€™s companions, yes. Theyâ€™re probably going to use the uniforms to grab more trucks, but I also am certain that theyâ€™re planning something much larger, and soon.â€

â€œI watch them, as much as Iâ€™m able,â€ Bronner said. â€œUnfortunately, theyâ€™ve made a crucial error.â€

â€œBy attacking the MPs directly, itâ€™s no longer just me who is forced to care about them,â€ Bronner said. â€œAnd donâ€™t jump to the conclusion that Iâ€™ve simply reported what I know. I havenâ€™t,â€ he said. â€œMy information is my own. But someone other than me will be looking for them.â€

â€œAnd what do you want meâ€” or Siegâ€” to do with this information?â€

â€œI donâ€™t want the capital to become a scorched wasteland,â€ Bronner said. â€œI canâ€™t stop Martin,â€ Hilde said.

â€œI donâ€™t expect that you could.â€

â€œSo what is it that you want?â€

â€œThen why do you come here pretending like youâ€™re helping him?â€

â€œCommodore Leigh wouldnâ€™tâ€”â€

â€œAnd if Martin wins?â€

â€œHe probably wonâ€™t win here against Littenheim, and he certainly wouldnâ€™t win against Braunschweig. Itâ€™s not a question of Herr Bufholtz winning. Itâ€™s a question of how many other people he drags onto the funeral pyre with him.â€

The power cable, still in Hildeâ€™s hands, was wrapped tightly enough around her palms that she had lost circulation in her fingers. Bronner was right, but she hated to admit it. She could see why all of Bronnerâ€™s visits to Kircheis had been in vain.

â€œAnd why do you think that I can do anything about it?â€ Hilde asked.

â€œWith the MPs turning more of their focus on Herr Bufholtzâ€™s activities, my ability to watch them is going to become even more constrained than it already has been.â€ He flipped through his stack of papers and handed Hilde a photograph of a nondescript industrial building, some of the windows shattered. â€œMartin is my friend,â€ Hilde said. â€œEven if youâ€™re right, I donâ€™t know why you think I would betray him.â€

â€œPeople have always managed to find their reasons,â€ Bronner said. â€œThatâ€™s a very old story. Maybe the oldest. Hilde scowled at him, and he left through the front door.

Â 

Â 

Kircheis returned about an hour later, hauling the full water jugs up the steps of the apartment. Hilde offered to help, but he just waved her off. She did at least help him assemble dinner from the stash of canned goods, though her hand kept going to the spare key in the pocket of her pants. They sat down at the table to eat their feast (canned corn, fried up slices of tinned ham, and coffee,) and Kircheis pulled out the letter he had picked up from his message exchange point. â€œMe? What for?â€ Hilde asked. She skimmed the letter that had been left for Kircheisâ€” it didnâ€™t say much other than that.

Kircheis gave a sympathetic smile. â€œI would assume he wants to lecture you, and ask how our plans for a distraction are coming. Iâ€™ll come with you,â€ he said.

â€œNo, thatâ€™s fine, you donâ€™t have to,â€ Hilde said. â€œIâ€™m happy to talk to Captain Obersteinâ€” I only met him for the first time at Hankâ€™s wedding. Will Oskar be there?â€

â€œProbably not.â€ Kircheis pointed at Obersteinâ€™s personal signature on the bottom of the note. â€œRear Admiral Reuenthal doesnâ€™t object to you being here, as far as I know, so I guess thereâ€™s no reason for him to want to meet.â€

â€œDoes Captain Oberstein object?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know why he would.â€

â€œAlright,â€ Hilde said. â€œIs it safe to go meet him? With the apartment being watched, anyway?â€

â€œYes,â€ Kircheis said. â€œOur meeting spot is outside the city, and itâ€™s pretty easy to be sure youâ€™re not followed if youâ€™re outside the city limits.â€

She nodded.

â€œAre you sure you donâ€™t want me to come?â€

â€œIf Captain Oberstein wants to make sure Iâ€™m not being a burden to you, having you come with me would do the opposite of reassure him,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s fine, Sieg. Iâ€™m capable of going to a meeting.â€

â€œI know.â€

There was a moment of silence between them. Hilde clutched the spare key in her pocket so hard that the ridges dug into her fingers, and then she steeled herself and pulled it out, placing it on the table between them. A flash of instant recognition crossed Kircheisâ€™s face.

â€œRear Admiral Bronner also wanted to meet me,â€ Hilde said quietly.

â€œOh.â€ Kircheis stared at the key, and didnâ€™t say anything more than that.

â€œDid he also ask you to tell him when Martin is going to make his moves?â€

â€œYes,â€ Kircheis said. â€œBut I donâ€™t know why he thinks that I can do that. I havenâ€™t spoken to Martin for a long time.â€ There was something off in Kircheisâ€™s voice, though.

â€œProbably for the best,â€ Hilde said.

â€œDid he say anything else to you?â€

â€œNot really,â€ Hilde said. â€œHe tried to convince me, but that was it.â€

â€œHe really thinksâ€”â€ There was a momentary flash of real anger in Kircheisâ€™s voice and expression, one that Hilde had never heard or seen before. He stifled it before he finished his sentence, but it was enough to be alarming.

â€œSiegâ€”â€

Kircheis collected himself. â€œEven if I marched myself up to Martinâ€™s hideout, he wouldnâ€™t tell me. Bronner knows that.â€

â€œNo, he doesnâ€™t,â€ Kircheis said. And he said it with such finality that Hilde couldnâ€™t argue. Perhaps Kircheis was right.Â

â€œYeah,â€ he said. â€œEnough that they know what Bronner has been doing. None of us trust him, but thereâ€™s no reason for me to stop talking to him, in case he does say something useful.â€

Hilde hesitated. â€œDoes Hank trust him?â€

â€œYes,â€ he said with a frown. â€œBut he trusts far too many people.â€

That rang true, but it had been the wrong thing for him to say.Â 

Hilde found herself thinking about it that night, long after Kircheis had turned off the single dangling lamp hung in his tented area, and they had both settled down to sleep. Kircheisâ€™s breath was irregular in his dreams, and the calmness he maintained when awake didnâ€™t keep him from tossing and turning at night.Â 

She wouldnâ€™t have said she pitied him, but that was the emotion she felt watching him thrash against his nightmares. She wished that there was something she could do to relieve him of his burden, but she felt suddenly like an outsider, even as she curled up at his side. He couldnâ€™tâ€” or wouldnâ€™tâ€” share anything he really felt. She thought about his uncharacteristic momentary anger, and how quickly he had choked it down, and she thought about the pain in his voice when he talked about Martinâ€™s love. Perhaps he thought it went without saying that he loved Martin still, or perhaps he simply didnâ€™t want to say it to her.

Why had Bronner come to her? Was she really weak enough to be convinced by his arguments, where Kircheis wasnâ€™t? Or was it the other way around?

She pulled the blankets up around her chin, and a terrible thought began to form in her mind.

Â 

Â 

Hilde went to meet with Oberstein two days later, out in the countryside. Their scheduled meeting time was early in the morning, which went against her instincts for clandestine encounters. She reassured Kircheis once again that she didnâ€™t need an escort and went by herself, though she did take a gun with her. She was hyper-aware of it at her hip beneath her coat. In her nondescript clothing, she felt just like every other hunched-shoulder pedestrian when she walked the city streets, quickly trying to get to her destination without letting trouble follow her. She made it out of the city without problems, sneaking past the guarded border just as the weak winter sun was coming up over the tops of the buildings. She navigated to the address of an abandoned house, and inside the garage found a car waiting for her, which she drove most of the remaining distance. Even though the car itself wasnâ€™t followedâ€” the roads were empty as far as her eye could seeâ€” she was still paranoid enough to leave it a mile from the meeting place, and trudge the rest of the way through the snow on foot.

They met in a convenience store, one whose shelves had all been stripped completely bare. The windows and doors hadnâ€™t been brokenâ€” either the proprietor had cleared the place out before there was any risk of looting, or any thieves had simply entered through the door, as Oberstein had. Hilde didnâ€™t know if or how he had unlocked it, but it was propped open when she arrived. An aging Dalmatian greeted her at the door, wagging its tail with the sluggish enthusiasm of an old man. Kircheis had told her what to expect, so she scratched its head in greeting and called out, â€œCaptain Oberstein, Iâ€™m here.â€

The dog led her to a tiny back room, one with a table and chairs presumably for the employees to eat their lunches at. There were old workplace posters stuck up on the walls, and there was a frozen brick of old coffee in the carafe of the machine on the counter. Oberstein sat at the table. Although he was wrapped in a heavy coat, it didnâ€™t make him appear any larger than he was, and his bony wrists showed in between where his leather gloves ended and his woolen sleeves began.

Hilde saluted at the doorway, and the dog wandered away from her to press its head into Obersteinâ€™s side. Oberstein nodded, but did not return her salute. â€œGood morning, Fraulein Mariendorf.â€ He had a nasal voice, and no expression on his face whatsoever.

â€œGood morning, sir,â€ she said.

He gestured for her to take a seat, and she did. From her bag, she pulled out all the preliminary material she had put together with Kircheis, which currently amounted to a few proposed plans about bombing the nuclear power station outside the city, or attacking the airfield where Littenheimâ€™s ships were sitting. Neither of the plans were ones that Hilde liked, but they had very few options available. She shuffled them around for a moment as she asked, â€œWhat did you want to discuss with me, sir?â€

â€œHave you come up with a plan for a diversion?â€ Oberstein asked, cutting directly to the point. â€œWhen I last spoke to Lieutenant Kircheis, he expressed hope that your presence would be beneficial. Additionally, Commodore Leigh has spoken highly of your abilities. I would like to know if we have the issue settled, so that Rear Admiral Reuenthal and I can finalize our own part in this.â€

She was somewhat relieved that this appeared to be a straightforward test from Oberstein, though she wasnâ€™t satisfied with any of the plans she had on hand. â€œIâ€™m glad to hear that Commodore Leigh is confident in me, sir. I hope that I live up to your expectations,â€ she said. â€œLieutenant Kircheis and I have been working on it.â€

Oberstein nodded again, and she laid out her plans on the table. â€œThere are two major approaches that weâ€™ve considered. Both of them have their downsides,â€ she said. She launched into a description of both plans.Â 

Oberstein listened impassively, though he pointed out the flaws in the plans before Hilde could bring them up. She agreed with him that it would be difficult to coordinate the destruction of the ships, though that would be the better target.Â 

â€œThe power plant is a softer target,â€ Oberstein said. â€œBut I would like to maintain infrastructure where possible. When Braunschweig arrives to take control, he will prioritize keeping necessities functioning.â€

Hilde looked into Obersteinâ€™s shiny, false eyes for a moment. â€œWill he, sir? Or will Commodore Leigh?â€

â€œThe latter, though the difference is immaterial at this moment,â€ Oberstein said. â€œI believe it is in everyoneâ€™s best interests to keep Commodore Leighâ€™s goals aligned with Duke Braunschweigâ€™s until the end of the civil war.â€

â€œYes, sir,â€ she said.

â€œWere those the only avenues that you are pursuing?â€

Hilde hesitated, then said, â€œCaptain Obersteinâ€” has Lieutenant Kircheis told you about Rear Admiral Bronner?â€

â€œYes,â€ Oberstein said. â€œHeâ€™s mentioned his position within the Military Police. A useful source of information, perhaps.â€

â€œDid Lieutenant Kircheis tell you what he wants?â€

â€œYes. I advised the Lieutenant that even if he could be assured of positive results, which he cannot be, it would not be worth wasting his efforts infiltrating a rebel cell. It would be of little use to us, since they are unlikely to be our allies.â€

â€œI see.â€

â€œWhy do you ask?â€

She hesitated again. â€œRear Admiral Bronner wanted us to find out the time when that group will be making their move. I assume it will be fairly soon. He stared her down, and she could see the glinting red traces of circuitry beneath the colored glass of his artificial eyes. â€œWe would not be able to plan without a date,â€ Oberstein said. â€œWe cannot have our plan resting on chance.â€

â€œI could get a date,â€ Hilde said. â€œI might need to offer them something. But I could get it.â€

â€œAnd this is not because Lieutenant Kircheis wants to help them?â€

â€œNo, sir,â€ she said. If Kircheis knew she had mentioned this to Oberstein at allâ€” she wondered if he would be furious. What would that flash of anger look like directed at her? She steeled herself to face it.

Oberstein studied her face for a moment, then nodded.

Â 

Â 

Hilde didnâ€™t have too much time. If Kircheis thought her meeting with Oberstein had run too long, he would start to be worried about her failure to reappear at home. She didnâ€™t want that to happen, but she nevertheless had a mission to accomplish.

Back inside the city, she made her way to the address that Bronner had provided. She went there on foot, and waited across the street, lingering in the stairwell on the street that descended into the basement storefront level. It gave her a decent vantage point while remaining unseen. She didnâ€™t think she could wait long, and she kept checking her watch to judge how long she could go before she needed to get back to Kircheis.Â 

The broken windows had been boarded up with plywood, so she couldnâ€™t tell how many people were inside, or what level of the building they were on, but here seemed to be plenty of people coming and going from the house, though this would only be apparent to someone like her, watching every movement near the grey stone building. People came and went one at a time, about every ten minutes or so, alternating which exits they used, and all dispersing in different directions. She didnâ€™t recognize any of them, though she squinted into the dim winter sunlight and studied their faces carefully. The majority were young, her age, and there were more men than women.

She was on the verge of giving up her stakeout when Martin emerged, finally. It had been nearly a year since she had last seen him, and although he looked differentâ€” leaner, with close cropped hair and an ill-fitting jacketâ€” she still recognized him easily. It was something about the way he walked. Even though he adopted the same careful lookout for trouble as every other person in the city, he still moved loosely, his arms dangling and his step light. After the momentary elation of finding her target, Hilde found herself angry at him on Kircheisâ€™s behalf. She tried to shake off the feeling as she crept out of her hiding place and followed Martin. It wouldnâ€™t be useful to yell at him; she needed to make a deal.

He walked quickly, but she kept pace, gaining on him until he realized he had a pursuer, and then he broke into a run, dodging down an alleyway. Hilde barreled after him. Of the two, she was the more athletic, though he was more familiar with this area of the city. She chased him for a minute, until his stamina began to flag. She had cornered him in an alley, him standing far in the back near the dumpsters, unable to find a way out, and she silhouetted in the entrance. Martin turned towards her and reached inside his jacket for his gun.

Hilde held up her hands, even as he pointed the weapon (Kircheisâ€™s gun, she remembered) at her.Â 

â€œBeen a while, Martin,â€ she said. â€œPut the gun down.â€

â€œHilde?â€ he asked. He didnâ€™t lower his weapon.

â€œWho else would it be?â€

â€œI thought you were in the countryside.â€

â€œWhy would you think that?â€

â€œThe Mariendorf estate is empty.â€

â€œIâ€™m staying with Sieg.â€

â€œSince when?â€

â€œDo you go by his apartment to check whoâ€™s there often?â€ she asked. â€œYou know he still keeps his spare key in the mailbox for you.â€

Martinâ€™s mouth opened silently, but he shut it quickly, getting control of the momentary emotion that had crossed his face. Still, it was enough for Hilde to take pity on him.

â€œIâ€™ve been there since last week,â€ she said. â€œWeâ€™reâ€”â€

â€œPlanning to take the crown?â€ he asked. The sneer in his voice frustrated her once again.

â€œBraunschweig doesnâ€™t have enough people on the planet for that,â€ she said.Â 

â€œWhat are you doing here?â€

â€œYou know youâ€™re being watched, right?â€

â€œWeâ€™ll be out of this place in a day or two.â€

Hilde shook her head. â€œWonâ€™t help. What you did at the city limits the other day has gotten you much more attention.â€

Martin stiffened. â€œI donâ€™t care.â€

â€œYouâ€™ll care whenâ€”â€

â€œI donâ€™t want to talk about this,â€ he said. â€œYou shouldnâ€™t have come here.â€ He stuffed the gun back into his pocket, and tried to shoulder his way out of the alley past her. Hilde grabbed his arm, and he tried to slip out of his jacket to get away. But she wouldnâ€™t let him go, despite his efforts. She grabbed both of his arms behind his back and hauled him into the alley.

â€œWeâ€™re going to talk,â€ she said. â€œSince Sieg canâ€™t, itâ€™s my job to.â€

â€œLet me go.â€ He tried again to pull himself out of her grip, but she didnâ€™t let him go.

â€œArenâ€™t we friends?â€ Hilde asked.

â€œLet me go,â€ he said again.Â 

â€œI just want to talk.â€

â€œLet me go.â€

â€œFine. Donâ€™t run.â€ She released him, and he turned around to scowl at her, but didnâ€™t try to get past her, perhaps because he knew how futile it was. Up close, she could see how much weight he had lostâ€” and he hadnâ€™t had much extra on his frame to lose to begin with. He was quite gaunt. It was no wonder it had been easy for her to outrun and then grab him. There was a granola bar in her pocket, one she had been saving to eat for lunch. She held it out to him as a peace offer. He took it, but didnâ€™t eat it, and instead put it in his own pocket.

â€œEat it,â€ she demanded. â€œIâ€™m giving it to you, not to your commune.â€

â€œI can see this conversation you want isnâ€™t going to go very well,â€ Martin said.

â€œItâ€™s one granola bar. Not exactly easy to share. Come on, Martin.â€

He smiled, but didnâ€™t take the snack out of his pocket. â€œIâ€™ll eat it later.â€

Hilde just shook her head. â€œI should tell Sieg that he should be more worried about you starving yourself to death than getting shot by Littenheimâ€™s MPs.â€

â€œHe shouldnâ€™t worry about me,â€ Martin said.

â€œHe does.â€

Martin scowled and looked away. â€œItâ€™s a waste of his energy.â€

â€œI will do you the favor of not telling him that you said that,â€ she said.

He was silent for a moment. â€œWhat do you want?â€

â€œI need to tell you something.â€

â€œIâ€™m not sure I want to hear it.â€

â€œItâ€™ll help you.â€

â€œI doubt it.â€

Hilde stared at him. â€œYouâ€™re planning to do something spectacular soon, arenâ€™t you?â€

â€œIâ€™m not going to answer that question.â€

â€œAlright. I donâ€™t care if you do or not. I know itâ€™s true.â€ She fished in her bag for her sheaf of papers, and pulled out the top sheet that showed the satellite view of the airfield where Littenheimâ€™s ships were parked. She held it out to Martin, who took it warily. â€œBraunschweig needs to get rid of Littenheimâ€™s ships,â€ she said. â€œSieg and I are responsible for figuring out how to do that.â€

â€œWhy does that matter to me?â€

â€œMarch fifteenth,â€ she said, picking a date that she thought could work. â€œEight at night. If that changes, Iâ€™ll let you know.â€

Martin looked her in the eyes. â€œWhy are you telling me this?â€

It was easy to lie about that, because the lie was true. â€œBecause I donâ€™t want you to die,â€ she said. â€œWhatever youâ€™re planning, do it then. The MPs will be distracted. It gives youâ€¦ a better chance.â€

â€œAnd you.â€ He could have said that with venom, but he didnâ€™t. She was grateful.

â€œYes,â€ she said. â€œI wonâ€™t pretend it doesnâ€™t. But you need the luck more than we do.â€

â€œDoes Sieg know youâ€™re here telling me this?â€

â€œNo,â€ she said. â€œHeâ€™s probably wondering where I am.â€

â€œWill you tell him that youâ€™ve made this offer to me?â€

Hilde hesitated. â€œShould I?â€

Martin didnâ€™t seem able to answer, so Hilde just held out her hand to him. He took it. Despite the boniness of his hand, he was feverishly warm.

â€œWe are still friends,â€ she said. â€œDonâ€™t think weâ€™re not.â€

â€œGood luck,â€ he said finally.

She nodded, and let him go.

Chapter End Notes

womp womp womp

well at least now you know how all three of the odin plots are going to tie together lol. i hope it all dovetails nicely ğŸ˜…ğŸ˜…

the title of this chapter is from les miserables, but also picked because of siegfried idyll :p

i like to think that hilde being a bit of an established go-getter could become a tragic flaw in a universe where nobody is capable of keeping their hands clean, as opposed to logh where most characters' hands are scrupulously shiny by narrative design

this will prooooooobably be the last chapter for a hot second. i have to write my rarepairs exchange fic, and then after that i'm going on vacation to europe for 3 weeks (reminder: if you are in or near glasgow, paris, or lisbon, dm me. i'd love to hang out). and also the next 3 chapters all happen essentially simultaneously, so i miiiiiiiiiight release them all at once so you can pick your reading order. that kinda depends on how able to keep things secret i am though lol

thank you so much as always to em for the beta read!

you can find me in the usual places: javert @ tumblr , natsinator @ twitter , and on discord https://discord.gg/2fu49B28nu . oh also if you're not already on my discord, i'm starting an epic group rewatch of logh for the ages. come join us! it's gonna be great! we're going to have the most unhinged watch order in the history of ever lol

No Children

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

February 489 I.C., Odin

Magdalena and Eva went on long walks through the woods to firm up their plans, far from any listening ears. The snow had fallen from the tree branches, but the ill-kept paths through the woods, little more than deer trails, were still covered in a muddy slush. Magdalena stomped through it, heedless of the dampness getting into her fur-lined boots. Eva was a little more delicate.

â€œWeâ€™ll have to ask the Earth Church for help,â€ Magdalena said, sounding quite annoyed by it, though she announced it with her usual practicality. â€œYou and I canâ€™t really do anything by ourselves.â€

â€œI thought that you said they had already surrounded Erwin Josef in Neue Sanssouci,â€ Eva said. â€œWhy havenâ€™t they done anything yet?â€

â€œOhâ€” Iâ€™m sure Lichtenlade knew that none of the palace staff could be trusted. That place was always a den of servants being paid off by someone or other. He took Erwin Josef with his own staff, to his own estate. And he must have been pretty smart about it, too. The Earth Church probably doesnâ€™t know where they are, or they would have done something already. But if we give them their location, they can help us get him out.â€

â€œThatâ€™s good.â€

â€œItâ€™s not,â€ Magdalena said. â€œI donâ€™t trust them.â€

â€œThe only thing I know about them is from Heinrich,â€ Eva said. â€œThey seem alright to me.â€

â€œThey made Ingrid into their tool. I donâ€™t trust them not to do the same to Erwin.â€

â€œIs there any way to stop that from happening?â€

â€œI donâ€™t want him to just disappear into the abyss.â€ She bit her lip. â€œWe canâ€™t just give them any information about how to rescue himâ€” you have to make yourself essential to them, so they canâ€™t operate without you. When you go into the house to get him, you have to be the only one who knows where it would be. And youâ€™ll have to keep watch over him when you go. You canâ€™t let him out of your sight.â€

Eva nodded. The full scope of what she had agreed to do was beginning to form in her mind: the blank check she had given Magdalena would be cashed to its fullest extent. The idea didnâ€™t trouble her as much as it should have. There was a strange comfort in being asked to find the limits of her own abilities. She imagined this was the feeling that Wolf had, when he went into battle.

She was quiet for a second as she thought about it. Finally, she asked,Â  â€œYou wonâ€™t come with me?â€

Magdalena looked distraught. â€œI canâ€™t.â€

â€œWhy not?â€ Her voice was strangely calm, even though she shivered.

â€œNobody can know that this is what weâ€™re doing,â€ Magdalena said. â€œAnd youâ€™re the only one who has an excuse to leave.â€

â€œI have an excuse to leave?â€ It took a moment for what Magdalena was saying to truly sink in, so she repeated the words wonderingly, like a parrot, as their meaning took form.

Magdalena stopped and looked at her. The noonday sun was weak through the branches of the pines, and Eva pulled her coat even more tightly around herself. â€œYou do.â€

â€œMaggieâ€”â€

Magdalena hastily turned away. â€œI canâ€™t tell it to you.â€

â€œYou know?â€

â€œOf course I know,â€ Magdalena said bitterly. â€œEverybody knows. Everybody knows except you.â€

â€œOh.â€ On some level, she had understood this, but it was difficult to hear it said.

â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

â€œHow long have you known?â€

â€œForever,â€ Magdalena said. â€œSince before I met you.â€

â€œThat longâ€¦â€ It was very strange to get confirmation that the secret of Wolfâ€™s somehow predated her marriage. How something that old could give her an excuse to leave him, she didnâ€™t understand. But it must be terrible, if he hadnâ€™t told her yet.

They walked in silence for a few minutes. â€œWhy canâ€™t you tell me?â€

â€œDo you want to know?â€

Eva looked at Magdalena, who was biting her lip, scraping off the waxy red chapstick she was wearing with her teeth, leaving a pink sliver of bare flesh where her teeth drew across. Did she want to know? It was impossible to say. She might be able to demand that Magdalena tell her right now, but she hesitated.

â€œI donâ€™t know.â€

â€œI canâ€™t tell you, because you have to make Elfriede tell you,â€ Magdalena said after a moment.Â 

â€œShe knows too?â€ The words felt flat as they came out of her mouth.

â€œOskar knowsâ€” she probably knows too, or at least she knows enough to find something horrible to say to you. Sheâ€™s that kind of person.â€

â€œHe can keep a secret, canâ€™t he?â€Â 

â€œNot this kind. Not from her.â€

â€œWhat does that mean?â€ She felt like a child.

â€œPlease donâ€™t make me tell you,â€ Magdalena said. â€œElfriede has to tell you.â€

â€œWhy her?â€

â€œYou have to be surprised by itâ€” you have to make her believe this is the reason youâ€™re leaving. Thereâ€™s no reason for her to lie about that to anyone who asks. She has to be the one. And if we can do it in front of witnesses, even better.â€ She tried to inject some humor into her voice, but it didnâ€™t work. â€œYouâ€™re not a good enough actor to fake surprise, darling.â€

â€œOh.â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ Magdalena said, and then again, much more sincere, â€œIâ€™m so sorry.â€

â€œWhat are you apologizing for? Itâ€™s not your fault.â€ Even though this was true, and she was saying it to comfort Maggie, the words came out dull.Â 

â€œAnd if it was?â€

â€œMaggieâ€”â€

â€œPlease donâ€™t hate me too much.â€

â€œYouâ€™re scaring me.â€

Magdalena just shook her head and was silent again.Â 

â€œHow do I get Elfriede to tell me?â€ Eva asked. She shoved what it was out of her mind, focused on the essentials. After all, it wasnâ€™t as if anything had changed.

â€œYou have to say something about her,â€ Magdalena said. â€œA secret she doesnâ€™t want you to know. A fair trade.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know anything about her,â€ Eva said.Â 

â€œBut I do. I used to love her, you know.â€

Eva looked over at Magdalena, who was staring up into the grey-cloud sky above. â€œNo,â€ she said, and another strange shiver passed through her. â€œNo, I didnâ€™t know that.â€

Â 

Â 

Eva argued back and forth with Magdalena about Heinrichâ€™s trustworthiness. Eva won the argument. She was surprised at how easily Magdalena capitulated. She was startled by this power she seemed to now possess: once she decided to do something, doing things became the easiest thing in the world.Â 

And so she found herself in Heinrichâ€™s room, a letter tucked into her dress pocket for him to give to his priest. He was asleep when she entered, but she sat down by the side of his bed anyway and just watched the rise and fall of his chest. He was very peaceful when he was asleep, and she didnâ€™t want to wake him. There wasnâ€™t any rush.

Perhaps it was the sound of her breathing and movement that woke him, but he woke after a few minutes, blinking and squinting into the light, his face contorting in a grimace with the pain that haunted him when he was awake. Eva poured him some water from the pitcher on the bedside table and held it out for him to take and drink before she spoke. His arms shook, and he spilled some on himself, but he drank nevertheless.

â€œGood morning, Heinrich,â€ she said.

â€œWere you waiting for me to wake up for long?â€ he asked.

â€œNot long. How are you feeling?â€

He smiled and did not answer the question.Â 

Although Eva had spent quite some time thinking about how she would broach the question, now that she was sitting at his bedside, it was tremendously difficult for her to bring it up. â€œIs something wrong, Eva?â€ Heinrich asked.

â€œNo,â€ Eva said. Then, â€œYes.â€

â€œWhat is it?â€Â 

â€œHas anyone told you what my husbandâ€™s secret is?â€

â€œYou havenâ€™t mentioned it.â€

â€œSo you donâ€™t know.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know very much at all.â€ His face twisted. â€œNothing much beyond the corners of this room.â€

â€œI wondered if Maggie might have told you.â€

â€œYou forget that youâ€™re the only one who pays me any mind,â€ Heinrich said. â€œMay I ask what the secret is?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know it.â€

â€œI see.â€ When she said nothing, he continued. â€œWhatâ€™s making you think about it now?â€

â€œCan you keep a secret, Heinrich?â€ She looked over at him, and their eyes met.

â€œTo the grave,â€ he said. The tone in his voice indicated that he didnâ€™t think that would be very far. But he was earnest.

â€œDonâ€™t say that.â€

â€œAlright.â€

She closed the book, but didnâ€™t put it down, and went back to sit next to his bedside. He smiled up at her, his thin and chapped lips pulled up over his teeth. She took his hand in hers. â€œIâ€™m going to do something terrible, I think,â€ she said.

â€œTerrible for whom?â€

â€œYou,â€ Eva said. â€œSo Iâ€™m very sorry about that.â€

â€œMe?â€ Heinrich asked. â€œI didnâ€™t realize you were planning to kill me for my inheritance. It seems like itâ€™s a very hasty thing to do. My will is in the vault in the basementâ€” youâ€™ll have to edit it first.â€

She was too sad to either scold him for the joke or play along. Instead she just pressed his hand to her cheek. â€œIâ€™m leaving, Heinrich.â€

â€œToday?â€

â€œNoâ€” I donâ€™t know when. Soon, though.â€

â€œBefore your husband gets back?â€ he asked. He pulled his hand away from her face, his waxy fingers slipping out of hers to land on the bed with a feather-light thump. She suddenly understood that the tone in his voice, soft but undeniable, was jealousy. He was looking away, out the window. Something about that realization made her stomach turn, though she couldnâ€™t place the sick feeling: pity or anger, maybe. â€œYes,â€ she said. â€œBefore then.â€

â€œCan I ask where youâ€™re going?â€

She almost changed her mind, almost told him the lie that would be delivered to Elfriede and everyone else. But that would have been cruel for no reason. â€œNot even Phezzan?â€

â€œIâ€™m not running away from my husband.â€

â€œThen why did you mention him?â€

â€œIâ€™m going to tell everyone thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m doing, but Iâ€™m not,â€ she said. She paused, suddenly not sure how to explain. Heinrich gave her time to compose herself. â€œIt feels so strange to say out loudâ€” youâ€™ll think Iâ€™m crazy.â€

â€œI wonâ€™t.â€ His simple earnesty reassured her.

â€œErwin Josef,â€ she said finally. â€œHis mother was Maggieâ€™s friend. And if no one gets him away from Odin, heâ€™s going to die. Maggieâ€” I canâ€™t let that happen.â€

â€œSo you and Countess Leigh are going to do something?â€

â€œNo,â€ she said. â€œJust me.â€

â€œAh.â€ He was still looking out the window. â€œThank you for telling me.â€ The jealousy in his voice was even stronger now, but the source of this was easily understood, and perhaps just as easily ameliorated.

â€œMy help?â€ There was hope in his voice, but by the end of his next sentence he crushed it. â€œIf itâ€™s money you need, you can have it. Or secretsâ€¦ I can keep a secret.â€

â€œNo, no.â€

â€œWhat, then?â€ He rolled his head to face her at last, and she pulled her letter from the pocket of her dress. When she held it out to him, her hand trembled.

â€œOf course. I will. Iâ€™ll make sure the right person gets it.â€

â€œThank you.â€ The relief in her voice was powerful, and it made Heinrich smile.

â€œNo,â€ she said. â€œThat would be worse.â€

â€œAre you going to come back?â€

â€œItâ€™s a long way to the other side of the galaxy.â€

â€œDonâ€™t go alone,â€ Heinrich said after some time.

â€œIâ€™ll have whoever the Earth Church sends with me.â€

â€œEven thenâ€” donâ€™t go alone. I donâ€™t want you to get hurt.â€

â€œI donâ€™t have anyone else to bring with me. Maggie canâ€™t come, and I donâ€™tâ€¦ thereâ€™s no one else.â€Â

â€œA man and a woman with a child looks safer, less easy to take advantage of, than a woman alone,â€ Heinrich said. â€œIt will help you, especially if youâ€™re in disguise. Consider it, please.â€

Evaâ€™s reluctance came not only from the practical considerations of involving someone else in the plan, but also from the distrust she had at the momentary soaring of her heart at the offer of help. â€œIâ€™ll think about it. Maggie wonâ€™t be happy.â€

Â 

Â 

It was March before Hilde returned, as she promised that she would. The snow had fully vanished after a warm front of a few days, but then the temperature plummeted far below freezing once again, the winter unwilling to relinquish their part of Odin. Without the glittering white blanket on the landscape, the whole world was the grey of bare tree branches and frozen mud. When Hilde arrived in time for dinner, the warm headlights of her car were the only things that pierced the gloom, and the bulky red sweater she wore as she emerged from the vehicle was the only color around. There wasnâ€™t even the bright hair of Herr Kircheis: Hilde had come alone. Eva waved to Hilde out the window as she walked up to the house, and then sat back down and waited.

The three women and Heinrich were all in their separate corners of the house, and Hilde made her rounds, paying each one a visit individually before dinner. Eva was in the parlor, listening to music and knitting, or at least trying to. Out the window, she had seen the car pull up in the driveway, and a cold fear had settled across her at what it meant. There was no other reason for Hilde to be here other than to warn them that the plans of those in the capital were about to be played out. There was no more time for Eva to think about what she was doing as a hypothetical.Â 

Hilde found Magdalena and Elfriede first, and then stuck her head into the parlor to greet Eva.

Evaâ€™s hands were shaking on her knitting needles, and she wasnâ€™t looking at her project (a shawl). She could feel herself dropping stitches, and if Wolfâ€™s mother had seen her jerky movements and the way her project was unraveling beneath her touch, she would have stopped her and scolded her immediately, and taken the half-made shawl onto her own lap to fix the destroyed row. But Hilde simply sat down in the chair across from Eva with a fixed smile, and her eyes glanced over Evaâ€™s project without comprehending the state that it was in. Hilde didnâ€™t know how to knit. What a blessing.

â€œHello, Eva,â€ Hilde said.

â€œWelcome backâ€” am I the last stop on your tour of the house, since youâ€™re sitting down?â€

â€œHeinrich will have to be,â€ Hilde said. â€œI looked in his room, but he was asleep. Isnâ€™t he usually awake to eat dinner, at least?â€

â€œUsually,â€ Eva said. â€œBut he was having a rough day, so I convinced him to take a painkiller a few hours ago. Heâ€™ll probably wake up later, at least for a little while, so he can eat something.â€

â€œIt smells delicious in here,â€ Hilde said, commenting on the chicken and potatoes that one of the servants was roasting for dinner. â€œI didnâ€™t realize when I left how terrible the food would be in the capital.â€

â€œHave you had enough to eat?â€ Eva asked. It was easy to let genuine worry into her voice. â€œAnd Herr Reuenthal, and Herr Kircheis?â€

â€œOh, yes, of course,â€ Hilde said. â€œWe just canâ€™t cook muchâ€” Sieg only has a one burner hotpot. Itâ€™s all canned beans and things like that, but I havenâ€™t been hungry.â€

â€œThatâ€™s good.â€ Eva smiled. â€œYouâ€™ve been gone for a while. That must be a lot of beans youâ€™ve eaten.â€

â€œI should have counted them one by one,â€ Hilde said. â€œIâ€™d report the number to you, if I knew it.â€

Eva laughed. â€œIâ€™m glad youâ€™ve been well.â€

â€œWell enough.â€ Some of what was clearly false cheer in Hildeâ€™s voice broke.

â€œOhâ€”â€ Hilde looked away. â€œI donâ€™t know.â€

â€œArenâ€™t you staying with him?â€

â€œYes,â€ Hilde said. â€œHeâ€™sâ€” itâ€™s fine. We had an argument.â€

â€œDo you want to talk about it?â€

â€œNot really,â€ Hilde said. â€œIâ€™ve apologized to him already.â€

â€œThese things happen to everyone,â€ Eva said. â€œI always felt terrible whenever Wolf and I had some kind of little fight. â€œOh, Iâ€™m fine,â€ she said, but her smile was thin. â€œI just miss Wolf.â€

â€œThey won at Iserlohn, so Iâ€™m sure heâ€™s fine. â€œI assume that means you and Herr Reuenthal will be making your move soon?â€ Eva asked.

â€œThe night of the fifteenth,â€ Hilde said. â€œI did promise to come warn you.â€

â€œThat is soon. I appreciate you keeping your promises.â€ Eva finally put down her knitting, unable to pretend that she was making her shawl rather than making a mess with the silver-flecked yarn. â€œHave your plans changed any?â€

â€œOnly Siegâ€™s,â€ Hilde said. â€œMine and Rear Admiral Reuenthalâ€™s are still the same.â€

â€œWhatâ€™s different about Siegâ€™s plan?â€

â€œHeâ€™ll be in a different part of the capital,â€ Hilde said. â€œIâ€™m in charge of an attack on Littenheimâ€™s ships, parked at the airfield.â€

â€œBy yourself?â€ Eva couldnâ€™t suppress her alarm.

â€œItâ€™s alright,â€ Hilde said. â€œI have a few of Duke Braunschweigâ€™s soldiers to help me on the actual day. And Sieg helped me set everything upâ€” itâ€™s mainly going to be automated.â€

â€œDo you mind if I ask how?â€

â€œOh, sure,â€ Hilde said. She got up from her seat and went to pace in front of the windows, gesturing as she explained her plan. She clearly was imitating the way Hank talked, at least subconsciously. â€œLittenheim has been supplying his men in the city with food and waterâ€” he gets supplies from his allies outside the city, and he trucks them in. The trucks are pretty vulnerable as targets. Thereâ€™s several different groups that have been attacking them to get the food insideâ€”â€

â€œItâ€™s that bad in the city?â€

â€œOh. Yeah,â€ Hilde said. Her concentration broken, her voice sounded strained. â€œItâ€™sâ€¦ pretty bad.â€

â€œSorryâ€” go on?â€

She nodded. â€œUsually, they leave the trucks on the road. Nothing they can do with them, anyway. Sometimes they burn them out, but theyâ€™re useful to us , so when we see that a truck has been raided we make noises like weâ€™re reinforcements coming, and the raiders scatter. â€œWhere are you going?â€ Magdalena asked.

It was theater. They had already planned exactly where Eva would go, a place where they could stage the next phase of their plan. But somehow it felt like an organic choice nowâ€” Eva couldnâ€™t stay here, and she had nowhere else to go. No cozy apartment waiting for her in the city, and she couldnâ€™t go back to Wolfâ€™s parents, a few districts away.Â 

But she didnâ€™t want to talk to Magdalena either. She kept addressing Hilde. â€œCan you take me to Count Landsbergâ€™s house?â€ she asked. â€œI donâ€™t know where else I can go.â€

â€œOn short notice? Nowhere,â€ Magdalena said. â€œYou donâ€™t have to leave, Eva.â€

â€œIâ€™ll take you there,â€ Hilde said. â€œOrâ€” I can find a place for you.â€

â€œYou donâ€™t have to worry about me.â€

â€œI do,â€ Hilde said.

Eva nodded and stood. The little burned out patch in her vision from staring at the candle made it easy to not look at Magdalenaâ€™s face as she walked out, and the darkness of the hallway felt absolute. She stumbled through it by memory alone, trying not to creak the stairs on her way up to Heinrichâ€™s room.

His bedroom was the same refuge it had always been, and she didnâ€™t notice he was awake as she sat down at his bedside. She hadnâ€™t turned on the light, and his eyes were closed.

â€œI heard you come in earlier,â€ he said, startling her.

â€œI was getting a painting for Elfriede,â€ she said. Her voice was raw, and he immediately understood that something was wrong. Blindly, he reached out his skeletal hand towards her. She couldnâ€™t take it, and so he left it laying on the bedspread, just in her reach.

â€œAre you alright?â€

â€œIâ€™m leaving tonight, Heinrich.â€

â€œDid something happen?â€

â€œI donâ€™t think I can talk about it,â€ Eva said. â€œAsk Maggie to tell you, once Iâ€™m gone.â€

He nodded and was silent. She was grateful for that, for everything about his companionship. If there hadnâ€™t been wheels in motion that she was now powerless to stop, she would have stayed in the house with him. His friendship would have been enough to keep her there. But even though the plan to rescue Erwin Josef was only a distant thought, far off and unreal, it was enough to force her to move. But still, she could sit there for a moment longer, dash her silent tears away with the back of her hand. His eyes were still closedâ€” he didnâ€™t see her crying.

She took off her wedding ring. It had been a permanent fixture on her hand for years, and she felt naked and empty without it on.

â€œWill you do me a favor?â€ she asked, though her voice was thick with tears.

â€œYes.â€

She picked up Heinrichâ€™s hand from the bedspread and pressed her wedding ring into his palm. She curled his fingers around it and held his hand between both of hers. â€œIf anything happens to meâ€” tell Wolf I forgive him. Please.â€

â€œIs that true?â€

â€œIt has to be,â€ she whispered. â€œI donâ€™t want to be cruel.â€

â€œI will.â€

â€œThank you.â€ She kept holding his hand in hers. She could hear, down the stairs, Hilde moving around and talking with Magdalena, though their voices were too distant to make out in anything other than indistinct tones. Hilde was angryâ€” short and clipped sentences.

â€œIâ€™m being cruel to you, arenâ€™t I?â€ she asked Heinrich suddenly.Â 

â€œDonâ€™t worry about me.â€ She understood what he meant, and there was no way to argue with him about it. He would do this because he loved herâ€” the kind of love that asked only for the otherâ€™s happiness, or wanted to ask only for that, if that was the only thing that was within reach.

Maybe it was true that she could forgive Wolf. Maybe she already had, at the bottom of her heart, prepared for this moment for as long as she had known there was a moment to prepare for. It was a foregone conclusion that she would forgive him, no matter how painful it might be to go through, and to come out the other side. But if that was true, what would she do with the pain she held? Where would it go?

The idea flitted through her mind, and if it had been any other day, any other hour, she would have rejected it. But she wondered, just for a moment, if balancing the scales of that pain would be enough to relieve herâ€” even if only a fraction.

â€œIs there anything else I can do?â€ Heinrich asked.Â 

She kept one hand on his, pinned to the bedspread, but with her other she reached out to touch his forehead, stroking his hair back from his forehead. Her fingers tangled through the bone white strands for a moment, and he stayed perfectly still, like a corpse.

She leaned forward, hovering her face just over his. She could feel his shallow breath on her skin.

â€œEvaâ€”â€ he said. His eyes were still closed.

â€œWhat?â€

â€œDonâ€™t do something youâ€™ll regret,â€ he said. â€œNot right now.â€

She looked at how thin his skin wasâ€” the way all his veins were visible, even in the dim light of the room, at the cracks in his lips, at the weakness of his arms. There would always be something to regret, she supposed, regardless of what she did or didnâ€™t do. And so she kissed him anyway, briefly, but enough to wet his lips and make his hand curl against hers.

â€œGoodbye, Heinrich,â€ she said. She didnâ€™t say anything about meeting againâ€” she rather doubted that they would.

Chapter End Notes

lol this chapter was originally supposed to be part of the next eva chapter, but then Em told me that it would probably work better on its own, so it has been split.

anyway now we can finally stop having this secret hanging over our heads lol. sorry eva........................

feel free to put another "a ring changes hands" check on your bingo cards if you're keeping track :p this was not the first and it certainly shall not be the last

reuenthal is ofc the presence haunting this conversation-- present in image only. elfriede unintentionally echoes his words when she asks eva if she hates her, and eva unintentionally echoes his actions when she stares into the candle flame to avoid looking at anyone else (see: TWS ch1)

evil women being godawful to each other in the horrid girl house...

i think this chapter was weird to write in some ways b/c a lot of it is about magdalena's traits-- which have thus far been presented as neutral ish-- being now turned around by elfride. kay from my discord probably will appreciate this lol since he is a noted magdalena critic :p

anyway sorry this one took so long... i'm trying to get back into the game lol. also: there's probably a bunch of stuff of mine that you haven't read. check out
