â€œLittenheimâ€™s people?â€ Reuenthal asked.

â€œCanâ€™t tellâ€” theyâ€™re armed, heading in the direction of the staircase. A few have split off, but not many.â€

â€œHow big of a group?â€

â€œForty, fifty, maybe.â€

â€œHave they spotted you?â€

â€œDonâ€™t think so.â€

â€œStay out of sight behind them until theyâ€™re on the stairs, if theyâ€™re all headed that way,â€

Â Reuenthal ordered. â€œWeâ€™ll corner them from above.â€

â€œSirâ€”â€ Bergengrun was clearly about to protest and tell Reuenthal that he didnâ€™t have enough people.

â€œBe prepared to get Lichtenlade and the boy if you see them,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œTheyâ€™ll probably end up in the tunnels, too, and whoever else is there is going to want them alive.â€

â€œYes, sir,â€ Bergengrun said.

Bergengrun would have been right to protest that Reuenthal and his fourteen men couldnâ€™t face a group of sixty, even if they met them at the top of the staircase. There were certain differentials in manpower that even the best terrain couldnâ€™t overcome. But if he could cause enough chaos up above that Bergengrunâ€™s larger group could make headway against them, that would be enough. Reuenthal could pick off the survivors from the outside.

He signaled to one of his men, the one carrying the zephyr particle cannisters. He doubted that they would be useful in combat, but he had brought them along as an option, and he was now glad he had. The man crouched down next to him in the underbrush, and Reuenthal pointed at the chimney of the Lichtenlade house, and the smoke blowing downwind.

â€œIs that hot enough to ignite zephyr gas?â€ Reuenthal asked.

â€œYes, sir,â€ the man said. â€œLooks like a wood fireâ€” thereâ€™s enough sparks that make it to the top to do it.â€

â€œCan you throw that far?â€

The man judged the distance to the roof. â€œNot without being seen,â€ he said.Â 

Reuenthal nodded and looked around, searching for another solution. â€œHow wide of a field can one of those cover?â€

â€œEffective range is twenty meters, sir, but itâ€™s only rated for indoor use.â€

He pointed towards a tree, thick pine branches shielding several of his men from sight of the house. â€œIf you were to climb to the same level as the chimney, and let the wind move the gas, would it ignite when it reaches the heat?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know, sir.â€

â€œTry it,â€ Reuenthal ordered. â€œUse multiple canisters.â€

The soldier nodded and hastened away, climbing the pine tree as stealthily as he could. The branches covered most of the view of the house, even up high.Â 

Reuenthal bit his tongueâ€” trying to stop himself from being annoyed at not being the one to light the fire himself. He wanted to wield a match. Instead, it was this inhuman and distant maneuver, invisible air carrying cold fire.Â 

He couldnâ€™t see if the zephyr gas had made it to the house, even when he heard the click and hiss of the canisters opening. He trained his binoculars on the chimney top, looking for the flash of ignition.

There wasnâ€™t any of the usual explosion of zephyr fire. The gas caught in tiny sparks, popping flashes near the chimney. They formed small expanding bubbles, reaching out from the first point of contact with the heat source and catching whatever sparse gasses had been carried in by the wind. They drifted for a moment and then faded away. But then, in a lull in the wind, when the next canister hissed open, they caught in longer and longer streams, ribbons or tongues of flame licking the roof. Usually, zephyr fire dispersed immediately, as the highly volatile fuel source was consumed, but with the gas so spread out, it lasted long enough to be seen.Â 

The red wooden slat tiles of the roof were flammable, though even with the intense heat that the zephyr particles generated, it took time and a third canister of gas for them to catch. Reuenthal, looking through his binoculars, saw it begin at the edges of the uppermost tiles, the fire traveling along their edges in a bright line, crawling faster when the wind pushed the sparks along.

It would take some time before the fire reached the houseâ€™s interior, needing to travel downwards into the building itself. It was painfully slow, the process of the roof catching.

While Reuenthal watched it through his binoculars, he pulled another one of his men over to him, von Viers. He too was one of the trusted ones who had come with him from his office in the Ministry of War, not one of Braunschweigâ€™s crew.Â 

â€œWe might have trouble getting out on foot,â€ Reuenthal said to him, voice low and not looking at him, just watching the fire. â€œEspecially if weâ€™re carrying prisoners.â€

â€œYes, sir,â€ Viers said.

â€œTake a team and go down to the shed where Lichtenlade keeps his motorbikesâ€” get as many as you can back up here.â€

â€œItâ€™ll be loud, sir.â€

â€œWe wonâ€™t have to worry about that in a minute,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œBut we need a way to get Lichtenlade out of here quickly, once we have him.â€

â€œYes, sir.â€ Viers summoned a handful of men and they disappeared into the undergrowth, heading down the road to the west. Reuenthalâ€™s team was very small now, but he didnâ€™t think that was a problem.

The fire had grown large enough to cover most of the roof, though when he peered through the windows of the house, no one seemed to have noticed it yet. The upper section of the building must have been an empty atticâ€” if the top floor was occupied, they would have heard it eating the wood by now.

One of the servants emerged from the house, a basket of wet laundry on her hip that she was planning to hang outside, and she stopped and sniffed the air. When she smelled the smoke, she turned around in confusion, and then caught sight of the roof ablaze. She started to yellâ€” too far away from where Reuenthal was for him to make out anything other than the sound and the flapping of her fleshy lips in the view of his binoculars. Several other servants emerged from the house at the sound, leaving the doors open as they did.

The topmost part of the roof began to sag, the timbers eaten away by fire, and a hole opened, blazing tiles falling through into the third floor, air rushing up and out, feeding the fire as it now spread indoors. An alarm began to wail, but now members of the Lichtenlade house were emerging in greater numbers: servants in plain clothes and well dressed women of the clan, wearing some echo of Elfriedeâ€™s face.

Reuenthal held his hand up to hold off his men from attacking as he scanned the gathering crowd. He was surprised that anyone at all had emerged from the house: if the family had tunnels dug underneath the building specifically for the purpose of escaping from danger, any emergency plan should involve heading there. But, of course, it was only the women who were coming outâ€” probably afraid of remaining in any structure on fire, even if the tunnels wouldnâ€™t be touched by it. Reuenthal swept his binoculars from door to door of the house, looking for Lichtenlade, but he didnâ€™t see him.

A servant holding the hand of a seven year-old boy emerged from the house. Before Reuenthal could even give the command, one of Braunschweigâ€™s men hidden in the bushes took a shot. If he was aiming at the servant woman with the boy, he missed, and instead struck the Lichtenlade family member behind her, who had been looking up at the fire with her hand held over her mouth in horror. Now, she staggered sideways, her hands clutching her throat, and fell to the ground.

There was a moment of total confusion from the Lichtenlade camp, and from Reuenthalâ€™s group. No one except the man who had fired the shot was clear about what had happened. But then the servant with the boy dragged him back into the burning house, his screams audible even from where Reuenthal was hiding. The rest of the Lichtenlades began to run, some heading back towards the house, others heading towards the trees.

Their cover now lost, Reuenthal ordered his men forwards, except for the few who would take up positions to guard the exits. Several of them took shots at the fleeing women, but Reuenthal headed for the open back door of the house with a single-minded determination, crossing the field where several womenâ€™s bodies now lay.

Reuenthal had entered through the kitchen, all tiled and not yet on fire, though the regular house fire was still roaring there in the hearth. There was no one in the kitchen, so he pushed through into the remainder of the building, several of his men now behind him. He signaled for them to split off and search the rest of the house. Flashes of blonde hair disappeared around corners, running from him, like a nightmare he had once had. His hands felt sluggish as he raised his rifle.

He kept running, looking for Lichtenlade. Despite the danger, he checked upstairs first, climbing the grand staircase and then moving through the upper hallways, shoving open bedroom doors as he went. All he found were empty rooms, while the roaring of the fire overhead grew louder. The heat from it was pressing down on this floor, and when he looked up, he could see it through the wooden beams girding the ceiling, seeping through the cracks in the third floor down to the second. As he heard timbers begin to give elsewhere, Reuenthal hastily headed back down to the ground floor. The fire grew hungrier the more it ate.

Even at the bottom of the house, smoke was beginning to fill the air, making it harder to see as he ran. The Lichtenlades had left many of the doors to the house open, and that only fed the fire more oxygen, at least around the outer walls of the house. It was being eaten away from the outside in.Â 

In the front hallway, the one that overlooked the cliff face, the entrance to the underground passageways was open. The elevator door was open, too, but the elevator itself had moved downwards about a meter and then stopped, some internal mechanism failed or disabled. The elevator was emptyâ€” those who had been trying to use it had pried the doors open and climbed back out to take the stairs.Â 

The stairs were pitch black; whoever had disabled the elevator must have also disabled the lights. From within, he heard agonized screaming, the sounds of a fight, and then people turning tail and running back up towards him. The family was encountering the other intruders, those who were also now trapped by the fire on one side, and Bergengrun and the rest of the team on the other. If the Lichtenlade family wanted to escape, they might decide to take their chances in the burning house, rather than the stairwell. Reuenthal dropped into the elevator and crouched down, hiding himself from sight, and watched people emerge from the staircase.

The first out was a servant, who stumbled through the house, heading for the front door. Reuenthal let her go. Next up was a young manâ€” fifteen, maybeâ€” with curly blond hair and a terrified expression. He took stock of the fire, now creeping down the walls of the hallway, and ran past Reuenthal without seeing him. Instead of heading for the door of the house, he picked up a decorative marble clock from the hall table and threw it at the big windows that overlooked the cliff face. The windows shattered, and he climbed out that way, cutting his hands on the broken glass. As he held on to the outside of the mangled window, he saw Reuenthal: their eyes met, his widening in shock and fear, and then he dropped down heavily to the ground outside, sliding down the near-sheer rock face. Reuenthal didnâ€™t know what became of him after that.

Several more members of the Lichtenlade clan pulled themselves out of the stairwell, and Reuenthal let them run off through the burning house without pursuing them. The fire was growing worse around him, the smoke thick and choking, making timbers groan.

Lichtenlade emerged from the stairwell. He was covered in blood, a wound on his arm bleeding profusely, and he stumbled forward, assisted by one of the young men of the household, this one brandishing a gun. Neither of them saw Reuenthal, and they began pushing their way through the house. Reuenthal let them get to the end of the hallway, so that Lichtenlade wouldnâ€™t have the ability to turn back into the stairwell, and then raised his rifle and shot the young man in the head. He toppled to the ground and brought Lichtenlade down with him.

The old man tried to right himself, but his wounded arm couldnâ€™t support his weight as he tried to get off the ground. Reuenthal leaped out of the elevator and sprinted down the corridor to get him. Several more people emerged from the stairwellâ€” these ones at a runâ€” and they didnâ€™t look like members of the Lichtenlade household. Reuenthal, guarding the prone Lichtenlade, shot them all.

â€œSir!â€ one of Reuenthalâ€™s men yelled, emerging from the smoke. â€œWe need to move!â€ He saw Lichtenlade on the ground behind Reuenthal and grabbed him, hauling him to his feet. Lichtenlade now seemed barely conscious, and the soldier pulled him in a firemanâ€™s carry over his shoulder, having to drop his gun to do so.

â€œIs there a clear way through?â€

â€œThe front is closest,â€ the soldier yelled over the crackling of the fire.

Reuenthal followed, taking up a position to guard them, and as they ran through the house he shot at anyone who came near, Lichtenlade family and the other intruders alike.

The smoke was very thick near the front door, and the flames were so hot that his skin felt like it was being torn apart. It was impossible to breatheâ€” like drowning. The door itself was open, and the doorframe itself was wreathed in flame.Â 

The soldier carrying Lichtenlade braced himself and ran straight through, and Reuenthal couldnâ€™t see what became of him after he made it out the door. The smoke was too thick and heavy to see more than a few feet ahead. Reuenthal himself was frozen.

There was no other way out except through the burning passage, nothing to do but to cross the threshold out of danger and into the cold air outside. But it was the doorway itself that transfixed him, cast a spell over him, held him from moving. He knew what crossing the doorway would feel like, or he could imagine it like one could imagine the flames of Hell.

Whatever pain happened in the moment would be instantaneous, temporary, but it wasnâ€™t exactly that which made him hesitate. It was the idea that he would remember the moment forever, live out stepping through the doorway over and over in his memory.Â 

His thoughts had only taken a fraction of a second, if that, and they were confused by lack of oxygen, the smoke scorching his lungs the longer he stood in the fire. He raised his arms over his head to shield his face, and he ran through the door.

The fire caught on his shirt, melting the synthetic camouflage jacket against his back, even as he dropped to the dirt outside and rolled to put out the fire. It was an excruciating pain, but it was localized and unlikely to spread. His hands were only scorched, his face and legs were unharmed.

â€œSir!â€ one of his men shouted. â€œOver here!â€

It was Viers, with the motorbikes. The soldier carrying Lichtenlade had already boarded one, the unconscious former prime minister slung across his back like a sack of potatoes. Viers and the other soldiers who had fetched the bikes were guarding them, shooting at anyone who came out of the house.

Reuenthal pulled himself up off the ground. He didnâ€™t try to take off his jacketâ€” if it was melted to his skin as he feared, that would only make the wound worse. He ran for the bikes and took one.Â 

â€œDid anyone get the boy?â€ he asked.

Viers was about to answer, but before he could, there was gunfire from the trees, and he instead yelled, â€œMove, sir!â€Â 

The shots fired at them missed their targetsâ€” the gunman might have been aiming to disable the wheels or engines of the motorbikesâ€” but it was enough to get the soldier holding Lichtenlade to drive off down the dirt road. Viers stayed standing out in the open and shot at the trees, guarding Reuenthalâ€™s retreat.

Reuenthal followed the other soldier, pushing his bike as fast as it would go, even as he was unfamiliar with the way it felt beneath him. It would have been darkly funny if that had been what killed him, but he managed to keep his balance even on the winding dirt trail.Â 

After they had made it a kilometer down the road, it became obvious that there was no real pursuit, and so they turned their bikes and headed for the predetermined meetup point, with their cars and supplies and radios.

Â 

Â 

It took several days for things to calm down enough for Reuenthal to take stock of the situation. The capital city was in complete chaos, and all radio communications out of it were being jammed. Reuenthal couldnâ€™t speak with Oberstein, let alone Mariendorf or Kircheis, to determine their statuses, unless he wanted to have couriers sneak into the city. And he didnâ€™t have any intention of doing that.

He and the remainder of his menâ€” twenty-five of them had made it out of the Lichtenlade house aliveâ€” were in the safehouse they had prepared ahead of time, a summer home owned by some distant relation of the dukeâ€™s that had fallen into complete disrepair. It was little more than a cabin, but it was far from what remained of civilization, and they were unlikely to be detected there.

A doctor from the closest town had been pressganged to treat the wounds of their group. The most serious was Lichtenlade, who had lost a significant amount of blood before anyone had been able to staunch the bleeding from the stab wound on his arm. He might lose the limb, and would probably never regain all function in itâ€” the knife had gone deep through critical muscles. They kept Lichtenlade sedatedâ€” a dose of opioids from their military med kits so strong that the doctor who had treated him cautioned them that any more might stop the manâ€™s breathing entirely. Reuenthal found it hard to care about that.

He had almost refused to let the doctor look at his own woundâ€” the nasty melted burn across his back. When they pulled off the jacket, skin came off with it. It was only the fact that the injury could become infected and kill him, especially without access to much in the way of antibiotics or advanced care, that he let anyone else touch it at all.Â 

He was told it would scar, a permanent swathe of ugliness down his back. That disgusted him far more than the sight or feeling of the wound did. Even if he couldnâ€™t see the wound, not under bandages, not under his shirt, not on his back, he avoided mirrors.

When the fire at the Lichtenlade house had been put out by rain, and there seemed to be no one watching the wreckage of the building, Reuenthal returned to the scene.Â 

The place where the house had stood was as unrecognizable as an alien planet. The fire had spread through the forest, though not too far. The mountain provided too many natural firebreaks for it to travel a great distance, and the whole forest was wet enough with snowmelt that the trees were reluctant to burn. But near the house the destruction was almost total. The skeletons of pines stood like soldiers, and all the undergrowth had burned away, leaving the sight lines clear for an unnatural distance. Only the stone structures of the house remained, empty walls like those of a labyrinth, and they showcased the pits that led down into the tunnels. Wind whistled up from them, bringing a smell of dampness and death. There were charred bodies on the former lawn, but those dead down below had escaped the purification of fire.

There were vultures circling overhead, scared off by the fresh arrival of the living. Several days had done their work on the corpses that lay outside on the scorched remains of the grassâ€” what animals had returned to the mountainside after the fire had already picked them over.

Two questions had brought Reuenthal back to the house: was Erwin Josef alive, and who was responsible for the other group during their attack? It seemed like too strange of a coincidence for it to occur on the same day as his planned invasionâ€” he suspected that there was an information leak somewhere, though he had not mentioned that thought to anyone else.

Of course, there was no reason that Reuenthal should need to visit the burned husk of the house himself. Any number of his men could have done it without him there. But he wanted to see the destruction.

Now that he was there surveying the wreckage, he felt empty and cold. He kicked through the ashes of the house, uncovering still smoldering coals, and thought nothing. There were bodies burned black where people had died in the fire, and he looked for any that might have belonged to a child. Some of the other men had the much more odious task of climbing down into the hole in the ground and picking over the rotting corpses for any kind of identification.Â 

Tucked against one corner of the stone walls, buried under a profusion of charred debris, Reuenthal found two corpses: one large, one smallâ€” a childâ€™s. Whoever this had been must have tried to take refuge against the stone as the fire swept through, but the house had collapsed on top of them, still burning. Touching the bodies with the toe of his shoe made them fall apart into carbonized flesh and bones, and there was no way of identifying who the people had once been. Gender was indistinguishable, and their clothing had been the first things to burn. It might have been the young Erwin Josef and the maid he had been with, but Reuenthal couldnâ€™t tell. Even if he had access to tools to sequence genetics, the body was probably too burned to provide any information.

He looked at the scene for a moment longer, then left it where it lay, going to look down into the empty staircase hole in the ground, carefully avoiding the sheer vertical shaft that had once been the elevator. The scent of rot was almost unbearableâ€” his men had drawn their shirts up over their noses to avoid as much of it as they could, but there was no escaping the putrification. Reuenthal could only see them in the beams of their flashlights as they swept over the bodies on the stairs, looking for clues.

â€œDid you find anything?â€ Reuenthal asked as one of them came up.

The soldier was holding a blood-stained white cloth, pinching it with two fingers and holding it away from himself to avoid touching the dirty parts. â€œLook at this, sir,â€ the man said as he laid the cloth on the ground outside.

It was a shawl of some sort, white woven fabric, but printed on it in unmistakeable letters were the words â€œEARTH IS MY MOTHER. EARTH IN MY HANDS.â€

â€œThe Earth Church?â€ Reuenthal asked.Â 

â€œOr someone pretending to be them,â€ the soldier said. â€œThough I donâ€™t know why anyone would do that. Thereâ€™s a whole bunch of these down there.â€

â€œStrange.â€ Reuenthal looked out across the barren landscape of the burned house. It was oddâ€” he remembered standing with Yang in the snow, watching the Earth Churchâ€™s headquarters in the capital burn down. That had been so many years ago that he had almost forgotten it, relegated Yangâ€™s curiosity about who the arsonist was to the back of his mind. The image stood out starkly in his vision now, the two fires superimposing themselves on his memory.

Â 

Â 

It took a few more days yet for Reuenthal to make his way to the Kummel house. He had been hoping that the situation in the capital would resolve enough for him to get in contact with Oberstein, Mariendorf, or Kircheis, but there seemed to be no sign of the radio jamming ending. The only way they would have to send messages in and out of the city, then, would be leaving them at a cache, and it seemed highly likely that Mariendorf would head to the Kummel house if she had something to report.Â 

There were other things he needed there, as well. If, as Reuenthal suspected, there had been an information leak somewhere to cause the Earth Church to attack the Lichtenlade house, the most likely source of it was Kummel himself, whom Reuenthal had not properly met. He knew that man was a devout member of the church, and it was not impossible that he had managed to gather enough information about Reuenthalâ€™s plan to betray him to the higher ups in the organization. Why the Earth Church was interested in attacking Lichtenlade, Reuenthal didnâ€™t know. He intended to find out.

Additionally, he had a reason to speak to Elfriede, to ask her if she had any young relatives whose body might have been the one he discovered in the wreckage of the house. If she didnâ€™t, Erwin Josef was likely to be dead.

The last reason, of course, was the most unpleasant. Reuenthal had not exactly been avoiding the odious duty of apologizing to Evangeline Mittermeyer, but he had done his best to put it out of his mind. Thinking about it now, he arrived at the Kummel estate in a foul mood.

It was a warming March day, late in the month, and the sun shone brightly through the trees. A few flowers had poked their heads up in the lawn outside the decrepit looking house, and only Magdalenaâ€™s car was in the driveway. Reuenthal had come alone to the house, and he knocked on the door. No one answered, so he knocked again, harder this time, making the door rattle.

Magdalenaâ€” the only one of the women Reuenthal had no business withâ€” came to the door. When she saw him, she paled like she was looking at a ghost.Â 

â€œOskar!â€

â€œCountess von Leigh. I need to speak to Elfriede,â€ he said, trying to step past her into the house.Â 

She didnâ€™t move, blocking the door, though it seemed to be more because she stood there in shock than any actual effort to block his path.

â€œI thought you were dead,â€ she finally said. She started to reach for his arm, as if to confirm that he stood there in the flesh before her, but she dropped her reaching hand when she processed the cold look on his face. Something about her, too, had changedâ€” the Magdalena of a few months ago would not have hesitated.

â€œOh? Why would you think that?â€

â€œItâ€™s been daysâ€” I thoughtâ€”â€ She finally moved out of the way, and he stepped into the hallway. â€œYou should have sent a message.â€Â 

â€œI have had more important things to worry about than reporting back to you,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œHilde didnâ€™t. She was here. She mentioned that she spoke to you earlierâ€” she was surprised you hadnâ€™t come by yet. That was what made me thinkâ€”â€

â€œHow long ago was she here?â€

â€œThree days ago.â€

â€œDid she leave a message?â€

â€œYes, a letter. Iâ€™ll get it for you.â€

â€œDid she tell you whatâ€™s happening in the capital? I havenâ€™t been able to contact anyone there.â€

Magdalenaâ€™s face fell further. â€œYou should read Hildeâ€™s letter. I assume sheâ€™ll tell you about it better than I can.â€

â€œFine. I need to speak with Elfriede, Baron Kummel, andâ€”â€

â€œHeinrich? What do you want with him?â€ The strange edge in her voice made Reuenthal look at her face, and she looked away. â€œHeâ€™s probably asleep right now, anyway,â€ she said.

â€œThen Iâ€™ll speak to him last. You can wake him up for me.â€

â€œPlease donâ€™t make meâ€” heâ€™s been so depressed since Eva left. They were very close.â€

â€œAnd youâ€™ll have to give me directions to the Landsberg house. Mariendorf told me she was staying there,â€ Reuenthal said, trying to sound bored. â€œI need to speak with her, as well.â€

There was a moment of strained silence. â€œSheâ€™s not there, Oskar.â€

â€œOh? And where is she?â€

Magdalena stared into his eyes. â€œWhere does any married woman go who doesnâ€™t want to be married anymore?â€

The worst thing about this feeling of victory was the knowledge that Mittermeyer would never forgive him. He felt sick. â€œItâ€™s very stupid to try to go to Phezzan at a time like this,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œI canâ€™t blame her,â€ Magdalena said.

Reuenthal scoffedâ€” Magdalena was as much to blame as anyone else. â€œWhere is Elfriede?â€ he asked again.

â€œAnd what do you want with her?â€

â€œIâ€™m right here,â€ Elfriede said, coming down the grand staircase into the entry hall. â€œI was told to assume that you died.â€

Magdalena made a face at Elfriedeâ€™s appearance and went upstairs herself, pushing past her on the stairway.

â€œYou must think very little of me to assume that,â€ Reuenthal said as she came towards him.

â€œI didnâ€™t say that I believed it.â€ She cocked her head at him. â€œHow is my grand-uncle?â€

â€œAlive,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œIn my custody.â€

â€œShall we sit down?â€ she asked.

â€œIâ€™m not planning to stay for long.â€

â€œPity.â€ She directed him towards the parlor and closed the door firmly behind them. When she tried to touch him, Reuenthal stepped away, hands behind his back (the motion pained his bandaged wound) and went to look out the window. Elfriede sat down on the couch.

â€œSit,â€ she said.

â€œNo. This isnâ€™t a social visit.â€

â€œThen what are you here for?â€

â€œDo you have any young cousins who might have been at that house?â€

â€œWhy do you ask?â€

â€œI found a corpse that I couldnâ€™t identify,â€ he said. â€œI would like to know whose it is.â€

â€œYou didnâ€™t get Erwin Josef when you got my grand-uncle, then?â€ she asked.

â€œHeâ€™s either dead or missing. I found a childâ€™s bodyâ€” I hope itâ€™s his. It will be quite annoying if heâ€™s still alive somewhere.â€

â€œYou think someone killed another child, took his head off, to make you think Erwin Josef was dead?â€

â€œYour uncle would do something like that?â€ Reuenthal asked. â€œIt would be a poor strategy.â€

â€œIf thatâ€™s not what happened, what makes you unable to identify the corpse?â€

â€œI burned the house down,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œThe body was beyond recognition.â€

She was silent for a moment. â€œThat wasnâ€™t the plan you described to me,â€ she said, getting up off the couch. She came up behind him. â€œDid you let your fantasies get the better of you?â€

When she tried to touch his back, Reuenthal turned around and slapped her hand away, snarling. She stepped back, real fear on her face.

â€œWhatâ€™s the matter with you?â€ she asked.

â€œWe werenâ€™t the only ones attacking the house that day,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œIt went badly.â€

â€œAre you accusing me of something?â€

Reuenthal turned away again. â€œNo, though I should.â€

She had learned her lesson, and didnâ€™t reach out to touch him. Her voice was cold, when she asked, â€œSo, who else was there?â€

â€œThe Earth Church,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œI wonder if your generous host didnâ€™t happen to overhear plans and betray us.â€

Elfried made a dismissive noise. â€œHeinrich is barely capable of staying awake fifteen minutes at a time. I doubt it. What use would he have with my uncle, anyway?â€

â€œThereâ€™s plenty of use for a boy-king,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œIs he dead, or is he alive?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know,â€ Elfriede said. She stepped away from him. â€œI havenâ€™t spoken to my family in a yearâ€” I have no idea who my uncle invited to stay with him.â€

â€œCould there have been another child in the house?â€

â€œAsk my uncle, if heâ€™s as alive as you say he is.â€

â€œWe keep him sedated,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œAny risk of him escaping is too high. And I think itâ€™s useful to not let him know that we do not have the boy.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know, Oskar,â€ she said. â€œThere. Does that answer your question?â€

â€œNo, it doesnâ€™t.â€

It was an awkward conversation, with their backs to one another, and they stood there silently. Reuenthal should have let her touch him, but the idea of her picking at the wound on his back filled him with an unbearable disgust. He tried to make himself want it, but failed, for the first time.

â€œYou should either thank me, or punish me,â€ Elfriede said in the silence. â€œPick one. I know thatâ€™s really what you came here for. Iâ€™m tired of this game.â€

â€œFor telling Evangeline my secrets?â€ Reuenthal asked. He stared out the window, pretending to be disaffected. â€œI donâ€™t care.â€

â€œLiar.â€

â€œDid you do it to upset me, or please me?â€ Reuenthal asked.

â€œIt had nothing to do with you.â€

â€œLiar.â€

â€œWeâ€™re well matched, then.â€

Reuenthal turned towards her. â€œIâ€™ve taken care of your family problem,â€ he said. â€œYou can be free of me now. Walk away. No need for me to keep you out of their hands. Iâ€™ll even make sure Leigh arranges things with the Kaiserine so that you have all their fortunes. The last survivor of the Lichtenlade family.â€

â€œHow generous of you.â€

â€œWhat are you trying to get out of me?â€ he asked.

â€œNothing.â€

â€œTell me what you want.â€

â€œI said nothing, Oskar.â€

â€œWere you planning to stay living in my house after this?â€

â€œItâ€™s funny that you think you have a house to go back to. Someone might have burned it down. Too bad you didnâ€™t do it yourself, before the opportunity was taken away from you. Or maybe you didnâ€™t do it because you werenâ€™t strong enough to.â€

He stepped towards her, and she turned around to face him at last. Her expression was strange and wild.

â€œI didnâ€™t need to do that,â€ he said. â€œAnd I didnâ€™t need anybody else to free me.â€

â€œAnd you think youâ€™re free?â€ She stepped up to him, chest to chest, though they didnâ€™t quite touch each other. His hands remained behind his back. He watched the way her throat moved when she swallowed.

â€œYou think youâ€™re the chain on me, Elfriede?â€ he asked.

She made a derisive noise but didnâ€™t say anything.

â€œAre you unhappy that I took your revenge for you?â€ he asked. â€œWould you have wanted to do it yourself?â€

She didnâ€™t answer that question either.

â€œDo you still want it?â€ he asked. â€œOr will you have me do it for you?â€

â€œWhat are you talking about?â€

â€œYouâ€™re not the last of the Lichtenlade clan yet,â€ Reuenthal said. â€œYour grand uncle is still alive.â€ He put a disaffected tone in his voice and looked over her heard. â€œAs I said, he wonâ€™t live too much longer. Someone will kill him when he outlives his usefulnessâ€” it could be you, if youâ€™re strong enough for it.â€

Elfriede slapped him across the face, hard enough to leave a red welt in the shape of her fingers on his cheek. Reuenthal froze for a moment in surprise.Â 

It wasnâ€™t the instantaneous pain that startled him, though Elfriede did not hold back in the least. It was the fact that he had managed to taunt her into hitting him firstâ€” it went completely contrary to the familiar, safe, pattern they had with each other. Elfriede had never before given Reuenthal the opportunity to be the first one on the defensive, the one allowed to lose control.

She seemed just as startled by it as he was, her eyes widening in shock, like she had been the one to be hit.Â 

What was strange to Reuenthal was that the sensation of losing control did not come. He still held every momentary possibility tightly in his hands: he could have easily walked away from Elfriede, stalked out the door and slammed it behind him. He could have slapped her back, or pulled her hair, or said something cutting. A better man than him might have done any of those things, but Reuenthal did not. He peeled back the options laid out before him, and he found the one that let the disgust fill his mouth like bileâ€” the option that would confirm to them both exactly what kind of man he was. Strong enough to do the worst thing; strong enough to keep control and choose to do it. They had never needed confirmation, but perhaps Elfriede wanted it.

His thoughts had taken no time at all. As Elfriede pulled her own stinging hand to her chest, Reuenthal shoved her backwards. She stumbled, tripping on the coffee table behind her, throwing her arms out to break her fall. Reuenthal grabbed her by the front of her dress before she could topple over, and she yelped as he shoved her back further.

â€œDonâ€™t make a sound,â€ he said. Though even if Elfriede screamed, he doubted that Magdalena would come interrupt. He shoved her onto the couch and climbed on top of her. There was no way that she could escape him; he was much stronger and heavier than she was. He forced her head against the arm of the couch, turning it so that he didnâ€™t directly have to see the genuine fear on her face.

He kept pressing down on her cheek with his palm, forcing her mouth to open against the arm of the couch: a muffled sound of pain emerging, and drool. Her eyes roved in their sockets, straining to look at his face.

He could have stopped at any point. It was a difficult, clumsy fumbling with one hand to hike her dress up around both their hips, force her legs open, pull off the silky nylons she wore. It was even harder to undo his belt and get his pants around his knees. They were awash in the fabric, and it separated them everywhere except for the crucial points of contact, his left hand on her face and his right hand on her cunt.

It would have been less disturbing if she had fought himâ€” that would have felt natural. But she was stiff and still beneath him, her hands curled into the fabric of her skirt.

He forced himself into herâ€” she didnâ€™t make a sound other than both their ragged breathing. Reuenthal lay atop her, his head near her neck, and he let go of her face. He closed his eyes. Without seeing, with the single blinding point of motion between them, pain and heat, there was no sense of where he ended and she began.Â 

â€œImagineâ€”â€ he said, haltingly, into her shoulder. â€œImagine Iâ€™m you, and youâ€™re meâ€”â€

â€œIâ€™ll kill you,â€ she said. â€œIâ€™ll kill youâ€”â€

â€œYesâ€”â€ he said.

When he was done, he left her there on the couch in the parlor. Reuenthal found Magdalena was in the kitchen, drinking a glass of wine. She seemed disaffected, either unaware or uncaring of what had happened in the other room.

â€œHereâ€™s your letter,â€ she said, holding a tan envelope out to him. He took it from her without saying a word. â€œAnd Heinrich took something like four of theseâ€ â€”she held up a mostly empty bottle of pills and rattled it aroundâ€” â€œso unless youâ€™re staying for dinner, you probably wonâ€™t be able to wake him up.â€

â€œNo, Iâ€™m not planning to stay. Iâ€™ll talk to him later.â€ Reuenthal said. There was a memo pad on the counter, along with a pen. He wrote the address of the safehouse on the paper, ripped it off, and left it on the table in front of Magdalena. â€œIf Mariendorf or Kircheis makes it out of the city looking for me, this is where they can find me.â€

â€œFine,â€ Magdalena said.

Reuenthal had nothing else to say to her, or anyone else in the house, so he simply left. Outside the Kummel house, the spring had taken hold of Odin, a warm sunset burning in the sky, and the smell of growing things rising up from the dirt.

Chapter End Notes

it's not the room, not beginning, not the crowd, not winning, not the planet, not spinning, not a ruse, not heat, not the fire lapping up the creek, not food, not to eat

March 489 I.C., Odin

On one of the warmer days in early March, Kircheis and Hilde were out collecting water from the trucks that Littenheim sent around the city. Water was one of the few bare necessities that Littenheim managed to get together for the embattled civilians who remained in the capital. In theory, food was also being distributed, but in practice it went only to those loyal to Littenheim, and anyone without connections had no hope of getting any unless they began stealing it, as Martinâ€™s group had. Hilde and Kircheisâ€™s trip to the water truck served two purposes. First, they needed water to live. But while Kircheis filled their big plastic jugs at the tap, Hilde performed mental calculus about how much they would need to empty from the huge tankâ€™s reservoir, in order to put in enough zephyr gas to make a powerful explosion. It might take too long to empty it to be worth sabotaging one or more of these trucks for their plans.

While Kircheis held his plastic jugs one by one beneath the gushing spigot, watched like a hawk by the soldier guarding the truck, Hilde walked around to the other side and leaned against the tank. She pretended to be nonchalant, but she had her ear pressed to the side of the tank. Though she rapped her knuckles against the metal in some approximation of a rhythm, pretending to amuse herself with the musical noises it made, she was estimating how much water was left in the tank at the beginning and end of its daily run, and trying to take guesses at the gauge of steel that made up the pressure vessel.

When Kircheis had filled all his containers and loaded them into their rickety shopping cart, they began making their way back to his apartment. Although they would have preferred to walk on the sidewalk and have at least one side covered by the buildings, the shopping cart forced them into the street. The sidewalks were piled so high with garbageâ€” months worthâ€” that it was impossible for anyone to walk on them except in single file, stepping on debris. The centers of the roads were clearer. There were few cars that went by, but whenever one came roaring past, Kircheis and Hilde both shoved the cart hastily to the side of the road to avoid getting hit.

As they walked, Kircheis became aware that there was someone on the other side of the street, barely visible on the sidewalk behind the pile of garbage, matching them step for step.

â€œWe have company,â€ he said to Hilde very quietly, in the Alliance languageâ€” an extra layer of security in case their pursuer had particularly good ears. Leigh had encouraged them both to learn it, but neither of them had much occasion to use it. â€œDonâ€™t look, but on the other side of the street, on your eight.â€

â€œDangerous?â€ Hilde asked. From the stiff way she moved, she was clearly itching to turn and look, but obeyed Kircheisâ€™s command to keep the pursuer from noticing.

â€œHeâ€™s been following us since the water station. I donâ€™t know.â€

â€œTurn towards the garage on Kingfisher Street,â€ Hilde said. â€œLetâ€™s see if he follows.â€

â€œAnd if he does?â€

Hilde didnâ€™t answer the question, but Kircheis became increasingly aware of the gun holstered beneath his jacket, its weight on his hip.

They turned the next corner and walked towards the underground garage. The silver gate that once drew down over the entrance had been forced up, and now the gate dangled half open, rattling when the wind blew. Kirchies and Hilde ducked inside, then carefully controlled their heavy shopping cart as they descended the ramp.

The garage was full of garbage, too, and without the wind to take the smell away, the rot was almost overpowering. Nevertheless, Hilde and Kircheis waited in the deep gloom at the bottom of the ramp, taking up positions on opposite sides of the wall and watching the entrance, hands on their guns. The pursuer appeared at the top of the ramp, silhouetted against the weak daylight.Â 

â€œI know you have your guns out,â€ Bronner called as he took the first steps down into the darkness. â€œIâ€™d appreciate you putting them away, unless one of you actually plans to shoot me.â€

Hilde stepped out of the shadows. â€œI thought you preferred coming to visit us at home.â€

â€œI told you, thatâ€™s too troublesome to do often.â€

â€œI was hoping you wouldn't bother at all,â€ Kircheis said. Reluctantly, he tucked his gun back into his holster and moved into the light so he could see Bronner better as he descended the ramp. He was wearing a long and rather dirty coat, and a green woolen hat that he pulled down over his ears. Although it was still chill outside, the outfit was overly warm for the weather, and he was only wearing it because it completely disguised his frame and gait, and obscured part of his face. â€œWhat do you want?â€

â€œAs always, Iâ€™m hoping that one of you has changed your minds. Do you have any information for me?â€

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said. â€œAnd donâ€™t ask again.â€

â€œIâ€™m not that easily dissuaded. As I saidâ€” if you tell me where your friend is going to be, I can make sure that he, at least, makes it through alright. Itâ€™s a generous offer, and one I highly recommend that you consider.â€ It was the same overture he had given every time they had spoken in the pastâ€” a rote line that he had to say to get through to the rest of the scene.

â€œI think youâ€™ve fundamentally misunderstood the kind of person that Martin is, sir,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œOh, no, I havenâ€™t misunderstood him. Iâ€™m well aware that he would consider living on after his comrades have died to be a kind of hell.â€ His teeth caught the light when he smiled. â€œBut, fortunately, itâ€™s not his opinion that matters.â€

â€œAnd I think youâ€™ve misunderstood me, as well,â€ Kircheis said.Â 

â€œWell, as they say, hope springs eternal. You might have changed your mind and decided to be useful to me.â€

â€œHow is your work going in Littenheimâ€™s offices?â€ Hilde asked.

Bronner made a derisive noise. â€œIt would be straining the truth to its utmost limits to even say that â€˜itâ€™s going.â€™ You should count yourself lucky that Leigh has such a poorly organized opponent.â€

â€œLeigh, and not Duke Braunschweig?â€ Hilde asked.

â€œAnd Duke Braunschweig should consider himself even more blessed that he and Leigh share an enemy.â€ Bronnerâ€™s nose wrinkled, like he was just now noticing the objectionable smell in the garage. â€œWell, if youâ€™re certain that you canâ€™t bring yourself to tell me a thingâ€”â€

â€œI donâ€™t even know anything to tell you,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI donâ€™t speak with Martin.â€

â€œYou could. Do you want his current address?â€

Â â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œWell, if we have nothing else to say to each other beyond continued pleasantriesâ€”â€ Bronner nodded at Hilde, and began to turn away.

Hilde glanced over at Kircheis, a strange expression on her face, and then said, â€œRear Admiralâ€” can I ask you a favor?â€

â€œOnly because itâ€™s so nice to be called that instead of lieutenant.â€

â€œI thought you enjoyed playing your various roles,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œIâ€™m not a method actor,â€ Bronner sniffed. â€œI enjoy taking off the costume when the play is over for the night. But what is it that you wanted?â€

â€œSince youâ€™re planning on warning the Military Police of disruptions anyway, you might want them, after sunset on March fifteenth, to heavily fortify the place where Littenheim keeps his ships.â€

Bronner was silent for a second. â€œAnd now why would I want to do that?â€

â€œBecause the more of his staff we can kill while we attack it, the better it will be,â€ Hilde said, annoyed.

Bronner laughed. â€œOf course. An excellent reason to make life more difficult for yourself.â€

â€œYou should know better than to ask questions.â€

â€œAnd are there any other soft targets you want me to make harder for you to get to?â€ Bronner asked.

â€œThe power plant outside the city,â€ Kircheis lied. â€œWeâ€™re blowing that up, too.â€

â€œAnd weâ€™re bombing the tanks of the northern water treatment facility,â€ Hilde added.

â€œAnd the last highway bridge, on the west end,â€ Kircheis tacked on.

â€œMy, you are busy people.â€ He pulled a small notebook and pen out from the pocket of his coat and wrote down what they said. â€œMay I ask what youâ€™re trying to distract all of Littenheimâ€™s forces from exactly?â€

â€œYou should know better than to ask questions,â€ Hilde repeated.

â€œI have never enjoyed the feeling that life is a series of unanswered questions,â€ Bronner said. â€œI, unfortunately, am cursed with a desire to know things.â€

â€œIâ€™m sure youâ€™ll know by the sixteenth,â€ Hilde said. â€œItâ€™s not that far away.â€

Bronner laughed. â€œOf courseâ€” Iâ€™ll try to wait patiently for the denouement.â€ He snapped his notebook shut and put it back in his pocket. â€œBut I make you no promises. And I would find it difficult to get all these warnings into the right ears without completely blowing my own cover, which you may understand that I have no desire to do.â€

â€œOf course not,â€ Hilde said.

â€œAnd I think it would just be a shame if two of Leighâ€™s favorite pupils got themselves killed in petty little acts of terrorism. But theyâ€™re your lives to live or lose,â€ he said with a smile. â€œIâ€™ll see you on the fifteenth, then.â€

â€œDonâ€™t go anywhere nearâ€”â€ Hilde said, then cut herself off.

â€œSo kind of you to care and almost tell me your real target. Fortunately for you, Iâ€™m very good at lying to my superior officers that I have somewhere else urgent to be. Always running back and forth between the offices of the Military Police and Neue Sanssouci.â€

â€œDo you even have an actual superior at either place?â€ Hilde asked.

Bronner just smiled and walked away, whistling some piece by Wagner, as he headed up the ramp out of the parking garage. The notes of his song echoed down the tunnel until he was gone, out into the street.

March 10, 489 I.C., Odin

A little past midnight on March tenth, Kircheis and Hilde returned from one of their nighttime jaunts to sabotage Lichtenladeâ€™s trucks. The mood as they walked back to his apartment was, as usual, mixed. For both of them, the excitement and release of tension was a powerful agent on their nervous systems. After the high stakes of scaring off those who had attacked the truck in the first place, then the necessary quick application of the patch to the truckâ€™s automatic driving system, and then getting away without being caught, they were both filled with energy. He was still jittery, clenching and unclenching his hands in his pockets as they walked, and Hilde took peculiar hops on her toes every couple of steps, just trying to burn it out of her system.Â 

If it had been their success alone that they were coming down from, they might have been legitimately happy, but it was tempered, as always, by the sight of bodies strewn across the road near the trucks. The bodies were mostly those of Littenheimâ€™s soldiers, but today when they approached the trucks, Kircheis ran past a figure on the ground and locked eyes with the wide-eyed corpse of a teenage girl, her blood pooling in the street beneath her. This was not the first time he had seen something like that, and it wouldnâ€™t be the last, if they kept finding trucks to suit their plan up until the final moment.

As they walked through the streets, they occasionally ducked down behind the piles of garbage whenever a carâ€™s headlights swept over the road. They didnâ€™t have much to say to each other, but Kircheis was very grateful for Hildeâ€™s presence. By the time they reached the apartment, a tense six kilometer walk, both of their energies had flagged to the point where Hilde leaned against the wall while Kircheis fumbled with the outer door.

They walked silently up the stairs out of habit, though at this point there was no need for stealth. It seemed that the people who had once lived in the apartments below Kircheisâ€” other students of ONUâ€” had finally left the building. He hoped that they had managed to escape into the countryside, to get back to wherever their families were, and he didnâ€™t want to think about it beyond holding that measure of hope. It left the whole building even more ghostly than it had been.

When Kircheis reached the top, and slipped his key into his own doorâ€™s lock, he discovered, very unpleasantly, that the door was already unlocked. He held up his hand to signal to Hilde, letting her know that there was someone inside.

â€œBronner?â€ she mouthed.

â€œI hope so,â€ he replied in kind. He made hand signals to indicate that she should go back down the stairs, outside, and then come up the fire escape onto the balcony. She nodded. He pointed to his watchâ€” Kircheis would enter the front door in five minutes. She would need to already be silently in the building by then, to help him with whatever the intruder was. Hilde slipped down the stairs, gun already out and in her hand. Kircheis heard the front door click open and shut down below.

He kept one hand on the doorhandle, looking at his watch for the prescribed time, while the other held his gun. The moments moved agonizingly slowly. He didnâ€™t hear a sound from inside the apartment, which was goodâ€” it at least meant that Hilde hadnâ€™t been caught getting in. As the second hand on his watch finally ticked around the last minute, Kircheis silently turned the doorhandle and stepped into his apartment.

He could see directly through the small entryway into the kitchen.
