â€œI like your father,â€ Martin said. â€œI hope heâ€™s well.â€

â€œThank you. I really appreciate that.â€

â€œDo you remember that picnic we had at your fatherâ€™s house?â€

â€œOf course I remember.â€

They talked about nothings, slowly eating their cooling bowls of soup. Reminiscences leading into one another, switching to a new subject as soon as any grew too painful. They talked for long after their bowls were empty. When they ran out of soup, Hilde got up and found a can of olives, and a box of crackers, and they split those, too. They talked until those had been exhausted, and long after they should have all gone to sleep. When Hilde was unable to hide her yawning, despite her desire to stay awake, she got up and took their dishes, then went to perform her nightly routine, leaving Martin and Kircheis by themselves.Â 

They wandered out through the living room to the balcony. Martin touched every piece of furniture he passed, and he looked at the pictures on the walls and the books on the coffee table with what was nowÂ  an open expression of pained longing.

Kircheis leaned on the cold wrought iron railing of the balcony, looking out over the dark city. There were so few lights on the ground that the stars were clearer than they had ever been in his life, the whole galaxy splayed out overhead.

â€œThank you for coming,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œDonâ€™t thank me. Itâ€™s for my sake, more than anything else. I told youâ€” I didnâ€™t want to regret anything.â€

â€œMartinâ€”â€

â€œMm?â€ He leaned on the balcony railing next to Kircheis, their elbows touching.

â€œIt feels like a gift, you being here.â€

â€œIt answers my question, I guess.â€

â€œWhat was your question?â€

â€œDo you forgive me for leaving?â€

Kircheis closed his eyes in pain. What he wanted to tell Martin was that he would have traded anything to have had the past year of their lives still together, to get that time back. But even though the sentiment rang through his mind like a drum, it would have been a lie to say. There had been a price, and Kircheis had chosen not to pay it. And now it was too late. â€œDo you forgive me for not coming with you?â€

â€œYes,â€ Martin said. â€œI do.â€

â€œI love you. I never stopped loving you.â€

Martin took his hand, linking their fingers together. â€œI know.â€

They were silent for a long time, shoulder to shoulder on the balcony, looking at the stars. It was cold enough that their breaths rose around their faces, but not so cold that either of them wanted to go inside.Â 

â€œI went by Triangle Street the other day,â€ Martin said.

â€œWhy?â€

â€œI just go there to think sometimes. Remind myself of what Iâ€™m doing.â€

Kircheis nodded.Â 

â€œYour graffiti is still there. Itâ€™ll probably stay there for a while. That was what made me make up my mind to come here. I had been thinking about it for a long time, but I hadnâ€™t worked up the strength.â€

â€œOh.â€

â€œI shouldnâ€™t have been so cruel, that day on the beach.â€ His voice broke a little. â€œI think about it a lot. I knowâ€” you were only trying to tell me that you loved me.â€

â€œMartinâ€”â€

â€œWhat?â€

â€œForget it, please. I forgive youâ€” donâ€™t think about it.â€

Martin pulled Kircheisâ€™s hand up off the balcony railing, raising his hand to his lips. â€œI know,â€ he said. He kissed Kircheisâ€™s knuckles. â€œI know.â€

Kircheis wanted to fall to his knees at Martinâ€™s feet and beg him not to die, to do anything except for die, but it wouldnâ€™t have done any good. Martin already knew whatever Kircheis wanted to say, and it was a test of Kircheisâ€™s love to not say it. Instead Kircheis traced his thumb against Martinâ€™s cheek, and Martin smiled.

â€œCan I kiss you goodbye?â€ Martin asked.

â€œStay until morning,â€ Kircheis said. â€œPlease.â€

â€œHildeâ€™s here.â€

â€œSheâ€™d want you to stay, too.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know if I have the courage,â€ Martin said quietly.

â€œYouâ€™ll regret it if you donâ€™t,â€ Kircheis replied, which was cruel of him, but true. â€œ Iâ€™ll regret it if you donâ€™t.â€ That was even crueler.

Martin leaned forward and pressed his head against the center of Kircheisâ€™s chest. He enfolded him in his arms, stroked his hand down his back, pressed his nose into Martinâ€™s unwashed hair.Â 

â€œAlright,â€ Martin said. â€œIâ€™ll stay.â€

â€œThank you.â€

Martin shiveredâ€” the wind had picked up, and it was too cold to stay on the balcony, so they came back inside. Hilde was in the kitchen, washing the dishes. Martin and Kircheis headed into the bedroom, where Kircheis pulled open the curtains of the makeshift canopy bed and switched on the lantern that was hanging inside. He started getting undressed.

Martin looked at the whole assembly with some amused approval. â€œI did wonder where the bookshelves went,â€ he said. He sat down on the bed, looking around at the unusually (for Kircheis) unmade bedsheets. Hildeâ€™s diary (a monogrammed black leatherbound notebook) was on one of the pillows. Martin had no reaction to this, but he noticed it.Â 

His eyes settled on the picture of Kircheis and the von Musel siblings that was resting on the bedside table, with the curl of blond hair tucked inside the frame. Kircheis tensed when Martin picked it up, but Martin had, for once, a warm expression on his face when he looked at the picture. â€œYou know, Sieg, it makes me happy that youâ€™ll think of me fondly, too. I should have probably figured that out a long time ago.â€

â€œMartinâ€”â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry you always seem to be the one getting left behind,â€ Martin said.

Kircheis tried to think of something to say to that, but he was spared from doing so by Hilde appearing in the doorway, already wearing her pajamas.

â€œSorry,â€ she said, wincing at the need to interrupt. â€œDo you mind if I grab some of the blankets for the other bed? If youâ€™re staying, I mean.â€ The guest bed had been completely stripped of linens to make the heat-retaining canopy.

â€œIâ€™m not going to make you freeze, Hilde,â€ Martin said. â€œWeâ€™re friends, arenâ€™t we?â€

Her lip trembled. â€œI hope so.â€

â€œThen come here,â€ Martin said, and flopped back on the bed. â€œI donâ€™t mind.â€

Hilde looked at Kircheis for confirmation, and Kircheis nodded, though at this point he was feeling too dire to even smile. If he moved his face at all he would start crying, and might never stop. Hilde seemed much the same. But she went around to the other side of the bed and climbed in, Martin in between her and Kircheis.

Kircheis turned off the light, dropping them into total darkness. None of them spokeâ€” there was only the sound of their breathing and the gentle rustling of the bedsheets as they settled down together. It was a tight fit in the bed, certainly not meant for three, but Martin had become so slight that it almost didnâ€™t matter.Â 

Kircheis pulled Martin against his chest, breathing in his human scent, clutching his bony frame so tightly that he was afraid he would break it. Hildeâ€™s arm draped across Martinâ€™s shoulder, and she tentatively carded her fingers through his hair.

Martin smiled against Kircheisâ€™s neck in contentmentâ€” Kircheis could feel the movement of his face, his lips ghosting over the tender skin in the crook of Kircheisâ€™s shoulder. Perhaps they all hoped that the comfort of being held would be an inoculant against whatever pain was coming.

He wanted to cling to him there forever. Kircheis tried to stay awake in the warm darkness, to memorize for the last time the sound of Martinâ€™s breath and the contours of his hands. How else could he love a man about to die?

He tried to stay awake, but he fell asleep some few hours before the sun rose, and Martin was long gone by then.

Â 

Â 

The next morning at breakfast was grim and nearly silent. Kircheis heated up a can of beans and they ate them spooned over crackers, drinking the last of the metallic water from their plastic jugs.

â€œDid you see Martin before he left?â€ Kircheis asked. The book of poetry was still on the kitchen table where it had been left the night before, and Kircheis touched the cover with his fingertips, but he didnâ€™t open the book. He just looked at it, the cover design with twined grapes, not looking up at Hilde.Â 

â€œYes,â€ she said. â€œHe woke me up to get out of bed. He didnâ€™t want to wake you.â€

Kircheis nodded.

â€œIâ€™m sorry if Iâ€”â€ Hilde began, then stopped.

â€œItâ€™s fine. He wanted you there.â€

She smashed a bean on her plate with her finger. â€œYeah.â€

â€œIâ€™m glad he came.â€

She nodded. â€œSiegâ€”â€

â€œYeah?â€

She had sounded on the verge of saying something else, but instead she said, â€œIâ€™ll do the water run today.â€

â€œIâ€™ll come with you.â€

â€œNo, itâ€™s fine. I can handle it.â€

â€œOkay.â€ Kircheis didnâ€™t want to be alone, but if Hilde wanted to be, he would let her. â€œWe have a meeting with Rear Admiral Reuenthal tonight.â€

â€œI know. Iâ€™ll be back by then.â€

â€œThe fifteenthâ€”â€ Kircheis said. â€œMaybe we should move our plans. We told Bronner to increase security that dayâ€¦ I donâ€™t wantâ€”â€

â€œSiegâ€”â€

There was something so horrible in Hildeâ€™s voice that Kircheis lifted his head to look at her. Her expression was just as pained.

â€œI should have told you this before,â€ she said. â€œI spoke to Martin a while agoâ€”â€

â€œWhen?â€

â€œAfter Bronner gave me where he was staying,â€ she said. Her voice was hardly above a whisper.

â€œWhy?â€

â€œI gave him the date of our plans,â€ Hilde said. â€œI told himâ€” it would be better for both of us if we were acting on the same day. Littenheimâ€™s attention would be split. He agreed with meâ€” thatâ€™s why theyâ€™re moving on the fifteenth.â€

A cold, hard anger like Kircheis never remembered feeling before, never even thought himself capable of feeling, rose up inside his chest. His hand shook as he smoothed out the cover of the poetry book. He took a deep breath, stuffed the feeling down where it couldnâ€™t escape, held the tension in his body like a suspension bridge, like the tension was the only thing keeping him upright, stopping him from flying into a million pieces. He was perfectly still.

â€œYouâ€™re using him,â€ he said. His voice was colder and harder than it had ever been, and he couldnâ€™t quite hate himself for it, though he should have.

â€œYes,â€ she said quietly. â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

Kircheis nodded, and said nothing else.

â€œIâ€™ll go get the water,â€ Hilde said.

Â 

Â 

When Kircheis left the house, he took very little, and left even less. He stuffed his bag full of a change of clothes and as many canned goods as he could carry. He had Leighâ€™s handgun in its holster at his side, and the book of poetry curled up inside his deep coat pocket.Â 

He left a note on the table for Hilde. He was too angry to say much, but he said enough. He knew that in a few days, he would either figure out how to forgive her, or it would cease to matter to him anymore. He dropped his key in his mailbox on the way out the door.

Kircheis didnâ€™t know exactly where he was going. He considered turning towards the Ministry of War, the building that Littenheimâ€™s forces had occupied to lend some legitimacy to their control of the capital. He would probably see Bronner there, and Bronner knew where Martin was staying. But without really thinking about it, Kircheisâ€™s feet took him across the city, ending up at Triangle Street.

Martin had been right: his graffiti was still there, though as he looked at it in the daylight, he could see that the lines of the unfamiliar letters were shaky. Some of the paint had worn off the brick in one spot, where acidic rainwater dripped out of a hole in a drainpipe above and scoured the wall. Kircheis took the book of poetry from his pocket and paged through it until he found the right poem, matching up his old writing to the crisp translated lines on the page. He sat down on the ground beneath the marking on the wall and read the page over and over, just waiting.

He couldnâ€™t have said why he was so sure that Martin would return here, but he was sure of it, and he would wait, at least until the sun began to go down.

He did wait for several hours, sitting against the cold brick with his coat wrapped around his shoulders. The street was deserted. Kircheis saw almost no one the entire time he was there. Even the sound of cars on the main road outside the square were muted, and perhaps only one went by every hour. The light changed, clouds passing back and forth across the sun, dappling the square in moments of shade and moments of warmth. He read through the entire poetry book, then flipped to the start and read it again. Not once did his hope flagâ€” he was sure that Martin would appear.Â 

He was looking down at the book when Martin arrived.

â€œSome say horses,â€ Martin said, standing silhouetted in the entrance to the square. â€œSome say soldiers. Some say a fleet of ships is the most beautiful thing in this dark world.â€

Kircheis didnâ€™t remember the next lines of the poem, nor did he care. He scrambled to his feet. â€œI knew youâ€™d come back here.â€

â€œBut you?â€ Martin askedâ€” though he seemed to hardly need to know the answerâ€” the smile on his face was radiant. Perhaps he had seen the bulging bag at Kircheisâ€™s feet and known what it meant, or perhaps he just knew that Kircheis wasnâ€™t unkind enough to make them part a second time.

â€œI changed my mind,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œWhy?â€ Martin asked. He came right up to Kircheis and took his hands. From being out in the cold for so long, his fingers were nearly numb, but Martinâ€™s touch warmed him more than enough.

â€œIt doesnâ€™t matter. Iâ€™m here.â€

â€œShould I say that I knew you would come, or just that I hoped you would come?â€

â€œHope is a safer thing,â€ Kircheis said. â€œI didnâ€™t know what I was going to do.â€

â€œIs it safer? I think some people say itâ€™s the most dangerous thing in the world.â€

Martin led Kircheis back to his headquarters, which was currently an empty elementary school, the children long gone. The school was in the middle of a tightly packed residential district, and though most of the people who lived there had fled to the countryside, Martin still waited until the cover of darkness to go in, and enforced strict light discipline even inside the building. It made the whole place extremely desolate, their shoes squeaking along the linoleum, beneath old murals of laughing children illuminated only by the starlight that came in through the windows. They could only turn on their flashlights when they were in a hallway that didnâ€™t have windows that opened onto the streets, so Kircheis followed behind Martin blindly, trusting that he, visible only as a darker shadow against the blackness of the hallway, knew where to go.

The majority of Martinâ€™s group, at least of those in the building, was gathered in the basement gymnasium. It was better lit than anywhere else: bright lights on stands were hooked up to a battery pack, casting stage-light down onto men and women lounging around on sleeping bags or gym mats or sitting on chairs that were far too small for them. There were about fifty people in the room, and several of them came up to Martin as soon as he came in. They glanced at Kircheis with a wary expression before saying anything, but Martin nodded at them to continue, and then when they had delivered their news he introduced Kircheis to them. He smiled and shook hands in as natural of a way as he could.

Kircheis was out of place in this milieu, not least because of the change that had come over Martin. He had always tried to stay far away from Martinâ€™s subversive activities, for both their sakes, and had done such a good job at this that he hadnâ€™t realized how important of a figure Martin clearly was. When Martin addressed anyone else in the room, though he called them comrade or citizen or friend interchangeably, he had an undeniable confidence in his own words.Â 

That , Kircheis was used toâ€” Martin had never said anything that he didnâ€™t believe wholeheartedlyâ€” but it was the way everyone around him instantly nodded and accepted what he said that came as a surprise.Â 

It was reminiscent of Leigh, Kircheis thoughtâ€” if in a strange inversion. When Leigh called Kircheis â€œLieutenant,â€ or even addressed Ansbach as â€œCommodore,â€ his tone always held the softness of â€œfriend.â€ When someone approached Martin and called him â€œcomrade,â€ it sounded quite a lot like â€œsir.â€ But even in this strange place, Martin spoke to Kircheis the same way he always had. It was almost as if the past year of absence had fallen away, and the casual and natural familiarity between them returned without any difficulty whatsoever.

Kircheis followed Martin like a shadow, up to the point where Martin stepped into the classroom he had adopted as his office, going to speak with two men and a woman, all armed, who looked at Kircheis with an even more suspicious glance than the people lounging in the gym had. Kircheis took the hint and went back to the gymnasium, sitting down on an ancient plush mat, the kind used for cushioning the falls of gymnasts. The blue fabric cover was worn thin almost everywhere, and Kircheis picked at the foam coming out of the ripped holes with his fingernails, watching everyone else in the room.

Most people were eating bowls of watery soup, which was being distributed by one teenage boy tending a camp stove on a folding table. The room smelled like the beans that had gone into it. Kircheis had given his stash of canned goods to Martin when they came in, and Martin had passed it off to someone else; Kircheis didnâ€™t know what had become of it after that. It might very well have become the soup. He didnâ€™t eat any, even when someone politely came over to offer him a bowl.Â 

Most of the people in the room were in much poorer shape than he was, having not had access to a supply of food like Kircheis had, and he could afford to miss his next few meals. He was suddenly very aware of exactly how Martin had become so thin so quickly. Kircheis did drink some water, since there seemed to be plenty of that: endless gallon jugs stacked against one wall.Â 

Everyone seemed to be in decent spirits, despite the paucity of food. People gathered in groups, mainly sitting in circles directly beneath the spotlights. Some were playing cards to pass the time, others reading or laying down to sleep. People came in and out of the school building at a steady rate. Kircheis heard many of them ask where Martin was, and they were directed to his â€œofficeâ€ â€” he seemed to be quite busy answering questions or giving instructions.

After a few hours of waiting around, Kircheis thumbing through his poetry book and eavesdropping on the conversations around him, someone came up to him. It was the teen boy who had been in charge of the soup. â€œHey, Comrade Redâ€” Martin wants you in there.â€

â€œMy nameâ€™s Siegfried,â€ he said as he stood up from the gym mat, stretching his legs. â€œIs there any soup left?â€

â€œA littleâ€” you want some?â€

â€œNo, Iâ€™m fine. I was just going to bring some to him, if he hasnâ€™t eaten.â€

The boy laughed. â€œGood luck with that, Comrade Red. But Iâ€™ll give you a bowl.â€

Kircheisâ€™s lips pinched in a frown, and he followed the boy to the folding table with the camp stove. He ladeled out a bowl of soup, fishing around in the bottom of the big aluminum pot for the remaining beans at the bottom, and he handed it to Kircheis.Â 

Kircheis made his way through the dark hallway, the room that Martin was in indicated only by the pale glow of a flashlightâ€™s beam reflected out the doorway.

â€œKnock knock,â€ Kircheis said at the door.

Martin was sitting on a chair that was far too small for himâ€” designed for a third grader at the very largestâ€” in a circle of other equally comically small chairs. A flashlight stood on its end in the center of the circle, at least making it bright enough to see the vague outlines of things. The classroom desks had been pushed to the side of the room, but the teacherâ€™s desk at the front had Martinâ€™s illuminated laptop, along with a stack of papers and several canisters of what looked like zephyr gas. Martin smiled at Kircheis when he came in.

â€œShut the door, if you would. Like my circle?â€ he asked.

Kircheis stepped over the chairs to enter it, and then pulled one out to sit in front of Martin, though it was more comfortable by far to sit on the tiny thing backwards, his elbow resting on the chairâ€™s back. He handed the bowl of soup to Martin, who made a face.

â€œEat,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œHas everyone else had some?â€

â€œYes,â€ Kircheis said. â€œThis was leftover.â€

Martin picked up the spoon, stirred the soup, and then asked, â€œHave you had some?â€

â€œEat it,â€ Kircheis said.Â 

â€œLetâ€™s share, then.â€ He offered the spoon to Kircheis.

â€œI have fifty kilograms on you.â€

â€œIâ€™m not going to starve to death, Sieg,â€ Martin said. But he covered up his wry smile by taking a few spoonfuls of soup. â€œHow are you liking my cell?â€

â€œAs schools go, this one isnâ€™t that much like a prison,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œNo, cell as in terrorist,â€ Martin said with a laugh. â€œWeâ€™ve only been in this building for a few days.â€

Kircheis smiled. â€œYou did a good job keeping this all secret from me,â€ he said. â€œI didnâ€™t realize how central you were.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t used to be,â€ he said. â€œThere didnâ€™t used to be much to keep secret, especially before the war. But things changedâ€¦â€ The tone indicated that someone had died, probably someone Martin had been close to. Kircheis didnâ€™t pry.

â€œIs this your whole group?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œItâ€™s most of my particular unit,â€ Martin said. â€œBut weâ€™re far from the only ones. Youâ€™ve seen the messengers from the other groups.â€

â€œHow many others are there?â€

â€œIâ€™m not going to tell you that , Sieg,â€ Martin said, kicking his leg gently. â€œBut I donâ€™t tell anyone anything. I donâ€™t even meet with everyoneâ€” you saw the leader of the Hundred-Twelfthâ€”â€

â€œYou have a hundred twelve units?â€

â€œNo, everyone picks their favorite numberâ€” it makes it harder to tell how many we are,â€ Martin said. â€œShe gives instructions to three or four other groups. We try to keep things pretty decentralizedâ€” I donâ€™t know where her groups quarter, or much else about them. I just ask her if they can do something and she tells me if they can or canâ€™t. And I suppose I have to trust her judgment on that.â€

â€œAnd what number unit is this?â€

â€œFirst,â€ Martin said. â€œItâ€™s a joke nameâ€” John picked it. As they say, the first shall be last.â€

Kircheis smiled. â€œAnd you coordinate all of this.â€

â€œI didnâ€™t used to,â€ Martin said. â€œBut for now, yes.â€

They sat in silence as Martin picked at his soup. He occasionally tried to offer it to Kircheis, who refused most of it.Â 

â€œDo you like being in charge?â€

â€œIâ€™m not in charge,â€ Martin said, but it was an empty protest. â€œCoordinating is different from ordering.â€

â€œPeople here really respect you.â€

Martin gave a breathy sigh. â€œThey respected Johnâ€” Iâ€™m just leftovers.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think thatâ€™s true.â€

â€œWell, if it is or isnâ€™t, itâ€™s what we have,â€ Martin said. â€œWeâ€™ll make the best of it.â€ He glanced behind him at the computer screen of his laptop. â€œIâ€™m glad youâ€™re hereâ€” I could use your help.â€

â€œWith what?â€

â€œSome of our last minute tactical thinking,â€ Martin said. He got up and went over to the desk, and picked up his computer, putting the empty soup bowl down.

â€œYou trust me with that?â€ Kircheis asked as Martin sat back down across from him on the circle of childrenâ€™s chairs.

Martin glanced up from the computer balanced on his lap and looked in Kircheisâ€™s eyes. â€œI do.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think your compatriots will appreciate that.â€ He thought of the suspicious glances from some of the other people when he had come in with Martin. He couldnâ€™t blame them; he was a stranger.

â€œSiegâ€” I trust you.â€

It was a nice thought, but a poor decision when it came to operational security, Kircheis thought. But he was warmed by Martinâ€™s trust, and he leaned forward to look at what he was pulling up on the computer. Kircheis, after a moment of study, pieced together what he was seeing: an intricate map of Neue Sanssouci. Entrances and exits were marked, rooms were labeled, and there were arrows and cutaway diagrams indicating passageways into and out of the palace grounds. There were notes about vulnerabilities, access codes to doors, locations of staff shortcuts through different locations, what was kept in each room, more information than Kircheis could process.

â€œHow did you get thisâ€¦â€ Kircheis muttered, reaching over to click around the map. It was incredibly comprehensive.

â€œWe made it,â€ Martin said. â€œJohn went out of his way to recruit former palace staffâ€” landscaping and maintenance workers especially. John was working on it before, but after all thisâ€” a lot of them who were seen as being loyal to Lichtenlade fled when Littenheim invaded, and we were able to help them. Individually, they knew very little, but togetherâ€” well, we can put the whole thing together.â€

â€œAnd what do you need my help with?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œYouâ€™ve been in the palace, right?â€

â€œYeah, a bit,â€ Kircheis said. â€œNot in any of the imperial family quarters, or any of the real nice areas. Just the areas around the colonial affairs office, and the grounds.â€

â€œMore than Iâ€™ve seen of it,â€ Martin said. â€œIâ€™d like to walk through some of the feasibility of getting people inside. We have plans, but thereâ€™s been no way to test them against reality. Maybe you can help. The former palace staff have a good sense of where things are, but none of them areâ€”â€

â€œSoldiers,â€ Kircheis offered.

Martin glanced up at him. â€œYes.â€

â€œI went to Neue Sanssouci the most when I was a student.â€

â€œI know,â€ Martin said. â€œI remember it.â€

â€œItâ€™s strange to use that now.â€

â€œArenâ€™t people always trying to take apart the masterâ€™s house with the masterâ€™s tools?â€ Martin asked.

â€œMm,â€ Kircheis said. He studied the map. â€œWhat are your goals?â€ he asked.

â€œYou seem concerned,â€ Martin said, ignoring the question.

Kircheis chose his words very carefully. â€œIâ€™m not concerned. It just feels strange. You once objected to everything that soldiers do.â€ He rotated the map on the screen. â€œIâ€™m happy to be of use to you in whatever way you need.â€

Martinâ€™s brow furrowed, and he looked down at the computer between them. â€œItâ€™s hard to be a pacifist in a world like this,â€ he said. â€œImpossible, maybe. Impossible to be a pacifist who gets things done, or survives even enough to keep people fed.â€

Kircheis nodded.

Martinâ€™s voice was odd. â€œDo you think thatâ€™s me betraying myself? The person I was a year ago, before all of this?â€ Unspoken: the principled version of Martin that Kircheis had loved.

â€œYou took my gun when you left,â€ Kircheis pointed out. â€œI understood what that meant back then.â€

â€œI donâ€™t think I did. You must know me better than I know myself.â€

This wasnâ€™t the case, but Kircheis was familiar with the specific pain that Martin was trying to articulate: the necessary hypocrisies, the endless string of self-betrayals, large and small, that made up a life.Â 

That had been the difference between them for so long, since the day Kircheis had become a soldier to survive. While it had been painful to feel Martinâ€™s disdain, it had also been something Kircheis had admired about himâ€” his refusal to cave under pressure and abandon his own values. And it had been even more painful for Kircheis to wonder about himself, exactly how much of himself he was willing to give up.Â 

It was another thing that had been turned over in this strange world. In returning to Martin, Kircheis had found exactly where his limits lie, and he was content with the answer.Â 

What Martin had said didnâ€™t need a reply, so Kircheis just put his hand on his knee. â€œTell me what you need,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™ll see what I can help with.â€

Martin smiled and focused himself, sitting up straighter in his chair. Kircheis could see the leader in him, the way he became animated when he spoke.

â€œWell, we have a few main goals,â€ Martin said. â€œOr, we have a few main political goals, but one strategy for getting them done. What we need to do is take the royal family hostage.â€

It was not surprising, but hearing it said aloud with such confidence made Kircheis shiver. â€œAnd then?â€

â€œWe demand that they sign a declaration of their intent to abolish the feudal system, free the serfs, open a parliament, and enfranchise the whole population. More immediately, we take control of the food supply into the city, and start getting it into peopleâ€™s hands.â€

â€œDo you expect them to actually do what you ask?â€

â€œWeâ€™re going to keep the palace occupied,â€ Martin said. â€œThey wonâ€™t have a choice. And if we have the royal family in custody, their armed forces canâ€™t risk attacking the palaceâ€” and usâ€” without them dying.â€

Kircheis was silent for a moment, but had to ask. â€œAnd when Duke Braunschweig arrives with his own claimant to the throne?â€

â€œDuke Braunschweig destroyed Iserlohn,â€ Martin said.

â€œYou knew about that?â€

â€œI know about a lot of things. But I think heâ€™s shot himselfâ€” Iâ€™m willing to bet that people would rather bow to Sabine than Elizabeth, since Braunschweig has demonstrated that he doesnâ€™t care about the nation or its people, only for his own personal standing. The fleet will oppose him for us, on Sabineâ€™s orders.â€

â€œI hope youâ€™re right,â€ Kircheis said. He was not as confident that people would respect a ruler who was being held hostage and puppeted by revolutionaries, but this was the only chance that Martin had, so he couldnâ€™t, and didnâ€™t, suggest an alternative.

â€œAnd someday,â€ Martin said, a little wistfully, â€œI hope that people realize that they donâ€™t have to bow.â€

â€œYeah.â€

â€œYour friend Leighâ€” and Hildeâ€” theyâ€™ll understand the way the tide is turning.â€ He said this more to himself than Kircheis, trying to reassure himself.

Kircheis wasnâ€™t so sure. Leigh, maybeâ€” Leigh was a republican, and always had been, so he might be able to turn against Braunschweig without many qualms. Hilde was a far more complicated question. If nothing else, Kircheis knew that she took her offered position as Elizabethâ€™s future advisor very seriously. But that alone wouldnâ€™t be enough to set her directly against both Leigh and Kircheis, her closest friends.Â 

The fact that Kircheis had abandoned her now might be. He frowned down at the computer screen. â€œYouâ€™re right,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™m sure theyâ€™ll understand.â€

Â 

Â 

March 11, 489 I.C., Odin

When Kircheis woke up the next day, Martin was already long gone. Early in the morning, there had been a great rousing of people in the gymnasium, most needing to get out of the building before dawn, which would make a stealthy exit more difficult. Kircheis woke up when he heard the noise begin, and found that Martin had been one of the first out, the space on the blue gym mat next to him empty except for Martinâ€™s meager bag of personal possessions.Â 

Without Martin to tag along after, Kircheis had very little to do with his time. There was breakfastâ€” the freckled teen who had been cooking last night made a pot of riceâ€” but Kircheis didnâ€™t take any. He volunteered to help clean the camp, and while at first his offers were rebuffed, someone finally handed him some rags and a mop and told him he could clean the bathrooms, if he was so enthusiastic.

For a camp without running water, occupied by a rotating cast of over fifty people, the bathrooms could have been in worse shape. They were probably only so reasonably kept because the camp had only been in use for a few days so far.

This was a girlâ€™s school, so there were no urinals in the bathrooms, only stalls, with curiously small and low to the ground toilets and sinks for the children. The tank lids had been lifted off the toilets so that they could use their grey water left over from washing hands or dishes to flush, though someone had written reminders on each door only to flush when absolutely necessary: water was a limited resource. Kircheis doubted that the reminders were very effective, since the bathrooms would be so dark at night that no one could read the message. The light now came in from a tiny window, and it was barely enough to see by, since it had been raining since some time in the middle of the night. Perhaps the lack of light, too, disguised the mess.

Rainwater at least meant that he could mop, as people had collected it in whatever implements they could find, and brought it inside to use.

Kircheis got started cleaning, judiciously mopping up the most egregious places where people had missed the mark on the small toilets in the dark. One of the stalls was occupied as he cleaned, and although he had announced when he entered the bathroom that was what he was doing, the occupant of the stall didnâ€™t move at all. Even when Kircheis finished cleaning all the rest, the person didnâ€™t get out of the stall. Considering that Kircheis had been cleaning for more than half an hour, and the pair of feet he could see beneath the door hadnâ€™t moved an inch, and nor had the person inside made a sound, he began to grow concerned.

He knocked on the stall door as gently as he could. He didnâ€™t even know if the occupant was a man or a woman, so he could only say, â€œExcuse me, I hate to be a bother, but are you alright?â€

There was no response from within the stall, and when Kircheis listened over the sound of rain outside, he didnâ€™t think he could hear any breathing.

Now seriously worried (though if the person in the bathroom was truly dead, it would be far too late for him to do anything about it), Kircheis left the bathroom and tried to flag down someone around camp for help. The only person who paid him any mind was the teen boy who doled out the food. He was reading a book, but looked up at Kircheis when he came in.

â€œLooking for someone, Comrade Red?â€ he asked. â€œMartinâ€™s not here.â€

â€œI know. I think thereâ€™s a problem in the bathroom.â€

â€œToilet jammed?â€ He looked at the mop in Kircheisâ€™s hand.

â€œNo,â€ Kircheis said. He hated to lay this at the feet of a sixteen year old kid, but he seemed somehow to be the person with most authority left in camp. And, besides, he had been sixteen when he went off to military school. â€œThereâ€™s someone in one of the stalls who hasnâ€™t moved at allâ€” I think they might be dead.â€

The boyâ€™s funny smile fell away, and he nodded. â€œLetâ€™s take a look.â€

They returned together to the bathroom, and Kircheis pointed out the stall, though he hardly needed to. The boy knocked on the door. â€œItâ€™s Fritzâ€” you okay, Comrade?â€

There was, of course, no response. Kircheis was now quite sure that whoever was in the stall was dead.

â€œDo you want me to get the door?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œIâ€™ll do it,â€ Fritz said. He was small, and he dropped to his knees and easily slid beneath the stall door. He had no audible reaction to what he found inside, but the door swung open a moment later, and he stepped out, face pale and serious.Â 

Sitting on the closed lid of the toilet, her upper body slumped back against the wall, was an older woman, in her late forties or early fifties. She was wearing a dress and comfortable menâ€™s running shoes, and her straw blonde hair was dirty but neatly combed into a thin braid. Her eyes were wide open and glassy, staring at the sky, and she was quite obviously dead. Her left hand was purple and swollen, not from whatever had killed her, but from the scrap of white fabric that was wrapped so tightly through her fingers and wrist as to cut off circulation. On the closed lid of the toilet tank behind her was an empty bottle of liquor and an equally empty pill bottle.

Fritz studied her. Although he was stoic, he didnâ€™t seem to know what to actually do.

â€œDo you know who this is?â€ Kircheis asked quietly.

â€œRosa. Markâ€™s mom,â€ Fritz said. â€œMartinâ€™s not going to be happy.â€

â€œWhat about Mark?â€ Kircheis askedâ€” that seemed like the more pertinent question.

Fritz looked at him like he was stupid. â€œMarkâ€™s been dead,â€ he said.

â€œAh.â€ Kircheis looked at the body for a moment more. â€œWe canâ€™t leave her in the bathroom,â€ he said. â€œWhere should we put her?â€

Fritz didnâ€™t have an answer at hand, but he didnâ€™t stop Kircheis from going into the stall and lifting up the dead woman, carrying her beneath her knees and shoulders. She weighed very little. He led Kircheis to a classroom a few doors down, and Kircheis put her body on the long table in the back of the room. He closed her eyes, and when he unwrapped the strip of fabric from her hand, the motion felt oddly familiar, like something he had done once before, long, long ago. He laid her hands over her chest.

â€œDo you have a blanket to cover her with?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œIâ€™ll get one.â€

When Fritz left, Kircheis studied her face, then the strip of cloth that was still in his own hand. He had thought it was a bandage when he had unwrapped it, but he realized that it was actually a strip of silkâ€” quite fine in quality. Embroidered on it in tiny letters, over and over, were the wordâ€™s of the Earth Churchâ€™s mantra: EARTH IS MY MOTHER. EARTH IN MY HANDS.

He remembered why the feeling of unwrapping it from her hand felt so familiar: he had done the same for the young Erwin Josef, years ago, when he had held him for his nurse. The memory made Kircheis shiver: his investigation into why the palaceâ€™s staff was full of members of the Earth Church had later led to Martinâ€™s friends burning down their headquarters as retaliation. The murder of Prince Ludwig had been blamed on republicans, but it seemed clear that the Earth Church had been the ones responsible, in order to secure themselves an heir to the throne who would be favorable to them. Martin had mentioned recruiting former palace staff to his efforts.

The whole thing felt dangerousâ€” did Martin not remember, or perhaps not care, that many of the former palace staff were Earth Church members? It seemed unreasonable that even the most downtrodden members of the staff would flock in great numbers to help Martinâ€™s revolutionary goals. From what Kircheis knew, the staff of Neue Sanssouci, especially those close to the royal family, tended to be proud of their positions. Even if Littenheim had swept through and removed them all from their postsâ€”

Kircheis stuffed the scrap of fabric into his pocket as Fritz returned, bearing a colorful crocheted blanket. â€œIt was hers,â€ he explained as he laid it down over top of her. His voice was rough now, and he blinked away the beginnings of tears. He stared at the covered form for a moment, then shoved his hands in his pockets, straightened himself up, and said, â€œWeâ€™ll have to ask Martin what to do about herâ€¦â€

â€œDo you have a place you usually bury people?â€

Fritz gave him another look like he was stupidâ€” maybe he was. â€œPeople donâ€™t die in camp.â€

The bodies left on the road.

â€œOh. Right.â€

â€œIâ€™ll send someone out to find Comrade Martin,â€ Fritz said. â€œI think Ella knows where he is today.â€ Fritz turned to go.

â€œWas she a former member of the palace staff?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œYeah,â€ Fritz said. â€œShe worked in housekeeping. Why?â€

â€œJust wondering,â€ Kircheis said. â€œThere arenâ€™t that many women aroundâ€” I just wondered how she got here.â€

â€œOh, it was Mark that brought her.â€

â€œHer son, you said?â€

â€œYeah. He and I were friends.â€ Fritz scuffed his foot on the ground for a moment. â€œAnywayâ€” Martinâ€™s not going to be happy.â€

It sounded like there was something more than the obvious regret for a death. â€œWhy?â€

â€œHe told her that she should leave the camp,â€ he said.

â€œWhat for?â€ This seemed antithetical to Martinâ€™s usual way of operatingâ€” kicking out a woman whose son had died.

â€œWellâ€”â€ Fritz gestured at her. â€œBecause of this. After Markâ€” she was starting to get too worried about everyone else, I guess. Martin just wanted her to leave the city. Somebody said that their family could take her in, but she didnâ€™t want to go. I donâ€™t knowâ€¦â€ He trailed off. â€œToo late now, anyway.â€

Â 

Â 

Even though the sun was still out, Martin returned to camp a few hours later, hastened back by the news. It was still raining, and though he was soaking wet when he came in, he still managed to command respect, people getting out of his way immediately as he walked in to look at the body. Whoever had gone to fetch him had told him the news in full, because he didnâ€™t ask any questions when he arrived. He pulled up one of the small childrenâ€™s chairs next to the table and sat down, pulling back the blanket to look at Rosaâ€™s face, and taking her hand in his.Â 

Kircheis, who stood at the side of the dim room, couldnâ€™t tell what he was thinking, but he sat there for a long time in total silence. Other people in the room coughed and shuffled awkwardly, or came and went, but Martin hardly breathed.

â€œCan we get her out of the city tonight to bury her?â€ Martin asked suddenly, breaking the silence and making half the room jump. â€œThis is a question of logisticsâ€” donâ€™t tell me something untrue because you think I want to hear it.â€

Although Kircheis had been able to sneak out of the city by himself many times, he didnâ€™t know how difficult it would be with several people, carrying a body. There was a moment of silence as people thought about it.

â€œWhatâ€™s the alternative if we canâ€™t?â€ one of the people who had returned with Martin asked. This was a woman, wearing menâ€™s clothing, with a rifle still slung across her back. Even inside camp, she seemed reluctant to put it down. This was the leader of one of the other groups, Kircheis remembered. She might feel safer and more comfortable elsewhere.

â€œThere are parks in the city,â€ someone else suggested.

â€œI wouldnâ€™t ask anyone to take that risk,â€ Martin said. â€œIt takes a long time to dig a grave.â€

â€œThe alternative?â€ the woman asked again.

â€œThe river,â€ Martin said. He still hadnâ€™t let go of the dead womanâ€™s hand. Although Kircheis expected there to be an immediate clamor of protest at this, people were silent, at least for long enough for Martin to say, â€œThe living are more important than the dead. I donâ€™t want anyone risking their lives over this.â€ Bitterly, he added, â€œShe wouldnâ€™t want that, either.â€

â€œAnd if we can do it safely?â€ the man who had suggested a city park asked.

â€œThen do it,â€ Martin said. â€œTell me before you go.â€

The man nodded, and Martin stood to go, laying Rosaâ€™s hand back on her chest and re-covering her with the blanket. He nodded at the people he had come back with, and they began to follow him out.

â€œMartinâ€”â€ Kircheis said.

Martin stopped in his tracks and looked over at him.

â€œCan I talk to you about something?â€ he asked.

â€œOf courseâ€” what is it?â€

â€œWho is this?â€ the woman asked.

â€œI told youâ€” this is Siegfried,â€ Martin said. â€œI trust him.â€

â€œAlone might be better,â€ Kircheis said.

â€œIf itâ€™s important, I think weâ€™d all like to know,â€ the woman said. â€œI would hate to feel like thereâ€™s secrets being kept around here.â€

â€œIsnâ€™t that what weâ€™re in the business of?â€ one of the men said, laughing to break the tension. It didnâ€™t work.

â€œIs this something personal?â€ Martin asked. It obviously wasnâ€™tâ€” Kircheis wouldnâ€™t have brought it up if it wasnâ€™t urgent.

Kircheis looked in his eyes for a moment. â€œI found this with her, when I found her body,â€ he said, and pulled the long white cloth from his pocket. He had folded it neatly, and it looked almost like a handkerchief until Martin unfolded it and ran his fingers across the embroidery. He understood what it wasâ€” recognition showed on his face.Â 

But he lifted his eyes and handed the white cloth to the man who had offered to bury her in the park. â€œThen it should be buried with her,â€ he said. â€œHereâ€” Emil.â€

Be careful. I think y ou're being set up , was what Kircheis wanted to say, but it was clear that he wasnâ€™t in a position to make any accusations. â€œDid you know she was a member of the Earth Church?â€ Kircheis asked.

â€œI knew,â€ Martin said. And was that the real reason he had asked her to leave camp, Kircheis wondered. â€œShe was a good womanâ€” I trusted her, too.â€

Chapter End Notes

sorry kay this one is more setup :p there's something a little awkward about this chapter in that the emotional scene is frontloaded and then immediately undercut by kircheis ending up going to martin. but ah well. there's no way to backload that emotional moment and have the necessary setup for the next chapter... if i kept it all as one massive chunk it might be less weird but i can't do that. i'm addicted to posting ğŸ˜”ğŸ˜”ğŸ˜”ğŸ˜” and also that would be a stupid amount of words to drop at once. so.

the song that martin hums is the school song of my alma mater, which did play from the clock tower at noon lol

"is kircheis saint peter" the worst fucking thread in the history of biblical allusions etc etc etc. he does have a textually important set of housekeys tho. so who's to say.

you'll almost certainly want to go check out the latest chapter of and the big wheel keep on turning

characters who know they're about to die do have a bit of a special place in my heart ğŸ’™ i think this is because i was raised catholic and that's sorta like. the whole thing.
