Â 

It was several more days before Mittermeyer could land on Odin. He had to go through the process of announcing Littenheimâ€™s death and the capture of Neue Sanssouci, then forcing the remaining ships in the air to stop their useless attacks and give themselves up. Once they had surrendered, he consolidated their crews onto transports to be used as temporary prison ships, then had his own men land the captured ships outside the city. He left his own fleet in the air, under the command of his adjutant, Captain Bayerlein, and descended to Odin. He didnâ€™t ask for permission from Merkatz on the planet, merely announced that he would be landing at the earliest possible convenience, and then did.

In the time between his conversation with Oberstein and his descent to the planet, no one said anything more about his wife. Reuenthal didnâ€™t ever attempt to get in contact with Mittermeyer, even after radio communication had been fully restored. It was this, more than anything else, that caused the sense of dread to claw its way to the forefront of his mind.

In any other time, Reuenthal would have borrowed or commandeered a shuttle to come up to visit Mittermeyer on his beautiful stolen flagship, or at the very least would have stopped at nothing to get a message to him. A letter, if not a radio call.

The joy that Mittermeyer should have felt at the end of the civil war was soured by this nagging fear, the sense that something terrible had happened that no one would tell him about. Perhaps it was just Reuenthal avoiding him for the usual reasons he cloistered himself away sometimes. He recalled the conversation they had on the balcony of the bar at Yangâ€™s bachelor party the previous summer, where they discussed looking forward to the happiness that was waiting on the other side of the civil war. He tried to tell himself that it was just Reuenthal not wanting to be part of Mittermeyerâ€™s saccharine, half-formed visions, or not able, anyway.

He regretted that conversation. It floated through his mind as his flagship descended onto the capitalâ€™s airfield. Even as he said that he imagined he would be happy, he knew that it was just the kind of lie he often told himself. And the sight of the ruined capital gave voice to that lie.

He had known what to expect from photographs, but that still was nothing compared to seeing it come closer and closer on the screens of the bridge: there was the smoldering, grey city with its skyline permanently altered; there was the airfield so pitted with holes that the runway was completely destroyed, and only ships capable of vertical takeoff were able to land in the area. The whole place was a pitiful sight, despite the greening of the trees in the forests, and the blueness of the sky, a perfect spring mid-afternoon.

When he touched down on the airfield and stepped out onto his shipâ€™s ramp, he could smell acrid smoke and a fetid rot in the air, carried on the wind brushing in over the city. It made him gag, and he briefly covered his mouth with his sleeve as he regained his composure and looked around.

There was no proper entourage to greet him when he landed, just one small figure leaning on the section of chain link fence that remained upright, watching the glittering and unmarred white ship descend. Waiting some yards away were a handful of soldiers, sharing too-few cigarettes between them. The smoke rose into the air, and they ignored the shipâ€™s descent. The small figure was clearly their leaderâ€” when he stepped forward, the soldiers turned to look, waiting for an order. But the person just crossed the tarmac towards him as he descended the ramp of the white ship.

From a distance, Mittermeyer couldnâ€™t tell who it wasâ€” wearing a soldierâ€™s jacket draped over his shoulders like a cape, too short and pale to be Yangâ€™s redheaded lieutenant, and not Reuenthal either, nor Oberstein, nor Merkatzâ€™s adjutant Schneider, and for a brief moment he thought it was his wife, but then the figure got close enough for him to see her shaggy hair and her youthful face.

Â It was Hildegarde von Mariendorf, whom Mittermeyer barely knew, though he remembered that she had been entrusted with some amount of responsibility, first by Yang and then by Oberstein. They had only met once before, at Yangâ€™s wedding, where they had exchanged a few pleasantries.

She gave him a salute as they met in the middle of the tarmac, and he gave one back, though it felt strange to salute a young woman. As he got closer, he could see that she was no longer quite the cheerful girl tagging along after Yang that she had been at his wedding. Her face was hardened, and there were shadows beneath her eyes. Her hair was roughly cut and unwashed, and the soldierâ€™s jacket she was half-wearing was torn. Nevertheless, despite her grim expression, she looked over Mittermeyerâ€™s shoulder with an undeniable curiosity in her eyes at his ship.

â€œWelcome back to Odin, Rear Admiral,â€ she said.

â€œThank you,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s good to see that youâ€™re well, Fraulein Mariendorf. Are you my only welcoming party?â€

â€œIâ€™m afraid so,â€ she said. â€œCaptain Oberstein mentioned that you were landing, and someone needed toâ€” no one else could.â€

He could hear something in her voice, see it written on her face, but he just said, â€œIâ€™m just surprised Lieutenant Kircheis wasnâ€™t the one to come get me.â€

A shadow crossed her eyes, her mouth twitched.

â€œHeâ€™s not dead, is he?â€

â€œNo,â€ she said. â€œHe was wounded.â€

â€œBadly?â€

â€œHeâ€™s recovering,â€ Hilde said, which meant nothing.

â€œI see. Iâ€™m sorry for him. If thereâ€™s anything I can doâ€¦?â€

â€œItâ€™s alright. If youâ€™ll come this way, Rear Admiral. Any of your men who are leaving your ship, they can head towards the outpost we have in the hangars.â€ She waved her arm, and the soldiers who had been with her hastened towards the ramp of the white ship, waiting for anyone else to come down. But she led Mittermeyer away down the airfield towards the service road, where she had a car waiting.Â 

It was his wifeâ€™s car. He blinked at it, not quite believing what he was seeing. She fished in the pocket of her soldierâ€™s coat for the key fob.

â€œLieutenant Kircheis told me where to get your car,â€ she said. â€œHe was the one who escortedâ€” well, your car was left in the city.â€

He took the keys, and sat down in the driverâ€™s seat. It was a terribly homesick feeling that gripped him, seeing the bird-shaped charm that dangled from the rearview mirror, and Evangelineâ€™s lipstick left in the cupholder.Â 

â€œYouâ€™ll have to tell me where weâ€™re going, Fraulein,â€ he said.Â 

But she didnâ€™t answer. He had his hands on the wheel but hadnâ€™t started the car, and he could tell that there was something wrong. Hilde sat down in the passenger seat, and the tension that hadnâ€™t been visible while she was standing was now obvious in the stiff way she held herself. She wanted to get him in private, in some simulacrum of a familiar environment, before breaking the bad news. Perhaps he should be grateful that she wasnâ€™t going to make him wait any longer, that someone was finally going to break whatever bad news they had been collectively hiding from him for days.

â€œPlease tell me what it is that youâ€™re here to tell me, Fraulein Mariendorf,â€ he said.

â€œRear Admiralâ€”â€

â€œWhy are you the one chosen to tell me whoâ€™s died?â€ he asked. His voice was completely flat and hard. â€œWhy isnâ€™t Reuenthal here?â€

She opened her mouth in a miserable, silent attempt to say something, and he remembered that she had known Reuenthal since she was a child, that he was a family friend of hers. Her voice cracked unpleasantly, like a teenage boyâ€™s, when she finally got the words out. â€œHeâ€™s outside the city.â€

â€œWhy isnâ€™t he here?â€ Being outside the city didnâ€™t exactly mean he was alive.

â€œHe thought it was best that someone else give you the news.â€ This sounded like a lie, not something that Reuenthal would say, but at least he was alive. There was only one alternative, then. If his parents were dead, it would be Evangeline giving him the news.

â€œIs my wife dead? She was staying with your cousinâ€” thatâ€™s what Oberstein said.â€

Hilde closed her eyes. â€œSheâ€™s alive. Iâ€™m sorryâ€”â€

â€œWhy are you apologizing?â€

â€œShe left,â€ Hilde said. â€œShe went to Phezzan.â€

He turned the keys of the car; the engine roared to life.Â 

With the worst of it out, Hilde kept talking. â€œShe was staying at my cousinâ€™s house, with myself, and Countess von Leigh, and Elfriede von Kohlrausch. There wasâ€” it was an argument. Elfriede told her about you and Rear Admiral Reuenthal,â€ she said. â€œAnd she left.â€

â€œWhat did she say?â€ He didnâ€™t know who he was asking about, Evangeline or the other woman.

â€œEverything,â€ Hilde said. â€œIâ€™m sorry. If I had knownâ€” I would haveâ€”â€

â€œWould have what?â€ Mittermeyer asked. He felt empty and flat. If it had been Reuenthal, he would have yelled, but instead there was this near-stranger delivering the news, this woman intruding on his life by accident or coincidence. It would have been like yelling at a news anchor on television. It stopped him from weeping, too.Â 

A numbness settled over him, almost physical, like his face was rubber. He couldnâ€™t feel the heat in his skin or the stinging of his eyes, and when he turned his head to scrape his cheek across the arm of his jacket, to wipe at his face, the heavy weave of the fabric felt like nothing at all, just pressure.Â 

He saw Hilde. The soldierâ€™s coat made her look very out of place, like she would have felt more natural stationed at the front lines with a gun in hand. That made two of them, a small moment of connection in this miserable car.Â 

Hilde kept her eyes fixed on the road in front of them, and silently pointed the way out of the airfield. He swerved around the bombed out craters on the ground, heading for the city streets. He followed her directions blindly.

â€œIt wasnâ€™t your secret to keep, and there was nothing you could have doneâ€” should have done. Iâ€™ve deserved this for years.â€ He turned a corner too sharply. â€œAs you clearly know.â€

â€œPlease donâ€™t blame Rear Admiral Reuenthal for this,â€ she said.

â€œI donâ€™t.â€ It was a familiar lie, one he told in order to make it true.

She nodded, and there was silence in the car.

â€œDid anybody think to warn her that the rebels are probably about to invade through Phezzan?â€

â€œI wasnâ€™t there when she leftâ€” I didnâ€™t find out until she was already gone. I would have tried to stop her if I had known thatâ€™s what she was planning to do.â€Â 

Mittermeyer shook his head.Â 

She pointed for him to avoid a city road that was completely blockaded with a mountain of garbage, and Mittermeyer turned the car the other direction. â€œWhere are you leading me, Fraulein?â€

â€œAdmiral Merkatz is in Neue Sanssouci,â€ she said.

â€œNo,â€ he said. â€œTell me where Reuenthal is.â€

Hilde seemed about to refuse to tell him, for his own sake, maybe, but she didnâ€™t end up arguing, just said, â€œWeâ€™ll have to go north.â€

He turned in the direction that she pointed, and drove through the ruins of the city.Â 

From the pocket of her soldierâ€™s jacket, she pulled out a handheld radio, turned it and honed through the fuzzy static to a clear channel. They listened to the open chatter of Braunschweigâ€™s men, letting it fill the space and wash over them. Sometimes what they said would make her direct the car along different streets. He should have asked her about the past few months on Odin, what everyone left behind had been doing, but while she might have been willing to give a report, he couldnâ€™t open his mouth to ask.

He could see it all clearly in the remains of the city. Even the parts that had not been directly hit with laser fire, everything was touched. Windows were smashed, or boarded up, or boarded up and then crashed through again. The streets were piled with garbage, vehicles were burned-out husks abandoned half hiked up onto the sidewalk, most of the decorative trees had been cut down for easy firewood. Every corner seemed to hold some new detail of miseryâ€” half melted pieces of paper pinned to telephone poles bearing the scrawled name of someoneâ€™s son, the rectangular patches of upturned dirt that marked shallow graves dug into the grass of the city parks.

He was grateful when they finally made it to one of the few remaining bridges at the edge of the city, where they passed through a guard checkpoint, and then were allowed to drive out into the less dense suburbs and forests beyond. Here, things were less destroyed, and the greening of spring had taken over the trees, putting out fresh buds and unfurling delicate and bright leaves, while daffodils poked their heads out from the ground, and forsythias turned plain bushes a riotous yellow.

He couldnâ€™t care much about that, though. Hilde said that Reuenthalâ€™s current outpost was about an hourâ€™s drive away, and that was enough time for the numbness to fall away, and for his thoughts to begin to churn.

It wasnâ€™t Reuenthalâ€™s fault, of course. Perhaps it had been his fault that Elfriede knew about them, but it wasnâ€™t his fault that Evangelineâ€”

It was hard to even think the words.

It was his own fault, exclusively and completely. His own actions for years, willfully and knowingly done, sometimes while his wife was just one room over. It wasnâ€™t difficult to admit guilt, culpability.Â 

He had managed to continue for so long only because he harbored a fantasy of forgiveness. Imagining himself confessing and her touching his head, his cheek, a benediction and an absolutionâ€” he could make that fantasy real enough that he felt the forgiveness before it came. It eased the guilt just enough to keep the tower standing, shored up the dam just enough that it didnâ€™t burst.

Of course, he had known that it was a delusion, and in his clearer moments he had been all too aware that it would all come crashing down, that Evangeline could not possibly forgive him for years of lies. The fear of that truth stopped him from confessing as much as the fantasy of forgiveness did, these two equal forces pressing up against him on either side, keeping him confined to the one track that he was already going down, compelled to follow it to the end.

And the end had arrived, unexpectedly, the ground dropping out from beneath him. Here in the car, next to this near-stranger, he felt the moment before gravity caught him and pulled him down and down, the single moment of continued momentum pushing him heedlessly towards Reuenthal.

If he had waited half a day, he wouldnâ€™t go in Reuenthalâ€™s direction. He had half an impulse to pull the car into one of the highway off ramps and turn around, return to the city, go meet with Merkatz instead. Cordon off every iota of personal feeling into a smaller and smaller chamber of his heart, squash it down, see no one, say nothing. He might never speak to Reuenthal again if he did that. Evangeline leaving might have accomplished the one thing her staying never could, which was to turn Mittermeyer into an upright man, or the husk of one. There seemed to be very little left of him when he searched inside himself.

The only thing that he could find was a roiling anger. It was a self-directed emotion, but that didnâ€™t stop it from needing to fly out through his hands and raw throat. It needed a target like a mirror, one that would direct the violence to the place that deserved it. It needed Reuenthal.

His hands gripped the steering wheel so tightly that he lost sensation in his fingers. When he reached to adjust the temperature in the car, he found that he couldnâ€™t uncurl his hands from their fused, claw-like bent without real effort.

Reuenthalâ€™s camp was a literal campground, tucked in a mountain valley with a placid lake shimmering under the blue sky. They had to pull off the highway onto a dirt road to get to it, and Hilde rolled down her window and stuck her head out so that the guards could see exactly who was coming long before they rolled up the track. They passed through the gates to the camp itself, where log cabins stood like soldiers in a row between the pines and the shore, and men in uniform stood on guard or walked between the buildings. Hilde, filling up space in the car, explained that Reuenthal had previously been at a much smaller safehouse, but with the arrival of Merkatzâ€™s reinforcements, they had moved back here. This was where Litchtenlade was being kept prisoner, but Mittermeyer tuned her out.

Hilde told him to stop the car in the dirt parking area, where there were a handful of other vehicles haphazardly lined up along the edge of the trees. It was late afternoon by the time they arrived, and the shadows were growing long.

â€œWhere is Reuenthal?â€ he asked.

â€œThe building near the dock,â€ she said, pointing towards the lake. â€œThatâ€™s the one he uses as an office.â€

It was a cabin like any other, and Mittermeyer marched towards it. He should have asked Hilde if Reuenthal knew he was coming. It was too late now. There was the wooden door, the wax-paper covered windows on the log cabin, the curl of smoke coming up out of the stone chimney. He knocked on the door. Pounded on it.

â€œReuenthal!â€ Anger was at least a comprehensible emotion.

It only took a second for someone to open the door. Aside from Reuenthal, there were three other men inside the dim cabinâ€” one of them was Merkatzâ€™s adjutant, Schneider, but Mittermeyer didnâ€™t recognize the other twoâ€” and they were all leaning over a table looking at a galactic map together. It was one of the others who had opened the door, a bearded captain, and he saluted when he saw the stripes on Mittermeyerâ€™s shoulders, but Reuenthal straightened up from his lean over the map and looked at Mittermeyer squarely.

â€œRear Admiral Mittermeyerâ€”â€ Schneider said, alarmed. â€œI thought you were going to Neue Sanssouci.â€

â€œI have business here.â€

â€œGentlemen, we can finish discussing this later,â€ Reuenthal said.

â€œI have to get back to the capital,â€ Schneider said. â€œIâ€™ll come back tomorrow.â€

â€œFine.â€

The other men filed out past Mittermeyer, professionalism stopping them from giving him any confused glances on their way out. Mittermeyer shut the cabin door behind himself, and then it was just him and Reuenthal, alone in the dim room, facing each other like they were on a stage.

â€œDo you want something to drink?â€ Reuenthal asked.

â€œNo.â€

Reuenthal fixed him a drink anyway. From a cardboard box sitting at the foot of the rickety but neatly made twin bunk bed against the back wall of the cabin, he pulled an unopened bottle of scotch, and poured it into two of the aluminum drinking cups that sat on the shelf above the fireplace. He took his own, but simply set the other on the table for Mittermeyer, in case he wanted it.Â 

â€œA gift from Admiral Merkatzâ€” from Neue Sanssouciâ€™s stores, apparently. As thanks for capturing Litchtenlade.â€ There was an open bitterness in his voice, one that Mittermeyer didnâ€™t understand, and didnâ€™t have the ability to think clearly about.

â€œYou know what happened to Evangeline?â€

â€œI do,â€ Reuenthal said. He turned away from Mittermeyer. â€œDid you come to demand I apologize?â€

â€œThereâ€™s no one left worth apologizing to.â€

â€œNot you, then.â€

â€œHildegarde von Mariendorf told me not to blame you.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know why she insists on involving herself. I told her to stay out of it.â€

â€œShe said you didnâ€™t want to be the one to break the news to me.â€

â€œThen sheâ€™s a liar. I would have told you, if I had known you were coming.â€

â€œYou didnâ€™t know?â€

Reuenthal walked over to one of the wax-papered windows, one where the corner of the covering was peeling up. He lifted it with his fingernail and looked out at the tiny sliver of the clear world it exposed. â€œI knew you were in orbit. The only way I can send messages is by courierâ€” I donâ€™t have any high powered radio here. Mariendorf brought you?â€

He must have seen her outside.

â€œYes.â€

â€œIâ€™m surprised she didnâ€™t bring you to the Kummel house. Leighâ€™s wifeâ€”â€

He was â€œLeighâ€ when Reuenthal was angry. â€œAnd what would I have to say to her?â€

â€œShe was one of the last people to see her, Iâ€™m told. She might know where she went, or if sheâ€™ll come back.â€

â€œI know the first and can guess at the second. No one runs away to Phezzan if theyâ€™re intending to come back.â€

Reuenthal turned back around towards Mittermeyer. â€œAnd what do you want me to say to you? That Iâ€™m glad sheâ€™s gone?â€

Unlike everyone else on Odin, Mittermeyer noticed that Reuenthal was both clean and clean-shaven, remaining fastidious despite the lack of running water and easy availability of soap. His chin was lifted, and his eyes were narrowed.

â€œI donâ€™t want you to say anything,â€ Mittermeyer said.

â€œThen why did you come here?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know.â€ He did know. For the first time, he thought he understood Reuenthal completely, understanding things that had once been opaque to himâ€” the way that he had sometimes antagonized Mittermeyer in the hope that Mittermeyer would lash out at him, provide him some kind of catharsis that life had denied. Mittermeyer felt it tooâ€” Evangelineâ€™s departure was not so much a punishment as it was a consequence. He realized it was a stupid thing to want, and it was a stupider thing to want from Reuenthal. There might have been something he could say to goad him, if he searched for it, but the thought of doing so sickened himâ€” he didnâ€™t deserve anything he had to seek out.

Reuenthal was silent. He left the window, went back to the table, smoothed his hand out across the paper map, the top layer of protective tissue crinkling audibly under his touch. In a single, sharp movement, he pulled the tissue paper up and crumpled it into a ball, which he then didnâ€™t seem to know what to do with. Mittermeyer took a step forward, and tried to take it from his hand, but Reuenthal whirled on his heel and stepped away. â€œDonâ€™t.â€

â€œDonâ€™t what?â€

He dropped the paper in the overfull garbage can that sat against the cabin door.

â€œYouâ€™re still wearing your wedding ring,â€ Reuenthal pointed out.

â€œAnd am I supposed to take it off?â€

â€œYou could.â€

â€œWould that make you happy?â€ He pulled the ring on his finger, tried to pry it off, but the change in atmosphere and minute shifting of gravity between space travel and being on a planet always left his fingers slightly swollen for a few days of readjustment, and he couldnâ€™t get it to slip cleanly from his finger, despite how much he pulled. Reuenthal watched him struggle, saying nothing.

â€œLeave it, then.â€

â€œYou wonâ€™t tell me to cut it off?â€ Reuenthalâ€™s knife, along with his sidearm, was resting on the bedside table of the lower bunk. Mittermeyer looked at them, and Reuenthal followed his gaze.

â€œI should, shouldnâ€™t I?â€ Reuenthal said. But he didnâ€™t.

He didnâ€™t know what he would do with the ring if he got it off. â€œIâ€™m still married in the eyes of the law, canâ€™t get divorced without her signature or her death certificate. It lets everyone know, when they ask about my wifeâ€” itâ€™s a brand.â€ He held up his hand.

â€œA brand,â€ Reuenthal repeated. He laughed darkly, then turned away. â€œWe have something in common, then.â€

â€œReuenthalâ€”â€

â€œCome back when youâ€™ve figured out what you want from me,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t have the patience to pry it out of you. It would have been better off for both of us if I never had.â€

Â 

Â 

He found Hilde sitting on the shore of the lake, picking up pebbles from the ground beside her and tossing them into the water. The sun was down low in the sky, the horizon stained red, and it made the ripples on the lake look like blood.

â€œIâ€™m ready to go.â€Â 

â€œI can take you back to your ship,â€ Hilde said. She didnâ€™t ask how his conversation with Reuenthal had gone.Â 

â€œIâ€™d rather see if my home is still standing,â€ Mittermeyer said.

Hilde didnâ€™t have the authority to contradict him, though he could see in her shadowed face she was coming up with reasons to: there was no running water or electricity; his ship would be a more comfortable place to spend the night. But she didnâ€™t say any of that. â€œAlright. Let me get you some water for the night, at least.â€

She made him wait while she gathered some gallon jugs and ration packs and a battered looking lantern with a fresh battery from Reuenthalâ€™s camp stores, and then she joined him to drive back to his house, going with him all the way with the excuse that he would need her help navigating the city. Although this turned out to be true, he knew he was under observationâ€” suicide watch, maybe. But he felt completely dull and numb, and could only distantly wonder why she had come to the conclusion that he needed it, and if she had appointed herself to the duty or if someone had ordered it. He bet Yangâ€™s wife told her to.

Miraculously, his apartment building was still standing, and the windows of his upper floor suite all remained shut and unbroken. The door was even still locked. Despite his assurances to Hilde that he was perfectly capable of carrying some water jugs, she insisted on helping him bring them up the stairs to his apartment, and he didnâ€™t bother to argue against her misplaced sense of chivalry.

It was dark inside, even with his lantern turned on, and freezing cold. It smelled like still water that had been left too longâ€” probably a scent oozing up from the empty drains. All the plants his wife had tended so carefully in their pots and macrame hangars were dead. Their leaves had fallen off and settled on the floor beneath the windows.Â 

But the furniture was just where he had left it, and there was the photo of their wedding on the wall. He shined his light over it, forgetting for just a second that Hilde stood awkwardly in the doorway behind him.

â€œDo you need a ride to wherever youâ€™re staying?â€

â€œNo, sir,â€ she said.

He should have insisted, driven her so that she wouldnâ€™t have to walk through the ruined city at night, but she must have been used to it. â€œGoodnight, then.â€

She saluted and slipped out, shutting the door behind herself. When her footsteps had fully receded down the stairs, Mittermeyer let himself wander through the apartment.Â 

In the kitchen, he picked up the single dirty glass that had been left on the otherwise clean counter, with a smear of chapstick where she must last have drank. He pressed the cup to his lips for a second, and then, with a cry and a jerk of his arm that he didnâ€™t feel in control of, threw the glass to shatter on the floor.

He stared at the shards sparkling on the linoleum in the lamplight, and then sank down against the counter, whatever strength had been holding him up all day gone, fell to the ground, curled his arms around his knees, and wept.

Chapter End Notes

This chapter is a structural inverse of Eva's earlier chapter, "Leaving the City". Both chapters are titled after Joanna Newsom songs from the same album (this one: "The Things I Say"), and Mittermeyer speaks to Reuenthal and then returns to the ruined city and the apartment that Eva left. He's escorted by Hilde rather than Kircheis, of course-- another structural inverse. If you read the two chapters side by side, there's a bunch of things that tie them directly together. But ignore me this is just me playing around with structure like it's a toy ğŸ˜…

Part of the Reumitt convo will have relevance to Yang in upcoming chapters. Place your bets on what that is now lol.

I do worry a little that the Reumitt convo was a bit short-- there were many, many things that did not get discussed. But this conversation was never one in which anything was going to get resolved, so maybe that's for the best.

Speaking of Yang-- thank god we're going back to Yang-land lol. Next chapter belongs to him. Hopefully it will be done soon. I really want to finish this book before the end of the year and I have a tonnnn of stuff I need to get done.

Anyway please leave a comment/let me know what you think/etc. We're coming very very close to the end of the story, so :]

thank you so much as always to em for the beta read!

uh you can find me in the usual places but i'm posting this from work so i'm too lazy to fish around and find the links. just go back to last chapter to grab the discord invite lmao. uhh logh watchparty saturdays at 5 eastern / thursdays 7 eastern rerun. join us.

Those Who Put Their Faith In Fire

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

April 489 I.C., Iserlohn Fortress

The official report from Odin was to be received by Braunschweig in one of the wardrooms off of Iserlohnâ€™s control room. Yang stumbled into the room first, uncharacteristic for him. He had gotten out of bed earlyâ€” also uncharacteristicâ€” but he had gotten up out of frustration. He had laid in bed for hours, completely unable to sleep, and when the appointed morning meeting crept closer, he gave up and hauled himself out of bed like a lurching puppet.Â 

It wasnâ€™t that sleep troubles were unusual for him, but lately they had been getting so dire that he could only sleep half a night out of every two. He tried using a tank bed to solve his problem in the days immediately following Mittermeyerâ€™s departure from Iserlohn, but spent the entire time until the timer ran out trapped in a nightmare so vivid and horrific that he woke up with a bloody nose and popped blood vessels in his eyes from the stress of the dream he physically couldnâ€™t escape. He considered himself lucky that he didnâ€™t bite through his own tongue. He didnâ€™t mention this to anyone, even when Vering asked about what happened to his eyes. Tank beds werenâ€™t supposed to let the sleeper dream; Yang thought there must be something wrong with him.

But it meant that it was a problem without a solution. The only thing that stopped him asking for a sleep aid, or drinking himself to sleep, was that supplies were short, and he felt like he would be taking it away from some grievously wounded who needed it more.

The last good night of sleep he had was weeks ago, the night before Mittermeyer returned to Odin. It hadnâ€™t even been in bed: Yang had fallen asleep on the couch, his hand tangled in Mittermeyerâ€™s hair. But he had slept that night for some eight or nine hours, and that rest had lasted him two days.

Yangâ€™s walk through Iserlohn to get to the bridge felt like an extension of his nightmares, or the nightmares felt like an extension of being awakeâ€” neither of which were restful or comforting sensations.

Iserlohn felt like a patchwork now, more than anything else. There were places completely untouched by the fighting to claim the fortressâ€” most of the meeting rooms and dormitories were like thatâ€” and there were places that were completely destroyed, like the gaping hole where the Thor Hammer had once been, or the agricultural floors where long rows of cornstalks now stood upright like charred bones. The strange, gravity-less atmosphere that the fire had burned in had meant that the plants hadnâ€™t collapsed under their own weight as they burned, and instead stayed standing as they turned into charcoal. Yang had walked through the farms once, though just once, and had run his hand through the cornâ€™s remains. It made a strange, hollow, tinkling, glass-like sound as he touched itâ€” fragile pieces snapping off and falling to the floorâ€” and his hands were stained with black soot that he found difficult to get off.Â 

The formerly lush pleasure gardens were also burned, but this left them looking like a barren moonscape, with the falseness of the fortressâ€™s architecture revealed beneath what had once been grass and trees. The sky display overhead was cracked and broken and stained with ash, and the few pieces that still lit up fritzed with digital noise, pure sparks of cyan and magenta lashing like lightning above. Yang had to carry a flashlight when he walked through there, but he avoided the place after his initial survey of the damage.

But most areas of Iserlohn were like the hallways, where fighting had left blastmarks on the ceiling, or doors torn from their hinges, or axe scratches gouged across the walls. Most of the debris, at least in the areas that Yang walked through, had been cleared away, but the marks remained.

And the air, everywhere, despite the fastidious filter-scrubbing, still smelled faintly of smoke and rotting flesh. It was a scent that Yang couldnâ€™t get used toâ€” it was always too multidimensional to let his nose become oversaturated with it and render it invisible to his senses. He would catch it just as he had a bite of food in his mouth, and it would make him suddenly so ill that heâ€™d have to run to the toilet. Or when he was laying in bed, heâ€™d start to smell the blood, and in the darkness of his bedroom heâ€™d become overwhelmed with the sensation that there was a corpse in bed next to him.

He kept holding out hope that he would get used to it, or that it would go away as repair work to Iserlohn got underway, but all of that seemed to be a long time in coming. He was doing his best to cope with it, though he often wondered if it wasnâ€™t just his exhausted mind playing tricks on him. Maybe there was no scent of rot.

Now, he sat in the wardroom, slumped over the shiny wooden table with his head resting on his arms, until the door opened. He straightened to see who it was, then slumped right back down when he saw it was Ansbach.

â€œSleep well, My Lord?â€ Ansbach asked in his usual dry voice. Yang managed a smile at him, which made Ansbach shake his head.

â€œDid you?â€ Yang asked. From what he could tell, Ansbach mostly slept in the tank beds in stretches of a scant hour or two, which meant that he was almost always otherwise awake: a constant presence in Iserlohnâ€™s control center.

Ansbach ignored the question, and went around fiddling with the computers in the room to prepare for the meeting. â€œOur latest patrol came back last night,â€ he said.

They almost didnâ€™t need to have the conversationâ€” both of them knew what Ansbach was referring to: a total lack of Alliance presence in the corridor, and how this felt like a sure prelude to a coming attack. Yang glanced at his watch, realized that everyone else would be arriving in a second, and decided to skip right to what they both wanted to discuss. â€œIs it too late to sue for peace?â€

Ansbach glanced over at him. â€œDonâ€™t ask Braunschweig about it.â€

â€œI would like to prevent an invasionâ€”â€

â€œItâ€™s too late.â€

â€œIt might not be.â€

â€œAre you going to say something?â€

Yang opened his mouth, but before he could say yes or no, Ansbach held up his hand and cut him off.

â€œIt wonâ€™t go over well if you say anything. If you think itâ€™s necessaryâ€” Iâ€™ll do the asking. Though I doubt it will accomplishâ€”â€

The door opened while Ansbach was in mid sentence. â€œAsk what?â€ Duke Braunschweig asked.

â€œIf we can petition Phezzan for a loan to rebuild. Iâ€™m not sure if that would be amenable to Count Vering and his business interests,â€ Ansbach said, smoothly delivering the lie without the slightest hesitation. â€œGood morning, sir.â€

Braunschweig nodded and waved him to sit down.

Everyone else trickled in after a minute, and so Yang was forced to sit up straight and pay attention. It was a small group who gathered to hear the news: Braunschweig, Ansbach, Yang, Hans von Vering, Captain Ferner, and a few others of Braunschweigâ€™s top staff. This was the first time that most of the leadership had gathered in one place since taking Iserlohnâ€” things had been too chaotic for everyone to sit down togetherâ€” and it made Yang strangely aware of how diminished their group had become. Even Baron Flegelâ€™s absence was keenly felt. Yang didnâ€™t miss him, and he had rarely contributed anything of note to their strategy, but his presence had made Braunschweig feel like he was among kin and allies. Without him there to speak up, there seemed to be only Yang, and those associated with him. Braunschweig, looking around the table while waiting for the call to connect, let his gaze linger on every man in turn, looking lastly at Yang, sitting directly across from him at the table.Â 

â€œCount Leigh,â€ Braunschweig said, causing Yang to look up at him with surprise. The use of his court title, rather than his rank, was unusual. â€œNow that weâ€™ve taken the capital, we will have to rearrange our personnel assignments.â€

Yang wasnâ€™t shocked by the pronouncement, but it did seem odd for Braunschweig to say it so directly.

â€œYes, sir,â€ he said. â€œIf you would like my recommendations, I can put a list together.â€

â€œI have some ideas of my own,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œWeâ€™ll need to assign Iserlohn a permanent commander. It seems as though almost all of usâ€”â€ and he glanced around the table again â€œâ€”will be returning to Odin with my daughter.â€

â€œI suggest you leave Commodore Leigh in command of Iserlohn,â€ Ansbach said, which made Braunschweig drum his fingers on the table. Yang carefully avoided looking at himâ€” that would only make things worse. Ansbach speaking up on his behalf, although he had done it many times over the past few months, had suddenly become dangerous. It seemed like only now did Ansbach realize just how dangerous it was, that there was a line that he had suddenly crossedâ€” one that made Braunschweig see him as a person for the first time. Ansbach stared straight ahead of himself.

â€œI have my own ideas,â€ Braunschweig repeated. â€œIâ€™m curious as to why you would suggest that, Ansbach.â€

â€œCommodore Leigh has demonstrated that he understands Iserlohn better than anyone else. He would be the best choice to defend it.â€

â€œHmm,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œDo you want the post, Leigh?â€ This, too, was a dangerous question, and one to which Yang didnâ€™t know the answer. He wanted to be in position to defend the country from invasion, but he wanted, on a gut level, to escape the fortressâ€™s ruin.

â€œIâ€”â€

But before Yang could say anything else, the screen at the front of the room made a chiming sound as the connection went through, and Merkatz appeared, alone on the screen.

Yang was both surprised and disappointed when it was Merkatz who called to report their victory at the capital. Perhaps it wasnâ€™t that strange that Merkatz chose to make the call, since he was in charge of the landing forces, and Baron Flegel was making himself either busy or useful elsewhere, but Yang had expected Mittermeyerâ€” or Reuenthal. Both of them had made explicit promises to call him when possible, and so those promises being broken made him concerned. They had both sent written messages, but those had been sparse on detail. If Yang thought this was only because Reuenthal and Mittermeyer were concerned about their messages being read, Yang would have been less concerned. But if there was one thing that Reuenthal was adept at, it was making himself understood in the barest few words, and none of the messages that Yang received contained any hint of personal feelings, and could have come from anyone.Â 

When the picture resolved, Yang recognized the backdrop: Merkatz was, at least temporarily, occupying Muckenburgerâ€™s former office within the palace. The portrait of Muckenburgerâ€™s father still hanging on the wall behind him made Yang feel very strange.

â€œI hear you have some good news for me,â€ Braunschweig said by way of greeting as Merkatz saluted.

â€œYes, sir,â€ Merkatz said. â€œThe capital has been fully brought under control, as has the space around it. We have confirmed that the Littenheim clan is no more.â€

Braunschweig nodded, and Merkatz began giving a full description of the events in the capital, from everything that had happened since the battle between Braunschweig and Littenheim in the sky, to Reuenthalâ€™s capture of Litchtenlade, to Merkatzâ€™s ground invasion that had finally brought the capital under control. Even though almost all of this information had been communicated to the fortress already, in short snippets of text updates as the ground invasion progressed, hearing it all together, delivered in Merkatzâ€™s serious, even tone had a sway. Everyone in the room listened silently until he had concluded his report.

â€œItâ€™s a pity about Christine,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œAmarie will be unhappy.â€

â€œYes. But she committed suicide during the invasion of the capital, as did Littenheimâ€” there was no way to prevent it.â€

Yang wondered if this is true. He spoke up, â€œWere you able to find out what happened to Sabine?â€

â€œShe was killed in the capital riots before we arrived,â€ Merkatz said. â€œI believe Hildegarde von Mariendorf knows more about the situation in the palace.â€

Yangâ€™s face paled, and he wanted to ask about Martin Bufholtz, but Merkatz would have no idea who that was, and so it would have been pointless.

â€œYouâ€™re certain that you have control of all the forces still in the city?â€ Braunschweig asked.

â€œAll of Littenheimâ€™s forces have surrendered and been put under guard in temporary barracks, and Baron Flegel has taken direct command of the Military Policeâ€™s remaining forces.â€

Braunschweigâ€™s face twitched in momentary concern or displeasure. â€œHas he replaced or vetted all of the officers? I wouldnâ€™t trust them.â€

â€œYes,â€ Merkatz said. â€œRear Admiral Bronner, who I am willing to vouch for, has given him a list of who to keep and who to purge.â€

â€œCan you send me a copy of that list?â€ Yang asked.

Merkatz nodded and gestured offscreen to his aide, Schneider.

â€œBronnerâ€” this is someone you know?â€ Braunschweig asked.

â€œMy former superior,â€ Yang said. â€œI trust him enough.â€

â€œWho does he work for?â€ Braunschweig asked. He was understandably wary of yet another man associated with Yang.

â€œHe was in naval intelligence,â€ Yang said, which didnâ€™t answer Braunschweigâ€™s question in the least, but the talk moved on.

â€œIs the situation on Odin stable enough to bring Elizabeth home?â€ Braunschweig asked. â€œI would like to crown her as quickly as possible.â€

â€œOn Odin, yes,â€ Merkatz said. â€œHowever, the route between Geiersburg and Odin may still be dangerous. The remaining forces in space have not been given an order to surrender. Litchtenlade wants to bargain with you before he makes an official acceptance of Elizabeth.â€

Braunschweig laughed. â€œBargain for what?â€

â€œHis life, I assume,â€ Merkatz said. â€œI can arrange for you to speak with him.â€

Braunschweig waved his hand. â€œFind out what he wants. I really have no desire to entertain him.â€

â€œHow are things on Odinâ€” for the civilian population, I mean?â€ Yang asked. Merkatz had covered the military situation in more than sufficient detail, but he had glossed over conditions on the ground for everyone else.

Merkatz was good at keeping his expression neutral. â€œConditions are improving. We have reestablished power to some of the core areas. The major difficulty is with foodâ€” we have been supplying both our own soldiers and the civilian population in the city from our stores, but without immediate resupply, we will need to begin tighter rationing, and risk further unrest.â€

â€œThereâ€™s nothing you can procure on the planet?â€ Braunschweig asked. â€œWhat about the southern farmlands? I wasnâ€™t aware that those were impacted.â€

â€œThe issue is not with the farmlands themselves,â€ Merkatz said. â€œThey may have produced a full harvest last season, but the issue became one of logistics: transportation of produce became dangerous, processing plants closed due to supply chain issues from the planet being cut off from the rest of the Empire.â€

â€œFood rotted in the fields,â€ Yang murmured.

â€œThe people in the farmlands were able to make good use of it,â€ Merkatz said. â€œWeâ€™re lucky for thatâ€” the starvation problem is confined to the north.â€

â€œHave they planted for next year?â€ Yang asked.

â€œProbably a limited amount,â€ Merkatz said. â€œIf they didnâ€™t have seeds and fertilizer on handâ€” usually fertilizer is an importâ€” I doubt itâ€™s going to be a full-scale harvest. This problem is going to persist at least through next year.â€

Yang looked at Ansbach. â€œWeâ€™ll need to start direct resupply from our alliesâ€™ territories to Odin. Can we dispatch transports toâ€”â€

â€œWesterland has its own processing facilities,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œI usually sell to Phezzan, but whatever they have on hand we can send to Odin. Will that be enough?â€

â€œIt will be a good first step,â€ Ansbach said.

â€œThe issue is with the safety of the transports,â€ Merkatz said. â€œIf the remaining forces do not surrenderâ€”â€

Braunschweig scowled. â€œFine. Get Litchtenlade on the ansible. I donâ€™t care what he asks forâ€” agree to it.â€

â€œWe should also reach out to Phezzan,â€ Hans von Vering said from the rear end of the table, unintentionally echoing Ansbachâ€™s earlier lie. â€œThey would likely be willing to give us a favorable loan of materialâ€” Iâ€™m sure that their economy has been suffering just as much as ours has. Theyâ€™ll be very interested in us getting back on our feet.â€

Yang glanced at Ansbach again, who just said, â€œThe embassy on Phezzan is loyal to Litchtenlade. We need them to agree to even speak with us before we can start reestablishing a relationship with Phezzan.â€

Yang slumped back in his seat. â€œLetâ€™s focus on moving supplies from our allied territories for now. Do we have enough ships to spare to provide convoys for transports?â€ He glanced over at Ferner, who was in charge of their small fleet brought from Cahokia.

â€œYes,â€ Ferner said. â€œThe bulk of the Iserlohn fleet is gone, but we did capture enough ships, including those that never launched from Iserlohn, that we can send out destroyers to escort transports while maintaining a sufficient force here. The issue is less ships and more crewsâ€” we have a personnel shortage.â€

The issue kept coming back to the surrender of the remaining Imperial forces. It felt like it should have been a foregone conclusionâ€” with both other alternatives for the throne deadâ€” but Braunschweigâ€™s capture of Iserlohn, and the rumor that he had killed Prince Ludwig before that, had made too many people unwilling to trust him. Elizabeth had less baggage as a leader, but she was too young, and no one could see her as anything other than her fatherâ€™s puppet.

â€œHave you been able to contact Count Mariendorf?â€ Yang asked.

â€œNo,â€ Merkatz said. â€œI will try again to, but I donâ€™t know where he was going, and as a single ship, his best chance at safety is to maintain complete communications silence.â€

Yang nodded. â€œIf we can get in contact with him, heâ€™ll be very useful in getting supplies to Odin. For now, anything that was going to our forces at Geiersburg can be redirected.â€

â€œGeiersburgâ€”â€ Braunschweig said. â€œYou are much closer to Geiersburg than we are. Can you dispatch an escort to bring Elizabeth back to Odin?â€

Merkatz nodded. â€œWe can arrange that.â€

â€œGood. Good,â€ Braunschweig said.

The conversation moved on to details about the rebuilding of Odin and Iserlohn, . Yang paid attention, but half of his mind was elsewhere. What he wanted to think about was the Alliance invasion that he knew was coming. It was a matter of when, not if, and a matter of weeks or days, not months. The Alliance would lose their chance to strike if they didnâ€™t move soon, and they would all be in trouble if the forces at Iserlohn were headed by an ineffective commander.

But although he wanted to turn that problem over and over in his head, his thoughts instead drifted to the people on Odin: Reuenthal and Mittermeyer, Hilde and Kircheis, Magdalenaâ€” and so many others.Â 

All of them were aliveâ€” that much he knewâ€” unless he was being lied to in the official reports. But a tightly-worded official communique was no substitute for seeing them all in person, and he desperately wanted to do so, though he had no way to. He was almost grateful for Braunschweigâ€™s not-so-veiled threat to reassign him off Iserlohn. He thought Yang was a liability in this position, and while Yang thought that he could do most good in the fortress, he yearned to go home to Odin.

Even now, when he caught himself thinking of it as home, he managed to startle himself. But it was unambiguously true.

Â 

Â 

It was strange, the way that Yangâ€™s circle of allies had shifted. He had tried not to take much note of the change, but as Braunschweig realized that it was a problem, Yang was forced to pay real attention to its consequences. He wondered if it was Flegelâ€™s faultâ€” if he had told Braunschweig about the moment where Ansbach had stepped in to protect Yang from Muckenburgerâ€™s gun. But it could have been Braunschweigâ€™s own paranoia finding an enemy within his own camp, now that they had won the civil war. He supposed it didnâ€™t really matter what the proximate cause was: the outcome was that Braunshweig was isolating himself, which was dangerous for everyone.Â 

Braunschweig had taken Ansbach out of his confidences. Ansbach now was summoned less often. Braunschweig ate his dinners without him, and Ansbach didnâ€™t spend his days at Braunschweigâ€™s shoulder. The upshot of this was that Ansbach spent the evening with Yang. He hoped Braunschweig didnâ€™t notice this, since it would reinforce the idea that Yang was the primary recipient of Ansbachâ€™s loyalty.

They were in one of Iserlohnâ€™s private officersâ€™ lounges together. Ansbach had aÂ  preliminary report about the plan for rebuilding the Thor Hammer balanced on his lap. If Yang had been handed that kind of thing, he would have found Mittermeyer to burden with it. But Ansbach read over the thick binder with a red pen in his hand, and didnâ€™t glance up from it except to reach for the tea on the table in front of his armchair. Yang sprawled on the leather couch across from him, his arm draped over his face.

â€œIf youâ€™re just going to lay there, you should go to bed, My Lord,â€ Ansbach said.

â€œIâ€™m thinking,â€ Yang said.

â€œAbout?â€

â€œPhezzan.â€

â€œWhat about it?â€

â€œI sent a message to Merkatz,â€ Yang said. â€œI asked him to send as large of a force as he could to Geiersburg. Thinking about if heâ€™ll follow through on that. I think he willâ€” but if he doesnâ€™tâ€”.â€

Ansbach pursed his lips. â€œSomeone might accuse you of having designs on the Kaiserinâ€™s life.â€

â€œGeiersburg is much closer to Phezzan than we are,â€ Yang said. â€œI donâ€™t want any Alliance forces reaching the capital.â€

â€œSomeone might accuse you of leaving Odin under-defended.â€

â€œI know,â€ Yang said, his voice thick with exhaustion. â€œIâ€™ve been on a single-man, fourteen-year campaign to destroy this country from the inside. Iâ€™m the most effective spy the Alliance has ever had. Too bad theyâ€™re not paying me.â€

â€œYouâ€™re lucky that youâ€™re sure their plans are set to invade through Phezzan,â€ he said. â€œIf they came through Iserlohn, youâ€™d be a dead man. My Lord.â€ He tacked the title on.

Yang shook his head in the crook of his elbow, still draped across his face. â€œIâ€™ve been living on borrowed time for a long time.â€

His left hand idly ran over his thigh, where the old scar was perceptible through the fabric of his uniform pants. Ansbach watched the movement, then picked up his teacup and went back to reading.

â€œYou need to get back into the dukeâ€™s good graces,â€ Yang said after a few minutes of silence.

â€œIf heâ€™s displeased with me, heâ€™ll let me know,â€ Ansbach said. â€œHeâ€™s a straightforward man.â€

â€œNo,â€ Yang said. â€œYou need to go back to being invisible.â€

Ansbach knew what he meant. â€œI havenâ€™t given him any reason to doubt me.â€

â€œParanoia doesnâ€™t need a reason.â€

â€œThen thereâ€™s nothing more I can do to prove my loyalty to him.â€

â€œStop trying to help me,â€ Yang said. â€œI can make my own suggestions to the duke, and I donâ€™t need you to be caught up in whatever fall I take.â€

â€œAre you planning to take one, My Lord?â€

â€œPride goeth before the fall,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t think Iâ€™m proud.â€

After a moment, Ansbach asked, â€œHas it ever saved anyone to not be?â€

â€œNo,â€ Yang said. He smiled, if grimly, his mouth the only part of his face not covered by his flung arm. â€œMaybe.â€

Ansbach shook his head, and went back to his reading. Eventually, in the silence, Yang fell asleep.

When he woke, six dreamless hours later, it was to Ansbach shaking him awake on the couch. His legs were tangled in unfamiliar fabric, and he was disoriented for a moment. But it was harmlessâ€” at some point during the night, Ansbach had draped a blanket over him.

â€œPhezzan is being invaded,â€ he said, as soon as Yang opened his eyes.

Â 

Â 

By the time that Yang and Ansbach made it to Iserlohnâ€™s bridge, it was almost too late for them to provide any strategic input. Braunschweig had already started ordering ships to prepare for launchâ€” even before they made it into the command center, they could hear him yelling through the open doors.Â 

Hans von Vering was standing outside the command center doors, and Ansbach gave him a curt nod as he passed. This was genuinely more warmth than Ansbach had ever given the young man, so Yang hung back for a second to let Ansbach go in. It served a dual purpose of giving Ansbach a visual separation from Yang in Braunschweigâ€™s eyes, and letting Yang ask Vering what was going on.

Vering, too, had dark circles under his eyesâ€” lately, even his youthful face had become sallow with exhaustion. Yang put his hand on Veringâ€™s shoulder without saying anything for a second, composing his own thoughts.

â€œWe got the news from Phezzanâ€™s embassy,â€ Vering said. â€œIt was addressed to you. Do you know why?â€

Yang winced. â€œMy spy,â€ he said. â€œHe must be breaking their official policy against not contacting us to get me the message. But I assume that didnâ€™t do me any favors in there.â€

Vering shook his head.

â€œWellâ€” itâ€™s the least of our problems.â€ Yang glanced over towards the still-open bridge door. â€œAnsbach knows what mood heâ€™s walking into? I assume you warned him.â€

â€œI called you, but he was the one who answered your phone.â€Â 

Yang wondered how that had happened. He pictured Ansbach picking up the phone he had placed on the coffee table, and pressing his unconscious thumb to the fingerprint reader to open it and answer the call. â€œI thought the duke would,â€ Vering said. When Yang had only a shrug and a knowing look as a response, Vering looked around to make sure they werenâ€™t being watched, then said, â€œI didnâ€™t think he was in trouble withâ€”â€

There was nervousness creeping into Veringâ€™s voice, and Yang patted his shoulder again. â€œDonâ€™t worry about it,â€ Yang said. â€œIf thereâ€™s one thing Ansbach is good at, itâ€™s solving the dukeâ€™s problems for him.â€

But Vering frowned. â€œI donâ€™t want to be in trouble because of you.â€

It was a very funny and childish way of putting it, and it made Yang laugh, despite the situation. â€œOh, you wonâ€™t be.â€ He tilted his head at Vering, studying him for a second. â€œI thinkâ€”â€

â€œWhat?â€

â€œThe duke is just having a moment where he sees people as they really are,â€ he said. â€œHeâ€™s known Ansbach since he was a kid, but I donâ€™t think heâ€™s ever once looked at him.â€

Vering didnâ€™t seem to understand what Yang was getting at.

â€œI think itâ€™s for the best,â€ Yang said. â€œHeâ€™ll realize soon enough that what he seesâ€” from me at leastâ€” is what he gets.â€

â€œAnd what does that have to do with me?â€

â€œThe duke seeing you as who you areâ€” or who he might think you areâ€” would be dangerous to you for other reasons,â€ Yang said. â€œBut I donâ€™t think heâ€™s going to do that, if heâ€™s busy worrying about me.â€

â€œWhat do you mean?â€ Vering asked, voice rising with alarm.

â€œYouâ€™re going to be the king-consort,â€ Yang pointed out. â€œHeâ€™ll be suspicious of you trying to take advantage of that position, not because of any association you have with me.â€Â 

â€œHe picked me because Iâ€™m weak.â€ There was a resentful note in his voice.

â€œAnd because your father is powerful,â€ Yang said. Vering just scowled. â€œBut if youâ€™re worriedâ€” stay away from me.â€

Yang turned away from Vering and headed inside. He didnâ€™t like warning Ansbach and Vering away from him. In a way, it had been easier to be friendless when they had all been his enemies (or only reluctant allies). Steeling himself to be alone again was hard to contemplateâ€” but getting them in trouble with his presence would be worse.

Inside Iserlohnâ€™s control center, Braunschweig leaned on the foremost computer console on the mezzanine level, looking out over the huge screen at the fore end of the room, which was displaying a map of the galaxy, with Iserlohn, Geiersburg, and Odin highlighted, along with all the remaining imperial forces, and the projected locations of the Alliance forces. Ansbach was down on the lower level, speaking to the hastily summoned group captains of their fleet, each one in charge of a sub unit of a hundred ships. Not all of them had arrived, but all who were there gave his status report to Ansbach as he tried to determine how quickly the fleet could launch.

Yang went to the back of the room and leaned on the wall, looking over the map, though he already had internalized everything that it said. The fleet Merkatz had dispatched from Odin was already en route to Geiersburg, and would arrive there within the week. Even if the Alliance forces didnâ€™t stop or slow down in the Phezzan corridor at all, their fleet would arrive at Geiersburg first.

But that didnâ€™t mean they would fight at Geiersburg. The only reason that they would go there, heading for the well-defended and dangerous fortress, rather than charging directly for Odin, was if they knew that Elizabeth was there, and they decided that capturing her was vital to their strategy. They probably did know that Elizabeth was at Geiersburgâ€” after all, Muller in the Imperial embassy on Phezzan knew that much, and the news probably would spread from there. But that didnâ€™t mean they would go there first.

Yang closed his eyes. The Alliance had wanted Erwin Josefâ€” they had his mother and were planning to use her as a puppet regent, as far as he could tell. But that plan was dead because Erwin Josef was dead, according to Reuenthalâ€™s reports. As was Sabine, according to Merkatz. Even among Kaiser Friedrichâ€™s children, only Amarie survived. The question was, would the Alliance decide capturing a monarch and using her as a puppet be better for their strategy, or would simply occupying the planet be enough? If he were the leader of the Alliance, he would try to take Odin, as long as he was confident that he could maintain his supply lines through space. Though the danger of avoiding the Geiersburg fleet also meant that any Alliance fleet that headed to Odin could be cornered and isolated there. He rolled the question over and over in his mind, almost to the exclusion of everything else. Ansbachâ€™s voice calling out unit numbers down below didnâ€™t really register for him.

Yang wanted to ask Mullerâ€” or even Bronner. Both of them kept a much closer watch on the Alliance high command than Yang did, and he was regretting the lack of attention he had paid to them over the past few years, after focusing all his energy and attention on internal Imperial politics.

But none of that was something that he could alter now. He cracked open his eyes, and saw Braunschweig moving pieces around the display overhead, taking their fleet and pushing it through the Imperial side of the corridor, to go join their forces at the exit of the Phezzan corridor.

Even though the display was high overhead, which meant that everyone could see it, no one had yet stopped Braunschweig from making the strategic blunder that he was walking into. Ansbach glanced up at the display, had no visible reaction, and then turned back to the group captains. He must have known what mistake Braunschweig was making as well as Yang didâ€” but maybe it was time for Yang to intervene without Ansbach stepping in to help him.Â 

He walked over to Braunschweig. â€œSir,â€ he said, without any preamble whatsoever, â€œWe should go through the rebel side of the galaxy, rather than our own.â€

Braunschweig turned towards Yang sharply. â€œI donâ€™t recall asking for your advice.â€

Yang tilted his head, and tried to keep his voice as calm and even as possible, despite the redness of Braunschweigâ€™s face. Some of his usually neat blonde hair was falling out of its queue and sticking to his forehead in sweaty curls. â€œIâ€™m on your payroll for the purposes of giving you advice, sir.â€

â€œIf we go through the rebel side of the galaxy, weâ€™ll be opening ourselves up to attack from every direction.â€

Yang turned away from Braunschweig and looked at the huge map. â€œThe way I see it, sirâ€”â€

â€œI donâ€™t care about the way you see it.â€

Yang just kept talking. â€œThe rebel fleet is probably committing almost everything that they have to this invasionâ€” maybe theyâ€™ve left a small force to guard Heinessen, and maybe theyâ€™ve left a small force at the exit of the Iserlohn corridor, but I bet that the vast majority of their ships are at Phezzan right now. We have seen so few of their patrols in the corridor that weâ€™ve been speculating for a long time that they are gathering their forces and preparing elsewhere, and now we know where that elsewhere is. If we charge through their side of space, we wonâ€™t meet much opposition until we reach Phezzan.â€

â€œAnd why would we do that, rather than meeting up with our allies?â€

â€œBecause their weakness is their supply line,â€ Yang said. â€œTheyâ€™re going to be stretched extremely thin, especially as they make their way towards Odin. Because of our countryâ€™s own supply problem from the civil war, they wonâ€™t be able to procure food and other supplies en route, even if they capture planets and make bases out of them. They need to rely on whatâ€™s coming in through Phezzan. If we can cut that off, or at least threaten it, theyâ€™ll be forced to retreat.â€

â€œWe donâ€™t have the forces for that, and neither does Merkatzâ€™s fleet,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œWe need to meet up with our allies and form a united front.â€

Yang pointed up at the scattered Imperial fleets. â€œWeâ€™re being invaded,â€ he said. â€œAnd of the three claimants to the throne, only Elizabeth remains. I thinkâ€” this will cement her place as ruler, especially if Litchtenlade bows to Elizabeth and tells the other fleets to cooperate. The fleet Merkatz is sending to Geiersburg can be reinforced by the former Iserlohn stationed fleetâ€” we know itâ€™s somewhere near there, even if we havenâ€™t been able to contact it.â€

Braunschweig was silent, so Yang just continued. He knew he was rambling, but he had to speak his mind.

â€œWhatever rear guard is being left at Phezzan, itâ€™ll be smaller than the main rebel force, so we should be able to put pressure there.â€

â€œWeâ€™d be able to do that just as well, and with support from our allies, if we went through our side.â€

Yang shook his head. â€œIf we go that way, weâ€™re meeting them head on,â€ he said. â€œAnd even if our forces end up equally matched, if we meet up with the forces at Geiersburg, and the fleet from Iserlohn, that will beâ€”â€ Bloodshed of a scale greater than any battle of the civil war. He could hear Muckenburgerâ€™s warning about what the destruction of Iserlohnâ€™s Thor Hammer would cost ringing through his head.Â 

â€œIt would be a battle,â€ Braunschweig said. â€œIâ€™m prepared to fight it.â€

â€œWeâ€™d be using shipsâ€” livesâ€” to build that wall,â€ Yang said finally. â€œWe could do it at a much lesser cost, by putting pressure in the right place.â€

Yang was right, and Braunschweig knew it, but he was inclined to ignore the advice because it was given by Yang.

â€œAnd youâ€™ll stay here on Iserlohn?â€ Braunschweig asked, curling his lip. He distrusted Yangâ€” thought he would turn against him and let the Alliance through, or attack him from behind. It was paranoia, and nothing but paranoia.

â€œNo, sir,â€ Yang said. â€œIâ€™ll come with you to the front.â€

Braunschweig stared at him. â€œAnd who will you suggest stays at Iserlohn? Ansbach?â€

Yang shook his head and held out his hands. â€œYou said that you had your own ideas, sir.â€

It was Vering who came to Yangâ€™s rescue, though it wasnâ€™t clear if he was doing it intentionally, or if he was just acting on his own confused instincts. He came up to Braunschweig.

â€œLet me have command of Iserlohn,â€ Vering said. â€œI can do it.â€

Braunschweig looked at him with undisguised distaste. â€œYouâ€™re a lieutenant commander.â€

â€œPromote me, then,â€ Vering said. That false confidence that he was so known for was thick in his voice, and it made Braunschweig sneer.

â€œYou havenâ€™t done anything that would make me consider that. And why do you want to stay on Iserlohn?â€ Braunschweig asked. â€œThere wonâ€™t be any opportunities for proving yourself if youâ€™re not at the front.â€ And when Veringâ€™s face twitched with flustered shame, Braunschweig said, â€œOf course,â€ and smiled grimly at Veringâ€™s expense.

â€œYou donâ€™t have anyone else to put in charge of it,â€ Vering said. â€œI can do a good job.â€

This gave Yang the opportunity to slip away, Braunschweig continuing to argue with Vering. As Yang walked away, he glanced behind himself, and Vering met his eyes, and that told him all that he needed to know.

Â 

Â 

Despite Braunschweig not wanting to take Yangâ€™s advice, he did eventually agree. They stopped receiving any further updates from the embassy on Phezzan, indicating that the embassy had fallen very quickly, and that the bulk of the Alliance forces would be steaming through the corridor. The Alliance fleet would be deep in Imperial territory long before Braunschweig could get close enough to meet them head on. So it forced his hand, and their fleet headed through the Alliance side. Vering and Ferner stayed on Iserlohn, as they had requested, splitting the small group that had started the civil war together even further. Ansbach and Yang accompanied Braunschweig through the corridor, both on board the Berlin .

There was no point in trying to be stealthy. They made it to the end of the corridor, steaming past Cahokia, in just a few days. At the corridorâ€™s exit, they met their first real resistance, getting an alert that there were obstacles in their path. When they dropped down to subluminal speeds, they were all relieved to find that it was ships, rather than a minefield, waiting for them.Â 

Braunschweigâ€™s fleet was small, but the nominal Alliance fleet that had been left at the exit of the corridor was even smaller. It seemed to be made up of just a handful of their scattered patrol fleets which stuck together, recognizable by their makeup of mainly being cruisers, rather than destroyers, and the way that most of the ships were known in Iserlohnâ€™s databases of enemy vessels.

All of this was very good for Yang. Despite Braunschweigâ€™s distrust of him, which had only been growing more and more powerful as time went on, Braunschweig did call Ansbach into his office to ask for his strategic advice about the enemy fleet looming in front of them. Yang gave his ideas to Ansbach, who delivered them to Braunschweig as though the ideas had formed in the ether, and didnâ€™t belong to either him or Yang. The important thing was that they shouldnâ€™t get bogged down in fighting this detachment, and instead should do their best to break through and keep moving on towards Phezzan, while, if possible, disguising their destination. The ideal thing to do would be to make it look like they were headed for Heinessen or another one of the Allianceâ€™s planets, like they wanted to provoke a response from the larger Alliance fleet and make them retreat through Phezzan. Perhaps this would have even been a good strategy to pursue, but when Yang looked at the name of the closest inhabited planets that they could try to attackâ€” El Facil among themâ€” a shiver ran down his spine, and he told Ansbach to suggest they just charge through in the direction of Heinessen, and then alter their course back towards Phezzan when they were out of detection range.

So, they met the small Alliance fleet at the exit of the corridor head on, Braunschweig forming his ships into a spindle to break directly through their center, like a ram. Another indication that the Alliance fleet was a hodgepodge was how they almost immediately scattered under this direct assault. Braunschweigâ€™s fleet had been operating together as a cohesive unit for the entire length of the civil war, and had been under the tutelage of the exacting Merkatz for almost that entire time. Unlike the Alliance fleet, they moved as one body, not allowing a single opening in their line as they moved cleanly between formations.Â 

When Braunschweigâ€” competent enough at moment to moment fleet movements that Yang felt neither the inclination nor desire to interveneâ€” ordered them to concentrate fire directly on the center point of the Allianceâ€™s formation, it broke apart into several distinct and uncoordinated units, each one firing at arbitrary sections of Braunschweigâ€™s fleet, or trying to turn to get out of the way. It was a chaotic scene.

The battle was over almost as quickly as it began. Although Braunschweig, standing from his command chair at the helm of the Berlin clenched his fists in annoyance, watching the Alliance fleet recede in the view of their rear scopes, clearly wanted to turn around and attack again to win conclusively rather than charging through and leaving an enemy alive, they had to keep moving. They leaped to faster than light speeds again, and headed briefly in the direction of Heinessen. After two days of travel in that direction, after which they were sure that the Alliance fleet was not chasing them but knew where they were headed, they altered course and turned back towards Phezzan.

The route now on the map was strangely familiar to Yang. He found himself looking at it in his spare time, tracing his fingers across the spiderweb threads between stars and planets, between the Alliance capital and Phezzan. He had traveled this exact route with his father a huge number of times when he was twelve. There had been a year, he remembered, where his fatherâ€™s ship had been chartered to haul route after route of terraforming equipment to tiny new settlements out in this direction. His father hadnâ€™t enjoyed the work, since he liked running routes between Phezzan and Heinessen, rather than tiny little colony planets. Not because the pay was betterâ€” in fact, hauling to remote destinations could command a real premiumâ€” but because at the end of every leg of a Phezzan-Heinessen trip, Tai-long and Wen-li would head down to the planet together, and wander through some new museum that they young Yang had never been to before. And then theyâ€™d get dinner, sitting in the booth of some diner while his father paged through whatever coffee table book he had picked up from the museum gift shop. One could fill up an entire lifetime with trips like thatâ€” Phezzan and Heinessen were both big enough for it.Â 

He tried not to wonder what his father would think of him now, and tried equally not to wonder what would become of Phezzanâ€™s museums under Alliance occupation.

Â Yang avoided the bridge whenever he could. He also avoided his own room, his difficulty sleeping chasing him across the galaxy, even though he had hoped that leaving Iserlohn would give him a little bit of a reprieve. He was exhausted, but only was able to drift off in unplanned and stolen moments. Usually, this was when he sat in the officerâ€™s lounge, during some odd hour of the night, when everyone else except for Yang and Ansbach had gone to bed.

He had told himself to avoid Ansbach, for Ansbachâ€™s sake, but they nevertheless found each other more often than not. Yang felt bad about this, but even when he was sitting in the lounge alone, Ansbach often made his way there, so it wasnâ€™t exclusively Yangâ€™s selfishness and desire for trusted company. It was strange, after so many years, that they had somehow become friends.

Yang made his way to the overly-warm officersâ€™ lounge after dinner, and found Ansbach there, as he knew that he would. Under his arm, he was carrying a map of Phezzan itself, showing the long, equatorial continent made up primarily of a mountain range so ancient that it had been blunted down by the passage of time. That was where the capital city sat, and its space elevator. There were long stretches of farmland to the north, and the other, much emptier continents where the secondary industrial cities lay. He had the map mainly as an excuse to find Ansbachâ€™s companyâ€” it would give them something to discuss, and he was murmuring to himself as he entered the room. â€œWish I knew how things had gone on Odin,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™d give us a very recent example of urban fightingâ€¦â€

Ansbach, who was looking at their lists of supplies and calculating how long they could last on what they took out of Iserlohnâ€™s stores, looked up at him with an annoyed expression. He had the supply tables up on the big projector display at the side of the room, along with his own calculations off to the side, and he clicked them closed as soon as Yang shut the door behind himself.Â 

â€œWhat do you want?â€ he asked.

Yang spread his hands, dropped his maps on the table, and then left the table to go sit down in the plush armchair by the bookcase. Ansbach stood and picked up the maps as Yang said, â€œIn case you wanted to talk about what weâ€™re going to find on Phezzan,â€ he said.

Ansbach looked at the maps dismissively. â€œIf I were the rebels, I wouldnâ€™t bother with the planet,â€ he said. â€œBlockade them from the sky, control the corridor from both endsâ€” itâ€™s not like Phezzan has a fleet of their own to deal with. Why would you want to turn the citizens even more against you than you have to, by making it a ground invasion?â€

Yang closed his eyes and nestled his head back into the overstuffed leather. â€œBecause they have to,â€ he said. â€œThey can only justify this battle to their own population if theyâ€™re doing it in order to take control of Phezzan itself. Ideology.â€

â€œIdeology could wait until theyâ€™ve actually won.â€

â€œIt never waits. Itâ€™s the driving force of everything they do.â€

â€œYouâ€™re lucky to live in a country where we can be ruled by pragmatism instead, My Lord,â€ Ansbach said, which made Yang laugh.

â€œBesides, they need to get information from Phezzan about how to navigate the corridor. It will slow them down too much if they have to map out the routes themselves. Phezzan controls all the detectors in the corridor that map out the safe routes. Itâ€™s hard to head through there without it.â€

â€œWill we have that problem?â€

â€œThere will be a lot of traffic,â€ Yang said, and waved his hand. â€œPeople bringing supplies in. Weâ€™ll have to ambush a supply convoy at the mouth of the corridor, and get the data out of their computers.â€

Ansbach nodded, then looked up from the maps Yang had dumped on the table. He turned to look at Yang, who was still sitting with his eyes closed.

â€œI see your pet conversation topic is already putting you to sleep,â€ Ansbach said.

â€œDonâ€™t let me interrupt you from your work,â€ Yang said.

â€œIâ€™m certain that My Lord has been given pleasant accommodations on board the ship,â€ Ansbach said with an annoyed tone. â€œBut if My Lordâ€™s bed is not up to his standardsâ€”â€

â€œPlease donâ€™t call me that,â€ Yang said.

Ansbach turned around fully, and leaned half-sat on the table, looking at Yang. His gaze and silence were both heavy enough that they made Yang crack his eyes open and look at him.

â€œAnd what should I call you insteadâ€” Hank?â€

â€œOnly my wife calls me Hank,â€ Yang said, and closed his eyes again. â€œYou donâ€™t have to call me anything.â€

â€œCount von Leigh.â€

Yang sighed and waved his hand in defeat.

â€œCommodore.â€

When Yang was silent, Ansbach gave up.

â€œJust â€˜youâ€™ then.â€

â€œWhy would you need to call someone anything else when youâ€™re speaking to them directly?â€ Yang asked. â€œItâ€™s all you need.â€ He yawned. â€œIt makes things equalâ€” in a way. Just you and meâ€¦ Could be anyone.â€

â€œMost people enjoy having a name for themselves.â€ Yang was silent, and Ansbach picked up his computer from where it sat on the table, and took up a seat on the couch across from Yang in the armchair. â€œBut whatever you like.â€

He still managed to pronounce the word like a sarcastic inversion of the royal we. But it made Yang smile.
